column10: web_notes

Located in the corner of a gently sloping field of the lower south – western slope of Ballincollig hill, the site affords expansive views to the southern half of the compass.  The site is bounded on its southern and south-western sides by a small stream . The site is previously unrecorded and was brought to my attention by the landowner who described it as a small “Liss”. However, the extant remains seem to represent the large central platform of a ring-barrow, 20m in diameter and 0.5m higher than the surrounding land. An encircling ditch, on average 2m wide and 0.3m deep, can be  traced around the northern and south-western sides of the site. Traces of a very denuded outer bank can also be seem to the south-west, where it remains to an internal height of 0.5m, external height of 0.3m and a width of 1.5m. The landowner also pointed out that the surviving ditch remained waterlogged throughout the year and stated that this was due to the presence of a spring, which was visible, in the south-western quadrant.The overall diameter of the site, where all elements are intact, is 26.5m.'   Description from ‘The Prehistoric Settlement of the Lee Valley, Tralee, Co. Kerry; A Landscape Perspective’ by Michael Connolly. PhD Thesis UCC 2008Date of upload: 20 June 2012

Located approximately 50.0m to the east of the above enclosure [KE030-075----], in the same field, this low semi-circular mound has been cut in half by an east/west field boundary. Only the southern half of this site now survives, as no trace remains in the reclaimed field to the north. What now survives measures 26.0m E-W by 12.0m N-S ( this does not represent the true N-S diameter because of the truncation by the field boundary ). The central mound survives to an average height of 0.60m and measures 16m in maximum length E-W. The top of the mound slopes inwards to a central depression, 10.50m E-W by 6.50m N-S.'   Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 4 May 2012
In pasture, on N-facing slope. Circular flat-topped mound (diam. c. 8m; H 0.9m from base of fosse) enclosed by fosse (Wth 4.2m; D 0.45m). External low rise (max. H 0.25m) evident NE-
column13: SE and SSW-
column14: SW. Top of mound (diam. 4m) defined by narrow earthen rim (H 0.3m). According to landowner, top of mound dug into by his great grandfather in an attempt to level it. During digging large stone slab with bones underneath recovered at depth of 3ft (Bowman 1934, 85). Locally known as 'fort', field called 'fort field'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: On summit of hill, overlooking Ballyglass Lough to N. Reconstructed after excavation. Circular mound (diam. 8.5m N-S; H 1.4m), proved upon excavation (Hencken 1935, 75-82) to be enclosed by fosse (D 0.5m), levelled E to ESE, and external earthen bank SSE to NNE, with break (Wth 1m) in NW. Erection of stone fence probably led to site disturbance on E. Contained burials (MA100-071002-).  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 41.  Date of upload: 4 February 2013

Situated atop a low ridge in pasture. Circular, steep-sided mound of earth and stone (diam. at base c. 2 1m; H 2.8m). At the top of the mound is a small irregularly-shaped, almost level area (dims. 5.1m NNE-SSW; 4.2m WNW-ESE). The mound is encircled by a wide, deep fosse (Wth 3.8m) which has a substantial bank of earth and stone (Wth. 6.5m; max. H 1m) at its outer lip. On the OS 1912 edition of the OS 25-inch map are five irregularly-shaped, recumbent boulders with the collective designation 'Standing Stones (Called the Children of the Mermaid)'. A sixth was identified during the site visit. A seventh is recorded in a legend, much of which is based at the site, which was recorded by Wood-Martin (1887-8, 290). There is no evidence that any of the boulders were ever in an upright position.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In level grassland. A well-preserved subcircular barrow (N-S 28.65m, E-W 25.9m) comprising a central mound (H c. 1.5m max.) encircled by an internal fosse and external bank. The bank is overlain by a field wall at E, and disturbed internally at E and S by a pathway. The mound, which is denuded at S, contains a slight central depression. Two other barrows (GA042-216----, GA042-217----) lie to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In pasture, prominently sited on the summit of a roughly E–W ridge, affording panoramic views, with Croagh Patrick silhouetted on the far horizon to SW, Nephin mountain to W, and the Ox mountains defining the skyline at NW–E.  Roughly circular mound (20m N–S; 17m E–W; H 3.5m at N, 2.5m at S) with steeply sloping sides falling from a narrow, flat top (diam. c. 5m). A fosse encloses the base of the mound, discernible at NE–S and NW as a very shallow depression (Wth 3-3.5m). A slight rise at the outer edge of the fosse at NE hints at an external bank. The mound is sod-covered and appears to be largely of earthen construction. However, disturbance at the top of the mound reveals stone filled cavities that may represent an internal stone chamber or cist. At W–N a field fence merges with the base of the mound, respecting its curve. A few meters to S of the barrow there is an E–W field fence/townland boundary, 20m to S of which is a complex of buildings associated with a water reservoir and telecommunications mast. Another bowl barrow (MA062-093002-) is located 40m to E on the same ridge top, and there is a mound (MA062-092) c. 140m down slope to W.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 9 December 2020

In pasture, prominently sited on the summit of a roughly E–W ridge, affording panoramic views, with Croagh Patrick silhouetted on the far horizon to SW, Nephin mountain to W, and the Ox mountains defining the skyline at NW–E.  Roughly circular mound (16.6m E–W; 13.5m N–S; H 2m at W, 2.3m at E) with steeply sloping sides falling from a narrow, flat top (diam. 3.8m). Enclosing the base is a broad, shallow fosse (Wth 4m), with a slightly raised rim (Wth 3.5-4m; int. H 0.2-0.6m) on its outer edge at W–N–E, which appears to be the remnants of an external bank. The fosse is barely discernible on the S arc. An upright stone (L 1.2m; Wth 0.4m; H 0.45m), long axis WNW–ESE, is set in the base of the fosse at W.  The mound is sod-covered; where the sod has been denuded in parts by farm stock, the mound appears to be of earthen construction. It is overlain on its S edge by a field wall/townland boundary that arcs slightly to respect the curve of the mound. To S of the wall, the poorly defined fosse is slightly truncated by a complex of buildings associated with a water reservoir and telecommunications mast. There is another bowl barrow (MA062-093001-) located 40m to W, and a mound (MA062-092----) c. 200m down slope to W on the same ridge.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 9 December 2020

On a ridge in pastureland. This poorly preserved circular ring-barrow (diam. 22m) comprises a central mound (diam. c. 8m; H 1.12-1.18m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. There is a possible entrance gap at WSW. The monument is overgrown with trees.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 16 August 2019

One of four barrows on Athenry golf course (GA083-066----; GA083-067----; GA083-068----; GA083-075----). On E end of a low ridge between the 13th and 14th fairways. Classified as 'bowl-barrow' (Topgr. Files, OPW) but described by Rynne (1991, 28-9) as a 'ring-barrow' (diam. c. 15m) it consists of a circular mound (diam. c. 9.5m), in fair condition, encircled by a fosse and a low external bank. The bank is best preserved from SE to SW and from NW to NNE.    Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 2 March 2015

On the NW side of a gently sloping ridge incorporated into the N boundary of a domestic garden 650m NE of the townland boundary with Dollas. A standing stone (LI030-017----) is located 140m to NE. The site is not depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map but is depicted as a mound (ext. dims. c. 14m N-S; 15m E-W) in a field on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map. The site is visible as rough ground within an enclosed garden to the rear of a house on the OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12 and on the Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. The mound is visible on the Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018. The site is visible as a mound (Wth. 6m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth. 1.5m) with an external bank (Wth. 2m) on the most recent Google earth orthoimage taken 14/02/2020. Archaeological monitoring of groundworks associated with the development of a house 40m S of the site did not reveal any archaeological deposits (Hayes 2004, 311).See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 28 September 2020

In pasture, on top of a low but prominent rise. A circular flat-topped mound (diam. c. 20m at base, c. 4.7m at top; H 4m). According to local information, the E edge of the mound was dug into prior to 1900.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top of a ridge. A circular mound (diam. at base 11m; H 1.8m) with a flat top (diam. 2.5m). A surrounding fosse (Wth 4m; D 0.2m) is evident along the W arc. A triangulation spot height is indicated here on the 1838 OS 6-inch map. A levelled barrow (SL032-220----) is c. 50m to ESE, a mound barrow (SL032-224----) c. 500m to NNE and another (SL032-072----) c. 200m to S, all on the same ridge.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In a slight hollow on an undulating landscape. This is a round-topped, oval, hazel-covered mound (dims of top 10.9m E-W; 10.5m N-S; dims of base 45m N-S; 33m E-W; H 3.6m at E to 4.8m at S) separated by a berm (Wth 4-5m) from a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 6.4-8.8m; Wth of base 2-3m; int. D 1.7-2.4m; ext. D 0.5-1m). There is a slight earthen bank (Wth c. 3m; int. H 0.2-0.4m) planted with whitethorn on the inner edge of the fosse, which survives S-NW and NE-SE (max. ext. dims 71m N-S; 61.3m E-W). The perimeter is quarried at SSW (diam. c. 9m), N-NE and at ENE.  An oval overgrown subcircular mound (RO032-009004-) (dims of base c. 25m ENE-WSW; 19.8m NNW-SSE; H 3m) extends out from the inner bank at ENE, and may be spoil from the quarries, although it has been interpreted as a bailey, and the barrow as a motte (Knox 1911a, 307-310; Graham 1988b, 26). Field system (RO032-009002-) is immediately to the NW, and rath (R032-008001-) is c. 80m to the NE. (Doran 2005, 377)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In low-lying, wet level pasture, with restricted views in all directions. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2000 and described as a circular-shaped flat-topped mound (diam. 9.8m; H 1m) enclosed by a broad, shallow, waterlogged fosse (overall Wth 14.2m; base Wth 11m; D 0.3m). Monument is visible as a circular-shaped tree-planted earthwork on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018. See attached Google Earth orthoimages.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 11 August 2020

On a NNW-facing slope, in pasture with moderate views to N and S, 115m W of a townland boundary with Monaster North. Enclosure (LI031-005----) lies 125m to E. Annotated ‘Sheenafinnoge Fort’ (Sídh na Fionnóige (hill of the raven)  on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map (OSNB Monasteranenagh Parish).  Depicted on 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a small, subcircular-shaped mound. Referred to by Westropp (1920, 372) as Síd Asail and described as a ‘holy mound’ in the vicinity of a pair of conjoined ringforts (LI031-010002-) indicated as the assembly place of the Óenach Cairbre, which lies 1.1km to SE. According to Westropp (1919, 19) an iron sword and mace were excavated from the mound in the 1800s and sent to the National Museum of Ireland.  Cantwell (1955, 48) recorded the following about  'Sheenavanogue. Sidhe na BhFeannog, the fairy mound of the scald crows.  This mound was partially opened upwards of a century ago and a sword and axe, both of iron, were found in it.  It is thought that it was the burial site of soldiers slain in the 1579 battle between Malby and the Earl of Desmond and that it thus marks the scene of the conflict, but while it may have served this purpose it was undoubtedly a mound sacred to the sidhe or fairy-folk'.   Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as a raised circular-shaped mound (4.7m N-S; 4m E-W) the summit of which has a depression enclosed by an earthen bank (Wth 8.6m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 3.15m) with the remains of a fosse (overall Wth 10.5m; basal Wth 2.0m; D 0.15m) best defined from ESE-SE-S-SSW, with a causewayed entrance (Wth 4m) at SSW and an outer bank (Wth 7.1m; int. H 0.45m; ext. H 0.85m) visible from NE-ENE and from ESE-S-SSW.  The summit of the small mound has a hollow-like appearance probably the result of the excavation carried out on the earthwork in the 19th century.  Monument is visible as an oval-shaped tree-planted earthwork on OSi aerial orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and sketch plans, cross-sections and photographs surveyed, drawn and taken by the ASI. Also sketch plan of the assembly place of the Óenach Cairbre and other associated monuments in its vicinity, on the floodplain of the Camoge River (after Westropp 1920, 373).    Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 27 October 2020

In pasture, on the crest of a rise, with Knocknashee Hill visible to the S. A circular mound (diam. 29.5m; H 1.8m) surrounded by a wide fosse (Wth 5m; D 0.3m) SW-NE. Some quarrying has occurred on the S side.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, at the junction of four field fences, prominently located on a top of a hill, the highest point (OD 372’) in the locality, with panoramic views of the surrounding grassland mixed with expanses of bog. Knocknarae, crowned by Maeve’s cairn (SL014-), is visible on the far horizon to N, with Ben Bulben to NW. This bowl barrow is named ‘Doomore Fort’ on the 1838 and 1920 OS 6-inch maps.  It consists of a substantial circular mound (diam. 27.4m; H 5m) with a domed profile. Enclosing the base of the mound is a broad, shallow depression/fosse, defined on its outer edge on the W half by an earthen field fence (Wth 0.8-1m; int. H 1.35m; ext. H 0.55m) and on the E half by a field wall (Wth 0.8m; int. H 1.1m; ext. H 0.3m). The fosse varies in width (Wth 7-8m at E and W, 5.5m at N, 6.5m at S). It appears slightly sunken relative to exterior ground level, suggesting that it is a primary fosse, rather than merely a gap intervening between the mound and field fence. The field fence is similar in form to others in the vicinity; it is relatively narrow relative to the fosse, and does not appear to be an original enclosing bank.  A small eroded section of the mound slope at W reveals that it is composed of earth and stone. It is grass-covered, with gorse bushes growing on S side. The encircling field fence is ringed with hawthorn bushes.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 26 June 2020

In pasture, at the E end of the summit of a ridge which affords a panoramic view. A circular sod-covered flat-topped mound of earth and stone (diam. 18.5m at base, 4.8m at top; H 4.2m). A small section of the top of the S edge of the mound has been dug away. The sides are steep and eroding in places. A field boundary (not shown on the 1838 OS 6-inch map) is immediately to NE. A rath (SL025-034----) lies c. 60m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In reclaimed pasture 90m N of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Garrynderk North.  Castle (LI047-039----) lies 160m to SE.  Not depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map.  It is shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a small circular-shaped mound (diam. c. 12m) defined by a fosse with traces of an external bank from SW-W-NW, reduced to a scarp elsewhere.  Intersected at S by drainage ditch running NW-SE. Outline of tree-covered mound with fosse and traces of an external bank are visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 16/03/2016.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 13 August 2021

In pasture, just off the crest of a drumlin. Described as an oval mound (16.8m N-S; 13m E-W; H 2.4m), domed in profile, with a 'slight bevel' towards the bottom at the E edge; faint traces of a fosse (Wth 1m) were noted along the E arc and where the grass cover had been removed the mound appeared to be composed of clay (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly). A rath (SL038-058----) lies c. 50m to NNW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In a hazel coppice, on the S-facing slope of a ridge. A roughly circular round-topped earthen mound (diam. c. 21.5m at base; H 1.8m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth 5m; D 0.4m). The barrow is heavily poached by cattle.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top of a ridge. A round-topped roughly circular earthen mound (diam. 12.5m at base; H 3.2m), partially eroded by animals and quarrying. Possible stone kerbing was noted along N and NE arcs (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly). A circular enclosure (SL038-114----) lies c. 130m to E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On the summit of a densely wooded rise. During the course of an illegal excavation in 1980 into this small, roughly circular, overgrown earthen mound (diam. c. 6.7m; H < 1.4m) an unprotected crouched adult skeleton (possibly male), aligned E-W, was found. The mound was described as 'bow-barrow type burial mound' (Topgr. files, NMI).   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 November 2019

On the S-facing slope of a drumlin. According to local information, a high steep-sided mound was levelled during recent land reclamation and is no longer visible at ground level (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top of a low rise. A grass-covered dome-shaped mound (diam. c. 8m; H c. 2m) of earth and stone with some hawthorn bushes growing on it.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On flat rough pasture with excellent views. Recorded in 1991 as a large oval earthen mound (dims. 9.7m x 4.2m; H 4m), conical in section, rising in terraces above a platform (SMR file).  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 April 2011

Situated on a broad gently-sloping hill on slight S-facing slope in pasture. Circular flat-topped mound ( diam. top 3m; diam. base 18m) of earth and rubble stone defined by a steep scarped edge (ext. H 4.35m) with an external fosse (Wth 8m; D 0.1m). The fosse is visible as enclosing the central mound SW-N.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

On the N-facing slope of a ridge in grassland. Described by Coffey (1904, 14-20), prior to his excavation in 1903, as a circular ‘tumulus’ that was ‘40 feet in diameter and 9 feet in height [diam. 12.2m; H 2.7m]’.  The excavation revealed that it was constructed of stones and earth with a layer of sandy soil at a depth of c. 0.9m. Beneath this layer, in the centre of the mound, lay the unprotected extended skeleton of an adult female whose head faced W. On one side, and to the S of the skeleton were a number of red deer bones and the skeleton of a horse. At the centre of the mound, on the old ground level, was an unprotected inverted cordoned urn containing cremated human bone, which rested on a flat slab (Waddell 1990, 93). When surveyed by Cody (1989, 152-3) it appeared as a disturbed circular inverted bowl-shaped mound with traces of a possible encircling fosse (Wth 2-3m; max. D 0.5m) on its W side. The E side had been partly removed, possibly as a result of the excavation. It was subsequently levelled and a barn was built on it. Probably a bowl-barrow. (Knox 1916c, 192-3 may also be referring to this mound; Waddell 1975, 16)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 November 2019

In undulating pasture, on top of a ridge. A subcircular earthen mound (7.5m N-S; 4m E-W; H 1.75m) with a central depression (3.7m x 4m) on top. A shallow fosse (Wth 1m; D 0.1m) is evident along the W arc of the mound and two trees grow in its N end.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on a broad gently sloping hill on slight S-facing slope in pasture. Circular flat-topped mound (dims. diam. top 3m; diam. base 18m) of earth and rubble stone defined by a steep scarped edge (ext. H 4.35m) with an external fosse (Wth 8m; D 0.1m). The fosse is visible as enclosing the central mound SW-N.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

Situated on the level summit of low, broad gently sloping E-W orientated ridge. Natural ground level slopes down gently to 15m to the N and S of the site. Circular flat-topped mound (dims. diam. top 12m; diam. base 34m) defined by a steep scarped edge (ext. H 8m) with an external fosse (Wth 8.1m; D 0.25m). A small triangular quarry (L NE-SW 10m; max. Wth NW-SE at NE end 6m; max. D 0.4m) is located on the side of the mound at NE. The fosse is visible as enclosing the central mound NW-NE.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

In pasture, c. 20m W of the Owenmore River. A flat-topped conical mound of earth and stone (diam. 10.5m at base; H 6.3m). A ring-barrow (SL026-124----) lies c. 100m to WSW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top and towards the W end of the level summit of a ridge. An almost conical mound (diam. 14m at base, 1.4m at top; H 2.5m). Two small now disused quarry pits are dug into the base of the mound, one at NW and the other at NE. The sides of the mound have been eroded by livestock NE-SE and as a result some loose rocks have fallen from it. There are now no visible remains of the stone setting (Wth 0.7m; H 0.5m) close to the base of the mound at SE which was noted by M. Keane and J. Farrelly (pers. comm.).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In natural woodland, on the summit of Doon Hill. Views are restricted by trees but Maeve's Cairn (SL014-076----) is clearly visible in the distance on top of Knocknarea to W. A roughly circular largely sod-covered mound (diam. at base: 23.5m E-W; c. 20m N-S; H 3.5m) of earth and stone. The flat top (diam. c. 6m) is uneven and disturbed in appearance and W-NW is broadly slumped. The mound has been quarried into at N and E; bedrock immediately to N has also been quarried out. Overgrowth obscures much of the NE edge of the mound.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on the spine of a N-S ridge which affords panoramic views. Part of a small barrow cemetery consisting of an adjacent ring-barrow (SL033-039003-) immediately to W and another larger bowl-barrow (SL033-039001-) c. 30m to S. This bowl-barrow consists of a conical oval grass-covered mound (diam. 9m at base; H 3.5m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 3.3m; D 0.4m). A resistivity survey indicated the presence of an outer bank (Mount 1995a, 81). Partial excavation in 1995 (Mount 1996, 78-9) revealed that the mound was constructed of clay, silt and sand with occasional cut sods and contained an iron fragment, animal and human bones and charcoal. The mound was revetted by a single course of stone kerbing (ibid.). It was also determined that the mound was built on top of scorched earth, probably resulting from the lighting of a funeral pyre and wood from the base of the fosse was radiocarbon dated to 380-120 cal. BC, giving an Iron Age date (Mount 1998, 21). The excavation also determined that the adjacent ring-barrow (SL033-039003-) was built onto the existing bowl-barrow creating a figure-of-eight monument (ibid.).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In undulating pasture, just off the summit of a N-S ridge which affords panoramic views. Part of a small barrow cemetery consisting of another bowl-barrow (SL033-039002-) with an adjacent ring-barrow (SL033-039003-) c. 30m to N. This bowl-barrow consists of a prominent conical grass-covered mound (diam. 24.5m x 23.5m; H 6.1m). A resistivity survey identified an extensive fosse enclosing the site (Mount 1995a, 81). Subsequent excavation in 1994 and 1995 (Mount 1996, 78-9) confirmed the presence of the fosse (Wth 6.7m; D 2.1m) and also revealed an external bank (Wth 2.4m) and a large displaced limestone boulder, probably a kerbstone. Preserved seeds from the lower fill of the fosse were radiocarbon dated to 3930-3520 cal. BC, placing the construction of the barrow in the earlier part of the Neolithic period (Mount 1998, 18).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In gently undulating pasture, on a slight W-facing slope. A large roughly circular dome-shaped mound (36m N-S; 40m E-W) defined by a fosse and an external earthen bank. The fosse (Wth 4.1m at base; Wth 8.95m at top) is evident all round and is densely overgrown and inaccessible E-W. The bank (int. H 0.85m to base of fosse; ext. H 1.1m) is evident all round, is incorporated into the field boundary system SE-SW and is densely overgrown and inaccessible E-W. The apex of the domed mound is slightly off-centre to S and is 4.1m higher than the top of the fosse. A disused quarry is situated outside the bank at NNE. This barrow appears to be formed around a natural hillock that has been modified to create a large earthwork. A ring-barrow (SL033-048----) lies c. 60m to SW and another (SL033-199----) c. 150m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In gently undulating pasture, on a slight E-facing slope. A conical grass-covered mound (diam. 9m; H 2m). A slight lip is visible around the base of the mound NNE-S, consisting of a level terrace (Wth 1.2m; ext. H 0.25m). At S the mound has been dug into revealing a compact sod layer and a shattered stone and clay core (pers. comm. J. Farrelly and M. Keane). Known locally as 'Corran'. A ring-barrow (SL033-051----) lies c. 50m to ENE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on level summit of broad E-W orientated ridge in pasture. Circular mound (base diam. 11m; H 1.9m) of earth and stone enclosed by a berm (Wth 2.3m) with an outer stone kerb (ext. H 0.6m). A NE-SW orientated drystone field wall traverses the site slightly to NW of centre. The summit of the central mound has been truncated on either side of the field wall to form a level D-shaped level area (dims. 4.5m NE-SW; 2.8m NW-SE). The straight side of the D-shaped area is defined NE-SE by an inward facing scarped edge (H 0.6m) and the curved portion of the D-shaped area is defined by original slope of the side of the mound NE-SE. The berm encloses the central mound NE-SW is absent elsewhere. The external edge of the berm is defined by an earthen scarped edge that is best preserved NNE-SW where a discontinuous kerb of small limestone slabs and boulders survives.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

Timoney (1984, 323, no. 11) describes this as follows: 'The diameter of the this circular bowl-barrow, sited on flat ground, is 6m and it is 1.25m in height. The small flat top is included to the south. There no evidence for a bank or fosse.' (Bergh 1995, 185, Carrowmore 11A with references)  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 27 January 2014

In pasture, on a W-facing slope below the crest of a flat-topped ridge; immediately W of a road and overlooking the Owenmore River to W. An oval flat-topped earthen mound (diam. 22m; H 3m) with sloping sides. The mound has been eroded by cattle giving it a terraced appearance. It is overgrown mainly with small trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

This barrow was excavated in 1977 by M.A. Timoney who published the following account (1987-8, 7): ‘A small tumulus, 11m in diameter and I.40m high, surrounded by a round-bottomed fosse and a slight bank, was sited on an east-west ridge on the opposite side of the road to the Cloverhill cist [SL014-211----]. Gravel excavation had removed the ridge to the east of the mound, leaving it at the top of a 15m high, gravel cliff. Some disturbance had taken place on the east side of the monument. Its pre-excavation appearance suggested that the monument had been formed by scarping the side of the high point of the gravel ridge and by levelling off its top: excavation, however, revealed that the monument was, in the main, artificially constructed. Beneath the sod, a layer of earth overlay an uneven mantle of largish stones. Beneath this was another layer of earth and an earlier mantle of largish stones, beneath which was the undisturbed glacial gravel. The two mantles of stones merged towards the edge of the mound where a well-constructed retaining wall, four to six courses high, remained at some places (elsewhere it had collapsed into the fosse). It seems possible to selectively, assign several stones to an arc formation. At the centre of the mound, in the earth cover between the two mantles of stones, two partly disarticulated burials were found, laid on a NE—SW axis in a poorly, it at all, prepared grave. One skull, that of a male of 20-30 years, was found beneath the pelvis of the lowermost skeleton while the other, that of a female of 30-40 years, was found about 30cm away from the nearest piece of bone. None of the bones of the spinal column, rib-cage, hands or feet was found. There were no accompanying grave goods nor any artifacts by which the monument can be dated.’ Macalister (Breuil and Macalister 1921-4, 5, footnote 1) records that a boulder carved with 'concentric ciclres' was on a mound to the south of the road to the south the field where the cist (SL014-211----) is located. It is possible that this may be the mound to which they refer and it may the stone that was incorporated in the outbuilding of the old school house to the south-west and subsequently removed to Sligo County musuem (see SL014-284010-) (pers. comm. M.A. Timoney). (Timoney 1984, 324, no. 15)  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 23 January 2014

Situated on a slight E-facing slope in a small clearing within a mature deciduous forest. The mound has been constructed in two tiers. The top tier consists of a circular flat-topped mound (diam. top 4m; diam. base 16m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (ext. H 0.7m). The second tier, at the base of the central mound, consists of a level terrace (Wth 2.5m) enclosed by a steep scarped edge (ext. H 2.2m; Total base diam of mound 20m). At the base of the second tier is a fosse (Wth 2.95m) and an external bank (Wth 3.8m; int. H 0.45m; ext. H 0.8m). The mound has slumped down and the fosse and external bank are absent W-NNW.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

In pasture, immediately E of townland boundary with Sunville Upper.  Holy Well (LI056-009001-) lies 270m to the E. Depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map as a sub-circular raised area defined by a scarp, intersected at SE by a post-1700 field boundary running NE-SW. Shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a circular mound with fosse and external bank. No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-2013 or on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimage Compiled by: Fiona Rooney Date of upload: 23 November 2021

Situated in gently undulating deciduous forest and now inaccessible. Recorded by a fieldworker in 1991 as a circular raised area (diam. 16m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 4m) and an external bank of earth (Wth 5m; int. H 1m). The external bank is absent NW-NE and incorporated into modern field boundaries at E and W. The interior is domed and rises to a maximum height of 2m above the fosse at S. (SMR file). The monument is now densely overgrown with scrub rendering satisfactory inspection impossible.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 22 April 2013

In the SW quadrant of a hilltop enclosure (SL033-149001-). A roughly circular grass-covered mound (diam. 6m at top; diam. 14m at base; H c. 2m). The NE portion of the mound has been disturbed by quarrying. (Condit, Gibbons and Timoney 1991, 62)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On low lying wet pasture, on the floodplain of the Camoge River 170m to W, which forms a townland boundary with Ragamus. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 225: AP 5/2015) as a roughly circular-shaped platform defined by a fosse. Monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped platform (21m N-S; 20m E-W) defined by a fosse, as seen on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on on Google Earth orthoimage taken 04/04/2013.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 225  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 19 November 2020  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP – 348/11 and 12  taken on 05/01/2003.

In pasture, on the top of a drumlin, with a view of Kesh Corann Hill in the distance to ESE. A circular mound (11.45m N-S; 10.75m E-W; H 1.75m), flat on top (diam. 3m) and enclosed at its base by a wide waterlogged fosse (Wth 4.1m; D 0.4m). There is a berm (Wth 1.25m) at the base of the mound S-N. The remains of a field boundary skirt the fosse along the N arc. The barrow is partially overgrown with gorse. Farrelly and Keane (2002, 100) noted similarities between this barrow and the stepped barrow (SL038-120001-) at Kilturra.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on the top of a drumlin. A large steep-sided conical mound (diam. 21.5m; H 6m) denuded at E, exposing earth and stone. A slight depression (Wth 4m) visible at E may be the remains of a fosse. Lewis (1837, vol. 2, 189) mentioned under the parish of Kilmorgan 'several mounds of earth covering stone graves, in which bones and urns containing ashes have been found, whence it is inferred that a battle was anciently fought here' (SL033-211----). It is not known to which site or sites Lewis was referring but this bowl-barrow and the cairn (SL033-108----), also in Doomore townland, are both in the parish of Kilmorgan.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In rough pasture, in centre of an archaeological complex (LI048-034006/042-) located on the 'Supposed Site of Temaír Erann', which was the ancient cemetery of the Ernai tribe on Slievereagh (Sliabh Riabhach) (Westropp 1919, 9; Westropp 1917-19, 179; Westropp 1918, 111). One of three possible bowl-barrows (LI048-034010/012-), within a large field system (LI048-034001-).  Ringfort (LI048-034008-) lies 50m to NE and a cist (LI048-034015-) lies 10m to SW.  Listed as 'Tumulus III' and was one of three bowl-barrows excavated by Ó Ríordáin (1940, 133-137) between 1934-5. Earthwork described as a ‘bowl-barrow’ by Ó Ríordáin which he recorded as follows; ‘There was no essential difference in structure between this mound and T[umulus] II [LI048-034012-] beyond the fact that it was slightly larger, its overall diameter being 54 feet [16.45m]. This mound had also been dug into in 1924 and when we cleared off the heavy growth of furze which covered this, though not the other tumuli, we found it possible to distinguish the mark of the earlier digging. This operation consisted of the cutting of a trench about 8 feet [2.4m] wide through the centre of the mound, though, as our sections revealed, the trench did not go down to the old ground surface under the tumulus and the digging had not been rewarded by any "finds." The soil had been replaced by the earlier investigators but certain irregularities in the surface of the mound marked the extent of their cutting, and the material thrown up formed a slight shoulder round the tumulus on about three-quarters of its circumference.  The sections showed the height of the tumulus above original ground level to be six feet [1.8m]. They showed plainly the cutting made in 1924, but showed also a second small disturbance which, also, did not reach original ground level. This second cutting may have been due to an earlier disturbance or may have been caused by further digging in 1924 of which we were not informed.   On the original ground level we found, over an irregular area of about 18 feet [5.5m] by 16 feet [4.87m], cremated bones and a thin layer of charcoal, evidently the site of the cremation pyre, and the remains of the burial. We have, therefore, in T[umulus] III a second example of the type of burial exemplified also in T [umulus] II, in which a tumulus was raised over the cremated remains on the site where the cremation had taken place' (ibid. 139). Monument visible as a raised circular platform or mound with traces of an external fosse on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth othoimages.See attached plans  from Ó Ríordáin and Google Earth orthoimages.Compiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 27 August 2021

In rough pasture, in centre of an archaeological complex (LI048-034006/042-) located on the 'Supposed Site of Temaír Erann', which was the ancient cemetery of the Ernai tribe on Slievereagh (Sliabh Riabhach) (Westropp 1919, 9; Westropp 1917-19, 179; Westropp 1918, 111). One of three burial mounds (LI048-034010/012-), within a large field system (LI048-034001-), ringfort (LI048-034008-) lies 20m to NE.  The most northerly of three bowl-barrows (LI048-034010/012-), within a large field system (LI048-034001-), ringfort (LI048-034008-) lies 20m to NE. Described by Westropp (1916-17, 465) as one of three tumuli consisting of; ‘a levelled mound (c), only a few feet high, 12 feet [3.6m] across, with a rock of conglomerate about 4 feet [1.2m] long on its base.’   Listed as Tumulus I by Ó Ríordáin (1940, 133-137) the burial mound was partially excavated in 1924 by T. Shea and the remains of an urn with cremated bone (LI048-034038-) uncovered and reinterred.  Excavations of the mound (H. 0.9m; diam. 11m) undertaken by Ó Ríordáin between 1934-5, revealed a cist (LI048-034039-) and the barrow was described as following; ‘This mound was low and insignificant in comparison with T [umulus] II [LI048-034012-] and T [umulus] III [LI048-034011-]. Its maximum height over ground-level was less than 3 feet [0.9m], and its greatest diameter about 36 feet [11m]. No signs of a surrounding fosse showed on the surface but there were some upright stones at the edge of the tumulus, others of which were revealed on excavation making a total of six found in position, which represented the remains of the kerb of the tumulus’ (ibid. 133).   Excavations revealed, ‘that the greater portion of it was covered by a paving of small stones packed rather closely together. This paving was at varying depths of 18 inches [0.45m] or less under the surface.  On and among the stones of this paving we found scattered fragments of small deposits of cremated bones’ (ibid. 135).   A possible fosse was also recorded inside the edge of the mound and ‘it did not make a complete circle, there being a gap of about one-fifth of its circumference on the northern side’ (ibid. 136). See attached plans and photos from Ó Ríordáin and Google Earth orthoimages.Compiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 27 August 2021

In rough pasture, in centre of an archaeological complex (LI048-034006/042-) located on the 'Supposed Site of Temaír Erann', which was the ancient cemetery of the Ernai tribe on Slievereagh (Sliabh Riabhach) (Westropp 1919, 9; Westropp 1917-19, 179; Westropp 1918, 111). One of three bowl-barrows (LI048-034010/012-), within a large field system (LI048-034001-), ringfort (LI048-034008-) lies 30m to NE and a cist (LI048-034015-) lies 38m to SW.  Listed as Tumulus II with cremated burial (LI048-034040-), excavated by Ó Ríordáin (1940, 137-8) between 1934-5. Monument described as one of three ‘bowl-barrows’ by Ó Ríordáin consisting of mound measuring ‘about 6 feet [1.8m], and each having a fosse which, though largely silted up, was still evident on the ground before excavation. The overall average diameter of the mound was 45 feet [13.7m]’ (ibid. 137).  Excavations revealed that 'on the old ground surface an area irregularly circular in outline and about 12 feet [4m] in diameter was found to be covered with a light charcoal deposit in which were scattered fragments of cremated bone [LI048-034040-). It was evident that this area was the site of a fire, on which, no doubt, the cremation had been carried out and over which the tumulus had been built'. Earthwork visible as a circular shaped mound defined by a shallow fosse on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages.See attached plan from Ó Ríordáin and Google Earth orthoimages.Compiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 30 August 2021

Marked only on the 1929 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on the crest of a low NW-SE ridge. Circular, flat-topped and grass-covered mound (diam. of base 13m NW-SE; diam. of top 7m NE-SW; 6.8 NW-SE; H 1.4-1.6m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth of base 1.8m; D 0.2m) E-S which is visible as a band of rushes (Wth 2-3m) S-N, but the fosse and the base of the mound are truncated by a WNW-ESE road bank at NE (max. ext. diam. 20.5m NW-SE). Rath (RO021-044----) is c. 170m to the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In the S interior of ceremonial enclosure (RO027-012001-). Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 21.5m NNE-SSW; 20.5m WNW-ESE; H 2m at ESE to 2.5-3.3m generally) with a slight bank (Wth c. 2-3m; int. H 0.3-0.7m) around the flat top (diam. 10.4m) which has a gap (Wth 1.7m) at ESE. There are traces of a fosse (Wth of base 2.2-2.8m; D 0.2-0.6m) around the base (max. ext. diam. c. 35m N-S).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Earthwork described in 1942-3 as following; 'This consists of a flat topped mound around which is an inner fosse. Leading across this fosse at the E.S.E. side is a narrow causeway. Outside this fosse is a very narrow, low bank, and the causeway across the inner fosse leads on to this. Outside the inner bank there is the middle fosse, which is shallow. Leading across this on the south side is another causeway which connects with the middle bank, which also is low and narrow. Outside this is the  outer fosse, and this is crossed by four causeways, all on the west and south sides. These four lead on to the inner slope of the outer bank, which is broad and fairly high. This bank is broken in three places, all of which seem to be accidental. The causeways across the fosses are not opposite one another. The whole monument has been cut through by a fence with a drain on each side. This runs east-west a little north of the centre of the mound. The monument on the north side of this fence has been badly defaced. The low banks are not visible as they have been covered by a large spoil heap accumulated from the cleaning of the drain. Nothing has been found in the making or cleaning of the drains where they run through the monument. The height of the mound over the fosse-bottom is 8' [2.4m] and the overall diameter 300' [100m]. Situated in marshy low-land' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 238).  Outline of S half of extant monument bisected by field drain clearly visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 6 March 2020

On a slight N-S ridge at the summit of Mewlaghadooey Hill. Circular, grass-covered flat-topped earthen mound (diam. of base 27m N-S; 25.5m E-W; diam. of top 9.8m N-S; 8.8m E-W; H 3.1m at E to 4m at W) with a slight pit (diam. 5.5m; D 0.2m) on the summit. It is within the hillfort (RO027-014001-), SW of the centre. Given its prominent position and its size, it might contain a passage tomb.  See the attached ground (003) and aerial (008) views both taken from the NE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on flat, poorly drained land in an upland area with church site (TN031-070001) to NE. A poorly preserved round-topped mound (diam. 23m N-S; H 1.2m) enclosed by a wide, flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 7.5m; ext. D 0.4m) which was waterlogged at time of visit.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In poorly drained pastureland. This poorly preserved roughly circular grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 19.7m; H above fosse 2.25-3.15m), which is slightly stepped and rounded in profile, is encircled by a shallow fosse. A small circular stone foundation (diam. 1.5m) is evident on top of the mound and a solitary hawthorn tree is growing at NW.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

In pasture, 10m S of road that forms townland boundary with Knocklong East. Annotated ‘Clogherbeg Moat’ on the 1840 ed. of the OSi 6-inch map, on which it is depicted as a small raised circular raised area intersected at W by a post-1700 field boundary running N-S. Shown on the 1897 ed OSi 25-inch as a small circular-shaped flat-topped mound (diam. c. 6m) standing in the centre of a narrow small field.  Earthwork described by Westropp (1919, 10-11) as 'a little green tumulus, called Clogherbeg Mote'.  The burial mound was described by Westropp (1916-19, 172) as  ‘a perfect little green tumulus in parts 11 ft. [3.3m] high; the base about 100ft. [30m] across, quite featureless; the ground falls abruptly to a T-shaped valley, where two streamlets meet’. An emergency excavation (Licence No. 96E0032) carried out in 1996 by Victor Buckley, recorded ‘that the site had been a large barrow, approx. 18m in diameter and 5m high. It had been levelled to the surrounding ground level. A large, 1.5m-square igneous erratic was still in place in the centre of where the mound had stood, suggesting that this stone may have had some ritual significance. No trace of an enclosing fosse was noted, but an area (3m sq.) of pyre debris, 0.2m deep, on the old ground surface was excavated. Some human remains, both cremated and uncremated, were retrieved. Analysis by Laureen Buckley revealed that the uncremated remains consisted of two adults, sex indeterminate; one adult and one juvenile were identified from the cremated remains. Several fragments of prehistoric pottery were also recovered.’   No surface remains visible of levelled barrow on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 13 July 2021

In gently undulating wet pasture at base of a slight SSE-facing slope and immediately to the N of the Bog River which forms county boundary with Tipperary. On the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map the earthwork is depicted standing in the SE corner of a field immediately N of the river the course of which may have since been altered.  On this map the monument is depicted standing in County Limerick with no remains of the earthwork standing in County Tipperary Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2005 and described as a raised roughly semi-circular shaped area (dims. c. 8m NNW-ESE; c. 12m ENE-WSW) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 2.2m; ext. H 1.3m) with an external fosse (overall Wth 3m; base Wth 1.4m; D 0.3m). At ENE and at WSW the scarped edge is partially eroded where a modern double drainage ditch and field boundary, that lies along the N bank of the Bog River, links to the edge of the barrow. The scarped edge is absent from E-WSW where the straight edge of the monument is defined by the NE-SW orientated Bog River. The river course may have altered since the monument was constructed and the monument may have extended further south.  The fosse is absent from ENE-W where the drainage ditch abuts the edge of the barrow at ENE and at WSW and also to the S of the Bog River. The interior undulates slightly, is dry and overgrown with trees and bushes but is accessible.  Outline of scrub-covered earthwork is visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  Same site as TS065-042----  See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 5 August 2021

In pasture, straddling the slightly convex summit of a drumlin ridge with the ground level falling away gently to E and W. Views are excellent in all directions. A circular flat-topped mound (diam. c. 28m at base, 5.6m at top; H 6.25m) surrounded by a broad shallow fosse (Wth 8m at base; D 0.15m) NNW-SSE; the line of the fosse is marked elsewhere by a band of dark grass. The summit of the mound slopes slightly down to NW and is clear of overgrowth while the sides are mostly overgrown with gorse and are inaccessible. Field boundaries abut the base of the mound at SSE and NNW. A rath (SL034-123----) lies c. 40m to W.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On the level summit of Knockaunnamoughilly, in level pasture, c. 125m to S of the Clare River, with excellent views in all directions. Depicted on the 1840 OS 6-inch map as a circular-shaped enclosure standing in the centre of a large circular-shaped field (approx. diam. 115m). Monument surveyed by the ASI in 1999 and described as a circular-shaped flat-topped mound (diam. 9m; H 0.4m) defined by a fosse (base Wth 2.4m; overall Wth 7m; D 0.15m) from E-SE-S. Visible as a tree-covered monument within the centre of a circular-shaped large enclosure (100m E-W; 90m N-S) on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  Possible barrow standing in centre of large ritual hilltop enclosure (LI007-005001-) known as 'Knockaunnamoughilly'.   See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 3 July 2020

In a locally prominent position, on top of a broad gently sloping rise, in gently undulating pasture. Originally circular, the bowl-barrow now consists of a roughly D-shaped raised area (dims. 16m N-S; 10m E-W) enclosed by a gently sloping earthen scarp (Wth 7m; ext. H 1.4m) with an broad flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 2.1m) and a very low broad external earthen bank (int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.1m; Wth at top 2m; overall Wth. 5m). From NNE-SE, the fosse and the external bank are absent and the scarp defining the interior is eroded back to form the straight side of the present D-shape. A roughly circular shallow pond (diam. c. 10m; max. D 0.5m) is located on the line of the fosse at NNE. The interior is level across the W two-thirds while the E one-third slopes gently facing E where the original scarp has been eroded back. A standing stone (TS057-015002-) is located on the top of the outer bank at SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture on a very slight N-facing slope. A possible moated site (TS057-058----) is located 60m to the SE. Circular flat-topped mound (dims. diam. top 5m; diam. base 7m; H 1m) of earth. The interior is very slightly dished at the centre but this is as a result of modern erosion by livestock.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In rough grazing, close to a break of slope at the E end of a ridge. One of a group of four barrows (see SL047-048001-; SL047-048003-; SL047-048004-). A circular round-topped steep-sided mound (9.7m N-S; 9m E-W; H 1.4m) enclosed by two fosses with intervening and external banks. Stones protrude in places from the sod-covered mound. The inner fosse (Wth 2m) is evident as a shallow depression marked by rushes and irises. The intervening bank (Wth 2.5m; int. H 0.35m; ext. H 0.3m) is evident as a broad low rise, difficult to discern NE-E. The external fosse (Wth 2.5m) is evident only as a slight depression marked by irises. The external bank (Wth 2.3m; int. H 0.35m; ext. H 0.25m) is evident S-SW and NW-NNW, but is barely perceptible elsewhere. The external bank and fosse are overlain ENE-ESE by the external bank of the conjoined ring-barrow (SL047-048001-) and the external bank is truncated at W by a field boundary.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated atop Sentry Hill with commanding views of the surrounding countryside.  Impressive well-preserved monument (overall diam. 19m N-S; 17.6m E-W) consisting of a circular-shaped round topped earthen mound (top diam. 8.5m N-S; 8m E-W; H 1-1.7m; base diam. 13.5m N-S; 13.4m E-W) enclosed by a well preserved waterlogged fosse (base Wth 1-2m; top Wth 2.5-3.5m; ext. D 0.3-0.5m) with traces of a poorly preserved external earthen bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.2m).   It is curious that the mound is not depicted as an antiquity on any edition of the Ordnance Survey six-inch map.  A trig. station marking the spot height 217ft OD is depicted on the OS 6-inch map where the mound is located.   Compiled by: Caimin O’Brien  Date of upload: 29 September 2015

In marshy ground, in a narrow valley flanked by two long narrow ridges. A roughly circular mound (diam. at base 13.8m NNE-SSW; 11.6m WNW-ESE; diam. at top: c. 3m; H 2.3m) with a small circular hollow (diam. 1.5m; D 0.2m) in the centre of its top. The SW portion is highest and steepest to compensate for the slight ground slope. A narrow terrace (Wth 0.8m; H 0.7m) is cut into the base of the mound S-SW. A barrow (SL047-083006-) lies c. 450m to NNE and two raths (SL047-078----; SL047-080----) are c. 50m to SSW and c. 70m to SE, respectively.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In poor pasture, on a high ridge summit with panoramic views. A circular platform (diam. c. 25m; H 3.4m) with a flat top (8m E-W; 7.5m N-S) is enclosed at its base by a fosse (Wth 3.5m) and an external earthen bank (Wth 5m; int. H 0.45m; ext. H 0.6m). The top of the platform slopes down gently to E. There is a linear field boundary on top of the bank on the W arc.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on flat pasture in an upland area with a stone pair (TN019-041----) c. 42m to the SE and rock outcrop decorated with cup-marks (TN019-053----) 20m to the S.  A well-preserved steep-sided flat-topped mound (H 3.5-4m; top diam. 11.5m N-S; base diam. 19m N-S) enclosed by wide flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 5m; ext. D 1m) with small orthostats protruding from the base of the fosse at E and S - probably natural rock outcrop. The base of the mound has been scarped and a water pump inserted into the fosse at E.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 12 March 2014

On the crest of an E-W drumlin ridge. Circular grass-covered but poached mound (diam. 24m; H 4-4.2m) with a flat summit (diam. 5m) separated by a berm (Wth 2.7-4m) from a fosse (Wth of top 3.3-3.6m; int. D 0.5-0.9m; ext. D 0.1-0.3m). There are slight traces of a bank (Wth 2m; int. H 0.1m) inside the fosse at E, and the fosse is surrounded by a hawthorn hedge (max. ext. diam. 37m N-S).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the summit of a NW-SE ridge. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 14.4m N-S; 12.3m E-W; diam. of top 6.2m N-S; 5.2m E-W; H 1.4-1.7m) with a slight hollow at the summit, defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of base 6-8.8m; D 0.1m) which is separated by a berm (Wth c. 3m) from an outer bank (Wth 3-3.5m; int. H 0.3-0.7m; ext. H 0.9-1.4m) with some bushes (max. ext. diam. 34.8m N-S; 32.7m E-W). There is no identifiable original entrance.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In gently undulating wet pasture. Raised circular area (diam. 10m) enclosed by a gently sloping earthen scarp (Wth 4-5m; ext. H 0.8-1.2m) and a broad external fosse (Wth at base 3m; overall Wth 4.5m; D 0.2m). The fosse is not visible at ground level NW-SW and a WNW-ESE orientated modern field drain lies along the line of the fosse NW-NE. The interior slopes slightly facing E and is clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On the crest of a NW-SE ridge, towards its NW end. Subcircular flat-topped and grass-covered mound (dims of base 19.7m ENE-WSW; 18.4m NNW-SSE; dims of top 14m ENE-WSW; 14.7m NNW-SSE; H 0.6m at E to 1.2m at W) separated by a rounded fosse (Wth of base 2-2.5m) or berm (Wth 3m) from an outer overgrown bank (Wth 5-8m; int. H 0.2-0.4m; ext. H 1.2-1.6m). This is surrounded by a field bank and hedge (max. ext. dims 38.8m NNW-SSE; 38m ENE-WSW). It is within ceremonial enclosure (RO027-047002-). (Herity 1984, 138)  See the attached aerial image taken from the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on top of a steep-sided hillock in a mountainous region with extensive views. A flat-topped circular mound (diam. 11.5m N-S; 16.5m E-W; H 2m) with possible traces of an enclosing fosse visible at E and W only. The base of the mound is intersected by an E-W field fence at S.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 2/2007).

On the summit of a drumlin. Subcircular, steep-sided, grass-covered and flat-topped earthen mound (dims of base 24.5m N-S; 22m E-W; diam. of top 2.5m; H 4m at N to 5.7m at S). A band of wet ground (Wth 4.5m) at the base indicates a fosse (max. ext. diam. c. 35m). Embanked enclosure (RO006-118001-) is c. 380m to the NE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On top of the S summit of a NE-SW ridge. Circular grass-covered and flat-topped earthen mound (diam. of base 33m N-S; 30m E-W; diam. of top 11m; H 5.2-5.3m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 7m at E to 9.8m at S; D 0.05m at S to 1m at E), with a small mound (diam. c. 3.5-3.75m; H 0.3m) on the summit (max. ext. diam. 45m). The embanked enclosure (RO006-118001-) is immediately outside the perimeter at W, and the fosse of the barrow may have straightened the bank of the enclosure here. Knox (1914b, 348-9) describes traces of an outer bank, and it may be an inauguration mound, although there are no historical references (FitzPatrick 2004, 82-4).  See the attached aerial image taken from the N with the barrow on the left.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the W-facing slope of a drumlin. Circular grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 10.2-10.5m; H 2m at N to 3.9m at W) with a slightly dished summit (diam. 2.6m). There is a berm (Wth 5.7m) around the base at E (max ext. diam. c. 25m) and, according to John O'Donovan in 1837, it was known as 'Dumha na Mias' (O'Flanagan 1931, vol. 1, 95-6). Barrow (RO006-071----) is c. 30m to the WSW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a slight rise of the broad WNW-ESE ridge of Carnfree. It has been identified as part of Dumha Selga, which has mythological associations (FitzPatrick 2004, 64-5). Flat-topped grass-covered mound (diam. of top 16m N-S; 15.2m E-W; diam. of base 30.5m E-W; 25.4m N-S; H 1.6-1.8m), with a slight bank on the summit (Wth c. 3m; H 0.2-0.9m) SW-N, perhaps spoil from a levelling of an originally rounded top or an ancient adaptation. The mound is surrounded by a fosse (Wth of top 13.2-15.1m; Wth of base 4-5m; D 0.5-0.8m) and outer flat-topped bank (Wth of base 9.2-10.7m; Wth of top 4.1-4.9m). This bank has an earthen field bank on its outer edge (Wth c. 2m; int. H 0.2-0.3m; ext. H 1.2-1.7m), perhaps spoil from the cutting of an external flat-bottomed fosse or drain (Wth of top 5-6.7m; Wth of base 1.5-2.5m; D 0.2-0.8m). There are no original entrances identified (max. ext. diam. 66m E-W), but the bank was removed NW-NE in the construction of rath (RO028-063002-) which is to the N (max. ext. diam. 65m E-W). Mound barrow (RO028-063004-) is c. 50m outside to the ESE and mound barrow (RO028-063005-) is c. 60m outside to the NE. Geophysical survey showed remarkably little variation with all techniques, suggesting that it is very uniform in composition. (Waddell et al. 2009, 124-135)  See the attached aerial image taken from SSE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a slight rise of the broad WNW-ESE ridge of Carnfree. It has been re-identified as Carn Lamha (FitzPatrick 2004, 65). Circular, conical and grass-covered mound (diam. of base 16m.3m N-S; H 3.5m) surrounded by a slight berm (Wth 1-1.2m) and fosse (Wth of top 5.5-9m; D 0.3m) (max. ext. diam. 35m N-S). There are also slight traces of an outer bank S-W, but this may be a field bank. The barrow is contained within a triangular area defined by field banks of the field system (RO028-056----). Ditch-barrows (RO028-071----; RO028-072001-; RO028-073----) are c. 60m to the W, c. 60m to the SSW and c. 90m SE respectively. (Herity 1983, 126-7; Waddell 1988, 15-6)  Geophysical survey recorded high anomalous values on the mound that might be associated with burning episodes at its summit. However, anomalies towards the base could indicate the presence of terracing, or a revetment or cladding hidden within it. (Waddell et al. 2009, 114-117)  See the attached image taken from the N  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the crest of the S-facing slope of a broad E-W ridge. Circular grass-covered and flat-topped earthen mound (diam. of base 9.3m N-S; diam. of top 2.3m; H 1.3m) with a slight flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of base 3.8-5.4m; D 0.05-0.1m), but there is no evidence of an outer bank (ext. diam. 21.6m N-S). Ceremonial enclosure (RO028-148002-) is c. 150m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture, near the top of a SE-facing slope. A circular steep-sided mound (diam. 15.6m) 2.1m high above the base of the fosse along the N arc and 1.85m high above it along the S arc, giving a stepped appearance. The base of the mound is enclosed all round by a fosse (Wth 5.2m) and along the S and W arcs by an external bank (Wth 3.9m; int. H 0.75m to base of fosse; ext. H 0.25m). The bank is incorporated into a field boundary along the N arc. The mound is overgrown with brambles.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On top of a hillock which was called Knockmelliagh (D'Alton 1845, 78-9). Circular grass-covered earthen mound (diam. of base 32m; H 5.5-6m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 3.3m at S to 9.5m at E; D 0.15-0.3m) NE-S-NW, which cannot be traced NW-NE (max. ext. diam. c. 47m). It has a flat summit (diam. 6.2-6.5m).  See the attached aerial (001) and ground views (002), both taken from the S.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 24 August 2010

Located at the summit of a low NE-SW ridge. Circular, grass-covered earthen mound with a flat summit (diam. of base 18.5m E-W; diam. of top 2.5m E-W; H 3.9-4.2m) defined by traces of a fosse (Wth of base 5-6.5m; D 0.05-0.1m) at E, and possibly at W (max. ext. diam. c. 30m E-W). The trivallate rath (RO006-153001-) is c. 100m to the WSW, and earthwork site (RO006-156----) is c. 90m to the S. Archaeological testing (02E0167) c. 140m to the NW failed to produce any related material (Read 2004k).  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 488  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated in a relatively low-lying position with ground rising gradually to the NW and S. A poorly preserved mound of gravel and clay which has been greatly altered by quarrying. It survives to a height of c. 2m and has a maximum diameter of c. 26m. The centre of the site has been completely quarried out, with an entrance cut through the mound to N and one to S. All that remains is the outer edge at the E and W, however, this could be augmented by spoil material which has been pushed outwards.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In flat, marshy terrain, land falling gradually to the SW, with hills visible to the N. A low, flat-topped, circular mound (H 0.87m; diam. 24m) enclosed by a waterlogged fosse. The fosse is visible as a wet area (Wth 5m; D 0.15m) at the base of the mound. An embanked enclosure (TS050-024----) and enclosure (TS050-025----) are located 180m and 120m to the NW respectively.   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 August 2012

In a broad, low-lying basin. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 15m NW-SE; diam. of top 5.7m NW-SE; H 4.1-4.3m) with some bushes, which has a berm (Wth 2.4m) at its base at SE. The mound is separated by a wet, rush-covered fosse (Wth of base 7m at SE to 11.6m at NW; ext. D 1.4-1.9m) from an earthen bank (Wth 10-11.4m; ext. H 1.45-2m). A field drain and outer field bank surround the perimeter SSW-NNE, and a field bank overlies the perimeter E-S (max. ext. diam. 59.5m NW-SE).  See the attached aerial image taken from the NNW  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Some 30m to the SE of a ring-barrow (GA100-103----). This well-preserved circular barrow (diam. 23m) comprises a flat-topped mound (diam. 5.3m; max. H 1.3m) encircled by a fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.2m). The side of the mound has been partially damaged and eroded by cattle and as a result a ledge-like feature runs around it giving it the appearance of a mound with a smaller mound on top (SMR file). A narrow drain runs off the fosse at NNE. Another possible barrow (GA100-103002-) lies c. 50m to the SW. (de Valera and Ó Nualláin, 1972, 29)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

Located in a prominent position at the N end of a N-S esker ridge. A roughly circular mound (diam. 26.5m N-S; 25.3m E-W) which utilises the N end of the esker and on the W side is enclosed by a fosse (Wth 4m) and stony outer bank (Wth 4.3m; int. H 0.74m; ext. H 3.73m) while there is a steep natural drop on the E side where the mound is c. 11m high.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Located in a low-lying position, in pasture. A roughly circular, steep-sided, earthen mound (c. 19m E-W; H 3.1m), with some stone protruding, particularly on top at S where a very low, rough stone wall is evident. There has been some slight quarrying S of this feature. The site suffers to some degree from cattle erosion and the base of the mound in the NE quadrant has been slightly truncated. Dumping has taken place along the base at S and in the NE quadrant. Some small trees and nettles are growing on this grass-covered mound, but it is otherwise relatively free of vegetation.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on top of a slight rise of ground in undulating countryside. A large steep-sided flat-topped mound (H 4m; top diam. 3.5m; base diam. 12.3m) of earth and stone with no evidence of an external fosse.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated in a nineteenth-century grove of trees alongside the driveway into Congor House. A steep-sided conical mound (H 3.4m; base diam. 11.6m NE-SW) of earth and stone with no evidence of an enclosing fosse. A possible burial mound which may have been reused as a landscape feature.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Located on a slight S-facing slope, with the edge of a bog c.100m to the S. A circular, steep-sided earthen mound (diam. c. 19m; H c. 2.65m). Field banks which abutted the base of the site at E and W have been levelled, however, the remains of these banks are still visible, forming a berm-like feature. There is a slight fosse in the NE quadrant (Wth c. 2.4m; D 0.2m). Uprooted scrub has been dumped on the mound itself and some large trees on the sides appear to have fallen in situ.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

At the summit of a broad NNW-ESE ridge. Circular grass-covered and domed mound (diam. 21.8m NW-SE; 21.5m NE-SW; H 1.55-2.5m) defined by a fosse (Wth of base 1-2.2m; D 0.55-0.7m), with an outer bank (at NW: Wth 11.8m; ext. H 0.8m) WSW-N-ENE on the downslope side (ext. diam. c. 40m NW-SE). There is a small drystone-built structure on the summit of the mound. Barrow (RO045-039----) is c. 45m to the SSE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Called a castle and the chapel of Mullaghnashee by O'Donovan in 1837 (O'Flanagan 1931, vol. 1, 50), the name has become attached and it is known locally as 'the Steeple', although there is no evidence of either structure. Known as Sídh Neannta it was one of the landmarks on the bounds of Uí Maine (O'Donovan 1843, 5). It is associated with the O'Hanley family, and it may have been an inauguration site for them. Situated at the summit of Fairymount Hill. D-shaped, grass-covered earthen mound with a gently domed summit (dims of top 13m E-W; 9m N-S; dims of base 28.2m E-W; 21.6m N-S; H 2.6-3m). A N-S field bank and drain clip the E edge of the mound and an E-W field bank with a drain on its N side truncates the mound towards the perimeter at S. Given its prominent location and its size, it might contain a passage tomb.  Some cut stone, including two fragments of an inscription (RO036-013003-), probably from a graveslab or a cross, mention Eilis and Peter Hanley. Barrow (RO036-014----) is c. 110m to the SE..  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Visible on aerial photographs (GSIAP: M 469-8), and situated on the crest of a small N-S esker ridge. Circular overgrown earthen mound (diam. of base 14.9m N-S; 14.8m E-W; H 1.8m) which is slightly truncated NE-SE, with a silted fosse (at SW: Wth of top 4m; max. D 0.6m) SSW-W-NNE (max. ext. diam. 23m). Archaeological testing (04E0458) immediately to the NE in Gortnasythe produced no related archaeological material (Rooney 2007b).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on the crest of a low hill, in pasture. A roughly circular mound (base diam. 12.5m N-S; top diam. 7m; H 1.55m) enclosed by a U-shaped fosse (Wth 2.6m; D 0.5m). Whitethorns are growing on the summit and around the edge of the site. There may have been quarrying into the summit at some stage (though not in memory of present landowner) with upcast around the edge of the summit to the SE and SW. A large boulder lies prostate at the outer edge of the fosse at N.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on top of a natural rise of ground with extensive views; river and hall-house (TN008-010001) to S. A well-preserved, large, conical-shaped, slightly round-topped mound of earth and stone construction (top diam. 6m; base diam. 16m; H 2-3m) with enclosing fosse (Wth 2.8m; ext. D 1.3m) and external bank (Wth 3m; ext. H 0.7m). Recent field-clearance debris dumped into fosse and along bank at NE.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on a low rise, on a NW-facing slope, in low-lying wet pasture, overlooking a stream c. 45m to NW. A castle site (WM029-034----) lies c. 40m to E. Depicted on the revised 1910 ed. OS 25-inch map as a small oval-shaped earthwork (approx. dims. 10m NE-SW; 8m NW-SE). Monument described in 1973 as a small, roughly circular-shaped mound of earth and stone the base of which is enclosed by traces of a fosse which is best preserved from SE-S-SW.
