In reclaimed grassland, possible barrow (LI048-122----) 90m to NW.  Outline of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 8m) defined by a ditch visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-13.   Could be the remains of a small ditch-barrow.   Compiled by: Caimin O’BrienDate of upload: 24 September 2020

On a gentle WSW-facing slope, in improved pasture, 72m E of a townland boundary with Portboy which also marks a main watercourse that flows into the Ballynamona River 740m to SE. The northern most of five contiguous barrows (LI032-289/290/291/292/293) arranged roughly NW-SE along the top of a long ridge and varying from 7-24m distance apart. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 291.01: AP 4/3609) as a small circular-shaped cropmark. Monument is not clearly visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, or on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 or on Google Earth orthoimage 20/09/20.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 291.01.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 27 November 2020

On a gentle WSW-facing slope, in improved pasture, 72m E of a townland boundary with Portboy which also marks a main watercourse that flows into the Ballynamona River 740m to SE. The second northern most of five contiguous barrows (LI032-289/290/291/292/293----) arranged roughly NW-SE along the top of a long ridge and varying from 7-24m distance apart. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 291.02: AP 4/3609) as a small circular-shaped cropmark. Monument is visible as a faint circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 8.5m) on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and is not visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 or on Google Earth orthoimage 20/09/20.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 291.02.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 27 November 2020

On a gentle WSW-facing slope, in improved pasture, 72m E of a townland boundary with Portboy which also marks a main watercourse that flows into the Ballynamona River 740m to SE. The central and best preserved of five contiguous barrows (LI032-289/290/291/292/293----) arranged roughly NW-SE along the top of a long ridge and varying from 7-24m distance apart. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 291.03: AP 4/3609) as a small circular-shaped cropmark. Monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 10m) on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and as a very faint circular-shaped cropmark on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013, although is not readily seen on Google Earth orthoimage 20/09/20.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 291.03.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 27 November 2020

In reclaimed pasture 90m N of a watercourse.  Earthwork (LI040-029----) lies 90m to W.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 68; AP 5/2076) as a possible barrow.  Visible as a circular-shaped area (diam. c. 7m) defined by a fosse on OSi orthophotos 2005-2012.  Outline of possible ditch-barrow visible on Google Earth orthoimages, where it lies immediately N of a drainage ditch running NE-SW.   See attached Bruff image with earthwork labelled 68 and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 28 June 2021

In wet pasture, on a low ridge 200m W of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Knocklong West.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 114.02; AP 5/2123) as a possible barrow. One of 28 barrows which make up the Elton barrow cemetery (LI040-229002/029-) recorded within a single field (Doody 1999, 97-8). Listed by the Discovery Programme as a potential barrow (Site No. 02) on examination of Bruff aerial photographic survey. Sixteen barrows clearly visible on a Topographic Survey of this field undertaken by the Discovery Programme (The Discovery Programme, “Topographic survey of Elton, County Limerick.,” accessed June 3 2021, http://discoveryprogrammeimages.locloudhosting.net/items/show/2868).  Twenty-two barrows were identified on a Magnetometry Survey of the same field carried out by the Discovery Programme (The Discovery Programme, “Magnetometry survey of Elton, County Limerick.,” accessed June 3, 2021, http://discoveryprogrammeimages.locloudhosting.net/items/show/2869). Faint cropmark of possible barrow visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13.   No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 14/09/2019.  See attached aerial photograph (Site No. 02), Google Earth orthoimages, topographic survey and Digital Terrain Model of Elton barrow cemetery by the Discovery Programme.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 25 June 2021

In improved, wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 42m SW of a main watercourse, which also marks a townland boundary with Ballincurra.  The northern-most of a group of three contiguous ditch-barrows running roughly N-S.  A cluster of three further ditch-barrows lie 35m to SW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 238: AP 5/2018) as a subcircular-shaped earthwork. Upstanding monument is clearly visible as a circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 13m) which appears to be defined by a fosse, as seen on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 238  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 24 November 2020

In rough wet pasture, 155m E of a watercourse which also marks a townland boundary with Ballynamona. Enclosure (LI032-271001-) and earthwork (LI032-271003-) lie 120m to WSW and 55m to S. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 235: AP 5/2018) as a circular-shaped earthwork. Upstanding monument is visible as a circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 12m) defined by a fosse, as best seen on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, although is not clearly visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 or on Google Earth orthoimage 20/09/2020.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 235Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 22 November 2020

In reclaimed pasture, 155m W of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Knocklong. Faint trace of circular cropmark visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 14/09/2019.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 8 July 2021

In reclaimed wet pasture, 70m of townland boundary with Doonmoon, a  possible barrow (LI040-145002-) lies 10m to the S. Not marked on OSi historic maps. In reclaimed wet pasture, 70m of townland boundary with Doonmoon, a possible barrow (LI040-145001-) lies 10m to the N. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Possible site identified during examination of aerial photographs (BGE 1/10,000, 72) taken 03/11/1984 on Bórd Gáis Éireann gas pipeline. In low-lying wet pasture, on a slight SSE-facing slope and c. 100m W of a stream. A roughly circular raised area (12m N-S; 11.4m E-W) defined by a scarp (H 0.9m) which is topped by a field boundary ESE-SSW. Possible traces of an external fosse are evident NE-E. The interior is gently undulating, poached by cattle and partially covered with overgrowth.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In improved, wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, to the immediate E of a townland boundary with Ballynamona.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 239: AP 5/2018) as a semicircular-shaped earthwork to the immediate E of a field boundary.  Upstanding monument is clearly visible as a pennanular-shaped earthwork (diam. 26m) which appears to be defined by a faint fosse and which is traversed by a field boundary running N-S to the immediate W, as seen on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 239  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 24 November 2020

On low lying wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 470m SW of a townland boundary with Milltown. Enclosure (LI032-284----) lies 10m to SW and enclosure (LI032-243----) lies 162m to NE. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 160.01: AP 4/3633) as a semi-circular-shaped cropmark which is cut by a field boundary and land drain running NW-SE across the SW edge. Monument visible as a suboval-shaped earthwork (35m NW-SE; 29m NE-SW) defined by a broad fosse (Wth 7m) and truncated by a field boundary running NW-SE across the SW edge, as seen on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, Digital Globe orthoimage 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage 25/03/2017. In reclaimed pasture immediately N of a field drain running NE-SW.  Bowl barrow (LI040-036----) lies 65m to SW.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified from McCloud aerial image (27).  Described by Sarah Cross and Eoin Grogan in 1994 (License No. 94E0172) as a ‘previously unrecorded ring-ditch was also noted 20m to the north. It measures 7m north-south and 6m east-west. The mound is 3.6m in diameter and c. 0.3m high’. Faint trace of cropmark visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.   See attached McCloud aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 2 July 2021

In rough wet pasture, 15m SW of the River Mahore that forms townland boundary with Oldtown. One of four barrows (LI040-037001-/003-). Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified by Tarbett (1987, 53) as ‘Site 4’ and described as; ‘The remains of this barrow can only be traced by the differential growth patterning in the encircling ring-ditch, no enclosing bank can be seen.  The diameter measures 7.70m N-S and 9m E-W.’ No surface remains visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-2012. Possible monument visible as circular cropmark or pond feature on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached location map and drawing from C. Tarbett and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 12 May 2021

Towards the bottom of a SE-facing slope. Flat-topped grass-covered mound with some bushes (diam. of base 11m E-W; 10.6m N-S; diam. of top 9m N-S; 8.4m E-W; H 0.7m at S to 1.2m at W) defined by a rounded fosse (Wth of top 3-3.8m; Wth of base 1.2-1.5m; D 0.3m at S to 0.7m at W). Barrow (RO027-050----) is c. 250m to the NE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In reclaimed pasture, 180m N of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Glenlary. Barrow (LI049-231----) lies 35m to E and barrow (LI049-232----) 80m to SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Possible barrow listed as ‘Mitchelstowndown West 54’ by Grogan (1989, 241). Excavated by Aoife Daly and Eoin Grogan of Discovery Programme in 1992 the results of which were summarised as follows; ‘The cemetery of Mitchelstowndown West near Knocklong contains 53 small barrows. Excavation of 4 of these [LI049-230/233----] took place over an 8-week period in July and August, 1992. The site is defined by a U-sectioned ditch. At the south-east the ditch extends outwards to define a crescentic area or shelf. On the exterior edge of the main ditch deep tool marks, the result of using a mattock or similar implement, were found. The inner edge of the ditch is a neat, almost vertical face. Tiny bone fragments were found in the ditch silt but are too fragmentary to be identified (Barra Ó Donnabháin, pers. comm.). The mound was built of material from the ditch. It survived to a maximum height of 0.1 8m. A second curvilinear ditch was located within the central area of the barrow. This is semi-circular in plan. It cut through the mound of Barrow 54 and thus post-dates it. In modern times the mound was flattened and the ditch had been deliberately filled. Finds include a fragment of chert debitage, a humanly modified chert pebble, a slightly burnt flint flake, a chert scraper and a fragment of a whetstone. The disturbance dates to the recent past as it contained modern delph and iron fragments.DiscussionThe Mitchelstowndown West sites form a clear element of the barrow complex and the associated funerary tradition in the Morningstar Valley and probably date to the Middle to Late Bronze Age. Because there is no conclusive evidence that the barrows had a funerary function it is postulated that burial deposits had become so token that the barrows’ function had become a symbolic monument associated with burial rituals and perhaps with remembrance of the dead’ (Daly and Grogan 1993, 43-4). No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 11 October 2021

In pasture 50m E of the townland boundary with Dromkeen. The ringfort (LI024-002----) known as ‘Gortavalley Fort’ lies 110m to NNE. The enclosure is not depicted on historic OSi maps. It is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 as a circular enclosure surrounded by a fosse (ext. diam. c. 12m). It is not visible on the Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 49; AP 4/3717) as a U-shaped enclosure. The site is not visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018. See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 49 and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by:  Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 17 September 2020

Marked as a circular embanked feature (ext. diam. c. 20m) on the 1837 and 1927 eds of the OS 6-inch map, and situated towards the bottom of the SW-facing slope of a broad NW-SE ridge. Described as a circular mound surrounded by a rounded fosse (Gannon 1972), it is not now visible at ground level in pasture. Barrow (RO027-049----) is c. 250m to the SW and barrow (RO027-051----) is c. 370m to the SE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In reclaimed pasture, 135m N of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Glenlary. Barrow (LI049-232----) lies 40m to SE and barrow (LI049-230----) 35m to W. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Possible barrow listed as ‘Mitchelstowndown West 55’ by Grogan (1989, 241). Excavated by Aoife Daly and Eoin Grogan of Discovery Programme in 1992 the results of which were summarised as follows; ‘The cemetery of Mitchelstowndown West near Knocklong contains 53 small barrows. Excavation of 4 of these [LI049-230/233----] took place over an 8-week period in July and August, 1992. Barrow 55. The ditch is U-shaped in profile having straight vertical sides and a flat base. After an apparently short period of silting, material collapsed into the ditch, sealing a layer of grassy fibres. A residue of the mound survived.Finds include a fragment of shert debitage, a chert flake with retouch and a fragment of flint debitage. The destruction of the barrow probably coincides with the destruction of Barrow 54 [LI049-230----].DiscussionThe Mitchelstowndown West sites form a clear element of the barrow complex and the associated funerary tradition in the Morningstar Valley and probably date to the Middle to Late Bronze Age. Because there is no conclusive evidence that the barrows had a funerary function it is postulated that burial deposits had become so token that the barrows’ function had become a symbolic monument associated with burial rituals and perhaps with remembrance of the dead’ (Daly and Grogan 1993, 44). No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 11 October 2021

In reclaimed pasture, 135m N of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Glenlary. Barrow (LI049-231----) lies 40m to NW and barrow (LI049-230----) 75m to NW. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Possible barrow listed as ‘Mitchelstowndown West 56’ by Grogan (1989, 241). Recorded as Site No. 61 when excavated by Aoife Daly and Eoin Grogan of Discovery Programme in 1992 the results of which were summarised as follows; ‘The cemetery of Mitchelstowndown West near Knocklong contains 53 small barrows. Excavation of 4 of these [LI049-230/233----] took place over an 8-week period in July and August, 1992. The ditch is U-shaped in profile having straight vertical sides and a flat base. After a period of silt accumulation, material had collapsed into the ditch sealing a layer of grassy fibres as in the ditch of Barrow 55 [LI049-231----]. The ditch was subsequently re-cut to a narrow V-shaped trench on the eastern side. At the southern side of the barrow, which lacked evidence for re-cutting, the interior edge had uneven tool-marks similar to those on Barrow 54 [LI049-230----]. There was no surviving mound. The ditch contained a retouched flint flake. This site was probably flattened at the same time as Barrows 54 and 55.DiscussionThe Mitchelstowndown West sites form a clear element of the barrow complex and the associated funerary tradition in the Morningstar Valley and probably date to the Middle to Late Bronze Age. Because there is no conclusive evidence that the barrows had a funerary function it is postulated that burial deposits had become so token that the barrows’ function had become a symbolic monument associated with burial rituals and perhaps with remembrance of the dead’ (Daly and Grogan 1993, 44).  Faint trace of circular cropmark visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 11 October 2021

A NE-SW field bank truncates the fosse at SE, and a NW-SE field bank truncates the fosse at SW. Barrow (RO027-050----) is c. 370m to the NW. In reclaimed pasture, immediately N of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Glenlary. Barrow (LI049-008----) lies 100m to E. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Possible barrow listed as ‘Mitchelstowndown West 58’ by Grogan (1989, 241). Recorded as Site No. 62 when excavated by Aoife Daly and Eoin Grogan of Discovery Programme in 1992, the results of which were summarised as follows; ‘The cemetery of Mitchelstowndown West near Knocklong contains 53 small barrows. Excavation of 4 of these [LI049-230/233----] took place over an 8-week period in July and August, 1992. Barrow 62 has a gently curved ditch profile. In the ditch a sterile silty deposit accumulated. It contained some tiny fragments of bone but this is too fragmentary to be identified as to species (Barra Ó Donnabháin, pets. comm.). The upper fill consisted of more solid material, probably derived from the mound of which there was no surviving evidence,DiscussionThe Mitchelstowndown West sites form a clear element of the barrow complex and the associated funerary tradition in the Morningstar Valley and probably date to the Middle to Late Bronze Age. Because there is no conclusive evidence that the barrows had a funerary function it is postulated that burial deposits had become so token that the barrows’ function had become a symbolic monument associated with burial rituals and perhaps with remembrance of the dead’ (Daly and Grogan 1993, 44). No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimage. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 11 October 2021

Ring-barrows (TS065-009001-; TS065-009002-; TS065-009003-; TS065-009004) are located c. 80m to the ESE, c. 85m to the SE; 26m to the ENE and c. 50m to the NE respectively Identified during field inspection. Circular area (diam. 5m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.8m; overall Wth 2m; D 0.1m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 12 May 2014

In wet pasture, 190m S of the River Mahore and 20m east of possible enclosure (LI033-142----). Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  Monument visible as small circular-shaped area defined by a fosse on aerial photograph (ASIAP (364) 8,(369) 7) taken 10/05/2003.  Trace of circular-shaped cropmark visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached aerial photograph (ASIAP (364) 8, (369) 7) and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 16 April 2021

In gently undulating wet pasture, on the E edge of a small barrow cemetery, with a ring-barrows (TS065-007001-; TS065-007002- and TS065-007003-) c. 100m to the W, c. 110m to the WNW and c. 45m to the NNW respectively and ditch barrows (TS065-007005-; TS065-007006- and TS065-007007-) c. 20m to the W, c. 50m to the SW and c. 70m to the WNW respectively. Identified during field inspection. Circular area (diam. 4m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.4m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4m; overall Wth 0.6m; D 0.1m). The scarped edge and fosse enclose the monument on all sides with the fosse being best preserved N-S being barely discernable S-N. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In wet pasture adjacent to a group of sites. A ditch-barrow (LI024-066----) lies 30m to NE, ring-barrow (LI024-065----) located 50m to W, enclosure (LI024-291----) located 7m to NE. The barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps nor is it visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 27; AP 4/3666) as a circular enclosure (ext. diam. c. 20m). It is not visible on ASI aerial photographic survey 23/08/2000 (ASIAP (132) 33). The ditch-barrow is not visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018, however, the curving NW ditch of the barrow is visible on the Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017. The W, S and E side have been incorporated into modern field boundaries.See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 27, ASI survey image showing the enclosure view NE, and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 14 September 2020

In pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 12m) defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 18 November 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. The size of the enclosure and the high concentration of barrows in the surrounding area would suggest that this is a barrow. It overlays, or is conjoined with, another ditch barrow (TS065-080----) which is visible (dims. c. 5m) projecting eastward from the E side of the enclosure. A ringfort (TS065-070----) is located c. 130m to the E.See attached:TS065-079----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 10 January 2022
Cropmark of possible ditch-barrow (diam. c. 8m) visible on Google Earth photograph taken 25/03/2017.
column13: See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 10 January 2022

column10: In pasture. A circular enclosure defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 18 November 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. The size of the enclosure and the high concentration of barrows in the surrounding area would suggest that this is a barrow. Only the E portion of the enclosure is visible (dims. c. 5m) projecting eastward from another ditch barrow (TS065-079----) which is either conjoined with it or overlies it. A ringfort (TS065-070----) is located c. 130m to the E.See attached:TS065-079----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 10 January 2022
Cropmark of possible ditch-barrow (diam. c. 8m) visible on Google Earth photograph taken 25/03/2017.
column13: See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 10 January 2022

column10: On SSE-facing slope, in wet pasture. Ring-barrow (LI024-065----) lies 110m to WSW. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OS 25-inch map as a raised circular-shaped area defined by a scarp. Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a circular-shaped area (diam. 16m) defined by a scarp (Wth 2.2m; H 0.5m) with fosse (Wth 4.5m; D 0.4m) visible from SSW-W-N-E-ESE. The interior is bisected by a linear scarp (Wth 3.75m; H 0.5m) running WNW-ESE. A rectangular-shaped stone (L 0.7m; Wth 0.3m; H 0.35m) is visible in the NE-quadrant.  A drainage channel and field boundary lie 6m to SE and 11m to NE, respectively.  Monument visible as a circular-shaped earthwork on ASI aerial photographs (ASIAP 132, 36) taken 23/08/2000 and 05/01/2003.  Outline of monument clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.See attached sketch plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI. See attached Google Earth orthoimages and ASIAP images taken 2003Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 18 July 2020

In wet pasture adjacent to and forming part of a group of barrows. It is conjoined with a ditch-barrow (LI024-066----) to the SW. Enclosure (LI024-291----) located 50m to WSW. The ditch-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps nor is it visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 218; AP 4/3666) as a circular enclosure (ext. diam. c. 28.5m N-S; 27.5m E-W). It is visible on ASI aerial photographic survey 05/01/2003 (ASIAP (353) 20). The enclosure is visible on the Google Earth orthoimages taken 25/03/2017, it is not clear on the Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 218, ASI survey image showing the enclosure view SW, and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 15 September 2020

In pasture, immediately W of a stream with Knockaunatarriff 210m to SW.  Earthwork (LI041-013016-) and ditch-barrow (LI041-013015-) lie 45m to the SE and 40m to the NE respectively. Not marked on historic OSi maps. Possible ring-barrow listed by Grogan (1989, 246). Monument is visible as a circular cropmark (diam. c, 3m) on Digital Globe orthophoto taken between 2011-13 and Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 4 August 2021See attached ASI aerial photographs ASIAP – 318/15 taken on 05/10/2002.

In pasture with stream immediately to E, Knockaunatarriff lies 250m to SW.  Earthwork (LI041-013016-) and ditch-barrow (LI041-013015-) lie 48m to the SE and 40m to the SW respectively. Not marked on historic OSi maps. Identified by Stenberger (1966, 39) as a possible barrow (Site V) consisting of one of ‘two barely distinguishable ring-shaped structures (LI041-013016-), one on each side of the stream which here runs from south to north’, described as a possible grave (No. V) which measured approx. 13m in diameter. Monument is visible as a circular cropmark (diam. c. 6m) defined by a ditch on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.See attached plan showing possible barrow marked Site V taken from Stenberger (1966) and Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 4 August 2021See attached ASI aerial photographs ASIAP – 318/15 taken on 05/10/2002.
Cropmark of possible ditch-barrow (diam. c. 8m) visible on Google Earth photograph taken 25/03/2017.
column13: See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 10 January 2022

column10: In reclaimed pasture, 75m S of townland boundary with Raheennamadra, barrows (LI049-241001/002- and LI049-021----) lie 50m and 11m to the NW respectively. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified as potential site immediately E of a linear cropmark running N-S on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2578, Site 255) taken 03/11/1984. Faint trace of circular-shaped cropmark visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.   See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 12 September 2021

In gently undulating low-lying wet pasture with a ring-barrow (TS065-024002-) located 18m to the S and others nearby. Identified on aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2430/29). Circular area (diam. 4m) enclosed by a scarped edge (Wth 0.8m; H 0.1m) with a shallow external fosse (Wth at base 0.4m; overall Wth 1m; D 0.1m). The scarped edge and fosse are absent NW-NNE where the edge of the barrow has been eroded by livestock. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 14 May 2014

Situated on level summit of a low elongated E-W orientated hillock, in pasture, 20m to the WSW of a ringbarrow (SL015-047001-). Circular area (diam. 6m) defined by an earthen scarp (ext. H 0.15). At the external foot of the scarp is a fosse (Wth 1.5m). From NW-NE and SSE-SSW the fosse is infilled and barely visible.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

In pasture 160m N of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Mitchelstowndown. A group of 3 barrows (LI049-029002/04-) lies 105m to SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as ‘Mitchelstowndown East 8’ by Grogan (1989, 239). Visible as a circular cropmark (diam. c. 6m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-2013. No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 13/08/2021. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 12 October 2021

In wet pasture, one of group of three barrows (LI049-029002/003-). Possible ditch-barrow (LI049-029003-) immediately to E. Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps. Potential barrow identified as a circular cropmark on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2579, Site 245) taken 03/11/1984. Faint trace of circular cropmark (diam. c. 4.5m) visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/03/2018.   See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 14 September 2021

In wet pasture, one of a group of three barrows (LI049-029002/004-). Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps. Potential barrow identified as a circular cropmark on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2579, Site 247) taken 03/11/1984. Faint trace of circular cropmark (diam. c. 4.75m) visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12.  Cropmark clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/03/2018.   See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 14 September 2021

In wet pasture, one of a group of three barrows (LI049-029002/004-). Possible ditch-barrow (LI049-0290032) immediately to W.  Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps. Potential barrow identified as a circular cropmark on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2579, Site 246) taken 03/11/1984. Faint trace of circular cropmark (diam. c. 4.5m) visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12.  Clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/03/2018.   See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 14 September 2021

On level ground in gently undulating pasture. Circular area (diam. 4m) enclosed by a very shallow fosse (av. overall Wth 1m; D 0.1m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth. The ditch barrow is poorly defined as the area is heavily trampled by livestock.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In wet pasture, in the NE quadrant of a group of monuments (LI049-027001/009-), earthwork (LI049-027007-) lies 15m to the W. Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps. Potential earthwork identified as a rectangular cropmark on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2779, Site 241) taken 03/11/1984. Possible faint trace visible of ditch-barrow on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12.  No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 13 September 2021

On slight SE-facing slope, in poorly drained pasture with stream 95m to SE.  Ring-barrow (LI024-224----) lies 170m to ENE. Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a poorly preserved monument consisting of a circular-shaped area (20m N-S; 18m E-W) defined by a scarp (Wth 3.4m; H 0.65m) with possible traces of a shallow external fosse visible from NW-N-NE. The interior has a gentle S-facing slope. According to local information this area is known as ‘the moat field’.   Outline of earthwork visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018 and 18/11/2018.See attached sketch plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI. See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 18 July 2020

In low-lying level rough pasture. Visible as a circular enclosure (diam. c. 8m) on an aerial photograph (OS 2429/30/31). A ditch barrow (TS065-029----) is located c. 100m to the SE and two ring-barrows (TS065-028001- and TS065-028002-) are located c. 200m and c. 160m to the SW respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 16 September 2014

In gently undulating wet pasture with two possible barrows (TS065-028001- and TS065-028002)  located 200-250m to the W and another (TS065-074----) c. 100m to the NW. Identified on an aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2430/1). Faint traces of a circular area (diam. c. 5m) defined by a shallow fosse (overall Wth c. 1m; D 0.05m) are visible at ground level. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 14 May 2014

On wet partially reclaimed pasture.  Two ring-barrows (LI024-041/243----) 30m to NNW, ringfort (LI024-040----) with hut site (LI024-299----) 42m to NNE.  Ringfort (LI024-341----) immediately to S, ditch-barrow (LI024-342----) 15m to ENE.  Outline of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 7m) defined by a ditch visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-12.  Outline of monument clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.    See attached Google Earth orthophoto courtesy of Edmond O'DonovanCompiled by: Caimin O’Brien based on details provided by Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 17 September 2020

On wet partially reclaimed pasture.  Two ring-barrows (LI024-041/243----) 30m to NNW, ringfort (LI024-040----) with hut site (LI024-299----) 24m to N.  Ringfort (LI024-341----) immediately to S, ditch-barrow (LI024-343----) 15m to WSW.  Outline of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 7m) defined by a ditch visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-12.  Outline of monument clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.    See attached Google Earth orthophoto courtesy of Edmond O'DonovanCompiled by: Caimin O’Brien based on details provided by Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 17 September 2020

On reclaimed pasture with Glenatrahaun Stream 100m to E. A cluster of three ring-ditches (LI024-225----) lie 35m to NW,  a ditch-barrow (LI024-070----) lies 50m to E and a ring-ditch (LI024-224----) lies 75m to SW.   Outline of monument visible as a circular-shaped area defined by a fosse on OSi orthophotos, Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin O’Brien  Date of upload: 18 July 2020

In pasture, 105m E of townland boundary with Mitchelstown East, Barrows (LI049-227/228----) lie 60m to the W and S respectively Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps. Possible ditch-barrow identified as a circular shaped cropmark on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2580, Site 231) taken 03/11/1984. Monument visible as a circular cropmark (diam. c. 5m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 20011-13 and clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage date 18/11/2018.   See attached BGE aerial photographsand Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 15 September 2021

In pasture, in the S quadrant of a group of monuments (LI049-033001/005-), barrow (LI049-033005-) lies 19m to the E and a cremation pit (LI049-036----) lies 60m to the S. Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps. Potential ditch-barrow identified as a circular cropmark immediately E of a relic watercourse running N-S on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2580, Site 235) taken 03/11/1984. No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 20011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 15 September 2021

In pasture, in the S quadrant of a group of monuments (LI049-033001/005-), barrow (LI049-033004-) lies 19m to the W and a cremation pit (LI049-036----) lies 60m to the S. Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps. Potential ditch-barrow identified as a circular cropmark on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2580, Site 234) taken 03/11/1984. Trace of circular cropmark (diam. c. 5m) visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 20011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimage date 18/11/2018.   See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 15 September 2021

On gentle SSE-facing slope, in reclaimed pasture with Glenatrahaun Stream 10m to E. A cluster of three ring-ditches (LI024-225----) lie 80m to NW and a ring-ditch (LI024-224----) lies 120m to SW. Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a circular-shaped area (24m E-W; 23m N-S) defined by a scarp (Wth 1.5m; H 0.3m) with traces of a shallow outer fosse (Wth 5.3m; D 0.15m), a slight gap (Wth 5m) in the scarp is visible at NNW and a second gap (Wth 6m) at WNW.  Linear drainage channels are visible in the field to the N, S and W of the site.  Monument is visible as a circular-shaped earthwork on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.See attached sketch plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI. See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 18 July 2020

In reclaimed pasture 10m S of a watercourse.  Possible barrow (LI049-216----) lies 135m to E and barrow (LI049-215----) 135m to NE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible cairn listed as ‘Ballyfroota 5’ by Grogan (1989, 215).  Visible as a raised circular-shaped area (diam. c. 13m) defined by a fosse on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 17 October 2021

In pasture, a cremation pit (LI049-036----) and earthwork (LI049-035----) lie 90m to the NW and 105m to the W respectively. Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps.  Ditch-barrow (site TR/2/18/2) identified alongside parallel and concentric ditches, hearth, pits and possible kiln(LI049-037001-) on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline (Gowen 1988, 84-94).  Excavated by Claire Walsh the results of which were summarised as following; 'Features revealed on this site stretched right across the stripped portion of the corridor. Excavation was carried out after grading had taken place, but it was clear during excavation that the features were truncated, prior to grading.   The ring-barrow ditch had external dimensions of 4.45-4.80m in diameter with an internal diameter of 3.20-3.64m. No finds were recovered from the fill, nor were there any surviving features or archaeological deposits in the interior. The field bank and drain which crossed the site also cut across its north-western half’ (Walsh 1987, 27-8).  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 15 September 2021

On high ground on E slope of prominent hill in Knockroe townland. Enclosure (LI033-152----) lies 275m to S and earthwork (LI024-069----) 300m to N. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Monument visible as an oval-shaped depression on aerial photograph (ASIAP (353) 1) taken 05/01/2003.  Visible as a faint cropmark immediately N of a linear field ditch running NE-SW on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12.   Visible as a circular depression immediately S of linear field ditch running NE-SW on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.See attached aerial photograph (ASIAP (353) 1, 2, 3, 4) and Google Earth orthoimages.Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload: 20 April 2021

In improved, wet, pasture immediately W of a watercourse.  Cairn (LI049-213----) lies 135m to SW and possible barrow (LI049-215----) 115m to NW. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as ‘Ballyfroota 3’ by Grogan (1989, 215).  Possible outline of ditch-barrow visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018. See attached Google Earth orthoimage. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 17 October 2021

On a very slight E-facing slope, under rough pasture, at the centre of a circular clearing (diam. c. 60m) in c. 15 year old coniferous forestry. Circular area (diam. 6.8m) defined by a shallow fosse (overall Wth 2.4m; Wth at base 0.8m; D 0.1m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth. Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In rough grazing, close to a break of slope at the E end of a ridge. A low circular flat-topped rise (diam. c. 5m; H c. 0.3m), engulfed in rushes. A silted-up fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.2m), noted during a previous site inspection in 1993 (SMR (1989) file), is now possibly masked by a dense growth of rushes. This is one of a group of four barrows (see SL047-048001-; SL047-048002-; SL047-048004-).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In improved pasture 250 W of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Knockderk. Field system (LI033-074001-) lies 80m to E.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 60; AP 4/3616) as a barrow. Outline of shallow depression (diam. c. 8m) visible on OSi orthophotos taken between 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018 maybe the remains of a possible ditch-barrow.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 26 March 2021

In rough grazing, close to a break of slope at the E end of a ridge. A circular flat-topped rise (diam. 4.8m; H 0.3m) defined by a low broadly sloping scarp. A band of wet ground (Wth c. 1.5m) outside the scarp S-W probably indicates the remains of a silted-up fosse. This is one of a group of four barrows (see SL047-048001-; SL047-048002-; SL037-048003-).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In wet pasture, 85m NE of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Knockaunavlyman. Barrow (LI049-236002--) lies 15m to the E and barrow (LI049-236003-) 25m to SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as ‘Newtown 4’ by Grogan (1989, 244). Faint outline visible on OSi orthoimage taken between 2005-12.  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 12 October 2021

In wet pasture, 85m NE of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Knockaunavlyman. Barrow (LI049-236001--) lies 15m to the W and barrow (LI049-236003-) 12m to SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as ‘Newtown 5’ by Grogan (1989, 244). Faint outline visible on OSi orthoimage taken between 2005-12. In low-lying level wet reclaimed pasture. Identified during field survey by Mark Keegan (5/11/2004). Circular area (diam. 5m) defined by an irregular shallow fosse (overall Wth 2-2.5m; Wth at base 1-1.5m; D 0.1m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth. According to local information, the barrow has a more regular form prior to the reclamation of the area.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 16 September 2014

In grassland, ditch-barrow (LI049-285----) 12m to S. Cropmark of ditch-barrow (diam. c. 7m) visible on Google Earth orthophoto taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O’BrienDate of upload: 8 December 2021

In grassland, ditch-barrow (LI049-285----) 12m to N. Cropmark of ditch-barrow (diam. c. 7m) visible on Google Earth orthophoto taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O’BrienDate of upload: 8 December 2021

At the summit towards the NW end of a NW-SE ridge and just S of the barrow (RO034-035001-). Described as a very small circular area defined by a shallow fosse and bounded at N by the outer bank of the large barrow (RO034-035001-) (Gannon 1972). It is not visible now at ground level.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 17/1977).

In pasture, 140m of townland boundary with Duntryleague. Located within a field system (LI049-048001-), in E quadrant of a group of monuments (LI049-048002/004-), possible barrow (LI049-051----) lies 75m to the E.  Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps.  Possible barrow identified as a circular cropmark on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000 2582, Site 049217) taken 03/11/1984.  Monument visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. c. 5m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13.  Faint trace visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Fiona Rooney Date of upload: 21 September 2021

In pasture, 60m W of townland boundary with Duntryleague. A field system  (LI049-048001-) lies 175m to the W with possible barrows (LI049-052/048004-) 40m to the S and 90m to the W respectively. In reclaimed pasture.   Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps. Bronze age ditch-barrow (site TR/2/16/2) excavated in 1986 by Eoin Grogan on the Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline (Gowen 1988, 72-79). The results of this excavation were summarised as following; ‘The first feature revealed was part of the outline of a ring-barrow [LI049-059001-]  extending onto the corridor from the fence line. Machine skimming of the surrounding area (which removed a further 5-10cm of topsoil) revealed the majority of the features excavated (LI049-059001-/004-). Two further ditch features were revealed after trenching in an area which was not accessible during excavation.  The ring-ditch - There were two main features, a central ring-ditch contained within a ditched enclosure [LI049-059002-], along with a complex of features including a hearth pit containing coarse undecorated pottery, eight further pits and twenty-two post and stake holes. Only one third of the ring-ditch was available for excavation. It was defined by a gapped trench enclosing part of a circle roughly 7m in diameter. It was 24-56cm wide and c. 40cm deep. Two gaps occurred in the excavated portion, one of which (48cm wide) was spanned by a narrow slot trench. The second gap was at least 1m wide extending beyond the fence line. Within the enclosed area, c. 30cm from the inner ditch edge, was a concentric trench, forming part of a possible discontinuous inner ditch. A very small sample of unidentifiable fragments of burnt bone was recovered from the outer ditch fill, along with two small sherds of coarse undecorated pottery. The outer enclosure ditch appeared to be a contemporary feature. The exposed portion described roughly one quarter of a circular or oval enclosure with a diameter of approximately 20m. It was 80cm in maximum width and 30cm deep. The hearth pit within this feature and lying 5.50m from the ring-ditch measured 64cm x 59cm x 6cm and had a charcoal-rich fill of clay and heat-shattered stones. Ten sherds of coarse undecorated pottery were recovered from the fill. One of the eight pits (73cm x 45cm x 33cm) contained e substantial portion of a single coarse undecorated pot. The post and stake holes within the enclosure formed no interpretable plan. While the hearth may represent some domestic activity, it would appear to be ancillary to the overall ritual nature of the site' (Grogan 1987, 25). No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached location map and plan taken from Gowen 1988, 73-5   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 27 September 2021

One of a cluster of 14 barrows (LI033-036001/009-; LI033-090/91-; LI033-121-122----; LI033-154----) concentrated in the S half of Derk townland with the closest (LI033-036002-) 12m to the SSE. Surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as a oval-shaped area (dims. 6m N-S; 4m E-W) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 3.4m-4.2m; D 0.15m-0.17m) and a low bank (Wth 3.9m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.15) from NE-WSW.  Possible causeway (Wth 1.3m) at SSW.    Linear depression running N-S 30m to E is one of a number of similar drainage ditches in surrounding fields.  Monument visible as a faint cropmark on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018. In flat pasture 16m E of a small stream, 120m SE of the townland boundary with Garrison. The monument lies 50m N of an enclosure (LI024-228----). The ditch-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but it is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 and on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 163.1; AP 4/3671) as a circular enclosure (ext. diam. c. 16m) and consists of a central circular area surrounded by a fosse. The ditch-barrow is visible on the Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018. There appears to be a ring-barrow (Wth 9.5m) located 35 NE of the ditch-barrow (LI024-227----).  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 163.1 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by:  Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 15 September 2020

One of 9 barrows (LI049-072001/009-) that make up a barrow cemetery concentrated in an area measuring 240m N-S x 50m E-W.  Six of the 9 barrows in this cemetery were excavated in 1934 by S. P. Ó Ríordáin (1936, 180-181). Site number II in Field C was excavated and described as following; ‘No. II was partly paved with a setting of small stones (see plan), and as this occurred also outside the ditch, thought not over the latter, we must conclude that it is older than the barrow.  Part of the paved area was flecked with charcoal’. No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached location maps and plan of Barrow II taken from Ó Ríordáin and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 23 September 2021

In reclaimed pasture 30m E of a stream and 155m W of the townland boundary with Lissard.  One of 6 barrows (LI049-072010/015-) in a field to E of drainage ditch that makes up a barrow cemetery concentrated in an area measuring 100m N-S x 115m E-W.  Barrow cemetery (LI049-072001/009-) lies 70m to W and enclosure (LI049-072016-) lies 110m to SE.  Three of the 6 barrows (LI049-072010/015-) in this cemetery were excavated in 1935 by S. P. Ó Ríordáin (1936, 176-177) the results of which were described as follows; ‘In 1935 further excavations were conducted on a total of twenty of these monuments.  The results were frankly disappointing as no unmistakable burial was found in any of the barrows excavated.  In one some scattered fragments of cremated bone were found, but it was not possible to say if these were human; in another three pockets filled with dark humified soil were revealed which may have marked disintegrated burials. Several solutions may be suggested to account for these negative results. It would appear on the available evidence probable that the majority of the burials were not contained in urns, and that they were burials after cremation. This being the case one may suppose on the evidence of the softness of the bones found in the Lissard barrow that an acid soil acting on the unprotected cremated remains completely dissolved them, leaving no trace. Another factor which we have to consider is the little protection afforded by the slight central mound. This was obviously formed by piling up some of the material from the comparatively shallow ditch, part going to the construction of the surrounding bank’ (Ó Ríordáin 1936, 177).  This site which was excavated is located immediately NE of a drainage ditch running NW-SE in W corner of field and is visible as a faint circular-shaped cropmark (diam. c. 6m) on Google Earth orthoimages 28/06/2018   See attached location map taken from Ó Ríordáin and Google Earth orthoimage.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 24 September 2021

In level pasture, at the foot of the Bricklieve Mountains. A slightly raised circular area (int. diam. 12.2m; H 0.25m) surrounded by waterlogged ground, possibly indicating a silted-up fosse. The perimeter is planted with trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In reclaimed pasture immediately E of the townland boundary with Ballynamona. One of 11 barrows (LI049-072017/026/33-) in the SW corner of Lissard townland that makes up a barrow cemetery concentrated in an area measuring 240m N-S x 230m E-W. Barrow cemetery (LI049-072010/015-) is located in field to W and barrow cemetery (LI041-032001/014-) in field to N. Not marked on OSi maps. In 1934 Ó Ríordáin (1936, 173) recorded numerous barrows in the townland of Lissard which he described as ‘very low earthen mounds surrounded by a slight ditch and sometimes showing also the remains of an outer bank.  The rise to the centre was in all cases very slight and the monuments were such that that one might easily walk over them without noticing them.  The slightly sunken circular ring which marked the position of the ditch was the most distinctive feature and was frequently to be noticed by reason of its wetness as compared with the surrounding ground, this causing the vegetation in it to be fresher and greener’.  Possible ditch-barrow (LI049-072033-), located 180m to NE, is the only barrow in this cemetery excavated in 1935 by S. P. Ó Ríordáin (1936, 173-175). No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached location map taken from Ó Ríordáin and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 27 September 2021
