Monument visible as a circular cropmark ( diam. c. 5m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached plan of survey from Ó Ríordáin (1936) and Google Earth orthoimage.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 26 July 2021

In reclaimed pasture, in NE quadrant of a group of fourteen barrows (LI041-032001/013-). Enclosure (LI041-031----) lies 305m to the SW and a barrow cemetery (LI049-072001/026-) lies to the S and SSW. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified in 1936 during a survey of the area undertaken by Ó Ríordáin (1936, 175). Monument visible as a circular cropmark (diam. c. 5m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached plan of survey from Ó Ríordáin (1936) and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 26 July 2021

In reclaimed pasture, in E quadrant of a group of fourteen barrows (LI041-032001/013-). Enclosure (LI041-031----) lies 270m to the SW and a barrow cemetery (LI049-072001/026-) lies to the S and SSW. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified in 1936 during a survey of the area undertaken by Ó Ríordáin (1936, 175). No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13.  Faint outline visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached plan of survey from Ó Ríordáin (1936) and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 26 July 2021

On a broad low E-W ridge. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 14.5m N-S 14.5m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of top 4-6m; int. D 0.1-0.2m; ext. D 0.1-0.3m). Barrow (RO027-054----) is c. 150m to the WNW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In improved pasture 125m N of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Cloghilawarreela. Ring-barrow (LI033-129----) lies 13m to NE and enclosure (LI033-104----) 100m to NE.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 99.01; AP 4/3618) as a ring-barrow.  Visible as a circular cropmark (diam. c. 9m) on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image labelled 99.01  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 13 April 2021

Visible as a circular feature on aerial photographs (OS: 2/4210/4252), and situated just off the crest of a WNW-ESE ridge on the S side. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 4.1m; H 0.2-0.3m) defined by a reed-filled fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.2-0.3m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level pasture with a barrow (TS066-090005-) located c. 50m to the SSE. Identified on aerial photograph (Bruff Survey aerial photo 5/2090). Circular slightly raised area (diam. 5m) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarp (Wth 1.6m; H 0.2m) with a flat-bottomed external fosse (overall Wth 1.6m; Wth at base 0.6m; D 0.1m). The fosse is best preserved N-ESE being shallow and difficult to trace WNW-N and ESE-SW. The fosse is not visible at ground level SW-WNW where a modern NNW-SSE orientated field boundary lies along the line of the fosse. The interior is level, dry and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

In reclaimed pasture, ringfort (LI024-029----) 70m to NW. Second possible ditch-barrow (LI024-348----) 40m to E.  Faint outline of ditch-barrow visible on Google Earth orthophoto taken 18/11/2018. See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 29 September 2020

In reclaimed pasture, ringfort (LI024-029----) 90m to NW. Second possible ditch-barrow (LI024-347----) 40m to W.  Faint outline of ditch-barrow visible on Google Earth orthophoto taken 18/11/2018. See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 29 September 2020

In improved pasture 100m NW of a watercourse. Enclosure (LI033-093----) 100m to N.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 78; AP 4/3626) as a ring-barrow.  Visible as a circular cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing possible monument labelled Bruff 78  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 12 April 2021

In a low-lying level area in otherwise gently undulating pasture. A ring-ditch (TS 066-034----) is located 50m to the NW and a ring-barrow (TS066-035----) 50m to the SW. Circular very slightly raised area (diam. 6m) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarp (Wth 1m; H 0.2m) with a flat-bottomed external fosse (overall Wth 2m; Wth at base 1m; D 0.1m). The fosse is not visible at ground level NE-SE. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved, wet pasture, on a natural curvilinear ridge, overlooking a low-lying level area (possible flood plain) to N. A ditch barrow (TS066-072----) is located c. 18m to the SE. A sub-circular area (dims. 4.75m N-S; 3.5m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.15m) which is broader and less defined in the NE quadrant and is backfilled at SW. The interior is grass covered with a N-facing slope. A dry drainage channel running NW-SE lies immediately SW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on a gentle N-facing slope. Circular area (diam. 5.5m) defined by fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.13m) which is best defined NNW-NNE. Former bed of stream (long axis E-W) to S and dry drainage channel c. 1.5m to W. Ditch barrow (TS066-072001-) is c. 18m to NW. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2434/5).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In flat pasture 26m E of the townland boundary with Ballynaclogh. The ring-barrow is 100m SW of a ringfort (LI024-252----) and 100m NNW of a ring-barrow (LI024-186----). The monument is not depicted on historic OSi maps, nor is it visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 nor on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 44; AP 4/3672) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 7m). The ring-barrow is not visible on the Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018, but is visible on an earlier Google Earth image taken 25/03/2017). See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 44 and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by:  Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 17 September 2020

In improved wet pasture, gently undulating due to former water activity. Sub-circular area (diam. 5.2m) defined by scarp (Wth 2-2.7m; H 0.3m). Slight dip in scarp at NE. Shallow depression (D 0.05-0.1m) within centre of interior. Exterior is saturated with water and poached by cattle NE-SE. Low bank (long axis ENE-WSW) to NNW may be part of old field boundary or up-cast from drainage. General area is characterised by natural water activity. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2435/4). A ring-barrow (TS066-076----) is c. 58m to W and two ring-barrows and a ditch barrow (TS066-076002-, TS066-076003- and TS066-076004-) are c. 69-77m to E.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture 35m W of townland boundary with Ballyneety South, an enclosure (LI033-106----) lies 272m to the NW. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 100; AP 4/3618) as circular cropmark. Visible as a circular cropmark (diam. c. 7m) on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image labelled 10   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 26 April 2021

In pasture, on a S-facing slope, overlooking rough pasture to the S. A ring-barrow (TS066-073----) is located c. 18m to the W. A circular area (dims. 6m N-S; 5.5m E-W) defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 1.75m; D 0.1m). The interior slopes down gently to the SSE with the prevalent slope. A field boundary is located 14m to the NW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved wet pasture, c. 5m to SW of natural scarp of old water channel (long-axis c. E-W). Circular area (dims. 3.2m N-S; 3.5m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 2.1m; D 0.18m) which is best defined (Wth 1.3m; D 0.14m) NNE-ESE. Gap (basal Wth 1.2m) at NNW. Interior is very low in profile and is c. 0.08m lower than exterior ground level. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2435/4). Two ring-barrows (TS066-076003- and TS066-076002-) are 1.1m to NW and 2m to W respectively. General area of monument is gently undulating due to former water activity.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In flat pasture 65m E of the townland boundary with Ballyshoneen.  Ring-barrow lies 90m NE of the ringfort (LI024-052----) known as ‘Rathaniska’ and 24m NNE of an enclosure (LI024-234----). The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but it is faintly visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 and on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 92; AP 4/3672) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. 10.3m) that consists of a central circular area surrounded by a fosse. The ring-barrow is visible on the Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018. See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 92 and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by:  Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 17 September 2020

In pasture, on a S-facing slope, overlooking rough pasture to the S. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (5 December 2008). A roughly circular area (dims. 4.2m N-S; 3.5m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.18m) best defined NNW-E-SW. The interior is 0.13m lower than the external ground level and tilts slightly downwards to S with the prevalent slope. There is a field boundary c. 8m to the NW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In pasture, on a S-facing slope, overlooking rough pasture to the S. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (5 December 2008). A circular area (diam. 6m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.15m). The interior slopes down to the S with the prevalent slope and is 0.1m below the external ground level. There is a shallow drain running NE-SW c. 3m to the NW and a field fence and deep land drain c. 10m to the E.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In pasture, on a gentle S-facing slope, overlooking rough pasture to the S and situated within the SE sector of a larger sub-circular area (diam. c. 12m) defined by low scarp (H 0.2m) NE-S-NW. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (5 December 2008). A sub-circular area (dims. 5m N-S; 4.2m E-W) defined by the remains of a shallow fosse (Wth 1.4m; D 0.05m) NE-S-NW. The monument has been levelled upslope across the N-sector. The interior is 0.1m higher than the external ground level. There is a field boundary 10m to the NW and the SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

On a gentle NW-facing slope, in reclaimed pasture. Enclosures (LI024-271/135---) lie 107m to NW and 185m to SW, respectively. Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Monument identified as a circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 99: AP 4/3677). Monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (approx. diam. 20m) on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018. See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial image labelled Bruff 99.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 25 July 2020

In level wet pasture with a ditch-barrow (TS058-043002-) located 16m to the NNE and ringfort (TS058-043----) 70m to the SW. Circular area (diam. 10m) defined by a very slight fosse (overall Wth 1m; D 0.05m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture with a ditch-barrow (TS058-043001-) located 16m to the SSW and ringfort (TS058-043----) 90m to the SW. Circular area (diam. 4m) defined by a very slight fosse (overall Wth 1.8m; Wth at base 0.6m; D 0.1m). From N-W the fosse is barely visible at ground level. No entrance feature is evident. The interior undulates slightly and is clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In wet terrain, on a gentle S-facing slope, in pasture. There are three ditch barrows (TS066-182001-; TS066-182002-; TS066-182003-) lying c. 107m, 112m and 137m to the NE respectively, a ring-barrow (TS066-073----) and a ditch barrow (TS066-073----) lying c. 247m and 220m to the ESE respectively and a ring-barrow (TS066-074----) lying c. 278m to the SE. Monument identified on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009) as a circular ring-ditch, c. 6m in diameter. It is likely that this is a ditch barrow given its proximity to other barrows. There are a lot of drainage channels in this field. There is no visible trace of the monument above ground.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 11 December 2013

In reclaimed grassland. Outline of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 7m) defined by a fosse visible on Digital Globe orthophoto taken 2011-13 and earlier OSi orthophotos.Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 24 June 2020

In reclaimed pasture, 70m S of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Bohercarron and 100m W of the County boundary with Tipperary.   Stepped barrow (TS066-122----) lies 200m to SE. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Possible barrow identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 16; AP 5/2133).  Faint trace of circular-shaped cropmark (diam. c. 5m) visible on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached Bruff aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 4 August 2021

In level pasture. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2436/5). Circular area (dims. 5.8m N-S; 5.5m E-W) defined by low profile fosse (Wth 2.75m; D 0.07m). Interior generally level and is same height as exterior ground level. Land drained leaving dry water channels across surrounding field.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In reclaimed grassland. Cropmark of ditch-barrow (diam. c. 5m) visible on Google Earth orthophoto taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O’BrienDate of upload: 6 December 2021

In reclaimed pasture 10m E of the townland boundary with Curraghturk. Enclosure (LI049-188----) lies 15m to NW.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  The monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark on oblique aerial photograph (ASIAP (34) 20) dated 05-01-2003. Faint cropmark visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 10/20/2006.    See oblique aerial photograph (ASIAP (34) 20) and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  5 October 2021

In reclaimed low-lying pasture. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 10m), defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There are a large number of barrows and enclosures in the general vicinity, including an enclosure (TS066-039003-) c. 150m to the SSE.  See attached: TS066-229----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2018)   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 7 January 2022

In improved pasture, with regeneration of rushes, on a W-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 6m N-S; 5.25m E-W) defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 1.75m; D 0.05m). Cork-Limerick Junction railway line is c. 22m to SE. Identified as a possible ring-barrow on an aerial photograph (OS 2397/8).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In reclaimed grassland. Outline of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 7m) defined by a fosse visible on Digital Globe orthophoto taken 2011-13 and earlier OSi orthophotos.Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 24 June 2020

In reclaimed grassland. Outline of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 7m) defined by a fosse visible on Digital Globe orthophoto taken 2011-13 and earlier OSi orthophotos.Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 24 June 2020

In gently undulating wet pasture with a barrow (TS066-092009-) c. 10m to the NE. Identified on Bruff Survey aerial photograph (ref. 2090). Circular area (diam. 5m) defined by a very slight fosse (Wth 1.5m; H 0.1m) marked with a growth of reeds. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

On a rise on the S-facing slope of Rathcroghan plateau. Circular grass-covered area (diam. c. 4m; H 0.1m) defined by a slight fosse (Wth c. 4m; D 0.1m). The N Mucklaghs (RO021-042015-) are c. 120m to the SW and the S Mucklaghs (RO021-042016-) are c. 150m to the SSW. (Herity 1983, 131; 1984, 129, Glenballythomas 20; Waddell 1987-8, 35, No. 52)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In reclaimed grassland. Cropmark of possible conjoined ditch-barrow (diam. c. 7m) visible on Google Earth orthophoto taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O’BrienDate of upload: 7 December 2021

At the foot of a N-facing slope of a gentle hillock, with a standing stone (TS066-198----) visible 86m to the SSE on the summit. A stream runs roughly NE-SW c. 70m to the NW. There is a ring-barrow (TS066-172----) and a stepped barrow (TS066-122---) 184m and 260m to the S respectively. Identified by Doody (Bruff 58, aerial photograph 2133). A very subtle monument consisting of a low, roughly circular raised area (diam. N-S 5m; E-W 5.2m; H 0.03-0.15m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.2-1.4m; D below ext. ground level 0.05-0.14m). There is no visible trace of an outer bank, the external ground level rises naturally to the E and S.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 March 2013

In improved, lush pasture, on a raised area of a gently undulating field. Oval area (dims. 5.9m NE-SW; 3.25m NW-SE) defined by fosse (Wth 1.95m; H 0.15m) which is best preserved at NW (max. D 0.2m). Identified during a survey by Eoin Grogan.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on a S-facing slope. A ring-barrow (TS066-027001-) is located c. 2m to NW. Identified as a circular feature on an aerial photograph (OS 2397/8) during fieldwork (ASI 2009). An oval area (dims. 4.8m N-S; 5.3m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.1m; D 0.12m) which is truncated by an old land drain (long-axis NW-SE) across the SSW-arc. Poorly drained area to the SW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on a S-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 4.2m N-S; 4m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 0.8m; H 0.05-0.2m) and fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.05m). Monument cut into slope W-N-ESE where scarp and fosse are best defined.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, 105m W of townland boundary with Knockaunacurragha. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible ditch-barrow identified as a circular-shaped cropmark, transected at S by a field boundary running E-W, on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/10,560; 0119) taken 03/11/1984. No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages.See attached Bórd Gáis Éireann aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Fiona Rooney Date of upload: 1 November 2021

In improved, level pasture. Identified as one of a pair of unclassified barrows during a survey by Eoin Grogan. Remains of oval area (dims. 4m NE-SW; 2.8m NW-SE) defined by shallow fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.12m) NNE-WNW and truncated by shallow land drain (long-axis NE-SW) across NW-sector. Interior only marginally lower than exterior by 0.03m. Ditch barrow (TS066-169001-) is conjoined to SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved, level pasture. Identified as one of a pair of unclassified barrows during a survey by Eoin Grogan. Circular area (dims. 5m N-S; 4.5m E-W) defined by remains of shallow fosse (Wth 1.95m; D 0.14m). Interior is level and is 0.08m below exterior ground level. Ditch barrow (TS066-169002-) is conjoined to NW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In gently undulating pasture where there are a large number of ditch barrows. The nearest barrow (TS066-092005-) lies c. 65m to the NNW, with another TS066-092006- c. 112m to the W. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009) as a roughly circular enclosure (diam. c. 6m). This monument is not visible above ground level.   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 11 December 2013

In rough, level pasture on a marginally higher area above old water channels. Circular area (dims. 6.5m N-S; 6.0m E-W) defined by low profile fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.15m) which is accentuated by wild irises. Interior level and same height as exterior ground level. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2435/6). Field boundary (long-axis E-W) is c. 10m to N.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In rough level pasture just above height of old water channels. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2435/6). A circular area (dims. 4.5m N-S; 4.5m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.3m; D 0.13m) which is waterlogged S-W-NW. The interior is generally level and sloping down gradually around its perimeter to the fosse. The interior is the same height as the external ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In gently undulating improved pasture with a ditch barrow (TS066-095001-) c. 47m to the ESE and another (TS066-095003-) c. 40m to the SE. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible in an aerial photograph (OSI 2436/5) and on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009) as a roughly circular enclosure (diam. c. 6m). This monument is not visible above ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 11 December 2013

In gently undulating improved pasture with a ditch barrow (TS066-095001-) c. 18m to the NE and another (TS066-095002-) c. 40m to the NW. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible in an aerial photograph (OSI 2436/5) and on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009) as a roughly circular enclosure (diam. c. 6m). This monument is not visible above ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 11 December 2013

In rough pasture, overlooking a poorly drained area to the ESE. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (9 December 2008). Conjoined to a ditch barrow (TS066-184003-) to the NE and a ditch barrow (TS066-183002-) is located c. 52m to the ENE. A circular area (dims. 4m N-S; 3.5m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.9m; D 0.11m) accentuated by wild irises and waterlogged in the S quadrant. The interior has a low dome-shaped profile.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

Visible as a circular feature (diam. c. 15m) defined by a fosse, probably with an outer bank that has an entrance at SE, on an aerial photographs (ACAP: V221, 117-18). Situated on a level low-lying landscape with an ESE-WNW stream or drain c. 20m to the N, it is not visible at ground level in reclaimed pasture. Rath (RO010-055----) is c. 100m to the ESE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In rough pasture, overlooking a poorly drained area to the ESE. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (9 December 2008). Conjoined to ditch barrow (TS066-184002-) to the SW. A circular area (dims. 5.1m N-S; 5.5m E-W) defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 2.0m; D 0.12m). The interior is sloping down to the SE with the prevalent slope and is c. 0.12m lower than the external ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In gently undulating improved pasture with a ditch barrow (TS066-095002-) c. 47m to the WNW and another (TS066-095003-) c. 18m to the SW. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible in an aerial photograph (OSI 2436/5) and on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009) as a roughly circular enclosure (diam. c. 6m). This monument is not visible above ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 11 December 2013

On top of a slight rise in gently undulating pasture with a ring-barrow (TS066-093001-) located 8m to the ESE. Identified on an aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2435/6). Oval slightly raised area (dims. 8m NE-SW; 5m NW-SE) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarp (Wth 1.8m; H 0.2m) with a flat-bottomed external fosse (overall Wth 2.2m; Wth at base 1.2m; D 0.05m). The fosse is best preserved SE-SSW being shallow and difficult to trace NNE-SE. The fosse is not visible at ground level SSW-NNE. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

In rough, gently undulating pasture. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (9 December 2008). A ditch barrow (TS066-183001-) is located c. 31m to the E and a ring-barrow and a ditch barrow (TS066-184001- and TS066-184002-) are located c. 52m to WSW. A circular area (dims. 4.75m N-S; 4.6m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.2m; D 0.04m). The interior is level and the same height as the external ground level. The monument overlooks a former bog to the N and E which was planted with conifers c. 8 years ago.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In rough, gently undulating pasture. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (9 December 2008). A ring-barrow (TS066-183002-) is located c. 31m to the W. A circular area (diam. 5.8m) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.3m; D 0.12m). The interior is generally the same height as the exterior and wild irises cover the N half and extend into the fosse. The monument overlooks a former bog to the N and E which was planted with conifers c. 8 years ago.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

Within interior of enclosure (TS066-079----), off-centre to N. A ditch barrow (TS066-079002-) is located just within the N sector of the enclosure. A circular area (dims. 5.8m N-S; 5.4m E-W) defined by the remains of a fosse (Wth 3.0m; D 0.2m) disturbed by two wide lazy beds, running NW-SE, which truncate the monument and give it a sunken appearance. The interior is c. 0.1m lower than the exterior and is disturbed by the lazy beds. It is visible on an aerial photograph (ref. OS 2437/6) as a roughly circular anomaly.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On top of a slight rise in gently undulating elevated pasture, within the approximate centre of the an enclosure (TS066-15501-). Visible on an aerial photograph (Bruff No. 5/2031). This roughly circular slightly raised area (diam. 24m) is defined by a gently sloping earthen scarp (overall Wth 5.4m; H 0.65m) with a shallow external fosse (overall Wth 3.7m; Wth at base 1.6m; D 0.2m). From NE-SE the fosse is absent and the scarp merges into the underlying natural slope. The original entrance is not recognisable. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

Just within N-sector of enclosure (TS066-079----). A ditch barrow (TS066-079001-) is located just N of the centre of the enclosure. A circular area (dims. 6m N-S; 6.5m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 2.0m; D 0.1m). The interior is generally level and is the same height as the external ground level. It is visible on an aerial photograph (ref. OS 2437/6) as a circular anomaly.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

A ditch barrow was uncovered during monitoring of the remaining untested road-take on the N8 Rathcormac-Fermoy Bypass between June 2004 and March 2005. Subsequent excavation revealed a circular area (diam. c. 4.25m) defined by a fosse (Wth 0.81-1m; D 0.31m) best preserved along the N arc. The fills in the fosse were of sandy clays. Flecks of charcoal indicate that burning had occurred in the area when the fosse was open. A second phase of activity occurred after the fosse was back-filled and consisted of a narrow fosse or slot being dug along and into the fills on the inner edge of the original ditch barrow. The fills of this second fosse were charcoal rich and included fragments of cremated human bone. The small amount of bone recovered suggests that it was only a token deposit. Evidence of burning in-situ from the upper fills of this second fosse produced a radiocarbon date of cal. BC 349-43 (UB-6770). The excavator suggests that this ditch barrow may be associated with the complex of Bronze Age/Iron Age monuments (CO044-073001- - CO044-073014-) immediately to the NE that were also excavated on the route of the N8. (Reilly 2006, 1-36)  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 5' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2009).  Date of upload: 22 December 2009

On top of Rathcroghan mound (RO022-057010-) at the highest point of the Rathcroghan plateau. Oval grass-covered mound (dims. 9m N-S; 6m E-W; H 0.2 -0.3m), which may have had a fosse (Knox 1911, 99). (Herity 1983, 130; Waddell, 1983, 27, Pl. 1)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 19/1934) and is now a National Monument in state ownership: No. 294.

In improved level pasture. Sub-circular area (dims. 9.5m N-S; 8.5m E-W) defined by low profile remains of fosse (Wth 2.25m; D 0.1m) NW-E-S-SW. Interior generally same height as exterior ground level. Visible on aerial photograph (ref. OS 2437/6) as a circular enclosure. A dtich barrow (TS066-081003-) is c. 4.5m to ENE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level, improved pasture. Two ditch barrows (TS066-081001-; TS066-081002-) are located c. 34m and c. 4.5m to the NNE and WSW respectively. An oval area (dims. 5m NE-SW; 4m NW-SE) defined by the remains of very shallow fosse (Wth 2.05m; D 0.2m) from S-W-NNE. The interior is 0.1m lower than the external ground level and has been levelled out across the SE sector where it falls very gradually into the fosse. It is visible on a aerial photograph (ref. OS 2437/6) as a sub-circular anomaly.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved level pasture. Sub-circular/penannular area (dims. 9m NE-SW; 10m NW-SE) and open (Wth 7.75m) to N-NE. Defined by fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.1m) NE-S-N, by a small depression N-NNE and undefined NNE-NE. Interior 0.05m higher than exterior ground level. Ground to NE disturbed, however may have been a smaller conjoined barrow. Not enough evidence visible on ground to support this. Two ditch barrows (TS066-081----; TS066-081003-) are located c. 40m and c. 34m to the NNE and SSW respectively. Visible on aerial photograph (ref. OS 2437/6) as pennanular enclosure.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Within enclosure (TS066-041005-), abutting interior of N bank. Identified on an aerial photograph (OS 2397/6 and 2348). Within enclosure (TS066-041005-), cutting N bank. Identified on an aerial photograph (OS 2397/6 and 2348). In rough low-lying pasture. In rough, level pasture which though drained remains wet and badly poached by cattle. A ring-barrow (TS066-041001-) is located c. 4.5m to the WNW. In rough pasture deeply poached by cattle, on a gentle NW-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 4.25m N-S; 4.75m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 0.75m; H 0.1m). Fosse (Wth 1.9m; D 0.1m) traceable NW-N-NE. On top of the level summit of a prominent hill with panoramic views in all directions, at the WSW side of an enclosure (TS058-023002-) containing a multi-period complex. A second ditch-barrow (TS058-023007-) is located 4m to the SE and a ring-barrow (TS058-023006-) is 8m to the ESE. A bowl-barrow (TS058-023003-) and a standing stone (TS058-023004-) are located 4m to the ENE. A standing stone (TS058-079----) is visible 800m to the NE; a large barrow 1.5km to the WSW and a mound-barrow (TS058-047----) 1.8km to the S. The enclosing elements are in good condition with crisp breaks of slope and no livestock damage. The ditch-barrow consists of a circular slightly raised area (diam. 2.4m) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarped edge (Wth 0.6m; H 0.4m) with an external narrow flat-bottomed fosse (overall Wth 1.15m; Wth at base 0.75 m; D 0.3m). The scarped edge and fosse enclose the barrow on all sides and have a consistent gently sloping profile. A causeway (Wth. 1m) across the fosse at SE marks the position of the original entrance. The interior is dry and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on gently sloping area of SSE-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 5.5m N-S; 6m E-W) defined by conspicuous fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.15m) highlighted by wild iris NNE-E. Interior slopes down gently to SSE and is same height as exterior ground level. Field boundary (long-axis WSW-ENE) c. 10m to S. Identified as a ring-ditch on aerial photograph (OS 2436/7 mono). On top of the level summit of a prominent hill with panoramic views in all directions, abutting the inner SW side of an enclosure (TS058-023002-) containing a multi-period. A second ditch-barrow (TS058-023005-) is located c. 20m to the NW and a ring-barrow (TS058-023006-) is 4m to the W. There is a standing stone (TS058-023004-) on the summit. Another standing stone (TS058-079----) is visible 800m to the NE; a large barrow 1.5km to the WSW and a mound-barrow (TS058-047----) 1.8km to the S. The enclosing elements are in good condition with crisp breaks of slope and little livestock damage. The barrow is, however, becoming engulfed with gorse making access difficult. The ditch-barrow consists of a semi-circular slightly raised area (dims. 3m NW-SE; 1.5m NE-SW) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarped edge (Wth 2.2m; H 0.75m) with an external narrow flat-bottomed fosse (overall Wth 1.55m; Wth at base 0.65 m; D 0.65m). The scarped edge and fosse enclose the ditch barrow W to SE have a consistent strongly sloping profile. From SE to W the monument is defined by the fosse of the larger enclosure (TS058-023002-). The interior is level, dry and mostly overgrown with gorse.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level pasture, at base of a gentle WSW-facing slope. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2437/6). It forms part of a barrow cemetery, with an adjacent ring-barrow (TS066-016004-) to the SW and a larger enclosure (TS066-016001-) to the NW. This monument is not visible at ground level due to ground disturbance.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 01 September 2014

In improved pasture, on a NE-facing slope overlooking wet marshy ground to NE. Circular area (dims. 4.75m N-S; 5m E-W) defined by remains of shallow fosse (Wth 3.05m; D 0.15m). Interior generally level and is c. 0.05m lower than exterior ground level. Identified as a ring-ditch on Bruff 29 aerial photograph survey (Aerial 2036?) and is visible on aerial photograph (OS 2396). Ditch barrow (TS066-016002-) c. 36m to E.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, on top of low rise. Good views across estate to W-N-E. Circular area (dims. 5.8m N-S; 5.4m E-W) defined by very shallow fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.1m). Interior generally level in centre and falling gently to fosse around its perimeter. Interior and exterior ground level same. Identified on an aerial photograph (252/2).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on a NE-facing slope overlooking wet marshy ground to NE. Low profile circular area (dims. 4.2m N-S; 4.3m E-W) defined by remains of shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.15m). Interior tilts downslope to NE with prevalent slope. Identified as a ring-ditch on Bruff 29 aerial photograph survey (Aerial 2036?). Ditch barrow (TS066-016003-) c. 36m to W.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture on high ground flanking the E and SE sides of a former lake, dry since drainage activities took place in the 1870s/1880s. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (28 November 2008). A ditch barrow and ring-barrow (TS066-179----; TS066-178----) are located c. 26m and c. 56m respectively to NE. The remains of a circular area (dims. 6.0m N-S; 5.0m E-W) defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.05m).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In improved pasture, on a level area of high ground flanking the E and SE sides of a former lake, dry since drainage activities took place in the 1870s/1880s. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (28 November 2008). Two ring-barrows (TS066-178----; TS066-180----) are located 9m and c. 36m to SSW and SW respectively. The remains of a circular area (dims. 5.0m N-S; 5.5m E-W) defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 2.0m; D 0.1m).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In improved pasture, on a gentle SSE-facing slope due S of a large pond and due SW of a rectangular shelter belt. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (28 November 2008). A circular area (dims. 4.5m N-S; 4.7m E-W) defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.1m), which is shared with an adjoining ditch barrow (TS066- 176002-) to the NNE. The interior is generally flat, tilting downslope slightly to SSE with the prevalent slope.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In improved pasture, on a gentle SSE-facing slope due S of a large pond and due SW of a rectangular shelter belt. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (28 November 2008). A circular area (dims. 6m N-S; 5.25m E-W) defined by a very shallow, indistinct fosse (Wth 2.0m; D 0.05m), which is shared with an adjoining ditch barrow (TS066-176001-) to the SSW. The fosse is more defined in the NE quadrant where the monument has been cut slightly into the SSE-facing hillslope. The interior is flatter than that of the adjoining barrow and is tilting gently downslope to SSE with the prevalent slope.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In gently undulating pasture, on low rise. Lots of old fluvial activity in field from old water courses. Circular area (dims. 6.5m N-S; 6m E-W) defined by very shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.15m). Interior generally level and same height as exterior ground level. Identified on aerial photograph.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved, level pasture, overlooking fen SE-WSW. Circular area (dims. 4.7m N-S; 4.25m E-W) defined by remains of shallow fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.1m). Interior generally same height as exterior ground level. Identified as one of a pair of ring-ditches on Bruff 30 aerial photograph survey (Aerial 2036?). Ditch barrow (TS066-016007-) c. 10m to S. Railway line close to N.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved, level pasture, overlooking fen SE-WSW. Circular area (dims. 6m N-S; 5m E-W) defined by lush green grass of shallow fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.08m) best defined SE-S-SW and traceable SW-N-SE. Interior generally same height as exterior ground level. Identified as one of a pair of ring-ditches on Bruff 30 aerial photograph survey (Aerial 2036?). Ditch barrow (TS066-016006-) c. 10m to N. Railway line close to N.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, on a short gentle SE-facing slope overlooking an area of old drainage channels. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (26 November 2008). There is a farm trackway c. 13m to N. Another ditch barrow (TS066-175----) is located c. 21m to SE. A circular area (dims. 6.2m N-S; 6.0m E-W) defined by a very shallow and indistinct fosse (Wth 2.4m; D 0.15m). The fosse has eroded SW-W-NW due to slight poaching by cattle. The interior is generally level and falls gently around the perimeter to the fosse.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In improved pasture (drained in the 1880s), on a low rise just above an old water course. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (26 November 2008). Another ditch barrow (TS066-174----) is located c. 21m to NW. A circular area (dims. 3.3m N-S; 3.5m E-W) defined by a very shallow, indistinct fosse (Wth 1.7m; D 0.1m). The interior slopes gently from the centre to the fosse all around.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In pasture, on a S-facing slope, abutting a ring-barrow (TS066-193002-) to the W. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (17 February 2009). An enclosure (TS066-192----) is located c. 25m to the SW. A circular area (dims. 5.25m N-S; 5.1m E-W) defined by a fosse (overall Wth 1.75m; basal Wth 0.4m; D 0.05m). The outer edge of the fosse is slightly damaged in the E quadrant by a land drain which flanks the NNW-SSE running field boundary.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

Towards the E end of a broad E-W ridge with a hill rising to the NE, and c. 400m from Shad Lough to the SE. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 6m N-S; 5.8m E-W; H 0.05m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 7m; Wth of base 2-3.8m; D 0.3-0.4m) (max. ext. diam. 19m N-S; 18.3m E-W). Ditch-barrow (RO028-242002-) is 10m to the S.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Towards the E end of a broad E-W ridge with a hill rising to the NE, and c. 400m from Shad Lough to the SE. Subcircular grass-covered area (dims 28.7m N-S; 26m E-W) defined by a slight fosse (Wth of top 5-6m; int. D 0.05-0.1m; ext. D 0.1-0.3m). There is no outer bank, and the perimeter at S is overlain by an E-W relict field bank. Ditch-barrow (RO028-242001-) is 10m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In poorly drained grassland.  Outline of possible ditch-barrow visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 2 November 2021

Towards the top of the S-facing slope of a hill overlooking Shad Lough, c. 600m to the S. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 16m; H 0.3m) defined by a rounded fosse (Wth of top 4.2-5.7m; Wth of base 1.8-2m; D 0.15-0.3m), with a causeway (Wth 1m) at WNW (ext. diam. 20m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Towards the E end of the broad WNW-ESE Carnfree ridge, c. 60m W of bowl barrow (RO028-070----). Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of top 5m; H 0.1m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth c. 3.5m; ext. D 0.1-0.3m; max. ext. diam. 12.5m N-S). Ditch barrow (RO028-072001-) is c. 80m to the SE. (Waddell 1988, 17)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Towards the E end of the broad WNW-ESE Carnfree ridge, c. 60m SW of bowl barrow (RO028-070----). Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 11m; H 0.1m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of top 6m; Wth of base 2-2.5m; ext. D 0.1-0.3m; max. ext. diam. 20.5m N-S). Ditch barrow (RO028-071----) is c. 80m to the NW and ditch barrow (RO028-073----) is c. 80m to the ESE. (Waddell 1988, 17)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the E end of the broad WNW-ESE Carnfree ridge, c. 90m SE of bowl barrow (RO028-070----). Circular flat-topped mound (diam. of top 4m; diam. of base 8m; H 0.1-0.3m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 4m; ext. D 0.1-0.3m; max. ext. diam. 13m). Ditch barrow (RO028-072001-) is c. 80m to the WNW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the crest of the N-facing slope of a WNW-ESE ridge on the N-facing slope of the broad WNW-ESE ridge of Carnfree. Circular, domed and grass-covered mound (diam. of base 10m; H 0.2-0.4m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 6-7m; D 0.2-0.4m) (ext. diam. 20m N-S; 20m E-W). Mound barrow (RO028-066002-) is c. 40m to the SE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In poorly drained grassland.  Outline of possible ditch-barrow visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 2 November 2021

On reclaimed grassland, immediately E of a field boundary which marks the townland boundary with Moanoola.  Cropmark of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 10m) defined by a ditch visible on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-12 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Edmond O'DonovanDate of upload: 22 September 2020

column10: In a valley, in a dip between two hummocks, on a slight S-facing slope of a gentle hillock in gently undulating hummocky wet terrain, in pasture. The view is generally good along the valley floor and also to the S of the N slopes of a hill range, including Moanour Mountain, Slievenamuck, Carrigeenina and The Steeple. A circular enclosure visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. A low circular flat-topped mound (diam. 7.3m; H 0.15m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.1m). There are a number of circular impressions immediately E of this mound, on the top of the natural rise, which have been created by cattle poaching around ring-feeders. The mound and fosse of the possible monument is more defined, the fosse being deeper and the mound therefore more accentuated, than the neighbouring circular impressions. Also its location in a hollow seems a poor choice for a ring-feeder. According to the landowners they don’t remember a ring-feeder ever being positioned in the hollow. However, similar to the neighbouring ring-feeders, there are a lot of nettles growing on the mound and in the fosse which suggests that the ground was more recently disturbed. Two ring-barrows (TS066-226----; TS066-228----) are located c. 90-100m to the NW.  See attached:TS066-228----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2018)TS066-228----_02 Overview from the ECompiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 14 January 2022

In improved, very undulating pasture where the land has been drained and ther is evidence of former water channels. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (2 February 2009). A farm trackway is depicted on the 2nd (1906) ed. OS 6-inch map c. 17m to the E. Ditch barrows (TS066-190001- and TS066-190002-) are located c. 14m to the SE and c. 12m to the E respectively. A circular area (dims. 3.9m N-S; 3.75m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.13m).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In improved, very undulating pasture where the land has been drained and ther is evidence of former water channels. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (2 February 2009). A farm trackway is depicted on the 2nd (1906) ed. OS 6-inch map c. 10m to the E. A ditch barrow (TS066-190002-) is located c. 14m to the SSE. A circular area (diam. 8m) defined by a fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.15m) N-SW and presumed fosse waterlogged from SW-W-N. The interior has been making the ground uneven.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In improved, undulating pasture, on a naturally elevated area defined by drainage water channels. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (2 February 2009). A farm trackway is depicted on the 2nd (1906) ed. OS 6-inch map c. 20m to the E. There are ditch barrows (TS066-190003- and TS066-190002-) c. 4m to the ENE and c. 8m to the NNE respectively and an enclosure (TS066-055----) is located c. 58m to the SW. A circular area (dims. 8m N-S; 8.5m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.7m; D 0.15m). The interior is grass covered and has a depression within centre.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In improved, undulating pasture, on a naturally elevated area defined by drainage water channels. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (2 February 2009). A farm trackway is depicted on the 2nd (1906) ed. OS 6-inch map c. 13m to the E. Ring-barrows (TS066-190003- and TS066-190001-) are located c. 6m to the SSE and c. 8m to the SSW respectively and an enclosure (TS066-055----) is located c. 85m to SW. A circular area (dims. 6m N-S; 6.5m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.75m; D 0.15m) which is less defined in the W quadrant (Wth 2.5m; D 0.1m). The interior is grass covered.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In improved, undulating pasture, on a naturally elevated area defined by drained water channels. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (2 February 2009). A farm trackway is depicted on the 2nd (1906) ed. OS 6-inch map c. 13m to the E. Ditch barrows (TS066-190001- and TS066-190002-) are located c. 4m to the WSW and c. 6m to the NNW respectively and an enclosure (TS066-055----) is located c. 60m to the SW. A circular area (dims. 2.9m N-S; 2.75m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.1m). The interior is grass covered.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

Situated on flat poorly drained reclaimed grassland.  Outline of ring-barrow (approx. diam. 6m) visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-12.  Outline of monument visible on Google Earth orthophotos taken 11/03/2014 and 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 18 October 2020

In improved, undulating pasture. An enclosure (TS066-057----) is located c. 3.5m to the W. A circular area (dims. 7.25m N-S; 6.75m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.7m; D 0.15m) which is waterlogged SSW-W-WNW. The interior has a gentle SW-facing slope and is the same height as the external ground level. A low, linear scarp running E-W lies c. 1.75m N of the monument and a similar, yet gradual scarp lies c. 11m to the S, these may be natural or man-made features.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Near the base of very slight NW-facing slope in gently undulating improved pasture. Circular slightly raised area (diam. 12.5m) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarped edge (Wth 3m; H 0.5-0.7m) with an external wide flat-bottomed fosse (overall Wth 3.2m; Wth at base 2 m; D 0.3m). An E-W orientated metalled farm track lies 2m to the N of the barrow. A slight ramp (Wth. 2m) across the scarped edge with a slight causeway across the fosse marks the position of the original entrance. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On reclaimed pasture depicted as a marshy area on the 1840 ed. OS 6-inch map with stepped barrow (LI016-013----) 140m to S.  Outline of possible ditch-barrow visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 05/05/2000.  Visible as a pond feature on later orthoimages including Google Earth orthophoto taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Alison McQueen and Vera O'RahillyDate of upload: 17 September 2020

A circular area (dims. 3m N-S; 3.5m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.35m; D 0.1m) SE-W-N and scarp which is shared by the enclosing enclosure at E. The definition of the monument is obscured at NE and ESE due to dense vegetation.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

column10: In improved pasture, on a naturally raised area above dry stream beds and water channels. Enclosure (TS066-061----) is located c. 2m to the E. A very low profile circular area (dims. 4.5m N-S.; 4m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.07m). The interior is level and is the same height as the external ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On top of a broad E-W ridge. Circular grass and scrub-covered but poached platform (diam. 15.2m N-S; 15m E-W), which is slightly domed, defined by a scarp (H 0.7m at S to 1.05m at W), and an outer fosse (Wth of base 3.2m; D 0.2m) W-NW. It is bisected by an E-W field bank and drain. Barrow (RO016-059----) is c. 140m to the W, and rath (RO016-061----) is c. 120m to the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In improved pasture, on an elevated area of ground defined by old water channels. Ditch barrows (TS066-061003- and TS066-061002-) are located c. 7m and 10m to the E respectively. A circular area (dims. 2.75m N-S.; 2.5m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.15m).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on an elevated area of ground defined by old water channels. A ditch barrow (TS066-061002-) abuts c. 2m to the ESE and another (TS066-061004-) is located c. 7m to the W. A circular area (dims. 2.5m N-S.; 2.3m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1m; D 0.08-0.1m). The perimeter of the interior is slightly higher SW-W-NW, possibly to compensate for the slight slope down to the W.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on an elevated area of ground defined by old water channels. A ditch barrow (TS066-061003-) abuts c. 2m to the WNW and a ditch barrow (TS066-061004-) is located c. 10m to the W. A circular area (dims. 2.2m N-S.; 2m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.05-0.12m). The interior is dome-shaped and is marginally higher than the external ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a broad plateau. Circular, grass-covered and slightly domed mound (diam. of base 15.8m N-S; 14.6m E-W; diam. of top 10.5m N-S; 10.3m E-W; H 0.3-0.5m) defined by a rounded fosse (Wth of top 8.6-9m N-E to 13m at S; Wth of base 4.5.4m; D 0.2-0.3m). Two relict field banks (RO035-115002-) (Wth c. 3m; H 0.1-0.2m) placed 12m apart approach the monumnet from the N (L 14m; 44m), that on the E running outside the fosse and continuing off to the SE (L c. 30m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On top of a slight rise, at W end of a low E-W orientated ridge, in gently undulating wet pasture. Natural ground level slopes down gently from the monument SE-SW. Views are good in all directions. Slightly raised circular area (diam at base 21m) defined by a broad shallow fosse (Wth at base 2m; overall Wth 4m; D 0.1m). The fosse is largely silted up and barely visible S-W and is completely infilled and not visible at ground level ESE-S. A modern E-W orientated field boundary bank abuts the outer edge of the fosse at N. The interior is slightly domed and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 10m), defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is an enclosure (TS058-003----) c. 200m to the SE and a ringfort (TS058-002----) c. 260m to the S.  See attached: TS058-095----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2018)   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 7 January 2022

A river flows roughly E-W c. 110m to the S and another flows roughly N-S c. 230m to the E, in reclaimed pasture. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 9m), defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is an enclosure (TS058-085----) c. 430m to the E.  See attached: TS058-094----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 7 January 2022

In low-lying wet terrain of former meandering streams, with a stream flowing roughly NW-SE c. 60m to the W, in pasture. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 9m), defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016 and 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There are two ring-barrows (TS066-204----; TS066-205----) c. 650m and 610m to the NW respectively.   See attached: TS066-231----_01 Google Earth satellite image (imagery date, 16 December 2016) TS066-231----_02 Google Earth satellite image (imagery date, 20 January 2020)   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 8 January 2022

In pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 8m) defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. The size of the enclosure and the presence of other barrows in the surrounding area, including a ring-barrow (TS066-203----) c. 350m to the SSW, would suggest that this is a barrow.See attached:TS066-225----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 10 January 2022

Situated on the flat floodplains of a small river located to the W of the site in undulating countryside with a nearby church and graveyard (TN006-003003) to the NW. An archaeological site consisting of a curvilinear V-shaped ditch was identified by Ken Hanley during the stripping of topsoil prior to development work being carried out behind the Riverrun House at Terryglass village in 1998 (Hanley 2000, 202). The site was partially excavated by Paul Stevens in November of 1998 and revealed a V-shaped ditch (Wth 2.8m; D 0.75m) from NE through S to SW which probably enclosed an area approximately 40m in diameter (Stevens 2000, 202). The fill of the excavated ditch contained a layer of charcoal with one tiny fragment of cremated bone. A second ditch feature abutting the larger ditch at E was also uncovered. The excavator suggested that it was possibly contemporary with the larger ditch although this could not be fully established without further excavation. The charcoal layer with cremated bone suggests that this was the site of a funerary monument measuring approximately 40m in diameter (ibid., 202).  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

At the base of a slight hollow, on a slight S-facing slope, in gently undulating improved pasture. Ringfort (TS058-055002-) is located 14m to the SW. Roughly circular area (diam. 16m) defined by a low broad earthen scarp (overall Wth 2-4m; H 0.3-0.5m) with an external fosse (overall Wth 6.5m; D 0.2-0.7m). A septic tank has been cut into the base of the fosse at NW. The scarped edge has been cut back and the fosse infilled NW-E and the NW-SE orientated N24 road abuts the line of the outer edge of the infilled fosse at E. The interior slopes slightly facing SW, undulates irregularly and is clear of overgrowth. Due to the underlying natural slope, external ground level is slightly higher than the level of the interior at N.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m) defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 16 December 2016), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. The size of the enclosure and the presence of barrows in the general area suggests that this is a barrow. Another ditch barrow (TS058-093----) is located c. 300m to the SE.See attached:TS058-092----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 16 December 2016)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 11 January 2022

Visible on aerial photographs (GSIAP: G 149-150), and situated on a level, low-lying landscape. Circular grass and rush-covered area (diam. 24m) defined by a scarp (H 0.1-0.2m) and an outer band of wet ground (Wth 4-4.5m) SE-NE. The large ring-barrow (RO006-163----) is c. 50m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m) defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 16 December 2016), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. In gently undulating, poorly drained pasture. Within the SE quadrant of a barrow (TS059-002----). A circular area (dims. 5.25m N-S; 5m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 0.85-3m; H 0.1-0.3m) which is best defined W-N-NE. The scarp is obscured by dense rushes in the S sector. In the SW quadrant, the scarp appears to extend southward to the edge of the larger barrow (TS059-002----).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 September 2013

In pasture, on crest of low gentle rise with good views from NW-NE. Remains consist of a slightly sunken circular-shaped area (diam. 10m) defined by a scarp with shallow fosse (Wth 2.3m; ext. D 0.2m).  Interior level, dry and clear of overgrowth.  Faint cropmark of ditch-barrow visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached sketch plan and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 27 October 2021

In wet pasture, at the E end of a low ridge (long axis c. E-W), on a gentle E-facing slope. Monument identified during ASI fieldwork. A circular area (dims. 6m E-W; 5.75m N-S) defined by a fosse (Wth 0.75-1m; D 0.05-0.1m). The interior is generally level. Enclosure (TS059-004----) is c. 28m to ESE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

In low-lying wet terrain criss-crossed with rivulets, in rough pasture. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 10m), defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 18 November 2018)), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is an enclosure (TS059-169----) c. 195m to the SSE and another (TS059-144----) c. 255m to the SE.  See attached: TS059-202----_01 Google Earth satellite image (imagery date, 18 November 2018)   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 8 January 2022

A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 10m), defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. This is probably a ditch barrow and a similar monument (TS059-198----) is located c. 30m to the NNE.   See attached: TS059-199----_01 Google Earth satellite image (imagery date, 20 January 2020)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 8 January 2022

A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 10m), defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère.
