See attached: TS059-198----_01 Google Earth satellite image (imagery date, 20 January 2020)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 8 January 2022

On an E-facing slope, off the crest of a flat hillock in undulating terrain, in pasture. There are good views to the E and S, though limited by trees and the view N and W is limited by a ridge. A circular enclosure visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. A low circular flat-topped mound (diam. 7.3m; H 0.1-0.15m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.1-0.15m). One of a group of four ditch barrows, TS067-136---- is 30m to the N; TS067-137--- is 40m to the NE, and TS067-139---- is c. 20m to the NE.See attached:TS067-138----_01 Overview from NTS067-138----_02 Overview from SETS067-138----_03 Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 26 January 2021

In generally flat terrain, sloping slightly to the E, in pasture. There are good views to the E and S, though limited by trees and the view N and W is limited by a ridge. A circular enclosure visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. A low circular flat-topped mound (diam. 5.4m; H 0.1m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 2.3m; D 0.1m). One of a group of four ditch barrows, TS067-137--- is 9m to the E, TS067-138---- is 30m to the S and TS067-139---- is c. 20m to the SE.See attached:TS067-136----_01 Overview from ETS067-136----_02 Overview from WTS067-136----_03 Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 26 January 2021

In generally flat terrain, sloping slightly to the E, in pasture. There are good views to the E and S, though limited by trees and the view N and W is limited by a ridge. A circular enclosure, one of a group of four ditch barrows (TS067-136---- is c. 20m to the NW; TS067-137--- is c. 17m to the NNE, and TS067-138---- is c. 20m to the SW) visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. The monument could not be identified at ground level at time of inspection.See attached:TS067-139----_01 Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 26 January 2021

In generally flat terrain, sloping slightly to the E, in pasture. There are good views to the E and S, though limited by trees and the view N and W is limited by a ridge. A circular enclosure visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. A low circular flat-topped mound (diam. 7.6m; H 0.2-0.6m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.1m). One of a group of four ditch barrows, TS067-136--- is 9m to the W, TS067-138---- is 40m to the SW and TS067-139---- is c. 17m to the SSW.See attached:TS067-137----_01 Overview from ETS067-137----_02 Overview from STS067-137----_03 Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 26 January 2021

On the N-facing slope of a hillock, on land sloping gently towards the edge of a steeper slope, in pasture. There are fair to good views to the N and E, but the view is impeded to the S and W by rising ground. A circular enclosure visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. A low circular flat-topped mound (diam. 6.6m; H 0.08-0.16m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.1m). See attached:TS067-140----_01 Overview from ETS067-140----_02 Overview from SWTS067-140----_03 Google Earth satellite imagery, 16 December 2016Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 26 January 2021

In poorly drained pasture, at the base of an E-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 7m N-S; 7.5m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.13m). The interior has a gentle E-facing slope. There is a linear drainage channel (long-axis NE-SW) c. 2m to the NW and a field boundary (long axis NNE-SSW) c. 6m to the WNW. An enclosure (TS059-112001-) is c. 115m to the NE, and a ring-barrow and possible embanked barrow (TS059-112007- and TS059-112008-) are c. 135m to the NE and 100m to the SE respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Within the interior of a barrow (TS059-112001-), in the N quadrant. A raised semi-circular area (dims. 9m N-S; 10m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 1.1m; H 0.35m) from NE-S-NW and by the scarp of the barrow from NW-N-NE, with an well defined, yet narrow fosse (Wth 1.95m; D 0.15m) from NE-S-NW. The interior is uneven and there is a slight curvilinear depression from NE-S concentric with scarp and c. 1.4m from scarp.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved, undulating pasture. A sunken oval area (overall dims. 12m N-S; 9m E-W) with traces of a raised, sub-circular area (dims. 5m N-S; 6.5m E-W) within the interior, defined by a fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.15m) from SE-S and NW-N. It is depicted on the 1840 OS 6-inch map as a sub-oval area with a small, sub-oval feature within. Field boundaries (long axis NNW-SSE) depicted on the 1901-05 edition OS 6-inch map extending to N and S have been removed.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a gentle S-facing slope of a golf course. Subcircular grass-covered platform (dims 3.3m N-S; 2.3m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of top 2-2.5m; D 0.1-0.2m) NE-S-NW. Rath (RO029-035----) is c. 30m to the SW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the crest of the SE-facing slope of the NE-SW shoulder of a hill, the summit of which is c. 300m to the WNW. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 13.8m E-W; 13m N-S; diam. of top 11m E-W; H 1m) with some bushes, that has slight traces of a fosse (Wth of top 4m; Wth of base 1m; D 0.2m) S-W. Barrow (RO045-143002-) is c. 110m to the N, and rath (RO045-145----) is c. 60m to the SSW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In gently undulating pasture. Monument identified during ASI fieldwork. A circular area (dims. 4.75m N-S; 4m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 2.55m; D 0.1m) best preserved NNW-SW. The fosse is slightly truncated on the exterior at W by a linear cultivation ridge (long axis generally N-S). Other similar ridges (Wth 1.4m; H 0.1m) in this area may be part of the field system in the deserted settlement (TS059-127----) of Kilfeakle. Pond c. 8m to N. A ringfort (TS059-128----) and enclosures (TS059-128001-; TS059-128002-) are located is c. 50-80m to SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

Situated in wet marshy pasture, atop low hillock with good views of Devils Bit to NE in mountian valley running NE-Sw in upland region. Well preserved possible ditch-barrow consisting of a circular mound (top diam. 9m NW-SE; base diam. 13m NW-SE; H 0.3m) and fosse (base Wth 5m; top Wth 9m; ext. D 0.45m) with no traces of an outer bank. Overall diameter measures 31m NW-SE.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated on a poorly drained SE-facing slope of rising ground in an upland area with a nearby enclosure (TN040-046001) 70m to the S. A low flat-topped mound (diam. 4.2m NE-SW; 4.4m E-W; H 0.45m) enclosed by a shallow water-logged fosse (Wth 2.4m; D 0.1m) with no evidence for an external bank.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated in gently undulating pastureland on a natural rise of ground, 500m N of Cloghjordan House (TN016-001003-) and the historic village of Cloghjordan (TN016-001----).  Geophysical survey carried out under licence No. 06R020 in this field in 2006 discovered the site of a ditch-barrow located immediately to the W of a levelled enclosure (TN011-029----).  Subsequent archaeological test trenching of this monument by Emer Dennehy on behalf of Margaret Gowen & Co. Ltd. in 2006 under licence number 06E0257 confirmed the feature as that of a ditch-barrow (TN011-038----) and suggested the possibility that the large enclosure (TN011-029----) may be the site of a prehistoric ritual enclosure rather than that of a possible medieval ringfort (Dennehy 2009, 490).  The monument survives in-situ.  The test excavation results were summarised by Dennehy (2009, 490) as following; 'The proposed development at Cloughjordan comprises a 67-acre site within which a ‘sustainable village’ is to be constructed. A total of 133 mixed residential units will be constructed on the southern twenty acres of the site and 30% of the development site will be used for woodlands with the remaining 40% used for agricultural activity. The site is in a rich archaeological and historical environment, with the three RMP sites located within or adjacent to the development. These sites, namely the moated site (TN011–028----) and Cloughjordan Castle (TN016–001----), attest the Anglo-Norman occupation of the area. The enclosure site [TN011-029----], though levelled, is illustrated on cartographic sources and was perceived to be medieval in date. However, a late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age ring-barrow (ext. diam. 16m) was identified immediately adjacent to the enclosure and now suggests the enclosure could be prehistoric.  Initial investigations involved a detailed geophysical survey (06R020) and this was followed by an archaeological impact assessment targeting known and suspected areas of archaeological activity'.  Archaeological test trench 12 which was opened across the SW quadrant of the barrow uncovered the disarticulated remains of skeletal material including skull fragments and a long bone which were left in-situ. This skeletal material was found at two locations within the interior of the barrow.  A section of the ditch of the barrow was excavated revealed that it was V-shaped in profile measuring 1.1m deep by 1.4m wide at the top and narrowing to 0.1m at the base (Dennehy 2006, 18).  See attached images showing location of barrow site, taken from Dennehy 2006.  See attached geophysical survey plot showing outline of  levelled enclosure (TN011-029----) with smaller ditch-barrow immediately to W, taken from Harrison 2006.   Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 6 May 2020

In level pasture. Very slightly raised (H 0.15m) circular area (diam. c. 4.5m) defined by shallow fosse (Wth c. 1m; D c. 0.12m). Ditch-barrows (TS-68-086002- and TS068-086003-) c. 60m to NE and c. 30m to N respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level pasture. Identified during field inspection (25/09/2006). Very slightly raised (H 0.15m) circular area (diam. c. 5m) defined by shallow fosse (Wth c. 1m; D c. 0.1m). Ditch-barrows (TS-68-08601- and TS068-08602-) c. 30m to S and NE respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, on a gentle E-facing slope. Roughly circular area (dims. c. 9m N-S; c. 8m E-W) defined by gentle scarp (H 0.55m; Wth 1.5m at N; Wth 2m at E). Mound is flat topped and tending downslope to E. External fosse (Wth 5.3m; D 0.45m) visible NW-N-ENE. Established hedgerow field boundary truncates S sector slightly and electric fence crosses W sector. Curvilinear depression E-SE-S extends from base of mound at ENE. Ringfort (TS068-038----) c. 135m to NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 9m), which appears to be defined by a fosse, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is an enclosure (TS060-005----) c. 250m to the SSW, an enclosure (TS060-003----) c. 300m to the NW and an enclosure (TS060-004----) and burnt mound (TS060-131----) c. 250-290m to the NNW respectively.  See attached: TS060-152----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 7 January 2022

On a S-facing slope. Archaeological excavation (E3270) during 2007 at Ardagawna 1 as part of the Athlone to Ballinasloe M6 road development revealed half of a small ring-ditch (int. diam. 4m; ext. diam. 5.35m NE-SW). The fosse (Wth c. 1m; D 0.4m) was round-bottomed and contained fragments of cremated human bone and a perforated stone. The fill of the fosse produced a C14 date of 1498-1466 cal. BC, and a C14 date from a tree-bole c. 22m to the N provided a C14 date of 1493-1429 cal. BC, suggesting that tree-clearance was connected with the barrow. The structure (RO052-031004-), c. 22m to the NNW, may be contemporary, but the ring-ditch is unassociated with the corn-drying kiln (RO052-031002-) c. 10m to the NW, the burial (RO052-031003-), and the three pits (RO052-031004-), c. 50m to the N and NE. Part of the ditch barrow survives outside the road at S. (Ó Séaghdha 2010a; 2010d, 8-9)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010 Amended: 25 November, 2013

Situated on flat pasture in undulating countryside. An aerial photograph (CUCAP, ATC 73) shows the clear outline of a possible ditch barrow. Not visible at ground level.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In improved pasture. Circular sunken area (dims. 5.2m N-S; 5m E-W) defined by fosse (overall Wth 2.5-3.15m; basal Wth 0.5-0.7m; D 0.15-0.25m). Interior is grass covered and level. Ditch-barrow (TS060-21 NEW) located c. 90m to NE and a depression is c. 100m to N and may represent a poorly preserved ditch-barrow as according to local information, clay was dumped into it. Enclosure (TS060-020----) is c. 12m to NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture. Circular sunken area (dims. 5.4m NNW-SSE; 5.2m ENE-WSW) defined by fosse (overall Wth 1.9m; basal Wth 0.3m; D 0.15m) NNW-S and disturbed by levelled field boundary (long axis NNW-SSE) to W. Ditch-barrow (TS060-20 NEW) is c. 90m to W. A third depression to NW may represent a poorly preserved ditch-barrow as according to local information, clay was dumped into it. Enclosure (TS060-020----) is c. 20m to W.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on exterior of enclosure (TS060-107005-). Circular area (dims. 2.75m N-S; 2.5m E-W) defined by shallow fosse (Wth 1.25m; D 0.13m). Interior is a low profile dome shape. Ditch-barrows (TS060-107008- and TS060-107009-) are 5.5m and 20m to E respectively and a small possible mound barrow (TS060-107010-) is 14m to the SSW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 14 July 2014

In improved pasture, on exterior of enclosure (TS060-107005-). Circular area (dims. 2.75m N-S; 3m E-W) defined by shallow fosse (Wth 1.2m; D 0.1m). Interior is a low dome-shaped profile. Ditch-barrow (TS060-107007- and TS060-107009-) are 5.5m to W and 9m to E respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on exterior of enclosure (TS060-107005-). Circular area (dims. 3.1m E-W; 3m N-S) defined by shallow fosse (Wth 1.55m; D 0.05m) which is best preserved NE-NW. Fosse is poorly defined and potentially backfilled on exterior due to trampling by animals. Interior is a low profile dome shape. Ditch-barrows (TS060-107008- and TS060-107007-) are 9m and 20m to W respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In flat grassland. In 1999, during the redevelopment of the stud farm, these earthworks, which possibly represents the remains of a deserted medieval village, were partially buried in topsoil to make the land safe for livestock (Purcell and Gowen 2000, 283). A digital terrain model of the earthworks, prior to this, revealed several features including three circular mounds (diam. 5-6m) which appear as 'shallow ring ditches' and may be barrows or 'residual features from circular feeding troughs' (O'Donovan and Duffy 2002, 39-40). Earthworks to the S which appear on aerial photographs (CUCAP 1967, ATA 64; CUCAP 1971, BGO 11) appear to be the remains of a medieval deserted settlement (TS053-042003-).   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In flat grassland. Motte and bailey (TS053-042002-) 200m to SW, fortified church (TS053-042001-) 130m to W and graveyard (TS053-042004-) 25m to W. Visible earthworks (TS053-042003-) extended eastward from the graveyard wall. In 1999, during the redevelopment of the stud farm, these earthworks, which possibly represents the remains of a deserted medieval village, were partially buried in topsoil to make the land safe for livestock (Purcell 2000, 283). A digital terrain model of the earthworks, prior to this, revealed several features including three circular mounds (diam. 5-6m) which appear as 'shallow ring ditches' and may be barrows or 'residual features from circular feeding troughs' (O'Donovan and Duffy 2003, 39-40). Earthworks to the N and E of the church and graveyard show up on aerial photographs (CUCAP 1967, ATA 64; CUCAP 1971, BGO 11).   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In flat grassland. Motte and bailey (TS053-042002-) 200m to SW, fortified church (TS053-042001-) 130m to W and graveyard (TS053-042004-) 25m to W. Visible earthworks (TS053-042003-) extended eastward from the graveyard wall. In 1999, during the redevelopment of the stud farm, these earthworks, which possibly represents the remains of a deserted medieval village, were partially buried in topsoil to make the land safe for livestock (Purcell and Gowen 2000, 283). A digital terrain model of the earthworks, prior to this, revealed several features including three circular mounds (diam. 5-6m) which appear as 'shallow ring ditches' and may be barrows or 'residual features from circular feeding troughs' (O'Donovan and Duffy 2002, 39-40). Earthworks to the N and E of the church and graveyard show up on aerial photographs (CUCAP 1967, ATA 64; CUCAP 1971, BGO 11).   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Within interior of enclosure (TS061-031----), off-centre to ENE. Excellent views in all directions except to W where highest point of slope is located. Ditch-barrow (dims. 1.9m E-W; 1.75m N-S) defined by low profile fosse (overall Wth 1.5m; basal Wth 0.5m; D 0.05m) conjoined a mound barrow (TS061-031001-) to the SW. The ditch barrow is less preserved than the mound barrow due to its location inside the entrance of the enclosure (TS061-031----). A ring-barrow (TS061-031003-) is c. 6.5m to E.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Within interior of enclosure (TS061-061----), off-centre to W. Circular area (dims. 2.1m N-S; 2.2m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 0.8-1.6m; D 0.05-0.08m). Well defined outer bank (overall Wth 2.5m; Wth at top 1m; int. H 0.05m; ext. H 0.05m) SE-NW. Interior is level. Damaged by machinery and by feeding of livestock at this location.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Excavated by Doody (1987, 10-21; 1988, 176-80) between April and May 1982. Circular area (diam. 11m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 1m; D 0.65m) (Doody 1988, 176). Charcoal or charred wood remains were recovered from portion of the fosse and a C14 date of 1535 +/- 40 BC was obtained from one of the pieces (ibid.). The only other finds in the fosse were two fragmentary sherds of coarse pottery and some waste flint flakes (ibid.). In the centre of the ring-ditch there is a cist (TS077-046003-) which contains an urn with the cremated remains of five individuals. Surrounding this cist, and within the confines of the ring-ditch, there was the remains of a circular timber structure (TS077-046010-), interpreted by the excavator as a mortuary structure (ibid.). Within the ditch barrow there were three pits, varying in size (Wth 0.75m, D 0.29m; Wth 2.05m x 0.35-0.9m, D 0.12-0.16m; Wth 1.25m, D 0.25m), the first contained a small amount of burnt bone and charcoal and the second charcoal enriched soil with stones (Doody 1987, 13). A sample from the second pit provided a radiocarbon date of 860 +/- 90 bc (ibid.). If all three pits are contemporary they may be associated with the Late Bronze Age settlement at Ballyveelish (TS077-046002-) (ibid.).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011
Cropmark of ring-ditch (diam. c. 5m) Google Earth photograph taken 18/01/2019.
column13: See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 14 January 2022

column10: On flat grassland with good views in all directions, no surface remains visible of any enclosure in area marked on six inch OS 6-inch map. Depicted as semi-circular-shaped enclosure (diam. c. 17m) on 1st (1840) ed. OS 6-inch map. It is depicted in more detail on the 25-inch OS map as a circular raised area surrounded by a fosse (diam. 12m). This depiction suggests the monument is a barrow, possibly a ring-barrow, but as an outer bank is not depicted it is classified as a possible ditch barrow.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 27 May 2015

On flat reclaimed pasture with good views in all directions with nearby Munster river to SE. Though originally marshy, the land has been drained and reclaimed. Aerial photographs (CUCAP APD 62, 63, 64) taken in 1966 reveal at least ten ring-ditches (TS043-019002- to TS043-019010-), in a roughly linear arrangement, aligned NW-SE, which show up as circular cropmarks. It is likely that these are a barrow group, and while they may be levelled ring-barrows, without evidence of an outer bank they have been classified as ditch-barrows. This ditch barrow, for which the cropmark is quite faint, is located in the southern end of the alignment and appears to be conjoined with a ditch barrow (TS043-019009-) of similar size to the E. The ditch barrow (TS043-019003-), at the NE end of the alignment, is the largest in the group. Cropmarks, indicative of a field system (TS043-019001-), consisting of two parallel linear ditches are visible to the W of the barrow group, with two single ditches to S and E. None of the features indicated on the aerial photographs are visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 March 2015

On flat reclaimed pasture with good views in all directions with nearby Munster river to SE. Though originally marshy, the land has been drained and reclaimed. Aerial photographs (CUCAP APD 62, 63, 64) taken in 1966 reveal at least ten ring-ditches (TS043-019002- to TS043-019010-), in a roughly linear arrangement, aligned NW-SE, which show up as circular cropmarks. It is likely that these are a barrow group, and while they may be levelled ring-barrows, without evidence of an outer bank they have been classified as ditch-barrows. This ditch barrow is located in the southern end of the alignment and appears to be conjoined with a ditch barrow (TS043-019010-) of similar size to the W, though the cropmark for the latter is more faint. The ditch barrow (TS043-019003-), at the NE end of the alignment, is the largest in the group. Cropmarks, indicative of a field system (TS043-019001-), consisting of two parallel linear ditches are visible to the W of the barrow group, with two single ditches to S and E. None of the features indicated on the aerial photographs are visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 March 2015

It is one of five similarly sized barrows (TS043-019002-; TS043-019008- to TS043-019010-) within the group. The ditch barrow (TS043-019003-), at the NE end of the alignment, is the largest in the group. Cropmarks, indicative of a field system (TS043-019001-), consisting of two parallel linear ditches are visible to the W of the barrow group, with two single ditches to S and E. None of the features indicated on the aerial photographs are visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 March 2015

On flat reclaimed pasture with good views in all directions with nearby Munster river to SE. Though originally marshy, the land has been drained and reclaimed. Aerial photographs (CUCAP APD 62, 63, 64) taken in 1966 reveal at least ten ring-ditches (TS043-019002- to TS043-019010-), in a roughly linear arrangement, which show up as circular cropmarks of varying sizes. It is likely that these are a barrow group, and while they may be levelled ring-barrows, without evidence of an outer bank they have been classified as ditch-barrows. This ditch barrow is located at the NW end of the alignment. One ditch barrow (TS043-019003-), at the NE end of the group, is larger than the others. Cropmarks, indicative of a field system (TS043-019001-), consisting of two parallel linear ditches are visible to the W of the barrow group, with two single ditches to S and E. None of the features indicated on the aerial photographs are visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 26 March 2015

Cropmark of ring-ditch (diam. c. 9m) Google Earth photograph taken 26/01/2018.
column13: See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 14 January 2022

column10: Situated on poorly drained lands of Sonna Demesne with enclosure (WM018-160----) 30m to NNW.  Small circular-shaped earthwork (approx. diam. 15m NNW-SSE) defined by a ditch and bisected by a post-1700 ditch is visible on Digital Globe aerial photography.  Not depicted on any edition of the OS maps.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 11 February 2019
Cropmark of ring-ditch (diam. c. 5m) Google Earth photograph taken 18/01/2019.
column13: See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 14 January 2022

column10: Situated in grassland, with large possible ceremonial enclosure (WM012-027---) 80m to NNW. Cropmark of curving ditch of possible barrow (approx. diam. 8m) visible from SSE-S-W only on Digital Globe aerial photograph.   See attached image taken from Digital Globe aerial photographs supplied by Brian Doyle  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Brian Doyle  Date of upload: 18 February 2019

Situated on flat poorly drained land with ring-barrow (WM019-095----) 45m to W.   Low outline of circular shaped mound (diam. 10m; H 0.2m) enclosed by fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.1m) with no evidence of an external bank.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 25 April 2019

Situated on top of a drumlin. A hachured mound is depicted as within a larger enclosure (MO011-003001-) only on the 1907 edition of the OS 6-inch map, and both are depicted as a planation on the 1834 edition. The barrow is a low grass-covered mound (diam. of top 7.5m N-S; 7.5m E-W; H 0.65m) with some deciduous trees defined by a fosse (Wth of base 0.8m; ext. D 0.3m). There is no outer bank (max. ext. diam. 14m), and there is no evidence now of an outer enclosure, but that was recorded in 1948 (OSFM) as a circular area (diam. c. 40m N-S) defined by a scarp (H c. 1m) NW-E-SW that melded into the slope elsewhere.  Date of revised upload: 26 January 2018

New monument uncovered during excavation by Eamonn Cotter under licence number 03E0461 in advance of the M7 Heath-Mayfield motorway scheme.  Area C encompassed the summit and slopes of the low hill which dominates the immediate landscape. Excavation in this area revealed a ditch-barrow located on the E slope of the low hill measuring 15m in diameter and enclosed by a U-shaped ditch (Wth 0.8-1.8m; D 0.9m). No archaeological features were uncovered within the barrow (Bennett 2006, 293).  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Situated in pasture, which overlooks lower ground to N. Barrows (WM020-113----/114----) lie c. 14m to S and c. 30m to SE, respectively. Not depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map or on the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map. Barely visible monument described in 1970-2 as a roughly circular-shaped area (diam. 5m N-S; 4.8m E-W) defined by a narrow, shallow fosse with no visible trace of a bank.  Monument is not visible on Digital Globe aerial photography.  See attached OS 25-inch map showing location of barrow.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin O’Brien.  Date of upload: 08 July 2019

Located on the N-facing crest of the summit of a prominent hill known as Slieve Gullion. Two small barrows are visible on Google Earth from 2009 but are most clearly visible on the most recent (16/03/2021). This feature appears to be complete as a grass-covered platform (diam. c. 5m) defined by ditch or fosse (ext. diam. c. 10m). The features are also visible on MapGenie imagery (2005-12; 2013-18), Digital Globe (2011-13) and Apple Maps, and were first reported by Jean Charles Caillére.  See the attached enhanced view from Google Earth (16/03/2021)Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 12 July 2022

Situated on a broad shelf at the bottom of the E-facing slope of a prominent hill known as Slieve Gullion. A circular grass-covered platform (diam. c. 6m) defined by a complete fosse (ext. diam. c. 13m) is visible on Google Earth (05/10/2009) where it is most distinct, and it has been excluded from a forest plantation since 2016. The enclosure (ME015-131----) is c. 50m to the W. The barrow is also visible on MapGenie imagery (2004-06; 2005-12; 2013-18), Digital Globe (2011-13) and Apple Maps, and while it is not depicted directly on any OS map, a 600 foot contour marks the location on the 1908 edition of the OS 6-inch map. The barrow and enclosure were first reported by Jean Charles Caillére.  See the attached enhanced view from Google Earth (05/10/2009)Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 12 July 2022

Located on a shelf towards the bottom of the E-facing slope of Galeastown Hill. This feature is not depicted on any OS 6-inch map but is visible on aerial photographs (GSIAP: N 259, 260). It is a subcircular dished and grass-covered area (int. dims 24.5m E-W; 21.5m N-S) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 3m; int. D 0.3m; ext. D 0.3m) SE-W-NE. There is no visible bank or entrance.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 10 January 2019

Situated in low lying pasture, with views restricted by the surrounding landscape. Depicted on the 1913 ed. OS 6-inch map as an oval-shaped earthwork. Monument described in 1971 and 1976 as a raised roughly oval-shaped area (dims. 23.4m N-S; 17m E-W) defined by a scarp and external fosse. The scarp is very slight as is the fosse (Wth at top 4.4m). The interior is flat and no features are discernible. There is a very slight depression running NE-SW across the monument. Levelled monument visible today as  an oval-shaped cropmark on Digital Globe aerial photography.   See attached profile of monument surveyed and drawn by the ASI.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin O’Brien.  Date of upload: 06 November 2019

Situated at the bottom of a gentle N-facing slope in a low col with the summits of hills rising c. 570m to the NNW and c. 630m to the E. It was first identified as a possible monument in remote sensing (07R3) for the re-alignment of the R708 Airport road, and confirmed in a test excavation (07E0347) by O. Scully (2007d) when an urn burial was recovered. It was fully excavated by D. J. Lalonde under the same licence.  A circular area (int. diam. 11.25m N-S; 10.5m E-W; ext. diam. 12.5m N-S; 12.5m E-W) defined by a complete round-bottomed fosse (wth of top c. 1-2m; D 0.25-0.6m) surrounded a circle (diam. c. 6m E-W; c. 5m N-S) of pits or post-holes (diam. c. 0.4-0.6m; D 0.15-0.4m) that is open (Wth c. 4m) to the NE like a kerb circle. The pits are arranged in pairs of adjacent inner and outer pits; one contained a cremation, two had inserted cremation burials, and one had a sherd of pottery. Within this circle were numerous stakeholes and soils with oxidised clay and charcoal inclusions.  At the E edge of the barrow three cremation burials were recovered from inverted Urns. Two of the urns were in stone-lined pits, and all three were in the Collared Urn tradition, one being a miniature urn. In addition two other cremation burials were found in pits in the central area, and another was c. 3m outside the ditch to the NW. There were also three shallow pits (diam. 0.75-1.37m; D 0.18-0,3m) outside the ditch at SE. Burnt mound (WA017-139----) is c. 100m to the NW. (Lalonde 2008; 2010a)   Lalonde, D. J. (2008) R708 Airport road realignment scheme Phase 3. Archaeoligical excavation at Monamintra 2, Co. Waterford. Preliminary report. (Unpublished report DEHLG) Daniel Noonan Archaeological Consultancy. Lalonde, D.J. (2010a) Monamintra. Bronze Age cremation enclosure. in I. Bennett (Ed.) Excavations 2007: summary accounts of excavations in Ireland, 517-8, No. 1832. Wordwell. Dublin  Scully, O. (2007d) R708 Airport road Realignment, Phase 3, Co. Waterford. Report on archaeological test excavations in advance of construction at three location along the route of the Airport Road Realignment. Unpublished report. DEHLG. Author.  Compiled by: Michael Moore   Date of upload: 16 February 2011

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Carlow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1993). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Large steep-sided mound with rounded summit (H 3m; base diam. c. 23m). Summit disturbed and overgrown but appears to be relatively small. Traces of fosse and possible levelled bank enclose mound.

On the NW outskirts of Gowran and immediately inside the medieval town defences. During an archaeological excavation (06E0625) carried out in advance of the construction of the ‘Ogenty’ housing development on the Kilkenny road, Gowran a ditch barrow (diam. c. 8m) with a central burial pit was noted (Ó Drisceoil 2009, 263). It was not excavated as the archaeological remains would not be disturbed by the development (ibid.).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 18 March 2021

Situated on a slight SE-facing slope in the S foothills at the E end of the Slieve na Calliagh ridge and in full view of Belview House c. 160m to the SE. It is not depicted on any OS map but it is visible on vertical aerial images (GSIAP: N 155). This is a subrectangular mound (dims of base 12.9m N-S; 12.2m E-W; H 0.6m) defined by a ditch or fosse (Wth of base 2-2.8m; ext. D 0.2-0.3m). Although there are decorative trees in this field there is none at this location and none of the trees have a mound at their base.   The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 10 January 2019

Situated on relatively low ground with limited views. There is a knoll immediately to the NE and a second one c. 100m to the E. A circular grass-covered platform (diam. 17.3m N-S; 16.8m E-W) is surrounded by a clearly visible U-shaped fosse (Wth of top c. 9m; Wth at base 3m; max. D c. 1m) except E-SSW where there is evidence for quarrying.  Compiled by: Claire Breen & Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 26 February 2019

Small circular-shaped earthwork located in field 130m W of Ardkill Church (KD008-009001-) and graveyard (KD008-009002-).  Cropmark of small circular area (approx. diam. 10) defined by a fosse the outline of which is visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph.  The small size and form of the monument may suggest that this is the site of a small ditch barrow.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Chris Corlett  Date of upload: 22 February 2018

Cropmark of possible ditch-barrow (approx. diam. 15m) visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph taken.    See attached image of Google Earth photograph taken 28/06/2018 which shows cropmark of the ditch-barrow based on information supplied by Anthony Murphy  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Anthony Murphy  Date of upload: 20 February 2019

Cropmark of possible ditch-barrow (approx. diam. 12m) visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph.    See attached image of Google Earth photograph taken 28/06/2018 which shows cropmark of the ditch-barrow based on information supplied by Anthony Murphy  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Anthony Murphy  Date of upload: 20 February 2019

On level ground. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A very slightly raised, sub-circular area (diams. 7m NE-SW; 5.8m NW-SE) is defined by a shallow, V-shaped fosse (Wth 0.5m; D 0.2m; ext. diam. 11.m). This is one of a group of six similar, closely associated monuments (KD022-072---- to KD022-077----) in this part of the Little Curragh.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On level ground. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A very slightly raised, sub-circular area (diams. 5.1m NW-SE; 4.7m NE-SW) is defined by a narrow, shallow fosse (Wth 1-1.7m; D 0.05m), clearly visible as a vegetation band girdling the central area. This is one of a group of six similar, closely associated monuments (KD022-072---- to KD022-077----) in this part of the Little Curragh.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

At the N edge of the broad ridge running across the Little Curragh. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). A small, low circular mound (diam. 4.8m; H 0.2m) covered in parched vegetation cover is girdled by vegetation band (Wth 2.2m) of lusher growth, which suggests the presence of a back-filled fosse.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On top of the low, broad ridge which forms the spine of the Little Curragh and which also carries three other possible ditch-barrows; (KD022-083----) c. 45m to the SE, (KD022-081---- and KD022-082----) c. 140m to the ESE, a large ring-barrow (KD022-042----) c. 110m to the SE and a second large ring-barrow (KD022-043----) c. 200m to the ESE. A fourth ditch-barrow (KD022-080----) lies c. 190m to NE. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A slightly raised circular area (diam. 7.4m) is defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 1.4-1.7m; D 0.2m). A footpath track bisects the interior N-S. In the SE quadrant different vegetation growth forms a well defined a circular area (diam 1.8m) and six other examples of this occur immediately outside the monument E-S-W. Their origin, function and relationship with the barrow is unclear. (Similar circular features, but represented by very shallow depressions, occur at another ditch-barrow (KD022-074----) c. 685m to the NW.)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On top of the low, broad ridge which forms the spine of the Little Curragh and which also carries three other possible ditch-barrows (KD022-085----) c. 40m to the NW, (KD022-081---- and KD022-082----) c. 100m to the ENE, a large ring-barrow (KD022-042----) c. 70m to the SE and a second large ring-barrow (KD022-043----) c. 170m to the E. A very slightly domed, circular area (diam. 8.3m) is defined by a narrow, shallow fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.15m).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Near the top of a long, gentle N-facing slope and overlooked by two large ring-barrows (KD022-042---- and KD022-043----) c. 40m to the S and E. A second ditch barrow (KD022-081---- ) lies only 2.8m to the NE and a third (KD022-083----) lies c. 100m to the WSW; there is a fourth (KD022-085---- ) c. 140m to the WNW and a fifth (KD022-086----) lies c. 150m to the NW. Visible on aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A poorly preserved, very slightly raised, oval area (diams. c. 3m NE-SW; c. 7m NW-SE) is defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 2-2.5m; D 0.2m). Cultivation ridges, running N-S, abut the W limits of the monument and may be responsible for the creation of what looks like a low, outer bank (Wth. 2m; H 0.1m) SW-W-NW.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Near the top of a long, gentle N-facing slope and overlooked by two large ring-barrows (KD022-042---- and KD022-043----) c. 40m to the E and S. A second ditch barrow (KD022-082---- ) lies only 2.8m to the SW and a third (KD022-083----) lies c. 100m to the WSW; there is a fourth (KD022-085---- ) c. 140m to the WNW and a fifth (KD022-086----) lies c. 150m to the NW. Visible on aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A very slightly raised sub-circular area (diams. 7.3m NE-SW; 6.4m NW-SE) is defined by a narrow, shallow fosse (av. Wth 1m; D 0.2m). Cultivation ridges, running N-S, abut the E limits of the site.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Mid way down a long, gentle N-facing slope, overlooked by two large ring-barrows (KD022-042---- and KD022-043----) and two small ditch barrows (KD022-081---- and KD022-082----) c. 100m to the S; a third possible ditch barrow (KD022-083----) lies c. 180m to SSW, a fourth (KD022-085----) c. 180m to SW and a fifth (KD022-086----) c. 160m to WSW. Visible on aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A very slightly raised circular area (diam 4.5m; H 0.2m) is defined by a narrow, shallow fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.1m) SE-SW (upslope) and elsewhere by a low scarp (H0.2m).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a narrow, level terrace at the E foot of a short, gentle slope. Two large ring barrows lie 70m to the NW (KD022-043----) and c. 170m to the W (KD022-042----); seven barrows (KD022-044----, KD022-080---- to KD022-083---- and KD022-085---- and KD022-086----) lie in an arc W-NNE, less than 250m away, while a second group of six barrows (KD022-087---- and KD023-077---- to KD023-081----) lie between 200m and 400m to the SE. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). A very slightly raised, sub circular area (diams. 9.3m N-S; 8.9m E-W; H 0.3m) is defined by a narrow, shallow fosse (Wth 0.6-1.0m; D 0.15m) WSW-SE, and elsewhere by a low scarp (H 0.5m).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a long, gentle S-facing slope. The northernmost of a linear group of nine possible barrows (KD022-090---- to KD022-098----) with two more 'outliers' at the N (KD022-089----) and S ends (KD022-099----). Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). The group form a gently curving line (L c. 80m NW-SE) and all comprise small, low, circular, flat-topped mounds (basal diams. 4.9-6.2m; upper surface diams. 2.8-3.4m; H 0.1-0.2m), all (except the most southerly (KD022-098----)) defined by faint traces of a fosse (Wth 1m). They are not evenly spaced and lie between 2m and 20m apart.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a long, gentle S-facing slope. The second northernmost of a linear group of nine possible barrows (KD022-090---- to KD022-098----) with two more 'outliers' at the N (KD022-089----) and S ends (KD022-099----). Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). The group form a gently curving line (L c. 80m NW-SE) and all comprise small, low, circular, flat-topped mounds (basal diams. 4.9-6.2m; upper surface diams. 2.8-3.4m; H 0.1-0.2m), all (except the most southerly (KD022-098----)) defined by faint traces of a fosse (Wth 1m). They are not evenly spaced and lie between 2m and 20m apart.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a long, gentle S-facing slope. The third northernmost of a linear group of nine possible barrows (KD022-090---- to KD022-098----) with two more 'outliers' at the N (KD022-089----) and S ends (KD022-099----). Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). The group form a gently curving line (L c. 80m NW-SE) and all comprise small, low, circular, flat-topped mounds (basal diams. 4.9-6.2m; upper surface diams. 2.8-3.4m; H 0.1-0.2m), all (except the most southerly (KD022-098----)) defined by faint traces of a fosse (Wth 1m). They are not evenly spaced and lie between 2m and 20m apart.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Near the bottom of a gentle SE-facing slope. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). The most westerly of three closely associated monuments; a second (KD023-078----) lies c. 40m to the E and there is a third (KD023-078----) c. 50m to the SE. A very slightly raised circular area (diam. 6.5m; H 0.05m) is girdled by a narrow vegetation band of lusher growth (Wth 1m), suggesting a possible back-filled fosse.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On level ground immediately E of the linear earthwork, 'The Black Pig's Dyke' (KD023-037----). Two other possible barrows lie nearby; c. 18m to the ENE (KD023-079----) and c. 5m to the N (KD023-080----). Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). Comprises a small, slightly raised, circular area (diam. 7.2m) defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 1m).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On level ground immediately E of the linear earthwork, 'The Black Pig's Dyke' (KD023-037----). Two other possible barrows lie nearby; c. 20m to the ESE (KD023-079----) and c. 5m to the S (KD023-081----). Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). A small, partially overgrown circular area (diam. 6.4m) is defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 1m). The track of a footpath is visible crossing the W limits N-S and vehicle tracks run over the S limits.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On level ground immediately E of the linear earthwork, 'The Black Pig's Dyke' (KD023-037----). Two other possible barrows lie nearby; c. 20 to the WNW (KD023-080----) and c. 18m to the SW (KD023-081----). Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). A small, low, sub circular mound (diams. 3.7m NE-SW; 3.35m NW-SE; H 0.5m) with a flat top (diams. 2.2m NE-SW; 1.9m NW-SE) is girdled by a narrow fosse (Wth 1.7m; D 0.4m).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a very gentle S-facing slope. A small, almost totally overgrown, slightly raised, circular area (diam. 9m) is girdled by a vegetation band (Wth 1-1.5m) which may represent a back-filled fosse.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a low, narrow E-W ridge. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A sub circular area (diams. 9.4m E-W; 8.5m N-S) is defined by a very faint fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.2m) SW-NW, and elsewhere by a low scarp (H 0.2-0.4M).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on summit of Mt Oriel, to NW of LH020-005002- and LH020-005003-. Level, circular platform (diam. 11m, H 0.6m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.7-2m, D 0.1m externally). No trace of external bank. Slight depression in surface of platform would appear to be due to modern tree-root disturbance.

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on the summit of Mt Oriel, in an alignment with LH020-005001- to the NW and LH020-005003- to the SE. Circular, round-topped mound (diam. 22.5m, H 3m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 5.5m, D 0.5m) from NNE-E-SE, though faint traces of the fosse remain elsewhere (overall diam. 32m N-S). Halfway up the mound is a berm-like feature (Wth 1.5m-2m) but this may be due to landscaping.

Located at the bottom of a SE-facing slope in the flood-plain of the NE-SW River Bann with the stream c. 500m to the SE. Archaeological monitoring in advance of building new sewage works identified a ditch-barrow that was completely excavated (99E0450). It was a subcircular area (int. dim3.6-4.25m) with no internal features defined by a complete ditch (Wth 0.28m at NE to 0.9m at S; D 0.2-0.4m) with some stake-holes. Five cremated deposits representing seven individuals were in the ditch, underlain in some cases by burnt timbers, some of which had nails. Three of the deposits had grave goods, and up to fifty glass beads, a stone pendant, a scrap of bronze and a sherd of coarse pottery were recovered. C14 dates of 2090 +- 50 BP and 2190 +- 50 BP have been obtained. The pit (WX015-069----) is c. 20m to the S. (Ryan 2000b; 2012; Ryan and Henry 2000)       Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 2 May, 2012 Amended: 21 October 2020

Situated in the SW part of the interior of the henge (ME019-016001-) and just NE of the hut site (ME019-016002-). Archaeological excavation (E000090) recorded a circular area (int. diam. 4.5m) defined by a continuous ditch (Wth of top 1-1.1m; Wth of base 0.5-0.6m; max. D 1m), the base of which was lined with cobbles. The cobbles had been removed at NE where there was a hearth, and a sherd of Beaker pottery was found at the base of the ditch. At the centre of the enclosed area a pit (diam. 0.5m; D 0.3m) had a fragile flat-based pot resting on a slab and one sherd of another finer ware but human remains did not survive. (Sweetman 1971, 139-40; 1976, 35-37)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 10 July 2007 Amended: 28 January 2021

Archaeological monitoring (01E0047) of topsoil stripping on a development site c. 750m W of the South Slob of Wexford harbour identified several areas of archaeological activity (Elder 2003), each of which was fully excavated (02E0606). This is site 2 and consisted of a penannular ring-ditch (int. diam. 13.8m; ext. diam. 14.4m) defined by a trench (Wth 0.55-0.6m; D 0.12-0.32m) with an entrance gap (Wth 4.1m) at E. There was a cluster of features at the centre including a cremation burial that produced a C14 date of 390-170 Cal. BC, thirteen dispersed post-holes and stake-holes. A C14 sample from the trench provided a date of 410-10 Cal. BC (McLoughlin 2007, 6-11). The excavated prehistoric pits (WX042-091----) are c. 60m to the N. (McLoughlin 2004; 2007, 6-11; McLoughlin et al. 2012, 161-4)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 28 May, 2013

Archaeological monitoring (01E0047) of topsoil stripping on a development site c. 750m W of the South Slob of Wexford harbour identified several areas of archaeological activity (Elder 2003), each of which was fully excavated (02E0606). This is site 4/5 and consisted of a penannular ring-ditch (diam. 9m N-S; 8.5m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 0.5-0.75m; D 0.2-0.5m), with bulbous terminals and an entrance gap (Wth 1.7m) at SW. There were no internal features, but 60 sherds of pottery, some with cord impressed decoration in the Beaker tradtion, were recovered from the fosse. Fragments of a Food Vessel were recovered from a pit (dims 1.55m x 0.6-0.95m) c. 7m to the NE, but there was no evidence of a burial.  About 20m to the NE a group of nine features inculding small pits, some inter-cutting (dims c. 0.2m to 0.6-0.8m; D 0.06-0.16m), produced lithics of a Neolithic type, and this is confimed by fragments of shell that produced a C14 date of 3810-3650 cal. BC. Two E-W gullies (Wth 0.7-0.9m; excavated L 16m; max. D 0.55m: Wth 1.15m; excavated L 17m; D 0.4m) have a staggered junction separated by a gap (Wth 3.2m). They respect the ring-ditch, lying just to its S, and may be prehistoric. The prehistoric pits (WX042-091----) are c. 90m to the S and the hut-site at Strandfield (WX042-097----) is c. 150m to the NE. (McLoughlin 2004; McLoughlin 2007, 13-17).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 28 May, 2013

column1: BALLYBIN (Ratoath By., Cookstown Par.),COOKSTOWN (Ratoath By., Cookstown Par.)
column10: Situated on a shelf of a gentle N-facing slope. Archaeological testing (03E1316) by L. McGowan of Area 23 in advance of the N2 bypass of Ahsbourne identified and fully excavated (excavations.ie 2004:1176) a small circular area (int. diam. 1.7m) defined by a slight fosse (Wth 0.7m; D 0.28m) that had three fills with  varying qualities of silt. It is unlikely that that this small feature had a mound or bank, and its S half was cut by a modern NE-SW field drain (Wth 0.66m; D 0.26m). One small trimming flint flake was found, but the charcoal recovered was insufficient to provide a radiocarbon date. (McGowan 2008)Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 21 December 2021

Situated towards the bottom of a SW-facing slope with a canalised W-E stream c. 60m to the S. Archaeological excavation (03E1214) by H. Schweitzer between March and October 2004 in advance of the northern section of the N2 by-pass around Ashbourne on site 27 involved the complete excavation of six areas numbered from the S.  Features recorded in Area 2 included a kiln (ME039-012001-) but the principal feature is this ditch-barrow. (Schweitzer 2009, 14)This is a subcircular area (int. dims 3.4-3.9m; ext. dims 4.8-5.1m) defined by a U-shaped ditch (Wth of top 0.5-0.65m; average D 0.5m) with two principal deposits. The primary silt layer had a seam of charcoal which contained fragments of faience beads (O’Carroll et al. 2012, 228-32), and samples of the charcoal produced C14 dates of 900-825 Cal. BC and 740-360 Cal. BC. The former date, from a piece of oak, could represent ‘old wood’, and the latter date is a more realistic determination. One flint flake was recovered from the upper fill. There is no evidence of a mound or outer bank, or even of a burial. (Schweitzer 2009, 37-8)Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 3 March 2021

Situated at the top of a SW-facing slope with a low ridge extending off to the NW and a small W-E canalised stream or ditch c. 240m to the SW. Archaeological excavation (03E1214) by H. Schweitzer between March and October 2004 in advance of the northern section of the N2 by-pass around Ashbourne on site 27 involved the complete excavation of six areas numbered from the S with Area 6 on the NE side of the original N2.  Features recorded in Area 5 include this completely excavated ditch barrow with the barrows (ME039-015----) and (ME039-013----) c. 4m and c. 25m to the S and SSE respectively (Schweitzer 2009, 22).This is a circular area (int. diam. 6m E-W; 5.8m N-S) defined by a fosse of variable form (Wth of top 1-1.2m; D 0.3m at E to 0.5m at N). There were five major layers in the fosse which indicated a history of original construction as a ring-barrow, with a little silting followed by some cremated deposits in the fosse at N. Further silting separated these from a second deposit of cremations. The ditch was sealed with redeposited natural, which appeared to have come from the central mound.  A trench (dims 3m x 0.7m; D 0.3m) was subsequently dug into the fosse at N and filled with charcoal-rich deposits including burnt bone, although not confirmed as human. Some flint debitage and a pot boiler were recovered from this phase. Further re-cuts were made in the fosse with two more cremated deposits, one with an iron nail. Three pits c. 12m to the W, some with cremated bone are probably related to the ditch-barrow (ibid. 2009, 25-7). The barrow was re-used in the Iron Age when a crouched burial was inserted into the fills of the ditch at SSW. The grave-cut (dims 1.3m x 0.66m; D 0.55m) contained a single individual facing W. Grave goods consisted of three copper alloy toe-rings. It proved impossible to produce a radiocarbon date, but toe-rings have been found on comparable graves in Britain and a date of first century BC / AD can be suggested (ibid. 36-7).  Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 3 March 2021

Situated at the top of a SW-facing slope with a low ridge extending off to the NW and a small W-E canalised stream or ditch c. 240m to the SW. Archaeological excavation (03E1214) by H. Schweitzer between March and October 2004 in advance of the northern section of the N2 by-pass around Ashbourne on site 27 involved the complete excavation of six areas numbered from the S with Area 6 on the NE side of the original N2 road. Features recorded in Area 5 include this completely excavated ditch-barrow with the barrow (ME039-015----) c. 4m to the N, and barrow (ME039-013----) c. 20m to the SSE (Schweitzer 2009, 22).This is a circular area (int. diam. 2.15m; ext. diam. 5.75m) defined by the shallow remains of a fosse (Wth c. 0.8m; D c. 0.08m) that was filled with a silty sand which had occasional charcoal inclusions. There were no features within the ditch and no artefacts were recovered from this severely truncated monument (ibid. 25).  Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 3 March 2021

Situated at the top of a SW-facing slope with a low ridge extending off to the NW and a small W-E canalised stream or ditch c. 240m to the SW. Archaeological excavation (03E1214) by H. Schweitzer between March and October 2004 in advance of the northern section of the N2 by-pass around Ashbourne on site 27 involved the complete excavation of six areas numbered from the S with Area 6 on the NE side of the original N2 road.  Features recorded in Area 5 include two completely excavated ring-ditches (ME039-014----; ME039-015----) but only the SW half of this third barrow was excavated, the rest being cut by the present N2 road. (Schweitzer 2009, 22)This consists of a circular area (int. diam. c. 13m; ext. diam. 15.8m) defined by a continuous U-shaped ditch (Wth of top 1.45m; D 0.45m) with a stony base, but the ditch had been re-cut once. The primary fills of silt, sand and clay contained occasional pieces of burnt bone. The upper fills were similar but had greater amounts of both charcoal and burnt bone. Finds from the re-cut level included three hammer-stones, the point of a stone ard, a flint blade, a stone mould, lumps of slag and fragments of iron, including ring-loops and fragments of moulds (ibid. 37). No concentrations of human bone were noted, and nor was there evidence of a covering mound or an outer bank (ibid. 23). Two pits within and six in the vicinity are probably associated with its use, and many of these contained some fragments of burnt bone, although articulated animal bone was also present in one of the pits (Schweitzer 2009, 22-5).   Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 3 March 2021

Discovered prior to road construction (Excavation Licence No. 00E0430). Located immediately to W of a Bronze Age enclosure (LH024-063----) and just N of a cemetery (LH024-054----) and cremation pyre (LH024-055----). Consisted of an annular ditch (average Wth 0.4m; D 0.45m) with an external diam. of c. 9 m. Finds recovered included pottery, flint, possible slag and burnt and unburnt bone. (Chapple 2003, 267)  Compiled by: Claire Breen  Date of upload: 03 July 2013

Situated in the S quadrant of the Phoenix Park.  Cropmark of circular-shaped area (approx. int. diam. 15m) defined by a ditch visible on Google Earth orthophotograph taken 28/01/2017.    See attached orthophoto taken from Google Earth dated 28/01/2017Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien Date of upload: 22 May 2020

Situated in the S quadrant of the Phoenix Park.  Cropmark of circular-shaped area (approx. int. diam. 15m) defined by a ditch visible on Google Earth orthophotograph taken 28/01/2017.    See attached orthophoto taken from Google Earth dated 28/01/2017Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien Date of upload: 22 May 2020

Ditch-barrow in area 4A was excavated in 2020 under licence 17E0292 by Muireann Ní Cheallacháin for IAC Archaeology during construction phase of residential development by Cairn Homes PLC.  Monument was described as following; 'Ring-ditch was annular in plan with a 3.5m internal diameter and a depth of only 0.2m. The shallow nature of the ring ditch is possibly indicative of modern truncation though ploughing. C3 contained a main silty sand fill (C4) present throughoutthe length of the feature along with four primary charcoal deposits recorded along the base(C25, C37, C41 & C43). These primary deposits did not appear to contain any burnt bone inclusions. Two middle charcoal deposits (C6 & C21) did not appear to contain burnt bone either. Three definite discrete cremation deposits (C5, C10 and C42) containing frequent charcoal and moderate burnt bone inclusions were recorded directly above the main fill (C4). A possible heat affected flint chunk was retrieved from cremation deposit C42.  The cremation deposits were all shallow in nature which suggests they were deposited on the backfilled barrow ditch and were not contained in individual cremation pits.  A small shallow circular pit (C30) was recorded less than 1m to the east of the ring barrow and it contained a single silty sand fill with moderate charcoal inclusions. The function of pit C30 may be associated in some form with the ring barrow (C3), however no other features were recorded in the periphery of the ring barrow' (Ní Cheallacháin and Spencer 2020, 36-7).Compiled by: Caimin O’BrienDate of upload: 10 November 2020

In the middle of a level pasture field with restricted views. A circular area (diam. 7m) is enclosed by a bank of earth and stone (Wth 2.2m; H 0.45m) which is partially obscured by overgrowth. Some field clearance debris has been placed on and against the bank and in the uneven interior. There is a ring-barrow (CO127-047----) c. 3km to the NW.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 5' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2009).  Date of upload: 22 December 2009

In pasture, located below the crest of a N–S ridge, close to the E–facing slope. Nephin Mountain looms to SSW and the Nephin Beg range defines the skyline at S–W. Slightly raised, flat-topped circular area (13m E–W; 12.5m N–S) defined by remnants of a stony earthen bank (Wth 1.5m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.5m). The bank survives sporadically, in short, discrete sections, mainly where it has been protected by the roots of hawthorn bushes; elsewhere it is eroded to a low scarp (H 0.3m). It is poorly preserved. It may be the remains of a mound barrow; the diameter is small for a rath.  A short straight length of E-W bank (L 6m; Wth 1.2m; H 0.3m), with a hawthorn bush growing on it, lies 2.6m to S of the barrow. There is no indication that this curved around the barrow; it may be the remnant of a field fence.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 17 July 2019

In gently undulating pasture, located on a natural rise/low hillock. There are good views of the surrounding countryside, with the Ox Mountains stretching to SE, and the summit of Nephin Mountain visible to SSW. An embankment for a defunct branch-line of the Great Western Railway lies immediately to SW, truncating the base of the rise.   This possible embanked barrow is not indicated on the 1838 OS-6-inch map, but is shown on the 1929 edition. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 11m) defined by a low, sod-covered earthen bank (Wth 1.4m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.2m at SE). The bank appears to incorporate some stone. It is low and degraded, and at W–N is reduced to a scarp.   Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 2 May 2019

In pasture, located on a slight elevation in an area of lowlying grassland. There are good views, with the Partry Mountains visible on the far horizon to W.  This monument is not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch maps.  Circular, flat-topped earthen mound (diam. 15m E?W; 14.5m N?S; H 0.85m at E, 0.6m at W) enclosed at its base by a fosse (Wth c. 2m), which is evident now as a barely discernible depression. The top (diam. 5-6m) of the mound retains a hint of a raised rim or bank (Wth c. 2m) on the S arc, which gives it a slightly saucer-shaped profile.  A ringbarrow (MA118-052----) is located 250m to NE and there is an embanked barrow (MA118-079----) 300m to SE.  Attached images: MA118-172----_01.JPG Viewed from NW MA118-172----_02.JPG Viewed from E  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 19 March 2021

In level pasture. Circular raised area (9.9m N-S; 10.4m E-W; H 0.4m), enclosed by low earthen bank (H 0.3m).  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 39.  Date of upload: 13 December 2013

In generally level pasture, located on a slight rise in level pasture 40m S of the Glenreeor Owenmore River. There is rising ground to S.  Not indicated on the 1837-8 OS 6-inch map, but shown on the 1922 edition. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 10m) defined by low sod-covered bank (Wth. 2.5m; int. H 0.2; ext. H 0.7m) of earth and stone. The bank is somewhat eroded at N, and incorporates field clearance stones at NE-E. It is ringed with hawthorn and brambles.  This may be an embanked barrow, and in this light it is interesting to note a ringbarrow (MA031-013----) located on the opposite bank of the river lies c. 115m to NNW. However, it could also be the remains of a hut site.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy   Date of upload: 13 June 2018

Situated in level pasture. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 13m) enclosed by a low broad earthen bank (Wth 6.8m; int. H 0.3m). There is no fosse visible at ground level. From WNW-N-NNE the bank is absent. The original entrance is not recognisable.  Compiled by: Mark Keegan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, sited on an elevation with excellent views over rolling grassland and to SE over an expanse of rough wet ground.  This barrow is not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch maps. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 5-5.5m) defined by a bank (Wth c. 2m; ext. H 0.45m at SE, 0.65m at NW) with a low internal rim. A few large stones lying against the external face of the bank at SW are likely to be field clearance stones. The barrow is largely obscured by clumps of gorse and brambles. A ringbarrow (MA092-063----) is located 15m to SE.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 17 May 2022

In rough/average pasture, straddling the gentle N-facing slope of a rise. The slope dips into a natural depression of wet ground beyond which ground rises again to a low ridge on the top of which a ring-barrow (MA092-006----) is visible c. 250m to NNW. There is a farmstead 30m to SSW. A slightly raised, circular area (9m NE–SW; 8.5m NW–SE) defined by a bank (Wth 2.7m, int. H 0.55m; ext. H 0.35-0.4m at SW, 0.55m at NE) of earth and stone. The bank is most substantial on the E arc –it may have been incorporated into a now levelled field fence on this side. At W–NW it has a broad external slump. The interior slopes down gently to NE. Grass cover, with a clump of brambles in the centre, and hawthorn bushes on the perimeter. There is a mound (MA091-109----) 220m to E.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 17 February 2022

In improved pasture, located at break of slope on top of a rise on a NW–SE ridge with extensive views over the SW shore of Mannin Lake. Higher ground restricts views to SW–N. Depicted on the 1838 OS 6-inch map as a circular embanked enclosure (diam. 15-20m), and on the 1917 edition as a circular hachured feature (diam. c.10-15m). A circular mound (13 NE–SW; 14m NW–SE; H 1.4m at SW, 1.6m at NE) with a saucer-shaped profile. The top (7.6m NE–SW; 9m NW–SE) of the mound is defined by a slightly raised rim grading seamlessly into the gently concave centre. It appears to be predominantly earthen in construction, although some stone protruding randomly from the sloping sides. It is well preserved, grass-covered, with a few hawthorn bushes growing on the perimeter. A field wall on NW?SE axis lies immediately to SW.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 24 February 2022

On a slight rise in pastureland. Circular enclosure (diam. 18.5m), in fair condition, defined by a substantial bank of earth and stone. It has been levelled from E to SSE. The interior rises slightly towards the centre. Possibly a barrow. A quarry pit lies immediately to the S.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 17 June 2019

This site is located  east of Knappogue Castle in a large field used for pasture immediately beside the Sixmilebridge-Ennis road. The surface of the field in which the site is located is uneven with long curvilinear natural banks of earth distributed throughout. The site is depicted as a hachured plan on the OS 6-inch-sheets. The site which overlooks the gently sloping ground to the south consists of a broad ditchless bank defining a roughly level subcircular area 29m in diameter. The bank stands up to 0.5m above the interior of the site and measures on average 8.7m wide. A farm gate is located just south of the enclosure leading onto the road. The remains of a byre and some other small structures are built on the bank at the south. No features were discernible on the interior of the site and there were no indications of an original entrance.  Compiled by Geraldine Stout Date of upload: 14/03/2012

In undulating pasture, located on a ridge-top plateau, overlooked by the summit of the ridge immediately to SW. Good views, especially extensive to N–SE.Circular platform (6m N–S; 6.5m E–W; H 0.4m) defined on its outer edge by a slightly raised internal lip, which gives the interior (diam. c. 3m) a slightly sunken or saucer-shaped profile. There is a hint of a fosse-like depression (Wth 1.4m) enclosing the platform on its W half.Compiled by: Jane O’ShaughnessyDate of upload: 22 December 2021

In pasture, located on the top of a low NW–SE ridge with a fall of ground to NE and good views over the surrounding countryside.Slightly raised circular area or platform (diam. 7.5m N–S) defined by a low, raised internal lip/bank (Wth 2.3m at N, 2m at S; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.4m at N, 0.7m at S). The platform is compact and well defined; grass-covered, with hawthorn bushes grows on the bank at NE.Compiled by: Jane O’ShaughnessyDate of upload: 20 December 2021

In pasture, crowns the top of a low rise, in an area of undulating grassland with an expanse of wet land to NE. Views are good but not extensive.   A circular area (diam. 10-11m) defined by an earthen bank (Wth c. 2-2.6m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.4m). The broad, seamless inward slump of the bank produces the impression of a slightly concave interior. The bank is largely sod-covered but appears to be composed of stony earth, incorporating large stones in parts. There is a degraded section/break (Wth c. 2m) at SSE.  Grass-covered, with a single hawthorn at NE.  A mound barrow (MA093-012002-) is located slightly downslope c. 20m to W, and there is a standing stone (MA093-011002-) on a prominent ridge 550m to W.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 14 June 2022

Situated in level elevated pasture. The site was probably circular originally, one half of which has been removed. Surface remains now comprise a slightly raised D-shaped area (dims. 13.5m N-S; 9m E-W) enclosed by a broad bank of earth (Wth 6.5m-7.4m; int. H 0.3m). No fosse is visible at ground level. From N-E-S the bank is absent and the site is defined by a slight linear N-S scarp (ext. H 0.15m).  Compiled by: Mark Keegan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, on the NE-facing shoulder of a drumlin. This barrow was partially excavated by Keane and Farrelly (1993, 56; 1994, 71) in 1992 and 1993. It was described prior to excavation as a concave circular area (int. diam. 9m) raised slightly above the external ground level and enclosed by an earth and stone bank (Wth 1.4m; ext. H 0.6m); a gap (Wth 4m) was noted in the bank at E; faint traces of an external fosse were visible along the N arc; the interior sloped gently to E and the bank height diminished towards E (Keane and Farrelly 1993, 56). Excavation revealed that the bank and fosse continue all round and that the possible entrance at E was a worn down section of bank (Keane and Farrelly 1994, 71). An oblong pit (1.5m x 0.8m), containing a dump of stones in a charcoal-rich sandy clay was uncovered in the NE quadrant. A large modern pit (3.4m N-S; 3.8m E-W) was also excavated in the interior which truncated all the internal layers in the other cuttings (ibid.). No evidence for house structures was found which suggests that this was not a habitation site and this is supported by the continuous bank and fosse (ibid.). Finds included quantities of worked chert and a flint thumb scraper (ibid.). A radiocarbon date obtained from charcoal from the base of the bank places the construction of this barrow in the Iron Age (Farrelly and Keane 2002, 100). There is a mound barrow (SL039-010----) in the adjoining field c. 190m to S and a ring-barrow (SL039-011----) c. 230m to SE. A cairn (SL040-008----) on Kesh Corann Hill is visible in the distance to E. Listed by Farrelly and Keane (2002, 98).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, between drumlins. Described as an enclosure barrow (overall diam. 26.6m N-S; 28m E-W) with a concave interior surrounded by a broad enclosing bank (Wth c. 8m; H 0.8m) (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly). Where the bank was eroded a distinct coloured soil, similar to that in a nearby barrow (SL033-202----), was exposed. (Farrelly and Keane 2002, 98)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on a gentle SW-facing slope. A raised circular area (int. diam. 8.3m N-S; 8.9m E-W) with a concave interior defined by a rim (int. H 1m; max. ext. H 1.8m). A single tree grows on the S perimeter. Listed by Farrelly and Keane (2002, 98).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On the N end of a gravel ridge with restricted views to N and E and more extensive views to S and W. Described in 1995 (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly) as a barrow (original overall diam. 11m WNW-ESE), the S half of which is destroyed by quarrying and the E edge of which is truncated by a field boundary. The remains consist of an arc of bank (Wth 4.2m; ext. H 0.55m) W-E. The section of the interior visible in the quarry face showed that the barrow was composed of gravel and large stones covered by a layer of topsoil. A small V-shaped pit (diam. 0.25m; D 0.3m), filled with dark brown clay, was also visible in the exposed section. (Farrelly and Keane 2002, 98)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top of a natural rise. A circular area (diam. 3.4m) defined by an earthen bank (int. H 0.35m; ext. H 0.3m). A slight reduction in the height of the bank along the W arc may indicate an entrance. The inner face of the bank slopes gently down towards the interior leaving only a small level central area (diam. 0.65m). There is no trace of the fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.6m) which was evident along the N arc during a previous inspection (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly). Listed by Farrelly and Keane (2002, 98).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on a slight N-facing slope and on top of a low natural rise. There are excellent views in all directions except S-SW. A circular raised area (6m N-S; 6m E-W) defined by an earthen bank (int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.6m at S, 0.85m at N). The interior is concave due to the broad inner slope of the bank. There is a level area (diam. 1.8m) at the centre. The N half of the interior is raised to compensate for the natural slope. Listed by Farrelly and Keane (2002, 98).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On the crest of a low rise, at the SW side of Kesh Corann Hill. Described in 1995 (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly) as having a flat interior enclosed by a broad earthen bank (Wth 5.8m; int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.8m) with a gentle external slope and a steep internal slope. The overall diameter was 14m NW-SE. A gap (Wth 1.8m) was noted at E. Some stone retaining the internal face of the bank and the planting of trees may indicate re-use as a landscape feature. (Farrelly and Keane 2002, 98)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In rough pasture, on a level terrace at a break of slope at the NW end of a ridge. One of a linear cluster of barrows (SL040-130001-; SL040-131----, SL040-132----). There are excellent views though it is overlooked to NW by Kesh Corann Hill. A roughly D-shaped area (4.8m NW-SE; 4.3m NE-SW) defined SE-NW by a low bank (Wth c. 1.3m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.3m) with a shallow external fosse (Wth c.1m) intersecting at SW with the bank of the adjoining ring-barrow (SL040-130001-). Bordered on the straight NE side by a NW-SE field boundary. The field boundary is located on the break of slope on the NE side of the ridge and there is an abrupt steep fall of ground on its NE side. The field boundary is engulfed in dense brambles and it was impossible to determine to what extent it incorporates or truncates the barrow. There is a possible causeway (Wth 1.4m) across the fosse at SW where the bank is low, linking this barrow with the adjoining ring-barrow (SL040-130001-) though there is no corresponding low section in the bank of the latter. Listed by Farrelly and Keane (2002, 98).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On level ground in gently undulating pasture. Slightly raised roughly circular area (dims. 14m E-W; 13m N-S) enclosed by a low broad bank of earth (Wth 6.2m; int. H 0.15m). There is no fosse visible at ground level. The bank encloses the site on all sides and has a very uniform profile. There is no break in the bank to indicate the position of an entrance feature.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011
