In pasture, on top of a drumlin. A central concave area enclosed by a broad low bank (Wth 5.25m; int. H 0.75m; ext. H 0.6m) with traces of a concentric external fosse (max. Wth 2.2m; D 0.2m) evident NW-SW; the overall dimensions are 21.7m N-S and 20.5m E-W (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly). One of a group of four barrows (SL040-130001-, SL040-130002-, SL040-131----). Listed by Farrelly and Keane (2002, 98).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top of a drumlin. A raised circular slightly concave area (int. diam. 3.8m) enclosed by a stony bank (Wth 1.4m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 1.25m). A number of narrow gaps were noted in the bank. The barrow is overgrown with ferns.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In level pasture, near the SE end of a ridge. Views are good to excellent in all directions. A circular raised area (overall diam. 8.65m) defined by an earthen bank (int. H 0.25-0.35m; ext. H 0.55-0.65m). The internal face of the bank has a long gentle slope while the external face is much sharper. The bank is broken at S (Wth 3m) due to the collapse of a hawthorn tree which has left a small depression in it. The interior (diam. 3.5m) is level and clear of overgrowth.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In reclaimed pasture on the summit of a ridge (OD 680ft.) known locally as ‘Oileán na crú’.  Possible pond barrow (LI033-020----) 70m to SW and ringfort (LI033-023----) 45m to W. Depicted on OSi 25-inch map as a raised circular-shaped area (diam. 15m) with a trigonometric station in N quadrant.  Surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as a circular-shaped area (diam. 15m) enclosed by an earth and stone bank (Wth 4.65m; int. H 0.25m; ext. H 0.65m), with fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.2m) and outer bank (Wth 1m; int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.5m) visible from NW-S and WSW-WNW.  Gaps in outer bank (Wth 5m) at NNW and (Wth 4.5m) at SSW with causewayed entrance (Wth 1.7m) at ENE.  A rectangular-shaped depression in the interior may indicate the location of the former trigonometric station.  Truncated at W by a linear field bank running NNW-SSE. Described in 1960 as follows; ‘Interior 36 feet (11m) in diameter. A 5 foot (1.5m) wide ditch is encircled by an outer bank 9 feet (2.7m).  On east side there is a gap which may denote an entrance.  Interior of this earthwork is lower than field outside (O’Dwyer 1958-61, 115; Knockroe 54).  Monument is clearly visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 30 March 2021  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 133/03, 04 taken 23/08/2000 and 353/7 taken 05/01/2003.

On a knoll in a low-lying level landscape. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 6m N-S; 5.2m E-W) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 2.8m; int. H 0.1-0.3m; ext. H 0.3-5m) which is reduced to a scarp at N. There is an entrance (Wth 2.7m) at SE (max. ext. diam. 11.3m N-S; 10.8m E-W). Enclosure (RO021-063005-) is c. 30m to the SSW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On SE-facing slope, in pasture. A barrow (LI024-197----) lies 150m to SW and two barrows (LI024-219-/-220----) lie 170m to SE. Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a circular-shaped area (19m N-S x 17m E-W) defined by the intermittent remains of a bank (Wth 3.4m; int. H 0.35m; ext. H 0.55m) visible from NW-NNW-N, from ENE-E-S-SSW and at WSW, elsewhere reduced to a scarp.  Monument is visible as a circular-shaped partially scrub covered earthwork on ASI aerail photograph (ASIAP 310, 37) taken 13/09/2002.  Outline of degraded monument visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.See attached sketch plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI. See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 19 July 2020

In improved level pasture, defined by the upper edge of an old water course to the N. Identified on an aerial photograph (OS 2436/7). A raised sub-circular area (dims. 7.75m N-S; 6.95m E-W) defined by the remains of a shallow fosse (max. basal Wth 2.75m; max. overall Wth 5.45m; D 0.05m) from ESE-S-WNW. The N sector of the monument, at edge of a dry watercourse, appears to have been levelled during drainage works. The interior has a D-shaped depression (Dth c. 0.015m) off-centre to the S.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On the N-facing slope of a low E-W ridge. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 17.3m E-W; 16.6m N-S) defined by a broad earthen bank (Wth 4-5m; int. H 0.1-0.3m; ext. H 0.2-0.6m). There is no visible fosse or identifiable entrance (ext. diam. 22.2m N-S; 19.7m E-W). Rath (RO022-079----) is c. 180m to the SW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a gentle N-facing slope. Raised circular grass-covered area (int. diam. 4m E-W) defined by an earthen bank (Wth of base 4m; int. H 0.1-0.2m; ext. H 0.8-1m), and an outer fosse (Wth of top 6-6.6m; Wth of base 3-4m; D 0.2-0.4m) SW-N-SE. There is no visible entrance (max. ext. diam. 20m E-W).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked only on the 1914 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on top of a small, steep-sided knoll. D-shaped grass-covered area (dims 9.3m E-W; 5m N-S) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 4.8m at W to 5.6m at E; int. H 1m; ext. H 0.6-1m generally to 1.7m at N) WSW-N-ESE, the perimeter being quarried away elsewhere. There is no visible fosse or entrance. Kilcolagh church (RO010-073001-) is c. 80m to the S.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the summit of a broad hill. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 15m E-W; 14.3m N-S) defined by a slight earthen bank (Wth 3.5-4.5m; int. H 0.1-0.2m; ext. H 0.45-0.85m) but the perimeter has been disturbed NNW-SSE (ext. diam. 21.4m E-W; 19.8m N-S). Pond-barrow (RO035-077----) is c. 50m to the N and ring-barrow (RO035-076----) is c. 60m to the W.  See the attached aerial images taken from the NW (001) and W (003).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked only on the 1914 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on the crest of a low, steep-sided knoll. Circular grass-covered area (int. diam. 3.3m) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 2.5m at S to 4m at W; int. H 0.4-0.9m; ext. H 0.4-0.9m). There is no visible entrance, and the centre is obscured by field stones (ext. dims 8.4m E-W; 6.7m N-S).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level pasture within a small field that appears to have been a cultivated garden in modern times. Circular slightly raised area (diam. 16m) defined by an internal low broad earthen bank (overall Wth 8.5m; Wth at top 3.5m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 4m) with an external shallow flat-bottomed fosse (overall Wth 3.6m; Wth at base 2m; D 0.1m). From NE-SSW the bank is low and irregular appearing to be disturbed in parts. A modern field boundary skirts the external face of the bank NW-NE with a NNE-WSW orientated field bank linking to the external face of the bank at N. The fosse is not visible NW-NE and is shallow and irregular elsewhere. A break (Wth 1.7m) in the internal bank at SSW possibly marks the position of the original entrance. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved, generally level, wet pasture. A sub-circular area (dims. 14m NE-SW; 11m NW-SE) defined by the remains of a low bank (overall Wth 2.3m; Wth at top 0.6m; int. H 0.18m; ext. H 0.45m) at SW and NW, elsewhere the bank is reduced to scarp (Wth 0.85m; H 0.3m) and an outer fosse (Wth 2.35-2.45m; D 0.05-0.15m). The scarp and fosse have been straightened across the NE sector. The interior is generally level and is planted with blackthorn trees. There are numerous undulations across the field to SW and SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture, on a gentle S-facing slope, overlooking an old, rushy flood plain, c. 4m to SSW. A low, circular mound (dims. 3.85m NNE-SSW; 4m WNW-ESE) defined by scarp (Wth 1.35m; H 0.25m) and slight traces of an outer fosse in places. The interior has a shallow depression within. Monument identified during fieldwork in 2009.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a slight NE-facing slope. Circular grass-covered are (int. diam. 2.8m WNW-ESE) defined by a broad earthen bank (Wth 5.2-5.4m; int. H c. 0.6m; ext. H 1.4-1.6m) with some scrub. An outer fosse was filled in within living memory, but there are slight traces of it at S (ext. diam. 13.5m WNW-ESE; 13.4m NNE-SSW).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a low NW-SE spur with valleys to the SW and NE. Circular grass-covered area (int. diam. 4.7m ENE-WSW) defined by a broad earthen bank (Wth 5.5m-6m; int. H 0.65m-1m; ext. H 1.5-1.7m) with some scrub. There are slight traces of an outer fosse (Wth of base 1m; D 0.4m) SSW-WNW (max. ext. dims. 18.3m ENE-WSW; 15.8m NNW-SSE).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At a place called Abbots Hill on a NE-facing slope overlooking a NW-SE valley. Circular grass and furze-covered area (int. diam. 8.8m NW-SE) defined by a grass-covered earthen bank (Wth 2.8-3m; int. H 0.25-0.65m; ext. H 0.5-0.95m) with an entrance (Wth 1.7m) at WSW. An internal bank (Wth 2.7m; H 0.4-0.6m) running ENE-WSW, perhaps the result of quarrying, cuts off a chord at S.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a low knoll on a gentle SE-facing slope. Depicted as a circular enclosure with the designation 'Fort' on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. A circular area (diam. 5.6m), slightly dished in profile, enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth 2-3m; H 0.5m). A break (Wth 2m) in the bank at NNE may mark the original entrance. Two mature larch trees are growing within the interior. At ESE a large boulder (H 0.7m; Wth 0.8m; T 0.2m) may have served as a facing stone on the inner face of the bank.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 4 February 2012

In pasture, on a gentle S-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 28m N-S; 30m E-W) defined by bank (Wth 9m; int. H 0.6m; ext. H 2.4m), reduced to scarp (Wth 3m; H 1.8m) in places. External fosse (Wth 5m; D 1.25m). Interior is generally level and planted occasionally with mixed tree species. Abuts possible embanked barrow (TS070-072001-) to S, where the respective fosses of are separated by a level ridge (Wth 2.7m). No evidence of a causewayed entrance. Ringfort (TS070-070----) located 230m to NNW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, on a gentle S-facing slope. Circular area (diam. 29m) defined by gentle bank (Wth 6.5m; int. H 0.6m; ext. H 1.0m), reduced to scarp (Wth 2.3m; H 0.8m) in places. External fosse (Wth 6m; D 0.15m) is shallow yet consistent. Interior is generally level and is planted with mature deciduous species. Abuts possible embanked barrow (TS070-072----) to N, where the respective fosses of are separated by a level ridge (Wth 2.7m). No evidence of a causewayed entrance. Ringfort (TS070-070----) located 275m to NNW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On an ENE-facing slope in low-lying pasture. A raised circular area (diam. at base 9.8m) enclosed by a wide, low bank of earth and stone (Wth 5.5m; H 0.3-1.1m). From NE-E-SE the outer face of the bank has been modified and incorporated into a field boundary. A break (Wth 2.5m) at SSE marks the original entrance. A stepped barrow (LF015-037002-) is c. 5m to the N. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

At foot of S slope of Slievenamon mountain, in flat terrain, under pasture. Woodland to N of E-W field boundary. Raised oval area (diam. 15m N-S; 17.3m E-W) defined by a broad earthen bank (Wth 4.3m; int. H 0.28m; ext. H 1.86m) best preserved in SW quadrant and external fosse (Wth 3.5m; D 0.3-0.45m). Barrow has suffered from cattle erosion and root damage from trees growing on the bank. Fosse is not visible from SE-E-N. Field clearance dumped along edge of barrow in NE and SE sectors. Bank largely reduced to scarp in N sector.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on what is probably a rise in an undulating landscape. The parch-mark in grass of a complex enclosure is visible only on Google Earth (14/07/2019). What might be a small mound (diam. c. 10m) is surrounded by what could be a fosse and a wide outer bank (Wth c. 5-10m) which has a narrow outer fosse or drain. There are entrances through the bank at S (Wth c. 5m) and N (Wth c. 5m). It is within a D-shaped enclosure (int. dims c. 65m NW-SE; c. 55m NE-SW) defined by a fosse that has an entrance gap (Wth c. 3m) at NW but this fosse is largely missing (L c. 30m) on the SW side. It was first reported by Anthony Murphy and it was also reported by Jean Charles Caillere.   See the attached image from Google Earth 14/07/2018  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 5 June 2019

Located on a slight NE-facing slope. This monument is not depicted on any map but it can be seen on Google Earth (05/10/2009). It is a subcircular grass-covered area (dims 24m N-S; 21m E-W; int. diam. c. 10m) defined by a wide earthen bank (at N: Wth of base 15m; int. H 0.5; ext. H 0.6m) which is reduced to an external scarp (H 0.5m) at S. There is no visible fosse or entrance (ext. dim. 35m E-W).Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 22 November 2021

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007Raised circular area defined by slight remains of bank (diam. 8m) with slight traces of external fosse. No visible entrance.

Situated on elevated grassland with good views. Low roughly circular shaped earth and stone mound (approx. diam. 12m; H 0.3m) best preserved at W with some dumping of field clearance debris at E.  The centre of the mound appears to have a hollow depression but this feature was difficult to interpret due to the growth of nettles and other vegetation on the mound.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Chris Corlett  Date of upload: 21 July 2017

Excavated as part of the Dundalk Western by-pass project (Excavation Licence No. 03E0873). A mound (diam. 26m) with an external turf bank. No evidence for a ditch. A disturbed, stone-lined burial chamber was discovered in the centre. Only the northern half survived as the southern half was truncated by the Dublin-Belfast railway embankment quarry. Finds consisted of scattered cremated bone, a few sherds of encrusted urn, a copper alloy pin, four small copper alloy ornaments or fastenings and three pieces of struck/worked flint. Situated c. 50m to the S of a burial cairn (LH004-134001-) and c. 50m to the E of two ring barrows (LH004-134003- and LH004-134004-). (Bayley 2006, 340-1; Bayley 2005, 10)  References:  Bayley, D. 2005 M1 Dundalk Western by-pass site 127: Carn More 5 chainage 24.810-25.100 NGR: 304912 / 310860, Post-excavation assessment and project design on behalf of Louth County Council and the National Roads Authority Licence. Unpublished Report, DAHG 03E0873, Irish Archaeological Consultancy.  Bayley, D. 2006 Site 127, Carn More 5, Faughart Bronze Age cemetery. In I. Bennett (ed.), Excavations 2003: summary accounts of archaeological excavations in Ireland, 340-1 (No. 1275). Bray. Wordwell   Compiled by: Claire Breen  Date of upload: 18 November 2011

In pasture, on a gentle E-facing slope. A grass-covered, oval mound (7.65m NW-SE; 5.2m NE-SW; H 0.75m) of earth, gravel and stones. The top of the mound is relatively flat with a slight slope down to the SE. The slope at NW is longer and more gentle than elsewhere. Numerous stones are visible in the SE half. A rath (KE058-039----) lies c. 100m to the W.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

In pasture, located on a low rise in an area of rolling grassland bordered 200m to N by the Deel River. Immediately to SE is a large swallow hole (c. 50m N–S; c. 20m E–W), several meters deep, engulfed in overgrowth, which is named ‘Polldotia’ on the 1922 OS 6-inch map. Nephin Mountain is prominently visible to SSW and the Nepin Beg Range extends along the skyline to W. Circular mound or cairn (diam. 11.5-12m; H 1.85m at N) of earth and stone. It is largely sod-covered and densely obscured by gorse and brambles. A field wall, which lies immediately to W, and a modern road immediately to N, both appear to respect the curve of the mound. A post and wire field fence, on an E–W axis, stands at the S edge of the mound. There is a possible barrow (MA038-050----) c. 35m to S, and a cluster of ringbarrows and possible barrows and cairns (MA038-051----; MA038-052----; MA038-053001- to MA038-053003-) are located in adjacent fields within a range of c. 100-250m to NE, SE and S. There is a possible ringcairn (MA038-054----) c. 400m to S.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 15 August 2019

In pasture, at the junction of two field walls, located on a low rise in an area of rolling grassland bordered 200m to N by the Deel River. Immediately to NW is a large swallow hole (c. 50m N–S; c. 20m E–W), several meters deep, which is named ‘Polldotia’ on the 1922 OS 6-inch map. Nephin Mountain is prominently visible to SSW and the Nephin Beg Range extends along the skyline to W. This possible barrow is named ‘Ratheen’ on the 1922 OS 6-inch maps. It consists of a circular mound or cairn (9m E–W; 9.5m N–S; H 1.1m at E, 1.4m at W) of earth and stone. The mound is largely sod-covered and obscured by hawthorn, brambles, and on the S and W sides by a jumble of loose field clearance stones.  There is another possible barrow (MA038-146----) c. 35m to N, and a cluster of ringbarrows and possible barrows and cairns (MA038-051----; MA038-052----; MA038-053001- to MA038-053003-; MA038-146----) are located in adjacent fields within a range of c. 100-250m to NE, SE and S. There is a possible ringcairn (MA038-054----) c. 400m to S.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 29 July 2019

Ministerial Consent was granted to Coillte 09/08/17 in order to fell trees within the vicinity of two National Monuments (NM580) (CO141-013001- and CO141-013002-) at Skeagh, Skibbereen, County Cork. The monitoring brief was extended to the extant ring-barrow (CO141-145----) located c. 44m to N and the cairn (CO141-144----) c. 22m to S due to their proximity and probable association as satellite monuments to the larger cairn (CO141-013002-; NM 580) A previously unrecorded barrow was noted c. 2m to SE of the large cairn (CO141-013002-), at the edge of the unplanted exclusion zone. It is an oval mound (dims. 4.8m N-S; 4.1m E-W) of earth and stone defined by a scarp (H 0.35m) all around. There is no extant trace of a fosse or a bank. Vegetation cover is limited as this monument was previously obscured by a fallen tree.Compiled by Alison McQueen & AssociatesDate of upload: 29 January 2018

In pasture, in an area of undulating terrain on a broad headland flanked to NW by the Palmerstown River, to N by Rathfran Bay and to E by Killala Bay. Situated on top of a low knoll with a steep slope on the SE–SW. The knoll forms the ESE terminal of a low ridge on a roughly NW–SE axis, and provides extensive views: Nephin and the Nephin Beg range are visible at SSW–W, Bartragh Island and Killala Bay at E–SE, with the Ox Mountains in the background.  Circular, platform-like mound (overall diam. 10m; diam. top 7.9m) defined by a scarp (H 0.45m at N, 0.65m at S). There is a slight circular depression in the top of the platform, somewhat off-centre to NE. A small section of the external slope is eroded at the SW revealing a kerb-like concentration of small-medium sized stones at the base of the mound. Two large boulders, which are embedded in the top of the scarp at S, may be the result of field clearance. A berm-like plinth projects 2m from the base of the mound on the W side and 3m on the E side, giving the impression when viewing the E–W profile that the mound sits on a low platform scarped into the knoll slope. However, this berm-like feature does not appear to extend to the N and S sides of the mound, and may simply be the result of modern farm activity. There are a ringbarrow (MA015-035----) c. 100m to SSW and a mound (MA015-086----) c. 120m to N.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 13 December 2018

In marshland, overlooking Ballin Lough to NW. Circular earthen mound (H 2.3m; diam. 20.5m) presently covered by growth of grass.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, at the S end of Bartragh Island, prominently located on top of a natural knoll utilising the steep natural fall of ground on the S, W and NW sides.  At S the slope falls to the shoreline. There are excellent views S over the estuary of the River Moy and E towards Enniscrone and the S side of Killala Bay. Oblong flat-topped mound (c. 20.8m E–W; c. 16.5m N-S) defined at SE–N by compact, steeply sloping sides (H 3.65m at W, 2.6m at N), enhanced by the natural fall of ground, and on the E side by a lower but well-defined scarp (H 1.4m). The top (8.4m E–W; 5m N–S) of the mound is flattened, although when seen from a distance, particularly from W and SW, it appears as if gently domed in profile. There are slight grass-covered depressions or hollows at the edge of the mound top at SW and at N, possibly as a result of past disturbance. Medium to large-sized stones protrude randomly from the sod covering on the mound, particularly on the mid to lower levels of the S–W slope. A sloping terrace or berm-like feature is evident enclosing the base at S–NW but this may be a natural undulation. There is a cup-marked stone (MA022-118002-) embedded in the sod surface on the W half of the flat top.   Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 19 September 2012

In a housing estate on the outskirts of Ballina town. Originally situated on a low knoll, providing good views of the surrounding undulating landscape, with the Ox Mountains defining the far horizon to the SE, and Nephin Mountain prominently visible to SW. The confluence of the River Moy with its tributary the Brusna River is located 700m to SW.  In 2007 this mound barrow was archaeologically tested in advance of a housing development (Fitzpatrick and Rooney 2007; 070E0627), and it was subsequently fully excavated (Wallace 2018; 070E0627 extension). Following the excavation, the knoll on which the barrow was sited was completely removed. Prior to excavation, the barrow consisted of a circular earthen mound (diam. 12m E-W; 13.8m N-S; H c. 1mm) defined by a scarp. The scarp (H 0.8m at E; 0.7m at W) was lower, and broadly slumped on the N half, but was significantly steeper (H c. 1.7m) at S where it was enhanced by the natural fall of ground. The top of the mound (diam. 9m E-W; 10.8m N-S) was relatively flat, but an almost seamless break of slope with the scarp gave it a gently domed profile when viewed from a distance. An ash tree and a whitethorn tree were growing on the eastern side of the mound, and their root systems disturbed the stratigraphy of the mound. Excavation revealed that a fosse (Wth 0.40-0.50m; D 0.30-0.40m) curved around the mound at NW?E; it could not be traced on the steeply sloping S side, where there was much scree and mudstone bedrock. It was difficult to investigate and record as it had been partly truncated by works associated with the housing development.  Beneath the topsoil, the mound was covered by a layer (D 0.3-0.4m) of mid-brown silty clay, incorporating a high concentration of medium-large stones, and an array of artefacts (pottery, iron nails, a clay pipe stem and lumps of mortar) dating to the modern era. Beneath this, there was a distinctive layer (0.10-0.40m) of yellow-orange, fine sand, which spread over the top of the platform, and in parts extended into the fosse. A large, flat slab was centrally located within this layer. The surface of the slab was covered by a lens of charcoal and ashy material, and surrounding the slab were several patches of charcoal and scorching, as well as heat-shattered granite rocks. The slab rested on a layer (D 0.15m) of loosely compacted, grey-brown silt, underneath which was a subcircular pit (diam. c. 1.2m; D 0.50m), with uneven sides, roughly lined with stones. A piece of worked flint and tiny fragments of burnt bone were recovered from the pit fill. Intense scorching around the pit suggested that this was the location of a cremation pyre; a small channel on the NW side of the pit may have been where a bellows was used to increase temperatures. Three other roughly circular pits were found beneath the yellow sandy layer on the S side of the mound, one of which contained fragments of pottery. The pottery was identified as a rim and neck sherd of a slightly open, shouldered or carinated bowl of the Western Neolithic Tradition, belonging to an early stage within the tradition, with a date centred on 3700 BC thought likely (Dr. A. L. Brindley, in Wallace 2018, Appendix 2). The finds assemblage also includes a flint scarper and a fragment of worked flint, which were recovered during the initial test excavation (Fitzpatrick and Rooney 2007, 17 & 19). A charcoal sample from one of the pits produced a radiocarbon date in the late Neolithic period of 2880-2580 BC (95.4% probability). The Neolithic date for activity at this site is particularly interesting, as barrow type monuments are known to date in the main to the Bronze Age and Iron Age periods. (Wallace 2018).  Attached image: MA030-093----_01.JPG prior to excavation, viewed from N MA030-093----_01.JPG prior to excavation, viewed from W  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy   Date of upload: 21 June 2018

This mound barrow was evident as a low, circular grass-covered mound when in 1937 it was quarried for sand and stone for road building. During the quarrying, a cremated burial with food vessel was exposed. Further burials were uncovered in 1939. The National Museum subsequently undertook an excavation of the barrow, approximately half of which had already been disturbed or destroyed (Raftery 1960, 79-93). The excavation revealed that the barrow (diam. c. 13m; H c. 1m) consisted of a circular mound (H c. 0.6m) of brown sandy soil on top of which, slightly to N of centre, there was a cairn of stones. The cairn was defined by a U-shaped setting of kerb stones. Underlying the barrow were nine graves -five pits or possible pits and four cists -which were built on or dug into the underlying subsoil. In all, the pits and cists contained the cremated remains of thirteen, possibly fourteen individuals, two of which were children. It was not possible to determine the gender of the remains. Food vessel pots accompanied the cremations in five of the graves. The evidence suggested that all the burials had been deposited at the same time, and then covered by the mound barrow. The excavator interpreted the remains as a Bronze Age cemetery (Raftery 1960, 90)  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 25 May 2020

In gently undulating, improved pasture, crowning the top of a low hillock, which provides extensive views, with the Ox Mountains dominating the skyline to E and SE.  This possible mound barrow is not shown on the 1837-8 and the 1922 OS 6-inch maps. It consists of a low, degraded circular mound (10m N-S; 9m E-W), with a flattish top, defined by a slight scarp (H 0.3m), which is barely distinguishable from the natural slope. A slab (Wth at least 0.55m; T 0.1m) protruding from the top of the mound at NE. The mound is known in local tradition as an ancient gravesite. There is a ringbarrow (MA031-069----) 150m to SW.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy   Date of upload: 5 July 2018

Situated on a gentle N-facing slope overlooking the Atlantic Ocean. Not marked on the 1837 edition of the OS 6-inch map. Small, low, circular, flat-topped mound of earth and stone (diam. 6.75m) defined from W-N-NNE and at ESE by a scarp faced with large stones or boulders (H 0.8m). Elsewhere the perimeter has been levelled and only its outline is identifiable. At the centre of the top of the mound is a large boulder.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, on a flat terrace at the summit of a ridge, close to the break of slope at SSW. Excellent views generally, but especially SW–NW along the valley of the Trimoge River. Trees and high fences restrict views now to NW along the spine of the ridge. A circular enclosure, with a small circular feature in the centre of the interior, is shown on the 1838 OS 6-inch map; it is not shown on later map editions.  Domed circular mound (16.8m NNE–SSW; 17.2m WNW–ESE; H 2.1m at SSW 1.5m NNE), with a narrow, flattened top (diam. c. 5m) and broadly sloping sides. The mound appears to be earthen. A gap of 4-6m separates the mound from the edge of the terrace at SSE–SW, where there is a sharp break of slope and a steep fall of ground (H 3-4m). This siting makes the mound prominently visible from the S. The mound is boxed into a small modern rectilinear field. A grassed-over sunken track extends along the NW side of the field, leading to a disused sandpit in the extreme SW corner of the field (c. 10m W of the mound). A telegraph pole stands immediately to E of the mound.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy
column13: Date of upload: 19 August 2021

column10: On a rise in flat marshland. Described by McCaffrey (1952, 20, 139, no. 8a) as 'the remains of a tumulus' that may have belonged to the barrow class of monuments. It comprised an almost circular mound ‘58 feet by 55 feet ... maximum height of 4 feet 6 inches [17.6m by 16.7m; H 1.4m]’ with kerb consisting of ‘a simple ring of limestone slabs placed on edge’. No visible surface trace survives.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 November 2019

On a gentle S-facing slope in pastureland. An oval flat-topped earthen mound (9m NW-SE; 8m NE-SW; H 0.85m), in fair condition, is clipped by a N-S running field wall at W. Rynne (SMR file) suggests that it may possibly be a barrow.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 30 July 2019

In a coniferous plantation, on the S slopes of the Ox Mountains and c. 50m W of a stream. An oval earthen mound (7m N-S; 8.1m E-W; H 1m) with a central rectangular hollow (2.2m N-S; 4m E-W), the sides of which are revetted by drystone-walling. A few trees have been planted on the mound. There is a rath (SL031-018002-) immediately to S.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on the E side of a low NW-SE ridge in undulating pasture. Circular, steep-sided, flat-topped mound (diam. at base 18.3m, at top 4.8m; H 3m) of earth and stone. A portion of the top of the mound has been dug away at W. There is also some disturbance to the side of the mound at S. A modern, but disused, trackway curves around the mound at W and N.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011
In small clearing in forestry atop Monteen Hill. Circular earthen mound (H 1.55m; diam. 10.9m) enclosed on top (diam. c. 5m) by low earthen bank E-
column13: N giving appearance of depression in centre. Investigated by Windele in 1842 (O'Mahoney 1909, 215-217) who describes hollow on top (2.5 feet deep and 11 feet diameter) and 'broken range of 25 stones' (diam. 35 feet) barely protruding above ground level around base. Tunnel was dug from E side and abandoned when 'no kist or remains of any kind' were found.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pasture, on a gentle NW-facing slope. A low circular mound (diam. c. 8.5m; H 0.4m). A ditch barrow (SL037-101----) lies c. 12m to NNE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, located in a lowlying hollow, on the S border of a tract of wet, marshy ground. Low, subcircular earthen mound (10.5m N-S; 9.3m E-W; H 1m at W, 1.15m at E). The top of the mound (6.6m N-S; 5.4m E-W) is level. No evidence of an encircling bank or fosse.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture on a slight NNW-facing slope with moderate to good views in all directions. Located 110m SW of the River Maigue and the townland boundary with Castleroberts, ringfort (LI021-083----) 450m to SSE. The site is depicted as a circular enclosure on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map.  Shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a raised area defined by a sloping bank (ext. diam. 25m). Inspected by the ASI in 2000 when it was described as a raised oval-shaped area (int. diam. 14m NNW-SSE; 10m ENE-WSW) defined by an earthen scarped edge with an external fosse (Wth 4.1m; int. D 1.1m; ext. D 0.3m) only visible at N and W. The interior is dry and clear of overgrowth. Trees located on the edge of the monument are visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018 and 14/02/2020.See attached sketch plan surveyed and drawn by the ASI and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 12 August 2020

In pasture, on top of a low rise. A grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 7.5m; H 1.5m), partially poached by cattle. A trigonometrical station was indicated on top of the mound on the 1914 OS 6-inch map. A circular enclosure (SL037-043001-) lies c. 100m to SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated at the E edge of a NW-SE ridge in rough pasture. Remains comprise a circular mound (diam. 11.8m N-S; surviving H 0.6m) whose centre has been quarried out (D of quarry hole 1.5m) leaving a ring (Wth. 2m) of mound material around the perimeter. Probably the remains of a barrow. There is rath (SL012-093001-) c. 20m to ENE.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In level wet pasture with poor views in all directions. Located 600m NE of the River Maigue and the townland boundary with Ballynahown. On the demesne lands of Caherass House located 625m to SW.  Woodland plantation annotated 'Brickfield Wood' shown on Cassini OSi 6-inch map 20m to W.   Ringfort (LI021-093----) 85m to S. The site is first depicted as a small scarped mound on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map (ext. diam. 13m N-S; 15m E-W). Inspected by the ASI in 2000 when it was described as a roughly circular-shaped earthen mound (int. diam. 10m) defined by a scarped edge with external fosse (Wth 9m; base Wth 3.5m; int. D 0.65m; ext. D 0.2m). The mound is highest on N side where it survives as a D-shaped mound tapering gently to the S and more steeply to the N. The fosse is wider and better preserved at the N that at the S side.   The monument is clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018 and 14/02/2020.See attached sketch plan surveyed and drawn by the ASI and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 16 August 2020

Some 70m to the W of a rath (GA104-065----). Classified by McCaffrey (1952, 18, no. 149) as a tumulus and described as being 'circular; overall diameter 55 feet; 2 feet 7 inches in height [diam. 16.8m; H 0.7m]'. He also noted the presence of 'stone slabs indicative of a cist'. No visible surface trace survives.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 11 November 2019

In rough pastureland. Classified by McCaffrey (1952, 17-18, no. 87) as a 'Simple, round, flat-topped' barrow which was circular in plan with an 'overall diameter 44 feet; height 3 feet [diam. 13.4m; H 0.9m]'. He also noted that the top of the grass covered mound, with a 'diameter of 33 feet [c. 10m]', was markedly flat. On inspection in March 1983 and on re-inspection in October 2001 the mound was densely overgrown with briars and thorn bushes making it impossible to examine the monument in detail. Based on McCaffrey's details it is possible that this is a mound barrow.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 November 2019

Situated on level summit of Sheeanmore Hill in pasture, with extensive views in all directions. The monument consists of a flat topped oval mound of earth and stone (dims. 4m N-S; 3.3m E-W; H 0.8m). There is no fosse visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Mark Keegan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

On a gentle E-facing slope in grassland. Known locally as ‘Muilleann Sidhe’ (McCaffrey 1952, 251, no. 51). This roughly circular flat-topped mound (diam. 6m; H c. 1m) is revetted by a single course of large limestone blocks at its base. The E sector has been disturbed and some bone (human?) projects through the soil. McCaffrey (ibid., no. 51a) also located a house to this spot - see GA104-267002-.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 November 2019

In pasture, on top of a ridge. A low circular mound (diam. 7m at base, c. 3.5m at top; max. H 0.6m) with a slight central depression. There is a local tradition of 'burials' in the mound.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on a slight SW-facing slope in gently rolling pasture. Circular mound of earth and stone (diam. of base; 13m; diam. top 1.6m; H 1.7m). The mound is roughly conical in shape. There is no fosse visible at ground level  Compiled by: Mark Keegan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, at a break of the W-facing slope of a ridge. A flat-topped circular mound of sod-covered earth and stone (diam. 22.1m at base, 11m NNE-SSW at top; H 1.5m). About one third of the W edge and a portion of the base of the mound at NNW have been quarried away. Two contiguous boulders have been exposed by quarrying at the base of the mound at NNW. A few stones protrude intermittently along the perimeter of the top of the mound N-E. A circular sod-covered rise (diam. c. 4m; H 0.5m) from which some large stones protrude, is evident on top of the mound close to the quarry edge at W. A rough line of stones skirting the base of the mound along the E edge may be field-clearance stones.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In rocky pasture, on a slight rise 7m S of a stream. A circular flat-topped mound (diam. at base c. 7m, at top 5m; max. H 1.2m) with a stone kerb (H 0.5m) evident SW-N. The mound is highest NE-SE where it merges with a natural break in slope but is low (H 0.5m) elsewhere. On the flat top of the mound are two roughly parallel lines of stones (long axes NW-SE), c. 2m apart. The NE line consists of two contiguous slabs (NW stone L 1.4m; Wth 0.24m; H 0.1m, SE stone L 0.95m; Wth 0.12m; H 0.15m). The SW line consists of one prominent stone (L 1m; Wth 0.12m; H 0.4m) at the NW end and at least five smaller barely discernible stones. A hawthorn tree grows on the perimeter of the mound at S.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Located on the narrow summit of a steep-sided hill which rises on the S side of a promontory jutting into the Atlantic. The hill provides extensive views, including Ben Bulbin and the Dartry Mountains at ENE-E, and Knocknarae and the Ox Mountains at SE–S. To W and NW there are views out to sea. Sod-covered, circular mound (overall diam. 7-8m) with a flat top (diam. 2-2.5m) and broadly sloping side (H c. 1-1.2m). An E-W earth and stone field bank (Wth 1-1.2m; H 0.5m), topped with post and wire fencing, overlies the mound to S of centre. There is an upright, concrete trigonometrical station on a concrete base on the flat top of the mound, immediately to N of the field fence. A slight depression is evident at the base of the mound at SE and also at W. The mound barrow is not shown on the 1837 and 1913 OS 6-inch maps, but the location is marked on both maps as a trigonometrical station. There is a promontory fort (SL007-001001-) c. 400m to NW.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy   Date of upload: 25 February 2014

In pasture, just below the top of a ridge on a gentle W-facing slope and in a slight natural depression. A circular platform (8.4m N-S; c. 9m E-W) defined by a low scarp (H 0.65m). There is a shallow surface depression (3m E-W; 2.4m N-S) on the top of the platform at W. The siting of this barrow on a slight slope gives the impression of a fosse-like dip (Wth c. 3m) between it and the rising ground N-E. Rushes and occasional small clumps of brambles and gorse grow on and around it. It is indicated on the 1838 OS 6-inch map.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top of a rise. A circular mound (diam. 11.5m NE-SW; 11.7m NW-SE; max. H 1.9m) crossed off-centre to NE by a NW-SE field boundary and drain. The top of the mound (diam. c. 4.5m) is level and has a central rectangular depression (1.4m NE-SW; 2.8m NW-SE; D 0.5m). A level area (Wth 2m) at the base of the mound SW-NW is defined by a slight scarp.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In the W half of the interior of a large oval enclosure (SL038-019001-). A low oval earthen mound (13m N-S; 11.9m E-W; H 0.3m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, at the SW end of a low ridge. A low roughly circular flat-topped mound (overall diam. 23m N-S; 25.7m E-W; diam. at top: c. 12m N-S; c. 14m E-W; H 1.25m) with broadly sloping sides. A trackway truncates the mound along the S edge.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on the summit of a ridge with excellent views of the surrounding countryside, the Ox Mountains to NE and Knocknashee Hill to SW. Indicated on the 1914 OS 6-inch map as a small circular mound. It is now evident as a roughly D-shaped mound (diam. c. 9m) of uneven height with a straight E side (H 1.4m). The S edge of the mound is almost vertical (H 0.7m) while on the W and N edges the slope is broader (max. H 1.8m). The top of the mound slopes down to E though there is a level area (Wth 2m) towards the S and SW. The mound is covered in long grass. A small heap of stones was noted c. 4.6m to E. A gently curving scarp (H 1.1m), c. 3m to S, extends W for several metres towards an adjacent field boundary. A rath (SL025-062----) lies c. 80m to NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 28 October 2011

In undulating pasture, on a slight rise c. 30m NE of Fin Lough. An oval grass-covered mound (18.4m NW-SE; 25.3m NE-SW) with broadly sloping sides NE-S and a steeper slope (H 1.8m) SW-N. The flat top encompasses an area c. 5m NW-SE and 12m NE-SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top of a drumlin. A flat-topped earthen mound (diam. 19.5m at base, 12.5m at top; H 0.95m). According to local tradition, a gallows once stood on the mound. A single fixed stone on top of the mound is all that remains of a cruciform setting of stones which was noted (pers. comm. M. A. Timoney) in 1989.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on a very slight rise in gently undulating pasture. Natural ground level falls away from the site on the NE side. Oval flat-topped mound (dims. top 4.5m NW-SE; 2.5m NE-SW; base 10m NW-SE; 7.5m NE-SW; H 1.2-1.6m) of earth and stone. There is no fosse visible at ground level. The mound is sod-covered and clear of overgrowth. According to Timoney (1984, 322, no. 1) 'There is a local belief that this barrow may be of nineteenth century date.’  Compiled by: Mark Keegan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In rolling pasture, on top of a drumlin, with ground sloping away sharply to N, S and W. Indicated on the 1914 OS 6-inch map as a mound in the SW corner of a field. Remains consist of a roughly semicircular raised area (12m N-S; 16m E-W) defined by a scarp (H 0.5m) N-SSE and truncated by field boundaries on the SW and NW sides. No remains of the mound are visible at ground level on the S or W sides of the field boundaries. A large flat boulder is embedded in the SE side. A rath (SL039-114----) lies c. 12m to E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Straddling summit of a slight E-W orientated ridge, in gently undulating pasture, on Oyster Island between Coney Island and Rosses Point. Originally circular but now consists of a roughly D-shaped, flat-topped mound (dims. top 6m N-S; 5m E-W; base 12.2m N-S; 11.6m E-W; H 1.45m) of earth and stone. There is no fosse visible at ground level. The mound is best preserved NW-SE where it has regular gently sloping sides. From SW-NW the edge of the mound has been removed leaving a steep modern crescent shaped cut. From SE-SW the edge of the mound has been eroded to form a level terrace (max. Wth 1m) half way down the side.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

Situated on poorly drained, partially reclaimed rushy pasture, that was formerly the floodplain of the Camoge River.  This stream flows from N to S immediately to the E.  A post-1700 linear drainage channel to W is visible as a cropmark on aerial photographs and on the revised edition of the OS 6-inch map.  One of five mounds recorded as feature G01F003 in 2012 LiDAR Survey (Motherway 2012, 77, 276).  Four mounds or possible barrows (LI022-258-/59-/60-/61) are visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-12.  On this aerial photograph the three possible barrows are roughly aligned on a NW-SE axis.Earthwork visible on OSi aerial photographs taken 2005-2012, present remains consist of a low circular-shaped mound immediately E of a post-1700 field drainage ditch.  Original watercourse of the Camoge River can be seen closer to the possible barrows on OSi aerial photographs 2005-2012.  This possible mound barrow is not visible today on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-2013.See attached LiDAR plot showing location of 5 mounds and OSi aerial orthophotos showing location of 3 possible barrows.Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Sarah McCutcheon and Ella MotherwayDate of upload: 29 April 2020

In rough pasture, on the crest of a drumlin, with commanding views. A circular flat-topped grass-covered mound (diam. 15.5m N-S; H 2.25m) with some stones visible on its surface; the upper part of the mound has indications of quarrying (pers. comm. J. Farrelly and M. Keane). An embanked barrow (SL039-009----) lies c. 190m to N and a ring-barrow (SL039-011----) c. 170m to E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In rolling pasture immediately E of a field boundary.  Present remains consist of a raised sub-circular shaped mound (dims. 11.6m N-S X 5.3m E-W; H 0.8m) with a gentle slope to N, S and E froming a platform in the centre.  Limestone outcropping throughout.  Earthwork is not visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 19/11/2019.Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate upload: 29 June 2020

In flat undulating pasture. A grass-covered gently sloping oval mound (dims. 41.1m x 17m; H 1.6m) which has been quarried into at W.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In flat pasture, c. 250m E of the Owenmore River. A circular mound (22.5m E-W; H 4.4m) slightly levelled out towards the top with a short step up to a flat-topped crest; a considerable amount of material has been quarried from the SW quadrant (pers. comm. J. Farrelly and M. Keane). Most of this monument was removed in the course of land reclamation undertaken in early 2008.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Revised by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 22 February 2008

In tillage, on N-facing slope. One of a group of four tumuli (11819, 11821, 11822) in field to S of burial ground (14062) and cist (11935). Roughly circular earthen mound (13m N-S; 17m E-W; H 1.82m); partially levelled.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In tillage, on N-facing slope. One of a group of four tumuli (11819, 11820, 11822) in field to S of burial ground (14062) and cist (11935). Roughly circular earthen mound (13m N-S; 10m E-W; H 0.4m); partially levelled.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In tillage, on gentle S-facing slope. One of a group of four tumuli (11819, 11820, 11821) in field to S of burial ground (14062) and cist (11935). Roughly circular earthen mound (18m N-S; 12m E-W; H 0.3m); partially levelled.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture recently planted with oak trees, on N-facing slope. One of a group of four tumuli (11820, 11821, 11822) in field to S of burial ground (14062) and cist (11935). Oval mound of earth and stone (11.4m NNW-SSE; 6.8m E-W; H 0.92m), tapering to tail at S end.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

One of a cluster of 6 barrows (LI014-163/164/155001/155002/156----) in wetland, located to the immediate SE of large barrow (LI014-155001----). Identified as a possible mound barrow (diam. 11.5m; H 1m) by Melanie McQuaid, archaeologist, Forestry Service, Dept of Agriculture, Food and the Marine in 2016 during site inspection of drains and removal of forestry saplings. Described in 2016 as following; ‘The mound has been cut by one forest drain and at the time of inspection no archaeological material was evident in the drain face or the mounds created from the excavated soil’ (McQuade 2016). The monument is visible on the Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and the Google Earth image taken in 2006 and 2018.  See attached Google earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 3 July 2020
Identified from aerial photographs on Bing Maps (www.bing.com/maps/) and Google Earth as a possible mound barrow.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 20 June 2013

On the W-facing slope of a drumlin. A circular mound (9.5m N-S; 9.8m E-W) with a max. H of 1.5m on the downslope side and a min. H of 0.4m on the upslope side. The top of the mound is uneven with some stones protruding and at the centre the surface has either collapsed or been dug into.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, between a farmyard and a house. An oval earthen mound (18m x 13m; H 2m) with large stone slabs lying on its surface. Mature trees grow on top of the mound.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On a break of the W-facing slope of Kesh Corann Hill. A flat-topped oval mound (Wth 9.8m; max. H 1.45m) truncated by a road at E and dug into at W.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On the top of a drumlin. An oval flat-topped mound (12.2m N-S; 10.8m E-W; max. H 2m) with steeply sloping sides.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In level tillage. Circular grass-covered earth and stone mound (11m N-S; 12m E-W; H 2.1m). West side sprawls outwards, possibly the result of quarrying. Known locally as "Lios". Flint scraper found nearby.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In reclaimed pasture, immediately S of a watercourse. Enclosure (LI040-030----) lies 65m to N. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a circular-shaped mound (diam. c. 12m). Identified by archaeologist Edmond O’Donovan in 2015 from examination of aerial photography.  Visible as a grass-covered mound on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages, where it is intersected at E by field boundary running NW-SE.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 28 July 2021

In pasture. A flat-topped circular mound (diam. 26m; H 2.1m) with gently sloping sides (pers. comm. M. A. Timoney).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top of a low rise. A circular mound (7m NE-SW; 7.4m NW-SE) defined by a scarp (H 0.6m) kerbed with sod-covered upright stones. The kerbstones are mostly contiguous or close-set, though there are some gaps and a few project slightly above the level of the mound. The top of the mound is slightly sunken. Conjoined at NE is another mound (SL040-149002-). The junction of the two mounds is barely perceptible and is marked by two kerbstones which barely project above the sod. The S and SE edges of both barrows are obscured by overgrowth.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Revised: P. Walsh  Date of revision: 30 April 2009

In pasture, on top of a low rise and conjoined to the SW edge of another mound barrow (SL040-149001-). A circular mound (4.8m NE-SW; 5m NW-SE; H 0.65m) with a gently domed profile, defined by a gapped kerb of upright stones (H 0.4-0.5m). The junction of the two mounds is barely perceptible and is marked by two kerbstones which barely project above the sod. The S and SE edges of both mounds are obscured by overgrowth.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Revised: P. Walsh  Date of revision: 30 April 2009

In the N interior of ceremonial enclosure (RO027-012001-). Grass-covered earthen mound (diam. of base 9-10m; H 0.6m at S to 1.2m generally), which had standing stone (RO027-012004-) on its summit (Knox 1911, 219, Fig. 4), but this is no longer visible.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a low knoll rising over a level landscape. Circular grass-covered and flat-topped mound (diam. of base 9.8m N-S; 9.8m E-W; diam. of top 7.7m E-W; 6.5m N-S; H 0.6m). (Timoney, M. A. 1990, 13)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In undulating grassland, located on top of a low ridge, close to the break of slope on the N side, where ground falls away steeply. The elevated position provides extensive views. The Ballygawley Mountains loom on the near horizon at NW?NE, with gaps in their range allowing views of Knocknarae at NW and the Dartrys to N. There are distant views of Kesh Corann at S, Knocknashee at SSW and the Ox Mountains at SW. Compact circular mound (7m N?S; 6m 6?W; H 1.15m at N, 0.7m at S) with a domed profile, slightly flattened on top. The N slope is higher, and somewhat more broadly slumped, enhanced by the natural fall of ground. The mound appears to be largely earthen, but medium to large-sized stones protrude in parts. It is grass-covered and a single sycamore tree grows on top. According to local information, this mound was investigated in the 1920s by Henry Morris (pers. comm. M. A. Timoney), but the results of this investigation were never published. There is a portal tomb (SL021-058----) 135m to N, and an embanked enclosure (SL021-051----) 325m to WSW.   Attached images: SL021-102----_01.JPG viewed from NW SL021-102----_02.JPG Viewed from S, with Ballygawley Mountains in the background  Revised by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of revision: 27 November2018

Situated on a slight rise, on slight N-facing slope, in gently undulating pasture. Circular flat-topped mound (diam. top 14m; base 18m; H 0.7) of earth with gently sloping sides. There is no fosse visible at ground level. The top of the mound undulates irregularly.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

Situated on a SW-facing slope of rising ground in a mountainous region. Depicted on the 1st ed. OS 6-inch map as a small circular enclosure transected by a townland boundary and described in an OS Field Memorandum (1938, A/217/44,46) as being a tumulus 15ft (4.57m) in diameter and 1ft (0.3m) high. Not visible at ground level. Three large contiguous stones, two of which are lying flat are indicated on the latest ed. OS 6-inch map as 'Dolmen (Remains of)' and are classified as megalithic tomb possible (25:29/02).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated in an upland area with nearby mound barrow (TN031-018) to the NE. A hillock has been scarped and flattened on top to form a flat-topped burial mound (H 3.2m; diam. 16m NE-SW; 11m NW-SE).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated in an upland area with nearby mound barrow (TN031-019) to the SW. A hillock has been scarped and flattened on top to form a flat-topped oval-shaped burial mound (H 2.7m; diam. 26.3m NE-SW; 18.5m NW-SE).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In wet pasture on N bank of Keale River that marks the townland boundary with Darragh Beg. Not depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map.  It is shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a raised circular-shaped mound (diam. c. 10m) enclosed by a fosse.  No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload:  5 November 2021

In poor pasture, on level ground on the N-facing slope of a ridge. A circular flat-topped grass-covered mound (diam. 10m; H 1.3m) stepped on its N and NW sides. A NW-SE field boundary clips the NE arc.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On a low E-W rise overlooking the W-E Boyle River which is c. 300m to the N. Circular rounded and grass-covered but poached earthen mound (diam. 13.2m N-S; 11.5m E-W; H 1.8m at N to 2.7m at S).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In undulating rocky pasture, in the Ballinafad valley between the Curlew and Bricklieve Mountains. A circular flat-topped mound of earth and stone (diam. 14m; max. H 1.5m), the E part of which is crossed by a stone field boundary. Sand extracted from the mound in several places led to the discovery of a pit-burial (SL040-155002-) in 1962 and a short cist (SL040-155003-) in 1970.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on flat poorly drained land with nearby River Small to the N. A natural hillock which has been scarped and flattened on top (top diam. 7m N-S; base diam. 20m approx.; H 2m) to form a mound barrow.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

At the summit towards the NW end of a NW-SE ridge, and at the NW edge of the central platform of the barrow (RO034-035001-). This is a small mound (dims 4m x 4.8m; H 0.3m).   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 17/1977).

At the summit towards the NW end of a NW-SE ridge and at the NE edge of the central platform of barrow (RO034-035001-). This is a small mound (dims 7.2m N-S; 6.2m E-W; H 0.45m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 17/1977).

Situated on top of a hillock in an upland area with extensive views and overlooking nearby ringfort (TN031-076) to SSW. A conical-shaped flat-topped mound of earth and stone (H 1.2m; diam. top 5.4m) with stones protruding from the surface of the mound.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

On a slight rise, bordering an expanse of wet pasture to WSW and within a field system (SL047-083004-). A circular steep-sided earthen mound (diam. at base 11.6m; diam. at top 6m). The S portion of the mound is highest (H 1.5m) due to a natural dip in the ground level. The top of the mound is defined by a slight rim and there is a hollow (diam. 3m) in the centre. This mound is located within a rectangular field (30m N-S; 49.5m E-W) defined by a low earthen bank (Wth 2m; H 0.4m). A mound (SL047-083005-) lies c. 400m to NE and a graveyard (SL047-083002-) c. 150m to NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Revised: P. Walsh  Date of revision: 30 April 2009

In undulating pasture, on a slight SE-facing slope. A roughly circular raised area (12m N-S; 13.6m E-W) defined by a scarp (H 1.1m). The interior, which is raised to compensate for the hillslope, is level and clear of overgrowth with some hawthorn bushes on the scarp at S.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On top of a rise, in undulating rocky pasture and c. 170m NE of a graveyard (SL047-083002-). A low grass-covered circular mound (diam. 6m at base, 2.6m at top; H 0.55m) with a flat top and broadly sloping sides. The mound barrow lies within a field system (SL047-083004-). Another mound (SL047-083006-) occurs c. 400m to SW and a road (SL047-083003-) lies c. 150m to ENE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Revised: P. Walsh  Date of upload: 30 April 2009

On a knoll on a W-facing slope. Circular grass-covered earthen mound (diam. of base 10.2m N-S; 9.6m E-W) with a flat top (diam. 3.6m N-S; 3.4m E-W; H 1.5-1.65m). Kerbstones are intermittently visible around the base.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture 75m E of townland boundary with Ballynamona. One of fourteen barrows (LI041-032001/013-).  Enclosure (LI041-031----) lies 45m to the SW and a barrow cemetery (LI049-072001/026-) lies immediately to S and SSW. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified in 1936 during a survey of the area undertaken by Ó Ríordáin (1936, 175).  Earthwork visible as a raised circulars-shaped platform (diam. c. 15m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached plan of survey from Ó Ríordáin (1936) and Google earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 15 July 2021

At the highest point of a WNW-ESE ridge. Traditionally this is the burial place of Ceat Mac Magach, one of Queen Meave's warriors, or of Cairbre Cinn Ceat, a Fir Bolg king (Gormley 1989, 17). Circular grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 8m E-W; 7.4m N-S; H 1.2-1.7m) which has been revetted with stones (H 0.8m) N-SE. It is situated on a subrectangular grass-covered platform (dims 11.5m E-W; c. 14m N-S) defined by a scarp (H 0.8m) at N and E (H c. 0.2m), but merging into the ground elsewhere, and which may indicate the boundary of land reclaimation. Barrow (RO021-042020-) is c. 210m to the N, fulacht fia (RO021-042022-) is c. 100m to the SE, and the barrow is surrounded by the field system (RO021-042023-). (Knox 1914a, 38-9; Herity 1983, 137)See the attached view from the SE.Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 24 August 2010

Some 50m to the W of Dooros burial ground (GA132-013001-). This poorly preserved almost circular flat-topped earthen mound (8m N-S; 7m E-W; H c. 0.6m) is partially obscured by overgrowth and field-clearance rubble. The Ordnance Survey Letters (O'Flanagan 1939, Vol. 2, 515) recorded that, according to local information, 'there was a friary [GA132-013003-] near the graveyard situated at the mound of earth which lies partially effaced in an adjacent field'; the 'mound' referred to may be this barrow, but no visible trace of any building was noted. According to local tradition, burials marked by small headstones existed here. However, no visible surface trace of any survives. Possibly a barrow that was re-used as a children's burial ground.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 24 July 2019

On the crest of a low WNW-ESE ridge. This is a circular grass-covered mound (diam. of top 4.2m; diam. of base 5.8m; H 0.3-0.45m). Ring-barrow (RO035-067002-) is 8m to the NE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the Rathcroghan plateau, c. 60m NW of Rathcroghan mound (RO022-057010-) and c. 40m SE of standing stone (RO022-05706-). Low grass-covered mound (diam. 8m; H 0.3-0.4m) ), to which Herity (1983, 130; Toberrory 12) applies the name 'Milleen Meva'. (Waddell 1987-8, 35, No. 51)  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 294.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a knoll at the N edge of the Rathcroghan plateau. Circular, grass-covered and flat-topped earthen mound (diam. of base 6.5m E-W; 5m N-S; diam. of top 3m E-W; H 0.3m at S to 0.7m at E). Barrow (RO022-056020-) is c. 150m to the ENE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In rough undulating pasture, on the N side of a ridge. Described during a previous inspection in 1992 as the remains of a circular flat-topped earthen mound (diam. 7m; H 1.2m) with a quarry hole (Wth 12m) cut into the S edge (SMR (1989) file). Now levelled and not visible at ground level. The quarry to S is now disused. A possible cairn (SL034-065----) lies c. 100m to SSW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On a slight rise on the Rathcroghan plateau, c. 170m S of Rathcroghan mound (RO022-057010-). Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 15.5m N-S; 14.4m E-W) defined by a scarp (H 0.3-0.4m) with a cairn (dims 3.6m E-W; 2.1m N-S; H 0.3m) S of the centre, and a hollow (diam. 3m) E of the centre. Knox (1914a, 29) describes this as a cashel (No. 3) while Herity (1983, 130; 1988, 134, Glenballythomas 8) describes a small mound (Glenballythomas 9) immediately to the SSW which is not visible at ground level. Barrow (RO022-056019-) is c. 85m to the NNE and barrow (RO022-056020-) is c. 70m to the ESE. Rath (RO022-056022-) is c. 110m to the S. (Waddell 1983, 29, No. 10)  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 473  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a slight NNE-SSW ridge at the N edge of the Rathcroghan plateau with a quarry immediately to the S. Subcircular grass-covered and flat-topped earthen mound (dims of base 8m N-S; 6.8m E-W; diam. of top 3.2m; H 0.5m at S to 1m). Barrow (RO022-056019-) is c. 150m to the WSW. (Herity 1983, fig. 37, 1984, 134, Toberrory 2; Waddell 1983, 37; No. 34)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a slight N-S ridge on the N-facing slope of Rathcroghan. Circular, flat-topped and grass-covered earth and stone mound (diam. of base 13.3m N-S; diam. of top 3m N-S; H 2.2-2.5m) with slip around its base. Rath (RO022-056023-) is 3.5m to the S. Geophysical testing failed to produce evidence of any internal structure, but it is suggested that the flat top might be a medieval adaption (Waddell et al. 2009, 49-55). (Knox 1914a, 16-7, 21; Herity 1983, fig. 37, Toberrory 3; 1984, 129; Waddell 1983, 37; 1988, 10, No. 35)  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 294.  See the attached view taken from the S.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a slight NW-facing slope, overlooking a NE-SW orientated valley, in improved pasture. A barrow (TS058-046----) is visible on the valley floor 750m to the NW and the standing stone (TS058-023004-) at Longstone is visible 1.8km to the N on the near horizon. Flat-topped ovoid earthen mound (dims. top 4.5m N-S; 3m E-W; base 17m N-S; 13m E-W; H 1.85-2.4m). No fosse or quarry ditch is visible at ground level. Erosion caused by livestock has formed a rough terrace midway up the side of the mound SW-SE. Some rubble stone has been exposed on the side of the mound at E. Clear of overgrowth except for two mature thorn bushes on the W side.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In undulating rocky pasture, on a slight S-facing slope and within a field system (SL034-233002-). A roughly circular raised area (diam. 10m) defined by an earth and stone scarp (H 0.6m). The interior is undulating with numerous moss-covered rocks. A disused N-S drystone field boundary crosses the interior W of centre.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Visible as a circular feature on aerial photographs (CUCAP AHN 2,3; AJO 17,20; AHM 103), and situated on a SE-facing slope of a NE-SW ridge within a golf-course. Circular, round-topped and grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 12m; H 1.1-1.3m). Ring-barrow (RO006-118005-) is c. 80m to the W.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on a gentle E-facing slope within a golf course. Circular, round-topped, grass-covered earthen mound (diam. of base c. 11m; H 0.5-1.5m). Embanked enclosure (RO006-118007-) is c. 125m to the W.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a knoll on the N-facing slope of Rathcroghan ridge. Subcircular grass-covered and flat-topped earthen mound (diam. of base 8.6m E-W; 7.6m N-S; diam. of top 2.4m; H 1-1.2m) within an oval enclosure (RO022-056052-) (int. dims 36m N-S; 23m E-W), which was probably defined by a stone wall that is now removed but visible as a parch mark (Wth 1m) in very dry seasons. This enclosure is truncated at S by the N bank of the road (RO022-056034-). A larger outer enclosure (RO022-056053-) (dims 74.7m N-S; 51.5m E-W) is defined by a scarp (H 0.2-0.4m) at the base of the knoll, although the perimeter may be incorporated into the S bank (Wth 5m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.8m) of the road (RO022-056034-) which overlies the outer enclosure at its S end. There is a fragment of an earthen bank (Wth 4.5m; H 0.9m) on the line of the outer enclosure at W where the knoll has been quarried and the perimeter of the outer enclosure is also quarried at N. Barrows (RO022-056036-; RO022-056037-) are c. 50m and 70m to the E, and the barrow known as Flanagan's Fort (RO022-056038-) is c. 180m to the ESE. (Knox 1914a, 19-20; Herity 1983, 130; 1987a, 134, Toberrory 7; Waddell 1983, 39; No. 39)  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 294.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On top of the level summit of a broad locally prominent hill, with gentle slopes falling to the W and N. Ringfort (TS066-008001-) is located 40m to the SE. A water reservoir is located 10m to the SE. Flat-topped circular earthen mound (diam. top 3.2m N-S; base 13.2m; H 1.95m) with no fosse or quarry ditch visible at ground level. The edge of the mound has been eroded SE-S leaving an irregular hollow extending from the summit to the base. An E-W orientated farm track abuts the base of the mound at S. The mound is clear of overgrowth except for a mature thorn bush on the S side.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a W-facing slope. Circular round-topped earthen mound (diam. 5.25-5.6m; H 1.1m at E to 1.75m at S) remains unplanted in a coniferous forest. The large ring-barrow (RO006-124001-) is just to the SE and barrow (RO006-124003-) is to the E. (Knox 1914b, 39-40)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a W-facing slope. Circular, round-topped and scrub-covered earthen mound (diam. of base 4.5-5m; H 1.1m generally to 1.4m at S) which remains unplanted in a coniferous forest.
