The large ring-barrow (RO006-124001-) is just to the S and barrow (RO006-124002-) is to the W. (Knox 1914b, 39-40)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the summit of an E-W drumlin ridge. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 10.1m E-W; 9m N-S; diam. of top 2.5m N-S; 2m E-W; H 1.5-1.6m).  See the attached image.   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture, on a rise in a sheltered hollow. An oval mound (14m N-S; 19.5m E-W; max. H 2.1m), damaged on its N edge by a mechanical digger exposing light brown soil with traces of iron pan. A fragment of metal slag and a charcoal fleck were noted in the soil. A few small limestone stones on the S edge of the mound may be the remains of an enclosing element; a slight trace of a fosse was noted on the W arc.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On the N side of the broad WNW-ESE Carnfree ridge. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 8.8m E-W; 8.5m N-S; H 0.2-0.4m) which is incorporated into a relict NE-SW field bank. Bowl-barrow (RO028-063001-) is c. 60m to the SW, mound barrow (RO028-063004-) is c. 70m to the S, and ring-barrow (RO028-064001-) is c. 210m to the E. Rath (RO028-063002-) is c. 50m to the SW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the broad WNW-ESE Carnfree ridge. Subcircular low grass-covered rise (dims 9m E-W; 8m N-S; H 0.2-0.3m). Bowl barrow (RO028-063001-) is 50m to the WNW, mound barrow (RO028-063005-) is c. 70m to the N and ring-barrow (RO028-064001-) is c. 200m to the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a slight E-facing slope, on the E side of a broad hillock, in pasture to the NE of Lattin village. A moated site (TS058-045----) is located 100m to the NW. A flat-topped circular earthen mound (diam. top 9m; base 37m; H 5.4-7.2m) with steeply sloping sides. The summit is level and well-spaced mature Douglas fir trees are growing across the monument.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Marked only on the 1945 ed. of the OS 6-inch map where it is described in gothic lettering as ‘Tomrud’. It is situated on the summit of a low E-W drumlin ridge on the floor of Glencar valley. This is a circular grass-covered platform with some bushes (diam. of base 9.5m E-W; 8.7m N-S; diam. of top 6.6m) defined by a scarp (H 1.1m at S to 1.4m at N).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

On the broad WNW-ESE Carnfree ridge, c. 80m SE of Carnfreee cairn (RO028-069001-). Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 6.2m E-W; 5.9m N-S; H 0.2-0.3m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the N-facing slope of the broad WNW-ESE Carnfree ridge abutting the E bank of road (RO028-062001-), which has been removed to its S (L c. 20m). Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 10m; H 0.5m at S to 1.3m at N). Ring-barrow (RO028-062003-) is 10m to the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the crest of the N-facing slope of a WNW-ESE ridge on the N-facing slope of the WNW-ESE Carnfree ridge. Circular, domed and grass-covered mound (diam. 10m; H 0.2m). Barrow (RO-028-066001-) is c. 40m to the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In rough pasture, on an E-facing slope. An oval grass-covered earth and stone mound (4.65m x 3.6m; H 1.1m). The top of the mound is uneven, possibly due to digging, and has an off-centre depression.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, atop hill. Heavily overgrown, roughly circular mound (max. H 1.55m; c. 14m E-W; c. 13m N-S). According to Coleman (1894, 35) locally called Móinteán an t-Rígean (Fairy Hill); 'It stood fifteen feet high; but was levelled by the present tenant all but a small portion, which yet remains untilled; during levelling 'three cists or graves were found 'containing 'human remains'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 2: East and South Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1994). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On bluff, on N bank of River Blackwater, within gardens of Ileclash House. Circular mound (diam. 42m; H 4.6m) with flat top; steps ascend to top on E and W sides; sides inaccessible due to heavy ornamental planting. Hachured as stepped circular mound on 1905 OS 6-inch map.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

Towards the bottom of a NW-facing slope. Grass-covered but poached oval mound (dims 10m NE-SW; 8.4m NW-SE; H 1.2-1.5m), from which St Patrick preached while travelling from Ogulla (RO022-106----) to Oran (RO034-080----), according to local tradition.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked only on the 1914 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on a slight S-facing slope. Eroded circular grass-covered area (diam. 12-12.4m) defined by a scarp (H 0.1-0.4m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On top of an E-W ridge. Circular, round-topped and grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 5-5.5m; H 0.5-0.95m). Ring-barrow (RO006-135001-) is c. 10m to the ESE. These monuments are particularly visible on Google Earth (18/03/2015). Archaeological testing (15E0105) c. 20m to the W produced no related material (Quinn 2015).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 2 April 2019 Amended: 5 February 2020

On a N-facing slope. Circular grass-covered and flat-topped mound (diam. of base 19.6m E-W; 19.5m N-S; diam. of top 12m N-S; 7.7m E-W; H 1.6-1.75m) with the remnants of a N-S field bank (Wth 2.4m; H 0.25m) on the summit. The base is slightly truncated by an E-W road wall at N. Rath (RO028-141----) is c. 35m to the WNW on the other side of an ENE-WSW road.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Located at the S edge of a plateau overlooking Glencar valley to the W. This is a circular, grass-covered earthen mound (diam. of base 9.4m E-W; 8.2m N-S: diam. of top 5.5m E-W; 5.8m N-S; H 1-1.4m) with an old quarry at the summit that is overgrown with rushes (diam. 3m N-S; 2.7m E-W; D 0.2-0.4m).   The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

On a rise in an undulating landscape. Circular, round-topped and grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 5.5m; H 0.75m at W to 1.2m at S) with traces of a kerb at SE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the summit of an E-W ridge. Circular grass-covered and flat-topped mound (diam. of base 24.5m NW-SE; 21.7m NE-SW; diam. of top 19.8m NW-SE; 15.5m NE-SW; H 0.2m at S to 1.4-1.5m N-E) which has been quarried back at N and probably lowered at S. A NNE-SSW field wall and hedge overlies it W of the centre. It is within ceremonial enclosure (RO028-148002-). Bowl barrow (RO028-153----) is c. 180m to the SSW. (Herity 1983, 129)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the highest point of a broad plateau. Circular flat-topped and grass-covered but poached earthen mound (diam. of base 15m N-S; 15.5m E-W; dims of top 4.8m N-S; 3.9m E-W; H 2m at W to 3.1m at S) with a trigonometric station on top. The large enclosure (RO016-053001-) is c. 50m to the N, and rath (RO016-055----) is c. 50m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked only on the 1914 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on a rise on a broad plateau. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 4.5m; H 0.6m) at the centre of a low subrectangular grass-covered platform (dims 18.5m NW-SE; 10.1m NE-SW at NW to 12.5m NE-SW at SE) defined by a scarp (H 0.45m at NW to 1.25m at SE) on all sides except the SW where it merges into the ground. The platform may be a result of land reclamation stopping short of the barrow. Rath (RO016-055----) is c. 60m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a broad col with slightly higher ground to the NW and SE, and slightly lower ground to the NE and SW. Subcircular grass-covered mound (dims 20.6m N-S; 17.3m E-W; H 1.2m) which was excavated and reconstructed in 1966-7 (Ó Ríordáin 1997). It consisted of a cairn (RO028-204002-) (diam. 13m N-S; 14m E-W; H 1.5m) defined by a drystone facing (H up to 0.5m) with a line of kerbstones E-SE where cremated bone was recovered. Eight cists were recovered under the cairn, within it, and outside it, containing a total of eight Bowl Food Vessels, a fragment of a bowl, the cremated remains of fourteen individuals, and three inhumations.   The cairn was covered in a clay mound (diam. c. 20m; H 1.5m), taking on the appearance of a mound barrow, and six secondary burial pits, largely in the mound, contained the cremated remains of ten individuals, fragments of two Vase Urns, an almost complete Vase Urn, a bowl, fragment of a bowl, a bone disc and a bronze dagger. Graves 1, 3, and 13 were in the old ground surface or the subsoil and probably pre-date the building of the cairn. Grave 2 was within the cairn close to its centre, and is probably contemporary with the building of the cairn. All the other cists and the pits appear to have been inserted in the cairn after the addition of the clay mantle.   Grave 1 is a cist (RO028-204003-) (int. dims 0.56m E-W; 0.5m N-S; H 0.3m) with a capstone (dims c. 1.45m x c. 0.8m) which contained a bowl food vessel and scattered cremation set into the old ground surface c. 2m inside the perimeter of the cairn at NE. Grave 2 is a cist (RO028-204004-) (int. dims 0.85m E-W; 0.6m N-S; H 0.45) with a large capstone (dims c. 1.75m x c. 1.45m) which contained two bowl food vessels and the inhumed remains of two individuals. It was close to the centre within the cairn. Grave 3 is a cist (RO028-204005-) (int. dims 0.38m E-W; 0.35m N-S; H 0.35m) with a double capstone (dims c. 0.87m x c. 0.8m; T 0.35m) which contained a bowl food vessel and an inhumed child. It was set in the subsoil c. 1.2m outside the kerb at N. Grave 13 is a cist (RO028-204010-) (int. dims 0.84 N-S; 0.57m E-W; H 0.52m) with a capstone (dims. c. 1.5m x 1.15m) which contained two bowl food vessels and a large deposit of cremated bone. It was set in the subsoil just NW of the centre of the cairn.  Grave 4 is a cist (RO028-204006-) (int. dims 0.5m N-S; 0.35m E-W; H0.3m) with a capstone (dims 0.8m x 0.75m) which contained a small amount of cremated bone. It had been inserted in the spill of the cairn at W, just outside the kerb. Grave 5 is a cist (RO028-204007-) (int. dims 0.7m NW-SE; 0.5m NE-SW; H 0.3m) with a capstone (dims 0.83 x 0.72m) which contained a cremation, a fragment of pottery and a bone pendant or bead. It was situated in the cairn spill at E and had been inserted into the mound. Grave 8 is a cist (RO028-204008-) (int. dims 1.17m N-S; 0.52m E-W; H 0.65m) with a capstone (dims. 2.25 N-S; 2m E-W; T 0.3m) which contained a bowl food vessel with a scattered cremation. It was inserted in the mound at E, inside the kerbstones of the cairn. Grave 8a is a cist (RO028-204009-) (int. dims 0.63m E-W; 0.44m N-S; H 0.27m) with a capstone (dims 1.05m x 0.95m) which contained a bowl food vessel and cremated deposit. Beneath the paving stones was further cremated material probably from the same event as those above. It is in the mound at SE.   Grave 6 is a pit burial (RO028-204011-) containing cremated remains, fragment of a Vase Urn, and a pygmy cup. It was in the mound at S. Grave 7 is a pit burial (RO028-204012-) containing cremated bone, unburnt human and animal bone and is situated in the mound at the centre. Grave 9 is a pit burial (RO028-204013-) containing fragments of a Vase Urn and a small cremation deposit. It was in the mound just SE of the centre. Grave 10 is a pit burial (RO028-204014-) containing a Vase Urn inverted over a stone and containing a large cremation deposit including a bronze dagger with its bone pommel. It was inserted in the moun
On top of a drumlin. Circular grass-covered but poached earthen mound (diam. 21m; H 1.5-1.8m). Rath (RO003-001----) is c. 100m to the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At a break in slope on a SE-facing slope, and known locally as 'Croghan'. D-shaped grass-covered mound (dims 7.4m E-W; 5.7m N-S; H 0.5-0.7m) which has been truncated at S by a relict earthen field bank.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a rise of a broad E-W ridge. Circular grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 12.5m E-W; 12m N-S; H 2.3m at W to 2.8m at S) with a flat summit (diam. 1.15m). Rath (RO016-063----) is c. 170m to the S, and barrow (RO016-060----) is c. 140m to the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked only on the 1914 ed. of the OS 6-inch map and situated on a rise in an undulating landscape at the N angle of a large rectangular field. Oval round-topped and grass-covered mound (dims of base 7m N-S; 5.5m E-W; H 0.9m at N to 1.1m at S) of earth and stone with intermittently visible kerbstones at its base. The perimeter is partially quarried at NE and E, and it may be a collection of field stones.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 5 June 2015

On a slight rise overlooking a basin S-NW. Subcircular, gently rounded and grass-covered earthen mound (dims 20.2m N-S; 17.2m E-W; H 1.6-1.9m) curtailed slightly by a N-S field wall at E and with slight remains of field banks on the other sides. There are some field stones on the mound.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In a low-lying landscape with higher ground all around. Subrectangular grass-covered mound with some scrub (dims 14.5m N-S; 14m E-W; max. H 1.6m) which has been curtailed at N and E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On an esker ridge in undulating pastureland. This circular barrow (diam. 23.5m), in fair condition, is defined by a raised flat-topped mound (diam. 3.2m; base diam. 14.45m; H c. 2m) surrounded by a berm (Wth 1.9-2m). It has been partially quarried out at N.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 16 August 2019

On top of the low WNW-ESE ridge of Caran Hill. Subcircular grass-covered and domed mound (dims 23m E-W; c. 20m N-S; H 1.7-2m) with the base of a small grass-covered cairn (RO028-138002-) (diam. 2.2m E-W; 1.8m N-S; H 0.5m), probably a clearance cairn, on the summit. The base of the mound is cut back slightly at N where there is a pond. It is described as a passage tomb (Ó Nualláin 1968, 27; Herity 1974, 280, Ro 4; de Valera and O'Nuallain 1972, 141-2). Archaeological testing (20E0594) by R. Ó Maoldúin just to the NE on the site of a proposed lay-by produced no related material (excavations.ie 2020:188).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010 Amended: 20 October 2021  See linked document with details from Ruaidhrí de Valera and Seán Ó Nualláin, Survey of the Megalithic Tombs of Ireland. Volume III. Counties Galway, Roscommon, Leitrim, Longford, Westmeath, Laoighis, Offaly, Kildare, Cavan. (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1972).

In undulating wet pasture that has been reclaimed, on S facing slope with good views from NW to E.  Remains consist of a slightly raised small sub-circular shaped area (diam. 4m N-S x 2.4m E-W) defined by a scarp with no trace of an enclosing fosse.  Depicted as a small mound on Cassini ed. OSi 6-inch map.  Not indicated on 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map.  Compiled by: Caimin O’BrienDate of upload: 20 October 2021

Marked only on the 1930 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on a rise of a broad plateau. Subcircular grass-covered mound (dims 6.2m N-S; 4.5m E-W; H 0.8m at W to 1.2m at N) which may have been slightly truncated at W. Rath (RO028-039----) is c. 80m to the ENE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on a SW-facing slope in undulating pasture. Depicted on 1st ed. (1840) OS 6-inch map as a semicircular clump of trees, possibly enclosed, immediately W of a field boundary. The depiction is clearer on the 1901-5 ed., once again showing a circular enclosure bisected from NW to SE with only W half surviving. The present remains consist of the much-disturbed W half of the mound (diam. NW-SE 25m; max. H 2m at NW) heavily overgrown with brambles and nettles. The only surviving portions, at NW and SW, do not give a true representation as dumped clay and stone has been pushed to the sides. Large concrete 'lintels' and stones have been dumped at the base of the mound in the NW quadrant and there is a lot of loose stone hidden in undergrowth. The N side of the site has been truncated and there is no trace of the site on the other side of the field boundary. Described by Ó Ríordáin (1953, 90) as 'a low mound [which] appears to have a kerb and also a concentric ring of stones outside it'. These stones appear to have been levelled.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In tillage atop Bagwells Hill. No visible surface trace. One of four tumuli (CO087-085---; CO087-092---; CO075-044---) referred to by Coleman (1894, 35) on the Great Island;....'called the Moate, hence the hill is named Cnocan Móta'. Power (1923, 200) refers to it as 'The Moat'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 2: East and South Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1994). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In flat pastureland. Marked on the 1946 revision of the OS 6-inch map as a circular enclosure (diam. c. 15m) with two trees in the interior. According to local information, a low mound here was destroyed during land clearance. Apart from a low hummock, no visible surface trace survives.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 25 July 2019

Marked only on the 1914 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated towads the bottom of the W-facing slope of a rise. Circular grass-covered but poached earth and stone mound (diam. 7m N-S; 6.5m E-W; H 0.1-0.2m). Rath (RO006-159----) is c. 140m to the NE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level pasture with restricted views.  Townland boundary with Behanagh 25m to S and N bank of Behanagh River 65m to S.    Remains consist of a raised circular-shaped mound (dims. 6.15m N-S x 6.1m E-W; H 1.1m) defined by a scarp with no evidence of an external fosse.  Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 26 October 2021

On a S-facing slope. A standing stone (RO010-087001-) was dislodged from a mound in 1967 when bones were reputedly found (NMI file). There is no visible surface evidence of the standing stone or mound in a pasture field.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked as a small circular feature (diam. c. 10m) on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on the crest at the NE end of a NE-SW ridge. Circular flat-topped and grass-covered earthen mound (diam. of base 9.8m; diam. of top 2.5m; H 1.5-1.7m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a low rise on a gentle SW-facing slope overlooking Lough Croan turlough, c. 200m to the SW. This is a low circular scrub-covered earthen mound (diam. 17m E-W; 16.6m N-S; H 0.7-1.3m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a rise on a gentle S-facing slope. Circular flat-topped and grass-covered earth and stone mound (dims of top 5m N-S; 4.3m E-W; dims of base 7m N-S; 7.4m E-W; H 0.4-0.5m generally to 0.7m at W). It is known locally as the Paupers Plot.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a rise on a gentle SW-facing slope. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 28m NE-SW; 26.5m NW-SE) with a flat top (diam. of top 9.8m NE-SW; 8.2m NW-SE; H 1.4-2m). It may be natural.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a gently undulating designed landscape at the centre of enclosure (RO045-126001-). Rectangular, grass-covered earth and stone mound (dims of top 6.1m NW-SE; 4.2m NE-SW; dims of base 10m NW-SE; 7.8m NE-SW; H 0.7-0.85m) surrounded by a curving field bank and hedge (Wth c. 2m; H 1m) S-N (diam. c. 90m). Raths (RO045-127----; RO045-128----) are c. 130m to the NE and E respectively.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On shelf of SE-facing hillslope in upland region overlooking river valley from ENE through E to S. Monument consists of a low flat-topped mound (top diam. 7.5m SE-NW; base diam. 10.5m SE-NW; H at NW 0.7m; H at SE 2m) of earth and stone construction with no traces of an enclosing fosse visible. Nearby field boundary running SE-NW runs close to base of mound at NE side. Mound appears to have been dug into the side of the hill as it is higher on the SE side.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On the summit of a NNW-SSE esker ridge. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 5.9m WNW-ESE; 5.6m NNE-SSW; H 0.1-0.3m) surrounded by a berm (Wth 1-2.3m) defined by the edges of the esker NNW-E and SSW-W, a low scarp (H 0.3m) E-SSW, and a scarp down to the mound (H 0.4m) W-NNW where the esker ridge is higher.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On top of a drumlin, c. 10m NE of rath (RO011-097001-). Circular grass-covered but poached earthen mound (diam. 7.7m N-S; 6.8m E-W; H 1.2-1.25m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On top of a prominent rise in an undulating landscape. This is a circular, flat-topped and grass-covered mound (diam. of base 4.4-4.7m; diam. of top 1.7m; H 0.6m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Located towards the bottom of a NW-facing fold on a general NE-facing slope overlooking Lough Melvin. This is a grass-covered circular mound (diam. 11m; H 0.8m) which is slightly lower at the centre than the perimeter. The ceremonial enclosure (LE008-004001-) is c. 90m to the S and a ring-barrow (LE008-003----) is c. 35m to the E.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

On a shelf overlooking the head of a SE-NW valley to the W. Circular flat-topped, grass-covered mound (diam. of top 16.5m N-S; 15.7m E-W; diam. of base 23m N-S; 23.5m E-W; H 0.6-1m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In flat poorly drained pasture on N side of the Clodiagh River in an upland region. The site consists of an irregular-shaped flat-topped earthen mound (H 2m; base dims. 20m NE-SW x 16m SE-NW) the top of which is defined by a scarp. The flat summit (diam. 12m NE-SW x 6m SE-NW) has a central depression (dims. D 0.3m; 1.7m x 1.3m) which may be an indication of a collapsed cist. Known locally as Quigley's fort.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

On the W-facing crest of a small NW-SE ridge on a broad plateau. Circular flat-topped, grass and scrub-covered mound (diam. of top 11.3m WNW-ESE; 10.9m NNE-SSW) defined by a scarp (H 1-1.25m) with facing-stones that are most evident at SW. Barrow (RO045-048001-) is c. 75m to the SE, and rath (RO045-046----) is c. 60m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the broad NE-SW shoulder of the hill, the summit of which is c. 350m to the W. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 12.5m NW-SE; 12.3m NE-SW; H 0.6-0.8m) with some stones protruding from the top of the mound which are probably field stones. Barrow (RO045-144----) is c. 110m to the S.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked only on the 1915 ed. of the OS 6-inch map as a small feature (diam. c. 10m), and situated on a slight N-S esker ridge. Subcircular earthen mound with deciduous trees (diam. of base 16.7m WNW-ESE; 15m NNE-SSW; H 1m N-E to 1.5m at S) with a gently rounded summit (dims 9.3m WNW-ESE; 8m NNE-SSW). Cashels (RO048-094----; RO048-095----) are c. 160m to the ENE and c. 70m to the S respectively.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture, to N of Castlemartyr to Killeagh road. Low, oval mound (6m N-S; 4m E-W; max. H 0.5m); stones partially exposed in SE quadrant, appear to form three sides of square (1.2m x 1.2m). According to Fitzgerald (1858, 12), farmer, while levelling mound, discovered cist (CO077-008002-) with larger cover stone containing two human skeletons. One of three tumuli in same townland; other two (CO077-00901-; CO077-010---) c. 400m to NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 2: East and South Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1994). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On high ground on SE-facing slope of rising poorly drained ground with good panoramic views to S and E. Now situated in large coniferous plantation poorly preserved monument consisting of a raised circular platform/mound (H 0.7m; diam. approx. 30m N-S; 17m E-W) defined by a scarp which has been quarried into on the downlsope destroying the S half of the mound. This quarry is indicated on the first ed. OS 6-inch map. Rest of interior has been planted with conifers and forestry drainage channels intersect the W side of the mound, no evidence of an enclosing fosse or bank. Imprerssive panoramic views of the surrounding countryside to S and E, land immediately around the mound was wet poorly drained land.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, atop hillock. Levelled; Windele (Borlase 1897, 14) gives brief description and sketch of tumulus containing 'a large cist in the centre'. According to Fitzgerald (1858, 12), farmer, while levelling mound, uncovered large stone cist 'eight feet square', containing large quantities of human bones; smaller 'stone chest' in same mound also contained two human skeletons and a third (18 inches square) contained 'slack lime'; cists broken up but bones 'replaced in their old sites'. One of three tumuli in same townland; one in same field (CO077-010---) 150m to ENE, second (CO077-00801-) lies 350m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 2: East and South Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1994). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on gentle N-facing slpoe. Mound (12m E-W; 7m N-S; max. H 1.1m) heavily overgrown; hollow in centre. According to Fitzgerald (1858, 11), mound dug into and cist discovered (7 feet by 3 feet) containing 'human skeleton in good preservation'.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 2: East and South Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1994). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, atop hillock. Levelled; according to Fitzgerald (1858, 12), farmer, while levelling mound, discovered cist with large cover stone containing two human skeletons. One of three tumuli in same townland; second (CO077-00901-) lies 150m to WSW and third (CO077-00801-) lies 500m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 2: East and South Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1994). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In level pasture. No visible surface trace. During construction of Mogeela church 'cart loads' of sand and gravel taken from tumulus exposing stone cist (Day 1910, 167-8). 'Cinerary urn' (21/4in high; 31/4in across rim) found in cist by Day, is according to O'Kelly, (1945, 16) a 'food vessel'; now in National Museum.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 2: East and South Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1994). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

National Monument in state ownership no. 348.  Situated at the base of the N-facing slope of a low hill with nearby mound (TN008-022----) to the S and ringfort (TN008-020----) to the SW. A small round-topped mound (H 2m; base diam. 9m N-S; 9m E-W) of earth and stone construction which has been slightly quarried at N. Field-clearance debris has been dumped at the base of the mound at E and W.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

National Monument in state ownership no. 348.  Situated at the base of a N-facing slope of a low hill with nearby mound (TN008-021----) to the N and ringfort (TN008-020----) to the SW. A round-topped mound (H 2.5-3m; base diam. 9m N-S) of earth and stone construction with evidence of external stone facing along the base of the mound at E. The mound has been partially eroded and scarped at W. Could be same site as TN008-062--- which is described in the NMI topographical files.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In pasture, atop hillock. According to local information, mound levelled and spread over field. O'Kelly (1945, 16-17) described circular mound (c. 24ft E-W; c. 23ft N-S; max. H 6ft) with two small stones protruding at E side. Tumulus (CO077-01201-) lies 350m to N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 2: East and South Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1994). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

Located at the N-facing crest of a small drumlin. This is depicted on the 1835 edition of the OS 6-inch map and on the 1945 revision as a small hachured feature. It is a grass-covered, circular, flat-topped mound (dims of base 15.8m N-S; 14.4m E-W; dims of top 5.7m E-W; 5.5m N-S; H 1.4-1.6m) which has been planted with trees around the base and at the centre.  See the attached view taken from the NE.
column13: The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 23 September 2008 Amended: 6 December 2019

column10: Located on the summit of a broad drumlin. This feature is indicated as a small area with bushes on the 1835 edition of the OS 6-inch map. It is a grass and scrub-covered flat-topped earthen mound (diam. of base 10m; diam. of top 2.8-3m; H 1.5m at S to 2m W-N) with slight traces of a fosse best preserved at N (Wth of base 2m; ext. D 0.3m). There is no evidence of an outer bank but a NNW-SSE field bank at E has been removed (max. ext. diam. 17m N-S; 16.8m E-W).
column13: The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 23 September 2008 Amended; 6 December, 2019

column10: At the NE end of NE-SW ridge in flat poorly drained countryside with good views in all directions. A poorly preserved, heavily overgrown round-topped mound (H 3m), the NE and SW sides of which have been quarried into. It was difficult to examine due to the dense cover of bushes, however, there was no enclosing feature visible. A field boundary intersects the mound at N on an E-W axis, with a second field boundary running across the W edge of the mound on a N-S axis. It is not marked on the 1st (1840) ed. OS 6-inch map.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved, level pasture, on E edge of rectangular enclosure (TS060-107006-). Excellent views ENE-NW. Low circular mound (dims. 1.3m E-W; 1.26m N-S; H 0.18m) defined by kerb of firm stones around base. Ground immediately enclosing monument appears slightly depressed. Farm trackway is 10m to S. A small possible cairn (TS060-107011-) lies 36m to the WNW and a ditch barrow (TS060-107007-) is 14m to the NNE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 14 July 2014

On summit of Knockillon Hill, just below the 402 ft. trig. station to SW. Cairn (TS075-064----) visible on summit of hill 6.4km to SW. Enclosure (TS075-017002-) located immediately SE of mound. Mound (dims. crest 6.6m N-S; 7.4m E-W; dims. base 13m N-S and E-W; H 1.26-1.83m E and S sides respectively) has been dug into at top giving a hollowed-out appearance at summit. Composed of clay with some stones and gravel. Mound is grass and nettle covered though the NE slope is partially eroded by animals. No visible trace of external fosse in N and W quadrants, however there is a slight depression (Wth 1.6m) in the E quadrant, obscured by dead wood and nettles, between the mound and the adjacent enclosure.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated at N end of  natural ridge in undulating pasture with good views in all directions. High oval-shaped flat-topped mound (top dims. 7.8m x 6.28m; base diam. c. 31m NE-SW x 24m NW-SE) of earth and stones with no evidence of an enclosing fosse or any other feature associated with the mound.  The sides of the mound are quite steep on W, N and E sides.  The NE side of the mound has been damaged by quarrying and there are some thorn bushes growing on the monument at this location.  Possible mound barrow classification as it would appear to be too small to classify as a small motte (SMR File 06/06/1985).   Mound barrow placed on the Register of Historic Monuments on the 18/06/1986.   Compiled by: Caimin O’Brien  Date of upload: 20 July 2015

Situated on a natural hillock with extensive views. A flat-topped earth and stone mound (H 1.3m; top diam. 4m; base diam. 7m approx.) the S half of which was levelled in the late 1970s during which a cist (TN034-093002) containing two female adult skeletons was revealed. The cartographic evidence suggests that the site originally consisted of two conjoined burial mounds, only the N half of one now survives.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

On the summit of a hill in undulating hilly terrain, in pasture, overlooking a fording point of the River Suir c. 500m to the WSW. There is a lot of limestone outcrop in the vicinity, particularly immediately NE of the mound. There are extensive views in all directions, except to the S which is limited by rising hills. Several mountain ranges are visible including the Comeraghs to the E, the Knockmealdowns to the S-SW and the Galtees to the NW. A cairn (TS075-064----) is visible on the summit of Bain Mountain in the Galtees.  A roughly circular low grass-covered mound (diam. 36m N-S; 34.6m; H 0.3m in S, 0.86m in N and 2.1m in W over a very gradual slope) identified by Bob Withers. There is low contiguous kerbing (L 2m; stones av. 0.4m x 0.2m, H 0.12m) visible at the base of the mound in the NW sector and other stones at irregular intervals around the base. The summit has been quarried into, forming an entrance (Wth 4.6m) on the NE side, opening out to a roughly oval-shaped depression (diam. c. 25m) which extends westward and southward into the mound. The NW portion is obscured by thick brambles. There is a slightly deeper hollow (dims. at base of slope c. 19m N-S; 6.3m E-W) in the SE quadrant. There are two mature hawthorn trees (maybe c. 50 years old) within the hollow which provide a rough terminus post quem for the quarrying. Within the hollow there is a large flat boulder (dims. 2.93m x 1.9m; T 0.3-0.45m) and a number of smaller boulders, some of which are earthfast, immediately to the SE. The location and morphology of the mound, including kerbing, suggest that this is probably a prehistoric burial mound.  See attached photographs: TS082-111----_01 Mound from the WSW TS082-111----_02 Mound from SW TS082-111----_03 Hollow from the NE TS082-111----_04 Boulders within hollow from E TS082-111----_05 Large flat boulder from N TS082-111----_06 Kerbing in NW sector  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 17 February 2021

Located on a gentle NE-facing slope at the edge of a valley, in rough pasture-land. Not indicated on the 1st ed. (1840) OS 6-inch map but depicted on the 1904 ed. as a small mound quite close to old farm buildings which are now gone except for a corrugated iron shed. An overgrown oval earthen mound (11m NE-SW; c. 9m NW-SE; max. H 1.28m; min H 0.66m) broader at NE and narrowing to the SW. There are a number of large burrow holes but no stone visible. An old field boundary (N-S) abuts the E quadrant of the mound.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated in an undulating, poorly drained, upland area. A natural hillock which has been scarped and flattened on top to form a mound (H 2.75m; diam. approx. 20m). A stone from a possible megalithic structure protrudes from the NW face of the mound (Stout 1984, 20-21).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on a gentle S-facing slope in very wet, rushy terrain in rough pasture, on a fairly flat ridge. A grass-covered mound (16.3m N-S; H 0.6-1m) defined by an interrupted non-contiguous circle of twenty-six substantial kerbstones of sandstone with some quartz inclusions (H 0.44-0.88m; Wth 0.52-0.8m; T 0.19-0.32m). Some of the kerbstones are split with their flat surface towards the interior. According to an OPW field report (30.12.77) there are cupmarks on the external faces of some of the kerbstones in the SE quad; these are now covered with lichen. A possible cupmark was noted on the internal face of a stone in the NNW quadrant and on the external face of a stone at ESE. Two boulders are exposed roughly in the centre of the mound aligned NW-SE and 0.48m apart. The SW stone is 0.93m long and at least 0.25m wide; the NE stone is more grass covered. Both appear to have their flat edge lining the interior of a possible cist; no visible end stones. Immediately S of the site the slope has been cut to form a field drainage ditch associated with a boundary bank.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In a slight hollow, off the crest of a hill, sloping to the N, in pasture. Oval, steep-sided, earthen mound (diam. at base 5.4m NE-SW; 9.2m NW-SE; H 2.15m) aligned NW-SE. The outer face has been truncated, probably the result of cattle erosion. A field bank runs along the SW side and the NE side is bounded by a wire fence. It is very overgrown with scrub. Though not depicted on the 1840 OS 6-inch map, the townland boundary clearly kinks out where the monument is located, obviously avoiding it.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 02 December 2013

Within interior of enclosure (TS061-031----), off-centre to ENE. Excellent views in all directions except to W where highest point of slope is located. Oval mound (dims. 2m E-W; 1.7m N-S) defined by low scarp (Wth 0.9m; H 0.15m). A ditch-barrow (TS061-031002-) is conjoined to NE. A ring-barrow (TS061-031003-) is c. 6.5m to E.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In generally level pasture with surface undulations due to limestone outcropping. Small oval mound (dims. 9.1m N-S; 12.7m E-W) defined by gradually sloping sides (Wth 3.0m; H 1.3m-1.4m) rising to a generally level area (dims. 4m N-S; 2.2m E-W). Off centre to N is a small mound (dims. 1.8m N-S; 2m E-W; H 0.5m) of earth and stone. Badly eroded by cattle. Named 'The Moat' on latest edition OS 6-inch map. According to Cahill (1982), unlikely to be medieval due to small scale and more synonymous with a prehistoric burial mound. Ringfort/rath (TS069-010----) is 350m to NNE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Outline of possible conjoined ring-barrows clearly visible on Google Earth aerial image taken 18/01/2018.   Monument  consists of a low circular mound (approx. diam. 9m) defined by a fosse with second barrow immediately to E.      See attached aerial photograph taken from Google Earth.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Dr. Rob O'Hara  Date of upload: 25 February 2020

Outline of possible conjoined barrows (OF043-076001-) clearly visible on Google Earth aerial image taken 18/01/2018.   Monument  consists of a low circular mound (approx. diam. 9m) defined by a fosse with second barrow immediately to W.      See attached aerial photograph taken from Google Earth.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Dr. Rob O'Hara  Date of upload: 25 February 2020

Cahill and Sikora (2011, 517-8) record that ‘in July 1975 human remains (WM030-124001-) were discovered during construction work for the rural electrical scheme at Aghanashanamore, near Mount Temple, Co. Westmeath. The site of discovery was close to a possible barrow , which the ESB took to be a ringfort. The site is not marked on the Ordnance Survey sheet but, according to measurements received, measured 8m in overall diameter. Two or three skeletons were discovered at a depth of 0.3-0.45m below ground level. The disposition of the remains is not known, but it was reported that the bones were those of `young men' and the teeth were in good condition. Work was stopped in the area pending an examination. The site was not investigated by NMI personnel and the remains were not acquired. The SMR records one site only, a ringfort (WM030-034----), in the townland of Aghanashanamore, but the sketch section provided with some notes on the site by Mr Bart Bambury of the ESB to Marcus Ó hEochaidhe, National Monuments Service, taken together with the maximum diameter of the site, 8m, suggests that this was a mound barrow'.    Date of upload:  13 August 2012

Situated on level pasture with possible mound barrow (WM016-032----) 120m to NE.  Dungolman River 320m to E.  Possible barrow identified as a circular vegetation mark different in colour from the rest of the field and consisting of a low circular shaped mound (diam. 8m E-W; 7m N-S; H c. 0.7m) of earth and stone with no external fosse.  The antiquity of this feature is uncertain.  Compiled by: Caimin O’Brien  Date of upload: 20 July 2015

Situated in a slight dip in the ground in level pasture with Dungolman River 240m to E.  Possible mound barrow (WM016-033----) 120m to SW.  Possible barrow site identified as a circular vegetation mark different in colour from the rest of the field and consisting of a low mound or natural rock outcrop (diam. 6m E-W; 4.5m N-S; H 0.3m) with no evidence of an external fosse.  The antiquity and classification of this feature is uncertain.  Compiled by: Caimin O’Brien  Date of upload: 20 July 2015

On a gentle SSW-facing slope in pasture. Depicted as a small circular enclosure with the designation 'Moat' on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. A circular, steep-sided, flat-topped mound of earth and stone (diam. at base 12.7m; diam. of summit 5.7m; H 2.3m). At W a portion of it has been destroyed by quarrying. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Indicated as a feature covered in bushes on the 1840 and 1927 eds of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on a rise in an undulating landscape on the floor of the Cappagh valley. This is an oval, grass-covered earthen mound (dims. 18m NE-SW; 13m NW-SE; H 1.9-2.2m) with no evidence of a kerb, fosse or outer bank.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 11th August, 2011. Compiled by: Michael Moore.

Situated on low hillock with good views of the surrounding countryside, higher ground to W and SW.  Ballynamuddagh House 170m to SSE.  Small sub-rectangular shaped  flat-topped steep-sided mound  (top diam. 4m; base diam. 10m; H 2m) of earth and stones with no visible trace of an enclosing fosse or external bank.  A livestock track runs across the top of the mound from NW to NE.  Compiled by: Caimin O’BrienDate of upload: 20 July 2015

Situated on a rise of ground on the N side of a prominent hill with good views to N, E and W, restricted views to S.  Small circular round-topped earthen mound (diam. 9m WNW-ESE; H 1.5-2m) of the base of which has been damaged by ploughing and digging (SMR File 15/06/1977).  No trace of any fosse enclosing the base of the mound.  No other features visible.  Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 55-6) as following: 'The survey-team was unable to gain access to this monument, which was described in 1971 and 1977 by ASI fieldworkers. The 1971 account is given here: A small earth and stone round-topped mound. Prob circular originally but the lower slopes are disturbed by digging and later plough? scarps. Red earth is visible in places where the mound is broken down. Not many stones are visible. There is a very slight earthen mound (modern looking) on the top of the barrow. No visible trace of a fosse. There is an old quarry-hole to the N of the mound. Situated on a high prominent hill. The ground rises gently from the site to the S. There are good views to the N. Overall diameters = 9.30m N-S and 9m E-W. Height = 1.50m [SMR file]. The 1977 account describes the mound as ‘very small’ and ‘gently rounded’, with no trace of a surrounding ditch. In view of both of these descriptions the ASI identification of the site as a bowl-barrow appears to be unjustified, and it is here taken to be a mound-barrow'.  Compiled and revised by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of revised upload: 20 July 2015

In pasture, on summit of a low hill in undulating pasture, townland boundary with Raheen immediately to SW.  Low roughly circular-shaped flat-topped earthen mound (H. c. 0.5m; diam. c. 3m) in W corner of field, the hedgerow of this field marks the townland boundary with Raheen from S-W-N.  Outline of earthwork visible on OSi orthoimage taken between 2005-12.  Possible mound-barrow visible on Google Earth orthophoto taken 25/04/2021.See attached photographs courtesy of Paul Gosling and Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/04/2021Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Paul GoslingDate of upload: 2 December 2021

On top of high ground in mountainous area. Circular flat topped mound (H 3m approx. top diam. 7m; base diam. 15m) with circular depression (Wth 2.5m; D 0.6m) on top with evidence of stone kerbing around depression (possible collapsed burial).  One of a group of five barrows (OF037-008001/003/004/005-).  According to local tradition these barrows are located on a hilltop which was the inauguration site of the O’Flanagans of Cinél Arga (Feehan 1979, 143).  It is possible that these burial mounds form part of a ritual landscape associated with this inauguration site.     The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 09 August 2012

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 35-7) as following: 'This is the well-known Early-Middle Bronze Age cemetery cairn on summit of Knockast, excavated by Hencken and Movius over three weeks in 1932 as part of the archaeological section of the anthropological survey of Ireland conducted by Harvard University. During excavation the ‘entire mound’ was removed, although the last three days were ‘devoted to restoring it as nearly as possible to its original appearance’; the reconstructed mound survives and according to a 1982 ASI account measures about 14m (N-S) x 15m (E-W), is 1.5-2m high, and slopes appreciably from SE to NW. Before excavation the cairn appeared as ‘a low, flat, grassy mound with a slight depression in the middle, [which] measured 60 feet [18.3m] in diameter and no more than  4 feet [1.2m] high at its highest point. In general, however, it was not much over 3 feet [0.91m] high’. Excavation showed the cairn to be composed of a core of stones ‘merely thrown together with no attempt at walling or any other arrangement’, and with dark soil between them and covering them, ‘so that only a few stones were visible on the surface’; a large limestone boulder on the natural ground was incorporated in W half of monument (Hencken and Movius 1932-4, 233-4).   The  excavation  uncovered  a  very  large  group  of  burials  reflecting  a  broad  variety  of  burial customs, including four inhumations in cists or unprotected, and thirty-nine cremations ‘in cists, in pots, in mere spaces between the stones, upon the earth at the base of the cairn, or in holes made in the original ground level below it’ (ibid., 248). Charcoal mixed with the cremations indicated that the funeral pyres were uniformly of oak. There was no evidence of a central, primary burial, most of the burials being located in the SE part of the cairn, ‘and indeed one small area in this vicinity, 17½ feet long by 4 feet wide, and running north and south, contained all the objects other than the pots that were found with burials’ (ibid., 249). These objects comprised three bronze shaving-razors, scraps of bronze, bone cylinders, a plano-convex flint knife and a rock crystal; much later in date, but found isolated deep within in the cairn, was an early medieval penannular brooch, possibly associated with one of the skeletons  ‘which must be a later intrusion in the cairn’ (ibid., 252-3). The pottery, though not so tightly distributed as the other grave goods, was again confined to the S and E quadrants, and amounted to ten pots, among which a Bowl Food Vessel, a Vase Food Vessel, an Encrusted Urn, a Vase Urn and a Cordoned Urn were identified. Also found were three pits dug in the original ground surface, containing ox, horse and sheep or goat bones, which, along with  signs  of  intense  conflagrations  beneath  the  cairn,  were  interpreted  as ‘probably traces  of  some ceremonial that took place before the cairn was erected’ (ibid., 247).   Cairn is on summit of very prominent limestone hill known as Knockast or Knockastia. The 1982 ASI account of the site gives a sense of the dramatic location of this monument: Situated on prominent knoll at NW end of ridge running approx NW-SE. Rock outcrop in the form of a crag bounds the spur on which site is situated from S to W. Ground falls away sharply on all other sides from ESE-E-NE-N-NW. [SMR file]  In the 1930s the name of this hill was pronounced ‘Knock Costha’ or ‘Connacostha’ and it appears to be the Cnoc in Coscair referred to in the medieval text Bruiden Da Chocae, in which ‘Eochain Bece, having gone away out of a battle described, fell on Cnoc Ni Coscair after weariness of conflict, so that there are many graves on it and it is called Beces Hill’ (Shaw 1921, 142-3; Hogan 1910, 275; Hencken and Movius 1932-4, 2).   On SW slopes of Knockast about 400m to W, the ASI documents a church and well (WM031-014----) — this is Toberavill holy well, at which John O’Donovan caught the tail end of a pilgrima

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 60) as following: 'Low, subcircular, flattish-topped mound (Diam. 4.9m N-S x 3.6m E-W) situated on rough but fairly level ground, which slopes down immediately to NE.  Mound reaches up to 0.47m in height on SE side; although probably higher on NE side, edge of mound blends imperceptibly into the natural slope here, precluding any clear measurement.  Monument is located on a low but prominent E-W running ridge with spectacular views in all directions, especially to N.  Farther W on same ridge, the ASI documents a second possible mound but this is not accepted as an archaeological feature here (WM024-015----).  Running along N side of ridge in the immediate vicinity of the mound is a low bank.  Other features in the immediate vicinity of the mound appear to be of later date.  Across the road to E, on same ridge, is a large mound with evidence of structures on its upper surface; this has been classified as a motte by the ASI (WM024-014----)'.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

On the highest point of a ridge in pasture. A circular, dome-shaped mound of earth and stone (diam. at base c. 8m; H 1.8-2m). There is no trace of an encircling bank or fosse. From NE-S-SSW it is skirted by a low field bank and ditch. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In grassland, on a S-facing slope of rising ground in upland region with good views in all directions except to N. Nearby enclosure (TS054-026----) 250m to the E. Low poorly defined mound (approx. diam. 21m N-S; 13m E-W; H 0.3m) with small quarry hole (diam. 5m; D 0.8m) in centre of mound. Mound best preserved on W side. Not indicated on first (1840) ed.OS 6-inch map may have something to do with nearby coal mining or may have been a ring-barrow which has been quarried into. Field has been reclaimed with new grass sown and monument may have been degraded during this reclamation work.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated in low-lying wet grassland.  Annotated as ‘Bull Ring’ on the 1837 OS Fair Plan map.  A small sub-rectangular shaped platform (diam. 9m N-S; 8.1m E-W) defined by a low earthen bank (Wth 0.5m; H 0.25m) and narrow shallow external fosse (Wth 0.3m).  At the centre of the interior is a mound of earth and stone (diam. 3.5m N-S; 2.7m E-W) with a fallen, grass-covered stone resting on it (WM010-022001-).  Compiled by: Frank Coyne and Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 9 June 2017

On a W-facing slope in pasture. A report in 1976 (SMR file) recorded a low subcircular mound of earth and stone (c. 18m E-W; c. 16m N-S; H. c. 1m). There was no trace of an encircling bank or fosse. The mound has since been levelled and its site is marked by an irregular rise. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on a low rise with good views in all directions.   Ringfort (WM010-006----) 130m to NW.  Ringfort (WM010-007----) 330m to ESE.  A flat-topped, steep sided oval-shaped mound of earth and stone (H 1.5m; base diam. 10m SSW-NNE; 13m WNW-ESE; top diam. 6m N-S; 7m E-W). A trigonometrical station marking the spot height 263 ft. is depicted here on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map in an area annotated as the ‘Fair Green’. Possible mound barrow.  Compiled by: Frank Coyne and Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 6 June 2017

Situated on a hillock (558ft/170m OD), in undulating pasture, with good views in all directions. Not depicted as an antiquity on any edition of the OS historic mapping, but is marked as an OS trig. point marking the spot height of 558 ft. OD.   Monument described in 1977 as a very small, low mound (diam. 5m) of earth and stone. The sides and a portion of the top (H 1.5-1.75m) have been cut away by digging and ploughing.   Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin O’Brien.  Date of upload: 27 August 2019

Monument identified and described by Schot (2016) as following; 'This feature is located on a slight rise littered with surface outcrop, c.75m SE of St Patrick’s Bed (WM024-059----), and may be a small barrow (Schot 2011). It consists of a low, circular earthen mound, c.5.5m in diameter and 0.4m in maximum height, with a gently rounded profile. There are no surface indications of an enclosing ditch or bank'.   See attached photo provided by Dr. Roseanne Schot  Compiled by: Dr. Roseanne Schot  Date of upload: 08 May 2019

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 56) as following: 'Sharply defined circular tumulus  (Diam.  15.5m N-S x  15.6m E-W) with irregular stony cap containing protruding boulders close to ESE side. Mound rises up to 2m in height above surrounding ground on NW side, its stony cap being up to 0.51m in height. Protruding boulders are visible at various points around the edge of the mound, with a row of them on the S side; it is unclear whether these are natural or form part of a kerb. On NE side of mound is a low, subrectangular projection (L. 3.5m; W. 3m) with boulders along its E side. A second low projection on W side might represent spill from mound. This mound appears to have been shaped from a natural landform.  Tumulus was excavated by Macalister and Praeger after hearing a story that it ‘had been violated in comparatively recent times, and that a cist had been found within it’; they ‘trenched through the mound’ but ‘no evidence was found by us to shew that such a structure had ever existed’. The only feature they noted, aside from a rusty iron hook just under the sod and a broken quartzite pebble close to NNE edge of mound, was as follows: At one place within and near the top of the mound the stones seemed to have been laid intentionally, in an arc 25’ [c. 7.6m] in diameter, surrounding the centre; but nothing was found within it.   No account of the excavation was provided, so it is unclear where their trench was dug or whether they accurately reconstructed the monument afterwards. Geophysical prospection by Roseanne Schot in 2005 and 2009, indicates that an arc of ditch surviving to N of the barrow originally formed part of an enormous hilltop enclosure (WM024-187----), defined by a rock-cut ditch and containing the barrow, which encircled the eastern summit of the Hill of Ushnagh (Schot 2010, 6).   4m-wide gap in enclosure at ENE, defined by the inwardly curved ends of the ditch, indicates an entrance aligned on the centrally positioned barrow.   Barrow lies near E end of broad summit of Hill of Ushnagh, directly N of the conjoined, figure-of-eight-shaped early medieval fort excavated by Macalister and Praeger, and precisely on a line that takes in part of the ancient avenue approaching this fort from the S and continues on to the Togherstown ringfort and tumulus at the north end of the Uisneach complex. There is a small, shallow pond 21m to N; farther N again is a larger kettle-hole lake, beyond which is another barrow (WM024-030----).  Frewin Hill (WM011-131----) and Knockdrin (WM012-032----), sites of hilltop barrows (McGuinness 2012, 28, 34-5), are visible to NE and ENE respectively'.  In 2009 a geophysical survey was undertaken in the field enclosing the mound barrow and the results were described as following; 'A prominent mound (WM024-173----), 1.7m high and about 20m in diameter, crowns the summit of the hill and is probably the monument identified in Dindshenchas as Carn Lugdach or the Sidan, where the god Lugh is said to have been buried after being drowned in the nearby lake (Schot, forthcoming; Gwynn 1924, 278-9). The reported discovery of a cist within the mound sometime prior to the 1920s (Macalister and Praeger 1928, 83) suggests that this may be a bowl-barrow of early Bronze Age date.  Magnetic gradiometry survey conducted around the mound in 2005 revealed a host of previously unrecorded archaeological features, including a curvilinear feature that was suspected to form part of a large enclosure encircling the eastern summit of the hill (Schot 2005). Evidenced as an arc-shaped, positive magnetic band curving from north to southeast across the western part of the surveyed area, this feature corresponds with a broad, shallow depression skirting the edge of the elevated plateau overlooking Lough Lugh (WM024-064002-), to the east, but exhibits no obvious surface trace elsewhere. Nevertheless, its geophysical and topographical signature suggested it to be an in-filled ditch, and the survey in A

Situated on grassland 150m E of Rock Brook House.  Outlined as a circular earthwork on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map with possible mound-barrow (WM010-045----) 110m to the S.   Not depicted as an antiquity on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map. No surface remains visible of levelled earthwork which appears to have been a landscape feature associated with Rock-Brook House.  Depicted in a similar fashion to the mound-barrow (WM010-045----) which may suggest that this earthwork was originally a mound barrow.  Alternatively it is possible that both monuments are landscaped tree-rings dating from the post 1700 period.     Compiled by: Frank Coyne and Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 8  June 2017

Situated on grassland 210m SE of Rock Brook House.  Outlined as a circular earthwork on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map with similar earthwork (WM010-016----) 110m to the N.   Not depicted as an antiquity on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map.  Present remains consist of a  circular shaped mound (diam. 17m) defined by a scarp with a shallow external fosse. There are traces of cultivation ridges on the mound and in the surrounding field.   It is possible that it is a mound-barrow which was landscaped as a tree ring associated with Rock Brook House in the post-1700 period.   Compiled by: Frank Coyne and Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 8  June 2017

Overlooking the River Goul, on the SE edge of a terrace running NE-SW roughly parallel to the river, which is located in the flood plain c. 5m below and c. 100m to the E, in pasture. There are good views in all directions, particularly from S-W. In the Ordnance Survey Letters (1839) it is described as 'a moat' (O'Flanagan 1930, vol. 1, 114 (39)). A small flat-topped mound (top diam. 8.8m N-S; 5.8m E-W; base diam. 17m N-S; 16.1m E-W; H 1.5m) with a few hawthorn trees growing on it. Some stone protrudes from the side of the mound.Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 28 August 2018

On top of high reclaimed pasture in upland area with good extensive views. Nearby ring-barrow (TS049-031----) and burials (TS049-030----) 124m and 260m to the W respectively. Natural hillock which has been scarped to form a low elongated mound (diam. 25m N-S; 35m E-W-; H 1m) with no enclosing bank or fosse visible. Stone flags visible protruding from top of mound may be remains of cist graves.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 60) as following: 'The survey-team was unable to gain access to this monument this season. The 1983 ASI description is as follows:  There is a small mound clearly visible on the shoulder of a hill to SE of ringfort (WM018-091----). This mound is certainly artificial and appears to be of some antiquity. It is roughly circular in shape, c.  6m in diameter on top. It is composed of earth and stone, & is c. 50cm high. Some bushes are growing beside it & on top of it. It commands a very good view. [SMR file]  If an ancient burial mound, this monument would appear to be a small mound-barrow  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 35) as following: 'Dome-shaped, roughly circular mound (Diam. 17m N-S x 15m E-W) reaching up to 2.2m in height on NE side. Monument has been severely eroded by cattle which congregate on its summit, and over large areas where hooves have stripped the sod and taken chunks from the mound’s edge, it can be seen to comprise a large number of stones mixed with some earth—more cairn than earthen barrow. Around N half of mound a narrow berm just above the base is clearly due to cattle walking on the mound and not an original feature. Mound is prominently sited on a broad, low hilltop at SE end of the NW-SE running ridge-like Hill of Laragh, which reaches a height of 123m OD 1km to NW. About 12m to E of the present site is a low grassy ridge or step running NE-SW, forming a distinct break in slope, with ground to NW being higher than that to SE. Possibly this is the remains of a removed field fence'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Situated midway along the top of a low natural ridge running NNE-SSW in low lying marshy pasture.   Ringfort (WM011-045----) located 30m to W.  Possible partially natural glacial hillock that has been scarped or modified to produce a roughly oval-shaped round-topped mound (diam. 20m) of earth and stones with no visible trace of an external fosse.  Partial damage to mound at ENE possibly the result of quarrying which has produced a steep scarp running N-S with some large flag stones visible  (SMR Files 17/10/1972;  28/08/1973).  See attached profile of monument surveyed and drawn by the ASI.   Compiled by: Caimin O’Brien  Date of upload: 17 July 2015

Monument surveyed by ASI in 1978 and described as following; 'A small roughly circular mound of earth and stone.  There is a broad shallow fosse at the foot of the mound on the W with a straight stretch of low earthen bank outside it.  This bank seems to be part of an old field bank and it is possible that the fosse is associated with this and is not an original feature.  There are no indications of either fosse or bank to be seen elsewhere.  A few fairly large stones can be seen in the base of the mound on the N and NW, may be part of a kerb.  A second line (?) of largish stones can be seen approx. halfway up the side of the mound, also on the W and on the E.  Unfortunately the mound seems to have been used as a dump for a small number of field stones.  The top of the mound is flat but has been disturbed by cattle on the E and N.  There is a stump of thorn tree in the edge of the mound on the S.  The site is on top of rise in undulating pasture land.  There are good views in all directions and extensive views to the SW and S.  The mound has slipped somewhat on the E-NE' (ASI File 12/06/1978). Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 15 February 2013

Situated in a col between low hills c. 400m to the NW and SE. This is an oval, scrub-covered earthen mound (dims. 19m NE-SW; 13m NW-SE; H 0.9-1.7m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 26th September 2011.

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 53) as following: 'Monument comprises a small, roughly circular but poorly defined mound (Diam. 5.9m N-S x 5.4m E-W) up to  0.51m in height on W and SE sides, which appears to have been shaped from the summit of a prominent conical knoll that reaches up  to  2m  in height below  mound  on N  side. Mound  has been hollowed out in the centre (2.5m N-S x 2m E-W) as if ransacked by treasure-hunters. Knoll appears to be a kame with kettle-hole lake close by in same field to SW; its NE side, adjacent to modern field fence, has been severely damaged or shorn off. The ASI fieldworker who visited the site in 1983 thought the knoll had been scarped and shaped, but this does not seem obvious to the writer except for the damaged NE side.  Monument is currently located in pastureland but surrounding field is full of old cultivation-ridges or lazy-beds. The monument is marked Crockaphuca (‘Hill of the Pooka’) on OS 6” map'.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 32-3) as following: 'Low sub-circular mound with long axis running NE-SW (Diam. 7.8m NE-SW x 5.7m NW-SE); NW side of mound is up to 0.6m in height and is appreciably higher than SE side, which may have been robbed or eroded in the past, although edge is fairly well defined on all sides. Large boulders protrude from parts of the edge and interior of the monument; another lies just beyond the current edge of the monument to NE in the direction of Frewin Hill. Monument is prominently positioned at N end of summit of low hill or ridge running N-S, with spectacular views to NE, centred on Frewin Hill. Four other barrows (WM018-069----; WM018-107----;WM018-070----; WM018-106---- ) lie in this townland, the two nearest being c. 400m to W and NNW respectively. This monument has not previously been recorded'.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

On a low rise. Depicted as a small circular enclosure with the designation 'Fort' on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. The depiction of the site on the 1913 ed. suggests that it may have been a small mound, possibly a burial mound. The site has been levelled and is not visible at ground level. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 32) as following: 'Circular tumulus (Diam. 8.5m N-S x 8.6m E-W) with well-defined edge, domed to conical in shape and up to 1.45 in height above ground level on NE side. Boulders protrude from upper surface of mound. Although mound was covered in fairly thick grass when visited, narrow circumferential terraces visible on its W side appear to show no pattern and are almost certainly due to erosion or soil-flow. Mound is very prominently sited on an eminence in a deliberately unplanted area of commercial forestry; view would be excellent but for trees. Four other barrows (WM018-069----; WM018-070----; WM018-106----; WM018-151----) lie in this townland, the nearest being c. 500m to WNW'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Barrow annotated 'Nicholastown Moat' on the 1838 ed. OS 6-inch map where OS Trig. station marks spot height of  464 ft. OD.   Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 57) as following: 'Tall, roughly conical tumulus (Diam. 12.4m N-S x 13.5m E-W) with flattened apex, up to 2m high on S side and striking in appearance. Monument is well preserved overall but some parts have eroded away, especially half-way up the E side where exposed soil indicates that mound is predominantly earthen in composition. Various boulders visible around edge of mound on W half, where it begins to rise steeply, seem to represent a kerb, although beyond base of mound (and not included in diameter measurements given above) there is a low, irregular berm of varying width (N: 2m; E: 1.7m; S: 1.2m: W 3.7m), perhaps due to slippage from mound—the disproportionately broad berm on W side is almost certainly due to later disturbance.  There  also  appears  to  be  a  ledge  up  to 1.20m  in  maximum  width  running  around circumference of mound, up to 0.95m above its base: this appears to be original. Flattish circular summit of mound (Diam. 3m N-S x 3m E-W), clear on all sides but N, slopes down very gently from S to N.  Monument is located at edge of farmyard on fairly level pasture, but, given its altitude, with spectacular  views  to  the  E.  According  to  landowner,  monument is known locally as the ‘Moat of Nicholastown’.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 55) as following: ‘With nothing visible by the time an ASI fieldworker visited the site on 6/8/79 [SMR file], this earthen mound or tumulus had been mostly destroyed by the time of its excavation in 1958, with only the NE quadrant being fairly intact and outline of remainder just traceable, from which Prendergast estimated an original diameter of 8m and a central height of ‘probably not more than 1m’. A single cutting on NW circumference revealed no evidence of a surrounding ditch, nor was there surface evidence for one farther out. Mound was of compact brown earth with some stone, on a layer of pasty grey clay which included a layer of charcoal covering the original ground surface including the central area; from the surviving stratigraphy, excavator believed mound to belong to a single construction phase, with the grey layer interpreted as a layer of turfs spread over the charcoal before rest of mound was constructed. Excavation of surviving portion of mound, comprising most of NE quadrant, uncovered four discrete cremation burials or collections of burials, along with three small pockets of cremated bone. Burial A, the remains of an adult, were covered by an Early-Middle Bronze Age Cordoned Urn; Burial B, containing at least one adult, had the barest stone protection and no grave goods; Burial C, comprising a large pile of cremated bones including adult remains and a c. 16-year-old youth, was enclosed by a half-destroyed polygonal cist, and contained two men’s shaving razors of a similar type to those found in the Knockast mound-barrow (Kavanagh 1991, 98-100); Burial D comprised some unprotected and unaccompanied adult remains. Given the poor condition of the bones from the burials and cremation-pockets, the total number of bodies and age and gender distribution could not be ascertained beyond the recognition of 5+ bodies including adults and children.  In the charcoal layer under core of mound was found a curved piece of thin bronze of unknown function; also found somewhere near centre of mound, at the lowest level, were fragments of a miniature vessel or Pygmy Cup.  The excavator took all this material to be contemporary as the mound was a single-phase construction. The ASI fieldworker who visited the site in 1979 was informed of similar pots having been found by a Mr Ross while working his land prior to the excavation of the barrow ‘to the E side of the road [from the barrow]’, suggesting the possibility that the barrow was just one component of a larger Bronze Age cemetery [SMR file].  (Prendergast 1960; Waddell 1990, 150-51; Kavanagh 1976, 375-6; 1977, 89; 1991, 98)’.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 9 February 2016

On a shelf of level ground on a WNW-facing slope. This circular, round-topped mound of earth and stone (diam. at base 11.5m; H 1-1.6m) is partially degraded by cattle trampling over it. There is no trace of an encircling bank or fosse. Probably the remains of a burial mound. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a low rise in pasture. Depicted on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map as a small tree-ring. An oval-shaped mound of earth and stone (dims. at base 14.5m E-W; 11m N-S; H 1.7-1.9m). The summit is flat topped (diam. 6.3m). There is no trace of an encircling bank or fosse. Probably a burial mound. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 39) as following: 'Enormous, steep-sided, roughly circular mound  (Diam. 33.5m NW-SE) with domed top, and no visible traces of a surrounding ditch or bank. Mound is covered by trees and other vegetation, making it difficult to examine in places; as such, only a single diameter measurement could be recorded. Mound rises up to 5.8m above surrounding ground on NE side. Monument is located in a fluvioglacial landscape, with numerous kames in the area—two close set kames form a ridge just SW of the mound—and has presumably been moulded from such a glacial landform given that there is no trace of a ditch from which the material for the massive mound might have derived; the landowner did, however, inform the writer that the soil around the mound was of a different quality to elsewhere in the same field, which might indicate that topsoil was scraped from a broad area to construct the mound or, more likely, enlarge an existing landform. On NW side, mound seems to taper off gradually to the natural ground, making it difficult to identify its edge. Around circumference of mound at varying heights are narrow terraces apparently due to soil-flow and/or animal movement; certainly a few parts of the mound have been poached by animals, showing it to be composed of earth with some stones. Although this prominent monument has the proportions of a Norman motte, and looks superficially like one, it has neither bank, ditch nor bailey, and its domed upper surface is unlike the flat top more usual for a motte.  Monument is located in undulating pasture. Croghan Hill (OF010-004001-) in Offaly is visible to ESE'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 38) as following: 'Very low, poorly defined mound with markedly oval ground-plan (Diam. 5m N-S x 9m E-W) on a low glacial knoll in undulating pastureland. Mound reaches a height of up to 0.37m on S side, where its edge is most clearly defined.
