Located on a broad WNW-ESE ridge with the WNW-ESE Broad Meadow Water c. 250m to the N, while the parish church of Greenoge (ME045-018----) is c. 70m to the NE. This is a grass-covered circular earthen mound (diam. of base 17.5m N-S; 16m WNW-ESE; H 2.1m at N to 3.5m at S) with a slight berm around the base at S. A trench has been dug across the mound E-W which is now a slightly sunken grass-covered feature (Wth 2m). Locally, this is thought to have happened c. 1920 when nothing was found except what is described as a pavement (SMR file). (Feeley 2001, 49-5, No. 40)The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 10 July 2007Amended: 17 December 2021

Located towards the E end of the E-W ridge of Bellewstown. A cist (ME027-029001-) was discovered c. 2m W of a mound c. 1890, and both of these were still extant in 1933 (NMI file). A record of a mound (Moore 1987, 28 No. 164) is erroneous. The mound was probably removed before the 1980s, and no description of it is available. Ring-ditch (ME027-110----) is c. 50m to the E.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 13 February 2019

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007  Circular mound (diam. 25m., H 6m) partially excavated and restored in 1979 by P. D. Sweetman (RMAHS 1982-3, 58-68) who demonstrated that it was a burial mound of the late Iron Age.  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 11/1977).

Located at the NW end of a natural knoll known as 'Dun Hill' which has been enclosed in antiquity (DU019-004002-). A later cairn was apparently built on top of a low earthen mound thought by Westropp (1922, 58-9) to be a barrow.  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Updated by: Christine Baker  Date of upload: 29 January 2015

Located in a grassy field, which is less than one kilometre from the coast, this almost circular enclosure measures 42.0m N-S by 37.5m E-W. The field in which this occurs has been heavily cultivated and at the moment is given over to the growth of grass for the purpose of silage making. The site is substantially denuded, but shows up as an almost perfect circle on aerial photography. The bank of this enclosure has an average external height of 1.00m and has an average width of 10.0m, no trace of a ditch, internal or external, could be found. The internal area of the enclosure is deeply dished, the lowest point of the interior being 1.50m below the crest of the bank as it now survives. A 9.00m long break in the bank occurs at east- this probably being the result of the enclosing element being pushed into the interior during an attempt at field clearance. Otherwise the interior is featureless. Internal diameter of the site is 22.0m N-S by 17.5m E-W. It seems likely that the banks were constructed by scooping out the material from interior and piling it up to form the enclosing bank.'Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.Date of upload: 03 May 2012

The site consists of a sub-circular enclosure measuring 21.5m N-S and 22m E-W with a dished profile and no trace of an internal or external ditch. The enclosing bank varies in width between 5.6m - 7.8m and is on average 0.4m high externally and 0.7m high internally. There is a possible 6m wide gap to the north-west which may be an original entrance but could equally be the result of flattening of the bank by animals.'Description from ‘The Prehistoric Settlement of the Lee Valley, Tralee, Co. Kerry; A Landscape Perspective’ by Michael Connolly. PhD Thesis UCC 2008Date of upload: 22 June 2012

The site is located in the corner of a large field on the south side of the N22. The field slopes down from the west to the east and north and is marshy in those areas at the base of the slope. The site affords good views to the east and north-east, while the low hill which is crowned by Glanbane hillfort is visible to the south – south-east. The embanked enclosure (KE039-202001-) shows up clearly on aerial photography and is situated in one of the marshy areas of the field. The site consists of a large, denuded bank, which can be traced all round the site. The bank is on average 9.5m wide, 0.57m high internally and 0.47m high externally. The site is partially scarped back into the natural slope of the ground at the north – north-west and this gives an exaggerated internal height (c. 1m ) at this point. There is no evidence for an entrance at any point. There appears to be evidence for an external ditch to the west – north-west but this is more than likely related to the possible barrow rather than the enclosure, as no definite ditch can be discerned elsewhere round the site. The interior is relatively flat at base but, due to the inward slope of the enclosing bank, the site would have a “saucer-like” profile. The interior is damp and has a heavy growth of irises. The internal dimensions of the site are 22.7m N-S and 21.5m E-W. The total dimensions of the site are 42.4m N-S and 40.9m E-W.'Description from ‘The Prehistoric Settlement of the Lee Valley, Tralee, Co. Kerry; A Landscape Perspective’ by Michael Connolly. PhD Thesis UCC 2008Date of upload: 25 June 2012

Located in level pasture, 300m E of Bushfield House, an 18th-century country house (now in ruins). This enclosure is not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch maps; it is visible in current aerial imagery.  Circular sunken area (diam. 21m) defined by a low-profile earthen bank (Wth 7m; int. H 0.9m; ext. H 0.75-0.8m). The bank has broadly slumped sides. The external slope is quite well defined, but the internal slope merging seamlessly with the shallow sunken interior. The interior is damp; there was a small pool in base  on the day of visit. Two hawthorn bushes grow on the bank, one at NE, the other at SE. This is an interesting and unusual enclosure enclosure. The fact that it is not shown on the OS maps might suggest that it is relatively recent in date, however, the broad, low bank and shallow, sunken interior suggest it might be a pond barrow.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of Upload: 11 May 2022

In pasture on the W edge of Knock village, located at the summit of a ridge with a gradual fall of ground NE–SE. The ridge commands excellent views, encompassing Croagh Patrick to W, Nephin Mountain to NW, the Ox Mountains to N, and an extensive sweep of lowlying pasture and bog to NE?SE.  Oval sunken area (31m NW–SE; 36m NE–SW) defined by a broad earthen bank (Wth 5.8m at SE, 8.7m at NW; int. H 1.4m at SE, 1.7m at NW; ext. H 0.7m at SE, 0.9m at NW). A few stones protrude randomly from the bank but do not appear to constitute a formal kerb. The bank has a broad internal slump which merges seamlessly with the sunken interior giving it a distinctly saucer-like profile. While the ridge top affords panoramic views, when one stands in the sunken interior views are significantly restricted. There are two low or eroded areas in the bank, one at E (Wth 3m), the other (Wth 2m) at ESE. Traces of cultivation ridges on NNE–SSW axis are visible in the base of the interior. A property wall, on a NW–SE axis, crosses the interior slightly N of centre. A concrete OS trigonometrical station is positioned on top of the bank at the W.   Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 23 February 2022

Situated in a wet hollow area of marshy land in upland region with higher ground to E. Large circular area (approx. diam. 35m) enclosed by a heather covered drystone wall (H 0.7m; T 0.7m) with low roughly rectangular shaped flat-topped drystone cairn (DG096-031001-) or leacht type feature located in the centre of the waterlogged interior. Local tradition asserts that this was the burial site of warriors killed in an ancient battle (pers. comm. S O'Beirne). The interior of this enclosure is very unusual in that it is very wet and marshy. The presence of so much sphagnum, which sinks down quite considerably as one walks over the surface, suggest that the original surface of the interior was much lower than the present level. It is possible that the interior of this site was slighly hollow or concave and that the field drains taking water from the mountain slope directly behind the monument have since blocked up causing the interior of this monument to become waterlogged in more recent times. There is evidence of an inner bank of earth and stone visible in the E quadrant of the interior, this feature does not fully enclose the interior. From higher ground the presence of the low cairn or leacht in the centre, the waterlogged interior, the hollow amphitheatre like location and the double enclosing feature and the possibility that the interior was once hollow or slightly concave gives the monument the appearance of a burial monument such as a possible pond barrow or some other form of unknown ritual type monument.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien Date of upload/revision: : 19 July 2010

Not indicated on any edition of the OS maps, this possible barrow was discovered in 2013 in the course of a review of LiDAR data where it is visible as a bi-vallate enclosure-like feature (diam. c. 45m). Although the remains bear a superficial resemblance to monuments of the ringfort class, it is to be noted that the inner enclosed area is almost 1m lower than the exterior ground level (pers. comm. Dr Steve Davis, UCD). In consequence, some caution is necessary in regard to classification and the remains could be interpreted as possibly falling within the pond-barrow or embanked barrow traditions. This interpretation is purely tentative and a proper elucidation of the monument must await further investigation. A second enclosure (SL008-200----) adjoins it immediately to the SE.  The attached image is uploaded courtesy of Dr. Steve Davis, UCD.  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 08 November 2013

On a slight rise in pastureland. On inspection in May 1983 this poorly preserved circular barrow (diam. 19m) was defined by a low bank  (H 0.5m above field level) with indistinct edges. Its centre was dished and was one metre below the top of the bank. On a re-inspection in April 2010 it was noted that an ESB pole had been erected at the NW limits of the site.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 16 August 2019

At the E end of a broad E-W ridge. Subcircular grass and rush-covered dished area (int. diam. 27.5 NE-SW; 23.7m NW-SE) defined by a grass-covered bank (Wth 10.5-11.3m; int. H 0.7-0.9m; ext. H 0.4-0.7m). The perimeter at NW is overlain by a NE-SW field bank and drains, and a water-tower has been built on the perimeter at W (max. ext. diam. 50m NE-SW). There is no visible entrance, and it may be a small pingo or a natural pond that is now dry.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In gently undulating, improved pasture, 30m W of a stream which also marks the townland boundary with Boherroe. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OS 25-inch map as a subcircular-shaped earthwork. Described by O’Dwyer (1959, 78) as a small circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 30ft/9m) enclosed by a broad bank (basal Wth 24ft/7.3m) with a gently sloping outer face and an almost vertical inner face (H 10ft/3m). A gap (Wth 6ft/1.8m) in the bank at E may have been the original entrance. The interior is below external ground level and is waterlogged. Possible pond barrow surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a raised circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 10m) enclosed by a bank (Wth at top 5.25-6.0m; ext. H 1.6m). The bank (ext. H 0.85m) is lower from SSE-S-SSW where it is eroded and modified by a cattle path. Pond-like interior is sunken and waterlogged and the edges are covered in dense overgrowth, restricting access. A report from Sarah McCutcheon, Limerick County Archaeologist in 2001 describes recent damage to the monument whereby the height of bank has been reduced at SE, the outer slope of the bank has been straightened from N-E-S and material removed at the base exposing the underlying material from N-E-S. Monument is visible as a roughly oval-shaped tree-planted earthwork on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached a profile of monument drawn by O’Dwyer in 1959, a sketch plan and partial cross-section which was measured and drawn by the ASI in 2008 and a Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 27 September 2020

In pasture, a ringfort (LI041-013011-) lies 15m to the NE and standing stone (LI041-013009-) lies 45m to the SW. Not depicted on the OSi historic maps. Earthwork described as a 'hollow' by Westropp (1919, 14) as located ‘56 feet [17m] to the SW’ of a ringfort (LI041-013011-) which consisted of ‘a regular shallow, oval hollow, 3 feet [0.9m] deep and 18 feet [5.4m] to 25 feet [7.6m] across.’  Monument visible as a sunken circular-shaped area on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 11/18/2018.See attached plan taken from Westropp (1916-19), and Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Fiona Rooney Date of upload: 28 July 2021See attached ASI aerial photographs ASIAP – 318/16 taken on 05/10/2002. 343/20 on 05/01/2003.

In reclaimed pasture close to the summit of a ridge (OD 680ft.) known locally as ‘Oileán na crú’.  Ringforts (LI033-021/023----) 15m to N and 70m to NE respectively.  Monument depicted on OSi 25-inch map as a sub-circular-shaped area enclosed by a bank, intersected at SW by a trackway running NW-SE.  Poorly preserved monument surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as an oval-shaped depression (dims. 6m NNE-SSW; 8m ESE-WNW) with traces of a possible bank from NNE-E.  Described in 1960 as a; ‘Platform 30 feet (9m) in diameter; has 5 foot (1.5m) wide bank.  A ditch 5 foot (1.5m) wide outside bank, and outside this ditch another 5 foot (1.5m) bank.  Both banks and ditch have a 6 foot (1.6m) gap on the east side where there is a well marked entrance running onto a platform (O’Dwyer 1960, 115; Knockroe 53). Outline of circular-shaped depression enclosed by a bank visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.     See attached Google Earth orthoimages   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 3 April 2021  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 133/03, 04 taken 23/08/2000 and 353/7 taken 05/01/2003.

In marshy pasture at S end of townland. One of three additional barrows identified by the Discovery Programme (No. 2) that formed part of a barrow cemetery that includes 13 ring-barrows (LI033-029001/017-) concentrated in three fields.   Outline of shallow depression (diam. c. 4.5m) enclosed by a bank is visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Discovery Programme aerial photograph with barrow labelled 2.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 30 March 2021

In reclaimed pasture 875m E of the summit of Derk Hill (OD 781 ft.). Fields enclosed by drainage ditches associated with estate belonging to Derk House located 650m to N.   One of a cluster of 14 barrows (LI033-036001/009-; LI033-090/091----; LI033-121/122----; LI033-154----) concentrated in the S half of Derk townland with the closest barrow (LI033-036005-) 70m to NW.   Not depicted on any OSi maps.   Surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as no surface remains visible. Not visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12.  Outline of shallow depression (diam. c. 8m) visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018 may be the remains of the possible barrow.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 30 March 2021

On undulating pasture 90m SE from the townland boundary with Cloghaderreen. One of three barrows (LI024-199001- and LI024-200----) outlying a ring-barrow cemetery (LI024-219/220----; LI024-325/-332----) 300m to W. The pond-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 9; AP 4/3626) as a circular pond-barrow (ext. diam. c. 24m). The internal pond (int. diam. c. 14m) is surrounded by an external fosse (Wth 2m) that defines the exterior of the monument. The pond-barrow is visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 9 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 9 September 2020

Visible on aerial photograph (CUCAP: AJO 21) taken in 1964, and situated on a S-facing slope. This is a circular, dished grass-covered area (diam. 13.8m N-S; 12.5m E-W; D flush at S to 1.4m at N) defined by a slight earthen bank (Wth 8m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.05m) SE-SW (downslope), which is replaced by a berm (Wth 3.6-6m) elsewhere. There is no entrance but the perimeter at E is slightly truncated by the track of a NNW-SSE relict field bank.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 4 June 2015

On a slight NW-facing slope, on the floor of a wide gently sloping NE-SW orientated valley, in low-lying wet pasture. Two ring-barrows (TS058-070001- and TS058-070002-) are located 18m to the SW and the standing stone (TS058-023004-) at Longstone is visible 1.5km to the NNE with a mound-barrow (TS058-047----) visible 750m to the SE. A circular hollow area (diam. 54m) defined by a substantial flat-topped earthen bank (overall Wth 20-21m; Wth at top 4m; int. H 1.1-2.9m; ext. H 0.7m). The bank has a very uniform profile with a flat top and the inner slope (Wth 10m) being consistently broader than the outer slope (Wth 6m). There is no entrance, however, there is a dip in the bank (Wth 3m; D 0.3m) in the NW and S quadrants where there bank has been denuded by cattle. The interior is level and waterlogged. The interior is level and waterlogged. A embanked enclosure (TS050-024----) is located 10km to the NE, it has a similar morphology but appears to have an original entrance.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 07 March 2014

On poorly drained S-facing slope of rising ground, with commanding views from E-S-W, summit of Cullaun Mountain 1km to N.  Townland boundary with Gannavane Upper lies 45m to N.  Possible ringfort (LI008-005----) lies c. 35m to NE. No antiquity is depicted at this location on the 1840 ed. OS 6-inch map. Depicted on the Cassini OSi 6-inch map as a small oval-shaped hollow, and referred to locally as a quarry (SMR File). Monument surveyed by the ASI in 1999 and described as a sunken circular-shaped area (18.9m N-S; 17.8m E-W) defined by an earthen bank (overall Wth 6.8m; Wth at top 1.2m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.6m) from NE-E-S-W-NW and by an internal scarp (H 2.2m; Wth 2m) which is almost vertical from NW-N-NE. The interior is level and is much lower than the external ground level across the N and E sectors. A field boundary running NE-SW extends from the bank at NE. Referred to locally as a quarry, although the smooth surface on its interior, presence of an enclosing bank suggests that it may be a pond barrow rather than the remains of a post-medieval quarry. Difficult to be certain about the barrow classification for this earthwork.  Visible as an oval-shaped tree-lined monument on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018. See attached sketch plan drawn and surveyed by the ASICompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 3 July 2020

Marked only on the 1930 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated at the crest of the S end of a N-S ridge at the E base of the Carnfree ridge. Circular grass-covered dished area (diam. 25.7m NW-SE; D 0.4-0.45m) defined by an earthen bank (Wth c. 2.7-3m; ext. H 0.1-0.2m) WNW-N-SE, although flush with the external ground elsewhere. There is a collapsed drystone wall and hedge on the perimeter S-WNW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the crest of the W-facing slope of a hill. Circular, grass-covered concave area (diam. 25m N-S; 24.4m E-W; D 0.8-1.3m) defined by a flat-topped earthen bank (Wth of base 4.8-7.1m; Wth of top 1.5-2.2m; ext. H 0.2-0.45m), which is surmounted by a field wall NNW-ENE. Ring-barrow (RO035-076----) is c. 50m to the SW and embanked barrow (RO035-078----) is c. 50m to the S. Rath (RO035-079----) is c. 120m to the NNE.  See the attached aerial images taken from the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on a rise on a slight W-facing slope. This enclosure is not depicted on any map but is visible on Google Earth (16/03/2011) and was first reported by Rob O’Hara. It is a circular grass-covered area (int. diam. 22.5m E-W; 19m N-S) defined by a wide earthen bank (Wth of base 10-13m; int. H 0.2-0.3m normally to 0.8m at N; ext. H 0.2m at E to 0.5-0.8m normally). There is no identifiable entrance. The standing stone (RO045-068----) is c. 180m to the SW.  See the attached enhanced view from Google Earth (01/03/2010) Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 25 February 2020Amended: 8 September 2020

In improved pasture, on a low rise. Monument identified during ASI fieldwork. A sunken, circular area (dims. 14m NNW-SSE; 13m ENE-WSW) defined by scarp (Wth 1.5m; H 0.15m) SSW-NE, low bank (Wth 4.5m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.17m) NE-ENE and WSW-WNW; Levelled ESE-SSW. The interior has a prevalent SSE-facing slope and the NE quadrant is higher than the rest of the interior. Enclosure (TS059-079----) is c. 42m NNW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

Located on a break in a N-facing slope in wet, upland terrain. A circular depression (diam. 24m N-S; 21m E-W) enclosed by a broad, flat bank (Wth 3.6m; int. H 0.35m; ext. H 0.18m). An old, low, earthen field bank extends N-S through the S half of the site. The interior is very wet and has been badly eroded by cattle. There is a small circular enclosure (diam. 13m) adjoining the NW quadrant. It is enclosed by a very low earthen bank except where it shares the pond barrow's bank.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated on the summit of a natural rise, close to the W edge of a gradual fall, overlooking a valley at the base of the slope. The site consists of a flat central area (14.3m N-S; 15m E-W) enclosed by a compact earthen bank (Wth 2.3m; int. H 0.35-0.55m; ext. H 0.18-0.35m), less visible at S. An entrance gap (Wth 3m) is visible at ESE. There is a small standing stone (TN039-011002-) in the interior in the SW sector with a second stone (TN039-011003-) standing at the entrance at ESE, in line with the outer edge of the bank.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated atop low rise of ground with good views in all directions, bullaun stone (WM036-038----) in same field c. 70m to NE.  Circular-shaped sunken area (diam. 17m; D 0.4m) enclosed by a low poorly preserved earthen bank (Wth. 5m; ext. H 0.2m), no entrance feature visible.  There has been some dumping of material inside the centre of the possible barrow.   See attached Bing Maps aerial photograph taken November 2011 which shows outline of possible pond barrow, taken from www.bing.com/maps/.   Compiled by: Caimin O’Brien  Date of upload: 11 August 2014

In wet, low-lying pasture. A circular, saucer-shaped depression (diam. 12.8m; D 0.45m) enclosed by a wide, low bank of earth and stone (Wth 5.95m; H 0.45m) with an external fosse (Wth 3.6m; D 0.5m). From SSW-W-WNW the outer face of the bank and the fosse have been modified and incorporated into a field boundary. From E-S-SW the fosse has been infilled and its outline is barely identifiable. The original entrance is not recognisable. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Located on top of high ground in mountainous area with good views in all directions. One of a group of 5 barrows (OF038-008001/002/003/004-) located in close proximity to each other.  According to local tradition these barrows are located on a hilltop which was the inauguration site of the O’Flanagans of Cinél Arga (Feehan 1979, 143).  It is possible that these burial mounds form part of a ritual landscape associated with this inauguration site.     Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 09 August 2012

Situated at the N edge of a col between Cnoiceen Hill to the SW and the Monavullagh Mountains to the E. This is a circular dished grass-covered area (diam. 24.5m) with some heather and ferns defined by an earth and stone bank (Wth 2.2-4.3m; int. H 0.3-05m; max. ext. ext. H 0.3-0.5m but 1.3m at N) S-N-SE, which is reduced to a scarp down to the interior SE-S. A gap at SW (Wth 0.7m) may be original but a gap at NE (Wth 4.5m) is not. (Moore 1995, 210, 213, 220-23, 243, Q3)  This monument forms part of the national monument complex at Coumaraglinmountain (National Monuments (Preservation) Order No. 4 of 1996).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 29 April 2011

National Monument in State Ownership No. 155.  Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 51) as following: 'Subcircular enclosure delimited by a broad, low bank  (Diam.  22.7m N-S x  25.5m E-W) surrounding a hollowed-out area roughly centred on an enormous, fragmentary limestone boulder (H. c. 4.5m) known as the ‘Catstone’, which is 3.7m from the bank where this is closest on SW side; interior reaches below external ground level and has presumably been excavated to gather material for the bank, and possibly to expose the lower part of the Catstone, as was suggested to Borlase by a local labourer. Monument is located in rough pastureland that slopes down steeply from NE to SW, the slope including both surrounding bank and hollowed interior. Bank ranges from 4.4m to 4.6m in width and reaches up to 1.36m above interior ground-level immediately inside high E side; although on SE side, where bank is prominent, it rises 2.1m above that part of interior immediately adjacent to Catstone; bank reaches up to  0.54m in height above external ground level but may be higher on overgrown S side, where ground falls away sharply.   This is the ‘Catstone’, a recent name derived from its supposed appearance. A cylindrical hole visible in the top of the central boulder was clearly intended to support the flag-pole which Macalister and Praeger say was erected on it in its capacity as a recent ‘centre for political and other meetings’. For the historical and mythic significance of this ancient and important monument marking the traditional centre of Ireland, and named variously as Aill na Mireann or ‘Rock of the Divisions’, Petram Coithrigi (Tírechán) and Umbilicus Hiberniæ (Giraldus Cambrensis), see Macalister and Praeger (1928, 78-80) and Schot (2006, 40-41).  Dr Cyril Fox, director of the National Museum of Wales, who assisted with the Uisneach excavations, suggested to Macalister and Praeger that the embanked enclosure ‘might have been added to the Catstone stone in order to produce an artificial resemblance to an umbilicus, thus linking the boulder to the Omphalos cult at Delphi and elsewhere’ (Macalister and Praeger 1928, 78). Certainly, as Schot demonstrates with an aerial photograph, it has the appearance of a navel from the air. Among early references to the site, Tírechán in his seventh-century Life of St. Patrick claims that the saint was here with ‘pilgrims’ (peregrini), apparently with the intention of founding a church, and that he met one of the sons of the progenitor of the Cenél Fiachach, Fíachu mac Néill, at the sone. In the Tripartite Life the saint actually founds a monastery at Uisneach: Macalister and Praeger suggest a ringfort c. 200m to SE (WM024-069----) as the site of the saint’s foundation. There are references in Camden to a Bishopric ‘of Meath or Elnamirand [Aill na Mireann]’ (Macalister and Praeger 1928, 78-80; Herity 2011, 81; Bieler 1979, 136-7).  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

On a low hillock in undulating pasture with good views in all directions. Depicted as ‘Mass Fort’ on the townland map of Ballybrien surveyed c. 1789 (NLI, MS 21 F. 40 (24)). A circular, concave depression (diam. 38.5m) is enclosed by a wide, flat-topped, tree-lined bank of earth and stone (base Wth 9.5–14m; top Wth 3m;  int. H 2–3m; ext. H 1–1.5m) with traces of a shallow, external fosse. The outer face of the bank was faced with drystone masonry possibly in the 18th or 19th century. The monument was used as a penal mass site (O’Donovan 2003, 17). See also (LF011-008----), which has similar morphological features.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan, Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 26 November 2012

On a gentle NE-facing slope, c. 55m to the NE of a standing stone (LF011-010----). A stone circle (LF011-007----) is c. 840m to the WNW. A concave, circular area (base diam. 12m; max. diam. 30.9m) enclosed by a wide and much-denuded, low bank of earth and stone (base Wth 13.4m; top Wth 7m; H 0.2m) with a wide, shallow, external fosse (base Wth 6m; top Wth 19.3m; D 0.25m). The surface of the concave area is between 0.25m (NNE) and 1.3m (SSE) below the external ground level and is similar morphologically to the possible pond-barrow (LF010-073----) at Ballybrien.Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 14 November 2011

In the Nore river valley, in tillage. There are a number of ring-ditches in the vicinity (KK010-053001- to KK010-053003-; KK010-054----; KK010-055001- to KK055-010----; KK010-142----; KK010-152----; KK010-162---- and KK010-187----).  Identified as a circular feature (diam. c. 10m) on an aerial photograph (CUCAP BGG047, 16 July 1971). However, this is not a cropmark enclosure but more likely a depression. Considering its location within a ring-ditch complex, it is possible that this may be a small pond barrow.Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 11 December 2018

On the summit of Knockmonaster Hill overlooking Fore Benedictine Abbey (WM004-035010-).  Described by McGuinness (2019, 51) as following; 'It comprises an annular bank, very slightly subcircular, which surrounds a sunken, dished interior (Diam. (overall) c. 11.5m N- x c. 11.10m E-; Diam. (interior) 6.5m N- x 5.6m E-). Height of bank over interior at cardinal points varies from 0.12m (E) to 0.21m (N) to 0.34m (S) to 0.41m (W). Although, as with the closely similar monument at Clonydonnin (No. 6), outer edge of bank blends almost seamlessly with external ground level, it is clearest and best preserved at SSE where its width and height over external ground level can be estimated as 2.5m and 0.37m respectively; and while the same ambiguity prevents an accurate depth measurement of the interior with reference to external ground level, it certainly has the appearance of falling below ground level. Near the centre of the monument is a large, overgrown and apparently earthfast boulder (L. 1.05m; W. 0.70m; H. 0.35m).  Monument is prominently positioned on summit of the low but striking Knocknamonaster Hill, some 54m to SE of a possible mound-barrow (No. 12) and some 12.5m to ESE of a dead-ice hollow, the low rim of which faces NW.   The earthwork is clearly visible on Google Earth aerial photographs taken 05/10/2009 and the two earthworks identified by McGuinness as possible barrows was surveyed and drawn by the ASI in the 1970s.    See attached Google earth aerial photograph showing possible site and earthwork plan surveyed and drawn by the ASI which shows the hollow feature.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 21 February 2020

Situated on a N-facing slope, just below the summit of a steep rise, in undulating pasture, with extensive views in all directions. Depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map and the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map as a small, circular-shaped earthwork. Monument described as a circular-shaped round-bottomed depression (dims. 12m E-W; 11.7m N-S), which has been scooped out of a natural rise and is defined by a bank and a fosse. The earthen bank is well preserved and there is a narrow, shallow, steep-sided outer fosse. There is no recognisable entrance. Monument is visible today as a small circular-shaped tree-planted earthwork on Digital Globe aerial photography.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin O’Brien.  Date of upload: 06 November 2019

In open level wet rough pasture. An oval, wet, pond-like area (int. diams. 23.3m NNW-SSE; 18m NNW-SSE) is defined by a low, very broad, denuded earthen bank (Wth 3.3 - 10m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.1 - 0.5m) densely overgrown with whins WNW-N. Two possible ring-barrows lie nearby; KD027-043---- c. 50m to the ENE and KD027-044---- c. 65m to the ESE.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy   Date of upload: 26 October 2012

Located on the summit of a NW-SE ridge, it is described as a ‘Fort’ but not represented within a rectangular wood on the 1836 and 1912 editions of the OS 6-inch map but the wood has been removed without trace. This is a circular, slightly dished (D 0.4-0.6m) and grass-covered area (diam. 18m N-S; 18m E-W) with some tree-stumps defined by a wide earthen bank (Wth of base 4-8m; int. H 0.4-1.2m; ext. H 0.9m). There is no visible fosse or entrance.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 22 February 2019

This site commands an extensive view W and SW towards the Blasket islands from its bleak and windswept location just E of the summit of Mám Clasach, a high mountain pass between Croaghmarhin and Coumaleague hill. A sub-circular area, c. 17m N-S and 20m E-W, is enclosed by a shallow fosse, 1 to 2.5m wide and no more than .4m deep, and an external bank rising a maximum of 1m internally and .8m externally; the overall dimensions are c. 38m E-W and 35m N-S. Two opposed entrances provide access to the interior from E and W. That to W is 2.1m wide and provided with a narrow causeway leading across the fosse; that to E is 3.6m wide and opens directly onto the bottom of the fosse. Immediately N of this latter entrance the bank appears to have been disturbed.The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 253. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

The ring-barrow located on the sandy pasture land behind and overlooking Ventry strand has been severely disturbed by rabbit burrowing and by a disused field fence which runs onto the bank at E, and its outline is very irregular. It consists of an external bank up to .75m high, an inner fosse c. 6m wide, and a central mound which rises c. 0.75m above the fosse and which is c. 7m in diameter across its upper surface; the overall dimensions of the site are c. 40m N-S and 35m E-W. There are 3 major breaks through the bank; that to NNW is possibly original, but the others are apparently due to more recent disturbance. About 10 to 20m to S is a ringfort (KE052-044----).The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 254. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

This is one of a group of 2 or possibly 3 (KE042-147---- and KE042-139----) similar monuments on the S slopes of an E-W spur of Lateevemore, overlooking Ventry Harbour. A low, roughly circular mound, measuring 7.7m N-S and 8.1m E-W, is surrounded by a fosse, 1 to 2m in width, and an external bank, the overall diameter being c. 16m. Due to its position on a sloping hillside, the bank rises only .15 to .2m externally on the N side, but reaches a maximum height of .6m on the downslope side; internally the bank height varies from .3m to 1m. The central mound rises a maximum of .6m above the fosse. Access to the interior is by means of 2 opposed entrances to E and W, the E gap now 5 to 6m wide due to disturbance. The W gap is more clearly defined, with a single course of stones, .1m high, lining its S edge. In the vicinity of the E gap the fosse is almost non-existent, possibly indicating a causeway, while to W the fosse is only a few cms in depth. There is a slight trace of possible stone revetting to the external face of the bank at NW.The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 250. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

Located about 150m E of KE042-138----, this site consists of a bank and internal fosse enclosing a low central mound, with opposed entrances to E and W, the overall diameter being c. 18 to 19m. Stones have been quarried from the interior (local information) and the mound, once probably circular, now measures c. 7.4m N-S x 10m E-W. The fosse is shallow, varying in depth from .1 to .3m and in width from .5 to 1.5m. For a short stretch to S the bank is represented only by a scarp falling .75m to the exterior, but it reaches a maximum internal height of 1.15m immediately N of the E entrance. Along the N portion of the bank, for a distance of 8m, the external face, here .25m high, is revetted with low drystone walling. The entrance gaps measure 2.25m and 2m wide respectively. There are no clearly defined causeways across the fosse, but the recent disturbance could have obscured these features if they formerly existed.The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 252. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

Uphill of KE042-147----, at a distance of about 200m, is a stony platform defined along its S side by a steep drop of c. 3m; it measures c. 11m E-W. Two trackways leading E from the site have disturbed it considerably and classification is uncertain. However it was described as being similar to KE042-138---- and KE042-147---- (local information).The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 255. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

Situated in rough pasture on a gentle ESE facing slope of Lateevemore, commanding an extensive view, particularly SE towards Dingle Harbour. A circular platform, 12m in diameter, is enclosed by a fosse, 1.5m wide, and an external bank c. 3m wide, the overall diameter averaging 23m. The bank measures c. 0.45m high externally, .9 to 1.1m high internally, and the platform rises about .25m above the base of the fosse. Two causewayed entrances, to ESE and WNW, provide access to the interior, that to WNW varying in width from 1.1m at the middle to 2m at either end, that to ESE being somewhat disturbed but measuring 1.7m to 2m in width. The latter causeway is raised very slightly above the level of the field beyond, and a large stone is visible at its NE edge; it is unclear whether or not this latter is naturally positioned. A number of disused field boundaries occur to N and W of the site, and the exterior of the bank at N has been disturbed by one of these, possibly even providing some of the material for its construction. 9.5m to N is a possible standing stone (KE043-123001-) .7m high and .75m wide, its long axis aligned ESE-WNW. About 150m to E is a 2nd larger standing stone (KE043-124----).The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 251. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

Between Lateevemore and Knockavrogeen is a small valley through which a tributary of the Milltown river flows SE towards Dingle Harbour. This site commands an excellent view from the steep slopes on the SW side of the valley, and a similar site (KE043-123----) lies about 600m to NW at the head of the valley. A sub-circular platform, 6m in diameter, is enclosed by a fosse and external bank. The fosse is 2m wide, .6m deep below the central platform, and 1.3m deep below the crest of the bank. The latter is 3.5m wide and c. 1m high above the external ground level. The site measures c. 20 to 27m in overall diameter. The SE portion of the bank has been replaced by a field boundary which appears to follow the former line of this feature; further damage to the site, including breaks in the bank, has been caused by animal traffic. However, 2 opposed entrances at E and W may be original. The gap in the bank at W is 2.5m wide, and a poorly preserved causeway, 1.4m wide, leads across the fosse to the central platform. No causeway is evident in the vicinity of the E gap but, as the bank to S of this has been removed, and the area is somewhat disturbed, it is possible that one formerly existed. A low standing stone (KE043-128----) is located 75m to SW in the adjacent field.The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 249. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

This site is located on the lower NE slopes of Bentee mountain and commands a fine view of the estuary of the Ferta river to N. An almost oval-shaped area, measuring 6.2m N-S x 7.2m E-W, is enclosed by a fosse and by a poorly preserved external bank. The overall diameter of the site averages 12m. The bank is best preserved at W, where it measures 1.6m wide and rises .25m externally. The fosse is flat-bottomed, varies in width from 1.3m to 2.5m, and averages .5m below the interior of the monument. The site's interior slopes steeply downwards to N. There is no apparent entrance to the site.The above description is derived from A. O'Sullivan and J. Sheehan (compilers), 'The Iveragh peninsula: an archaeological survey of South Kerry'. Cork University Press (1996), no. 441. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload: 28 July 2013

A short distance E of KE079-121---- is a second well-preserved ring-barrow. It consists of a subcircular area, 5.2m in diameter E-W, which is enclosed by a fosse, measuring 1.2m wide and up to .7m deep, and by an external bank. The bank is not preserved on the uphill, S side of the site. It rises at N to a maximum external height of .75m, where it features a possible causewayed entrance, 1.6m wide. The overall diameter of the monument averages 12.25m.The above description is derived from A. O'Sullivan and J. Sheehan (compilers), 'The Iveragh peninsula: an archaeological survey of South Kerry'. Cork University Press (1996), no. 442. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload: 30 July 2013

In rough pasture, on a N-facing slope overlooking Ballydonegan Bay. An uneven and disturbed circular area (diam. 8m) enclosed by the remains of a fosse (Wth 1-1.2m; D 0.2-0.5m) with a damaged external bank (Wth 2.5-3.5m; ext. H 0.1-0.5m). There are breaks in the bank at E and W. A number of small mounds appear along the edge of the interior, giving the impression of the remains of an inner bank. However it is likely that they may have resulted from site disturbance. There are some field-clearance stones on the ring-barrow and it is partially covered by long grass and overgrowth. There is an embanked barrow (CO127-036----) c. 3km to the SE.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 5' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2009).  Date of upload: 22 December 2009

The small enclosure marked on the OS maps and named 'Fort' on the OS Fair Plan was levelled about 1980. It consisted of a low mound surrounded by a fosse and low external bank (information: T. Creedon), and its outline is still discernible as a cropmark. This latter indicates a diameter of about 12.5m from the outer edges of the fosse and an internal diameter of c. 7.7m. The land in the immediate vicinity is fairly level but falls away E and S towards the Emlagh river.The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 256. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

About 275m E of KE045-036----, across a small tributary of the Emlagh river, a similar embanked enclosure was levelled during removal of the adjacent field fences (local information).The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 257. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

A low upright stone stood on a very slight circular mound here, on the S slopes of the central mountain ridge overlooking the Emlagh river valley. It was located about 450m N of KE045-040----. It was .51m high and measured .82m x .16m at base. In 1983 the field was ploughed and the stone removed. This revealed a 2 to 3m wide band of dark soil encircling the mound which was 3 to 4m in diameter. This band was clearly distinguished from the lighter coloured soil of the mound and the surrounding field and may indicate the former presence of a fosse.The above description is derived from J. Cuppage, ‘Corca Dhuibhne. Dingle Peninsula archaeological survey. Ballyferriter. Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne’ (1986), no. 258. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 4 August 2013

This site is located on a low rise in boggy pasture on the W side of the Ardsheelhane river valley. It is marked on the second edition of the OS map as a small univallate enclosure, and consists of an overgrown sub-circular area, 5.2m N-S x 6.5m E-W, which is enclosed by a fosse and an external bank. Access to the interior is provided by a narrow causeway, 2.3m wide, which crosses the fosse at NE. The entrance gap through the bank is defined by two slabs set on edge. The bank survives best at S, where it measures 1.5m high externally and rises to a maximum height of .85m above the flat-bottomed, 1.2m wide, fosse.The above description is derived from A. O'Sullivan and J. Sheehan (compilers), 'The Iveragh peninsula: an archaeological survey of South Kerry'. Cork University Press (1996), no. 439. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload: 28 July 2013

Situated on the gentle S-facing slope of a coastal ridge in a boggy area used for grazing with good views E to NW. A fairly well-preserved circular area (20.1m N-S; 19.5m E-W) with a central flat mound (12m N-S; 13m E-W; H 0.3m), a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 0.8-1.2m) and a well-defined outer bank (Wth 3.5m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.2-0.5). There is a causewayed entrance (Wth 3m) at E and the fosse is waterlogged to N and S of this. A small water-filled hollow (Wth 1.8m; D 0.5m) is located near the centre but does not appear to be contemporary. Another ring-barrow (CL065-109002-) lies 75m to SE and a third (CL065-109003-) lay c. 140m to SE but the third one has been destroyed by quarrying at the adjacent promontory fort (CL065-027----).  The following images have been uploaded: CL065-109001-_01.jpg View of ring-barrow from S. CL065-109001-_02.jpg View from NW. CL065-109001-_03.jpg View of entrance feature at E.  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 3/2002).  Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 11 March 2019

Situated on the gentle S-facing slope of a coastal ridge in pasture immediately N of a promontory fort (CL065-027----). One of three ring-barrows visited in May 1992 (pers. comm. Markus Casey, SMR file). On inspection in 2003 it was noted that this area was quarried away as part of extensive quarrying at the adjacent promontory fort. It is possible that spoil heaps immediately N of the quarried area are covering the monument. The other two ring-barrows (CL065-109002- and CL065-109001-) are extant (in 2019) and lie 65m to N and 140m to NNW respectively.  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 3/2002).  Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 11 March 2019

Situated on the gentle S-facing slope of a coastal ridge in a boggy area used for grazing with good views E to NW. The poorly preserved remains of a ring-barrow comprising an almost circular area (17.6m N-S; 21.2m E-W) with a central flat mound (12.5m N-S; 14m E-W) a fosse (Wth 1m) and an outer bank (Wth 3m). The outer bank is reduced to a scarp at W (H 0.5m) and is damaged at N and SW where there are trackways. There is an entrance (Wth 2.4m) at W. Another ring-barrow (CL065-109001-) lies 75m to NW and a third (CL065-109003-) lay c. 65m to S but the third one has been destroyed by quarrying at the adjacent promontory fort (CL065-027----).  The following images have been uploaded: CL065-109002-_01.jpg View of ring-barrow from W. CL065-109002-_02.jpg View of entrance feature at W.  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 3/2002).  Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 11 March 2019

Possible barrow surrounding a standing stone described by Lynch (1892, 80-3) as follows; 'Mr. B. M'Elligott, a farmer in that neighbourhood, was employed with some workmen in widening the old road which passes near the gallaun [KE020-020001-]. In the course of his work, within about 3 feet [0.9m] of the rut of the old road, and about 2 feet [0.6m] below the surface, he found some small and thin flags of limestone, on removing which he found they covered a grave or tomb [KE020-020003-] lined at the sides with flags of the same kind as those covering it.  The grave was about 2 feet [0.6m] wide, and as far as he examined it about 2 feet [0.6m] long, lying east and west.  The grave lay within about 80 yards [73m] of the conspicuous gallaun or pillar stone [KE020-020001-] which crowns the highest point of the limestone ridge that runs east and west for some miles through the plains of Clanmaurice.  The townland around the gallaun is known as Ardconnel (the height of Conal), and I have no doubt that this Ardconnel is the very ancient Ardconail mentioned in the "Book of Rights" as the site of one of the Portaibh or Royal seats of the Kings of Cashel. This pillar stone, which is a very remarkable one, visible from every point of the compass for many miles, consists of a block of whinstone, 8 feet [2.4m] high over the present surface, about 3 feet [0.9m] broad, and 15 inches [0.4m] thick, must have been brought from the cliffs near Kerry Head, about 9 miles distant, where stones of that kind are found in large quantities. This may have been the monumental stone of the illustrious chief Conal, whose name is thus preserved by the townland designation, but of whose name and fame history and legend are silent.  The gallaun [KE020-020001-] is surrounded by a shallow trench and embankment forming a circle about 40 yards [36m] in diameter'.Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 13 June 2022

In 1939 notes by Capt. D. B. O'Connell, attached with a letter to Harold G. Leask states=d that the 'fine ''cup-barrow'' and the gallaun on the summit are still there.' The standing stone in question appears to be KE020-020001-.  Outline of possible ring-barrow visible to SW of ring-barrow (KE020-020002-) and standing stone (KE020-020003-) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages.See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 13 June 2022

This monument is located on the crest of a low ridge which runs parallel to the River Blackwater. About 100m to N is a standing stone (KE091-043002-), while in the bog at E are a number of relatively modern fionnán enclosures. The ring-barrow survives as a well-preserved, level, circular area, c. 7.5m in diameter, which is defined by a fosse and an external earthen bank. The fosse is 1.1m wide and averages .7m deep, while the bank ranges from 1.2m to 2.5m wide and averages .8m high externally. The overall diameter of the site averages 15m. Access to the interior is by means of two opposed causewayed entrances at E and W. The gap in the bank at E, 2.15m wide, is flanked on either side by a slab set on edge, while two large slabs, which now lie prostrate on the S edge of the causeway at W, may have originally flanked the 2.5m wide entrance here. Both causeways are well-defined and average 2m wide.The above description is derived from A. O'Sullivan and J. Sheehan (compilers), 'The Iveragh peninsula: an archaeological survey of South Kerry'. Cork University Press (1996), no. 440. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload: 28 July 2013

This site is situated at the top of a large pastoral field. It consists of a circular mound enclosed by a well-defined inner fosse and earthen bank. It had an overall external diameter of 37m. The inner circular area is platformed and the external height above the fosse varies between 1m-1.8m. The internal diameter E-W of the inner area measures 14m, while the external diameter measures 17.8m. The width of the fosse on average measures 5m. The surrounding earthen bank measures between 4m to 6m in width at the base of the bank, the external height of the bank measures 1.2m, while the internal height above the fosse measured 1.6m.From the N through E to SE the outer bank has been completely levelled and the fosse is difficult to determine. There are two breaks in the outer bank, one to the SE, the other SW, both of which measure c 2m in width.This could possibly be the site that Ó Ríordáin partly excavated (1943). He noted some stones that were possibly the remains of a kerb. Some cremated bones were found and they would appear to have been protected by three stone slabs. Also found were two flint flakes.The above description is derived from C. Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 100. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

The land is quite marshy and wet and is used as rough grazing for cattle at the moment. Several low banks of earth and stone also occur in this complex, but, as yet, their relationship to the barrows is unknown. Located on the west bank of a small river which is prone to flooding, c.200m from the coast in an area of marshy grassland...... situated in the same field as the previous two barrows [KE038-138----, KE038-139----], this site occurs c.60m to the west of the River Lee, this circular barrow has been partially disturbed by a field fence which ran in an E-W direction through the middle of the enclosure. Only the lowest course of the fence now survives, the boundary having been removed since being recorded on the OS 2nd Ed. Map. A sizable chunk of the barrow, approximately 2.50m by 2.50m has also been removed on its south east side in an attempt to quarry rock and stone from the area. Total dimensions of the site are 23.0m N-S by 23.0m E-W. The enclosing bank has an average width of 3.00m, and has a maximum external height of 0.80m at south, average height being 0.40m. An inner ditch, averaging 2.50m in width, encloses a circular central platform 10.0m in diameter and 0.35m high. This ditch is 0.40m below the crest of the bank and is 0.35m below the level of the central platform.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 30 April 2012

In rough grazing on E-facing slope. Circular area (11.15m N-S; 10.55m E-W ) enclosed by fosse (D 0.6m) with external earthen bank (H 0.8m). Entrance (Wth 2.55m) with causeway across fosse at E. Interior level, with central stone-lined cist (1.6m E-W; 0.7m N-S). The E end-stone and the capstone of the cist are missing.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

Test excavations took place prior to application for full planning permission for a house. The site had been noted from an aerial photograph, and could also be seen on the ground at the time of the excavation. It is in low-lying pasture, with a moderate view all around but particularly uphill to the south.  It measures 15.7m north-south 14.6m east-west approx. and consists of a slightly raised interior, c 11m in diameter, and a slight external ditch. Prior to the commencement of this excavation, engineers' test-pits been dug at the northern and southern ends of the monument. To minimise further destruction, Trench 1 (19.2m long in total) was dug from 3m to the north of the site, through the pit to the north and southwards through the centre ofthe site, with a dog-leg to the west to avoid the second pit, as it was found that the stratigraphy was too disturbed in these areas to be of archaeological use. The main feature noted was the fosse, 1.7m wide and at least 0.84m deep. It was not bottomed as this was merely a test excavation to confirm the presence of the monument. Much charcoal was present in the layers investigated but there were no finds. Apart from two possible areas of burning within the monument, there were no other features noted in this trench. Trench 2 ran for 37m in a north-west/south-east direction to the north east of the site. Another possible area of burning or perhaps the base of a small pit was found in the trench, and a narrow U-bottomed fosse/ditch, 0.8m wide and 0.75m deep, was also sectioned. One of its layers was again very charcoal-rich. The monument straddled the development site in question, and that adjacent to it to the west, but investigation took place only within the area defined in the planning application.'   Description from ‘The Prehistoric Settlement of the Lee Valley, Tralee, Co. Kerry; A Landscape Perspective’ by Michael Connolly. PhD Thesis UCC 2008  Date of upload: 22 June 2012

This barrow lies in a field of reclaimed grassland on a ridge in the foothills of the Slieve Mish mountains, which affords superb views in all directions. This site has now all but been obliterated, and is visible as little more than a cropmark. It is almost circular, measuring 23.0m N-S by 21.0m E-W, although the eastern side of this site has been almost completely destroyed. Remains of a central platform can be seen, 0.10m in height and 12.0m in diameter. This is surrounded by a ditch, 2.50m in average width and is 0.01m below the level of the platform. This ditch is visible as a dark green ring of grass. Enclosing this is the remains of a bank 0.01m in height and averaging 3.00m in width. The crest of this bank is 0.01m above the bottom of the ditch. It is unlikely that any trace of this site will survive the intensive agriculture carried out on this farm, as this ring barrow has now been almost completely obliterated. Any further attempted reclamation of this field, which is still a little marshy and wet, will remove the last traces of this site.'  Description from ‘The Prehistoric Settlement of the Lee Valley, Tralee, Co. Kerry; A Landscape Perspective’ by Michael Connolly. PhD Thesis UCC 2008  Date of upload: 20 June 2012

This is the first of a pair of ring-barrows, the second of which lies immediately N. Although half of this site has been completely ploughed out, a small section of the external bank, fosse and inner area survives, to the N through W to SW. The external height of the bank measures 1.2m, the width of the bank at the base measures 4.4m and the internal height of the bank measures .8m. The width of the fosse measures 1.6m and .6m below the internal area.The above description is derived from C. Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 90. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

This site, the second of the pair, is in an excellent state of preservation. It consists of a circular area measuring 7.4m N-S enclosed by a fosse and external earthen bank. The external height of the bank measures 1.7m, the width of the bank at the base measures 4.7m, and the internal height rises to a maximum of 1.5m above the fosse. Access to the interior is gained by an entrance to the SE; the gap is 3.2m wide and has a causeway leading across the fosse, which measures 1.6m wide.The above description is derived from C. Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 91. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

This site is marked on the OS maps as 'Kilbrickaun fort' (Cill Bhreacáin - church of Breacán (personal name - saint)). A low, roughly circular mound measuring 17.2m N-S and 16.6m E-W is surrounded by a fosse ranging between 3m to 5m in width and an external earthen bank. In the centre of the interior some mounds are to be noted, and one of these produced burnt earth and stones. The overall dimensions of this site measure 39m N-S and 39.8m E-W.The above description is derived from C. Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 89. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

This barrow is to be found on top of a low spur of limestone outcrop in an area of marginal land at the lowest foothills of the Slieve Mish mountains. The site affords panoramic views from north through west to south. This barrow has been partially denuded and consists of a low bank and internal ditch enclosing a low central mound. The enclosing bank is 6.00m in width and has an external height of 0.50m. The ditch has an average width of 3.00m and is 0.30m below the top of the bank. The central platform is sub-circular and measures 10.0m E-W by 8.00m N-S and is 0.30m above the level of the ditch. The bank appears to be constructed of a mixture of earth and stone. Total dimensions of the site are 28.0m N-S by 25.0m E-W.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 03 May 2012

Located in a reclaimed field on the immediate north side of the River Lee is the remains of a partially destroyed ring-barrow. Only the northern half of this barrow survives, the southern half obviously being destroyed by the extensive reclaimation which has occurred in this field. The remains of several field drains can be seen crossing the area. Despite the intense reclaimation the field is still quite wet, and probably prone to flooding. Most of the internal platform survives and measures 15m E-W. It is enclosed by a fosse and external bank, which survive from east through north to north-west. The fosse is 2.00m wide and 0.30m below the central platform, and 0.40m below the crest of the bank. This bank has a maximum width on its eastern side of 3.00m with an external height of 0.40m. A total diameter can be gauged from N/W to S/E where the site measures 22m. Though partially levelled, enough above ground remains are visible to allow this to be identified as a ring-barrow. No entrance was apparent.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 02 May 2012

The external diameter of this ring-barrow measures 17m N-S. It consists of a circular mound averaging .5m high, surrounded by an internal fosse 1.8m in width and .5m deep and an external earthen bank rising to a maximum height of 1m internally and .8m externally. Access to the interior is gained by a causeway to the E which is 1.8m wide. In the centre of the interior is a depression .75m x 2.3m which reveals some stones.The above description is derived from C. Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 85. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

Located in gently sloping hillside immediately to the east of a plantation of trees known as Monument Wood, this barrow lies in a field devoted to the growth of grass for the purposes of silage making. A  circular platform 17.0m in diameter is enclosed by a fosse 4.00m wide and an external bank 6.00m in width, the overall diameter averaging 37.0m.The bank measures 0.30m above external ground surface, 0.40m internally with the central platform rising c.0.30m above the base of the fosse. No entrance was apparent. Its location in a field which has obviously undergone quite a lot of cultivation  would explain the  rather denuded state of the site.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 03 May 2012
See field inspection report (diary NF6, 130-9) (SMR file).  This record was formerly classed as an enclosure. Following a site inspection its class has been changed to ring-barrow.

This site, situated on poor land sloping in a NE direction, consists of a raised circular area enclosed by a fosse and external earthen bank. The internal circular area measures c26m N-S and 28m E-W and its maximum height above the fosse is 8m. There is a break in the internal area S through SW. In the E sector of the interior is a small mound lined with stones, possibly indicating a burial site, measuring 1m x 1.8m. A section of the internal area has been completely levelled to the S through SW.The internal fosse survives as a well-defined, shallow, flat-bottomed ditch. However, to the NW, S, and SW it is difficult to distinguish: firstly, because of a field fence that cuts through the NW sector of this site, and secondly because the internal area S and SW has been levelled. Overall the width of the fosse ranges between 3m and 4m.The outer earthen bank encloses the whole interior area except to the NW, where it has been cut by a fieldbank. It ranges between 2m and 4m in width at the base. It has a maximum internal height above the fosse of 1.2m and the external height of the bank measures 1.4m. The entrance would appear to lie to the SE, where it measures 4m in width.The above description is derived from C. Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 97. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

Ring-barrow described by Connolly (2000, 46) as follows; 'This site is marked as an enclosure on the Sites & Monuments Record for County Kerry (KE030-002----) but is in fact a ring-barrow. It consists of a circular central platform 12m in diameter and rising to a height of 2m above the base of the encircling ditch. The ditch is on average 3m in width and the remains of the enclosing bank can be seen to north and south where they remain to an average height of 1m and a maximum width of 4m'.  Outline of ring-barrow visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13.Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 23 June 2022

Situated at the base of a S facing slope in poorly drained pasture.  Possible ring-barrow (overall diam. 35m N-S x 37.5m E-W) described by the Castleisland District Archaeological Survey as a circular-shaped area (diam. 25.9m N-S x 27.5m E-W) defined by a fosse, bank, external fosse and possible outer bank.  Outline of monument clearly visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 7 June 2022

Situated on a prominent hilltop ridge in an area devoted to rich pasture, and located on  the immediate east side of a north/south field boundary, this circular barrow has been partially levelled in the past few years. As it has been flattened, the dimensions may be somewhat distorted. The central platform is much denuded, but still visible as a low circular mound 12.0m N-S by 12.0m E-W, and is 0.20m above the level of the surrounding fosse. This fosse is an average of 3.00m wide and is 0.40m below the crest of the bank. This bank  has an  average width of  5.00m, and survives to an average height of 0.40m above exterior ground level, although it does attain a maximum height of 0.50m at north.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 4 May 2012

This site was recorded as an earthwork in the Sites & Monuments Record for County Kerry (KE030-010----), however the site would appear to be a very denuded ring-barrow. The landowner indicated that the site had been substantially levelled around 50 years ago but stated that it had consisted of a central platform “about 4.5 feet in height with a ditch around the outside”. Traces of this barrow can still be clearly seen on the ground. The circular remains of the central platform measure 15m in diameter and survive to a height of 0.5m above the base of the encircling ditch.  The ditch is 3.00m in width and the base of the ditch is 0.40m below the crest of the outer bank. This bank is 4.00m in width and a possible entrance, 2.00m wide, occurs at the east. The site is very denuded and its southern extent is hard to define. It is situated 15m to the west of a small stream.'  Description from ‘The Prehistoric Settlement of the Lee Valley, Tralee, Co. Kerry; A Landscape Perspective’ by Michael Connolly. PhD Thesis UCC 2008  Date of upload:  12 July 2012

Situated in poorly drained scrubland 160m NNE of a ringfort (KE005-027----), and 20m S of the townland boundary with Kilcock Lower.   Outline of ring-barrow (approx. overall diam. 16m) visible as a circular area of scrub on the Ordnance Survey Ireland (OSI) 1995 Black & White aerial orthophotograph. On the OSI 2005 orthophotograph it is visible as a central circular-shaped mound enclosed by an inner fosse and outer bank.  The monument is clearly visible today on Digital Globe aerial photograph.  See attached Google earth aerial photographs taken 16/03/2106 and 10/02/2009 showing outline of monument    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Dr. Rob O'Hara & Ms Richa Marwaha  Date of upload: 19 February 2020

This site commands a panoramic view of the surrounding countryside especially SW through NW. It is a roughly oval-shaped area with an overall diameter of c 11m NW-SE and 14m NE-SW. An external earthen bank 2.5m-3m wide and on average 1m high encloses an internal area which rises to a mound 4.6m NW-SE and 7.05m NE-SW. The interior is sloping NW and in the interior of the SE sector a hollow sound was noted, as if something lay beneath. Local stories speak of a chieftain being buried there.The above description is derived from C. Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 87. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

This site consists of a circular area measuring internally 29m N-S and 27m E-W. It is enclosed by a fosse and a well-defined outer earthen bank. To the SSE through S to SW the banks have been levelled. A modern ditch has been dug around most of this site, thus exaggerating the exterior height of the outer bank which measures between 2m-3m. The width of the bank at the base measures 4m and the internal height of the bank above the fosse varies between .6m to 1.2m. The width of the fosse varies between 1.2m- 2m. The maximum external height of the enclosing bank measures .7m, the width of the bank at the base measures 4m, and the internal height of the bank over the internal area measures .4m.Towards the centre of the internal area there is a depression measuring 5m x 5m. In the WSW sector of the interior there is a small stone mound that measures 3m x 3.2m externally.The above description is derived from C. Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 98. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

In pasture, on a gentle SW-facing slope. A circular area (diam. c. 7m N-S) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 0.9m at base; D 0.8m) and a low external earth and stone bank (Wth 1.9m; int. H 0.8m; ext. H 0.35m). A possible entrance is at NE, with a possible causeway across the fosse. The fosse and bank are very overgrown with furze and briars along the W arc while along the NE arc they have been poached by cattle. The interior, which is covered with overgrowth, is marginally higher than the external ground level and is slightly convex at the centre.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

In level pasture, with views SW to Mangerton Mountain. A roughly circular area (c. 12m E-W; c. 10m N-S) enclosed by a low earthen bank (Wth 3.3m; int. H 0.25m; ext. H 0.3m). Faint traces of an internal fosse are evident ENE-SW. Boulders and smaller stones clutter the S half of the interior and its enclosing bank. Trees and undergrowth partially obscure the ring-barrow.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

On the gentle N slopes of a ridge with marshy ground to the N. Listed as 'enclosure' in the SMR (1992) and the RMP (1996). A circular area (diam. 16m) defined by a low bank (Wth 8m; int. H 0.45m; ext. H 1.1m) reduced to a scarp (H 0.6-0.7m) NW-SE, separated by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of base 7-10m) from an outer bank (Wth 2.5-4m; int. H 0.3-0.6m; ext. H 0.5-0.7m) which is incorporated into a field bank E-S (max. ext. diam. 46.5m NE-SW; 44.5m NW-SE). An entrance (Wth 1.7m) in the outer bank at ENE is probably original. The site is bisected by a NW-SE townland boundary and is grass-covered to NE and overgrown to SW of this feature.Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 15 April 2020

This ring-barrow was discoverd by Mr. Colm Mac Diarmada (pers. comm. December 2014). It is in an upland area of rough grazing and cut-away bogland on a plateau on the SW hillslope of Binn Shléibhe/Ben Levy. Panoramic views - overlooking Lough Corrib to the SE and an inlet of Lough Mask to the NW. The ring-barrow is defined by a central mound (max. H 0.5m; base Wth 2.9m; top Wth 0.7m) that is surrounded by a wet fosse (max. Wth 1.2m) and outer bank (int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.4m; base Wth 0.92m; top Wth 0.3m). The mound and bank are composed of peaty soil interspersed with stone. A narrow gap (Wth 0.5m) cutting through the bank at SW appears to be a later feature. There is a possible hut site (GA026-021----) c. 55m to the SW and a standing stone (GA026-019----) lies c. 260 m to the SSE.  Compiled by: Olive Alcock  Date of upload: 22 October 2015

In rough pasture, located on a natural rise or terrace on the lower S-facing slopes of the Partry Mountains, overlooking the western shores of Lough Mask, with the skyline at S?SW dominated by the dramatic ridges of Maumtrasna Mountain. This ringbarrow consists of a flat circular area (diam. 2m; H 0.2m above fosse) enclosed by a fosse. The fosse (Wth 0.8m) is sharply defined and also deeper (D 0.5m) relative to external ground level at SSW?NW, where it cuts through a slight natural rise in surrounding ground level; elsewhere it is evident as a poorly defined, shallow depression (ext. D 0.2m). It was noted during an inspection in 1999 that the barrow lacked a clearly defined outer bank. An inspection in 2017, found a hint of a rise (Wth c. 0.6m) immediately outside the fosse at W?NW. It is marked by shorter grass growth, and might represent the remnants of a levelled external bank, but it cannot be traced elsewhere around the circuit. The diameter of the barrow to the external edge of the fosse is 4m. There is a stone row (MA116A005001-) 2m to W. Another stone row (MA116A006001-) and a cairn (MA116A006002-) are located 300m to WSW.  Images: MA116A005002-_01.JPG Viewed from N MA116A005002-_02.JPG Viewed from E  Compiled by: Jane O’ Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 27 September 2017

Toor ring-barrow is situated on the slope of a hill affording extensive views in all directions. The site has an external diameter of 50m and is cut in two almost equal parts by a fieldbank running in an E-W direction. The portion of the ring-barrow N of the fieldbank is in very good condition, whereas the section to the S is barely perceptible. There is also another fieldbank running N-S which slightly cuts the E sector, the enclosing bank, and the inner fosse. This site consists of a circular area 32m N-S, enclosed by a well-defined fosse, especially in the N field where it ranged in width between 4.6m and 6.2m. In the S field it is difficult to see in places, though to the SE it measures 5.6m. The enclosing low, wide earthen bank measures in width between 3.7m and 4.2m and rises to a maximum of 1m internally and .7m externally.The above description is derived from C.
