Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 88. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

At the crest of a N-facing slope. Listed as 'Enclosure' in the SMR (1992) and the RMP (1996). A circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 30.5m E-W; 29.5m N-S; H 0.8m at W to 1.4m at S) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 11m; ext. D 0.5m at WSW to 1.4m NW-SE), and an outer bank (at WSW: Wth 8m; ext. H 0.8m; at N: Wth 12m; ext. H 0.6m; at ENE: Wth 6m; ext. H 0.7m) which is reduced to a scarp (H 0.4m) SE-SW. The fosse was re-cut as a drain (Wth of base 1.6-4.5m; D 0.4m) SE-NW with an exit drain at S. There is an entrance (Wth 7m) in the bank and a causeway (Wth 7m) at E which lead to a subrectangular hut site (CL038-034002-) on the mound, and there is a modern entrance through the bank at NW (max. ext. dims. 74m N-S; 66m E-W).Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 28 April 2020

In pasture, at the E end of a ridge. A circular mound (diam. 20.8m; H 0.55m) defined by a fosse (Wth c. 4m) and an external bank (Wth 7.45m; int. H 1m; ext. H 1.35m). The W half of the mound appears to be slightly flatter on top than the E half and cultivation ridges (Wth c. 1m) were noted in the N quadrant. The bank is overgrown in places and denuded by cattle. The entrance (Wth c. 2m) is at E where there is also a causeway across the fosse. The bank is slightly denuded on either side of the entrance. A rock lies in the middle of the entrance, in line with the external edge the bank. There is also a cattle gap in the bank at W. Some rocks have been dumped into the fosse at N. A NE-SW field boundary may have been incorporated into the bank at NE. A second field boundary, on an E-W axis, extends to W from the bank at NW. There is a limekiln (KE059-044----) c. 80m to the NE.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

In reclaimed pasture, near top of hill. Circular mound (diam. 4.7m; H 0.9m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.9m) with external bank (H 1.1m). Central rectangular depression on top of mound (possible result of digging). Break in bank to SE. Single stone (long axis set radially to centre of mound) in inner face of bank at break.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

This site consists of an earthen bank and internal fosse enclosing a mound 7.2m N-S and 7.4m E-W. The surrounding fosse measures 1.2m wide, while the external bank measures 3.2m wide; its height above the surrounding land measures .6m while its height above the fosse measures .3m. The NNW sector of the external bank is intersected by a depression measuring 3.5m in diameter and .8m deep. Contained within this depression is a large stone (KE011-042002-) measuring 1.6m x .6m x .38m, which possibly gives the ring-barrow its name. It is marked on the 1939 OS map as 'Cloch Liath' (grey stone).The above description is derived from C. Toal, ‘North Kerry Archaeological Survey’. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 86. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

In pasture, situated on a low rise in an area of undulating terrain, overlooked by an E–W ridge of higher ground to N. There is a gentle rise in ground to E. Nephin Mountain dominates the view to SSW, and the Nephin Beg range defines the skyline at S–W. A slightly raised, circular platform (diam. 9.5m) defined by a slight scarp (H 0.4m), and enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.8m) with an external bank (Wth 2.6m; int. H 0.45m; ext. H 0.85m). Some field clearance stones are strewn in the interior and on the bank. Hawthorn trees ring the perimeter.   Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 1 August 2019

Incorporated into a farmyard, located on a low rise in an area of rolling grassland, bordered 250m to NW by the Deel River. Nephin Mountain is prominently visible to SSW and the Nephin Beg Range extends along the skyline to W.  Raised circular area (diam. 11m) defined by a low scarp (H 0.45-0.5m) and enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2.5-3m) with an external bank (Wth c. 3m, at NW; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 1m). The overall diameter (mid bank-mid-bank) is 19.5m. The interior is covered in long grass and brambles, with deciduous and coniferous trees growing on the outer edge of the bank. A farm trackway clips the external face of the bank at W–N. The bank at E is incorporated into a field fence, immediately to E of which there is a farmyard and shed. There is a bungalow immediately to W.  A cluster of ringbarrows and possible barrows and cairns (MA038-050----; MA038-051----; MA038-053001- to MA038-053003-; MA038-146----) is located in adjacent fields within a range of c. 100-450m to N, NE, and E, and a possible ringcairn (MA038-054----) c. 400m to S.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 29 July 2019

In pasture, located at the S end of a rise, in an area of rolling limestone grassland bordered 200m to NW by the Deel River. Nephin Mountain is prominently visible to SSW and the Nephin Beg Range extends along the skyline to W. Circular area or platform (diam. 8m) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.4m; D 0.35-0.4m) with an external bank (Wth 2m at NE, 2.7m at SW; int. H 0.35-0.4m; ext. H 0.5m). Overall diameter (mid bank): 14.5m N–S; 15.5m E–W. The central platform is level, and is well defined by the shallow, flat-based fosse. The external bank is low but well defined, and appears to be constructed of a mix of earth and stone. There is a break (Wth 2.5m) in the bank at ENE, with a corresponding causeway across the fosse to the central platform. The perimeter is ringed with hawthorn. A field fence, on a roughly E–W axis abuts the external face of the bank at S.  There is another ringbarrow (MA038-053002-) c. 80 to SE, and a possible cairn (MA038-053003-) c. 60m to S. A cluster of other ringbarrows and possible barrows (MA038-050----; MA038-051----; MA038-052----; MA038-146----) are located in adjacent fields within a range of c. 100-250m to SW, NW and NE. There is a possible ringcairn (MA038-054----) c. 300m to SSW.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 29 July 2019

In pasture, located on a rise in an area of rolling limestone grassland bordered 200m to NW by the Deel River. Nephin Mountain is prominently visible to SSW and the Nephin Beg Range extends along the skyline to W. Circular area (diam. 9.3m; H 0.45m) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.7-2m) with an external bank (Wth 1.9m at S, 2.72m at N; int. H 0.35m at S, 0.6m at N; ext. H 0.3-0.4m). Ext. diam. (mid bank) 14.6m. The central platform is level and well defined by the shallow fosse. The external bank is low but well defined, and is constructed of stony earth. It has a broad external slump at N and NW, and at S merges with the natural fall of ground. A section of the fosse and external bank at E have been overlain by a N–S field fence. There is another ringbarrow (MA038-053001) c. 80 to NW, and a possible cairn (MA038-053003) c. 50m to W. A cluster of other ringbarrows and possible barrows (MA038-050; MA038-051; MA038-052; MA038-146) are located in adjacent fields within a range of c. 150-300m to W, NW and NE. There is a possible ringcairn (MA038-054) c. 300m to SSW.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 29 July 2019

In pasture, located on a low rise in an area of rolling grassland, bordered 200m to N by the Deel River. Nephin Mountain is prominently visible to SSW and the Nephin Beg Range extends along the skyline to W. This ringbarrow is not shown on the 1838 OS 6-inch map, but is shown on the 1922 edition. It consists of a circular area (diam. c. 10m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.2-1.4m) with an external bank (Wth 1.7m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.5m). The overall diameter (mid bank to mid bank) is 15-15.5m. The bank was incorporated into a later field fences at W and N, but the fences since have been removed, leaving remnants of stone facing in parts on the external edge of the bank. There is a grassed-over depression (c. 10m N–S; c. 2-3m E–W), the result of past disturbance, immediately to W of the barrow, almost abutting the external edge of the bank.  This is the most north-easterly barrow in a cluster of ringbarrows, possible barrows and cairns. The other examples (MA038-050----; MA038-052----; MA038-053001- to MA038-053003-; MA038-146----) are located within 240-400m to WSW and SW. There is a possible ringcairn (MA038-054----) c. 550m to SW.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 29 July 2019

In a coniferous forest, on the summit of Sheagh hill. A ring-barrow, which was 'completely destroyed' during tree planting, was noted to the N of another ring-barrow (CO141-013001-) in 1960 (UCC). There are no visible remains of this ring-barrow. There are two cairns (CO141-013002-; CO141-144----) c. 70m and c. 100m to the S, respectively.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 5' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2009).  Date of upload: 22 December 2009

In coniferous forest c. 20m N of cairn (CO141-013002-). Circular area (8.5m N-S) enclosed by fosse (D 0.3m) with external earthen bank (H 1.5m). Entrance (Wth 2.8m) with causeway across fosse at E. Recent break in bank to S. Interior level. (UCC).The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, located on a rise, with a fall of ground into a natural hollow at S and W. There are good views over surrounding undulating landscape, with Nephin dominating the skyline to SW.  Circular platform (7.4m E–W; 7.5m N–S) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.6m) with an external stony bank (Wth 1.8-2.2m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.4-0.6m). Overall diameter: 13.7m N–S; 13.4m E–W.  The central platform is defined NE–SE by a slight scarp; it is less distinct on the W half where the fosse is largely infilled. The external stone bank is evident as a moss- and sod-covered rise of jumbled stones, with a break (Wth 2.4m) at WNW and another (Wth 1.5m) at NE. There is a hollow or pit (diam. 3-3.5m; D 0.45m) on the central platform, slightly off-centre to S. Remnants of relict field fence abut external bank at WNW. There is a rath (MA038-117----) 200m to SE.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 13 August 2019

On a low rise in the NE corner of an undulating field in pasture immediately S of the road from Lisdoonvarna to Doolin with good views E-S-W. A possible ring-barrow with a central mound (Wth c. 5.5m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth c. 1.6m). An uneven low external bank (Wth c. 2.4m) is visible on a Google Earth image taken on 23 January 2010. A small area has been disturbed by animal poaching at SW. Portion of the rise may have continued into the adjacent field to the E and the N-S field boundary may slightly truncate the monument.   Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

In pasture, on a slight NW-facing slope. A circular area (diam. 9.6m) enclosed by a fosse (D 0.2m; Wth 1.05m) with an external earthen bank (int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.4m). There is a causeway entrance (Wth 1.7m) at ENE. The level interior is under pasture. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, on the summit of hill. A raised circular area (diam. 15.9m) defined by three fosses with intervening banks and an outer bank. The inner fosse (Wth 3.55m; D 0.4m), which is waterlogged N-E, is surrounded by a low flat-topped earthen bank (int. H 0.85m; ext. H 0.75m). The second fosse (Wth 5m) is surrounded by the second earthen bank (int. H 1m; ext. H 0.9m). The third fosse (Wth 5m) is truncated along the NW arc by a field boundary and was infilled along the SE arc in recent times. The external earthen bank (int. H 1.25m; ext. H 0.8m), which is evident NNW-S and WSW-WNW, is incorporated into a field boundary system NNE-WSW. The outer bank is narrowest along the SE arc. The entrance is at E, where there is also the remains of a causeway across the third fosse. According to local information, an entrance gap in the outer bank at E is now blocked. A recent breach through the banks at W is in line with a farm gate to the W. There is a standing stone (KE060-004002-), slightly off-centre, in the level interior. There is a local tradition of a children's burial ground (KE060-004003-) on or near the S arc of the outer bank.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

In pasture, on a gentle N-facing slope, c. 850m downslope of a large barrow (KE060-004001-). A circular area (diam. c. 13m) enclosed by a low bank (Wth. c. 1.5m; H 0.5m). The interior is slightly raised and is concave in profile. This ring-barrow was recorded as a 'fort' in Pat Cronin's land in the 1940s (Schools Manuscript, Co. Kerry). A children's burial ground (KE060-030003-) is c. 15m to the W in the adjacent field.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

In pasture, on top of a rounded hillock, with views S to The Paps of Dana. A circular area (9.8m N-S; 9.05m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.15m) and an outer bank (Wth 3m; int. H 1.04m; ext. H 0.45m). Part of the bank is incorporated into a field boundary along the N arc. There is a break (Wth 1.2m) in the bank at NNE and a possible entrance (Wth 2.85m) with a causeway at W. There is a mound of stones at the centre of the interior and a stone-filled depression immediately to its S. The entire ring-barrow is obscured by gorse and briars.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

In pasture, on a SE-facing slope, with views S to The Paps of Dana. A circular area (9.65m NE-SW; 8.85m NW-SE) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.4m; D 0.1m) and an external bank (Wth 2.72m; int. H 0.8m; ext. H 0.5m). The bank is incorporated into a linear field boundary at S. The entrance, with a causeway, is at E (Wth 2.5m), and at W (Wth 3.5m). A linear bank (Wth 1m; H 0.5m) extends (c. 14m) to the N from the exterior at NW. Coniferous trees grow in and around the ring-barrow. It was recorded in the 1840s as 'Lisheenatumpaun' in the centre of which was a 'stone lying flat on the surface of the earth' (OSNB, Kilcummin, no. 2, 36). It is probably the 'lios' referred to in the 1940s (Schools Manuscript, Co. Kerry) on Michael Kelliher's land. Another ring-barrow (KE068-011001-) lies c. 20m to the NE.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

In pasture, on a SE-facing slope, with views S to The Paps of Dana. A circular area (6.5m NNE-SSW; 6.4m NNW-SSE) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.4m) and an external bank (Wth 2.4m; int. H 0.62m; ext. H 0.94m), covered with overgrowth. Part of the bank is incorporated into a field boundary at S. The entrance, with a causeway (Wth 2m), is at S. Coniferous trees grow in and around the ring-barrow. It is probably the 'lisín' referred to in the 1940s (Schools Manuscript, Co. Kerry) on Michael Kelliher's land. Another ring-barrow (KE068-011----) lies c. 20m to the SW.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

On a slight W-facing slope on a small NE-SW ridge in pasture with good views in all directions. A slightly dished subcircular area (12.35m N-S; 13.4m E-W) defined by a scarp (Wth 1.45-2.8m; H 0.2-0.4m) and a shallow fosse (Wth 1.75-2.8m; D 0.1m ) (max. dims. N-S 22m; E-W 20.85m). No evident entrance. Identified by Emmet Byrnes, Forest Service. Another barrow (CL008-118----) and a mound (CL008-117----) are visible on another ridge c. 300m to the NW.  The following images have been uploaded: CL008-137----_01.jpg View of barrow from N. CL008-137----_02.jpg View upslope from W.  Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 19 August 2019

In level pasture. A circular area (diam. 10m) defined by an internal fosse (Wth 5m; D 0.2m) and an external bank (Wth 1.3m; H 0.5m). The bank is best preserved N-E but cut by a drain at SE. There is a possible entrance gap (Wth 2m) at SSE. The overall dimensions of the ring-barrow are 28m E-W and 25m N-S. A central depression (D 0.6m) in the interior may be recent. The ring-barrow is indicated on the 1846 OS 6-inch map as a circular enclosure (diam. c. 20m).  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

On an E-W ridge in pasture, with wide views all around. Hachured on the OS 25-inch plan (1897) and 1920 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. Listed as ‘Enclosure’ in the RMP (1996). This circular ring-barrow (max. diam. c. 27m N–S) is defined by a slightly domed central area (diam. c. 17m; H 1.2-1.6m) and a fosse, which overgrown with rushes and is visible from S to SW (Wth 3m) and from NW to NE (Wth 7m). There is no trace of an outer bank. However, the mound is truncated by drains and modern field banks at S, W and N, and by a field bank at E. A rath (CL009-099----) lies c. 123m to the WSW.Compiled by: Olive Alcock and Conn HerriottDate of upload: 4 May 2022

In rough grazing, 40m S of barrow (MA121-001----). Circular mound (diam. 5.3m N-S), enclosed by fosse (D 0.4m), with low external bank (H 0.2m).  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 49.  Date of upload: 21 January 2015

In rough grazing atop low rise, 40m N of barrow (MA121-188----). Circular mound (diam. 7.8m E-W), enclosed by fosse (D 0.5m), with external earthen bank (H 0.9m). Overlain by two stone fences and heavily overgrown on NE.  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 48.  Date of upload: 12 December 2014

In pasture, on a slight SW-facing slope. A circular area (7.75m N-S; 8.2m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (D 0.3m; Wth 0.8m) with an external bank (int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.35m). There are opposite causewayed entrances at E (Wth 1.4m) and at W (Wth 1.8m). The interior is level and covered by grass which has been poached by cattle.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In marshy pasture, on a N-facing slope. Circular mound (diam. 5.1m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 2.8m) with an external earthen bank (Wth 4.4m). During ploughing in the early 1960s the top of the mound, which is very uneven, was removed and subsequentially reconstituted.   Compiled by: Matt Kelleher  Date of upload: 29 January 2013

At the top of a low NE–SW ridge overlooking the Burren plateau, within the NE section of a forest plantation, though the monument itself and the area immediately surrounding it have not been planted. Slieve Elva is visible to the NW. Listed as ‘Enclosure’ in the RMP (1996). This subcircular ring-barrow (max. est. dims. 41.7m N–S, 38.7m E–W) is defined by slightly domed central area (21.6m N–S; 19.9m E–W; H 0.6-0.8m) surrounded by a flat-bottomed fosse (av. Wth 2.5–3.7m; D 0.3–0.4m) and an outer bank (base Wth 3–4.5m; Wth at top 1.5–2m; int. H 0.3–0.4m; ext. H 0.2–0.5m). Rushes are growing in the fosse, which widens to 5m at S and narrows to 1.5m at N. The outer bank is best preserved from E to W but is hardly visible from NNW to E. Gaps at SE (Wth 6.5m) and NW (Wth 7.5m) do not appear to be original.Compiled by: Olive Alcock and Conn HerriottDate of upload: 15 October 2021

Near the top of a hill on a N-facing slope in marginal grazing land, with good views in all directions but now surrounded by planted deciduous trees. Hachured on the 1916 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. Listed as ‘Enclosure’ in the RMP (1996). A barely visible circular area (diam. 16m) defined by a low earthen bank (max. H 0.1m; Wth 2m) and shallow internal fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.2m). The bank is especially degraded to the W and NE, and the whole site is overgrown with brambles, reeds and rushes.Compiled by: Mary TunneyDate of upload: 2 February 2022

In pasture, straddles the E side of a low rise in a relatively lowlying position on an expanse of undulating grassland which merging with expanse of grass-covered sand dunes at NE, and is flanked to NW by the mouth of the Palmerstown River, and to SE by Killala Bay. Overlooked c. 100m to NNE by a hillock on top of which is a mound barrow (MA015-085----). Nephin Mountain is clearly visible to SSE and the Ox Mountains define the distant skyline on the opposite side of Killala Bay to S–SE. This ringbarrow consists of a circular platform (13.8m N–S; 13.8m E–W; H 0.6m above fosse base) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.35m) with an external bank (Wth 4m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.65m at S). The overall diameter is c. 23m. The central platform appears slightly higher in the centre with a slight slope down to S–SE. There are two boulders embedded in the platform, one (max. dim. c. 0.75m; H 0.4m) in the centre, and another of similar size c. 2m to SE.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 6 December 2018

In pasture, located on the gently E-facing slope of a low hill.  This enclosure is indicated on the 1838 OS 6-inch as a roughly circular feature outlined by a dashed line, with trees indicated in the interior; on the 1930 edition it is outlined with a solid line, with trees depicted in the interior. Circular area (17m E?W; 19m N?S) with a sunken interior defined by a slightly raised rim with an external fosse on the N arc. Constructed on sloping ground, the sunken interior slopes steeply from W down to E, with a drop of 1.6m from the perimeter at W to the centre, where the ground gently levels out. The perimeter has a hint of a raised rim but it does not constitute a clearly defined ‘bank’. It has a low external scarp, which is pronounced (ext. H 0.7m) only on the downslope S arc, but is almost flush (max. ext. H 0.2m) with exterior ground level on the upslope W arc; and it drops directly into the fosse on the N arc. There is a slightly raised internal lip (Wth 1-2m) on the downslope E arc, but elsewhere there is no clearly defined internal edge, instead the perimeter merges seamlessly with the steep slope of the sunken interior. The fosse is evident NW?NE as a very shallow depression (Wth 2m; ext. D 0.2m); it cannot be traced elsewhere around the circuit. Five mature ash trees, a beech tree and two hawthorn trees grow around the perimeter. There is a dense growth of nettles in the interior.  The nature of this enclosure is uncertain. Lavelle (1994, 9, no. 42) classified it as a ringbarrow and mistook it as the find spot of two excavated cists (MA100-056----; MA100-056001-). In fact, the cists were found c. 30m to N (Movius 1934, 72, fig. 1). It may be the remains of a ringbarrow, the interior of which has been disturbed or quarried out. Another possibility is that it is some form of estate feature or tree-ring.  Attached images: MA100-056002-_01.JPG Viewed from N MA100-056002-_02.JPG Interior, from N  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 12 March 2021

In rough pasture near the top of a SW-facing slope, overlooking a valley to the S. Listed as ‘Potential site (air photo)’ in the RMP (1996). On inspection it proved to be a ring-barrow defined by an uneven subcircular central platform (11.3m NE–SW; 10.1m NW–SE; H 0.3–0.5m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth 4.7–5.7m; D 0.3m–0.5m), and the remains of an outer bank (Wth 3.3m; H 0.3m) from W to NW. From S to W the fosse and outer bank are cut by a drainage ditch and field bank; elsewhere no entrance or causeway are visible. The interior slopes down from the NE to SW. There is a small grass-covered mound or rise (H 0.2m) in the N part of the interior, which may be a pre-modern spoil heap.Compiled by: Olive Alcock and Conn HerriottDate of upload: 21 October 2021

In pasture. Bowman (1934, 646) recorded 'Tumulus' c. 30m SW of stone row (CO021-05101-); 'This had been completely levelled. Diameter of the outer fence c. 39 feet; diam. at base of mound, c. 27 feet'. No visible surface trace. According to local information, grass growth indicates area of ringbarrow in springtime.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In level pasture, on a slight S-facing slope with views to The Paps of Dana. A circular area (diam. 7m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 3.4m; D 0.4m) SE-W and by faint traces of a fosse W-SE. An external earthen bank (Wth 4m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.6m) is evident ESE-NNE and a low intermittent bank NNE-ESE. There is a break (Wth 2.8m) in the bank W-WNW.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

Located at the NW end of a NW–SE rise in rolling average pasture. Killala Bay is visible to NE, the Ox Mountains define the far horizon to E–SE, and Nephin Mountain looms to SSW. Slightly raised circular area (8m N–S; 8m E–W; H 0.35m) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.6m at N) with an external bank (Wth 2-2.4m; int. H 0.5-0.8m; ext. H 0.55-0.7m at SSE). The perimeter of the central platform is well defined SW–NE, but elsewhere it is degraded and indistinct, merging with the fosse, and giving the impression that the central platform is set off-centre to NW within the ring of the outer bank. The outer bank is fairly compact and well-defined. The overall diameter is 17m. There is a cross-inscribed stone (MA022-044001-) and an inscribed stone (MA022-044002-) in the same field 70m to NW.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 1 May 2019
In rough pasture, on N-facing slope. Circular area (diam. c. 5.18m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.6m) with external bank (int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.5m). Bank levelled NE-
column13: SE; gap to WNW. According to Bowman (1934, 454), field named 'An Liosan'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pasture, on high ground with slope to E. Circular mound (12.5m N-S; 11.4m E-W), enclosed by fosse (D 0.6m), with external bank (H 0.9m). External face of bank disturbed by animal burrowing, on the N. Site overgrown SW to N.  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 44.  Date of upload: 25 January 2013

Not marked on 1842 and 1904 OS 6-inch maps. Hachured as circular enclosure (diam. c. 12m) on 1937 OS 6-inch map. In pasture, on NE-facing slope. Circular area (9.4m N-S; 9.6m E-W) enclosed by fosse (D 0.1m); low rise (H 0.08m) around perimiter probably indicates levelled bank. Stone-filled depression on N edge of interior.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on hillcrest overlooking stream valley to E. Subcircular area enclosed by shallow fosse with almost levellled external bank (H 0.3m). Possible entrance to SW. Faint trace of outer bank.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on gentle ESE-facing slope. Bowman (1934, 467) recorded levelled 'tumulus' on J. Collin's land. 'Diameter of surrounding fence, 49 feet: Diameter of base of mound, 31 feet' (ibid.). Arc formed by low rise to W and N gives approx. diameter of 25-30m. According to local information, site called 'fort' in 'fort field' and ploughed numerous times. Ring barrow (CO021-027---) in same field c. 30m to SSE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, near top of gentle N-facing slope overlooking Athnaloingebaine River. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 9.3m) enclosed by fosse with external bank (ext. H 0.55m; int. H 0.65m). Divided by field fence, roughly E-W; smaller portion to S.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on gentle ESE-facing slope; possible ringbarrow (CO021-028---) c. 60m to NNW. Circular raised area (diam. 5m; H 0.5m) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.2m). Low undulations to NW and SE may indicate former presence of external bank. Bowman (1934, 467) gives diameter of interior as 25ft (7.62m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In rough grazing, on S-facing slope. Entire monument is circular (10.3m E-W; 9.3m N-S) in plan and built with stones of type used in cairns. Circular area (5.1m N-S; 6.1m E-W; H 0.45m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.45m) with external bank of stone (H 0.6m). Stone bank low to E for short section. Fosse shallow due to collapse from bank and interior; completely infilled ESE-
column13: SSE. Numerous hollows noted on surface of interior where stones have been removed. Site covered by light layer of peat.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In level pasture. Circular area (diam. 7m) enclosed by fosse with external bank (ext. H 0.5m; int. H 1.1m). Entrance (Wth c. 3m) with causeway to E; two stones outside S side of entrance, one leaning heavily to SE (H 0.6m; 0.5m x 0.3m). Field fence to W removed; clearance material dumped in W half of site.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on gentle W-facing slope. Noted as area of differential growth in field. According to local information, circle of thistles and daisies (diam. c. 7m) clearly visible at certain times. Visible as cropmark on aerial photograph (CASAP).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, in rolling countryside. Slightly raised circular area (H 0.25m; 5.1m N-S; 5.7m E-W) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.15m). Recorded by Bowman (1934, 468) as 'Levelled. Diameter of surrounding fence 34ft. Diam. of base of mound 18 feet'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In undulating pasture, with extensive view to S and E. Recorded by Bowman (1934, 435) as 'levelled. Surrounding fence c. 2ft high, diam. of same 34 feet. Diam. of base of mound 22ft 8in. A depression is in the centre of site of mound'. Levelled 1980s; outer bank visible as low rise; field fence truncates N side, second ring-barrow (11849) c. 230m to SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In undulating pasture with view to NW. Levelled in 1980s. Circular area (9.6m N-S; 10.6m E-W) survives with dip indicating external fosse. Bowman (1934, 452) recorded 'Diam. of surrounding fence 32ft. Diam. at base of mound, 16ft. A circle of stones was around the base of the mound but was removed many years ago'. Second ring-barrow (11848) c. 230m to NW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, in rolling countryside. Roughly circular raised area (H 0.55m; 6m N-S; 6.5m E-W) enclosed by shallow fosse with external bank (int. H 0.75m; ext. H 0.35m). Four stones (L 0.6m; 0.3m x 0.5m: L 0.6m; 0.3m x 0.45m: L 0.8m; 0.25m x 0.65m: L 0.5m; 0.2m x 0.6m) lying on surface of interior form rough square. Second ring-barrow (11856) c. 8m to SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, in rolling countryside. Circular area (4.5m N-S; 4.6m E-W) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.4m) with almost levelled external bank (int. H 0.45m). Second ring-barrow (11855) c. 8m to NW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on the SSW-facing slope of a low hill. A circular area (12.3m N-S; 11.9m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (D 0.35m; Wth 1.95m) with an external bank (int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.4m). The fosse is waterlogged and covered by a stand of rushes. There are opposite causewayed entrances at E (Wth 2.6m) and at W (Wth 3m). A field boundary skirts the bank at N. The interior is level and covered by rough grazing with some rushes growing on its partially waterlogged surface. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, located on the narrow summit of a steep-sided E-W ridge, in sharply undulating terrain of E-W ridges and drumlin-like hillocks. At the base of the steep S slope of the ridge there is a small natural basin of rush-grown boggy ground. The ridge provides widespread views: Bartagh Island and Killala Bay to N, the Moy estuary at NE–E, with the Ox Mountains on the horizon to E, Nephin Mountain prominent to SSW, and the Nephin Beg Range extending along the far horizon at SW–S. This possible ringbarrow is very low profile and poorly defined. It consists of a low, circular mound (diam. c. 14m E–W; c. 16m N–S; H 0.45-0.55m at E and W; 1.1-1.3m at N and S) with a gently domed, broadly slumped profile. The mound spans the N-S width of the narrow ridge top, and the height of slope on the N and S sides is enhanced by the natural fall of the ridge. A gap (Wth 2.2.5m), possibly a fosse, intervenes between the mound and an outer, slightly raised enclosing undulation which appears to be a levelled bank. This external bank can be traced at SE–NNE, but peters out at NE–E. The overall diameter is 24-25m.  Compiled by: Jane O’ Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 12 February 2016

In level pasture with extensive view in all directions. Circular area (14.3m N-S; 15.3m E-W) enclosed by fosse (D 0.7m) with external bank (ext. H 0.7m; int. H 0.8m). Causewayed entrances to E (Wth 3m) and to WSW (Wth 2.3m). According to local information, used as children's burial ground (14090).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

At the base of a W-facing slope, in improved rough pasture, immediately SE of a stream with moderate views to W, N and E, and obscured by a forestry plantation to S. This monument was identified on Bing satellite imagery (https://binged.it/2qT1TAO, taken in 2012 and accessed on 6 June 2017). It consists of a circular area (18m N-S; 17m E-W) defined by a fosse (basal Wth 3m; overall Wth 7m; D 0.2m) N-WSW. There is a very wide intervening berm (int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.1m; Wth at top 5.5m; overall Wth 9.55m) ENE-SW of which there is a faint trace N-E. An outer fosse (basal Wth 2.8m; overall Wth 5.2m; D 0.15m) is present NE-SW. The enclosing elements are largely levelled SW-NW, however it is clear from the Bing and Google satellite photographs that they continued in a full circle with the outer fosse directly abutting the stream to NW (max. overall diam. 61m). The outer enclosing elements of the monument appear to have been disturbed across the NE sector by a field boundary (long-axis NW-SE) which is depicted on all OS historic mapping. There is a causewayed entrance (Wth at top 3.5m; overall Wth 5m; L 21m) at ESE, which extends across the inner fosse to the intervening berm and appears to have been disturbed in the vicinity of the outer fosse, where it is difficult to trace. The interior is generally level and there is a slight depression in the NE sector. Kiltoraght church (CL016-086001-) lies 120m to the NE.   The following images have been uploaded:  CL016-178----_01.jpg From S. General view of monument. CL016-178----_02.jpg From W. Cross-section view of fosse (inner) and intervening bank at S. CL016-178----_03.jpg From W. Causewayed entrance at E. CL016-178----_04.jpg From W. General view of monument.  Compiled by: Mary Tunney, Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 21 May 2018

In the SW corner of a modern pasture field, located at the break of slope at the N edge of a hill or small ridge, in an area of sharply undulating limestone terrain. The ground falls away steeply to N and NE into a natural hollow. Flat-topped circular mound (diam. 13m overall, flat top 7.3m; H 1.45m at W, 2.4m at E) of earth and stone, enclosed by remnants of a fosse and external bank. The mound slope at NE-SE is higher and steeper to compensate for the sharp natural fall of ground. The fosse (Wth 1.8m) at W-N appears as a very shallow depression, changing at NE-SE to a flat terrace (Wth 2.2.5m). It is truncated at S by a later E-W field wall. The external bank can be traced as a slight rise (Wth 1.2-1.4m; H 0.25m) at NW-NNW, petering out at N. At S and SW it has been truncated by later field walls. There is a cashel (MA121-024001) 10m to S-SE of the barrow on top the same hill.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy   Date of upload: 22 December 2014

On a knoll, near the bottom of an E-facing slope overlooking a N-S stream with high ground to the E. The views are limited but another barrow (CL016-029----) is visible c. 800m to the W. Hachured on the 1840 and 1916 OS 6-inch maps. Listed as ‘ring-barrow (possible)’ in the RMP (1996).A poorly preserved ring-barrow (20.4m NW-SE; 20m NE-SW) comprising a low subrectangular mound (8.9m NW-SE; 5.1m NE-SW) with slightly raised edges surrounded by a slight but continuous fosse (Wth 1-4m) and an outer bank (Wth 4.4-6m; int. H 0.1-0.3m; ext. H 0.3-1.3m) from NE to S. The bank is highest (1.3m) from E-SE where it merges with the natural slope. A large limestone boulder (L 1.7m; Wth 0.9m; T 0.5m) sits on the projected line of the bank at SW and another possible vestige of the bank is visible at WNW. A gap in the bank at SW (Wth 6.3m) may be an original entrance. The barrow has been cut by field drains at W and N.Compiled by: Mary Tunney and Lynda McCormackDate of upload: 11 May 2022

In pasture, on W-facing slope c. 110m N of cairn (11803) and ring barrow (11844). Circular area (11m N-S; 13m E-W) enclosed by fosse with external bank (ext. H 0.1m; int. H 0.35m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In rough grazing 54m E of Caha River. Circular area (6.7m N-S; 6.6m E-W) enclosed by fosse (D 0.45m) with external earthen bank (H 0.40m). Entrance (Wth c.1m) with causeway across fosse at SE. Interior level with small depression (diam. 1m; D 0.25m) in SE quadrant. Natural platform adjoins bank from SE-
column13: SSE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pasture, on S-facing slope c. 40m E of cairn (11803) and c. 110m S of ring-barrow (11843). Almost levelled circular area (6.9m N-S; 6.5m E-W) enclosed by fosse with external bank (int. H 0.65m; ext. H 0.75m). Stone (H 0.3m; 0.4m x 0.15m) set radially into bank to N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In level pasture, c. 70m to S of ringfort (8016). According to land owner, small enclosure c. 20ft in diameter levelled during land reclamation. No visible surface trace. Broker (1937, 55) recorded on Dan Gearon's land, besides his large fort (8016), two other nearly levelled enclosures '30 and 10 yards in diameter', one of which 'is alleged to have the fosse inside the rampart'. Second possible ring-barrow (7885) c. 150m to SE.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In garden, on S side of house. Circular area (10m E-W; 9.4m N-S) enclosed by earthen bank (int. H 0.25m; ext. H 0.55m). Extension to house interferes with bank on N side. Ope (Wth 1m) in bank to SSW. Noted by Bowman (1934, 466) as 'Tumulus...levelled...outer fence c. 2ft high, diam. 33ft'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In level pasture. According to landowner, small enclosure c. 6-7 yards in diameter with 2ft high bank found during land reclamation. Broker (1937,55) recorded on Dan Gearon's land, besides his large fort (8016), two other nearly levelled enclosures, '30 and 10 yards in diameter', one of which 'is alleged to have the fosse inside the rampart'. No visible surface trace. Another possible ring-barrow (7884) c. 150m to NW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on N-facing slope. Depicted on 1904 OS 6-inch map as hachured circular area straddling N-S field fence; on 1937 OS 6-inch map field fence removed except where it crosses site. Raised circular area (H 0.5m; diam. c. 9.9m) enclosed by fosse with outer earthen bank (int. H 1.35m; ext. H 0.45m). Breaks in bank to N (Wth 5.2m) and S (Wth 6m). Remains of N-S field fence in interior with shallow drain on either side.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

Situated on top of Knockloon Hill. A ring-barrow partially excavated by the Irish Fieldschool of Prehistoric Archeology (NUIG) in 2018 (Ó Maoldúin 2020). Excavation revealed a sequence of activity stretching from the Chalcolithic/Early Bronze Age to the modern day. The Chalcolithic/EBA activity identified was funerary in nature, comprising depositions of small deposits of cremated bone accompanied by artefacts including a small white flint barbed and tanged arrowhead. Four white flint flakes were also found on the barrow possibly representing one knapping episode. The excavation of the barrow ditch may have contributed to the raising of the interior however the majority of upcast material appears to have been used to construct the external bank. A standing stone was erected centrally at some point. Prior to excavation just a small portion protruded above the grass. More cremation deposits were placed around this, apparently as late as the 6th-9th century AD. Other activity that occurred on the barrow during this time appears to have included feasting and possible glass bead production. Radiocarbon dates will follow to determine the sequence of fills in the ditch and the activity in the centre of the barrow.  Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 13 October 2020

On a slight rise in the centre of Eanty Valley, at the E edge of a wide shallow ravine, with wide views all around. Hachured on the 1842 and 1920 eds. of the OS 6-inch map. Listed as ‘Enclosure’ in the RMP (1996). This well-preserved ring-barrow (26.8m N–S; 26.3m E–W) is defined by a circular flat-topped central mound (H 0.8–1.1m; diam. at base 10.5m N–S; 9.9m E–W; diam. at top 4.9m N–S; 4.8m E–W) surrounded by a well-rounded fosse (Wth of base 2.4–3.4m; ext. D 0.8–1.1m) with a rounded external bank (Wth at base 5.2–5.4m; With at top 0.7–2.5m; ext. H 0.5–0.8). However, at S–WNW the bank has largely eroded into the adjacent ravine.Compiled by: Mary Tunney and Conn HerriottDate of upload: 25 January 2022

Hachured as circular mound on 1842 OS 6-inch map; not shown on 1904 OS 6-inch map; indicated as subrectangular field (diam. c. 10m) on 1937 OS 6-inch map. In pasture, on S-facing slope. Circular area (7.5m N-S; 9.2m E-W) enclosed by fosse with external bank (H 0.5m). Some disturbance to interior on W side.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On a slight rise in pasture. Circular mound (6.4m N-S; 5.7m E-W), enclosed by fosse (D 0.45m), with external earthen bank (H 0.5m).  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 47.  Date of upload: 22 November 2013
In wet ground, on N-facing slope. Roughly circular area (24m N-S; 20m E-W) enclosed by fosse (D 0.3m) NE-
column13: W; fosse disturbed elsewhere. N-S hollow in NW quadrant. Possibly levelled fort referred to by Bowman (1934, 450) in J. O'Callaghan's land.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In a grassy clearing surrounded by scrub in an area of upland karst. A subcircular or irregular area (diam. c. 30m) defined possibly by a low bank and fosse visible only on OS 2005 orthophotography. Noted by Ros Ó Maoldúin. Compiled by: Mary TunneyDate of upload: 23 November 2021

In pasture, on ESE-facing slope. Oval grass-covered mound (H 0.65m; 17.3m N-S; 20.7m E-W) with external fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.8m); the barrow has been truncated on its SE side by a field boundary. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In a slight sheltered depression surrounded by higher ground on all sides except W and NW and within an extensive multiperiod field system (CL009-084001-). Hachured on the 1840 and 1916 eds. of the  OS 6-inch maps. Listed as ‘cashel’ in the RMP (1996). Described by Westropp (1898, 361) as one of two ‘uninjured cahers’.A subcircular ring-barrow (30.5m NNE-SSW; 26m WNW-ESE) with a roughly circular central mound (15m NNE-SSW; 14.6m WNW-ESE) which is poorly preserved from S to NW and is defined by a fosse (Wth 2.6-3.6m; ext. H 0.55-0.9m; int. H 0.4-0.6m) and a bank (Wth 2.4-5.2m; int. H 0.55-0.9m; ext. H 0.3-0.9m). The fosse has displaced rocks from the bank at its flat base and the bank has been considerably disturbed by rabbit burrows. The bank contains occasional boulders and has been disturbed by cattle at N where a mixture of clay, gravel and stone has been exposed. A later gap (Wth 4.8m) has been cut into the bank at S. The bank (Wth 5m; int. H 1m; ext. H 1.1m) is best preserved to the E of this gap and is poorly preserved from WSW-WNW.Compiled by: Mary Tunney and Lynda McCormackDate of upload: 15 June 2022

In pasture, on NE-facing slope. Circular area (7.5m N-S; 9.5m E-W) enclosed by shallow fosse with low external bank (int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.8m). E-W field fence skirts N side of site. Two stones in centre 0.85m apart; upright stone (H 1.27m; 1.36m x 0.8m) is roughly rectangular in plan, long axis NE-SW; second stone (L 1.34m; 0.68m x 0.66m) is prostrate.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In rough upland pasture, on a mountain plateau with panoramic views S, W and N. Croagh Patrick is visible on the distant horizon to W, and the Nephin Beg Range defines the horizon at NNW. At NE ground rises to higher ridges. Inspected in 1998, this possible ringbarrow is evident as a low, roughly circular platform (14.5m E-W; 12-13m N-S; H 0.5m) defined on the downslope S half by a low scarp. The scarp is indistinct on the N half where the platform is almost flush with exterior ground level. An earlier report (NMI Topographical Files, undated), recorded this monument as follows: ‘Measures 13m in diameter consisting of a low boat shaped mound and appears to have a stony core. There are slight traces of a surrounding ditch and bank.’ Another possible ringbarrow (MA080-043002-) is 60m upslope to NE.Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy
column13: Date of upload: 3 December 2021

column10: In rough upland pasture, on a mountain plateau with panoramic views S, W and N. Croagh Patrick looms in splendid isolation on the distant horizon to W, and the Nephin Beg Range defines the horizon at NNW. At NE ground rises to higher ridges. It is prominently sited on a low E-W spine of raised ground on the relatively level plateau.Inspected in 1998, this possible ring-barrow consists of a gently domed grass-covered mound (6m E?W; 6.7m N?S; H 0.9m at N & S, 0.4m at E; o.6m at W) apparently of earthen construction. There is a shallow depression/hollow (4m NW?SE; 3m NE-SW) adjacent to the mound at SW.An earlier report (NMI Topographical Files, undated) recorded this monument as follows: ‘Slightly damaged in spring in digging. It is c. 10m in diameter with a central low mound surrounded by a ditch and external bank.’ Another ring-barrow (MA080-043002-) is located 60m downslope to SW.Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy
column13: Date of upload: 3 December 2021

column10: In level pasture. Circular area (15m N-S; 15m E-W) enclosed by V-shaped fosse (D 0.9m; Wth 3m); external earthen bank (H 0.4m) E-
column13: N. Bank overgrown with gorse; truncated to NE by roadway. Interior slightly raised and covered with gorse.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pasture, atop hill. Circular area (3.7m N-S; 4m E-W) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.2m) with almost levelled external bank (H 0.1m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In undulating pasture, located in a slight dip on the N side of a hillock. There are excellent views of the surrounding countryside, with the Ox Mountains dominating the skyline to E and SE.  This ringbarrow is not shown on the 1837-8 and the 1922 OS 6-inch maps. It consists of a low, circular platform (6m N-S; 5.5m E-W; H 0.6m) enclosed by a well-defined fosse (Wth 2.2; ext. D 0.95m) and remnants of an external bank. The bank has been largely levelled; a slight rise is still evident in parts, but it is evident mainly as a cropmark (Wth 1.6m). The central platform appears to be earthen, composed of fine sandy soil. A concentration of boulders occupies most of the platform. The largest boulder (H 1.2m; circ. 4.45m) is slightly off-centre to S. It occupies a shallow depression and appears to rest on a number of smaller stones. Adjacent to the NE, is a narrow, recumbent stone (L 1.3m; Wth 0.4m), oval in cross-section. To N of this, is an upright boulder (H 1.05m; circ. 2.4m), which appears to be set in the ground. Several smaller stones are scattered over the surface. The haphazard arrangement of the boulders and stones suggests that some, at least, are the result of field clearance. The depth and sharp definition of the fosse contrasts with the degraded nature of the bank, and may be result of modern activity; OPW field notes record a number of channels or drains cutting through the bank (SMR file). The ringbarrow was enclosed within a rectilinear enclosure (c. 33m E?W; c. 22m N?S), defined by a field bank. This enclosure is shown on the 1922 OS 6-inch map, although the barrow is not. The enclosure, which was levelled during land reclamation works, is likely to have dated to the modern era.   Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy   Date of upload: 5 July 2018
In level wet pasture c. 17m NNW of ringbarrow (15287). Circular area (diam. 3.5m) enclosed by shallow fosse, best preserved NW-
column13: NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In low-lying level pasture E of Bealanascartaune river. Circular area (8m N-S; 8m E-W) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.65m) with remains of external bank (H 0.8m) from N-

column10: In pasture, prominently sited close to break of slope at SE end of a ridge. The location provides excellent views, with the Ox Mountains on the horizon at E?S, and Nephin Mountain and the Nephin Beg range visible to W. There is a stream c. 55m to S at the base of the ridge slope. Circular platform (diam.12.2m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.8-2m) with an outer earthen bank (Wth 2.3m; int. H 0.7; ext. H 0.9m). Overall diameter is 20m. The outer bank is compact and well-defined, except for a low section at NW-NNE. At SE there is a causeway (Wth 1.4m) over the fosse, and a corresponding low area (Wth 0.6m) in the outer bank, but it is not clear if this is a primary feature of the barrow. To N, 0.8m outside the bank, is a low, sod-covered linear feature (L 4m; Wth 1.2m; H 0.6m) of uncertain significance; it may be a field clearance heap or remnant of a field division.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 5 June 2018

In pasture, located in gently undulating terrain, c. 50m N the Glenree or Owenmore River. Circular platform (diam. 8.4m) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.2m to NNW; 2.6m to SSE) and an external bank (Wth 3m; int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.4m to SSE; 0.85m to NNW) of earth and stone. The overall diameter is 16.4m. The bank incorporates some field clearance stones, and is ringed with hawthorn and brambles. A field fence skirts the barrow, 1m to W.  There is a possible embanked barrow (MA031-014----) location on the opposite side of river c. 115m to SE.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy   Date of upload: 13 June 2018

In pasture, on E-facing slope. Circular area (diam. 5.2m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.45m) with external earthen bank (H 0.47m). Causewayed entrance (Wth 1.4m) to E. Noted by Bowman (1934, 182) as ' Tumulus...levelled. The surrounding fence still stands, diam.of same 27ft. Diameter at base of mound 16 feet'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On the crest of a slight ridge some 60m SW of another barrow (GA042-216----). A poorly preserved low circular platform (D 21m, H 1m max.) encircled by a fosse and external bank, traces of which survive only at SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

On top of a hill, to W of Musherabeg. Circular area (13.3m N-S; 13.5m E-W) defined by earthen bank (H 0.45m); flagstone (0.76m x 0.68m) and two white quartzite stones at centre. According to local information urn found here during turf cutting by Tim Roche c. 1913. 'Coarse flat-bottomed pot' found under blanket bog during investigation by E. Fahy, Department of Archaeology, UCC (Doody 1986, Cork no. 17). Surrounding land planted with young coniferous trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On E-facing slope of a slight ridge, c. 260m SW of barrow (GA042-215----). A circular barrow (D 19.15m), in fair condition, comprising a slightly flat- topped central mound (H c. 0.75m max.) encircled by an internal fosse and external bank. Trees and bushes grow around the monument which has been denuded especially at SE. Another barrow (GA042-217----) lies 60m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In pasture, near top of N-facing slope. Circular area enclosed by fosse (D 0.15m) with external bank (int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.38m). Bullaun stone (CO005-02302-) in fosse on E side.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On high level pasture, with commanding views to N and NW over Blackwater River valley and E over Owenbaun River valley. Circular area (diam. 8m) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.3m; Wth 4m) and outer earthen bank (max. H1m). Bank highest to W and N; low points to SW and NE may mark possible entrances. Slightly raised interior, has poorly defined edge with gradual rise towards centre. Site planted with coniferous trees. Second ring-barrow (7870) c. 12m to S.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On high level pasture, c. 12m to S of second ring-barrow (7869). Circular area (9m N-S; 8.5m E-W) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.3m; Wth 3m) with outer earthen bank (H 0.55m). Causewayed entrance (Wth 2m) to SSW. Interiorlevel. Site planted with coniferous trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on a S-facing slope. A circular earthen mound (H 0.7m; 7.6m N-S; 8.2m E-W) surrounded by a level berm (Wth. 4.35m), with an external fosse (D 0.6m; Wth 3.2m). A field drain runs radially out from the base of the mound at E and another field drain crosses the line of the fosse at NW. There is no evident trace of the fosse E-
column13: NW. An ESB pole stands at the base of the mound at NNW. A large tank sits in the fosse at NNW. The entire site is under rough pasture. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

column10: In pasture, crowning the narrow top of a NW–SE rise/small ridge in an area of undulating terrain. Ground falls away for 100m to S–SW toward the meandering Trimoge River, with a bend in the river just to NW. Views are generally not extensive but a break in the encircling ridges opens a distant view to NW of Nephin Mountain and the Nephin Beg Range. This is one of three ringbarrows in a close-set NW–SE row on the ridge top: Another ringbarrow (MA071-101001-) lies immediately to SE and a third (MA071-101----) is 5m to SE of the second. Not indicated on the 1838 and 1931 OS 6-inch maps. A central circular platform (diam. 4.7m) defined by a scarp (H 0.35m) with a hint of an internal lip, and enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.5-1.7m) with an external bank (Wth 1.7m; int. H 0.2-0.4m; ext. H 0.2-0.4). A causeway-like feature (Wth 1.5m) extends from the central platform across the fosse at SW. The barrow is located at the narrow tip of the ridge, and spans its full width. It is covered by heather.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy
column13: Date of upload: 19 August 2021

column10: In a thicket of blackthorn and hazel in a pasture field, crowning the narrow top of a NW–SE rise/small ridge in an area of undulating terrain. Ground falls away for 100m to S–SW toward the meandering Trimoge River, with a bend in the river just to NW. Views are generally not extensive but a break in the encircling ridges opens a distant view to NW of Nephin Mountain and the Nephin Beg Range. This is one of three ringbarrows in a close-set NW–SE row on the ridge top: another ringbarrow (MA071-101----) is 5m to SE, and a third (MA071-101002-) lies immediately to NW. Not indicated on the 1838 and 1931 OS 6-inch maps. A central circular platform (diam. 5m) defined by a scarp (H 0.6m) with a low internal lip (Wth c. 1m; int. H 0.3m), and enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.7m; ext. D 0.35m), best preserved SE–S. It is enhanced by the natural fall of ground to SW. It is largely obscured by hazel scrub, brambles and ferns.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy
column13: Date of upload: 19 August 2021

column10: In pasture, located on a slight rise in gently undulating landscape, with good but not extensive views. A circular embanked enclosure (diam. 15-20m), bordered on the N edge by an E?W field boundary, is shown on the 1838 OS 6-inch map; a hachured sunken feature is shown on the 1931 edition. It has been levelled, but the outline is visible as a cropmark. An intermittent band (Wth c. 2m) of yellow grass, possibly a levelled bank, defines a level D-shaped area (14m E–W; 15m N–S to lane), truncated on the straight side at N by a laneway. A circular area (diam. c. 5m) of yellow grass is visible roughly in the centre of the enclosed space, with a gap of c. 3–4m intervening between it and the enclosing band of yellow grass. These cropmarks may preserve the outline of a levelled ringbarrow.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy
column13: Date of upload: 19 August 2021

column10: In a thicket of blackthorn and hazel in a pasture field, crowning the narrow top of a NW–SE rise/small ridge in an area of undulating terrain. Ground falls away for 100m to S–SW toward the meandering Trimoge River, with a bend in the river just to NW. Views are generally not extensive but a break in the encircling ridges opens a distant view to NW of Nephin Mountain and the Nephin Beg Range. This is one of three ringbarrows in a close-set NW–SE row on the ridge top; a second ringbarrow (MA071-101001-) is 5m to NW and a third (MA071-101002-) lies immediately to NW of the second. This barrow is indicated on the 1838 and 1931 OS 6-inch maps. A low, central circular platform (diam. 5.4m; H 0.25m) is enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.5-1.7m) with an external bank (Wth 2-2.3m; int. H 0.55m; ext. H 0.55-0.6m), outside which is a second fosse (Wth W 1.9m; D 0.2m), with possible traces at NNE of an external bank. The central platform is low but well defined. Both fosses are shallow and the intervening bank of earth and stone is compact and well defined. There is a break (Wth 1.4m) in the outermost bank at NNE. Overgrowth obscures the S half of the barrow. A field ditch and field fence on a NNE-SSW axis lies immediately to SE.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy
column13: Date of upload: 19 August 2021

column10: In pasture, at the base of a NE-facing slope. A circular area (10.4m N-S; 10.8m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (D 0.3m; Wth 2.6m base) with an external earthen bank (int. H 0.45m; ext. H 0.15m). Both fosse and bank are truncated WNW-
column13: N by a field boundary. The outer edge of the bank clipped by a stream N-
column14: ENE. The level interior is under pasture. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

column10: Located on a broad low rise in lowlying poorly drained pasture. This ringbarrow (overall diameter. 23m N?S; 23m E?W) was recorded in 1982 as a low, circular platform (diam. 9m N?S; 9m E?W) enclosed by a shallow, water-logged fosse, with a wide, low, earthen external bank (OPW Field Notes). The ringbarrow was levelled in the 1980’s during land reclamation works. When inspection in 2000, the outline of the central platform and the enclosing fosse could be discerned as slight surface undulations.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy   Date of upload:  16 May 2017

In pasture, in a thicket of overgrowth on the W edge of modern rectangular field, located on a slight rise with good but not extensive views. A very slightly raised, roughly circular area (10.3m N–S; 10m E–W) defined by the remains of a bank (Wth 1.2m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.55m, at SSW). The bank is largely earthen but incorporates stones in parts. It is best preserved at E–SW but is low and degraded elsewhere, with sections at W and N which are almost entirely levelled. The centre of the interior appears to be gently raised or domed, but is difficult to examine due to overgrowth.  It is in a dilapidated condition and is ringed with hawthorn and blackthorn bushes. There is property fence immediately to NW. Classification of this monument is difficult -it may be a ring-barrow.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 13 July 2021

In pasture, on S-facing slope, adjoining N side of field fence. Circular raised area (10m E-W; 9.5m N-S) enclosed by fosse (D 0.8m; Wth 6m) with outer earthen bank (H 1m). Causewayed entrance (Wth 3.5m) to E. Interior slopes gently down to S. Site planted with coniferous trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In flat marshy grassland. This small circular barrow (D 18m int.) was noted during aerial reconnaissance (ASGAP 226:45). It consists of a flat area enclosed by an earthen bank (Wth 5.5m; int. H 0.45m; ext. H 0.55m) overgrown with gorse at N and NE. A band of vegetation surrounding it may mirror the line of a fosse. Possibly a ring-barrow. (Alcock et al. 1999, 13, no. 1077)Updated by: Olive AlcockDate of revised upload: 13 May 2022

In level pasture; to S, land rises to Musheramore. Circular area (9.35m N-S; 8.65m E-W) defined by earthen bank (max. H 0.6m), with some stones visible on surface. Bank partially levelled to S. According to Broker (1937, 50), on Michael Kelliher's land is 'fort, less than 1-16th of acre. Almost levelled'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In gently undulating marshy grassland. A poorly preserved circular barrow (D 21.9m) consisting of a central mound (D c. 10m, H 0.7m), fosse and external bank. A field wall cuts the monument at W and E, to N of which it has been levelled. A CBG (GA028-015001-) is associated.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In strip of land, lying between two public roads (R523 & N21), which is covered by dense overgrowth. Described by O Rahilly (1990) as 'a D-shaped area- may originally have been circular but subsequently truncated to the south by the old road ... measures c. 34m east-west and the internal level is approx. 1m below surrounding ground level ... it may be a ring barrow site'.   Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In gently undulating pastureland. A circular barrow (D 22.9m), in fair condition, consisting of a slightly raised central area (D c. 4m, H 0.2m) encircled by a bank. There are slight traces of a fosse, between the central area and the bank, and of an external fosse from NW through N to SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010
On rocky ground to NE of Rathbarry Castle (CO143-074002-). Central mound (diam. c. 8m; H 0.6m) surrounded by fosse (D 0.2m) with external bank (H 0.6m) from SW-
column13: SE. Much disturbance from SE-
column14: SW. Gap in bank at ESE. Identified as remains of circular tower associated with Rathbarry Castle by Gillman (1895, 5) but this is very unlikely.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pasture, on NE-facing slope. Circular area (diam. 13.6m) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.25m) with almost levelled outer bank (ext. H 0.2m; int. H 0.45m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In grassland. A well-preserved circular barrow (D 32m) comprising a flat central area (N-S 9.3m, E-W 8.3m, H 0.3m) encircled by a shallow flat-bottomed fosse and a bank of earth and stone. A gap in the bank at SE appears modern  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In level pasture. Circular area (diam. c. 13m) enclosed by shallow fosse with outer almost levelled earthen bank. Two possible ringbarrows (CO006-02801- and 02802-) to N and NE respectively. Probably one of three 'tumuli' recorded by Bowman (1934, 649) in this townland.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In level pasture. Levelled c. 1974; no visible surface trace. May be one of three 'tumuli' recorded by Bowman (1934, 694) in field called 'The Lios...No. 1...mound ... about 3ft high, the diameter on top is 21ft. No. 2 ...mound is about 4ft high,...surrounded by a vallum, the diameter of which is 53 feet. Diameter at base of mound is 28 feet. No. 3...irregular shaped mound, about 3ft high and covering an area of about 27 sq. yards'. Ringbarrow (CO006-02802-) c. 25m to S; second possible ringbarrow (CO006-02803-) c. 20m to SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In level pasture. Levelled c. 1974; no visible surface trace. May be one of three 'tumuli' recorded by Bowman (1934, 694) in this townland (see CO006-02801-). Second possible ringbarrow (CO006-02801-) c. 20m to NW; ringbarrow (CO006-02802-) c. 20m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In level pasture. Circular area (12m N-S; 13.5m E-W) defined by scarped edge (H 0.2m; Wth 1.45m) with external fosse (D 0.55m; base Wth 1.2m) and external bank (int. H 0.75m; ext. H 0.15m; Wth 6.95m). Breaks (Wth c. 2.75m) in external bank at NW and SE. Interior level and entire monument under grass. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, located at the SE end of a NW–SE rise, with a stream a few meters o SSW at the base of the rise. Low central platform (diam. c. 2.5m; H 0.3m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 0.90m at NE, 1.5m at SW) with traces of an outer bank (Wth c. 2m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.3m) at W–N. The outer bank appears to have been dug away at E–SE. Due to the greater width of the fosse at the S–SW the central platform appears to be slightly off centre.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 26 May 2021

In pasture, sited on an elevation with excellent views over rolling grassland and to SE over an expanse of rough wet ground.  This monument is not on 1838 OS 6-inch map; it is depicted as a small hachured circle on the 1917 edition. Circular area (diam. 7m -mid bank) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 2.5-3m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.7m) with an external fosse (Wth 1.4m). The inner face of the bank has a shallow, gradual slope which is not clearly defined. The fosse is evident as a shallow depression with a deeper section at E which may be the result of relatively recent disturbance.  There are several animal burrows in the bank, and gorse and brambles cover much of the barrow. An embanked barrow (MA092-063001-) is located 15m to NW.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 17 May 2022

In pasture, on a gently S-facing slope, c. 100m from the N bank of the River Deel. A circular area (11.7m N-S; 12.2m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (D 0.25m; Wth 2.2m) with an external bank (ext. H 0.2m). There is a gap in the bank (Wth 2.4m) at N; from this a shallow linear depression (Wth 2.4m) extends for c. 18m to the S. The fosse is waterlogged E-
column13: W. The bank is best preserved NNE-
column14: S. The level interior is under pasture.Compiled by: Denis PowerDate of upload: 26 August 2011

column10: In flat arable land, surrounded by hills. Circular area (15.45m NW-SE; 14.5m NE-SW) enclosed by earthen bank (H 0.8m). Shallow fosse inside bank defined by slight rise towards centre. Gap (Wth 4.2m) in bank to WSW. Stone 1m x 0.8m lying near centre of interior.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In undulating grassland. This ring-barrow is defined by a grassed-over flat-topped roughly circular mound of earth and stone (diam. c. 21.5m; H 0.9m). A shallow circular depression (diam. 1.5m) lies just W of its centre and a few trees are growing on it at N. According to local information, it was known as a burial place and it was formerly surrounded by a fosse or bank. No visible surface trace of the latter survives. (McCaffrey 1952, 18-19, 116, no. 27)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 November 2019

In pasture, near top of hill. Circular area (diam. c. 10m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.5m) with external bank (int. H 0.63m; ext. H 1.3m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On a low ridge in flat pastureland. This ring-barrow (diam. 10.6m) was noted following aerial reconnaissance by Markus Casey (SMR file).
