On inspection in February 1992, it was fairly well preserved and was defined by a flat-topped circular mound (diam. 3.8m; H 0.3-0.4m) encircled by a fosse (Wth 1.5-1.8m) and external bank (Wth 1.5-2m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.3m). A possible entrance gap (Wth 2.1m), with traces of a causeway, was visible at NE. Some field-clearance material, consisting of large loosely placed boulders, lay to its S. Aerial imagery (see OSi Ortho_ITM and digitalglobe images) indicates that this area was subsequently developed as a large quarry and the ring-barrow appears to have been levelled.Compiled by: Olive AlcockDate of upload: 7th April 2022

Depicted on 1842, 1905 and 1937 OS 6-inch maps as hachured circular enclosure (diam. c. 19m). According to Bowman (1934, 149), 'single-ramparted, c. 31/2ft high. Diam. 19 yards' with 'fosse, now practically filled in...inside the rampart'. Permission to inspect site refused.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, c. 20m to WNW of possible standing stones (CO060-106002-). Circular area (diam. 8m) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.1m; Wth 1m) with external earthen bank (H 0.2m). According to local information, 'used as children's burial ground within living memory' (Hartnett 1939, 53).The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009Image provided by and copyright of Amanda Clarke 2016-2022 https://holywellscorkandkerry.com/
In level pasture. Slightly raised oval area (4.6m NE-SW; 5m NW-SE) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.4m) SW-
column13: NE. Site truncated to SW by NE-SW field fence.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pasture on break in S-facing hillslope. Circular area (7.2m N-S; 7.2m E-W) enclosed by low earthen bank (H 0.7m). Possible entrance at SE. Interior slopes gently downwards to SE and is covered by dumped field clearance stones.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

Outside W edge of ringfort (CO040-06101-). Levelled. Circular area (3.4m NNW-SSE) enclosed by traces of fosse and outer bank.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

Situated on very slight E-facing slope in pasture. Raised circular area (diam. 30m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (ext. H 0.6m) with a fosse (Wth 3.6m) and a substantial external earthen bank (Wth 3.3m; int. H 1.2m; ext. H 0.65m). A break in the external bank (Wth 4m), with a corresponding causeway across the fosse, at E marks the position of the original entrance.  Compiled by: Mark Keegan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

On the edge of a high bluff on the N bank of the estuary of the Kilcolgan River. A circular area (diam. 19m) is defined by a deep steep-sided fosse with an external earthen bank. Though Redington (1912, 176) mentioned ‘a circular bank … within it’, McCaffrey (1952, 202, no. 20) noted the absence of any internal bank. The interior is uneven. A laneway cuts across the monument from SE to NW; to its SW only slight traces of the fosse survive on the cliff edge.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 31 July 2019

Roughly depicted as circular area (diam. c. 18m) on 1842 OS 6-inch map; hachured as raised circular area (diam. c. 20m) on 1905 and 1937 OS 6-inch maps. In pasture, on S-facing slope. Raised circular area (23m N-S; 18m E-W) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.26m); truncated by field fence on S side.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On a slight rise in undulating pastureland overlooking the estuary of the Clarinbridge River to the N. This  circular ring-barrow (diam. c. 20m) is defined by a central mound (diam. c. 4m; H 1.34m) encircled by a fosse and traces of an external bank. The centre of the monument has been disturbed and some field-clearance material has been dumped in the fosse from W to N. A number of hawthorn trees are growing on it. (McCaffrey 1952, 30, no. 16a; 1955, 225)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 16 August 2019

In rough pastureland. A possible ring-barrow, roughly circular in plan (max. diam. c. 15m) is most clearly visible on Google Earth aerial imagery dated March 2019. Identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère.The following image has been uploaded: GA015-177----_01.jpg Google Earth image (12 March 2019)Compiled by: Olive AlcockDate of upload: 4 July 2022

In wettish, rushy pasture, located on a slight rise on flood-prone ground, 10m N of the current shoreline of Lough Killaturly. Ground rises gradually to N for c. 150m, then more steeply towards an E–W ridge.  A low circular platform (3.9m N–S; 3.6m E–W; H above fosse 0.15-0.35m) is enclosed by a fosse (Wth 0.5-0.6m) with an external bank (Wth 1.2-1.7m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.25m).  Another ringbarrow (MA062-107001-) is located c.140 m to N.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 26 January 2021

In wettish, rushy pasture, located on a slight rise. Ground rises steeply towards a ridge to N, and falls gently to S for c. 150m to the shores of Lough Killaturly. A farm lane lies a few meters to NW. Low, circular platform (6m N–S; 5.3m E–W; H 0.7m at N; 0.65m at S) enclosed by a narrow fosse (Wth 1.2m; D 0.25m). There is a slight rise (Wth 1.2m; ext. H 0.15m) on the outer edge of the fosse at the SE, which may be the remnant of an external bank. At NNW–N the fosse is truncated by a shallow, rectangular pit, which is bordered on its N side by the farm laneway. Another small, oval quarry pit lies 1.5m to E. Another ringbarrow (MA062-107002-) is located c. 140m to S at the lake shore.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 26 January 2021

In pasture, on top of rise is generally level terrain. A circular, flat topped mound (H 2m; diam. c. 6m at crest, c. 12m at base) with a concentric fosse (D 0.45m; Wth 1.4m) at its base. There is a ledge halfway up the N side of the mound from which a ramp leads up to the summit. The mound is covered by scrub overgrowth.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On NE slope of Carrigagour. Circular, slightly raised platform (diam. 4.8m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.48m; Wth 3m) with external bank (H 0.4m). Site overgrown with bracken. Locally known as 'lios' (Hartnett 1939, 79).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, situated at the break of slope on the steep NE-facing slope of a NW-SE ridge. Much degraded, circular area (diam. 9.4m; H 0.6 at SW, 1.4mat NE) defined by a slightly raised rim (Wth c. 1m) which may be a levelled bank. The internal area is saucer-shaped in profile. A larger enclosure (SL012-005002-) lies 19m to NE.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

At the foot of a low hill in flat farmland. This subcircular ring-barrow (25.5m E-W; 22.7m N-S), in fair condition, is defined by an oval central mound (11.3m E-W; H 0.3-0.65m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. A hollow is visible just off-centre in the mound. The external face of the bank has been defaced as a result of the construction of a later field boundary against it. The monument is overgrown with brushwood.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 16 August 2019

In pasture, c. 30m E of a small stream. Not indicated on any edition of the OS 6-inch maps. Listed in the SMR (1991) and the RMP (1997) on the basis of information from a local source, who noted a circular enclosure or possible ringbarrow here. No visible trace is now evident at ground level.    Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 21 May 2021

In level marshy terrain, on the S side of a stream. A circular area (diam. 14m) enclosed by a fosse (D 0.3m; Wth 7.4m) with an external bank (int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.6m) and an external fosse (D 0.35m; Wth 5m). There are opposite gaps in the bank at E (Wth 8m) and at W (Wth 6m). The entire site is covered by tall marshy vegetation except for the level interior which is dry and under grass. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture. Circular area (diam. 13.5m) enclosed by low earthen bank (int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.15m). Interior and bank overgrown with gorse.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In low-lying pastureland. Excavated in 1970 by E. Rynne (pers. comm.), this circular ring-barrow (diam. 11m) comprised a low earthen mound (diam. 5.5m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. Three concentrations of cremated bones were uncovered: in the central mound, in the fosse at SW, and in the fosse at NE. Fragments of bronze and over 80 glass beads accompanied the bone at NE, suggesting an Early Iron Age date for the barrow. The monument was destroyed as a result of quarrying n the early 1980s and no visible surface trace survives.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

In pasture, on top of a low rise, with bog to N and S. A slightly raised area (c. 20m N-S; c. 23m E-W) surrounded by a wide fosse (Wth 3.4m) and a broad external earthen bank (Wth 7.3m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.65m). The fosse appears in parts to be higher than the surrounding ground level. From N-NNE the earthen bank is evident only as a barely perceptible rise. The bank is narrower and higher for short sections along the E and W arcs. This may be due to disturbance by a lane and farmyard buildings abutting the bank to E and W respectively as shown on the 1838 OS 6-inch map. A depression remains where the farm building once stood. Numerous gaps were noted in the bank. The interior is level and raised at max. 0.45m above the base of the fosse. The barrow is grass-covered and heavily poached by cattle. According to local information, it was used as a children's burial ground (SL042-001001-).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On a rise in low-lying pastureland. Classified by McCaffrey (1952, 36-7) as a 'henge' monument, this low penannular ring-barrow (overall diam. 24.5m) is defined by a slightly raised area (diam. 14.3m) encircled by a traces of a fosse and an external earthen bank. An entrance gap (Wth 2.5m) at E is marked by two limestone slabs. McCaffrey (ibid.) noted that a pit had been dug at the centre of the interior and that the upcast had been spread on the surface to its S. A children's burial ground (GA095-087----) is associated. (Killanin and Duignan 1967, 395)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

In pasture, located on a NW–SE ridge, at the break of slope on the SW side where the slope falls steeply to an expanse of wet ground, beyond which a possible embanked barrow (MA092-005----) is visible on a rise c. 250m to SSW. There is a megalithic tomb (MA092-007----) 200m to NE. Circular platform (5.4m NE–SW; 5.3m NW-SE) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.4m at NE, 1.7m at SW) with a broadly slumped external bank (Wth 3.6m at NE, 4. 8m at SW; int. H 0.35m at NE, 0.8m at SW; ext. H 0.1m at NE, 1.4m at SW). The platform has a very slight central depression. The external bank is topped with stones at SE and SW. Grass cover, with two hawthorn bushes growing on the perimeter.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 17 February 2022

In pasture, on a hillock overlooking a steep fall of ground NW?NE.Slightly raised circular area (6.4m; H 0.1m at SW; 0.35m at NW) defined by a poorly defined, silted-up fosse (Wth 2m at S 2.4m at E) with an external earth and stone bank (Wth 1.7m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.3m at S, 0.5m at NW). Overall diam. (crest of ext. bank): 13m.The bank is incorporated into a field fence at NNW?E and is overlain by remnants of another field fence at SE and SW. Ringed with hawthorn, blackthorn and hazel trees. Compiled by: Jane O’ShaughnessyDate of upload: 8 December 2021

In pasture on E-facing slope. Circular area (9m E-W; 10m N-S) enclosed by fosse (D 0.4m) with external bank (H 0.5m). Interior level; site planted with trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On a gentle S-facing slope the remains consists of a circular ring-barrow (diam. 15m) in fair condition. It comprises a low flat central area (diam. 3m) encircled by a fosse and a broad low external bank. A gap (Wth 6m) in the bank at NE appears to be the result of field clearance. One set stone is visible in this area. (Rynne 1991, 29)  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 2 March 2015

One of four barrows on Athenry golf course (GA083-066----; GA083-067----; GA083-068----; GA083-075----). This barrow is on the 9th fairway and consists of a very poorly preserved circular ring-barrow (diam. c. 12m), with a low central mound (diam. 5.5m) surrounded by a fosse and traces of an outer bank. (Rynne 1991, 28)  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 2 March 2015
In pasture, on an elevated ridge. A circular area (diam. 16m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 0.65m; D 0.3m) with an external earthen bank (int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.4m). The bank is best preserved E-
column13: NW, there is no apparent gap in the bank but there is a slight dip at E. The interior, which is flat and c. 0.3m above the level of the top of the bank, is covered with briar and furze bushes. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

column10: On an E-facing slope in undulating grassland, and immediately SW of a byroad. A large circular barrow in fair condition, though partially obscured by overgrowth and field clearance. It comprises a flat central area encircled by an internal fosse, inner bank (E-W 54m, N-S 53.5m), intervening fosse and outer bank. No trace of the enclosing elements survive from N to E, probably as a result of the road widening carried out in 1972. However, 3rd ed. of OS 6-inch map (1932) shows small gaps at E and S, the former possibly corresponding to a water-filled hollow on the line of the inner fosse and bank. In 1972, a small inconclusive rescue excavation (Champion and Champion 1973, 13) was carried out on the enclosing elements at N. (see also Waddell 1977, 59)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

One of four barrows on Athenry golf course (GA083-066----; GA083-067----; GA083-068----; GA083-075----). Situated on level ground and now acting as a trap in front of the 1st green this circular ring-barrow (diam. 20m), in fair condition, comprises a central mound (diam. 5.2m) encircled by a fosse and external denuded bank. The central mound has been dug out from NW to E and is horseshoe-shaped in plan as a result. (Rynne 1991, 28)  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 2 March 2015

On a slight rise in low-lying pastureland. This well-preserved circular ring-barrow (overall diam. 19.5m) consists of a central flat-topped mound of earth and stone (diam. 8m; H 0.9m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. There is a gap in the bank at E. The area to the N of the monument has been quarried. (McCaffrey 1952, 28, no. 50b; 1955, 224)  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2017

In pasture, on low rise with good views; overlooked by higher ground to S and N. A driveway to a house lies a few meters to E of the ringbarrow.Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch maps. Low circular platform (diam. 2.7m; H 0.3m at NE, 0.45m at SW) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.5m) with an external bank (Wth 2-2.4m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.35m at N, 0.5m at SW). Overall diam. (across ext. bank): 8.5mThe central platform has a slightly concave profile. The external bank is composed of gravelly earth incorporating some large stones. It is slightly damaged at S?SW by quarrying. Compiled by: Jane O’ShaughnessyDate of upload: 8 December 2021

In gently-undulating pasture. A circular area (diam. 12.7m) enclosed by a fosse (D 0.3m; Wth 1.55m) with an external earthen bank (ext. H 0.6m; int. H 1.1m). The interior slopes gently up towards the centre. Both the interior and the enclosing element are covered by scrub vegetation and there is a stand of ash trees at the centre. The bank has dry-stone facing on its external face W-
column13: NE, where it forms part of an E-W field boundary. A second field boundary abuts the bank at S, on the W side of which is a gap (Wth 2m) in the enclosing bank. There is a second gap in the bank at W (Wth 7.4m), and probably a third at E but this area is covered by dense vegetation overgrowth. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

column10: In pasture, on top of a hill with excellent views of the surrounding undulating landscape.Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch maps. Raised circular area (6m NW-SE; NE-SW; H 0.6m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.5-2m) with an external bank (Wth 2.4m; int. H 0.3-0.4m; ext. H 0.3m at NW, 0.7m at SW). Overall diam. (bank to bank): c. 12mThe central mound is slightly domed in profile. An eroded portion of the mound at N reveals a makeup of large angular stones and gravelly earth. The fosse and external bank are rather poorly defined, but the external bank is enhanced by the natural fall of ground at SW?N. There is a low area or break (Wth 0.5m) in the bank at SSW. A straight NW?SE field wall clips the outer edge of the bank at N?NE and remnants of another field fence at SE merge with the bank at SE. Three thorn bushes growing on the central mound.Compiled by: Jane O’ShaughnessyDate of upload: 8 December 2021
In pasture. Semicircular, slightly raised platform (diam. 10m N-S) defined by fosse (D 1m; Wth 3m) S-
column13: N with external bank (H 1m). Break in bank to WNW. Site overgrown with furze bushes. Laneway depicted on 1842 OS 6-inch map cut through E half of barrow. No visible surface trace of laneway or E half of site survives. Second ring-barrow (7878) c. 25m to ESE; two possible ring-barrows (7889, 7888) c. 10m to ESE and c. 25m to NE respectively.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pasture, between two ring-barrows (7877, 7878) and to SW of possible ring-barrow (7888). Area of bank now visible as low rise.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture. Shown only on 1842 OS 6-inch map as hachured arc (c. 10m NE-SW) on SE side of NE-SW lane. Lane removed; no visible surface trace of site. Two ring-barrows c. 25m to SW (7877) and c. 30m to S (7878); possible ring-barrow (7889) to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture. Circular, slightly raised platform (diam. 14m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.8m; Wth 3m) with external earthen bank (H 0.5m). Hartnett (1939, 73) describes break in bank to ESE, which is not well defined and may be modern. Second ringbarrow (7877) c. 25m to WNW; two possible ringbarrows (7889, 7888) c. 15m to WNW and c. 30m to N respectively.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

Situated in a natural amphitheatre bounded to N and E by a curving ridge with the Hell River immediately to the SW. Described as a ‘true mote’ by Westropp (1900-02, 446), named ‘Cregnakeeroge Fort (Mound of Magh Adhair)’ on the 1921 OS 6-inch map, listed as ‘Enclosure’ in the SMR (1992) and the RMP (1996) and noted as a possible barrow by Condit and Grogan (2000, 23-4). Herity (1993, 144) remarks that the archaeological evidence at Magh Adhair places it with little doubt in the prehistoric period. The true nature of the mound is unknown as it remains unexcavated but its use as an inauguration site (CL034-095007-) is well documented. A subcircular grass and scrub-covered mound (dims. of top 26m N-S; 22m E-W; base 37m N-S; H 3.1m at S to 5.5m at N) which is flat-topped, but sloping down to the S (H 1.3m). A stone revetment (H 0.1-0.3m) lines the top edge externally N-ESE. The mound is surrounded by a fosse (Wth of top 7m; Wth of base 2.8-3.3m) with an outer bank of earth and stone (Wth 4-8m; int. H 0.5-1.5m; ext. H 0.5-1.5m). A causeway (Wth 5m; H 1-1.4m) of earth flanked with stone facing crosses the fosse at SW. A stone-lined bank at N (L 1.2m) with stone facing at W (H 1m) may represent a second causeway across the fosse. Condit and O’Sullivan (1998) note that the flat top and possible entrance features are likely to be medieval modifications to the probable original Bronze Age burial mound. This is one of a number of monuments in the immediate area dating from prehistory to the medieval period. A cairn (CL034-095004-) lies 7m to the W, a bullaun stone (CL034-095003-) with quartzite inclusions lies 27m to the NW and a standing stone (CL034-095005-) is 70m to the W. A rath (CL034-095008-) is 36m to NW with a conjoined D-shaped enclosure (CL034-095009-) and a number of field boundaries (CL034-095010-) are visible c. 7m N of these enclosures (visible on Google Earth satellite image taken 5 February 2009, accessed 4 March 2015).  Grogan and Condit (2000, 23-4) note both the barrow-like morphology and the presence of the stone with quartzite inclusions to the NW. They cite barrows at Glennagross (CL052-064003-) and Carrownanelly (CL042-004001-) in the same region that also have small standing stones with quartzite inclusions close to the perimeter of their outer banks.  Magh Adhair is a national monument in state care, no. 224.   The following images have been uploaded:  CL034-095001-_01.jpg View of mound from NW with bullaun stone CL034-095003- in foreground. CL034-095001-_02.jpg View of mound from E. CL034-095001-_03.jpg View from W. CL034-095001-_04.jpg View from SW.  Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 11 July 2018

In pasture. Circular area (diam. 11m) defined by fosse (D 1m; Wth 4m) with outer earthen bank (H 1.1m). Bank partially overgrown with bushes and briars. Part of centre of interior and NE quadrant excavated by Jane O'Shaughnessy (1991, 17-8). Trench opened revealed arc (Wth 0.5m), off-centre to NE, formed by 'large, haphazardly-set stones', the full extent of which lay beyond edge of excavation but 'it appeared to form subcircular enclosure, diam. 4.5m' (ibid., 17). No artefacts or evidence for burial found. Section cut through fosse and bank to E. Fosse originally 3m in width and 1.4m deep; primary core of bank appeared to be constucted 2.5m outside edge of fosse. Circular hearth-like feature (diam. 0.5m) sealed under outer edge of bank consisting of 'shallow concentration of small, angular apparently heat-shattered stones set in a matrix of dark brown charcoal-rich soil (ibid., 18). Charcoal from hearth-like feature yielded radiocarbon date (UB 3620) 3175+/-46 BP (pers. comm. Jane O'Shaughnessy).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, c. 30m N of pond. Circular, slightly raised platform (diam. 11m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.5m; Wth 2m) with external earthen bank (H 0.4m). Break in bank to S. Stones protruding above surface of interior; according to Hartnett (1939, 84), may be remains of cist-like structure. Site planted with coniferous trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, located on a roughly E–W ridge, with panoramic views over the surrounding rolling grassland; Nephin Mountain is visible on the horizon to NW. Circular platform (5m N–S; 6m E–W; H 0.3m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 3–3.4m) with an external bank (Wth c. 3m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.45m) of earth and stone.  Overall diam. (crest of ext. bank): 14.3m N–S; 15.3m N–S. The external bank has a broad, high external slope (ext. H 1.15m) at N–NE where it merges with the ridge slope; at WSW–N it is truncated on its exterior edge by a modern NE?SW field wall. Three hawthorn bushes grow on the bank. A rath (MA081-013----) is located c. 100m to NW on the same ridge.Compiled by: Jane O’ShaughnessyDate of upload: 8 December 2021

In rough upland area on the summit of a ridge, ringfort known locally as 'Lissnaderne' (LI038-022----) lies 270m to SW.   Not marked on OSi historic maps.  Surveyed in 1994 and described as a flat circular-shaped area (diam. 5m) defined by a U-shaped fosse (top Wth 2m; base Wth 0.8m; D 0.7m) and a low earth and stone bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.4m; int. H 0.8m) with traces of a possible causewayed entrance (Wth 1.5m) at ESE (SMR File, Field Report P. Danaher 01/07/1994). Outline of monument visible as circular-shaped area of clear vegetation on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-2012.  Scrub-free area visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  Monument placed on the Register of Historic Monuments in 1994 (Schedule Serial No. 14/94).    See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 17 April 2021

In level pasture. Raised circular area (H 0.5m; diam. 18m) enclosed by fosse with external bank (int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.3m). Standing stone (9930) in fosse to E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In undulating average pasture, situated on top of a NE-SW ridge in pasture. Roughly circular area (diam. 12.6m) enclosed by an earthen bank (Wth 3.3m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.5m). At the inner foot of the bank is a shallow depression or fosse (Wth 1.2m; D 0.2m). A N–S field fence and drain truncates a section of the bank at E.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, located on top of a hillock, at the break of slope on the SE side. The location provides extensive views over the surrounding undulating terrain; trees block views of Croagh Patrick to W and Nephin Mountain to NW. Another barrow (MA093-038001) is visible on a prominent elevation c. 200m to SSW. When inspected in 1998, this monument consisted of a central circular mound (2.4m N–S; 2.6m E–W; H 0.35m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.2m) with an external bank (Wth 2-2.5m; int. H 0.2-0.3m), with an overall diameter of c. 9m. The outer bank was poorly defined, and graded into the hill slope, and the E side of the barrow was partly dug away. An inspection in March 2017 found that the barrow has been entirely levelled.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 25 August 2017

In pasture. Depicted as hachured circular raised area (diam. c. 12m) on 1842, 1903 and 1938 OS 6-inch maps. Levelled early 1960s (UCC); surface uneven in area of site. According to Hartnett (PJH), circular raised platform (diam. c. 7m) enclosed by fosse (D 1m) with external earthen bank (H 0.6m); causewayed entrance to E. According to landowner "gold diggers" dug hole at centre of site (Hartnett 1939, 85); depression still visible, marked as souterrain (CO061-006002-) at centre of site on 1938 OS 6-inch map. Second similar depression nearby in same field. Second ring-barrow (CO061-006003-) c. 5m to S.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture. Depicted as hachured circular raised area (diam. c. 10m) on 1842, 1903 and 1938 OS 6-inch maps. Levelled early 1960s (UCC); surface uneven in area of site. According to Hartnett (1939, 84, Fig. XXI), circular raised platform enclosed by fosse with external earthen bank, of similar dimensions to ring-barrow (CO061-006001-), c. 5m to N; causewayed entrance to E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pastureland. A circular ring-barrow (diam. 13.3m), in fair condition, comprising a low flat-topped central mound (diam. 4.1m; H 0.2-0.55m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. It has been damaged at NW where a laneway runs.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

Shown on 1842, 1904 and 1939 OS 6-inch maps as hachured circular enclosure (diam. c. 20m), straddling townland boundary between Barrahaurin and Kilmartin Upper. Levelled; no visible surface trace. Hartnett (1939, 197) recorded outer bank (H c. 1m; Wth c. 3m); slight inner fosse; waterlogged interior. Stone row (6503) c. 25m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, located on the E side of a low rise. Circular platform (diam. 12m; ext. H 0.6m at W, 1.1m at E) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.5-2m) and external earth and stone bank (Wth 3-3.5m; int. H 1.2-1.5m; ext. H 0.2m at W, 1.2m at E). The central platform is slightly domed in profile, with a shallow depression (diam. c. 2m) on the NE side. The fosse is narrow relative to the external bank which is substantial, but low externally at W where it is dug into the rising slope. Stony remnants of a field fence overlie the external bank at N–E. Overall diam. (crest to crest ext. bank): 21mThe central platform is grass covered; the outer bank is ringed with gorse, thorn bushes and brambles. There is another barrow (MA082-046----) 300m to NW.Compiled by: Jane O’ShaughnessyDate of upload: 20 December 2021

In marshy flat ground, to SW of a stream. A slightly raised central area (c. 22m N-S; c. 29m E-W) defined by a dry flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 2.2m) SSE-NNE and by a scarp (H 0.5m) elsewhere. The external bank (Wth 6.6m; ext. H 1.45m; int. H 1m) is evident SSW-NNE. The E half of the interior is poached by cattle while the remainder is convex and raised c. 0.4m above the base of the fosse. Field boundaries skirt the ring-barrow E-SSE and W-N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Some 24m to the S of another ring-barrow (GA104-242----). According to McCaffrey (1952, 29, no. 19a; 1955, 225), this was a circular ring-barrow (diam. c. 13m) comprising a low flat-topped mound (diam. c. 7m; H 0.3m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. It had been levelled and cultivation ridges crossed it. No visible surface trace now survives.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 15 August 2019

On a slight hill in reclaimed pastureland. According to McCaffrey (1952, 29, no. 19b; 1955, 225), this circular ring-barrow (diam. c. 23m), comprising a low flat-topped mound (diam. c. 14m; H 0.3m) encircled by a fosse and external bank, was overgrown with furze. Cultivation ridges ran across it and numerous pits were visible in its S and W sectors. It was further damaged by an 'old ditch' which cut across it at S. No visible surface trace survives. Another ring-barrow (GA104-242001-) lies c. 24m to the S.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 15 August 2019

In tillage. Very poorly preserved subcircular enclosure (14.6m N-S; 13.5m E-W) defined by an almost completely levelled grassed-over central mound (13.5m E-W; 13.2m N-S; H 0.35-0.4m) surrounded by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.4m).   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 24 July 2019

On a hummock in gently undulating grassland. This poorly preserved circular ring-barrow (diam. c. 19.7m)  comprises a central platform surrounded by a wide shallow fosse (Wth 5.5m; D 0.4m) and a low denuded external earthen bank. The W half of the monument has been almost completely levelled.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

In pastureland. According to McCaffrey (1952, 25, no. 136; 1955, 222), this was a circular ring-barrow (diam. 20.5m) defined by a low flat-topped mound (diam. 8.8m; H 0.9m) encircled by a fosse and external bank; the NW half of the monument was destroyed during construction of the railway line which cuts across it from NE to WSW. No visible surface trace survives.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 9 August 2019

In pasture, on NW-facing slope. Depicted as hachured circular enclosure (diam. c. 18m) on 1842 OS 6-inch map; as hachured circular raised area (diam. c. 15m) on 1936 OS 6-inch map. Small, circular, grass-covered, raised area (19.50m E-W; 18.4m N-S, taken to outer limits); top level. According to local information, fosse once surrounded site but has been infilled.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pastureland at the S end of a small esker. This circular ring-barrow (diam. 24.6m), in fair condition, is defined by a flat-topped mound (diam. 9.9m; H 0.6m) encircled by a fosse (Wth 4-5m) and a low external bank (Wth 2.6-3m; int. H 0.1-0.4m; ext. H 0.35m) which is badly eroded at N. The centre of the mound has been disturbed. (McCaffrey 1952, 29, no. 21; 1955, 225; Killanin and Duignan 1967, 68)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 3 September 2018  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 4/1970).

In flat pastureland. Marked on the 1838 edition of the OS 6-inch map as a subcircular enclosure (c. 26m NW-SE; c. 22m NE-SW) and as a small mound (diam. c. 6m) surrounded by a fosse on the OS 1:2500 plan (surveyed 1912-16). No visible surface trace survives. Possibly a ring-barrow.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 30 July 2019

In a small stand of ash and sycamore trees, in a narrow strip of pasture, bordered to N by a bungalow and to S by farm sheds, located on a low rise in a natural basin of lowlying ground, with gently rising ground to NE. It is overlooked by higher ground at S. Views are restricted on all sides by farm buildings, trees and fences. Central circular mound (9.5m E–W; 10.4m N–S; H 1.25m at E, 0.9m at W), with a hint of a slightly raised rim around the flattened top. It is compact and well-defined, with a broad, steep external slope, enclosed SW–NE by a fosse (Wth 1.7m) and external bank (Wth 2.7m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.2m at W). The fosse and outer bank are well defined, although the bank is rather degraded at N–NE where its external face is incorporated into a field fence. The fosse and outer bank have been levelled at E–S; a slight surface depression at S probably indicates the line of the fosse. The ringbarrow is fenced off by a field bank at N and by post and wire fences on E, S and W. Immediately to W the ground has been partly quarried out.  Compiled by: Jane O’Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 14 June 2022

On a rise in level pastureland. This well-preserved circular ring-barrow (diam. 45.7m) comprises a low flat-topped mound (diam. 21.3m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. McCaffrey (1952, 26, 283, no. 9; 1955, 223) referred to a stone-lined ‘trough’ or ‘passage’ (L c. 3m; Wth/H c. 0.2m) in the NW quadrant, which led towards the centre of the barrow. It was built of drystone walling and roofed with lintels. A similar ‘passage’ lay to the N. No visible surface trace of these features was noted. A number of trees have been planted all over the monument and numerous rabbit burrows are evident.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

In gently undulating pastureland. Marked on the OS 1:2500 plan (surveyed 1912-16) as a roughly subcircular enclosure (c. 33m E-W; c. 30m N-S) with a central mound (c. 14m E-W; c. 12m N-S). On inspection in February 1984 no visible surface trace survived. However, its outline is very clearly visible on current OSi aerial imagery (Google Earth 2018). Possibly a ring-barrow.   Compiled by: Olive Alcock  Date of upload: 14 June 2019

In flat pastureland. Marked on the 1921 edition of the OS 6-inch map as a small circular mound (diam. c. 10m). Apart from a low rise, no visible surface trace survives. Possibly a ring-barrow as a number occur in the area: see GA114-130----, GA114-132---- and GA114-134----.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 30 July 2019

In pasture, located on a prominent rise overlooking Crossbeg Lough, which is 120m to SW and is now drained and converted to pasture.A roughly circular platform (overall diam. 7-8m; top, c. 4m; H 0.85m) of earth and stone, with a hint of a raised internal lip (Wth c. 1m), and enclosed externally by a fosse (Wth1.2-1.8m; D 0.2-0.3m) which is evident as a shallow depression. Sections of the fosse at NE, SE and W are entirely silted up or are filled with field clearance stones. The mound is partly obscured by gorse and brambles.Compiled by: Jane O’ShaughnessyDate of upload: 22 December 2021

In flat pastureland. This poorly preserved overgrown ring-barrow (diam. 25m) comprises a central platform (diam. c. 13m; H 0.9-1m) surrounded by a fosse. In 1953 Duignan (SMR file) noted traces of a ‘bank demolished in places’; no visible surface trace survives. The interior is planted with coniferous trees. A number of field-clearance spoil heaps have been piled along the edge of fosse. Other ring-barrows (GA114-130----, GA114-132---- and GA114-135----) lie c. 200m to the NE, c. 260m to the ENE and c. 90m to the SW respectively.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

On an esker ridge, c. 40m to the SW of a rath (GA104-008001-). This circular ring-barrow (diam. 15.7m) is definded by a low flat-topped mound (diam. 6.5m; H 1m) encircled by a fosse and external bank of earth and stone. The centre of the mound has been disturbed and no visible surface trace of the fosse and bank survive from NW through N to SE (SMR file). (McCaffrey 1952, 24, 208, no. 26; 1955, 221; Killanin and Duignan 1967, 190)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 9 August 2019

On a raised area in flat pastureland. This roughly circular ring-barrow (diam. 52.7m), in fair condition,  comprises a low flat-topped mound (diam. 43.4m) encircled by a fosse and external bank of earth and stone. There are two possible entrances in the bank, at N and S. Other ring-barrows (GA114-132----, GA114-134---- and GA114-135----) lies c. 80m to SSE, c. 200m to SW and c. 310m to the SSW respectively.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

On a ridge. This circular ring-barrow (diam. c. 35m) comprises a flat-topped central mound (diam. c. 13m; H 0.75-1m) which is encircled by a fosse and external bank. From SE to SSW the bank has been levelled and the fosse has been partially in-filled. The construction of a slurry pit has disturbed the bank from SW to W. (McCaffrey 1952, 26, no. 143; 1955, 223)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

In level grassland, c. 110m to the SE of a ring-barrow (GA114-130----). A NW-SE running field boundary clips the monument at SW. This densely overgrown circular area (diam. 38.3m) is defined by a fosse and traces of a possible external earthen bank. The interior is lower than the surrounding field level. Other ring-barrows (GA114-130----, GA114-134---- and GA114-135----) lie c. 80m to the NNE, c. 260m to the WSW and c. 355m to the SSW respectively.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 3 September 2018    This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 4/1971).

In level marshy land within the former demesne of Aggard House. This well-preserved circular ring-barrow (diam. 22m) is defined by a flat-topped earthen mound (diam. 14m; H 0.67-1.5m) encircled by a shallow fosse. There is a slight depression in the N sector.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 9 August 2019

Named 'Giant's Grave' and marked on the 1921 edition of the OS 6-inch map as a very small circular mound (diam. c. 7m) which was located at the NE end of a steep gravel hill named 'Giant's Hill'. The hill has since been quarried out and no visible surface trace of the monument survives. It was described in 1953 (SMR file) as a ‘low mound surrounded by a ditch and having at or near centre a degenerate chamber or cist, partly exposed’. According to local information, large quantities of unburnt bone came to light during quarrying operations, as well as one ‘small cut headstone’. (de Valera and Ó Nualláin 1972, 27)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

In pastureland. This very well-defined circular ring-barrow (overall diam. 36.2m) is defined by a central flat-topped area (diam. c. 7.5m; H 0.1m) that is level with the surrounding field or perhaps slightly lower that it. The fosse is wide and deep and the outer bank is also wide and flat and slopes to the external field level. A gap in the NW quadrant may be modern. A slight depression in the central area may indicate disturbance. A rath (GA114-131----) lies c. 25m to the SE.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 30 August 2018  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 4/1956).

In pasture, on gentle SE-facing slope. Circular area (diam. 6m-8m) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.1m) with almost levelled external bank (int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.15m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

Immediately N of a prominent E-W running ridge in rolling farmland. A well-preserved circular barrow (D 17.25m) consisting of a flat central area (D 3.8m, H 0.8m max.) encircled by a fosse, and a well-defined flat-topped external bank which has traces of an outer stone revetment at SE. A modern soil heap abuts it at NE.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

On a S-facing slope in pastureland. Named 'Lisheen' on the OS 6-inch maps, this roughly circular ring-barrow (diam. c. 20m; H 0.82m) comprises a central mound (diam. c. 4m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. A field wall overlies the bank from E through S to W. Gaps at N and S are modern. McCaffrey (1952, 25, no. 66; 1955, 222; Killanin and Duignan 1967, 190)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 9 August 2019

In pasture, on SSW-facing slope. Hachured on 1936 OS 6-inch map as mound surrounded by fosse. Levelled; circular slightly raised area (12.6m N-S; 11.5m E-W) survives, enclosed by shallow external fosse (D 0.3m). Site clearly visible as crop mark in aerial photograph (CASAP).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In level pastureland. A well-preserved circular ring-barrow (diam. 24.7m) comprising a low flat-topped mound (diam. c. 11m; H 0.9m) encircled by a fosse and external bank of earth and stone. No visible surface trace of the bank survives at SW as a result of quarrying (McCaffrey 1952, 28, no. 146; 1955, 224). Field-clearance material has been dumped on it in the SE sector.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019
In level pasture. Circular area (8m N-S; 8.5m E-W) enclosed by pair of infilled concentric fosses with almost levelled external banks (H 0.2m - 0.55m); some trace of third fosse and bank NE-
column13: ESE. Possible entrance to NNE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pastureland, c. 30m to the NW of another much-larger ring-barrow (GA114-089----) and clearly visible on an aerial photograph taken in 1970 (CUCAP BDN 37). This ring-barrow (diam. c. 15.6m), which was partially excavated by Macalister (1917, 508-11) in 1916, comprised a central flat-topped mound (diam. c. 5.3m; H 0.6m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. Macalister examined an area (diam. c. 1.5m) in the centre of the mound and found three scattered unprotected cremations, some glass beads and a fragment of a bone pin. He suggested an Iron Age date for the monument. It was re-excavated in 1969 by E. Rynne (pers. comm.) who discovered traces of seven to nine cremations, most of which were concentrated in the fosse at NW and SE. Other finds included fragments of fibulae, glass and bone beads and a gaming piece. The monument has since been quarried out and no visible surface trace survives. (Armstrong 1923, 3)   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

Immediately SE of meander in Maigue River, in rough level pasture and rushes liable to flooding. Sub-circular area (18m NNW-SSE; 21m WSW-ENE) defined by scarped edge (Wth 5.4m; H 1.05m) with three concentric flat-topped external banks and intervening fosses. The enclosing element is only fully evident SSW-W but has been partially obscured by backfilling W-E. Inner bank (Wth at top 1.6m; int. H 0.55m; ext. H 0.5m) separated from scarp by shallow fosse (Wth at base 2.5m). It widens out into level area W-E (Wth c. 10m) probably as the result of the backfilling of its external fosse. This fosse (Wth at base 2.2m) is best preserved NNE-W. Second outer bank (Wth at top 2m; int. H 0.65m; ext. H 0.2m) is best preserved NE-WNW. Its external fosse (Wth at base 1.2m) evident SSW-W and outermost bank (Wth at top 1.4m; int. H 0.8m; ext. H 0.4m) evident SSW-W. The outer elements of the enclosure have been disturbed by the draining of the river on its NW side; along the bank of the river are mounds of excavated material of recent origin. The outermost bank probably passes very close to bank of river. A mound (LI046-032----) lies immediately N of the barrow. Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

column1: CLASHGANNIV (Orrery and Kilmore By., Churchtown Par.)
column10: In level rough grazing, on E bank of stream. Circular area (24.8m NE-SW; 23.8m NW-SE) enclosed by shallow marshy fosse (D c. 0.25m) with low bank NE-
column13: ESE and SSW-
column15: N by stream and associated drain.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In level pasture. Depicted as hachured, roughly circular enclosure (diam. c. 40m) on 1842 and 1905 OS 6-inch maps; as hachured mound (diam. c. 16m) surrounded by fosse and outer bank on 1936 OS 6-inch map. Fosse shown on 1936 OS 6-inch map as solid lines with gaps to NE and S. According to local information, levelled c. 1959. Slight rise may indicate line of bank to SW; dark band of grass indicates line of fosse to E. Circular enclosure visible in aerial photograph (GSIAP, R584) as cropmark of bank and internal fosse. Possible ringfort (13053) lies c. 200m to NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In tillage on break in S-facing slope. Circular area (10m N-S; 9.8m E-W) enclosed by fosse (D 0.7m) with low external bank (H 0.4m). Bank levelled for a distance of 1.2m and fosse partially filled-in at NW. Causeway at E. Interior level.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On a rise in tillage. This circular ring-barrow (diam. 24m overall) is defined by an earthen bank,  which is overlain by a modern field wall from NNE through E to SSW, and a central mound (diam. c. 6m). McCaffrey (1952, 221, no. 83a) noted the presence of an entrance at SW. He also noted ‘an internal bank and two ditches … in the interior’. None of the above features were visible at the time of the site visit. The interior is now used as a rubbish dump.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 18 February 2019

On low-lying pastureland at the interface between reclaimed pastureland to the E and wet marshy land to the W. This poorly preserved ring-barrow (11.7m E-W) is defined by a central mound (3m E-W; H 0.6m), internal fosse (Wth 3.3m) and outer bank (Wth 1.7m; base Wth 5.4m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.85m). The fosse and outer bank are visible from S through W to N. Stone revetment is visible along the outer face of the bank at SW. It is densely overgrown with briars and thorn bushes. A modern field wall cuts through the barrow at NNE and SSE and beyond it to the E, it is obscured by rubble from field clearance.  Compiled by: Olive Alcock  Date of upload: 13 February 2019

On the summit of Kiltullagh Hill, just 5m NE of standing stone (RO032-001001-). Subcircular grass-covered area (int. dims 2.9m N-S; 2.3m E-W) defined by an earth and stone bank (Wth 2.8-3.7m; int. H 0.1m at N to 0.4m at W; ext. H 0.2m generally to 0.5m at N) with some inner facing-stones, which is quarried at E. Excavation (96E0179) revealed an outer fosse (max. ext. diam. 11m) with a cremation while the central pit was disturbed by robbing, but the mound had contained inhumations (RO031-001004-) (Coombs and Maude 1997). There was a second barrow (RO032-001003-) described by Knox (1914a, 45-6, Ring 2), whose location is uncertain but which lay to the W and might have been in Co. Mayo.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

A very much ploughed-out feature not previously marked on the OS 6-inch maps. The site consists of a low, almost circular, earthen mound c. 4.2m in diameter surrounded by a largely filled-up fosse and an exter-nal, almost ploughed out earthen bank. The latter is only .16m high. The overall diameter is 9m. There is a 2.3m gap in the bank opposite a causeway across the fosse on the E side. The site is located on marshy ground in an area of generally good pasture on a low E-W ridge on the Glencolumkille valley floor.  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

On an esker ridge overlooking lower land to the S. This circular ring-barrow (diam. 19m), in fair condition,  consists of a central mound (diam. 8.8m; H 0.65-0.9m) surrounded by a fosse and external bank. McCaffrey (1952, 27, no. 84) noted one stone slab set on edge near the centre of the monument and another possible one nearby; no visible surface trace of these survive.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

On a prominent esker hillock in pastureland. Described by McCaffrey (1952, 27, 237, no. 39a; 1955, 224) as ‘the possible remains of a smaller tumulus of the same type contiguous to, if not conjoined to’ the ring-barrow (see GA104-108----) ‘on its western side’. It is defined by a low roughly circular rise (diam. 4m; H 0.15m).   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

On a prominent esker hillock in pastureland. This circular ring-barrow (diam. 10.2m) is defined by a central mound (diam. 3.2m; H 0.2-0.6m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. No visible surface trace of the bank survives from S through W to N. McCaffrey (1952, 27, 237, no. 39a; 1955, 224), noted ‘the possible remains of a smaller tumulus [see GA104-180001-] of the same type contiguous to, if not conjoined to’ the monument ‘on its western side’.    Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

On top of a low rise, in level ground which is liable to flooding. A circular flat-topped mound (diam. c. 8m; H c. 0.3m) enclosed by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 4.7m; D c. 0.5m). The remains of an external earthen bank (H c. 0.1m) are evident W-SE with wide breaks at NE and NW. A number of kerbstones are evident around the top of the mound c. 1m in from the edge. A linear E-W field boundary has been built on the outer edge of fosse at S.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

This monument, depicted on the 1924 OS six-inch map as an embanked circular enclosure (diam. c. 45m) has been levelled. However, it is clearly evident as a cropmark on: http://binged.it/13zJonQ. The cropmark appears to show that the monument is a 'henge' type enclosure with its ditch/fosse inside the enclosing bank. This information was conveyed to ASI by Simon Dowling on 9 July 2013. Compiled by: Denis PowerDate of upload: 19 August 2013See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP – 306/15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 26 on 13/09/2002.

In pasture, just below the summit of a ridge, on a S-facing slope. This possible ring-barrow which was noted by M. A. Timoney (pers. comm.) has been levelled and is not visible at ground level. The surrounding field boundaries have also been levelled. It was one of four barrows (SL032-071----; SL032-220----; SL032-224----) on the same ridge.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In reclaimed pasture, 60m E of townland boundary with Kilbreedy, enclosure (LI039-052----) a300m to NW and enclosure (LI039-162----) 170m to NE.  Depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a raised sub-circular shaped area (dims. c. 22m N-S; 25m E-W) enclosed by a fosse, bank with external fosse. Cropmark of levelled monument clearly visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages. Faint trace of cropmark of levelled monument intersected from E-ESE by modern fence running NE-SW visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 20/09/2020.  Outline of irregular shaped area defined by a wide fosse visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 19/03/2015.  The cartographic representation of the monument on the OSi 25-inch map may suggest that this levelled earthwork was some form of barrow, possibly a large ring-barrow.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages.Compiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 8 April 2021See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP – 306/10 on 13/09/2002.

On the summit of Muckelty Hill, with commanding views all round. A raised circular area (c. 13.5m E-W) defined by a scarp (H c. 0.5m) NE-WNW with a fosse (Wth 10m) NE-WNW. An outer drystone wall (Wth 5.6m; int. H 0.7m; ext. H 1m) is evident all round. A N-S field boundary crosses the E side of the barrow and a second extends W from it crossing the N half of the interior.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On a natural rise, in pasture with panoramic views from NNE-E-S-W-NW, 105m ESE of a townland boundary with Corrabulbeg. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a circular-shaped earthwork. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as a subcircular-shaped area (18m E-W; 16m N-S) defined by a fosse (Wth 4.75m; D 0.2m) from ESE-SE and by a scarp (Wth 1.0m; H 0.15m) from ESE-SE-SSE. A wide outer bank (Wth 9.2m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.2m) is present from ESE-SE-SSE, which is reduced to scarp (Wth 0.7m; H 0.2m) from SW-W-N-NE. The surviving bank and scarp are defined by a ring of mature beech and thorn trees. Traces of an outer fosse (Wth 3.2m; D 0.2m) are present from SW-W-N-NE. There is a possible entrance at NE. The interior has a SW-facing slope and is grass covered.  Monument is visible as a roughly subcircular-shaped tree-planted earthwork on OSi aerial orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 24 October 2020
In pasture. Arc (diam. 8.5m) S-
column13: N, formed by earthen bank (max. H 2m) with depression on inside; no visible surface trace of E half. Locally known as 'lios' (Hartnett 1939, 168).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pasture. Depicted as hachured circular enclosure (diam. c. 15m) on 1842 OS 6-inch map; as hachured mound (diam. c. 9m) enclosed by fosse on 1903 OS 6-inch map. Levelled; surrounding field fences removed. According to Hartnett (1939, 180), central platform surrounded by water-logged fosse with outer earthen bank (H 3-4ft) encircling whole complex; entrance to W with field clearance stones forming causeway across fosse.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On Limerick racecourse track on a slight NW-facing slope.  Fulacht fia (LI022-226----) lies 220m to W and enclosure (LI022-185----) 200m to SE.  Not depicted on the 1840 0S 6-inch map or the 1897 25-inch OS map. Identified as Site 22 by Celie O’Rahilly, archaeologist, Limerick Corporation as part of an archaeological assessment for the development of a racecourse at Greenmount, Co. Limerick. The monument was described as following; ‘a low bank defining a figure-of-eight shape, orientated south-west/north-east.  The central area measuring 22m long by 12m wide is at a slightly lower area than the surrounding field, which slopes gently eastwards. Possible double ring-barrow’ (O‘Rahilly 1995). Visited by the ASI in 2000 and described as no surface remains visible.  Not visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 19/11/2019. See attached location map by Celie O'Rahilly showing location of site 22.Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate upload: 11 August 2020

In pasture, on gentle S-facing slope. Circular area (5.2m N-S; 5m E-W) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.25m) with almost levelled outer bank.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In farmland, c. 40m to the ESE of the site of a rath (GA104-019----). According to McCaffrey (1952, 24, no. 55; 1955, 222), this circular ring-barrow (diam. 37m) was defined by a low flat-topped mound (diam. 17.7m; H c. 0.42m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. It was subsequently bulldozed (Topgr. Files, NMI) and no visible surface trace survives. However, its outline is clearly visible as a cropmark on aerial imagery taken in 2018 (Google 2019).  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 9 August 2019

In low-lying wet pasture, 220m E of townland boundary with Ballinroche East, ring- arrows (LI022-149/150----) lie 160m to SE and enclosure (LI022-007----) lies 140m to E. Identified from an examination of 1:5000 aerial photographs (BGE No. 3224; Site No. 022195) taken 03/11/1984 associated with the Bord Gáis Éireann Cork-Dublin gas pipeline. No surface remains visible.  Site not visible on OSi orthophotos or Digital Globe imagery.  See attached Bord Gáis Éireann aerial photo (BGE No. 3224) with site labelled 022195 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 05/04/2006   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 14 August 2020

In pasture, on a NE-facing slope just below the summit of a rise. A circular mound (diam. at base: 10.4m N-S, 10.2m E-W; H 0.25m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth c. 3m; D 0.05m). A possible external bank is visible in an aerial photograph (IASAP, 3033155-6) but not at ground level.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In undulating pasture, 118m N of townland boundary with Shanaclogh, ring-barrows (LI022-150/148----) lie 15m to E and 160m to NW respectively.  Possible ringfort (LI022-007----) lies 150m to NE.  Identified from an examination of 1:5000 aerial photographs (BGE No. 3224; Site No. 022196) taken 03/11/1984 associated with the Bord Gáis Éireann Cork-Dublin gas pipeline. Site visited by the ASI in 2000 and described as irregular undulations in area of possible monument however no definite enclosing element visible. Faint outline of possible ring-barrow visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 2006.   See attached Bord Gáis Éireann aerial photo (BGE No. 3224) with site labelled 022196 and Google Earth orthoimages taken 05/04/2006  and 14/02/2020  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 14 August 2020

In undulating pasture, 118m N of townland boundary with Shanaclogh, ring-barrows (LI022-150/148----) lie 15m to E and 160m to NW respectively.  Possible ringfort (LI022-007----) lies 150m to NE.  Identified from an examination of 1:5000 aerial photographs (BGE No. 3224; Site No. 022197) taken 03/11/1984 associated with the Bord Gáis Éireann Cork-Dublin gas pipeline. Site visited by ASI in 2000 and described as circular shaped area (7.40m N-S; 7.35m E-W) defined by a bank (Wth 3.2m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.2m) with gap (1.8m) at NNW-NNE. Interior level is lower than external ground level and material for bank appears to have been scarped from interior. Faint outline of possible ring-barrow visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 2006.   See attached attached sketch plan ASI and Bord Gáis Éireann aerial photo (BGE No. 3224) with site labelled 022197 and Google Earth orthoimages taken 05/04/2006  and 14/02/2020  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 14 August 2020

In pasture. Depicted as hachured circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m) on 1842 OS 6-inch map. Levelled; no visible surface trace. According to Hartnett (1939, 285), site 'still faintly traceable....appears to have been a small ring-barrow'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on an E-facing slope. A circular flat-topped area (8.4m NW-SE) defined by a fosse (Wth 3.1m) and an external bank (int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.35m). There is a break in the bank at E with a corresponding causeway across the fosse. The edge of the interior, the fosse and the bank have been quarried into at S. Two possible barrows (SL032-183----; SL032-184----) lie c. 250m to NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on the summit of ridge. A circular flat-topped area (diam. 10m) enclosed by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 7.8m; D 1m). An external bank (Wth 3.5m; int. H 0.75m; ext. H 0.2m) is evident SE-WNW. The interior is level with the external ground in parts but is raised up to 0.45m along the S arc.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture.  Cropmark of circular-shaped area (int. diam. c. 10m; overall diam. c. 32m) defined by two widely spaced ditches approximately 7m apart visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  Possible levelled ring-barrow.    See attached Google Earth orthophotos
column13: Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère   Date of upload: 23 April 2021

column10: In undulating pasture, on the NE-facing slope of a low rise. A circular mound (diam. 6m; H 0.85m) surrounded by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 2.5m) with an external earthen bank (Wth c. 2.5m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.9m) which is stony along the SW arc. The top of the mound slopes down slightly to NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on W-facing slope. Circular area (13.8m N-S; 13.4m E-W) consisting of interior platform and infilled fosse enclosed by outer bank of earth and stone (int. H 0.75m; ext. H 1m). Low revetment of three large stones inside bank to NW. Interior planted with trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On top of a low rise, surrounded by recently planted trees. Indicated on the 1941-2 OS 6-inch map as a circular enclosure. The N half has been removed by quarrying, leaving only the S half of a circular mound (diam. 12m; H c. 0.65m) which is surrounded by a fosse (Wth c. 4.2m; D 0.35m) with an external earthen bank (Wth c. 4m; H c. 0.65m). Another ring-barrow (SL038-006----) lies c. 70m to NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on top of a low rise. A circular mound (diam. 4m; H 0.9m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.2m) ENE-N with short stretches of an external earthen bank (Wth 2.6m; H 0.8m) evident at E, S and NW. The top of the mound is concave with a slight hollow (diam. c. 2.3m; D 0.1m) in the centre. The NE edge of the ring-barrow has been removed by quarrying. A disused field boundary extends to SW from the fosse at W. Another ring-barrow (SL038-005----) lies c. 70m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated atop a low rise in pasture. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 6.6m) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth. 2.5m - 2.8m; H 0.4m) with internal fosse (Wth. 1.7m; 0.3m). Original entrance not recognisable.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In tillage, on edge of scarp which slopes down to SE. Depicted as hachured oval-shaped enclosure (c. 20m NW-SE; c. 18m NE-SW) on 1842 OS 6-inch map. Circular enclosure visible in aerial photograph (GSIAP, R526) as cropmark of fosse and faint trace of external bank. Levelled; rock outcrop, which appears to have been quarried, visible in area of site; large quarry to E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on top of a low ridge. A circular platform (diam. 5.9m; H 0.4m) surrounded by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 3.3m; D c. 0.15m) with an external earthen bank (Wth 3.5m; H 0.7m). The entrance (Wth 2m) is at NE with a causeway across the fosse. There is a field boundary on top of the bank S-N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on N-facing slope. Circular area (9.15m N-S; 9.5m E-W) enclosed by fosse with outer bank (int. H 0.85m; ext. H 0.4m). Interior planted with trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In pasture, on a NW-facing slope. A circular platform (7m N-S; 6.4m E-W) defined by a scarp (H c. 1.7m) SW-SE and surrounded by a fosse (Wth 8.8m) SW-SE with an external earthen bank (Wth 4.2m; ext. H 1.65m) all round. Another ring-barrow (SL038-055----) lies c. 450m to SSE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on a low rise in rolling pasture. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 10.4m) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth. 2.8m - 3.7m; H 0.4m) with an internal fosse (Wth. 2.3m - 2.9m; D 0.5m). The E half of the central area is largely occupied by a horizontal concrete slab from which a pipe protrudes. Immediately W of this is a shallow depression and a scattering of stones.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, on a gentle E-facing slope, immediately W of SS. Nathy and Brigid Catholic church. A circular earthen mound (diam. 8.5m; H 0.4m) with a central circular flat-bottomed depression (diam. c. 3m; D 0.5m). The mound is surrounded by a fosse (Wth 2.6m; D 0.2m) with an external earthen bank (Wth 2.1m; ext. H 0.4m). There are entrances at NE (Wth 2.5m) and WSW (Wth 1.8m) with causeways across the fosse. An E-W field boundary tops the bank along the S arc. A ditch barrow (SL038-012----) lies c. 250m to NE, a ring-barrow (SL038-015----) c. 420m to E and two possible barrows (SL038-013----; SL038-014----) c. 480m to NE and c. 350m to ESE respectively.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on the crest of a ridge with excellent views. A slightly raised subcircular area (22.5m N-S; c. 21m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 6m; D 0.65m) with an external step (Wth 4.2m; H 0.65m) and by an outer earthen bank (Wth 4.2m; ext. H 0.7m). The barrow is poached by cattle and a small portion of the interior has been removed by quarrying. A NW-SE field boundary crosses the NW edge of the interior. A ring-barrow (SL038-056----) lies c. 450m to NNW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on a low rise in rolling countryside. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 13m) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth. 2.7m - 3m; H 0.25m) with an internal fosse (Wth. 2.5m; D 0.5m). Original entrance not recognisable.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, on the S-facing slope of a ridge. A low oval mound (dims. at base 6m N-S; 7.6m E-W; max. H 0.5m) surrounded by a shallow fosse (Wth 4.5m; D 0.1-0.6m). A low outer bank is visible in an aerial photograph (IASAP, 3033162-3).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture atop hill. Circular area (diam. 9.2m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.6m) with external bank (H 0.7m). Entrance, with causeway across fosse at E. Interior level.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 1: West Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1992). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In undulating pasture, just off the top of a low rise. A circular area (diam. 8m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth 3m; D c. 0.5m) and an external earthen bank (Wth 3m; ext. H 0.7m). The entrance is at E with a causeway across the fosse. The bank is overgrown with blackthorn and hawthorn bushes. This is one of five barrows in the vicinity (SL038-011----; SL038-012----; SL038-013----; SL038-014----).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In rough grazing, on gentle SW-facing slope. Circular area (diam. c. 5.2m) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.3m) with external earthen bank (H 0.35m). Four fulachta fiadh (11010, 11011, 11012, 11013) c. 50m to N, c. 40m to S, c. 40m to NNE, c. 50m to ESE respectively. Two fulachta fiadh (11014, 11015) c. 150m to E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On a low dry rise, in otherwise flat poorly drained ground. Kesh Corann, crowned by its cairn (SL040-008----), is visible in the distance to E. A low circular platform (11.4m E-W; H 0.3m at NE), with a slightly concave top, is defined by a fosse (Wth 3.7m) and an external bank (Wth 3.7m; int. H 0.2-0.5m; ext. H 0.3m). Moss-covered stones are visible barely protruding from the perimeter of the central platform, and from the external bank. A gap (Wth 3.8m) at N is approached from N by a linear depression (L c. 7m; Wth 3.8m). The overall diameter of the external bank is 21m. A ring-barrow (SL038-085----) lies c. 600m to ENE.
