The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of revised upload: 6 November 2017

In improved pasture 160m N of Camoge River. Enclosure (LI031-160---) lies 260m to SW.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified from examination of aerial photograph (BGE 1:5000 No. 44) of the region taken on 03/11/1984 associated with Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraghleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline.  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 or on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 25 March 2021
In pasture, on N-facing slope. More northerly of a pair of conjoined ring-barrows (11847). Circular area (diam. 3.4m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.26m) with external bank (H 0.33m). Bank conjoined SE-
column13: SW, to bank of other ring-barrow.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In pasture, on N-facing slope. More southerly of a pair of conjoined ring-barrows (11846). Circular area (diam. 5m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.16m) with external bank (H 0.16m). Bank conjoined NW-
column13: NE to bank of other ring-barrow.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In gently undulating pasture on a slight E-facing slope 70m E of townland boundary with Bawnacouma.  Ringfort (LI022-029----) located 150m to W. Surveyed by the ASI in 2000 and described as a raised circular shaped area (diam. 12m) defined by a scarped edge (H 0.4m) and an external fosse (Wth 4m) visible from SE to N with a possible ramped entrance (Wth 3m) at E. The undulating interior has a channel (Wth 1.1m; D 0.2m) running E-W, possibley a drainage ditch. Local information indicated the site was levelled c. 1950.  The outline of the monument bisected by a post 1700 drainage ditch is visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 06/02/2018.See attached sketch plan surveyed by the ASI and Google Earth orthoimage Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 7 August 2020

In level pasture. Circular area (diam. 5.6m) enclosed by fosse (D 0.15m) with external bank (H 0.14m). Almost levelled.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In flat pasture. A raised circular area (diam. 1.7m) surrounded by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.3m) and an external bank (Wth 1.9m; ext. H 0.56m); some disturbance has occurred along the E arc causing bank slippage (pers. comm. J. Farrelly and M. Keane). Another ring-barrow (SL038-084----) lies c. 600m to WSW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

This monument is located in undulating, low-lying pasture NW of the Camoge river. The monument looks onto a broken circle of hills which surround the county from Foynes in the NW to Drumcollliher in the S and the Galty Mtns in the SE. It comprises a broken circuit of bank (Wth 5m, H 1m), inside of which is a silted-up fosse (Wth 4m, D 0.4m) giving the monument an overall diameter of c. 42m. There is a definite break in the E (Wth 2m). The bank either side of this is squared off and retained by a stone revetment (O'Kelly, 1944-5, 49).  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout   Date of upload: 3 February 2012  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 308/31 taken 13/09/2002 and 329/7 taken 05/10/2002.

In pasture, on the highest point of a bog-island. A circular level area (diam. c. 10m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2.8m; D 0.15m). A possible external bank, visible in an aerial photograph (IASAP, 3033069-70) E-S, is not visible at ground level. The barrow is heavily poached by cattle.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, 15m SW of a townland boundary with Cloghnamanagh. Enclosure (LI031-031----) and ringfort (LI031-029----) lie 175m to SW and 270m to W, respectively. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a roughly oval-shaped earthwork (34m NE-SW; 30m NW-SE) defined by a field boundary from W-NW. Classified by O’Kelly (1944, 49) as a ring-barrow and described as following: ‘This consists of a low bank inside which there is a fosse, while the centre is occupied by a low mound. The bank and fosse are continuous on the E, S and N sides, but on the W a modern fence has been built over them. The overall diameter is 90’ (27m) and the maximum height of the mound is 8’ (2.4m).’    Monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped area defined by a fosse with external bank, on OSi aerial orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe aerial orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 3 November 2020

On a gentle W-facing slope, in undulating pasture, with moderate views in all directions. The townland boundary with Kilderry lies 225m to SW. Ring-barrow (LI022-203----) 65m to S. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a small circular-shaped cropmark, by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 7902: AP4/3071). Monument surveyed in 2000 by the ASI and described as no surface remains visible. Faint outline of possible monument visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12.  Circular shaped feature barely visible on Digital Globe orthophoto taken 25/03/2017.  Not visible on other Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff aerial survey image with feature labelled 7902.   Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 28 August 2020

This is the record for a monument identified by The Discovery Programme, from medium-altitude aerial photographs taken in 1986 [see Doody, M. (2008) The Ballyhoura Hills Project, Discovery Programme Monograph No 7, Wordwell, pp 65-100]. The reference for this monument is LI022: Bruff 7901: AP 4/3701.

Situated on a lawn in the rear garden of a dwelling. The ring-barrow stands immediately W of the remains of a megalithic tomb (SL007-040001-). It measures c. 6.5-7m in diameter. The central mound (diam. c. 3m) and outer-bank (Wth 1-1.2m) are visible as a slight rise (0.1-0.15m) above the surface of the lawn. The outer element of the bank at W fades into a slight rise in ground surface where it borders the remains of the megalithic tomb.  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 20 April 2012  See linked document with plan.

In wet pasture. Possible site  (Site No. 031189) identified during examination of aerial photographs (BGE 1/50000 2506) taken 03/11/1984 on the Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraghleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline.   Cropmark of small circular-shaped earthwork immediately south of a pond visible on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-12 and on Google earth orthoimage dated 04/04/2013.    See attached aerial photograph from Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh-Limerick gas pipeline (BGE 1/50000 2506) and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 26 March 2021  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP – 307/15 taken 13/09/2002

This is the record for a monument identified from medium-altitude aerial photographs taken in 1986 (see Doody, M. (2008) The Ballyhoura Hills Project, Discovery Programme Monograph No 7, Wordwell, pp 65-100; the Ballyhoura Hills Project reference number LI022: Bruff 86: AP 4/3700).  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 14 August 2012

In reclaimed wet pasture 300m NW of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Rathcannon.  A conifer plantation is located 180m to S. Possible barrow (LI031- 151002-) lies 80m to SE.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  Identified from examination of aerial photograph (BGE 1:5000 No. 48) of the region taken 03/11/1984 associated with Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline.  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophotos taken between 2005-2012 or on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 16 March  2021

In wet pasture 285m NW of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Rathcannon.  A conifer plantation is located 200m to S. Possible barrow (LI031- 151004-) lies 15m to SE.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  Identified from examination of aerial photograph (BGE 1:5000 No. 48) of the region taken 03/11/1984 associated with Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline.  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-2012 or on any Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 16 March  2021

In wet pasture 270m NW of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Rathcannon.  A conifer plantation is located 185m to S. Possible barrow (LI031- 151003-) lies 15m to NW.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  Identified from examination of aerial photograph (BGE 1:5000 No. 48) of the region taken 03/11/1984 associated with Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline.  Visible as a cropmark on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 16 March  2021

In flat pasture within a small field 134m SE of the Morningstar River and the townland boundary with Mortgage. Glenogra Castle (LI031-038004-) lies 60m to WNW with an enclosure (LI031-038008-) 185m to SSE.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. The ring-barrow is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12; not visible on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 1000: AP 4/3598) as a ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 6m). The site is visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017 but not on the later orthoimage taken 28/06/2018. See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 1000 and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 20 October 2020

In undulating pasture, on top of a NE-SW ridge. A circular area enclosed by an earthen bank (Wth 2.8m; int. H 0.65m; ext. H 0.9m) with traces of a possible internal fosse (Wth c. 1.5m) evident NNW-SE. The overall diameter is 23.2m E-W. The bank is uniform, overgrown with hawthorn bushes and incorporated into a field boundary SSE-SSW. The interior is a low flattened dome-shape with gently sloping sides most clearly defined W-SE. Field boundaries lie immediately to the E of the barrow and there is a steep slope immediately to E and S.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In reclaimed pasture 140m W the townland boundary with Ballygubba North. Depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map as a circular-shaped earthwork.  Shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a roughly circular-shaped area (diam. c. 16m) defined by a scarp with fosse and outer bank truncated at S by drainage ditch running E-W.  Levelled monument visible as a circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12.  Outline of levelled ring-barrow (overall diam. c. 32m) visible on Google Earth orthoimages visible to the immediate N of a drainage ditch running E-W.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 6 May 2021

In improved pasture 75m S of R516 that marks the townland boundary with Camas. Not depicted on any OSi historic maps.  Monument identified as a ring-barrow by Grogan (1989, 222) and labelled in his thesis as 'Carrigeen 1'.  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 or on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 1 April 2021

Circular area (diam. 18.5m) enclosed by earthen bank (H 1.5m). Interior inaccessible due to overgrowth. According to Hartnett (1939, 240), wet fosse inside bank 'encircles a low central platform'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On flat pasture 240m S of the townland boundary with Glenogra. Moated site (LI031-042----) 360m to ESE and enclosure (LI031-202---) 60m to SSW. The site is not depicted on OSi historic maps. The ring-barrow is faintly visible on the OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 and on the Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 65: AP 4/3598) as a ring-barrow (ext. dims. c. 6m). The ring barrow is not identifiable on Google Earth orthoimages including the most recent taken 25/03/2017 and 28/06/2018. See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 65 and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 19 October 2020

In reclaimed pasture, 150m from Morningstar River that marks townland boundary with Camas South and 140m NW of excavation site (LI031-115----). Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible earthwork identified from examination of aerial photographs dated 06/11/1984  associated with Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraghleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline (map 6, Site 6/1).   Monument visible as an oval-shaped area (dims. c. 7m NW-SE; 11m NE-SW) defined by a fosse with external bank on Google Earth orthoimages.  A curvilinear feature visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 04/04/2013 represents the remains of a watercourse running either side of the monument.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 29 March 2021

This is the record for a monument identified by The Discovery Programme, from medium-altitude aerial photographs taken in 1986 [see Doody, M. (2008) The Ballyhoura Hills Project, Discovery Programme Monograph No 7, Wordwell, pp 65-100]. The reference for this monument is LI022: Bruff 95: AP 4/3651.

Ring barrow discovered by Frank Coyne in summer of 2010. He describes it as follows: 'This ring barrow is located in a large open field, devoted to pasture, to the W of Kilmallock town, in the townland of Ash Hill. It is situated 170m to the W of the outer extent of the edge of the proposed development, and 40m to the S of Greenfield Road. A low circular grass?covered mound (5.5m in diameter) is defined by a 1.5m wide fosse, with an outer bank (1.6m wide by 0.2m high above exterior ground level. The bank is denuded at SE, where a 6m wide gap occurs. This may represent the location of the original entrance.'

Situated on poorly drained floodplains of the Graigue River which runs past the monument immediately to S.  Area depicted as wet land, annotated ‘Liable to Floods’ on the 1840 ed. OS 6-inch map.  Outline of circular shaped area (approx. int. diam. 20m; ext. diam. 50m) defined by a scarp with ditch, bank, ditch and external bank which is clearly visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-13.   Outline of monument clearly visible on 2005 OSi orthophoto and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 16/03/2016.See attached Google Earth orthophotos taken 16/03/2016Compiled by: Caimin O’BrienDate of upload: 29 May 2020

In pasture, on the NW-facing slope of a drumlin. A slightly raised circular area (4m N-S; 3.95m E-W) enclosed by a shallow waterlogged fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.35m) and an external earth and stone bank (Wth 3.6m; int. H 0.75m; ext. H 0.8m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on level summit of a broad rise in gently undulating pasture. Circular area (diam. 14m) defined by a scarp (ext. H 0.2m) with a fosse (Wth 5.3m) and an external bank of earth (Wth 6m; int. H 0.4m). An E-W orientated field boundary bank of earth and stone crosses the site at SW and at SE. The scarped edge, the fosse and the external bank are absent to the S of this boundary. There is a modern break (Wth 4m) in the external bank at NE.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

In flat wet pasture, with gently rising ground to SW. Visible as an oval enclosure in an aerial photograph (OSAP 6, 4083-4). The barrow lies within a dense expanse of irises and rushes and little of it is visible at ground level. A band (Wth c. 3m) of mixed rushes and irises suggests a possible fosse enclosing a roughly circular flat area (diam. c. 20m). At NW, a slight rise (Wth 3-4m) may represent an outer bank.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture. Depicted as hachured circular enclosure (diam. c. 18m) on 1842, 1903 and 1940 OS 6-inch maps. Levelled; no visible surface trace. According to Hartnett (1939, 140), consisted of 'an earthen bank, with inner ditch, surrounding a circular (slightly convex) central platform'; overall diameter 85ft.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 3: Mid Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In rough pasture, 208m W of townland with Ballygreenan. One of a cluster of 3 barrows (LI039-044002/007-) with the closest barrow (LI039-044002-) 10m to the E. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Possible site  (Site No. 039147) identified during examination of aerial photographs (BGE 1/50000 2544) taken 03/11/1984 on the Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh-Limerick gas pipeline. Cropmark of small circular-shaped earthwork visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google earth orthoimages.    See attached aerial photograph from Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh-Limerick gas pipeline (BGE 1/50000 2544) and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 6 April 2021

Situated on poorly drained, partially reclaimed rushy pasture, that was formerly the floodplain of the Camoge River.  This stream flows from N to S immediately to the E.  A post-1700 linear drainage channel to W is visible as a cropmark on aerial photographs and on the revised edition of the OS 6-inch map.  One of five mounds recorded as feature G01F003 in 2012 LiDAR Survey (Motherway 2012, 77, 276).  Four mounds or possible barrows (LI022-258-/59-/60-/61-) are visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-12.  On this aerial photograph three possible barrows are roughly aligned on a NW-SE axis.Earthwork visible on OSi aerial photographs taken 2005-2012, present remains consist of a low circular-shaped mound (approx. int. diam. 7m) enclosed by a ditch (approx. Wth 1m) immediately E of a post-1700 field drainage ditch.  Original watercourse of the Camoge River can be seen closer to the possible barrows on OSi aerial photographs 2005-2012.  This possible ring-barrow is not visible today on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-2013.See attached LiDAR plot showing location of 5 mounds and OSi aerial orthophotos showing location of 3 possible barrows.Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Sarah McCutcheon and Ella MotherwayDate of upload: 29 April 2020

On flat wet pasture 125m SW of townland boundary with Ballycullane and Grange, 1.7km WNW of Lough Gur. The ring-barrow (LI031-176002-) is one of nine ring-barrows with an enclosure (LI031-076001-; LI031-076003/8- and LI031-177001/2-) in a ring-barrow cemetery within a 200m radius. The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps. It is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 and on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 37; AP 4/3644) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 6m). The ring-barrow is faintly visible on the Google Earth orthoimage taken 05/04/2006, but not on the latest Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 37 and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 22 October 2020

In rough pasture, on the W-facing slope of a drumlin. Described as a raised oval area (18m N-S; 16.2m E-W) enclosed by a broad shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.25m) with an external earthen bank (Wth 2.1m; int. H 0.9m; ext. H 0.5m); some stones are evident in the bank composition (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly). The bank is incorporated into a field boundary along the W arc. A barrow (SL039-009----) lies c. 230m to NW and a mound barrow (SL039-010----) c. 170m to W. A cairn (SL040-008----) on Kesh Corann Hill is visible in the distance to E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On undulating pasture 140m SW of the townland boundary with Stonepark. The ring-barrow (LI023-268----) is one of a pair of ring-barrows (LI023-292----) 8m apart. Ring-barrow (LI023-269----) located in the adjacent field 120m to ESE. The site is not depicted on historic OSi maps but is visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 24901; AP 4/3706) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 10m). The ring-barrow is visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 02/06/2018, it is less obvious on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 24901 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 4 September 2020

In low-lying, wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses. A ring-barrow (LI023-268----) lies 4m to SW and a ring-barrow (LI023-269----) lies 110m to ESE. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a small, circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 249.01: AP 4/3706). Monument is visible as a suboval-shaped cropmark (11m NE-SW; 10m NW-SE) on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthophoto taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage 25/03/2017 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 249.01.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 14 September 2020

On a low-lying level landscape with a NW-SE stream c. 20m to the NE. Subcircular grass-covered platform (dims 15.5m N-S; 11.8m E-W; H 0.4-0.5m) defined by a fosse (at S: Wth of top 4.7m; Wth of base 3m; D 0.6m; at E: Wth of top 7.4m; Wth of base 5.4m; D 0.6m) and outer bank (Wth 3.8-5.2m; ext. H 0.2-0.4m). The platform and bank are quarried at SE, while the bank has been augmented at N (Wth 7.4m) and removed (L 12m) by a NE-SW farm track at NW (max. ext. dims 34.2m N-S; 30.3m E-W).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 23/1956).

On undulating pasture 70m SW of the townland boundary with Stonepark.   Ring-barrows (LI023-268/292----) are located in the adjacent field 120m to WNW. The site is not depicted on historic OSi maps but is visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 24903; AP 4/3706) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 10m). The ring-barrow is visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 06/02/2018, it is less obvious on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 02/07/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 24903 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 4 September 2020

This is the record for a monument identified by The Discovery Programme, from medium-altitude aerial photographs taken in 1986 [see Doody, M. (2008) The Ballyhoura Hills Project, Discovery Programme Monograph No 7, Wordwell, pp 65-100]. The reference for this monument is LI023: Bruff 15901: AP 4/3696.

On the N side of a ridge with good views N, E and W. Located 30m SW of the historic road/trackway (LI023-241----) overlooking the Camoge River 580m to N.  Cave site (LI023-240----) 270m to S near the summit of the ridge. The barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps but is visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12.   Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 118; AP 4/3665) as a circular ring–barrow (ext. diam. c. 15m) defined by a fosse. The N side of the barrow abuts an E-W field boundary. The site is visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 05/04/2006, 16/03/2016 and 28/06/2018.See attached Bruff survey image showing ring-barrow labelled Bruff 118 and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload:  25 August 2020

On a very slight rise in an expanse of flat poorly drained pasture. The ground slopes down gently to E towards the Owenmore River. A slightly raised circular platform (23.8m NE-SW; c. 20m NW-SE) defined by a broadly sloping scarp (H 1.2m; Wth slope 4.7m) with traces of an internal lip. A shallow external fosse (Wth 4-5m), marked by soft wet ground and a dense growth of rushes, is evident all round while the outer bank (Wth c. 5m) survives SW-NW as a broad low rise. The outer edge of the fosse is poorly defined and S-SW merges imperceptibly with the very boggy surrounding ground. The top of the platform is level. A bowl-barrow (SL026-125----) lies c. 100m to ENE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on a slight rise, on a slight NNE-facing slope, in gently undulating, good pasture. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 4.1m) enclosed by a broad scarp of earth (ext. H 0.2m). At the base of the scarp is a fosse (Wth 2.5m) and a broad external bank of earth (Wth 3.5m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.45m). A modern causeway (Wth 1.9m) crosses the fosse at W.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

Situated on a slight SE-facing slope in gently undulating elevated rocky pasture. The site is very disturbed and low in profile. Circular mound (diam. base 10m; H 0.2m) of earth and stone. Around the external base of the mound is a berm (Wth 2m) and an external bank (Wth 3.6m; H 0.15m) of earth and stone. The interior of the central mound has been removed and the spoil has been thrown up around the edge to form an irregular bank of earth and stone (Wth 3.5-4.7m; int. H 0.15-0.3m; ext. H 0.2m) E-NNE. From SW-NE the external bank and berm are absent. The external bank has been incorporated into a now relic field boundary bank NE-SW. Relic field boundary banks link to the external bank at NE and at E.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

Situated on a slight rise, on a slight E-facing slope, in gently undulating good pasture. Circular area (diam. 7m) enclosed by a broad scarp of earth (ext. H 0.15m). At the base of the scarp is a fosse (Wth 2.7m) and an external bank of earth (Wth 3.1m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.35m). The external bank has been almost entirely removed NE-SE where it is barely visible.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

Timoney (1984, 322, no. 5) describes this as follows: ‘The total diameter of this barrow, sited on the crest of a glacial ridge, is 21m. A central platform, 6.60m in diameter and 70cm high, is surrounded by a fosse, 2.90m wide and 20cm deep and this in turn by a bank 1.70m wide by 25cm high. There is a bank, 2.50m wide and 60cm high, along part of the northern edge of the central platform. Parts of the west and south sides of this monument have been disturbed in antiquity and the break in the outer bank does not appear to be original. Land improvements in 1982 resulted in the destruction of the outer bank. Burenhult (1980, 94) lists this as Structure 26, Knocknahur North, recte Breeoge. It is within Phosphate Field XIV. Only very small increases of phosphate values were recorded (Burenhult 1980:1, 105).’  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 28 January 2014

Timoney (1984, 322, no. 2) describes this as follows: ‘Sited on top of a drumlin and overgrown with whins, this ring-barrow is 14.50 m in overall diameter. A circular mound, 6.10 m in diameter and 65 cm high, is surrounded by "U"-bottomed fosse, 1.90 m wide and 55 cm deep, and this in turn is surrounded by a bank, 2.30 m wide and 50 cm high. Burenhult (1980:1, 93, 107) includes this within Structure 13, Knocknahur North, recte Ballybeg, a group of five structures, all of which registered very low phosphate values.’  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 28 January 2014

Timoney (1984, 322, no. 3) describes this as follows: ‘This ring-barrow on flat ground has been ploughed down to a considerable extent and is perceptible only under a low setting sun. The total diameter appears to be in the region of 18.50 m. On the southwest side the bank remains to a height of only 13 cm. This is surrounded by a 3 m wide by 15 cm deep fosse and a bank, 3.50 m wide which averages 20 cm in height but is at most 30 cm high. Burenhult (1980:1, 93, 107) includes this within Strutture 13, Knocknahur North, recte Seafield, a group of five structures, all of which registered very low phosphate values. This would appear to be one of the structures included in map 26 (Burenhult 1980:1, 109), the other being unknown to the writer. However recent ploughing for the development of this field for sports has destroyed all of the surface except for the two Seafield barrows listed herein (3).’  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 28 January 2014

Timoney (1984, 322, no. 4) describes this as follows: ‘The total diameter of this ring-barrow, sited on flat ground, is 15 m. A circular mound, 5 m in diameter and 40 cm high, is surrounded by a "U"-bottomed fosse 2.70 m wide and 35 cm deep and this in turn by a bank 2.30 m wide and 40 cm high. The south side of the bank has been disturbed by the building of a modern field bank. The developments of the field mentioned above under Seafield I have caused the removal of the top part of the bank and the barrow-proper for most of the northwest third of the monument. Burenhult (1980:1, 93, 107) includes this within Structure 13, Knocknahur North, recte Seafield, a group of five structures, all of which registered very low phosphate values.’  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 28 January 2014

Timoney (1984, 322, no. 6) describes this as follows: ‘The total diameter of this overgrown ring-barrow, sited on the crest of a glacial ridge, is in the region of 19m. It is known locally as "Jenny's Fort". A low flat topped mound, 10m in diameter and not more than 30cm high, is enclosed by a "U'-bottomed fosse, 2.50m wide and 40cm deep, and this in turn-by a bank, 2m wide and 35cm high. Burenhult (1980:1, 95) lists this as Structure 46, Knocknahur North, recte Breeoge. It is within Phosphate Field XIV. Only very small increases of phosphate values were recorded (Burenhult 1980:1, 105).’  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 28 January 2014

Situated on a slight SW-facing slope in gently undulating pasture. Circular area (diam. 5.5m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (ext. H 0.15m). At the external base of the scarp are a fosse (Wth 3m) and an external bank of earth (Wth 3m; H 0.25m). There is a modern causeway across the fosse, with a corresponding break (Wth 2m) in the external bank, at SW.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

In an overgrown copse to the S of modern houses. A raised circular area (diam. 13m) is enclosed by a fosse (Wth 4.1m), an earthen bank (int. H 1.19m; ext. H 0.94m; Wth 3.7m), which encloses the site from SE to N, an outer fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.94m), which encloses the site from SW to NW and an external bank (dims. unattainable due to dense vegetation), which encloses the site from SW to NW. There is a causewayed entrance (Wth 4.5m) at the E.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

On flat pasture on the E side of a ridge. The site is located 250m W of the townland boundary with Ballingoola, 80m NE of the enclosure (LI023-064----) and 180m SW of a ringfort (LI023-068----). The barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps but is faintly visible feature on Digital Globe orthoimage. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 as ‘not clear on AP’ (Bruff 123; AP 4/3642). A faint circular ring–barrow defined by an external fosse (ext. diam. c. 11m) is visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 16/03/2016 and 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing ring-barrow labelled Bruff 123 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 31 August 2020

In wet pasture, 10m N of a land drain and 30m E of a tributary of the Camoge River. A ring-barrow (LI023-239----) lies 115m to NE. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Described by Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott (1949, 127) as a barrow on an irregularly-shaped platform. Visible as a small circular-shaped earthwork on the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff AP 4/3642). Monument is visible as a faint circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 8m) on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018 and location map showing barrow marked site X after Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott 1949.   Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 28 August 2020

In wet pasture, 5m E of a tributary of the Camoge River. A second ring-barrow (LI023-067002-) lies 4m to S. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott (1949, 127) as a ring-barrow (Ballingoola II) and described as a level circular-shaped area (diam. 6m) defined by a shallow ditch and the remains of an outer bank which was only discernible in places.  Excavated by MacDermott and described as following; The sites, which consisted of a level space enclosed by a shallow ditch and a very slight outer bank (only discernible in places), were approximately of equal size 6 metres in diameter from outside of ditch to outside ofditch. Their centres were 10 metres apart. Before excavation the ditch of Site I (the southern barrow) was most clearly marked at the south side and traces of an outer bank were discernible at the south and south-east, rising up at the south-east towards the edge of a modern field-ditch which bordered on the sites at this side. The outer bank was again visible at the northwhere the ground rose and fell again to leave a slight depression between Sites I and II. The ditch of Site II was clearly marked at the south, north and west, and on the west the outer bank could also be traced. At the east the ditch was barely visible and there was no trace of a bank.Outside the barrows, to the east, the ground sloped towards a depression caused by an ancient river bed which could be also traced round the south of Barrow I.  On removal of the sod from Site II, charcoal spreads were again noted. In the south-east quadrant a few fragments of pottery and stone-axe chips were found in a stony charcoal spread just outside the ditch at the east. This spread formed part of a raised stony area which appeared at the north east of the barrow and which contained much charcoal. Extensions were cut to determine the extent of the burnt material and a widespread stony area was revealed containing thick deposits of charcoal and burnt bone. A considerable quantity of pottery, Beaker and Neolithic in type, was found in this area, also numerous flints and some fragments of stone axes. A setting of stones indicating a hearth site overlay a pit with a heavy charcoal content in which pottery and flints were found to a depth of 44 cm. Another pit, 35 cm. deep, also contained much charcoal and burnt bone' (Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott 1949, 139-42).Monument is not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018. See attached sketch plan of barrow and location map showing barrow marked II after Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott 1949.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 29 August 2020

In flat pasture 150m E of a tributary flowing gently N to the Camoge River. A ring-barrow (LI023-065----) lies 115m to SW. The monument is not depicted on historic OSi maps but is visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12 and on the later Digital Globe orthoimage. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 119; AP 4/3642) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 10m). Outline of monument visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 25/03/2017, not visible on the most recent image taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing enclosure labelled Bruff 119 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 31 August 2020

In wet pasture, 5m E of a tributary of the Camoge River. A second ring-barrow (LI023-067001-) lies 4m to N. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott (1949, 127) as a ring-barrow (Ballingoola I) and described as a level circular-shaped area (diam. 6m) defined by a shallow ditch and the remains of an outer bank which was only discernible in places.  Excavated by MacDermott and described as following; The sites, which consisted of a level space enclosed by a shallow ditch and a very slight outer bank (only discernible in places), were approximately of equal size 6 metres in diameter from outside of ditch to outside ofditch. Their centres were 10 metres apart. Before excavation the ditch of Site I (the southern barrow) was most clearly marked at the south side and traces of an outer bank were discernible at the south and south-east, rising up at the south-east towards the edge of a modern field-ditch which bordered on the sites at this side. The outer bank was again visible at the northwhere the ground rose and fell again to leave a slight depression between Sites I and II. Outside the barrows, to the east, the ground sloped towards a depression caused by an ancient river bed which could be also traced round the south of Barrow I.  On excavation it was seen that the soil conditions on these sites were similar to those at Ballingoola III and IV a tenaciousyellow clay underlay the humus everywhere except in the western half of Site I where boulder clay appeared. The ditches were cut into the clay to a depth of approximately 48cm. They had evidently filled or been filled very rapidly because the fill was practically indistinguishable from the undisturbed clay, but their outline was clearly marked in the sections by a dark humus band. The slight outer bank could not be seen in all the sections but in some places appeared clearly as a thin spread over the old turf line. There were no traces of any structure or grave remainsin either barrow.  Scatters of charcoal and burnt stone appeared near the centre in all quadrants of Site I. In the south-east quadrant were two dark hollows, approximate depth 35 cm., containing much charcoal and burnt stone.  Some small fragments of coarse gritty pottery came from the hollow at the south. Trenches were cut through these hollows to determine the relationship between them and the ditch and it was revealed that the ditch had been cut into the burnt material which therefore ante-dated the barrow. Charcoal and burnt stone also appeared under the bank at the east. Besides the pottery which was not distinctive, the only other finds from Ballingoola I were a small flint flake and some waste fragments of chert' (Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott 1949, 139-42).Monument is not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018. See attached sketch plan of barrow and location map showing barrow marked I after Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott 1949.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 29 August 2020

In wet, low-lying pasture, in the angle of two land drains, 160m SW of a townland boundary with Ballingoola. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as Site Y by Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott (1949, 127) and described as a ring-barrow cut into the surface of a rectangular-shaped platform (LI023-069001-) along with two other ring-barrows (LI023-069002-/004-).   This monument was described by O'Kelly (1944, 48) as a 'very low rectangular platform surrounded by a very shallow fosse.  The entrance is not recognisable.  It measures overall 75' [22.8m] N-S by 45' [13.7m] E-W.  At its S end and lying sided by side are two barrows, one oval and the other circular.  These are low mounds surrounded by shallow fosses which are joined into that of the rectangle.  The oval barrow is 45' [13.7m] N-S by 23' [7m] E-W while the other is 24' [7.3m] in diameter.  The third one, also 24' [7.3m] in diameter, lies to the south of the oval barrow, both fosses being conjoined.  The monuments are situated just beyond the edge of an extensive marsh'.  Monuments are not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018. See attached Google Earth orthoimages and location map showing platform and ring-barrows marked Y after Ó Ríordáin and MacDermott 1949.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 29 August 2020

Situated on slight S-facing slope, on the side of a small hillock, in gently undulating pasture. In reclaimed pasture, immediately N of townland boundary with Ballynamona, within a field system (LI040-061001-), N of barrow complex (LI040-061002-/061009-). Depicted on the Cassini ed. OSi 6-inch map as a small circular platform (diam. c. 15m) defined by a scarp. Monument described by O'Kelly (1944, 52) as a ring-barrow; ‘This structure is part of the above complex but is separated from the other monuments by the townland boundary. It is a very low mound surrounded by a slight fosse outside which there is a definite bank, and outside that another fosse. The max. height of the bank is 1’ 6” [0.48m] and the overall diameter is 60’ [18.2m]. The structure is somewhat larger than the usual barrow of this type in the barony. It is possible that it is a small fort but the continuous fosse seems to indicate otherwise”. Monument visible as a circular-shaped area defined by overgrown fosse on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages dated 24/09/2018 and 14/09/2019. In level pasture, at the break of a NW-facing slope. A circular area (diam. 2m) defined by a fosse and external earthen bank. The fosse (Wth c. 1.3m) is visible only as an area of soft ground inside the bank. The surface of the interior is even and grass-covered and level with the external ground level. The bank (Wth 4.2m; int. H 0.35m; ext. H 0.40m) is evident all around but is broken at SW and NW where it is crossed by a N-S field boundary.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005). In pasture, on the spine of a ridge which affords panoramic views. Part of a small barrow cemetery consisting of an adjacent bowl-barrow (SL033-039002-) immediately to E and another larger bowl-barrow (SL033-039001-) c. 30m to S. Excavation in 1993 (Mount 1995a, 81-5) showed that this ring-barrow consisted of a low circular mound (diam. 6m; H 0.5m above fosse) enclosed by a shallow penannular fosse (Wth 0.36m at base, 1.6m at top; D 0.68m) with a low external bank (Wth 1.7m; H 0.25m above original ground level) SE-NE; no fosse or bank existed along the E arc where they respect the fosse and low bank of the adjacent bowl-barrow (SL033-039002-). A number of pits were uncovered in the mound, two of which contained small quantities of bone fragments, and in the base of the fosse at W there was a deposit of charcoal and cremated bone (Mount 1998, 21). A sample of charcoal from one of the pits in the mound was radiocarbon dated to cal. BC 114-71 AD (ibid.).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In level pasture, with good view of Knockroe Hill to ENE. Circular area (18m NNW-SSE; 17m WSW-ENE) defined by scarped edge (Wth 5.3m; Dth 0.3m) with external earthen bank (Wth 9.75m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 2.45m); the bank is lowest ENE-E. Wide intervening fosse (basal Wth 4.5m; overall Wth 16.2m; Dth 1.05m) is well defined except ENE-E where shallow. Fosse is fenced off and waterlogged WSW-WNW. Remains of outer bank (Wth 9.95m; int. H 1.05m; ext. H 0.25m) intermittent WNW-NNE and ESE-S-WSW; truncated by land drain and field boundary WSW-WNW. Dry, linear depression truncates exterior of outer bank SSE-SSW. Electricity pylon stands 5m to SE of monument.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 31 October 2013

In pasture, on the top of and on the W edge of a ridge. A subcircular flat area (diam. 7.5m) defined by a fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.6m) with the remains of an external earthen bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.4m). There is a causeway (Wth 2m) across the fosse at NE. The barrow is overgrown with furze bushes. A ring-barrow (SL033-048----) is c. 100m to ENE and a bowl-barrow (SL033-049----) c. 150m to NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In gently undulating pasture on level ground. A roughly circular area (diam. 2.8m) defined by a fosse and an outer earthen bank. The interior consists of firm undisturbed ground while the fosse is clearly evident as a band of soft ground (Wth 1.7m) N-SW but less distinct SW-N. The bank (Wth 2.9m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.4m) is evident all round with a break at W (Wth 2.4m). Another ring-barrow (SL033-199----) lies c. 100m to WSW and a bowl-barrow (SL033-049----) c. 50m to NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In gently undulating pasture, on the E side of the summit of a low broad ridge. A circular flat-topped mound (diam. 12.6m at base, 8m at top) surrounded by a fosse (Wth 2.4m at base) and an external earth and stone bank (Wth 5.6m; int. H 1.05m; ext. H 0.3m). The mound rises 1.35m above the base of the fosse. Recorded in 1836 as 'Sídheán a'Gháire' (OSL, 423), a translation of which was given in Wood-Martin (1887-8, 269) as 'the Fairy Mount of Laughter'. A bowl-barrow (SL033-050----) lies c. 50m to WSW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   This ring-barrow was severely damaged by land reclamation work in April 2006: the enclosing bank was levelled, the fosse infilled and several pits dug through the central mound. A rescue excavation (06E0720) was undertaken over three weeks in August 2006 by Margaret Keane, National Monuments Service (Keane 2009, 469, no. 1770). The excavation concentrated on the western side of the crest of the mound, and in addition a single trench was excavated across the fosse and external bank. The excavation of the fosse revealed that it was originally c. 2.5m wide at the top and c. 0.9m deep, with a sharply cut external edge, a rounded base, and a shallower profile on the internal mound side. A single post-hole was recorded just inside the edge of the mound crest. On the crest of the mound, the upper deposits consisted of spreads of charcoal-rich soils, with burnt bone and occasional artefacts interleaving with a spread of compact white/grey silt. Burnt material spread across the site may represent rakings of funeral pyre material. Beneath these layers, were a cluster of eight pits (max. dims. 0.3-1.3m) filled with deposits of burnt bone, in a clayey matrix with occasional artefacts. The interior edges of some of the pits were significantly charred. The most impressive pit (D c. 0.5m) had a basal deposit of cremated bone, and upper fills rich in charcoal and burnt bone. Artefacts recovered include ten glass beads or bead fragments, two unperforated glass beads/toggles, a single copper alloy spiral ring, five copper alloy pins, a copper alloy rod, copper alloy fragments, iron fragments, pieces of slag, worked flint and chert. (Keane 2009, 469, no. 1770).   Date of revised upload: 10 March 2016

Timoney (1984, 323, no. 12) describes this as follows: ‘The total diameter of this ring-barrow, sited on low ground, is 16.30 m. It consists of a circular mound, 5.50m in diameter and 40cm high, surrounded by a "U"-bottomed fosse, 1.50m wide and 30cm deep, and by a bank, 2m wide and 60cm high. Petrie (1837; Stokes 1868, 245) in dealing with the megalithic remains at Carrowmore refers to this as follows: "This circle which is situated near the road, and eastnortheast of no. 9, is composed of small stones mixed with earth and is forty feet in diameter. There is a stone sepulchre in the center but no cromlcach". Since then it has consistently been classified as a megalithic tomb. Wood-Martin (1888, p. 15, fig. 1) marked this monument on his map as no. 12 and restated Petrie's description of it. Following them Borlase (1897, 151), who completely misinterprets Wood-Martin's plan of the monument, Herity (1974. 266) and Kitchen (1983, 161) all have sought to explain this monument as the remains of a megalithic tomb. If Pertie's no. 12 be equatable with the monument described above, and there seems to be no cartographic or literary reason to do otherwise, then the interpretation of this monument as being the remains of a megalithic tomb are unwarranted. Burenhult (1980:1, 93) lists this not as a megalith, but as Structure 3, Carrowmore.’ (Bergh 1995, 186, Carrowmore 12)  This is a National Monument in State care (No. 153).  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 12 February 2014

In level area of gently undulating pasture, at base of WNW-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 15m N-S; 16m E-W) defined by scarped edge (Wth 6m; H 0.5m) and external fosse (basal Wth 2.75m; overall Wth 11.75m; Dth 0.15m). Fosse truncated by field boundary WSW-NW. Traces of an outer bank (Wth 9.5m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.15m) N-NE. Interior generally level and monument largely levelled and incorporated into rest of field as pasture.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 31 October 2013

In level area of gently undulating pasture, at base of WNW-facing slope. Circular area (11m N-S; 9.5m E-W) defined by scarped edge (Wth 3m; H 0.3m) awith external fosse (basal Wth 2m; overall Wth 10.45m; Dth 0.55m). Fosse in-filled at SW and SSE where former field boundary (long-axis WNW-ESE) was located; boundary now replaced by electric fence. Interior generally level and is incorporated into rest of field.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 31 October 2013

In gently undulating pasture on a slight E-facing slope. A slightly raised, roughly semicircular area (6m N-S) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.4m; D 0.2m) NNE-S. A band of light-coloured grass (Wth 2m) outside the fosse may indicate a levelled external bank. There is a barrow (SL033-064001-) in the adjoining field to N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

(2008) The Ballyhoura Hills Project, Discovery Programme Monograph No 7, Wordwell, pp 65-100]. The reference for this monument is LI023: Bruff 17001: AP 4/3710.

This is the record for a monument identified by The Discovery Programme, from medium-altitude aerial photographs taken in 1986 [see Doody, M. In improved wet pasture, to the immediate N of a townland boundary with Caherelly West and 115m W of a watercourse. Enclosure (LI023-206----) 125m to NW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 141: AP 4/3658). Monument is not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-2013 or on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage 28/06/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 141.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 4 September

In improved pasture, on grounds of Kilballyowen House, 70m N of current access road which lies 700m W of a townland boundary with Knockainy. Ring-barrow (LI032-126002-) lies to the immediate E. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Grogan (1989, 234) as a circular-shaped cropmark labelled ‘Kilballyowen 1’. Monument is not visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.  The precise location of this monument cannot be confirmed without access to thesis which is not included in the paper file.See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 9 November 2020

In pasture, on ENE-facing slope. Caherelly Castle (LI023-083----) 60m to NW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Grogan (1989 Vol. 2, 221) as a ring-barrow (Caherelly West No. 1). Recorded by the ASI in 2007 and described as no surface remains visible. Levelled monument is not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage 28/06/2018.   Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 28 August 2020

In improved pasture, on the grounds of Kilballyowen House, 75m to N of current access road and which lies 690m W of a townland boundary with Knockainy. Ring-barrow (LI032-126001-) lies to the immediate W. Not depicted on OSi historic maps, although this location is shown to the immediately S of an earlier driveway leading to Kilballyowen House. Identified by Grogan (1989, 234) as a circular-shaped cropmark labelled ‘Kilballyowen 2’ . Area of monument is obscured by trees on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018. In pasture, on gentle N-facing slope. Subcircular area (11.4m E-W; 14m N-S) enclosed by shallow fosse with low external bank (int. H 0.18m; ext. H 0.5m); entire site (22.4m E-W; 26.4m N-S) raised slightly above field level (H 0.5m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

On the dry margin just above the edge of the floodplain of the Camoge River, located 200m to S. The site is 100m W of the townland boundary with Knockcorragh. Ringfort (LI023-086----) 55m to S. Not depicted on historic OSi maps but is visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 255; AP 4/3659) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 5m). The ring-barrow appears to have been partially truncated by a later E-W orientated field boundary that runs over its N side. The site is visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the ring-barrow labelled Bruff 255 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 4 September 2020

On poorly drained grassland. Enclosure (LI023-345----) 115m to NE. The mound is not depicted on historic OSi maps but is clearly visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 17301: AP 4/3710AP) as a mound which appears to be surrounded by a fosse (ext. diam. c. 8m). The mound is visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 05/04/2006 and 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the enclosure labelled Bruff 17301 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload:  1 September 2020

In wet pasture, in NE corner of field immediately W of a local road.  This is the most S of 13 barrows (LI040-070001/013-) recorded within an area measuring 200m N-S x 250m E-W. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by the Discovery Programme as a ring-barrow on examination of Bord Gáis Éireann aerial photograph (BGE 2557) taken 03/11/1984. Outline of monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. c. 10m) intersected at N and E by post-1700 field boundaries on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12. No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached Bord Gáis Éireann aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  26 May 2021

On flat pasture 1km NE of the Camoge River. The townland boundary with Knockcorragh is 45m to S. The church and graveyard at Caherelly (LI023-085001/2-) is 320m to WSW. A mound (LI023-208----) lies 200m to NE, ring-barrows (LI023-216001/3-) 150m to E and an enclosure (LI023-217----) 150m to S. The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps or visible on the OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 271; AP 4/3658) as a ring-barrow. The site of the monument is visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 271 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 1 September 2020

On low-lying, improved wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses. A watercourse lies 95m to S which also marks a townland boundary with Knockcorragh. Enclosure (LI023-216001-) and ring-barrow (LI023-216003-) lie 15m to NW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a small oval-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 13803: AP 4/3658). Monument is not visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 or on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage 28/06/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 13803.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 6 September 2020

One of a complex of 12 monuments (LI032-073001-/013-).   Listed by O'Kelly as monuments No. 4 & 5 and described in 1943 as following; 'These are the second pair of small forts. They are much better preserved than Nos. I and 2, and consist of continuous banks surrounded by well denned fosses. The banks are 2' [0.6m] to 3' [0.9m] high, and the overall diameters of both are 60' [18m]. A trench runs as described from the corner of rectangle No. 3 and joins into the fosse of No. 4 on the south-west side. From the fosse of No. 4 on the north-east side, a similar trench runs out and joins the fosse of No. 5 on the north-west side. The rectangle is 141' [43m] from No. 4 and No. 4 is 84' [26m] from No. 5 and all three are in a straight line running north and south. As the banks of Nos. 4 and 5 are continuous, these might be looked upon as ring-barrows. Their centres are level with the field outside.  All these monuments, except Nos. 1 to 5 inclusive, are situated in a low-land marsh. Nos.  1, 2, 3, 10, 11 and 12 are not marked on the OS Maps' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 181-2).   The outline of the monument is not visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 27 February 2020  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP – 351/20 taken 05/01/2003.

One of a complex of 12 monuments (LI032-073001-/013-).   Listed by O'Kelly as monument No. 3 and described in 1943 as following; 'This is a very slightly elevated rectangular platform surrounded by a continuous fosse, and is one of the Type A structures. It measures 70' [21m] north-south by 40' [12m], and the platform is barely 1' [0.3m] high. From the south-west corner of the fosse a straight shallow trench runs in a southerly direction and connects into the fosse of monument No. 4.  All these monuments, except Nos. 1 to 5 inclusive, are situated in a low-land marsh. Nos.  1, 2, 3, 10, 11 and 12 are not marked on the OS Maps' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 181-2).   The outline of the monument is not visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 27 February 2020  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP – 351/20 taken 05/01/2003.

One of a complex of 12 monuments (LI032-073001-/013-).   Listed by O'Kelly as monument No. 8 and described in 1943 as following; 'This is a circular earthen platform of Type A. There is no bank either on the platform or around it. The fosse is continuous. The height of the platform is 3' [0.9m] and its overall diameter is 120' [36m].  All these monuments, except Nos. 1 to 5 inclusive, are situated in a low-land marsh. Nos.  1, 2, 3, 10, 11 and 12 are not marked on the OS Maps (O'Kelly 1942-3, 181-2).   The outline of the monument is not visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 27 February 2020  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP – 351/20 taken 05/01/2003.

In pasture sloping gently to NE, a possible barrow (LI040-015----) lies 140m to the SW. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified by Tarbett (1989, 7) as one of two ring-barrows, ‘Ringbarrow B’ and described as follows; ‘This poorly surviving barrow is located in the lower NE quadrant of the same field next to the roadway. The interior platform of the barrow is circular and slightly raised above the surrounding ground level. It is outlined by a shallow fosse, 10cm deep, which can only be traced at the N, SE and SW. An enclosing low sized bank is visible at the N and SW measuring no more than 20cm in height. No bank or ditch can be traced at the NE. This barrow, larger than the former (LI040-015----) measures 12m in diameter. A later bank orientated from E-W partially cuts through the enclosing bank of the monument at the South.’  Possible faint trace of monument visible as circular cropmark on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12.  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  Uncertain about location of monument on the Historic Environment Viewer.  See attached location map and drawing from C. Tarbett and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 19 May 2021

In pasture sloping gently NE, a possible ring-barrow (LI040-014----) lies 140m to the NE. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified by Tarbett (1989, 7) as one of two ring-barrows, ‘Ringbarrow A’ and described as follows; ‘This barrow, located in the NE quadrant of the field is the better surviving of the two monuments. It is relatively small measuring only 10m in diameter from mid bank to mid bank. It is outlined mostly by a shallow fosse with a maximum depth of 20cm. The fosse encircles a slightly raised interior platform which is ovoid in shape and which slopes to the NE. A low sized enclosing bank is only noticeable at the SE where it measures no more than 20cm in height.’  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages.   Uncertain about location of monument on the Historic Environment Viewer.  See attached location map and drawing from C. Tarbett and Google Earth orthoimage.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 12 May 2021

One of a complex of 12 monuments (LI032-073001-/013-).  Listed by O'Kelly two ring-barrows (LI032-073005-) and described in 1943 as following; 'Two Ring Barrows are situated on its top both on the eastern side of the centre line. One is entirely in the N.E. quadrant and the second is partly in the N.E. and partly in the S.E. These consist of very low mounds surrounded by continuous fosses. Their overall diameters are 18' [5.5m] and 24' [7.3m]'.  All these monuments, except Nos. 1 to 5 inclusive, are situated in a low-land marsh. Nos.  1, 2, 3, 10, 11 and 12 are not marked on the OS Maps (O'Kelly 1942-3, 181-2).   The outline of the monument is visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 27 February 2020See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP – 349/11and 351/20 taken 05/01/2003.

In wet, low-lying pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, on the floodplain of the Camoge River, which lies 330m to E. A mound (LI023-073009-) and a ring-barrow (LI023-073011-) lie 180m to SW and SSW, respectively and an enclosure (LI023-073016-) lies  190m to S. Not depicted on OSi historic maps.Excavated by Máire MacDermott in 1949 and described as a low circular-shaped mound (diam. 4m) defined by a well-preserved fosse with the remains of a slight outer bank (overall diam. 12m) (MacDermott 1949, 101). Prior to investigation, a depression in the bank at N was thought to indicate an entrance, however on excavation, there was no evidence to support this (ibid). Excavation did prove that the fosse had been excavated to a depth of 0.5m.  There was no trace of any burials, pits, post-holes or other signs of activity. Toward the centre of the mound, there was a slight flecking of charcoal containing some charred seeds (ibid). Excavation has dated the mound to the Neolithic period based on a piece of pottery of Windmill Hill type. Other finds include an unfinished chert arrowhead, a flake of greenstone axe and a few pieces of chert and flint debitage (ibid). Remains of monument is visible as a very faint, roughly oval-shaped cropmark on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 25/05/2017. See attached Google Earth orthoimage 25/05/2017 and pre-excavation image of monument by Marie MacDermott (1949). Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 30 August 2020

Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 14 September 2020

Four trackways cut across the interior.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

This is the record for a monument identified by The Discovery Programme, from medium-altitude aerial photographs taken in 1986 [see Doody, M. (2008) The Ballyhoura Hills Project, Discovery Programme Monograph No 7, Wordwell, pp 65-100]. The reference for this monument is LI023: Bruff 20402: AP 4/3711.

Situated on a slight E-facing slope in gently undulating pasture. Circular area (diam. 2.6m) defined by a bank of earth (Wth 0.9m; int. H 0.2m). There is no fosse visible at ground level. The interior of the site is slopes slightly from W-E.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

A group of five contiguous barrows (LI032-139001-/008-) on Knockainy Hill described in 2004 as following; 'A linear group of barrows is located to the west of Doonainy cairn [LI032-139005-] and towards the south-west end of the cursus monument [LI032-139007-]. It consists of five contiguous barrows, four of which are marked on the OS maps and arranged in a line in a north-south direction. All of the barrows are contained within the banks of the cursus, but it is difficult to determine whether portions of the banks of the barrows are built on top of or against the cursus banks. The first [LI032-139001-], most southerly example, 28m in diameter, consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing a 15m-wide inner mound. The second barrow [LI032-139002-] is partially obscured by a field fence. It measures 25m in diameter and consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing an 11.5m-wide inner mound. The third barrow [LI032-139003-] is partially obscured by the same field fence. It shares its bank with the fourth and northernmost barrow [LI032-139004-]. The bank and internal ditch enclose an 11m-wide inner mound. The fourth barrow is named 'Carn of Uainide' on the OS map. Its eastern perimeter is obscured by a field fence. The monument is 20m in diameter and consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing an 11m-wide inner mound. Barrow 5 [LI032-139008-], a previously unrecorded barrow, lies directly to the east of 'Carn of Uainide'. It consists of a central domed circular mound, 11 m in diameter, enclosed by a ditch, best preserved on its southern side. The outer bank appears to have been completely levelled, but on its western side it would have been contiguous with 'Carn of Uainide', from which it is now separated by a field fence' (Condit and Coyne 2004). These barrows were described by O'Kelly (1944, 21) as following; 'A short distance to the W. of the tumulus [LI032-139005-] there are four ring-barrows. They lie close together in a line running N.S. The three southern barrows are low mounds surrounded by fosses, while the northern monument had a higher mound and seems to have had an outer bank between which and the mound there was a fosse. A large portion of it has been dug away—much of the mound and almost all of the bank. The overall diameter is 60' [18.3m], the mound itself being 18' [5.5m] approx., and 4' [1.2m] high. The overall diameters of the other monuments vary between 66' [20m] and 75' [23m] and the heights are from 3' [0.9m] to 4' 6" [1.4m]. Westropp without much evidence to support his claim, identifies these sites as the habitations of Uainide, Eoghabal, Áine, and Fer Fi, legendary figures connected with the hill of Knockainy'.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 06 August 2019  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 304/26 taken on 13/09/2002; 348/2 and 348/13 taken on 05/01/2003.

A group of five contiguous barrows (LI032-139001-/008-) on Knockainy Hill described in 2004 as following; 'A linear group of barrows is located to the west of Doonainy cairn [LI032-139005-] and towards the south-west end of the cursus monument [LI032-139007-]. It consists of five contiguous barrows, four of which are marked on the OS maps and arranged in a line in a north-south direction. All of the barrows are contained within the banks of the cursus, but it is difficult to determine whether portions of the banks of the barrows are built on top of or against the cursus banks. The first [LI032-139001-], most southerly example, 28m in diameter, consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing a 15m-wide inner mound. The second barrow [LI032-139002-] is partially obscured by a field fence. It measures 25m in diameter and consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing an 11.5m-wide inner mound. The third barrow [LI032-139003-] is partially obscured by the same field fence. It shares its bank with the fourth and northernmost barrow [LI032-139004-]. The bank and internal ditch enclose an 11m-wide inner mound. The fourth barrow is named 'Carn of Uainide' on the OS map. Its eastern perimeter is obscured by a field fence. The monument is 20m in diameter and consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing an 11m-wide inner mound. Barrow 5 [LI032-139008-], a previously unrecorded barrow, lies directly to the east of 'Carn of Uainide'. It consists of a central domed circular mound, 11 m in diameter, enclosed by a ditch, best preserved on its southern side. The outer bank appears to have been completely levelled, but on its western side it would have been contiguous with 'Carn of Uainide', from which it is now separated by a field fence' (Condit and Coyne 2004). These barrows were described by O'Kelly (1944, 21) as following; 'A short distance to the W. of the tumulus [LI032-139005-] there are four ring-barrows. They lie close together in a line running N.S. The three southern barrows are low mounds surrounded by fosses, while the northern monument had a higher mound and seems to have had an outer bank between which and the mound there was a fosse. A large portion of it has been dug away—much of the mound and almost all of the bank. The overall diameter is 60' [18.3m], the mound itself being 18' [5.5m] approx., and 4' [1.2m] high. The overall diameters of the other monuments vary between 66' [20m] and 75' [23m] and the heights are from 3' [0.9m] to 4' 6" [1.4m]. Westropp without much evidence to support his claim, identifies these sites as the habitations of Uainide, Eoghabal, Áine, and Fer Fi, legendary figures connected with the hill of Knockainy'.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 06 August 2019  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 304/26 taken on 13/09/2002; 348/2 and 348/13 taken on 05/01/2003.

In pasture, on a gentle WSW-facing slope of a low rise. Circular area (5.65m N-S; 5.5m E-W) defined by fosse (max. basal Wth 1m; max. overall Wth 2.5m; D 0.15m) with an external bank (max. Wth 4.2m; max. int. H 0.2m; max. ext. H 0.3m) WNW-WSW. Dished interior may indicate excavation in antiquity. Barrow (LI023-092002-) is c. 45m to NE and barrows (LI023-092003- and LI023-092004-) c. 55m and c. 90m to SE respectively.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 19 November 2013
