In level pasture, on top of low lying natural rise. Circular area (8.9m N-S; 7.4m E-W; D 0.15m) enclosed by earthen bank (Wth 4.85m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.2m), with external fosse (basal Wth 0.9m; overall Wth 3.75m; D 0.05m) and counter-scarp bank (Wth 4m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.1m) WSW-WNW. Lazy beds (long-axis NNE-SSW) cut across the field, but respect monument. Dished interior may indicate excavation in antiquity. According to local information, an 'earthen cup' was found in one of the four barrows in this field. Ring-barrow (LI023-092001-) is c. 45m to SW and barrows (LI023-092003- and LI023-092004-) c. 50m and c. 150m to S respectively.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 19 November 2013

In level pasture, on top of low lying natural rise. Circular area (6.1m N-S; 6.2m E-W) defined by fosse (basal Wth 0.5m; overall Wth 3.2m; D 0.15m) and external bank (max. Wth 3.25m; max. int. H 0.3m; max. ext. H 0.15m). Gap (Wth 0.8m) at NNE may be entrance. Interior is slightly higher to E, possibly due cattle poaching. Lazy beds (long-axis NNE-SSW) cut across field, but respect monument. Ring-barrow (LI023-092001-) is c. 55m to NW, ring-barrow (LI023-092002-) is c. 50m to N and ring-barrow (LI023-092004-) is c. 100m to S.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 19 November 2013

In level pasture, on top of low lying natural rise. Circular area (7.8m NE-SW; c. 6.5m NW-SE) defined by shallow fosse (max. total Wth 2.7m; max. basal Wth 0.5m; D 0.1m), with traces of an external bank (basal Wth 2.25; overall Wth 4.9m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.2m) NW-SW. Monument truncated by lazy beds (long-axis c. N-S) and is levelled in W-sector. Ring-barrow (LI023-092001-) is c. 90m to NW, ring-barrow (LI023-092002-) is c. 150m to N and ring-barrow (LI023-092003-) is c. 100m to N.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 19 November 2013

In upland pasture, on a spot height (524ft/160m) which is located 60m ENE of a mound ‘Doonainy’ (LI032-139005-) which crowns the summit (537ft/164m) of Knockainy and the archaeological complex which consists of five contiguous ring-barrows (LI032-139001-/02-/03-/04/08-). A cursus leading to the group of ring-barrows lies 115m to N. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Grogan (1989, 234) as a ring-barrow which he labelled as 'Knockainy West 7’. Monument is visible as a subcircular-shaped earthwork on oblique aerial photograph (ASIAP 348, 2).  Not visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-2012, or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013 or on Google Earth orthoimages taken 25/03/2017 or 20/09/2020.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and ASIAP (348, 2).  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 9 November 2020  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 304/26 taken on 13/09/2002; 348/2 and 348/13 taken on 05/01/2003.

Conjoined barrows described in 2004 as following; 'This pair of contiguous barrows lies c. 200m to the south-east of Doonainy cairn [LI032-139005-].  The northernmost barrow (barrow 6), 46m in overall diameter, consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing a 19m-wide inner mound. A 9m-wide circular mound is located in the north-western quadrant of the central platform. This is the largest barrow on Knockainy Hill.  The southern barrow (barrow 7) is bisected by a field fence. It measures 39m in diameter and consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing a 21m-wide circular inner mound' (Condit and Coyne 2004). This barrow was described in 1944 as following; 'On the S.E. slope of the E. shoulder of Knockainy the O.S. map shows what seems to be a large barrow. On the ground practically no trace remains, as the monument has been almost obliterated. Its overall diameter seems to have been about 100' [30m]' (O'Kelly 1944, 21).  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 07 August 2019

Conjoined barrows described in 2004 as following; 'This pair of contiguous barrows lies c. 200m to the south-east of Doonainy cairn [LI032-139005-].  The northernmost barrow (barrow 6), 46m in overall diameter, consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing a 19m-wide inner mound. A 9m-wide circular mound is located in the north-western quadrant of the central platform. This is the largest barrow on Knockainy Hill.  The southern barrow (barrow 7) is bisected by a field fence. It measures 39m in diameter and consists of a bank and internal ditch enclosing a 21 m-wide circular inner mound' (Condit and Coyne 2004). This barrow was described in 1944 as following; 'is now nearly obliterated. The overall diameter seems to have been about 100' [30m]' (O'Kelly 1944, 22).   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 07 August 2019

Situated on a low knoll on a gentle S-facing slope. This is a circular grass and rush-covered area (diam. c. 60m E-W; 56.5m N-S) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 5.3-7.8m; Wth of base 2.9-4m; int. D 0.4-0.6m; ext. D 0.3-0.8m), and an outer earthen bank  with some bushes NE-E (Wth of base 6.3m; Wth of top 2.3m; int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.9m) and SE-WNW (Wth of base 2.8-4.5m; int. H 0.3-08m; ext. H 0.2-0.3m) that is incorporated into a field bank WNW-NE. The fosse is missing NE-SE. The interior is overlain by a N-S field wall towards the perimeter at E, and it is more overgrown E of this feature.   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 5 February 2018

In improved pasture, on the edge of Herbertstown village, 675m E of the Camoge River, which also marks a townland boundary with Kilcullane. Barrow (LI032-209----) lies 415m to WSW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 182: AP 4/3607), as a circular-shaped cropmark.  Monument is visible as an arc of a fosse (C 27m) on Google Earth orthoimage taken 05/04/2006 and as a circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 34m) defined by an internal fosse and an outer bank, on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 182  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 16 November 2020  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP – 351/15 taken on 05/01/2003.
Identified from aerial photographs on Bing Maps (www.bing.com/maps/) and Google Earth as a possible ringbarrow.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 20 June 2013

Identified from aerial photographs on Bing Maps (www.bing.com/maps/) and Google Earth as a possible ringbarrow in the SW corner of a larger enclosure (LI014-155001-).  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 20 June 2013

This is the record for a monument identified by The Discovery Programme, from medium-altitude aerial photographs taken in 1986 [see Doody, M. (2008) The Ballyhoura Hills Project, Discovery Programme Monograph No 7, Wordwell, pp 65-100]. The reference for this monument is LI023: Bruff 242: AP 4/3689.

In undulating pasture, in a slight natural depression on the top of a hill. There are excellent views in all directions except towards a hill at WNW. A circular raised area (15m N-S; 15m E-W) defined by an earth and stone bank (int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.9m) NNE-W and by a scarp elsewhere. The interior is clear of overgrowth and is undulating, possibly due to quarrying; a quarry hole (4m N-S; 2m E-W; D 0.4m) is evident to N of centre. A dump of earth and stone (2m x 2m; H 0.3m) was noted against the internal face of the bank at S. A now disused field drain has been cut against the external face of the bank E-S and sections of a disused field boundary abut the external face of the bank at S and E. While there is no evidence of an internal fosse, the diameter and the location of this site suggest it is a ring-barrow.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On low-lying wet pasture, shaped by flood waters and cut by land drains and watercourses. Ring-barrow (LI023-180001-) lies 45m to N. Not depicted on OSI historic maps. On low-lying ready wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses. Ring-barrow (LI023-181----) lies 10m to NW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Described by O'Kelly (1944, 22) as following; 'A circular platform [LI032-142001-] surrounded by a fosse. Overall diameter 152' [46.3m], height 4' [1.2m]. The entrance is not recognisable. Centred on the E-W diameter and just inside the E. edge of the platform there is a ring-barrow [LI032-142003-]. This is a low mound surrounded by a fosse and has an overall diameter of 30' [9.1m]. Immediately to the S.E. of the platform is another barrow [LI032-142002-], similar in appearance, but having a diameter of 21' [6.4m]'. On flat pasture partially bisected by the townland boundary with Rathjordan, 50m E of the townland boundary with Doonvullen Upper. Ring-barrow (LI023-211----) 250m to N. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 282 AP 4/3658) as a ring-barrow comprised of a circular area defined by a fosse with an external bank (ext. diam. 38m E-W). In rough, wet pasture, 15m E of a townland boundary with Doonvullen Upper and 50m SE of a watercourse. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 149: AP 4/3661). Monument is visible as an irregular suboval-shaped cropmark on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage 28/06/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 149.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 6 September 2020

On low-lying, improved wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses. A roadway lies 10m to W and a watercourse lies 25m to NE. A cluster of three ring-barrows (LI023-222001-/002-/003-) lie 300m to NW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a circular-shaped earthwork by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 151: AP 4/3662). Monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 35m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage 28/06/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 151.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 8 September 2020

In improved, rough, wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 65m SW of a townland boundary with Knockainy East.  Ring-barrow (LI032-310----) lies 2m to SE.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  Monument identified on an aerial photograph (ASIAP 348, 7) taken 05/01/2003 where it is visible as a small circular-shaped earthwork.   Upstanding monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 11m) on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage 05/04/2006.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and ASIAP (348, 7)  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 29 November 2020

In improved, rough, wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 6m SW of a townland boundary with Knockainy East.  Ring-barrow (LI032-311----) lies 2m to NW.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  Monument identified on aerial photograph (ASIAP 348, 7) taken 05/01/2003 where it is visible as a small circular-shaped earthwork. Upstanding monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 13m) on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage 05/04/2006.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and ASIAP (348, 7)  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 29 November 2020

In improved pasture, 195m SSE of a townland boundary with Ballinscoola (Cahercorney) and an area of boggy heath. A possible enclosure (LI032-257----) lies 95m TO NNW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 185: AP 4/3608) as a circular-shaped mound enclosed by a fosse. Upstanding monument visible as an oval-shaped earthwork (82m E-W; 79m N-S) with a  roughly circular-shaped central mound (32m E-W; 30m N-S) enclosed by three fosses with two intervening banks, as seen on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 20/09/20. Monument is also visible as same on oblique aerial images (ASIAP 351, 8 & 9) taken 05/01/2003.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 185  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 21 November 2020

This is the record for a monument identified by The Discovery Programme, from medium-altitude aerial photographs taken in 1986 [see Doody, M. (2008) The Ballyhoura Hills Project, Discovery Programme Monograph No 7, Wordwell, pp 65-100]. The reference for this monument is LI023: Bruff 228: AP 4/3713.

On flat pasture 40m S of the crest of a ridge above a shallow valley with good views in all directions. The site is located 315m W of the townland boundary with Galgoola and 480m SE of a ring-barrow (LI023-223----). The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 153; AP 4/3662) as an embanked enclosure (ext. diam. c. 20m). It appears to have been levelled as there are no surface remains visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing ring-barrow labelled Bruff 153 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 31 August 2020

Earthwork complex described in 1943 as following; 'Complex of 2 Earthworks of Type A and 3 Ring-barrows.   The third barrow is in the northern part of the same field. This is a very low mound surrounded by a fosse and outer bank. Both bank and fosse were originally continuous, but the bank is now broken on the north side where a modern fence has been built. Its overall diameter is 36' [11m]. All five monuments are in a lowland marshy meadow' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 172).   Outline of monument barely visible today on Digital Globe aerial photograph.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 24 February 2020

In wet pasture on the floodplains of the Camoge River that forms townland boundary with Ballycahill.  A group of eleven barrows (LI040-026002-; 026004-/026013-) and an enclosure (LI040-026003-) lie to the W. Large impressive and well preserved bivallate barrow (overall diam. 107m) depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a circular-shaped platform (diam. c. 26m) defined by a scarp and wide waterlogged fosse, and wide bank with berm and gap at E, with fosse both of which are transected at E by a post-1700 field boundary running roughly N-S.  Remains of a second outer bank are visible from S-W only.  The impressive monument is visible on oblique aerial photographs (CUCAP AVT026; AYO038) taken 20/07/1968 and 10/07/1969 and on Archaeological Survey of Ireland aerial images (ASIAP (347) 21) taken 05/01/2003.   Well preserved barrow visible on Digital Globe orthophotograph taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached CUCAP, ASIAP aerial photographs and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 14 May 2021

Earthwork complex described in 1943 as following; 'Complex of 2 Earthworks of Type A and 3 Ring-barrows.   The second barrow lies to the south east of the last monument [LI032-099001-] described, and is separated from it by a distance of 60' [18m]. This consists of a very slight mound surrounded by a fosse. It is not quite circular, but its average overall diameter is 36' [11m].  All five monuments are in a lowland marshy meadow' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 172).   Outline of monument visible today on Digital Globe aerial photograph.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 24 February 2020

In wet, low-lying pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses. Enclosure (LI023-099001/005-) lie 80m to SW and 110m to WNW, respectively and ring-barrows (LI023-099002/--4-) lie 100m to SW and 200m to NW, respectively. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. This monument is an additional part of an earthwork complex described by O’Kelly as following: 'A Complex of 2 earthworks of Type A and 3 ring-barrows (O’Kelly 1943, 172). Monument is not visible on the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff AP 130.1). Monument is visible as a faint, roughly oval-shaped cropmark (30m E-W; 23m N-S) on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 25/05/2017.   See attached Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 130.1 and Google Earth orthoimage 25/05/2017.   Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 31August 2020

In flat pasture 1.5km W of the Killeenagarriff River. Possible ringfort (LI006-029----) located 350m to the SE. The description is based upon its depiction on the 1897 OS 25-inch map and on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018. A raised circular-shaped area (internal dims. c. 26m W) surrounded by an external fosse (c. 5m W). The enclosure appears to have further concentric outer ditches suggesting that it may have been a bivallate or even a trivallate enclosure that could have been up to 60m in diameter. Similar multivallate enclosures, such as Rathanny (LI040-026001-) in Co. Limerick has been attributed to the Bronze Age and is considered as a barrow or burial mound.  This monument may be similar to a triple-ditched barrow (LI048-092----) in the townland of Ballyroe Lower.See attached Google Earth orthophotosCompiled by: Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 22 July 2020

In reclaimed pasture, abutting a townland boundary with Castlefarm to S. Depicted on 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a suboval-shaped platform (52m E-W; 47m N-S) with fosse to W and curvilinear drainage ditch from N-E-SE, intersected by road at S. Described by Westropp (1922, 71) as: ‘There is a large, conspicuous hill, north-east from Knockainey, and about four miles from it, called Cromwell Hill. The only antiquities known to me between the two ridges are a stone circle [LI032-099----] and earth-ring [LI032-101----], cut by a laneway, in Ballinamona, an outlier of the Loch Gur group’.  Upstanding monument is visible a roughly circular-shaped ring-barrow on Archaeological Survey of Ireland aerial photographs (ASIAP 351, 1 & 352, 0), on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-2012.  Well preserved monument (overall diam. c. 54m) visible on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013 as a circular-shaped area (diam. c. 28m) defined by a scarp with fosse and outer bank with external fosse which have been intersected at SSE by public road.  Monument visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 20/03/2018, where it is truncated by a road running NE-SW across the SE edge and is flanked by a curvilinear land drain from NW-N-NE-E.See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 8 November 2020

On low-lying, improved pasture. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a roughly oval-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 154: AP 4/3662). Monument is visible as an oval-shaped earthwork (22m NNW-SSE; 17m ENE-WSW) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013, however is not visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage 28/06/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 154.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 8 September 2020

On undulating pasture facing SW 15m NE of the townland boundary with Rootiagh. The ring-barrow (LI023-236001-) is one of five ring-barrows (LI023-236001/005-). The ring-barrows (LI023-236001/5-) form a linear cluster of sites c. 6m apart, roughly orientated in a NW-SE alignment.  The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps but is faintly visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 23701; AP 4/3634) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 7.5m). Visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017, the vegetation cover was more dense on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 23701 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 3 September 2020

Ring-barrow described in 1943 as following; 'In the north-east corner of the same field as the above monument [LI032-103----] is a small barrow. It consists of a very low outer bank inside which there is a fosse. Both are continuous. In the centre is a very low mound, The overall diameter is 24' [7.3m]' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 171).  No surface remains visible today on Digital Globe aerial photograph.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 24 February 2020

In rough, wet, water-shaped pasture, 55m E of a townland boundary with Tonteere and 90m S of a watercourse. Ring-barrows (LI023-325/326----) lie 10m to NE and 25m to ENE, respectively. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 23401: AP 4/3664). Monument is visible as a circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 12m) on OSi aerial orthoimage taken 2005-2012, although is not visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage 28/06/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 23401.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 6 September 2020

Situated on a slight NW-facing slope near summit of hillock, in gently undulating pasture. Circular slightly raised area (diam. 11m) defined by a low bank of earth (Wth 2.65m; int. H 0.3m). At the external foot of the bank is a fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.35m). A break in the bank (Wth 1.15m) with an irregular causeway across the fosse appears to be modern. At the centre of the interior is a slightly raised area (diam. 4m), defined by a faint scarped edge, which may mark the remains of a central mound.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

On a flat marshy floodplain, on the N bank of the Arrow or Unshin River. A low subcircular mound abutting the riverbank at S and enclosed SW-SE by two fosses with intervening and external banks, all of which peter out at SW and SE before reaching the riverbank. The broadly slumped mound (14m N-S; c. 12m E-W; H 0.5m at S, 0.8m at N) is poorly preserved with a rather flattened top. Its E edge is damaged or partially levelled. Around the base of the mound is the innermost fosse (Wth 4.5m) which is silted up and marked by a dense growth of rushes. Outside this fosse is the intervening bank (Wth c. 3m; int. H 0.25m; ext. H 0.5m) which is in turn surrounded by another fosse (Wth 4.8m) evident as a broad wet depression marked by rushes. The external bank (Wth 5m; int. H 0.35m; ext. H 0.5m) is evident as a broad low flattened grass-covered rise, except SW-W where it has been removed.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on an E-facing slope in undulating pasture with good views to S and W. The monument consists of a roughly circular area (6.4m E-W; 5.7m N-S) defined by a scarped edge (Wth 1m; H 0.25m) with an external fosse (Wth 1m; D 0.25m), and remains of a counter-scarp bank (int. h 0.1m; Wth 1.3m; ext. H 0.3m) from NE to SE.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 25 June 2013

In tillage, on gentle SE-facing slope. Circular area (16m E-W) enclosed by wide, shallow fosse (Wth 15m; D 0.5m) with external bank (H 0.3m). Gap to S and WSW, latter possibly ancient. Regularly ploughed.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In improved wet pasture, liable to floods and 20m NW of the Ballynamona River which also marks a townland boundary with Ballinlough.  Enclosure (LI032-262----) lies 145m to SW. Monument is not depicted on OSi historic maps.  Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 297: AP4/3611) as a circular-shaped earthwork defined by a fosse. Upstanding monument is visible as a well preserved circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 27m) defined by a fosse and an outer bank, as seen on aerial photograph (ASIAP 352, 12) taken 05/01/2003, on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage 20/09/2020.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 297.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 289November 2020

Enclosure (LI032-049001-) and ring-barrows described in 1942-3 as following; 'This is a circular earthen platform surrounded by two banks and two fosses. The entrance is not recognisable. The maximum height of the platform over the fosse-bottom is 5' [1.5m] and the overall diameter is 306' [93m]. A fence and drainage trench have cut through the west side of the defences and another trench has cut through them on the south. Situated in wet low-land.  In the field immediately to the N.E. of this there were at least three ring-barrows [LI032-149002-/003-004-], one of which now remains. This consists of a very slight mound surrounded by a fosse. The overall diameter is 18' [6m]. The field is a meadow and the other barrows were levelled to facilitate the operation of machinery therein. Nothing was found when they were cleared away' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 237).  Cropmark of enclosure (LI032-149001-) visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.  No cropmark visible today of levelled barrows in field to NE of enclosure.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 4 March 2020

In rough pasture, on a level terrace at the break of slope at the NW end of a ridge. There are excellent views though overlooked to NW by Kesh Corann Hill. One of a linear cluster of barrows (SL040-130002-; SL040-131----, SL040-132----). A circular area (3m NE-SW; 3.4m NW-SE; H 0.25m) defined by a fosse (Wth 1m) with an external bank (Wth 1.8m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.4m). Although low and degraded the defining features are distinct with the central platform and the bank marked by a rich growth of grass. An embanked barrow (SL040-130002-) is immediately to NE with a possible causeway linking both barrows. A ring-barrow (SL040-131----) lies c. 50m upslope to SE and an embanked barrow (SL040-132----) c. 100m to SE on the level summit of the ridge.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on the NW-facing slope of a drumlin. A raised circular area (diam. 11m; H 0.7m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2m) and an external bank (Wth 3.55m; int. H 1m; ext. H 0.65m). There is a causeway across the fosse at E. Earth and stones have recently been dumped into the fosse at S. A field boundary skirts the barrow N-ESE. This is one of a group of four barrows (SL040-130001-, SL040-130002-, SL040-132----).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In undulating pasture within a large rectangular field 125m N of the townland boundary with Ballyphilip. One of 12 ring-barrows (LI023-275/79---- and LI023-280/866----) in three adjacent fields in a cluster / cemetery (ext. diam. c. 200m). Ring-barrow (LI023-276---) lies 15m to ESE. A separate ring-barrow cemetery also comprising of twelve sites (LI023-22501/12-) is located 300m to SE in Ballyphilip (Clanwilliam By.) townland.  The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Not visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 26101; AP 4/3665) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 10 N-S; 8m E-W). The ring-barrow is not visible on Google Earth orthoimages. The cultivated grass cover suggests the field has been reclaimed in the late 20th or early 21st century as is visible from the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.   See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 26101 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 7 September 2020

In low-lying pastureland immediately to the SSW of a rath (GA098-078001-). This circular ring-barrow (diam. 24m), in fair condition, comprises a low central mound (diam. 5.3m; max. H 0.47m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. A trackway abuts the bank at N.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

In undulating pasture within a large rectangular field 160m N of the townland boundary with Ballyphilip. One of 12 ring-barrows (LI023-275/79---- and LI023-280/86----) in three adjacent fields in a cluster / cemetery (ext. diam. c. 200m). A ring-barrow (LI023-281---) lies 26m to SE. A separate ring-barrow cemetery comprising of twelve sites (LI023-22501/12-) is located 300m to SE in Ballyphilip (Clanwilliam By.) townland.  The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Not visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 26103; AP 4/3665) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 7m N-S; 8m E-W). The ring-barrow is not visible on Google Earth orthoimages. The cultivated grass cover suggests the field has been reclaimed in the late 20th or early 21st century as is visible from the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 26103 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 7 September 2020

In rough pasture on low hill overlooking a tributary of the Mulkear River, 60m W of the townland boundary with Curraghaveara. Enclosure (LI023-163----) located 170m to SSE. On the 1840 ed. OS 6-inch map the monument is shown standing in the townland of Baskethill.  However on the revised 1897 ed. OS map the ring-barrow is now shown standing in the townland of Clashbane as the townland boundary has been moved S between the two editions of the OSi maps.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps or visible on the OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 252; AP 4/3715) as a ring-barrow. The site of the monument is visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 252 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 3 September 2020

In low-lying, wet pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses and which is adjacent to W of a linear land drain running N-S. In improved pasture which is liable to floods, 40m S of a farm trackway and 65m SW of the River Mahore which also marks a townland boundary with Oldtown (Bennett). Ring-barrow (LI032-153002-) lies 30m to N. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a ring-barrow (Site 5) by Christine Tarbett and described as  ‘This barrow nearest to the farm buildings and due E from them sits slightly elevated in the field. It has an external diameter of 13m and is circular in outline. The interior platform measures 7m in diameter. The ring-ditch is well defined where it measures circa 15cm in depth 1.3m in width. An enclosing bank is mostly continuous all around but low sited in the NE and E,’ (Tarbett 1987, 52).   Monument is not visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-2012 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013, although a small circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 7m) can be seen on Google Earth orthoimage taken 20/09/2020.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and a location map (Site 5) and sketch plan by Christine Tarbett (1987, 50 and 53).Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 9 November 2020

In improved and drained pasture which is liable to floods, 7m SW of a farm trackway and 45m SW of the River Mahore which also marks a townland boundary with Oldtown (Bennett). Ring-barrow (LI032-153001-) lies 30m to S. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a barrow (Site 7) by Christine Tarbett and described as: ‘This barrow no longer survives as being visible on the surface. It was rotavated prior to knowledge of its purpose in the early 1970s,’ (Tarbett 1987, 52).   Monument is not visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-2012 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013, although a small circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 5m) can be seen on Google Earth orthoimage taken 20/09/2020.See attached Google Earth orthoimage and a location map (Site 7) by Christine Tarbett (1987, 50).Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 9 November 2020

In wet pasture, 42m SW of the River Mahore that forms townland boundary with Oldtown. The most northerly of a group of four barrows (LI040-037002-/004-). Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified as Site I by Tarbett (1987, 53) and described as, ‘the best surviving of the ring barrows. It measures 14m in diameter and follows the line of the ground slope to the East. The interior platform is circular measuring 7m in diameter, it is well defined by the ring ditch which measures circa 20cms in depth 1m in width, the enclosing bank can visibly be traced all around where it measures not more than 50cms in height.'  Possible trace of monument visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-13.   Possible outline visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 25/05/2017.  See attached location map and drawing from C. Tarbett and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 12 May 2021

In wet pasture, 90m SW of the River Mahore that forms townland boundary with Oldtown. One of four barrows (LI040-037001/004-). Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified by Tarbett (1987, 51) as ‘Site 2’ and described as, 'larger in overall diameter than site one and more ovoid in shape. It has an external N-S diameter of 15.50m and 18m E-W. It cannot be easily traced in the field, the shallow ditch does not clearly define the interior platform at the North. The enclosing bank is low and is not seen to survive at the NW or at the East. The interior platform measures 8.50m in diameter N-S and 11m E-W. The ditch measures circa 1.50m in width and 20cms in depth, the bank measures 20cms in height. This barrow is located 150m due South from Site one’.  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached location map and drawing from C. Tarbett and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 12 May 2021

On low lying wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 500m SW of a townland boundary with Milltown.  Enclosure (LI033-064----) lies 115m to ENE and earthwork (LI032-284----) lies 175m to NW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 290: AP 4/3633) as a small circular-shaped cropmark. Upstanding monument is clearly visible as a well-preserved circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 11m) defined by an inner fosse and an external bank, as seen on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage 25/03/2017.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 290.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 25 November 2020

In rough wet pasture, 15m SW of the River Mahore that forms townland boundary with Oldtown. One of four barrows (LI040-037001/004-). Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified by Tarbett (1987, 53) as ‘Site 3' and described as; ‘This barrow is circular with an external diameter of 12m. The interior platform measures 5m in diameter and is relatively well defined by the shallow ring ditch which measures circa 1.50m in width and 15cms in depth. Only traces of the enclosing bank survive at the NW and South’.   No surface remains visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached location map and drawing from C. Tarbett and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 12 May 2021

In low-lying, wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 25m N of a townland boundary with Kildromin. A ring-barrow (LI023-297----) lies 9m to SE and an enclosure (LI023-299----) lies 70m to SW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a small, circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 194: AP 4/3632). Monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 8m) on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage 25/03/2017 and Bruff aerial survey image.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 14 September 2020  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 352/23 taken 05/01/2003.

In low-lying, wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 18m N of a townland boundary with Kildromin. A ring-barrow (LI023-298----) lies 9m to NW and an enclosure (LI023-299----) lies 70m to SW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a small, circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 194: AP 4/3632). Monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 13.5m) on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage 25/03/2017 and Bruff aerial survey image.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 14 September 2020  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 352/23 taken 05/01/2003.

In rough pasture, 11m S of field boundary and 80m W of a stream that marks townland boundary with Feloree.  A cluster of ring-barrows (LI023-226001-/009-) lie 280m to W and linear earthworks (LI024-179002-) lie 260 to NE. Not depicted on OS historical mapping. Identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 26; AP 4/3665) as a small circular cropmark of a possible ring-barrow. Cropmark is visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff survey image marked Bruff 26.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 27 July 2020

At the top of the S-facing slope of Mewlaghadooey Hill, and on the line of the perimeter of hillfort (RO027-014001-) at SE. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 30m; H 0.6-0.8m) separated by a berm (Wth 5-6.5m) from a slight outer bank (Wth c. 5m; H 0.1m) N-SE. It is overlain by a NW-SE field bank and does not survive SW of it. Ring-barrow (RO027-014004-) is c. 20m to the ENE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture 180m SE of enclosure (LI023-058----).    Not depicted on the OS maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 22; AP 4/3665) as circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 30m) defined by a scarp. Upstanding monument (approx. ext. diam. 34m) clearly visible as a circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 18m) enclosed by a fosse and outer bank on OSi orthoimage.  Pond immediately to NNE and a second pond to SSE.  Cropmark of levelled monument visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 25/05/2017.  Same site as LI024-177----.Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload:  21 July 2020

On the broad summit of Mewlaghadooey Hill, on the line of the perimeter of hillfort (RO027-014001-) at E. Circular grass-covered area (int. diam. 9.3m E-W; 8.7m N-S) defined by a slight earthen bank (Wth c. 5-6m; int. H 0.1-0.2m; ext. H 0.3-0.4m). There is no visible entrance. Ring-barrow (RO027-014003-) is c. 20m to the WSW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In low-lying pasture cut by land drains and watercourses, 110m NE of a townland boundary with Kildromin. Ring-barrow (LI024-284----) and enclosure (LI024-285----) lie 55m to S. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey (Bruff 2: AP 4/3632) in 1986. Monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 11m) on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017.See attached Bruff aerial photo taken in 1986 numbered 2 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 6 October 2020

In low-lying, wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 90m NE of a townland boundary with Kildromin, which also marks a parish boundary with Kilteely. Within the NW quadrant of a rectangular-shaped enclosure (LI024-285----). Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified as a circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 284: AP 4/3632). Monument is visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 14m) on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 284.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 12 October 2020  See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 352/23 taken 05/01/2003.

Barrow described in 1942-3 as following; 'This structure consists of a slight mound surrounded by two fosses and two banks. The inner fosse and bank are continuous. The outer bank has two breaks none of which seem original and are probably due to efforts to drain the fosse, which is water-logged. The diameter of the mound itself is 45'  [14m] approximately and the overall diameter of the whole monument is 210' [64m]. The surrounding field is a low-land marsh meadow which is subject to flooding. The height of the mound is about 4' [1.2m] (O'Kelly 1942-3, 238).  Outline of barrow clearly visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 6 March 2020
The cropmark of a ringbarrow is evident on Google Earth aerial photograph at this location.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 30 August 2013

In pasture 20m S of Enclosure (LI024-240----).  Not depicted on OS maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 51; AP 4/3684) as a circular-shaped crop mark (approx. diam. 15m) visible on Digital Globe Imagery 2011-2013.Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload:  21 July 2020

On a low rise. Subcircular grass-covered platform (diam. 26.5m N-S; 24.5m E-W; H 0.45-0.7m) defined by three rush-covered fosses and three grass-covered outer banks, of which only the outermost has bushes. The inner fosse (Wth of base 3.5-3.9m; ext. D 0.6-1m) is separated by a bank (Wth 3.5-4.8m; H 0.8-1.4m) from the middle fosse (Wth of base 3.9-4.7m). This fosse is separated by the middle bank (Wth 3.5-5m; H 0.8-1.2m) from the outer fosse (Wth of base 4-4.6m; ext. D 0.5-1.25m). The outer bank (at W: Wth 3.2m; ext. H 0.8m; at E: Wth 5.5m; ext. H 1.2m) which survives SW-NW and ENE-E. The outer bank is incorporated into a field bank SE-SW, and this field bank is also built in the outer fosse SW-NW. There are gaps (Wth 3.5-4m) in the banks at E (max. ext. diam. 78m E-W).  See the attached aerial view taken from the W.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010
The cropmark of a ringbarrow is evident on Google Earth aerial photograph at this location.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 30 August 2013

In wet unimproved pasture, 170m SE of Glenatrahaun Stream. A ring-barrow (LI024-214----) lies 50m to S. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OS 25-inch map as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork. Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a circular-shaped area (diam. 16m) defined by a scarp (H 0.75m), with fosse (Wth 4.55m; base Wth 2m; D 0.65m) visible from SE-S-W-N-NNE and an outer bank (Wth 3m; int. H 0.65m; ext. H 0.25m) is evident from SE-S-W-N-NNE. A raised oval shape area (3m N-S; 5.5m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 1.3m; H 0.5m) is visible in S quadrant of the interior and could be the remains of a small ring-ditch. A field boundary lies to the immediate W of the monument.   Ring-barrow is visible as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork on ASI aerial photograph (ASIAP 132, 33, 34 taken 23/058/2000 and 05/01/2003).  Well preserved monument visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.See attached sketch plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI. See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 18 July 2020

In pasture 15m W of stream that marks the townland boundary with Killeenaverra. Ring-barrow (LI024-152002-) located 15m to S. Not depicted on the OS maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 55; AP 4/3683) as a circular shaped cropmark.  A circular cropmark is visible in the NE corner of field on Google Earth orthoimage dated 28/06/2018.    Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  22 July 2020

In wet pasture, 260m S of Glenatrahaun Stream and the townland boundary with Ballynagally. A ring-barrow (LI024-064----) lies 50m to N and an enclosure (LI024-215----) is located abutting the ring-barrow to the E. The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 30.1; AP 4/3631) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 25m), the site is characterised by a central wide interior surrounded by a fosse (Wth 2m). The Bruff survey identified a central mound (Bruff 30.2) within the interior of the site. Recorded by ASI aerial photographic survey 23/08/2000 (ASIAP (132) 34. The ring-barrow is faintly visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 30.1-2, ASI survey image showing the ring-barrow view S, and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond O’Donovan  Date of upload: 14 September 2020

In pasture 15m W of stream that marks the townland boundary with Killeenaverra. Ring-barrow (LI024-152001-) located 15m to N. Not depicted on the OS maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 55(2); AP 4/3683) as a circular shaped cropmark. Visible as a cropmark on Google Earth orthoimage dated 28/06/2018.    Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  22 July 2020

Barrow described in 1942-3 as following; 'This consists of a circular platform surrounded by a fosse. Outside the fosse is a slight bank which is broken in four places. These breaks seem to have been caused by the making of drains in the field. But in spite of the drains the fosse remains water-logged. The platform has a height of 1' [0.3m] over the field level and the overall diameter is 204' [62m]. It is in low-lying marshy ground. In the north-west quadrant of the platform is a very well made ring-barrow. This consists of a slight mound around which there is a fosse which is well defined. Outside this there is a very slight continuous bank. The overall diameter is 36' [11m] (O'Kelly 1942-3, 239).  Outline of barrow clearly visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 6 March 2020See attached ASI aerial photographs ASIAP - 369/2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 on 10/05/2003.

In the S quadrant of large barrow or burial mound (LI033-015001-).  Surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as a sub-circular shaped area (4.2m N-S; 4.5m E-W) defined by a scarp (Wth 1m; H 1.2m), fosse (base Wth 0.5m) and outer bank (Wth 2.75m; H 0.2m). Visible as a roughly circular-shaped depression (diam. c. 4m) in the S of interior on OSi orthophotos 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimages dated 18/11/2018Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload: 3 April 2021See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 132/35 on 23/08/2000. 352/24 on 05/01/2003. 353/13, 15, 19 on 05/01/2003.

In pasture 140m N of the summit of Cromwell Hill (OD 586 feet).  Ring-barrow (LI033-050002-) lies 65m to SW and bowl-barrow (LI033-050001-) 140m to S.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 55; AP 5/2022) as a circular-shaped cropmark. Visible as a circular-shaped area (diam. c. 7.5m) enclosed by a bank with external fosse on OSi orthophotos taken between 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 23 March 2021See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP - 133/09 on 23/08/2000. 332/15, 16, 19 on 05/10/2002.

In gently undulating wet pasture, on the W edge of a small barrow cemetery, with ring-barrows (TS 065-007001- and TS065-007003-) c. 20m to the SSE and c. 100m to the NE respectively and ditch barrows (TS 065-007004-; TS 065-007005-; TS 065-007006- and TS 065-007007-) c. 100m to the E, c. 90m to the E, c. 95m to the SE and c. 50m to the NE respectively. Identified on an aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2404/3). Circular area (diam. 5m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.7m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6m) and an external low broad earthen bank (int. H 0.1m; overall Wth 1m). The W half of the circuit is better preserved while the E half is barely visible at ground level. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 12 May 2014

The W half of the circuit is better preserved while the E half is barely visible at ground level. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth. In wet pasture, on gentle SE-facing slope, 260m SE of Glenatrahaun Stream. A ring-barrow (LI024-216001-) lies 190m to S, with a cluster of sites (LI024--066/217-/218-/291-) lie 70m to E. H 0.35m) visible from W-N-E only, berm (Wth 4-6m) only visible from WNW-N-ENE, fosse (Wth 5.8m; D 0.45m) and outer bank (Wth 11.8m; int. H 0.45m; ext. H 0.55m) only visible from NW-N-ENE. In gently undulating wet pasture. One of a cluster of 5 barrows. In improved flat pasture adjacent to a field boundary, 180m N of the townland boundary with Scart. The ring-barrow (LI024-216001-) is located within an enclosure (LI024-216----). A ring-barrow (LI025-065----) is located 165m NNW. The site is not depicted on historic OSi maps; it is faintly visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 and on the Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified during a re-examination of the Bruff aerial photographic survey of 1986. Described as 'within this enclosure (LI024-216----) there is a small barrow (LI024-216001-), on the north-west side. Very clear through stereoscope', Robert Dolan (pers. comm. 20/03/2015). The site is faintly visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018. See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by:  Edmond O’DonovanDate of upload: 18 September 2020

Situated in recently planted coniferous forestry, on a gentle slope down to SW into the valley of the Mulkear River, with good views in all directions. Identified from an aerial photograph as a possible ring barrow (Bruff 10; 4/3733). The monumet is no longer evident in dense undergrowth.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 23 October 2013

In flat terrain in reclaimed field under pasture. Within a linear barrow cemetery (L c. 130m) which runs NE-SW. Monument identified on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009). This ring-barrow (overall diam. 13.5m N-S; 11m E-W) is conjoined with another ring-barrow (TS065-073002-) to the E, both sharing their outer bank at the junction. Other ring-barrows in the cemetery include TS065-073003-; TS065-073004- and TS065-073005- which lie 28m, 58m and 121m to the NE respectively and  TS065-073006- and TS065-073007- which lie 58m and 121m to the ENE respectively. It consists of a circular area (dims 7.4m N-S; 7.1m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.2-1.5m; D 0.15-0.2m) with evidence of an outer bank at the NW-N (int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.15m; Wth at base 1.9m; Wth at crest 0.9m) and at the E (Wth 1.2m).   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

In flat terrain in reclaimed field under pasture. Within a linear barrow cemetery which runs NE-SW (L c. 130m). Monument identified on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009). This ring-barrow (overall diam. 10.9m N-S; 11.2m E-W) is conjoined with another ring-barrow (TS065-073001-) to the W, both sharing their outer bank at the junction. Other ring-barrows in the cemetery include TS065-073003-; TS065-073004- and TS065-073005- which lie 15m, 50m and 111m to the NE respectively and  TS065-073006- and TS065-073007- which lie 94m and 112m to the ENE respectively. It consists of a circular area (dims 4.8m N-S; 5.3m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.2-1.3m; D 0.12-0.16m) with evidence of a much denuded outer bank in the SE-S sector and SW-W-NW (int. H 0.12-0.2m; ext. H 0.05m; Wth at base 1.2m; Wth at crest 0.6m).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

In flat terrain, in a reclaimed field under pasture. Within a linear barrow cemetery which runs NE-SW (L c. 130m). Monument identified on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009). This ring-barrow (overall diam. 10.1m N-S; 11.7m E-W) consists of a low flat circular area (diam. 5.1m N-S; 5.6m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1-1.15m; D 0.08m) with traces of an outer bank in the N, E and W quadrants (Wth 1.1-1.5m; int. H 0.11-0.15m; ext. H 0.08-0.1m). Other ring-barrows in the cemetery include TS065-073001- and TS065-073002- which lie 28m and 15m to the SW respectively and TS065-073004- and TS065-073005- which lie 26m and 92m to the NE respectively and TS065-073006- and TS065-073007- which lie 74m and 95m to the ENE respectively.   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

In flat terrain, in a reclaimed field under pasture. Within a linear barrow cemetery which runs NE-SW (L c. 130m). Monument identified on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009). This ring-barrow (overall diam. 10.8m N-S; 11.2m E-W) consists of a low circular area (diam. 5.2m N-S; 5.4m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.4m; D 0.06m) with slight traces of an outer bank in the SE quadrant (Wth 2.05m at base; 0.9m at creast; H above int. 0.11m; H above ext. 0.06m). Other ring-barrows in the cemetery include TS065-073001-; TS065-073002- and TS065-073003- which lie 58m, 50m and 26m to the SW respectively, TS065-073005- lies 60m to the NE and TS065-073006- and TS065-073007- lie 45m and 67m to the ENE respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

On a natural rise in an area of flat wet terrain under pasture. There is a linear barrow cemetery (TS065-073001-; TS065-073002-; TS065-073003-; TS065-073004-; TS065-073005-; TS065-073006-; TS065-073007-) c. 130-230m to the S-SW which runs NE-SW. This monument (overall diam. 13.6m N-S; 13m E-W) was identified as a circular feature on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009). It consists of a central mound (diam. 5.1m N-S; 5.4m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.3m; D 0.12-0.2m) and an outer bank (Wth at base 3m; Wth at crest 1.2m; H above int. 0.22m; H above ext. 0.12m). The outer bank is clearly visible in the NW and from NE-SW. There are flag irises growing in the fosse in the SW and W sectors and on the bank in the W quadrant. A field drain (Wth 1.5m; D 0.15m) runs into the fosse in the N quadrant.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

In flat terrain, in a reclaimed field under pasture. Within a linear barrow cemetery which runs NE-SW (L c. 130m). Monument identified on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009). This ring-barrow (overall diam. 12.1m N-S; 13.5m E-W) consists of a low circular area (diam. 5.2m N-S; 5m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.1-1.4m; D 0.08-0.1m) with slight traces of a flattened outer bank from E-NW (Wth 3.6m at base; 1.3-1.8m at creast; H above int. 0.16-0.21m; H above ext. 0.8-0.17m). There is a slight depression in the interior mound, slightly NE of centre. There are rushes growing in the fosse from NE-S and some in the interior in the NW quadrant. Other ring-barrows in the cemetery include TS065-073001-; TS065-073002-; TS065-073003- and TS065-073004- which lie 121m, 111m, 92m and 60m to the SW respectively, TS065-073006- and TS065-073007- lie 43m and 24m to the S and SE respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

On a raised hummock within generally flat wet terrain, in a reclaimed field under pasture. Within a linear barrow cemetery (L c. 130m) which runs NE-SW. Monument identified during fieldwork. This ring-barrow consists of a well-defined dome-shaped mound enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.7-2.15m; D 0.1-0.15m) and outer bank (Wth at base 2.1-2.7m; Wth at crest 1.2-1.4m; H above int. 0.15-0.17m; H above ext. 0.04-0.09m). The outer bank has been truncated in the S quadrant by a field boundary which runs E-W. Other ring-barrows in the cemetery include TS065-073001-; TS065-073002- and TS065-073003- - which lie 58m, 94m and 74m to the SW respectively, TS065-073004 which lies 45m to the W, TS065-073005- which lies 43m to the N and TS065-073007- which lies 29m to the NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

Immediately W of a field boundary which runs NE-SW, in generally flat wet terrain, in a reclaimed field under pasture. Within a linear barrow cemetery (L c. 130m) which runs NE-SW. This monument was identified as a circular feature on Google Earth aerial imagery (Imagery Date: 2/20/2009). There is no visible trace of this monument above ground. There are a number of field drains in this specific area which may be creating the false impression of monument on the aerial. However, it has been classified as a ring-barrow possible based on its appearance on the Google aerial and its close proximity to a ring-barrow cemetery. Ring-barrows in the cemetery include TS065-073001-; TS065-073002-; TS065-073003-; TS065-073004- which lie 124m, 111m, 95m and 66m to the SW respectively, TS065-073005- which lies 27m to the NW and TS065-073006- which lies 29m to the SSW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

In gently undulating wet pasture 8m to S of an E-W flowing stream. Mound barrow almost completely levelled and now consists of a circular area (diam. 16m) enclosed by an external earthen bank (int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.2m; Wth at top 1m; overall Wth 3.1m) NW-NNE and the trace remains (av. Wth 3.4m) of the levelled external bank NNE-NW. An internal fosse (Wth at base 0.8m) survives immediately within the extant portion of the external bank and is absent elsewhere. The interior has been almost entirely levelled except for a roughly triangular portion (dims. 4m N-S; 5m E-W; H 0.3m) of the edge of the NNW quadrant immediately within the surviving portion of the fosse and external bank. The interior is dry and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture. Bowl-barrow (TS057-011----) located c. 40m to the SW. Circular area (diam. 4.1m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.4-0.65m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4-0.7m) and an external low broad earthen bank (int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.05-0.1m; Wth at top 1-1.3m; overall Wth 1.8-2.4m). From SE-SW the external bank is almost entirely absent where a silted up E-W orientated modern drain abuts the S side of the ring-barrow. Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In gently undulating low-lying wet pasture with a ring-barrow (TS065-024005-) abutting the edge of the barrow at NE with others nearby. Identified on aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2430/29). In gently undulating wet pasture with a group of ring-barrows (TS065-024001- to TS065-024007-) located 60m to the N. Identified on aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2430 (mono)). In low-lying level wet pasture. Visible as a circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m) on an aerial photograph (OS 2430/1). Not visible at ground level. Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on summit of a low elongated E-W orientated hillock, in pasture, 20m to the ENE of a ditch barrow (SL015-047002-). Natural ground level slopes down gently to the N, E and S of the site. Circular slightly raised area (diam. 7m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (ext. H 0.15-0.4m). At the external foot of the scarp are a fosse (Wth 2.6m) and an external bank (Wth 1.75-2.65m; int. H 0.2m). The NE one-third of the site slopes gently facing NE reflecting the underlying natural slope of the hillock.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

In reclaimed wet pasture, with a spring well 20m to SSE and a stream 100m to SE marking townland boundary with Coologe.  On the 1840 ed. OS 6-inch map the townland boundary with Ballynagally is depicted standing immediately E of the monument.  Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as the remains of a circular-shaped area (26m ENE-WSW; 24m NNW-SSE) the S half of which has been levelled. The N half of the monument survives as a semi-circular-shaped area (26m ENE-WSW; 10m NNW-SSE) defined by a scarp (Wth 1.2m; H 0.5m) with fosse (Wth 7.2m; D 0.45m) visible from NNW-N-ENE, with possible traces of an outer bank (Wth 8.7m; int. H 0.45m; ext. H 0.3m) from N-NNE-ENE. The S half of the monument is defined by the remains of a much degraded bank (Wth 5.5m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.6m) visible from ENE-E-S-WSW.  Monument is visible as a circular-shaped earthwork on ASI aerial photographs (ASIAP 353, 23) taken 05/01/2003.  Monument is visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.See attached sketch plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI. See attached Google Earth orthoimages and ASIAP images taken 2003Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 18 July 2020

In poorly drained rush-covered grazing, on top of a narrow ridge. A slightly raised circular area (6.7m N-S; 6.6m E-W) enclosed by two earthen banks with an intervening fosse. The inner bank (Wth 2.5m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.5m) has a low internal face. The fosse (Wth 2m) is shallow and flat-bottomed and marginally raised above exterior ground level. The outer bank (Wth 2m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.3m) is evident as a low compact rise with a well-defined external face. The overall diameter is 15m N-S and 15.5m E-W and it is almost completely engulfed in rushes. A ring-barrow (SL047-071----) lies c. 55m to E. This ring-barrow is indicated on the 1838 OS 6-inch map.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In poorly drained rush-covered grazing, on top of a narrow E-W ridge. A slightly raised circular area (6.8m N-S; 6.8m E-W; H 0.4m) enclosed by a fosse and external bank. The fosse (Wth c. 3m) is shallow and waterlogged. The bank (Wth 2.5m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.35m) is broad, low and poorly defined. A break (Wth 4m) in the bank at W, opposite a relatively dry section of the fosse, may be the result of damage rather than the location of an entrance. A ring-barrow (SL047-070001-) lies c. 55m to W.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture truncated by a drainage ditch / field boundary 90m SW of the townland boundary with Glen (Clanwilliam By.). The barrow is one of a group of four ring-barrows (LI024-161002/003-; LI024-244/245----) in a cemetery 20m apart. The site is not depicted on historic OSi maps, it is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 and on the Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified during examination of Bruff aerial photographic survey of 1986 (Bruff AP 4/3681) as a ring-barrow. The site is visible with its SW side truncated by a field boundary and drainage ditch, visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018. The Placenames Database of Ireland records that Knocknacrohy is derived from the Irish Cnoc na Croiche or Hill of the Gallows (www.logainm.ie). The placename may preserve a folk memory to burial on the hill relating to the proliferation of Bronze Age funerary monuments or ring-barrows on and around it.See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 245 and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by:  Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 18 September 2020

On a NW-facing slope, in rough, wet pasture, 100m NE of a townland boundary with Knocknacrohy. Within a complex of five barrows (LI024-041/243/246/342/341----). Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a small, circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 68: AP 4/3681). Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile circular-shaped area (4.2m N-S; 4m E-W) defined by a scarp (Wth 0.6-0.75m; H 0.05-0.08m) and a fosse (Wth 2.2-2.55m; D 0.02-0.2m). An outer bank (Wth 2.95-3.55m; int. H 0.02-0.2m; ext. H 0.05-0.4m) is truncated from N-NE by a linear earthen bank running (L 28m) NW-SE. The interior is generally level. A poorly drained, sunken area abutting the exterior at SW is choked with rushes and appears to contain a spring which drains to W. The remains of a bank running WNW-ESE are situated to SW. Monument is visible as a subcircular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-201, and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached aerial photo labelled Bruff 68 and sketch profile drawn by the ASI in 2008 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 29 September 2020

Part of a complex excavated in 1948 (O'Kelly, 1952). Excavation revealed circular 'very low mound' (diam. 52ft) enclosed by 'round bottomed' fosse (D 1ft; Wth 3ft). This overlay pits, stake-holes, charcoal spreads and fragments of a human skull and 'produced a range of pottery types which date the monument to the Neolithic period' (ibid.); subsequent activity on site of three more phases interpreted as follows: multiple cist cairn (CO027-069---) placed on mound of ringbarrow and within fosse; food vessel burial (CO027-161---) outside fosse; urn burial (CO027-260---) also outside fosse, which was extended to enclose burial. This sequence recently questioned in light of two radiocarbon dates from the site and reclassification of 'Neolithic' pottery as Beaker pottery (Brindley et al., 1987/8, 13-20). Three phases suggested: short term settlement with beaker pottery, pits etc.; multiple cist cairn with food vessel burial to SW; cist reused and cairn modified by enclosing it with fosse, which soon after was extended to enclose urn burial.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but it is faintly visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 and on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 32; AP 4/3668) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 10m) that consists of a central circular area surrounded by a fosse, the site appears to have a slight external bank. See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 32 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by:  Edmond ODonovan  Date of upload: 15 September 2020

Ring-barrow which is one of 12 monuments forming an archaeological complex located in three fields and described by O'Kelly (1944, 17) as following; 'All these monuments are situated in a low-land marsh meadow, the entire complex covering three fields. In one field are 8 of the barrows and the two platforms [LI033-029001-/014-]. In the nearest corner of the next field to the east is the tumulus, and the 9th barrow is in the nearest corner of the next field to the north. The road lies immediately to the west of all these, and the sand-pit is just west of this. The Barrows are all exactly the same in method of construction but the diameters vary. They consist of very slight circular mounds surrounded by fosses and have no outer banks. The diameters vary between 15' [4.5m] and 36' [11m]. In their lay-out in the held there is no particular arrangement observable'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien   Date of upload: 09 August 2019

On top of a very slight drier rise in gently undulating wet pasture. Two ring-barrows (TS 057-038----) is located 70m to the SSE and a second ring-barrow (TS057-03----) is located 86m to the S. Circular area (diam. 5m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.5m) and an traces of an external low broad earthen bank (int. H 0.1m; Wth at top 0.8m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Ring-barrow which is one of 12 monuments forming an archaeological complex located in three fields and described by O'Kelly (1944, 17) as following; 'All these monuments are situated in a low-land marsh meadow, the entire complex covering three fields. In one field are 8 of the barrows and the two platforms [LI033-029001-/014-]. In the nearest corner of the next field to the east is the tumulus, and the 9th barrow is in the nearest corner of the next field to the north. The road lies immediately to the west of all these, and the sand-pit is just west of this. The Barrows are all exactly the same in method of construction but the diameters vary. They consist of very slight circular mounds surrounded by fosses and have no outer banks. The diameters vary between 15' [4.5m] and 36' [11m]. In their lay-out in the held there is no particular arrangement observable'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien   Date of upload: 09 August 2019

On reclaimed pasture, 65m N of the Mulkear River. Monument identified as a roughly circular-shaped ring-barrow by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 141: AP 4/3732). Monument not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey imageCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 21 July 2020
Outline of small possible ring-barrow visible on aerial photographs.  Not visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph. Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien Date of upload: 09 August 2019

On top of a very slight drier rise in gently undulating wet pasture. Ring-barrow (TS057-038----) is located 16m to the NE and a second ring-barrow (TS057-039----) is located 86m to the N. Circular area (diam. 4m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.95m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6m) and an external low broad earthen bank (int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1m; Wth at top 0.6m; overall Wth 1.95m). Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On top of a very slight drier rise in gently undulating wet pasture. Ring-barrow (TS 057-037----) located 16m to the SW and a second ring-barrow (TS057-039----) is located 70m to NW. Circular very slightly raised area (diam. 3m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.2m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6m) and an external low broad earthen bank (int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.1m; Wth at top 0.6m; overall Wth 1.9m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On top of a very slight rise at the centre of a circular clearing (diam. c. 60m) in c. 10 year old coniferous forestry. Identified on an aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2430/1). Circular area (diam. 8m) defined by a shallow fosse (overall Wth 1.8m; Wth at base 0.6m; D 0.15m) with traces of an external earthen bank (overall Wth 1.7m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 14 May 2014

Situated atop high ground in an upland area with nearby barrow group (TN031-024001/002/003)) to S and ringfort (TN031-022) to N. A slightly raised circular area (diam. 11.5m NW-SE; H 0.65m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.7m) and external bank (Wth 2.2m; ext. H 0.8m; int. H 0.6m) with causewayed entrance (Wth 2m) at W. The interior is planted with conifers and is intersected at E by a NW-SE field fence.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In pasture 100m N of public road and 300m S of the Glenatrahaun Stream that marks the boundary with Ballynagally. Ring-barrow (LI024-226----) located 185m to NW. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 33(01); AP 4/3668) as a circular shaped cropmark. Outline of monument visible as a circular shaped area (approx. diam. 7.5m) defined by a ditch on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-3013 and Global Earth orthoimage dated 28/06/2018.    See attached Google Earth orthophoto taken 28/06/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 33(01).  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  27 July 2020

Situated on the SW slope of a hilltop in an upland area with nearby barrow group (TN031-024) to NE. A well-preserved circular area (diam. 11.5m N-S) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2m) and outer bank (Wth 2.5m; ext. H 0.75m). There is a causewayed entrance (Wth 2m) at E.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on top of a hill in an upland area with nearby ringfort (TN031-022) to NW and three ring-barrows (TN031-025, TN031-023,TN031-026 ) to W, N and SE respectively. Conjoined ring-barrows, the first consisting of a circular area (diam. approx. 16.5m NW-SE) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2.2m) and outer bank (Wth 1.7m; ext. H 1.2m) both of which are best preserved at S where the adjoining barrow sits. This barrow consists of a circular area (diam. 13.6m N-S) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2.2m) and outer bank with causewayed entrance (Wth 2.7m) at E. The interior and enclosing banks are planted with conifers.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on top of a hill in an upland area with nearby ringfort (TN031-022) to NW and three ring-barrows (TN031-025, TN031-023, TN031-026) to W, N and SE respectively. The site is immediately SE of the conjoined barrows (TN031-024001). A small well-preserved consisting of a circular flat-topped mound (diam. 4.5m N-S; H 0.7m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.2m) with traces of an external bank. Ring-barrow (TN031-024003) is situated to the S.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on top of a hill in an upland area with nearby ringfort (TN031-022) to NW and three ring-barrows (TN031-025, TN031-023, TN031-026) to W, N and SE respectively. This site consists of a circular area (diam. 4.3m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.4m) and external bank (Wth 1m; ext. H 0.4m; int. H 0.2m). Ring-barrow (TN031-024002) is situated immediately to the N.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008
