Situated in the SE quadrant of a circular enclosure (LI015-05901-), in a field of undulating pasture. Identified from aerial photography (Bruff Survey: Map 15, no 14.02; 4/3731) as a ring barrow. The monument consists of a sub-circular area (5m E-W; 4.8m N-S) defined by a scarped edge with an external fosse (Wth 1m; D 0.15m).  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 23 October 2013
The cropmark of a possible ringbarrow is evident on Google Earth aerial photographs, at this location.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 4 September 2013
The cropmark of at least two possible ringbarrow is evident on Google Earth aerial photographs, at this location.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 4 September 2013

In level wet pasture on the NW side of a field system (TS057-016014-) and with a ring-barrow (TS057-016005-) 24m to the NE and another (TS057-016007-) 10m to the SSE with others nearby. Circular area (diam. 4.2m) enclosed by a low earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.1m) with a shallow external fosse (Wth at base 0.4m; D 0.1m). From SSW-NW the scarp has been truncated and the fosse removed by a NNW-ESE orientated modern field drain. Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture on the NW side of a field system (TS 057-016014-) and with a ring-barrow (TS057-016006-) 10m to the NNW and another (TS057-016008-) immediately to the SSE with others nearby. Circular area (diam. c. 4.m) enclosed by a low earthen scarp (Wth 0.4m; H 0.1m) with a shallow external fosse (Wth at base 0.5m; D 0.1m). Scarp and fosse are best preserved NNW-SSE where the profile is well defined and consistent being barely visible at ground level NW-NNW and SSE-SW. From SE-NW the scarp has been truncated and the fosse removed by a NNW-ESE orientated modern field drain. The fosse is absent SSE-SW where the edge of the ring-barrow abuts the edge of another ring-barrow (TS057-016008-) immediately to the SSE. Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture on the NW side of a field system (TS057-016016-) with a ring-barrow (TS057-016007-) immediately to the NNW and others nearby. Circular area (diam. 4.m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.8m; H 0.2m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4m) and a low external earthen bank (int. H 0.15; ext. H 0.05m: Wth at top 0.6m; overall Wth 1.6m). The scarp, fosse and external bank enclose the ring-barrow NW-SE. The external bank is best preserved NNE-SE and is barely NW-NNE where the ring-barrow abuts the S edge of another ringbarrow (TS057-016007-). From SE-NW the edge of the interior is defined by the rounded corner of a modern field drain that has removed the fosse and the external bank. Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture on the NW side of a field system (TS057-016014-) and with a ringfort (TS057-016001-) 16m to the E and ring-barrow (TS057-016006-) 24m to the SW with other ring-barrows nearby. Circular area (diam. 4m) enclosed by a low earthen scarp (Wth 0.4m; H 0.1-0.15m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4) and traces of an external earthen bank (int. H 0.1; overall Wth 0.6). Interior is level and clear of overgrowth. A WNW-ESE orientated channel (dims. Wth at base 1.4m; overall Wth 2.2m; D 0.2m) of the nearby field system (TS 057-01616) abuts the external edge of the bank at SSW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture on the NW side of a field system (TS057-016014-) with a ringfort (TS057-016001-) 16m to the NE and a ring-barrow (TS057-010009-) 8m to the ENE with others nearby. Roughly circular slightly raised area (diam. 4.8m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.4-0.8m; H 0.2m) with a shallow external fosse (Wth at base 0.4-0.6m; overall Wth 1-1.2m; D 0.15m). From SE-S the fosse is absent where the edge of the ring-barrow has been eroded by livestock. Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture on the W side of a field system (TS057-016014-) with a ring-barrow (TS057-016010-) 10m to the WSW and other ring-barrows nearby. Circular slightly raised area (diam. 1.75m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.4-0.5m; H 0.2m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.8) and a low broad external earthen bank (int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.1m; Wth at top 0.6-0.7m; overall Wth 1.2-1.3m). Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In rough grazing, close to a break of slope at the E end of a ridge. One of a group of four barrows forming a barrow cemetery (see SL047-048002; SL047-048003-; SL047-048004-). A circular area (c. 11m E-W; 11.7m N-S) enclosed by a fosse (Wth c. 3m) which is evident as a broad band of waterlogged ground supporting a dense growth of rushes and irises. A stony external flat-topped bank (Wth 2.4m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.2m) is evident all round. A possible entrance (Wth 1.35m) at ESE is marked by a low section of the bank and a corresponding dry section of the fosse. There is a gap (Wth 3m) in the bank at E. The overall diameter of the barrow is 20m N-S and 19.7m E-W. It is conjoined at W to a bowl-barrow (SL047-048002-). A ditch barrow (SL047-048003-) lies c. 14m to W and another (SL047-04804-) c. 30m to ESE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In level wet pasture on the NW side of a field system (TS057-016014-) with a ringfort (TS057-016001-) 8m to the NE and ring-barrow (TS057-016010-) 8m to the SSW with other ring-barrows nearby. Roughly circular area (dims. 5m N-S; 4m E-W) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.1-0.2m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4) and slight traces of a barely visible external earthen bank (int. H 0.1-0.2m; overall Wth 0.8m). Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture near the centre of a field system (TS057-016014-) with a ring-barrow (TS057-016009-) 8m to the NW and other ring-barrows nearby. Roughly circular slightly raised area (diam. 5.2m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.2m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6) and a low broad external earthen bank (int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.1m; Wth at top 0.7m; overall Wth 1.7m). From NW-NNE the scarped edge has been truncated and the fosse removed where an ENE-WSW orientated field bank crosses the N edge of the ring-barrow. The external bank is best preserved NNE-ESE being barely visible at ground level ESE-NW been removed NW-NNE where the field bank crosses the N edge of the monument. Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture on the SW side of a field system (TS057-016014-) and with a ring-barrow (TS057-016012-) c. 40m to the NNW and another (TS065-069002-) immediately to the ENE with others nearby. Identified during field survey by Mark Keegan (8/11/2004). Roughly circular slightly raised area (diam. 4m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.15m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4m) and a low external earthen bank (int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1m; Wth at top 0.7m; overall Wth 1.9m). The scarp is eroded and the fosse and external bank are absent NW-E where the external edge of the barrow abuts an ENE-WSW orientated portion of the nearby field system (TS057-016014-) and another ring-barrow (TS065-069002-) immediately to the ENE. The interior s level clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 16 September 2014

In level wet pasture on the SW side of a field system (TS057-016014-) and with a ring-barrow (TS057-016012-) c. 40m to the NNW and another (TS065-069001-) immediately to the WSW with others nearby. Identified during field survey by Mark Keegan (8/11/2004). Circular slightly raised area (diam. 3.5m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.4m; H 0.15m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4-0.5m) and a low external earthen bank (int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1m; Wth at top 0.6m; overall Wth 1.5m). The fosse and external bank are absent WSW-NNW where the external edge of the monument abuts another ring-barrow (TS065-069001-) immediately to the WSW. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 16 September 2014

In level wet pasture on the NE side of a field system (TS057-016014-) with a ring-barrow (TS057-016002-) 18m to the NE and second (TS057-016003-) 18m to the ENE with others nearby. Circular slightly raised area (diam. 4m) enclosed by a slight earthen scarp (Wth 0.4m; H 0.1-0.15m) with a shallow external fosse (Wth at base 0.45m; overall Wth 0.85m; D 0.1m). From ESE-SW the scarped edge and the fosse are absent where an ENE-WSW orientated modern field drain truncates the S side of the ring-barrow. Interior is level clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture on the NE side of a field system (TS057-016014-) and with ringfort (TS057-016001-) 34m to the WSW and ring-barrow (TS057-016003-) 2m to the SE and second ring-barrow (TS057-016004-) 18m to the SW with others nearby. Circular area (diam. 3.9m) enclosed by a low earthen scarp (Wth 0.6-0.7m; H 0.2-0.25m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6-0.65m) and an external low broad earthen bank (int. H 0.15-2m; overall Wth 1.5). The external bank is absent E-SE with very slight remains elsewhere. Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture on the NE side of a field system (TS057-016014-) with a ring-barrow (TS057-016002-) 2m to the NW and second (TS057-016004-) 18m to the WSW with others nearby. Circular area (diam. 4m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4m; overall Wth 0.8m; D 0.1m) separated by a level berm (Wth 0.8m) from a shallow external fosse (Wth at base 0.45m; overall Wth 1.45m; D 0.1m). From SSE-SSW the scarped edge has been truncated by an ENE-WSW orientated modern field drain and from SE-SW the fosses and the intermediate berm are absent. Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Towards the top of a gentle W-facing slope. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 15.8m N-S; H 0.15-0.2m) defined by a slight fosse (Wth of top 3.4-5m; Wth of base 1.5-1.9m; D 0.25-0.6m) and an outer flat-topped bank (Wth of base 3.7-4.2m; Wth of top 1.3-1.4m; ext. H 0.1-0.3m). There are entrances through the bank at ESE (Wth 1.7m) and WNW (Wth 2m), but there are no discernible causeways (max. ext. diam. 28.8m N-S).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the summit towards the NW end of a NW-SE ridge and just WSW of the barrow (RO034-035001-). Described as a circular mound defined by a fosse and outer bank (diam. 11m N-S; 10.5m E-W) (Gannon 1972). it is now visible as a grass-covered domed mound (diam. 4m; H 0.15m) defined by slight traces of a fosse (Wth of base 1.2m; D 0.1m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 17/1977).

On a slight rise overlooking a S-N stream c. 45m to the W and the seashore of Donegal Bay c. 45m to the N. This is a grass-covered circular mound (diam. 26m; H 0.8-1.2m) defined by a flat- bottomed fosse (Wth 4-6m) and an outer earth and stone bank (Wth 6-8m; H over fosse 0.7- 1m; ext. H 0.5m). There is no identifiable original entrance. The outer bank is truncated slightly by a NNW-SSE field wall at W, and slightly clipped by field banks at S and E (max. ext. dim. 51.5m N-S).  See the attached aerial view taken from the E  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

In reclaimed pasture. The site of an enclosure (LI024-324-) lies 60m to ENE which is depicted on the 1840 ed. OS 6-inch amp.  A ring-barrow (LI024-125----) lies 240m to ESE. Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Monument identified as a semicircular-shaped earthwork by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 126: AP 4/3721). Monument is vaguely traceable as a semicircular-shaped cropmark (approx. dims. 10m NE-SW; 8.5m NW-SE), on the E side of a field boundary, on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018. There is no visible trace of the monument on the WNW side of the field boundary.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 23 July 2020

In damp pasture, on a N-facing slope. D-shaped area (4m NE-SW straight side; 4m NW-SE) defined by inner fosse (Wth 2.95m; D 0.25m) SW-NE which is infilled S-SW with up-cast drainage material. Outer bank (Wth 2.4m; int. H 0.25m; ext. H 0.15m) is best preserved SW-W but barely traceable W-NW. Monument truncated by field drain ENE-SE. Ringfort (LI024-014001-) c. 24m to NNW. Level interior under oasture.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 6 December 2013

On an elevated area of rough, wet pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, 65m W of a townland boundary with Ballyvoneen. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Ring-barrow (LI024-014002-) and enclosure (LI024-014001-) are 12m to NW and 65m to W, respectively. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile circular-shaped area (9.4m N-S; 9m E-W) defined by a scarp (Wth 0.65m; H 0.05-0.15m) and external fosse (Wth 1.8-1.9m; D 0.1-0.17m). The interior has an E-facing slope and is grass covered. Monument is visible as a much larger oval-shaped cropmark (25m N-S; 20m E-W) on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 16 October 2020

In reclaimed pasture. An enclosure (LI024-324----) lies 175m to NW and a ring-barrow (LI024-124----) lies 240m to ESE. Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Monument identified as a circular-shaped earthwork by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 74: AP 4/3680). Earthwork visible as an oval-shaped area (approx. dims. 37m WNW-ESE; 33m NNE-SSW) defined by a distinct fosse, on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 23 July 2020

Situated on a W-facing slope of rising ground in a mountainous area with a standing stone (TN031-015002) protruding from the surface of the central mound. The present remains consist of a sunken circular mound (diam. 7m N-S; H 0.6m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2m) and external bank (Wth 2.5m; int. H 1.25m; ext. H 0.2-0.5m).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Just off the summit of a NW-SE ridge at its E end, with the stepped barrow (RO034-035001-) c. 320m to the WNW. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. of top 6m E-W; 5.5m N-S; diam. of base 8.2m E-W; 7.8m N-S; H 0.4-0.6m) separated by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 3.8-4.3m; Wth of base 1.8-2m; D 0.3m) from traces of an outer bank (at N: Wth 3m; H 0.1m) which only survive N-NE and SE-S (max. ext. diam. 14m E-W; 13.6m E-W).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the summit of a WNW-ESE ridge. Described as a rectangular mound (dims of top c. 4.2m x 4.2m; dims of base c. 6.5m x c. 6.5m; H c. 0.9m) within a rectangular enclosure (dims c. 16m x 16m) defined by fosse (Wth c. 1m; D c. 0.0.7m) and an outer earthen bank (Wth c. 1.8m) which is reputed to have had a standing stone (RO034-018002-) on the central mound (Knox 1911, 339-340). This is a circular grass-covered and flat-topped mound (diam. of top 4.8m NW-SE; diam. of base 7.1m NW-SE; H 0.8-0.9m) on top of a broader circular platform (diam. of top 14.8m NW-SE; diam. of base 19m NW-SE; H 0.7-0.85m). It is enclosed in a rectangular, scrub-covered area (dims c. 25m NW-SE; c. 25m NE-SW) defined by a flat-topped earthen field bank (Wth of top 1.4m; int. H 0.25m; ext. H 0.6m). There is no evidence of a standing stone.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On level ground in low-lying gently undulating pasture with a ring-barrow (TS065-062002-) located c. 20m to the SE and two ditch barrows (TS065-065003- and TS065-065004-) c. 60m and c. 100m to the SE respectively. Visible as a faint roughly circular enclosure (diam. c. 8m) on an aerial photograph (Bruff 62, 2093). No visible surface trace at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 10 September 2014

In low-lying wet pasture with ring-barrows (TS065-006002-; TS065-006003-) located c. 30m to the ENE and c. 120m to the SE respectively. Circular area (diam. 4m) enclosed by a slight scarped edge (Wth 1m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.8m: D 0.05m) and a low broad external earthen bank (overall Wth 4m; Wth at top 1.5m; ext H 0.1m). From NW-NE the scarped edge, fosse and external bank are not visible at ground level and a modern WSW-ENE orientated modern field drain lies along the line of the fosse. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 12 May 2014

On level ground in low-lying gently undulating pasture with a ring-barrow (TS065-062001-) located c. 20m to the NWand two ditch barrows (TS065-065003- and TS065-065004-) c. 30m and c. 70m to the SE respectively. Visible as a faint roughly circular enclosure (diam. c. 8m) on an aerial photograph (Bruff 62, 2093). No visible surface trace at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 10 September 2014

On W-facing slope, in reclaimed pasture. Possible ring-barrow (LI024-126002-) conjoined to ESE. Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Monument identified as a circular-shaped conjoined earthwork by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 127(01): AP 4/3721).  Monument visible as a circular-shaped earthwork (approx. diam. 11m) defined by a distinct fosse, on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 23 July 2020

On W-facing slope, in reclaimed pasture.  Ring-barrow (LI024-126001-) conjoined to WNW. Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Monument identified as a circular-shaped conjoined earthwork by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 127(02): AP 4/3721). Monument is visible as a circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 10m) on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 23 July 2020

In low-lying wet pasture with ring-barrows (TS 065-006001-; TS 065-006003-) located c. 30m to the WSW and c. 110m to the SE respectively. Circular area (diam. 4m) enclosed by a slight scarped edge (Wth 1m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.8m: D 0.05m) and a low broad external earthen bank (overall Wth 4m; Wth at top 1.5m; ext H 0.1m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 12 May 2014

On a NW-facing slope, in improved pasture, 15m to SE of a townland boundary with Bunavie. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Abutting outer fosse of enclosure (LI024-015----) at SW. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile, circular-shaped area (1.9m N-S; 1.2m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.1m; D 0.05m) and the remains of an outer bank (Wth 2.4m; int. H 0.05m; ext. H 1.3m). Monument is visible as a faint, roughly circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 15 October 2020

In level wet pasture with two ring-barrows (TS065-006001- and TS065-006002-) located c. 120m and 110m to the NW respectively. Visible as a circular enclosure (diam. c. 8m) on an aerial photograph (Bruff No. 5/2041). Not visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 12 May 2014

On undulating pasture 50m NE of the townland boundary with Ballincassa. One of 12 ring-barrows in a cemetery (LI024-219/220----; LI024-325/-332----). Ring-barrow (LI024-220----) located 5m to NE. The site is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 165.1; AP 4/3626) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 6.5m). The ring-barrow is visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 165.1 and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 15 September 2020

On undulating pasture 65m NE of the townland boundary with Ballincassa. One of 12 ring-barrows in a cemetery (LI024-219/220----; LI024-325/-332----). Ring-barrow (LI024-219----) located 5m to SW. The site is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 165.2; AP 4/3626) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 7m). The ring-barrow is visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 165.2 and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 15 September 2020

Situated on a S-facing slope of rising ground in a mountainous area with nearby ringfort (TN031-016) to the N. Only the S half of the ring-barrow survives and this consists of a semicircular mound (diam. 12m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.3m) and an external bank (Wth 2.3m) with a causewayed entrance (Wth 2.3m) at S. A field fence bisects the site on an E-W axis. The remainder of the site to the N of the field fence is not visible at ground level.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

On SE facing slope in reclaimed pasture 600m E of the summit of Derk Hill (OD 781 ft.) and 200m SE of a stream that marks the townland boundary with Knockderk. Fields enclosed by drainage ditches associated with estate belonging to Derk House located 600m to NE.  The most N of a cluster of 14 barrows (LI033-036001/009; LI033-090/91-; LI033-121-122----; LI033-154----) concentrated in the S half of Derk townland with the closest (LI033-036003-) 12m to the NNW. Not depicted on any OSi maps. Surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as a sub-circular-shaped area (dims. 4.5m N-S; 5m E-W) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 3.05m-3.85m; D 0.12m-0.15m) and a low bank (Wth 4.4m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.17).  A linear depression running N-S 30m to E is one of a number of similar drainage ditches in surrounding fields.  Monument visible as a faint cropmark on OSi orthophotos 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  22 March 2021

On a slight rise in reclaimed pasture 800m SE of the summit of Derk Hill (OD 781 ft.) and 220m E of townland boundary with Knockderk. At the crest of the N-facing slope of a rise that forms the SE summit of a broad NW-SE ridge. Described as a rectangular platform (dims of top c. 9m NE-SW; c. 6m NW-SE; H c. 1.5m) separated by a fosse from an outer bank which only survived at NW (Knox 1918a, 161, Pl. VIII, E). It is now a D-shaped, flat-topped and grass-covered mound which has been damaged at W (dims of base 9.5m NNE-SSW; 8m WNW-ESE; dims of top 6.3m NNE-SSW; 4.6m WNW-ESE; H 0.8-1m). There is no evidence of a fosse or outer bank but a WNW-ESE field bank is immediately to the N. Ring-barrow (RO034-066001-) is c. 25m to the ENE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

H 1-1.2m; ext. H 0.35m at N to 0.95m at S). There is an entrance (Wth 3.5m) in the bank at NE (max. ext. diam. 49.6m N-S). Ring-barrow (RO034-066002-) is c. 25m to the WSW and enclosure (RO034-067001-) is c. 75m to the ESE. (Knox 1918a, 161)  See the attached aerial view taken from the SSE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a NE-facing slope. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 21m E-W; 20.5m N-S; H 0.25m at S to 0.4-0.6m generally) separated by a fosse (Wth of top 7.5-9m; Wth of base 5m; D 0.9-1.25m) from an outer bank (Wth 3.8-4.3m; H 0.4-0.45m). Located at the crest of the E-facing slope of a broad N-S ridge, with the round tower of Oran (RO034-080003-) c. 250m to the SSW. A geophysical survey (11R0074) of possible routes for a re-directed section of the N60 at Oran identified a number of possible enclosures defined by ditches (Gimson and Regan 2011). Archaeological testing (11E0247) disproved many of the anomalies, but a group of four features in Field 2 proved to be archaeological, and elements of the field system (RO034-081003-) may extend into this area (OHara 2011, 5-6, 24-5).  Only the S half of this enclosure was excavated (E004887). It is a circular area (int. diam. c. 24.5m; ext. diam. c. 32m) defined by a continuous V-shaped ditch (max. Wth of top 5.25m; max. D 1.8m) that was never re-cut and had no obvious entrance feature, although a widening of the fosse at W suggests there may be one at NW. A small quantity of animal bones from the ditch, acquired during the testing, provide a C14 date of 170 cal. BC   4 cal. AD. Although there was no evidence of an outer bank, it is postulated that one was present from the slip-lines in the ditch, and to occupy the space between it and the ring-ditch (RO034-112004-), 5m to the S.  A pit burial (diam. 0.68m; D 0.24m) containing a fill of burnt clay and charcoal beneath a deposit of burnt bone was off-centre in the interior, with a smaller spread beside it. The pit was topped with a final layer of silty clay with charcoal and burnt bone. No artefacts were recovered from the pit-burial, but it returned a C14 date of 1191-924 cal. BC, proving it to be unrelated to the enclosing ditch. Eight pieces of chert, a polishing stone and an iron object were recovered from the base of the ditch. Three phases are recognised in the ditch fill with silt present at the base. Charcoal spreads were present at the bottom as well as the articulated remains of a person with outstretched arms and the severed left foot placed between the legs. A second fill is a brown silty clay probably derived from an outer bank. A third phase was represented by a brown silty clay with charcoal concentrations which was sealed by a thin brown soil thought to be a humus. A charcoal spread E of the enclosure, and a curving slot-trench (Wth 0.5m; D 0.38m; L 5.8m plus) just to the NW cannot be stratigraphically linked with what is probably a barrow but all are probably contemporary. All the features were truncated by post-medieval furrows and a field ditch ran N-S just E of the barrows fosse. (McIlreavy 2018)   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 3 December, 2014 Amended: 24 November 2020

On a W-facing slope. In pasture, 130m E of the townland boundary with Ballynamona. An earthwork (LI041-031----) lies 90m to the NW and barrow cemeteries (LI049-072001/026-; LI041-031001/013-) lie immediately to S and N respectively. Not marked on the historic OSi maps. In 1934 Ó Ríordáin (1936, 173) recorded numerous barrows in the townland of Lissard and Ballynamona, Site a was described as The central area of this monument was about 22 [6.7m] in diameter and showed a slight rise towards the centre; the ditch was well marked and there was a slight but definite outer bank.  Excavation of the central area and trenches through the fosse and bank, revealed an urn burial in the centre which consisted of an urn [that] had been placed mouth downwards on the original ground surface over a cremated burial.(ibid.) No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached plans and photos from Ó Ríordáin.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 4 August 2021

In low-lying wet pasture, 45m NW of a townland boundary with Ballyhurst, excellent views of Knockseefin to WNW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Situated within large enclosure (LI024-049001-) and one of nine associated ring-barrows of which eight are satellite ring-barrows (LI024-049001-/02-/03-/04-/05-/06-/07-; LI024-288/308----) located outside the large enclosure. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile circular-shaped area (5.3m NW-SE; 5m NE-SW) defined by a scarp (Wth 0.8-1.15m; H 0.12-0.19m),  with fosse (Wth 3.2-3.35m; D 0.14-0.25m) and an outer bank (Wth 3.3-3.95m; int. H 0.14-0.25m; ext. H 0.05-0.15m) which are best preserved from SSW-W-N-E-SSE, levelled from SSE-S-SSW. The interior has a very slight SE-facing slope and is grass covered. See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 16 October 2020

On top of a very slight rise in gently undulating low-lying wet pasture with a ring-barrow (TS065-065003-) located c. 70m to the W and others nearby. Identified during field survey by Martin Doody. The berm (Wth 0.6m) and the second external bank (overall Wth 1.2m; Wth at top 0.6m; H 0.1m) link to the first external bank at SW and NW at being concentric with the external bank of the barrow SW-NW. Situated at the base of a NE-facing slope in gently rolling pasture with good views in all directions. Identified from aerial photography (Bruff Survey: Map 15, no 29; 4/3728). In wet, level pasture, with excellent views of Knockseefin to WNW and 45m NW of a townland boundary with Ballyhurst.  A cluster of six possible barrows (LI024-049002-/007-), with enclosure (LI024-049001-) in centre of field.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 90.03; AP 4/3678) as a ring-barrow.   Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a raised circular-shaped area (4m NE-SW; 3.5m NW-SE) defined by a scarp (Wth 1.15m; H 0.16-0.2m) with fosse (Wth 3.55-4.55m; D 0.15-0.18m) visible from NE-E-S-W-NW and a possible outer bank (Wth 4.75m; int. H 0.18m; ext. H 0.18m) visible from NE-ENE-E. The monument is open from NW-N-NE where it is truncated by a drain running NE-SW. The interior is level and grass covered. Monument is visible as a faint, roughly oval-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached photocopy of Bruff aerial photograph labelled 90.03 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick and Alison McQueen  Date of upload: 6 April 2021

In improved, wet pasture, on a natural curvilinear ridge, overlooking a low-lying level area (possible flood plain) to the N. A ring-barrow (TS066-075001-) is located c. 55m to the ENE. A circular area (dims. 3.6m N-S; 3.3m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.3-1.4m; D 0.07-0.13m) and outer bank (Wth 2.6m; int. H 0.13m; ext. H 0.1m) in the NW quadrant. A drainage channel running N-S to the immediate E accentuates the higher ground around the E-arc. The interior is grass covered and has a gentle N-facing slope. A deep land drain running ESE-WNW, flanked by a field boundary, is c. 3.5m to the S.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved wet pasture, on a natural curvilinear ridge, overlooking low-lying level area of ground (possible flood plain) to N. Identified on aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2434/5)). Circular area (dims. c. 6m N-S; 5m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.05m) S-N-SSE and outer bank (Wth 3.65m; int. H 0.05m; ext. H 0.1m) WSW-N-ENE is best defined NNE-ENE. Land drain (long axis NE-SW) has truncated exterior of fosse SSE-S. Interior has a N-facing slope in N-half and is level is S-half. Ring-barrow (TS066-075008-) is c. 55m to the WSW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 3 September 2014

Within N-sector of possible enclosure (TS066-075007-). Identified on aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2434/5). Circular area (dims. 5.2m N-S; 4.5m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 1.5-2m; D 0.1m) and possible traces of an outer bank (Wth 3.25m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1m) SW-W. Fosse is partially backfilled SE-SSE and exterior is damaged by drainage activity at NW. Interior is grass covered and generally level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 3 September 2014

In improved pasture, on a N-facing slope, slightly undulating with former water channels. Identified on aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2434/5). Circular area (dims. 5.6m N-S; 4.75m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 1.85-1.9m; D 0.1-0.15m) and possible outer bank (Wth 2.85m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.12m) N-E is best preserved at NE. Interior is grass covered and has a gentle N-facing slope.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 3 September 2014

On a slight SE-facing slope in gently undulating pasture. Ring-ditch (TS066-034----) is located 100m to the N and a ditch-barrow (TS066-157----) 50m to the NE. Circular slightly raised area (diam. 3m) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.8m) and an external earthen bank (overall Wth 2.8m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.2m). Interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a slight NW-facing slope. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 3.3m N-S; H 0.1-0.3m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 2.3-2.5m; Wth of base 1m; D 0.6-0.7m) and outer bank (Wth 4.4m; ext. H 0.1-0.2m). There is no visible entrance (max. ext. diam. 14.8m N-S). Ring-barrow (RO034-019----) is c. 100m to the SSE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Visible on aerial photographs (GSIAP: M 66-7), and situated on a gentle W-facing slope. Circular grass-covered and slightly domed platform (diam. of top 18.6m NE-SW; 17m NW-SE; diam. of base 27.5m NE-SW; 24.2m NW-SE; H 0.6-0.8m) defined by a gently rounded fosse (Wth of top 13.4-15m; Wth of base 3.5-7m; D 1-1.8m) and outer bank (Wth 3.2-5.4m; H 0.3-0.5m) which is incorporated into a flat-topped field bank (Wth of base 4.4m; Wth of top 2m; H 1.3m) E-SSW (max. ext. diam. 53.8m NE-SW; 50.4m NW-SE). There is an entrance (Wth 12.8m) in the bank at NE. Ring-barrow (RO034-103----) is c. 100m to the NNW.  See the attached aerial view taken from the ESE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In gently undulating pasture with a barrow (TS066-165001-) located 75m to the NE. Identified on an aerial photograph (Bruff 57). Circular area (diam. 3m) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarp (Wth 1.6m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4m) and an external flat-topped earthen bank (overall Wth 3.6m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1m). The interior is slightly domed and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

Situated on high ground in an upland area with extensive views; standing stone (TN020-058002) 8m to the E. A circular flat-topped mound (H 0.5m; diam. 10m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2m; ext. D 0.3-0.9m) and external bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.2-0.8m) best preserved at NW. Two large boulders protrude from the surface of the mound one in the S sector and the other in the SE.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In gently undulating pasture with a barrow (TS066-165002-) located 75m to the SW. Identified on an aerial photograph (Bruff 57). Circular area (diam. 4m) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarp (Wth 1.6m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4m) and an external flat-topped earthen bank (overall Wth 3.6m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1m). The interior is slightly domed and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In improved wet pasture, gently undulating due to former water activity. Very low profile circular area (diam. 4.5m) defined by remains of fosse (Wth 2.1m; D 0.13m), which is best defined W-NNW, and an outer bank (Wth 3.5m; int. H 0.13m; ext. H 0.05m) W-NNW and NE-E. Interior is grass covered and has a gentle S-facing slope. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2435/4). A possible ditch barrow (TS066-076001-) is c. 58m to E.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture 100m E of the townland boundary with Ballynaclogh.  Ring-barrow (LI024-229----) located 50m to E and ring-barrow (LI024-187----) 180m to S.  Not depicted on the OS maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 43(01); AP 4/3673) as a circular crop mark. Outline of monument visible as a circular shaped area defined by a ditch on OSi orthophotos 2005-2012.   See attached Google Earth orthophoto taken 18/11/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 43(01).  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  27 July 2020

In improved pasture 75m W of townland boundary with Garrydoolis. One of eight possible barrows (LI033-115001/008-) concentrated in a large field (125m N-S; 175m E-W) in the W of the townland. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 122.04; AP 7/2028) as a ring-barrow.  Faint traces of cropmark visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12. Visible as a circular-shaped area (diam. c. 8m) enclosed by a bank on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.    See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 122.07  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 15 April 2021

Marked only on the 1929 ed. of the OS 6-inch map as a small mound (diam. c. 10m), and situated on a slight rise at the crest of the N-facing slope of a broad W-E spur. This is a circular, domed and grass-covered mound (diam. 22.5m N-S; 21m E-W; H 0.25m). Geophysical survey (09R145) confirms that it was a mound (diam. c. 8m), possibly with a central pit, enclosed by a fosse (ext. diam. c. 12-15m) and outer bank (max. ext. diam. c. 25m), which may have had an entrance at SW (Barton 2009). Archaeological testing (09E0525) outside a buffer zone ((Wth c. 30m) failed to produce any related material (Morahan 2012). Moated site (RO034-070----) is c. 40m to the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the SW-facing slope of a small NW-SE spur. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 17.6m NW-SE; H 0.4-0.7m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 8.2-10.2m; Wth of base 3.4-4.5m; D 1.5m) with some reeds, and an outer grass-covered bank (Wth 5.6-6.2m; H 0.25-0.6m) with some furze (max. ext. diam. 40.5m NW-SE). There is no identifiable original entrance. The possible rath (RO034-077----) is c. 30m to the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In lush pasture, on a S-facing slope. Circular area (diam. 6m) defined by low profile fosse (Wth 1.7m; D 0.1m) and an outer bank (Wth 3m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.05m). Interior generally same level as exterior ground level. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2435/6 mono). Field boundary (long-axis NE-SW) is c. 12m to N. Ditch barrow (TS066-073001-) c. 18m to E.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level, improved pasture. Circular area (dims. 4.5m N-S; 4.2m E-W) defined by low profile fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.05m) which is waterlogged S-W-N. Remains of low profile outer bank (Wth 2.8m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.1m) best defined ENE-S-NNE. Interior level and is same height as exterior ground level. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2350 (mono) 2436/5). Drain (long axis NE-SW) c. 8.5m to N and c. 14m to W, latter along townland boundary (long axis NW-SE).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture 75m N of the townland boundary with Plaukarauka.  Ring-barrows (LI024-186/229----) located 180m to N.  Not depicted on the OS maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 42; AP 4/3673) as a circular cropmark. Outline of monument visible as a circular -shaped area (approx. diam. 12.5m) defined by a ditch on OSi orthophotos 2005-2012.    See attached Google Earth orthophoto taken 18/11/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 42.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  27 July 2020

In improved wet pasture, c. 2.2m to S of natural scarp of old water channel (long-axis c. E-W). Low profile circular area (dims. 3.25m N-S; 3m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.15m), which is best preserved SSW-NNE, and an outer bank (Wth 4.1m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.05m) SSE-WNW. Gap (basal Wth 1.25m) at NE. Interior is very low in profile and is c. 0.07m lower than exterior ground level. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2435/4). Ring-barrow and ditch barrow (TS066-076003- and TS066-076004-) are 0.9m to NE and 2m to E respectively. General area of monument is gently undulating due to former water activity.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved wet pasture, c. 1m to S of natural scarp of old water channel (long-axis c. E-W). Low profile circular area (dims. 3.35m N-S; 3.5m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.15m) which is shallow on the interior side. Possible traces of outer bank (Wth 2.85m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.03m) NE-E. Gap (basal Wth 1.2m) at SSE. Interior is very low in profile and is c. 0.07m lower than exterior ground level. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2435/4). Ring-barrow and ditch barrow (TS066-076002- and TS066-076004-) are 0.9m to SW and 1.1m to SE respectively. General area of monument is gently undulating due to former water activity.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on top of a hillock in an upland area with extensive views. A low partially destroyed mound (diam. 7.7m N-S; H 0.8m) with small hollow depressions on its surface enclosed by a poorly preserved fosse (Wth 1m; ext. D 0.7m) and outer bank (Wth 1.7m; ext. H 1-1.5m) which is totally destroyed at W. Traces of a shallow external fosse are visible from N to E.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In improved, gently undulating pasture. Circular area (dims. 4.8m N-S; 4.2m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 1.2m; D 0.1m) and remains of an outer bank (Wth 2.35m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.14m) SE-NW. Interior is slightly lower (0.04m) than exterior ground level. Wet rushy area to SE appears to be an old water channel. Land across this area has been sculpted in past by water activity and subsequently drained. Identified on an aerial photograph as a ring-ditch (OS 2435/4).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In low-lying, improved pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 75m E of a townland boundary with Ballyhurst. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Ring-barrow (LI024-267----) and a standing stone (LI024-290----) lie 110m to NNE and 120m to SE, respectively. Monument identified as a circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 161: AP 4/3677). Monument is visible as a faint, roughly circular-shaped cropmark (diam. 11m) on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 161.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 11 October 2020

On flat pasture 25m E of a N-S field drain and 125m E of the townland boundary with Ballyshoneen. The ring-barrow is 50m S of an earthwork (LI024-268----). The monument is not depicted on historic OSi maps. It is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12.  Not visible on the Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 41; AP 4/3672) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 10m) comprised of a central mound surrounded by a fosse and external bank. The ring-barrow is faintly visible on the Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018. See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 41 and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by:  Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 17 September 2020

In flat farmland, formerly part of the demesne of Castle Kelly. An overgrown circular barrow (D 46.6m ext.), in fair condition, comprising a flat central area (D 22.1m, H c. 0.5m) encircled by an internal fosse and external bank.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In rough pasture within a forest clearing 100m NW of the townland boundary with Newtown. The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 40; AP 4/3625) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 10m). The ring-barrow is not visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 40 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond ODonovan  Date of upload: 9 September 2020

On a slight E-facing slope in rolling pasture and is conjoined to a second slightly larger ring-barrow (TS058-088----) to the SSE. Circular area (diam. 4m) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6m; D 0.05m) and an external earthen bank (overall Wth 2.2m; Wth at top 1m; H 0.1m). The external bank is absent SW-NW where the line of a now removed N-S orientated field boundary abuts the W edge of the barrow. The interior slopes slightly facing E and is clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a slight E-facing slope in rolling pasture and conjoined to a second slightly smaller ring-barrow (TS058-088001-) to the NNW. Circular area (diam. 8m) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6m; D 0.05m) and an external earthen bank (overall Wth 2.2m; Wth at top 1m; H 0.1m). The external bank is absent SW-NW where the line of a now removed N-S orientated field boundary abuts the W edge of the barrow. The interior slopes slightly facing E and is clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In undulating rocky pasture, on a slight N-facing slope. A roughly circular earth and stone mound (diam. 4.5m at top; H 1.1m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth 2.8m) NW-SSE. The outer edge of the fosse is defined by an earth and stone bank (int. H 0.35m; ext. H 1.3m) NW-N and ENE-SE and by a scarp N-ENE; it is levelled elsewhere. At S, a small portion of the mound has been dug away. Moss-covered stones are strewn across the barrow which is dry and clear of overgrowth. A barrow (SL034-207002-) lies c. 30m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In low-lying rough pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 190m E of a townland boundary with Ballyhurst. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Ring-barrows (LI024-053003-/265----) lie 35m to S and 125m to NW, respectively and a standing stone (LI024-290----) lies 45m to NE. Monument identified as a subcircular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 266: AP 4/3677). Monument is not visible on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, or on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 or on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 266.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 11 October 2020

In wet, level pasture, with excellent views of Knockseefin/Pallashill to WNW. Not depicted on OS historic mapping (O'Dwyer 1964, 98). Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile semi-circular-shaped area (4.7m E-W; 3m N-S) defined by a scarp (H 0.15m) at N, truncated by a drain and wide earthen field boundary running E-W across the S half with fosse (Wth 2.95m; D 0.15m) and an external bank (int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.15m; Wth 2.55m) visible from NE-E.   A barrow (LI024-053001-) lies c. 50m to SSW and a ring-barrow (LI024-053002-) lies c. 80m to SE. A high concentration of barrows are located within a 300m radius of this monument.  Monument is not readily visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.  See attached plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI.   Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 15 July 2020

In low-lying wet pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, 50m NW of a townland boundary with Bohernagraga. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. The central of a cluster of three ring-barrows (LI024-310001-/002-/003-) which are aligned in a row running NW-SE. Visible as a circular-shaped cropmark on the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff AP 4/3673) and identified as a ring-barrow by the ASI during further analysis of the survey in 2010. Monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark (11m E-W; 9m N-S) on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthophotos and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018 and Bruff Survey image showing monument highlighted.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 17 October 2020

In low-lying wet pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, 45m NW of a townland boundary with Bohernagraga. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. The central of a cluster of three ring-barrows (LI024-310001-/002-/003-) which are aligned in a row running NW-SE. Visible as a circular-shaped cropmark on the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff AP 4/3673) and identified as a ring-barrow by the ASI during further analysis of the survey in 2010. Monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark (12m E-W; 10.6m N-S) on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthophotos and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018 and Bruff Survey image showing monument highlighted.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 16 October 2020

In low-lying wet pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, 40m NW of a townland boundary with Bohernagraga. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. The eastern most of a cluster of three ring-barrows (LI024-310001-/002-/003-) which are aligned in a row running NW-SE. Visible as a circular-shaped cropmark on the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff AP 4/3673) and identified as a ring-barrow by the ASI during further analysis of the survey in 2010. Monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped area on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012 and on Digital Globe orthophotos and is visible as a suboval-shaped cropmark (13m E-W; 9.5m N-S) on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018 and Bruff Survey image showing monument highlighted.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 16 October 2020

On a gentle E-facing slope inside the perimeter of ceremonial enclosure (RO021-042011-) at E. Circular grass-covered hollow (diam. c. 8m; max. D 0.4m at W). Herity (1983, 132) suggests that this is a ring-barrow, but Waddell (1983, 35) regards it as a quarry pit. (Waddell 2009, 57)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the crest of a short NE-SW ridge (L c. 100m; Wth c. 30m; H c. 3-4m). D-shaped grass-covered mound (dims of base 5.5m N-S; c. 3m E-W; H 0.3m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top c. 4m; max. D 0.3m) which is most clearly seen at NE and SW (max. ext. dim. 13.3m NE-SW), but at SE and NW it merges into the slope of the ridge. Souterrain (RO021-042003-) is c. 30m to the SW and the segment of road (RO021-042006-) is c. 140m to the SE. Little Rathbeg (RO022-056016-) is c. 250m to the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In wet, level pasture, with excellent views of Knockseefin/Pallashill to WNW. Not depicted on OS historic mapping (O'Dwyer 1964, 96-8). Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile, circular-shaped area (4.6m N-S; 4.1m E-W) defined by an inner fosse (Wth 2.05-2.75m; D 0.14m) well preserved from WSW-W-N-E-S-SSW and external bank (int. H 0.14m; ext. H 0.2-0.23m; Wth 2.5-2.6m) best preserved from NE-E-S-W-NW, merges with a raised area adjoining the exterior from NW-N-NE.  A linear mound (Wth 3.5m; H 0.2m) running NNW-SSE lies c. 5.5m to W. A barrow (LI024-053001-) and a possible barrow (LI024-053003-) lie c. 50m and c. 80m to SW and SE respectively. A high concentration of barrows are located within a 300m radius of this monument.  Monument is not clearly visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.  See attached plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI.   Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 15 July 2020

Visible as a circular feature on aerial photograph (OS: 2/4212), and situated towards the bottom of the N facing slope of a WNW-ESE ridge. Circular grass-covered area (int. diam. 12.2m N-S) defined by a slight bank (Wth c. 3m; max. H 0.1m) N-E-SW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In rough, wet pasture, 12m SE of a field boundary and 70m SW of a stream. Ditch-barrows (LI024-319/320/318----) lie 185m to N, 200m to NE and 190m to NE, respectively. Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Monument identified as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 149: AP 4/3677). Monument is visible as an oval-shaped cropmark (approx. dim. 19m NE-SW; 15m NW-SE) on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13.  Vague traces of a cropmark are visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018. See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 149.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 24 July 2020

On poorly drained reclaimed grassland, 10m NW of a small stream that flows NE into the Reask River. Enclosure (LI024-203----) located 60m to SW. The site is not depicted on historic OSi maps nor is it visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 16.2; AP 4/3625) as a circular ring-barrow. The ring-barrow is not visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 16.2 and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 15 September 2020

In wet level terrain under pasture in a stud farm. This possible ring-barrow was identified on an aerial photograph (Bruff aerial survey ref. 2029) (Doody 1993, 175). There is no visible trace of this monument above ground. It may have been disturbed by a field drain which runs NE-SW across this portion of the field.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

In low-lying, gently undulating, marshy terrain, in rough pasture, at the base of a hillock which is surmounted by a standing stone (TS066-198----), visible 100m to the N. A stream runs roughly N-S c. 120m to the W. There is a stepped barrow (TS066-122----) 80m to the S and a ditch barrow (TS066-166----) 184m to the N. This monument was identified on an aerial photograph (Air Corps 249/16, 02/09/1959). A circular, slightly raised mound (diam. 6.5m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.4-1.6m; D 0.08-0.14m) and a poorly preserved outer bank (int. H 0.1-0.15m; ext. H 0.8-0.1m; Wth 1.2-1.9m at crest, 1.4-2.3m at base).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 March 2013

On a knoll towards the N edge of the Rathcroghan plateau, and enclosed within a farmyard. Described as an earthen mound (diam. c. 7m; H c. 0.9m) separated by a fosse from an earthen bank (Wth c. 1.8m) with traces of an outer fosse (max. ext. diam. c. 18m) (Knox 1911, 234-5). It is now a circular scrub-covered mound (diam. c. 14m E-W; c. 13m N-S; H c. 1m) confined by silage pits and animal pens excavated into the ground around it to the W and N (D c. 1.5m) and with a laneway to the E. Rathmore (RO022-056-017-) is c. 160m to the ENE, and ring-barrow (RO021-042004-) is c. 250m to the W. (Herity 1983, 130; 1984, 134 Moneylea 2; Waddell 1983, 37, No. 27)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the summit of a gentle hillock in gently undulating terrain, in pasture. A stream runs E-W c. 70m to the N. Identified as a circular enclosure on aerial photograph (Bruff aerial survey ref. 2090) (Doody 1993, 178). Appears to be located immediately NE of a quarry or hillock on aerial photograph (ibid.). A very subtle monument consisting of a roughly circular slightly raised mound (diam. 9m N-S; 8.8m E-W; H 0.1-0.14m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.6-1.9m; D 0.07-0.1m) and outer bank (Wth 1.4m crest; 2.4m base; ext. H 0.1m). Some years ago the field had been levelled off and the monument appears to have been damaged by this activity.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 14 March 2013

In improved pasture, on a S-facing slope. A ditch barrow (TS066-027002-) is located c. 2m to the SE. Identified as a circular feature on an aerial photograph (OS 2397/8) during fieldwork (ASI 2009). An oval area (dims. 4.5m N-S; 5.7m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.05m) which is truncated by old land drain (long-axis NW-SE) across the SSW-arc. There are the possible remains of an outer bank (Wth 4.35m; int. H 0.05m; ext. H 0.12m) at W and a poorly drained area to the SW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level improved pasture. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but archaeological excavation here in 1935 revealed a circular ring-barrow (diam. c. 5m) defined by a fosse and outer bank (Ó Ríordáin 1936, 183-4). No burials were found. The excavation 'revealed three peculiar pockets in the original ground-surface filled with dark humified soil. Each about 2 feet [0.6m] in length and consisted of a circular part, 6-inches in diameter, and a long narrow portion about 3-inches [0.07m] in width, this latter part being filled with material somewhat lighter in colour because less humified. The maximum depth of these pockets was only 2½-inches [0.06m]. Their purpose is not clear; one might suggest their having contained deposits of cremated remains that had been completely dissolved by soil-acids, but this is only surmise (ibid. 184). No surface trace now visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 14 October 2015

On a gentle S-facing slope of Rathcroghan plateau. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. of base 12.7m N-S; diam. of top 8.3m N-S; H 0.2m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 4.6-6.2m; D 0.4m) and outer bank (Wth 3.5-3.7m; ext. H 0.3-0.4m), which is missing W-NW and which has a stone-marked entrance (Wth 1.5m) at NE (max. ext. diam. 23.4m N-S). Earthwork (RO022-057028-) is c. 120m to the SE. (Knox 1914a, 35 Ring No. 2; Herity 1983, 132; 1984, 113, Glenballythomas 15; Waddell 1983, 33, No. 22; 1988, 10)  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 473  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level, poorly drained area of improved pasture, at base of SE-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 5.8m N-S; 6.0m E-W) defined by remains of a shallow fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.12m) and the remains of outer bank (Wth at top 1.6m; total Wth 4.5m; int. H 0.12m; ext. H 0.14m) WSW-NNE. The fosse is waterlogged SSW-SE. Interior is level and same height as exterior ground level. Identified as a barrow during a survey by Eoin Grogan.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, on N-facing slope, 87m SE of Reask River which marks townland boundary with Brackyle and 105m E of townland boundary with Knockballyfookeen. A possible enclosure (LI024-170----) lies 70m to NE, three barrows (LI024-058001/002-; LI024-292----/293----),  enclosure (LI024-058004-) and earthwork (LI024-058002-) lie 264m to SE. The westernmost ring-barrow of a cluster of five ring-barrows (LI024-171002-/005-).  Identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 106 (1); AP 4/3676) as a small circular cropmark of a possible ring-barrow. Faint trace of cropmark visible on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, not visible on the Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing cropmark labelled Bruff 106(1)  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 22 July 2020

In pasture, on N-facing slope, 92m SE of Reask River which marks townland boundary with Brackyle and 123m E of townland boundary with Knockballyfookeen. A possible enclosure (LI024-170----) lies 70m to NE, three barrows (LI024-058001-; LI024-292/293-----),  enclosure (LI024-058004-) and earthwork (LI024-058002-) lie 247m to SE. . Located in the SE corner of a cluster of five ring-barrows (LI024-171001/005-). Identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 106 (3); AP 4/3676) as a small circular cropmark of a possible ring-barrow. Monument not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing cropmark labelled Bruff 106(3)  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 22 July 2020

In pasture, on N-facing slope, 92m SE of Reask River which marks townland boundary with Brackyle and 123m E of townland boundary with Knockballyfookeen. A possible enclosure (LI024-170----) lies 70m to NE, three barrows (LI024-058001-; LI024-292/293-----),  enclosure (LI024-058004-) and earthwork (LI024-058002-) lie 247m to SE. Located northeast in a cluster of five ring-barrows (LI024-171001/171005-). In pasture, on N-facing slope, 92m SE of Reask River which marks townland boundary with Brackyle and 123m E of townland boundary with Knockballyfookeen. In pasture, on N-facing slope, 92m SE of Reask River which marks townland boundary with Brackyle and 123m E of townland boundary with Knockballyfookeen. Identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 106 (5); AP 4/3676) as a small circular cropmark of a possible ring-barrow.
