In rough pasture, overlooking a poorly drained area to the ESE. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (9 December 2008). Conjoined ditch barrows (TS066-184002- and TS066-184003-) are located c. 7m to the SE and a ditch barrow (TS066-183002-) is located c. 52m to the ENE. A circular area (dims. 3.15m N-S; 3.3m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.03m), accentuated by wild irises in the S quadrant, with the remains of a possible outer bank (Wth 2.95m; int. H 0.14m; ext. H 0.04m) W-S-SE. The interior is 0.07m lower in height than the external ground level. The remains of a poorly defined mound of similar size adjoin to the NW indicating that this may have been a conjoined barrow.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

On a slight N-S ridge at the highest point of the Rathcroghan plateau. Subcircular grass-covered mound (dims 17.3m N-S; 12.9m E-W; H 1.2-1.5m) defined by a berm (Wth 3.4m at N to 6m at E; H 0.7m at S to 1.4m at N). This is surrounded by another berm (Wth 2.3-3.3m; H 0.1m at E to 0.7m at W), with an outer bank (Wth 2m; H 0.1-0.2m) SE-SW (max. ext. dims 37.7m N-S; 37.3m E-W). A quarry damages the perimeter at NW (total H 1.8m at S to 3.6m at N). (Knox 1911, 234-5; Herity 1983, 130; 1988, 134, Toberrory 11; Waddell 1983, 35; 1988, 12, No. 25)  Geophysical survey confirmed that the berms are shallow fosses with outer banks, and that there may be a third outer fosse. However, no evidence of internal structures was recovered, apart from what may have been intense burning at the summit of the mound. Archaeological testing (08E0867) on a relict field bank with a ditches on the N side c. 120m to the NW produced no conclusive results but suggests that the field system may be post-medieval in date (McCarthy 2012a). Archaeological monitoring (E004965) of the removal of farm buildings and the restoration of grass c. 170m to the SE produced no related material (Murphy 2019; excavations.ie 2019:594). (Waddell et al. 2009, 104-112)  See the attached images taken from the N in Summer (001) and Winter (005), and an aerial image taken from the NE (006).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 5 February, 2013 Amended: 29 January, 2020; 28 October 2020  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 21/1934), and is now a National Monument in state ownership: No. 294.

On the crest of a low WNW-ESE ridge. Slightly raised, circular, grass-covered area (diam. 17m N-S; 16.7m E-W; H 0.1-0.2m) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 2.6-3.5m; H 0.3-0.45m). There is no visible fosse or identifiable original entrance (ext. diam. c. 22m). Barrow (RO035-067001-) is 8m to the SW.  See the attached image taken from the N with (RO035-067001-) in the right background.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In improved pasture, on a N-facing slope with gentle undulations. Circular area (dims. 6.25m N-S; 6.6m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 1m; H 0.05m), fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.05m) which is best preserved SW-N-E-SSE and the remains of possible outer bank (Wth 4.2m; int. H 0.12m; ext. H 0.13m) N-E. Identified as a barrow on Bruff 27 aerial photograph survey.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a SE slight facing slope in gently undulating pasture. Monument identified during field inspection of adjacent ditch-barrow (TS066-093----) located 8m to the WNW. Circular area (diam. 5m) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6m) and traces of an external earthen bank (overall Wth 1.6m). Traces of the external bank enclose the barrow NW-NE and SE-SW with no visible traces elsewhere at ground level. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

On top of level surface of a slight rise, on the floor of a wide gently sloping NE-SW orientated valley, in level low-lying wet pasture. This ring-barrow is conjoined to a second ring-barrow (TS058-070002-) to the ESE. An embanked enclosure (TS058-046----) is located 18m to the NE, the standing stone (TS058-023004-) at Longstone is visible 1.5km to the NNE with a mound-barrow (TS058-047----) visible 750m to the SE. Circular area (diam. 5.5m) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.05-0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6m) and an external earthen bank (overall Wth 1m; int. H 0.05-0.1m). The external bank is incorporated into the external bank of a slightly smaller ring-barrow (TS058-070001-) E-ESE. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On top of level surface of a slight rise, on the floor of a wide gently sloping NE-SW orientated valley, in level low-lying wet pasture. This ring-barrow is conjoined to a second ring-barrow (TS058-070001-) to the ESE. An embanked enclosure (TS058-046----) is located 18m to the NE, the standing stone (TS058-023004-) at Longstone is visible 1.5km to the NNE with a mound-barrow (TS058-047----) visible 750m to the SE. Circular area (diam. 2.4m) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.15m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.7m) and an external earthen bank (overall Wth 2.8m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.05m). The external bank is incorporated into the external bank of a slightly smaller ring-barrow (TS058-070001-) WSW-WNW. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

At the N-facing crest of an E-W drumlin ridge. Oval flat-topped and grass-covered mound (dims of top 14m NE-SW; 10.4m NW-SE; dims of base 17m NW-SW; 14.4m NW-SE; H 0.7m at SW to 1.4m generally) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 6.7-7.3m; Wth of base 3.5-4.5m; D 0.3-0.4m) and outer bank (Wth 1m at SW to 3.4m at NW; ext. H 0.2-0.6m) which is incorporated into a field bank (Wth 4.4-5.4m; int. H 1.2-1.8m; ext. H 0.5-0.8m) NE-S (max. ext. dims 32.7m N-S; 29m E-W). There is an entrance (Wth 3.5m) in the bank at S. Archaeological testing (05E0385) c. 130m to the SW failed to produce any related material (Read, C. 2008h).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010
The cropmark of a possible ringbarrow is evident on Google Earth aerial photographs, at this location.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 4 September 2013

On a N-facing slope, in rough, wet pasture, 120m S of the Reask River, which also marks a townland boundary with Brackyle. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. One of two satellite ring-barrows (LI024-292/293----) which are situated 5m to N of a large barrow (LI024-058001-). Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile circular-shaped area (2.2m NE-SW; 1.5m NW-SE) defined by a scarp (Wth 1.5-1.6m; H 0.15-0.35m) and fosse (Wth 3.65-5.1m; D 0.18-0.45m) which are traceable from NW-N-E-SE. A land drain running NNE-SSW extends from the fosse at NNE. Monument is not visible on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, or on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013, or on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 14 October 2020

On a N-facing slope, in rough, wet pasture, 120m S of the Reask River, which also marks a townland boundary with Brackyle. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. One of two satellite ring-barrows (LI024-292/293----) which are situated 5m to N of a large barrow (LI024-058001-). Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile circular-shaped area (4.75m N-S; 4.4m E-W) defined by a scarp (Wth 0.7-0.95m; H 0.15-0.17m), fosse (Wth 2.7-2.9m; D 0.08-0.2m) and an outer bank (Wth 2.35-2.9m; int. H 0.08-0.2m; ext. H 0.14-0.15m) which are present from NE-E-S-W-N and are obscured by vegetation from N-NNE-NE. The interior is level and clear of vegetation. Monument is visible as a faint, roughly circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 14 October 2020

In gently undulating pasture, at S edge of a poorly drained area. Identified on Bruff Survey aerial photograph (ref. 2133; Bruff 48). Circular area (dims. 5.3m N-S; 5.75m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.1m) and remains of an outer bank (Wth 3.6m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.18m) NW-N-E and a naturally undulating area defines monument SSE-W. Breaks (Wth c. 3m) in bank at WNW and ESE. Interior slopes downwards to NE with prevalent slope. Shallow drain (long-axis c. NNE-SSW) to immediate E and W. A ringfort (TS066-123----) lies c. 6-8m to SSW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

On a S-facing slope of Rathcroghan plateau with slight N-S ridges to the E and W. Visible on an aerial photograph and described as a small mound (diam. c. 5m) (SMR file), it is not visible at ground level in pasture. Ring-barrow (RO022-057075-) is c. 20m to the SSE, and rath (RO022-057022-) is c. 75m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the Rathcroghan plateau, c. 60m SE of Rathcroghan mound (RO022-057010-) and within ceremonial enclosure (RO022-056012-). It is also on the line of the roadway (RO022-057021-). Known only from aerial photographs and described as c. 6-7m in diameter (Waddell, 1983, 29, No. 6). Ring-barrow (RO022-057016-) is just to the E, and barrow (RO022-056019-) is c. 60m to the SE. It is not visible at ground level. (Herity 1983, 130; 1988, 131, Glenballythomas 5)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a S-facing slope of Rathcroghan plateau with slight N-S ridges to the E and W. Visible on an aerial photograph and described as a small mound (diam. c. 3m) (SMR file). It is not visible at ground level in pasture. Ring-barrow (RO022-057074-) is c. 20m to the NNW, and ring-barrow (RO022-057076-) is c. 10m to the SSE. Rath (RO022-057022-) is c. 90m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a S-facing slope of Rathcroghan plateau with slight N-S ridges to the E and W. Visible on an aerial photograph and described as a small mound (diam. c. 3m) (SMR file). It is not visible at ground level in pasture. Ring-barrow (RO022-057075-) is c. 10m to the NNW, and rath (RO022-057022-) is c. 110m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the Rathcroghan plateau, c. 60m SE of Rathcroghan mound (RO022-057010-) and within the ceremonial enclosure (RO022-056012-). It is also on the line of the roadway (RO022-057021-). Known only from aerial photographs and described as c. 6-7m in diameter (Waddell, 1983, 29, No. 7). Ring-barrow (RO022-057015-) is just to the W, and barrow (RO022-056019-) is c. 40m to the S. It is not visible at ground level. (Herity 1983, 130; 1988, 131, Glenballythomas 6)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a rise of the Rathcroghan plateau. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 31.5m N-S; 27.6m E-W) sloping down to the N and defined by a scarp (H 0.3m at S to 1m at N), with a slight bank (Wth 5m; int. H 0.1m; ext H 0.6m) on the perimeter at N. There is a slight mound (diam. c. 6m; max. H 0.4m) at the centre from which modern field walls run W and S. Knox (1914a, 29) describes it as a cashel (No. 2), while Waddell (1983, 29, No. 11) and Herity (1983, 130; 1988, 134, Glenballythomas 10) regard it as a ring-barrow. Barrow (RO022-056017-) is c. 70m to the WNW and barrow (RO022-056019-) is c. 110m to the N. Rath (RO022-056022-) is c. 60m to the SSW.  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 473  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In wet pasture with Reask River 65m to NE, which forms the townland boundary with Milltown. Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as no surface remains visible of site listed by O'Dwyer (1958-61, 96-8). There is a slight rise in the field at this point with a gentle depression. A linear ridge (Wth 3m; H 0.2m) running NE-SW lies to W.  Monument is not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.  The precise location of this monument is uncertain as two different locations are recorded for this same monument by Eoin Grogan in his thesis and by Michael O'Dwyer.See attached sketch plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI. Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 21 July 2020

At the S edge of the Rathcroghan plateau. Reputed to be the burial place of Daithaí, nephew of Niall of the Nine Hostages and the last of the early mythological High Kings of Ireland (Gormley 1989, 9, 10). Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 18m E-W; 16.4m N-S; H 0.2m at N to 1.3m at W) separated by a fosse (at S: Wth of top 9m) from an outer bank (at S: Wth 7m; int. H 1.3m; ext. H 0.9m) E-W, which is incorporated into a field bank (Wth 2m; H 1m) elsewhere (max. ext. diam. 34m E-W; 33m N-S). There are breaks in the bank at W (Wth 5.2m) and ESE (Wth 4.2m). Standing stone (RO022-057047-) is on the summit. (Knox, 1914a, 36-7; Herity 1983, 131; 1984, 131, Glenballythomas 27; Waddell 1983, 31-2, No. 14; 1988, 10-12, No. 14)  It was investigated in 1913, and limited excavation in 1981 confirmed that it is a natural gravel ridge which was moulded into its present form. The outer bank is artificial, and charcoal from its lower levels provided C14 dates of 1940 +- 70 BP (GrN 11429) and 2120+-25 BP (GrN 11430). The original fosse (Wth of top 3m; Wth of base 0.6m; ext. D 0.5m) was filled at the bottom with homogeneous stone-free clay, perhaps soon after its completion. Finds included waste flint and chert, a medieval stickpin and post-medieval pottery. (Waddell 1987-8; Waddell 1988, 10-2; Kavanagh 2013)  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 473  See the attached image taken from the ESE (007) and the aerial image of the barrow taken from the NE (006).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the Rathcroghan plateau, c. 70m E of Rathcroghan mound (RO022-057010-) and centrally placed between the arms of the avenue (RO022-057093-). Marked as a circular embanked enclosure (diam. c. 20m) on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, it is described as a circular mound (diam. c. 13.5m) defined by a fosse (Wth c. 1m) with an outer bank (Wth c. 1.8m) and outer fosse (Wth c. 1.8m) (Knox 1914a, 14, ring No. 1).  It is visible now as a slight depression (diam. c. 21m). Geophysical survey confirms that it has two fosses (max. ext. diam. c. 26m) but appears to have causeways across them at WNW and ESE and there may be a central pit (diam. c. 4m). It appears to post-date ring-barrow (RO022-057013-), which is immediately to the N as its outer defining feature is slightly flattened at N. (Waddell et al. 2009, 151-2, 193). (Herity 1983, 130; 1988, 129, Tobberrory 15; Waddell 1983, 29, No. 4)  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 294.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the Rathcroghan plateau, c. 70m E of Rathcroghan mound (RO022-057010-) and centrally placed between the arms of the avenue (RO022-057093-). Circular area (int. diam. 7m) defined by a parch mark (Wth 2m) visible in drought conditions. Geophysical survey confirms that it has a fosse and external bank (max. ext. diam. c. 12m), and probably pre-dates ring-barrow (RO022-057014-) which is immediately to the S (Waddell et al. 2009, 151-2, 193). (Herity 1983, 130; 1988, 129, Toberrory 16; Waddell 1983, 29, No. 5)  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 294.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In rough, level pasture deeply poached by cattle. Circular area (dims. 3.1m N-S; 3.3m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.1m) which is waterlogged W-N. Remains of external bank (Wth 3.55m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.12m) best defined N-S-NW. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2397/6 and 2348 mono). Ditch barrow (TS066-041007-) c. 4.5m to ESE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011
The cropmark of a possible ringbarrow is evident on Google Earth aerial photographs, at this location.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 4 September 2013

At the N end of a slight N-S ridge on the N-facing slope of Rathcroghan ridge. Circular grass-covered and flat-topped mound (diam. of base 9m E-W; 8.6m N-S; diam. of top 2.2m E-W; 2.6m N-S; H 1.5-1.8m) separated by a fosse (Wth of base 2.5m) from an earthen bank (Wth 3.2-5m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.6-1.2m) SE-W. The bank has been levelled into the fosse to create a berm (Wth 4.2m) defined by a scarp (H 0.7-1m) W-N-SE (max. ext. diam. 22.4m E-W). Ditch-barrow (RO022-056007-) is c. 30m to the S. (Knox 1914, 40-1; Herity 1983, 131; 1984, 131, Grallagh 1; Waddell 1983, 37, No. 32; Waddell 1988, 10)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a slight N-facing slope in gently undulating wet pasture with another two barrows (TS058-071001- and TS058-071002-) located 100m to the NW. Circular area (diam. 6m) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.4m; H 0.05-0.1m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4m) and an external earthen bank (overall Wth 2.4m; H 0.05). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On level area of improved pasture. Circular area (dims. 6m N-S; 5.4m E-W) defined by distinctive fosse (Wth 1.95m; D 0.1m) abutting conjoined ditch barrow (TS066-099001-) to WSW. Possible traces of a levelled bank (Wth 2.9m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.15m) best preserved WNW-N and NE-ENE and levelled elsewhere. Interior generally level and slightly lower than exterior ground level. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2436/7 mono).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a rise towards the top of the NE-facing slope of Rathcroghan ridge. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 19.5m NE-SW; 17.3m NW-SE; H 0.1-0.8m) which slopes down to the E. It is bisected by a NE-SW bank of the field system (RO022-057003-), and is barely visible SE of this feature. The platform is surrounded by a berm (Wth 4.2-4.6m), with an outer bank (Wth 3m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.2m) SW-NW. (Herity 1983, 130; 1988, 134, Toberrory 10; Waddell 1983, 39, No. 38)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In improved pasture, on a plateau of a N-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 4m N-S; 4m E-W) defined by distinctive fosse (Wth 2.45m; D 0.18m) with traces of possible outer bank (Wth 4.05m; int. H 0.18m; ext. H 0.05m) best preserved NW-NNE and E-WSW. Interior is slightly dome shaped sloping down gently all around to fosse. Perimeter of interior is c. 0.08m below exterior ground level, but crown in centre of dome shaped interior is same height as exterior ground level. visible on aerial photograph (ref. OS 2437/6) as a roughly circular enclosure.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On the crest of a low WNW-ESE ridge. Described (Gannon 1972) as a slightly domed circular area defined by a degraded fosse and outer bank (diam. c. 35m N-S). It is not now visible at ground level in reclaimed pasture.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture, on a low rise of an otherwise NE-facing slope; overlooking poorly drained land to E. Circular area (dims. 4m N-S; 3.9m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 0.7m; H 0.1m) and a fosse (Wth 1.6-2.75m; D 0.1-0.15m). Slight trace of levelled outer bank best defined NE-ESE and traceable NW-E-SW. Monument cut into hillslope SW-W-NW to level the interior which has a slight NE-facing slope. Identified on aerial photographs (OS 2396/7 and 2347/8) as a ring-ditch. Ditch-barrows (TS066-031001- and TS066-031002-) are c. 73m and c. 66m to SE respectively. Cork-Limerick Junction railway line is c. 100m to SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On top of the level summit of a prominent hill with panoramic views in all directions, abutting the inner SSE side of an enclosure (TS058-023002-) containing a multi-period. A ditch-barrow (TS058-023005-) is located 8m to the NW and a second ditch-barrow (TS058-023007-) is 4m to the W. A standing stone (TS058-079----) is visible 800m to the NE; a large barrow 1.5km to the WSW and a mound-barrow (TS058-047----) 1.8km to the S. The enclosing elements are in good condition with crisp breaks of slope and little livestock damage. The ring-barrow is, however, becoming engulfed with gorse making access difficult. It consists of a circular area (diam. 8m) defined by a scarped edge (Wth 1m; H 0.4-0.5m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.4m) and an external earthen bank (overall Wth 3.6-4m; int. H 0.9m; ext. H 0.15m). The scarped edge, fosse and external bank enclose the monument from SSW to NW and from NNE to SE and has a consistent regular profile. From NW to NNE the fosse and external bank are absent and the edge of the monument is defined by fosse of the neighbouring bowl-barrow (TS058-028003-). From SE to SW the fosse and external bank are absent and the edge is defined by fosse of the large enclosure (TS058-028002-). The interior is level, dry and clear of overgrowth but the fosse and external bank are densely overgrown with gorse.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Visible as a circular feature on aerial photographs (CUCAP AHN 2-7), and situated towards the top of the S-facing slope of the NE summit of a NE-SW ridge. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 6.5m; H 0.05-0.1m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 4.5m) and outer bank (Wth 3.7m; H 0.2m) with a second external fosse (Wth of top 3.5m; D 0.1-0.2m) and a second external bank (Wth 3.3m; H 0.1m), all of which only survive S-W. It is now incorporated into a golfing tee, and the rath (RO006-118004-) is c. 30m to the W while barrow (RO006-118006-) is c. 80m to the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Within an enclosure (TS058-042005-) in the SW quadrant. The enclosure is located near the base of a slight N-facing slope in low-lying improved pasture. It is situated at the SE edge of a relic field system (TS058-042001-) with an enclosure (TS058-042003-) and ring-barrow (TS058-042004-) located 10m to the NW. Ovoid area (dims. 7.5m E-W; 4m N-S) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 0.6m; H 0.15-0.2m) with a shallow fosse (Wth at base 0.6m) and an external earthen bank (overall Wth 1.4-1.9m; Wth at top 0.6-1.10m; int. H 0.15-0.3m; ext H 0.15m). From NE-SE the edge of the enclosing elements have been removed by a by a SSE-WNW flowing drain. From SE-SW the external bank overlies the scarp defining the enclosure within which the ring-barrow is located. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 7 October 2015

In improved pasture on low rise at NNW-edge of old sinuous water channel. Circular area (dims. 6.5m N-S; 7m E-W) defined by very distinctive fosse (basal Wth 0.5-0.9m; overall Wth 3.5-3.7m; D 0.1-0.4m) and remains of an indistinct levelled external bank (Wth 3.6-4.2m; int. H 0.25-0.5m; ext. H 0.1-0.15m) S-ESE. Interior generally level in centre and falling gently to fosse around its perimeter. In general, this monument is distinctively saucer shaped. Identified on aerial photograph (251/20, 251/21).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011
The cropmark of a possible ringbarrow is evident on Google Earth aerial photographs, at this location.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 4 September 2013

Within enclosure (TS066-047001-), on W-edge of scarp. A sub-circular area (dims. 5.25m N-S; 7m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.15m) and remains of a low bank (Wth 2.95m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.1m) NW-N-E-S-SW and potentially disturbed SW-W-NW by cattle erosion on scarp of main enclosure.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a slight rise at the E edge of the Rathcroghan plateau. Described as a central mound (diam. c. 11m) surrounded by a berm (Wth c. 3.5m) and outer bank (Wth c. 1.8m; H c. 0.75m) (Knox, 1914, 35, ring No. 3). It is visible as a slight grass-covered depression (diam. 23.7m N-S; 22m E-W) defined by a slight bank (Wth c. 4m - c. 7m; int. H 0.1m; max. ext. H 0.4m) E-NW, and a scarp (max. H 0.3m) down to the centre elsewhere. (Herity 1983, 131; 1984, 131, Glenballythomas 12; Waddell 1983, 41, No. 48)  This is a National Monument in state ownership: No. 473  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level, poorly drained pasture, on a low natural rise. Circular area (diam. 6m) defined by remains of low profile fosse (Wth 1.35m; D 0.05m). Remains of low bank (Wth 2.75m; int. H 0.05m; ext. H 0.2m) WSW-N-ESE. Interior slopes down to W and has a slight depression within centre. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2347 mono).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011
The cropmark of a possible ringbarrow is evident on Google Earth aerial photographs, at this location.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 4 September 2013

In pasture, on S-facing slope. Hachured on 1842 OS 6-inch map as circular enclosure (diam. c. 15m). Roughly circular area (diam. 9.7m) enclosed by shallow fosse (D 0.26m).   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

In improved level pasture, on a low rise of a gently undulating field. Identified on aerial photograph (Ordnance Survey 2396/7). Circular area (dims. 8m N-S; 7.5m E-W) defined by remains of shallow fosse (basal Wth 1.0m; overall Wth 2.4m; D 0.1m) and levelled external bank (Wth 3.9m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.15m) best defined NNE-ENE. Interior level in centre and falling gently to shallow fosse.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 3 September 2014

In pasture, on a gentle SE-facing slope. Semi-circular area (dims. 20m ENE-WSW; 9m WNW-ESE) defined by curvilinear scarp (Wth 3.2m; H 0.55m) E-SW, an inner fosse (basal Wth 2.15m; overall Wth 7.2m; D 0.4m) E-SW and intervening bank (int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.5m; Wth 6.35m) E-SW and an outer fosse (basal Wth 1.5m; overall Wth 5.55m; D 0.3m) E-SW and outer bank (int H 0.2m; ext. H 0.3m; Wth 5.7m) E-SW, has gap (Wth 6m) at SSE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, on a gentle SE-facing slope, c. 3m to S of ring-barrow (TS066-101001-). Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (25 November 2008). An oval area (dims. 22m NW-SE; 18m NE-SW) bisected by an estate ditch and retaining wall running NW-SE off-centre to the SW. The interior is defined by a shallow waterlogged fosse (basal Wth 2.5m; overall Wth 5.25m; D 0.1m) all around except where truncated by a ditch. There are two mature trees within the monument on the SW side of the field boundary. The monument SW of the field boundary is not visible at ground level where it appears to have been transected by a shallow drain (basal Wth 4.4m; overall Wth 7.85m; D 0.25m) running NW-SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

On flat pasture, 200m ESE of enclosure (LI024-209----) and 330m SE of the townland boundary with Newtown North. The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 18; AP 4/3622) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 17m) and appears to be characterised by a central low mound defined by a fosse (Wth 2m), with an external bank (Wth 3m). The ring-barrow is visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 18 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond ODonovan  Date of upload: 14 September 2020
In level pasture. Circular area (9m NNE-SSW; 8.8m NNW-SSE) enclosed by fosse (D 0.4m); external bank (H 0.2m) SW-
column13: SSW. Entrance with causeway (Wth 2m) across fosse to SSW. Field clearance stones scattered across site. (CASAP)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 2: East and South Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1994). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

column10: In improved pasture on a gentle W-facing slope of a low rise, overlooking wet area N-E. Circular area (dims. 6.2m N-S; 6m E-W) defined by remains of low profile fosse (basal Wth 0.7m; overall Wth 2.8m; D 0.15m). Remains of outer bank (Wth 3.1m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.05m) W-SE. Interior slopes down gently to W with prevalent slope. Interior is c. 0.12m lower than exterior ground level on the E-side as monument is cut slightly into hillslope here. Identified as a ring-ditch on an aerial photograph (OS 2396 mono).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a W-facing slope. Circular overgrown platform (diam. c. 8m; H 0.6m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top c. 4m) and earthen bank (Wth 5-6m; int. H 0.6-0.8m; ext. H 1.5m). A flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top c. 5.5m) and middle bank (Wth 4m; int. H 1m) are separated by a second fosse (Wth of top 5.5m; D 0.15m) from a third outer bank (Wth 5m. int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.2-0.45m). The monument has been truncated at E and W by NW-SE roads, and the overgrown outer features only survive W-N and E-S (max. ext. diam. c. 65m NW-SE). Barrows (RO006-124002-) and (RO006-124003-) are immediately outside the perimeter to the NW and N. (Knox 1914b, 39-40)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In wet pasture, on slight N-facing slope.  Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as an oval-shaped area (24m N-S; 21m E-W) defined by an inner fosse, an outer bank, an outer fosse and the possible remains of a second outer bank with possible entrance (overall Wth 6m; base Wth 2m) at NNE.   The inner fosse (Wth 10.25m; D 0.3m) is best defined from SW-W and from NNE-ENE. The remains of an outer bank (Wth 11.25m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.75m) are visible from SW-W-N-NE and appear to be truncated by a curvilinear drain and field boundary from ENE-E-S-SW.  An outer fosse (Wth 8.25m; D 0.2m) is visible from SW-W-N-NE. The possible remains of a second outer bank are visible from NNW-N-NNE. The interior is grass covered and slightly uneven. A shallow drainage channel extends from the monument at NE in a northerly direction. The monument is respected by a field boundary from ENE-E-S-SW, which also forms a townland boundary from SE-S-SW.  Monument is visible as a partially tree-lined earthwork on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.  See attached sketch plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 17 July 2020

In improved pasture, on a very gentle W-facing slope in undulating field, on higher ground flanking the E and SE side of a former lake, which has been dry since drainage activities took place in the 1870s/1880s. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (28 November 2008). A ditch barrow and ring-barrow (TS066-179----; TS066-180----) are located 9m and c. 56m to SSW and SW respectively. A circular area (dims. 4.6m N-S; 5.0m E-W) defined by a distinctive fosse (basal Wth 1.15m; overall Wth 2.9m; D 0.15m) and an outer bank (Wth 4.4m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.2m) best defined SW-N-E. The interior is generally level and sloping down gently around the perimeter to the fosse.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In pasture. A possible ring-barrow (diam. c. 13m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 18 November 2018) by Jean-Charles Caillère. Two conjoined possible ring-barrows (TS066-218---- and TS066-219----) are located c. 22m to the NE.  See attached photograph: TS066-217----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (18 November 2018)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 8 January 2020

In pasture. A possible ring-barrow (diam. c. 6m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 18 November 2018) by Jean-Charles Caillère. It is conjoined on its E side with another possible ring-barrow (TS066-219----). Another possible ring-barrow (TS066-217----) is located c. 22m to the SW.  See attached photograph: TS066-218----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (18 November 2018)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 8 January 2020

In pasture. A possible ring-barrow (diam. c. 8m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 18 November 2018) by Jean-Charles Caillère. It is conjoined on its W side with another possible ring-barrow (TS066-218----). Another possible ring-barrow (TS066-217----) is located c. 22m to the SW.  See attached photograph: TS066-219----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (18 November 2018)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 8 January 2020

On the summit of a drumlin. Circular grass-covered domed area (diam. 22m; H 0.6m) separated by a fosse (Wth of base 3-3.5m; D 0.2-0.4m) from the remains of an earthen bank (Wth 3-3.5m; int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.4-0.5m) that survives SSE-NE (max. ext. diam. c. 36m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

First identified in an unpublished archaeological LiDAR report (Davis, 2015) commissioned by Roscommon County Council as part of the Environmental Impact Assessment for the N5 Ballaghaderreen - Scramoge road development. It is situated in pasture on a level landscape. The LiDAR image depicts a circular platform (diam. c.30m) defined by a fosse feature (Wth c. 7m) and an outer bank feature (Wth c. 8m). The edge of the central platform can be detected as a slight scarp (Wth 4m; H 0.3m) N-NE, but no other evidence of what appears to be a ring-barrow is visible at ground level. It is overlain by a N-S field bank W of the centre.Date of revised upload: 3 July, 2017

In low-lying wet pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, 20m N of a townland boundary with Coolbaun. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. The central of a cluster of three ring-barrows (LI024-309001-/002-/003-) which are aligned in a row running NW-SE. Monument identified by Emmet Byrnes, Forest Service archaeologist in 2010 and described as a low profile circular-shaped mound (diam. 7.6m; H 0.4m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1m) and an outer bank (approx. Wth 2.4m; approx. H 0.4m) (SMR file). Forestry planted to W and N. Monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthophotos and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 16 October 2020

In low-lying wet pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, 35m N of a townland boundary with Coolbaun. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. The western most of a cluster of three ring-barrows (LI024-309001-/002-/003-) which are aligned in a row running NW-SE. Monument identified by Emmet Byrnes, Forest Service archaeologist in 2010 and described as a low profile circular-shaped mound (diam. 5m; H 0.4m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.2m) and an outer bank (approx. Wth 1.8m; approx. H 0.4m) (SMR file). Forestry planted to W and N. Monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthophotos and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 16 October 2020

In gently undulating pasture, on a low rise. Circular area (dims. 6m N-S; 5.5m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.05m) which is in-filled at WSW due to disturbance from drainage channel (long axis NNW-SSE) to W. Traces of levelled external bank (Wth 6.2m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.15m) SE-SSW and possibly at N. Identified as one of a pair of conjoined ring-barrows on an aerial photograph (OS 2396). Ring-barrow (TS066-050001-) conjoined to NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In low-lying wet pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, 15m N of a townland boundary with Coolbaun. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. The eastern most of a cluster of three ring-barrows (LI024-309001-/002-/003-) which are aligned in a row running NW-SE. Monument identified by Emmet Byrnes, Forest Service archaeologist in 2010 and described as a low profile circular-shaped mound (diam. 4.2m; H 0.5m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 0.9) and an outer bank (approx. Wth 2.2m; approx. H 0.4m) (SMR file). Forestry planted to W and N. Monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthophotos and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018   Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 16 October 2020

In gently undulating pasture, on a low rise. Circular area (dims. 5m N-S; 4.6m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 1.4m; D 0.1m) which is best preserved NW-E-S-W-WNW; in-filled at WNW-NW. Possible remains of levelled external bank (Wth 4.4m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.15m) SSW-NW and NE-E-S. Monument disturbed by linear drain (long-axis E-W) across N-sector. Identified as one of a pair of conjoined ring-barrows on an aerial photograph (OS 2396). Ring-barrow (TS066-050003-) conjoined to SW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Just off the crest of a broad W-E ridge or spur on the S side. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of top 6.7m E-W; 6.3m N-S; H 0.2m at E to 0.6m at S) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 3.8m at E to 6.8m at S; Wth of base 2m; D 0.4m at S to 0.9m at N) and an outer bank (Wth 3-4m; H 0.2-0.6m). There is no visible entrance, but the bank at E has been straightened (L 20m) (max. ext. dims 23m N-S; 21m E-W).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In improved pasture, on a SE-facing slope. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (17 February 2009). A circular area (dims. 5.9m N-S; 5.7m E-W) defined by a fosse (overall Wth 3.1m; basal Wth 0.85m; D 0.15m) and outer bank (Wth 3.1m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.05m) N-E-WSW. There is a dry drainage channel running NNE-SSW is c. 5m to the NW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In rough wet pasture, on a natural ridge/shelf, the land slopes steeply to the S c. 18m to the S of monument where there is a flood plain. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (17 February 2009). A circular area (dims. 5m N-S; 4.75m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.6-1.9m; D 0.2-0.3m) and outer bank (Wth 3.35m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.17m) E-S. There are irises in the fosse all around with rushes and briars at the E. A slight depression (Wth 1.3m) in the outer area at ENE may be an entrance. The interior is grass covered with frequent irises and the barrow is slightly poached by livestock. There is a field boundary 6m to the S and a linear land drain runs N-S 4.5m to the W and another runs NW-SE to the E.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In pasture, on a S-facing slope where there are numerous dry, linear drainage channels. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (17 February 2009). A circular area (dims. 5m N-S; 4.8m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.2-1.95m; D 0.1-0.11m) and the remains of a possible bank (Wth 2.1-2.35m; int. H 0.1-0.18m; ext. H 0.1-0.11m) in the SE quadrant. The interior has been raised on the S side to create a level platform within. A drainage channel running N-S abuts the fosse at the W.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

In pasture, on a S-facing slope, abutting a ditch barrow (TS066-193001-) to the E. Identified during field survey by Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly (17 February 2009). An enclosure (TS066-192----) is located c. 23m to the SW. A D-shaped area (dims. 5.6m N-S; 3.25m E-W) defined by a well-preserved fosse (overall Wth 2.05m; basal Wth 0.4m; D 0.2m) and the remains of a possible outer bank visible in the SE and NW quadrants. The monument is transected by a linear feature aligned N-S (Wth 1m; H 0.06m), which is possibly up-cast from a shallow drain across the W sector.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 9 September 2014

At the crest of the S end of a broad NW-SE ridge overlooking a turlough c. 200m to the SW. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 35.5m N-S; 33m E-W; H 0.0.3-0.7m) defined by a fosse (Wth of base 3.3-4m; D 0.2-0.7m), with a slight outer bank (Wth 6m; ext. H 0.1m) N-E-S. The perimeter of the platform is damaged by quarries N-E, and the spoil was probably added to the interior making a domed mound (diam. 16.5m N-S; 15.8m E-W; H 0.4m). Ring-barrow (RO028-127002-) is 10m to the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture, on the summit of a low narrow ridge. A low circular convex mound (10.6m N-S; 9.8m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.6m) and an external bank (Wth 1.3m; ext. H 0.6m). The fosse is 0.75m below the mound and 0.5m below the bank. The mound is uneven, possibly as a result of digging, and overgrown with nettles and three blackthorn bushes. The mound and bank are both stony; the bank is burrowed into on the E side.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In gently undulating, rough pasture, 25m E of a townland boundary with Kilmacogue. Not depicted on OS ihistoric maps. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a circular-shaped area (4m N-S; 5m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.55m; H 0.17m) which is best preserved from SE-S-W and outer bank (Wth 2.7-4.6m; int. H 0.17-0.22m; ext. H 0.05-0.16m) from NE-E-S-W, which is broad and difficult to define on exterior from SE-S-SW. The interior is dry in contrast to a waterlogged fosse. Monument is disturbed by old drainage activity from W-N-NE, where the ground remains very wet. Monument is visible as a faint circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012, although is not visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and seems to be within an unplanted area of forestry on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.   See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 14 October 2020

At the crest of the S end of a broad NW-SE ridge overlooking a turlough c. 200m to the SW. Subcircular, domed and grass-covered mound (dims 16m WNW-ESE; 14m NNE-SSW; H 0.5-0.7m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of base 5-7.5m; D 0.2-0.8m) and an outer bank (Wth 7-7.6m; ext. H 0.2-0.4m). There is a shallow quarry (diam. c. 12m; D 0.1m) on the perimeter where it is conjoined with the bank of ring-barrow (RO028-127003-) immediately to the E, and ring-barrow (RO028-127001-) is 10m to the W (max. ext. diam. 42.2m NNE-SSW).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the broad WNW-ESE ridge of Carnfree. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. of top 7.6m E-W; 7m N-S; diam. of base 10.6m E-W; 10m N-S; H 0.2-0.3m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth of top 3.2m at N to 6m E-S; Wth of base 2-2.5m) and outer bank (Wth 4-5m; int. H 0.5-0.8m; ext. H 0.75-1m). A gap (Wth 1.7m) has been broken in the bank at E (ext. diam. 23.6m N-S; 23.4m E-W). Barrows (RO028-063004-; RO028-063005-) are c. 200m to the W. Enclosure (RO028-063005-) is c. 50m to the W and enclosure (RO028-064002-) is c. 50m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the crest of the S end of a broad NW-SE ridge overlooking a turlough c. 200m to the SW. Circular, domed and grass-covered mound (diam. 13.6m N-S; 13.4m E-W; H 0.6m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of base 7-10m; D 0.6m) and outer bank (at N: Wth 5.4m; ext. H 0.7m) SW-W-NE. The fosse is reduced to a berm (Wth 10-13m) defined by a scarp (H 0.2-0.4m) NE-E-SW, and the perimeter is clipped by a NW-SE field bank at NE and by a NE-SW field bank at SE. There is a shallow quarry (diam. 12m; D 0.1m) on the perimeter where it is conjoined with ring-barrow (RO-028-127002-) immediately to the W.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture. A small circular enclosure (diam. c. 8m), possibly a ring-barrow, identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 18 November 2018) by Jean-Charles Caillère.   See attached photograph: TS066-207----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (18 November 2018)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 7 January 2020

On a low rise on a W-facing slope. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 24.5m E-W; 23m N-S; H 1.2m) defined by a wide fosse (Wth. of top 7-8.5m; Wth of base 2-3.5m) and an outer bank (Wth. 3.8m at S to 5.6m at E; int. H 1m at S to 1.5m at E; ext. H 0.85m at N to 1.1m generally). There is no visible entrance (max. ext. diam. 48m N-S; 50m E-W).  See the attached wide-angle view taken from the SW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In rough, level pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, 200m W of a townland boundary with Moanoola. Ring-barrow (LI025-035----) lies 7m to S. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile circular-shaped area (diam. 4.8m) defined by a scarp (Wth 0.7m; H 0.1m) and a fosse (Wth 1.85m; D 0.06m). The fosse is present from WNW-N-E-ESE and is truncated by a shallow linear drain running WNW-ESE, to S. An outer bank (Wth 2.3m; int. H 0.06m; ext. H 0.2m) is visible from NW-N-E-ESE. The interior is generally level and grass covered. Monument is not visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-2012, or on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-2013, or on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 22 October 2020

In rough, level pasture, which is cut by land drains and watercourses, 200m to W of a townland boundary with Moanoola. Ring-barrow (LI025-034----) lies 7m to N. Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a low profile circular-shaped area (diam. 3.2m) defined by a scarp (Wth 0.5-0.75m; H 0.08-0.11m), a fosse (Wth 2.05-2.6m; D 0.05-0.07m) and an outer bank (Wth 1.95-2.8m; int. H 0.05-0.07m; ext. H 0.05-0.09m). The monument is waterlogged at present. Monument is visible as a faint, roughly circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 22 October 2020

See attached photograph: TS066-209----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (18 November 2018)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 8 January 2020

Within enclosure (TS066-125----), off-centre to N. A sunken, circular area (dims 4m N-S; 3.9m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.55-2.15m; D 0.1-0.2m), crescent-shaped berm or very low outer bank (Wth 1.75m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.05m) N-E-S, which has a corresponding outer fosse (Wth 1.65m; D 0.15m). The iterior is level and grass covered.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On the N-facing slope of the broad WNW-ESE Carnfree ridge. Described as a ring-barrow in 1958 (SMR file), it is not now visible between the two banks of road (RO028-06201-). Mound barrow (RO028-062004-) is 10m to the SE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On flat pasture 140m E of the N tip of the townland boundary with Castlelloyd. One of five barrows (LI025-033001/003/004-/005-) in a barrow cemetery. The ring-barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps, but is visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12.  Not visible on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 10.2; AP 4/3621) as a circular ring-barrow (ext. diam. c. 7.5m). On flat pasture 140m E of the N tip of the townland boundary with Castlelloyd. One of five barrows (LI025-033001/002/004/005-) in a barrow cemetery. On flat pasture 140m E of the N tip of the townland boundary with Castlelloyd. One of five barrows (LI025-033001/002/003/005-) in a barrow cemetery. On the summit of Cullaun, on a slight NW-facing slope, in rough mountain bog, in the Slievefelim Mountains. Annotated 'Mound' and depicted on the OS 25-inch map as a small oval-shaped earthwork standing on the townland boundary with Falleenadatha.  The mound may be related to the OS trig station marking spot height of 1524 ft. OD which is immediately W of the mound.  Or may be the remains of a boundary cairn constructed by the Ordnance Survey to mark this boundary.Monument surveyed by the ASI in 1999 and described as a circular-shaped flat-topped mound (diam. 8m; H 0.3m) of earth and stone defined by a fosse (basal Wth 1.4m; overall Wth 6.3m; D 0.5m). A narrow routeway (Wth 0.6m) is cut (D 0.15m) from the outer edge of the fosse to the top of the mound at E and appears to be a relatively recent modification.  Visible as an oval-shaped area of differential growth on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018. See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 3 July 2020

On reclaimed pasture, with moderate views in all directions, ring-barrow (LI025-032----) 20m to W.  Cropmark of a double-ditched ring-barrow visible on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-12 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018 and photos courtesy of Ed O'DonovanCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Edmond O'DonovanDate of upload: 24 September 2020

On reclaimed pasture, with moderate views in all directions, ring-barrows (LI025-032/041----) 120m and 105m to NW respectively. At the crest of the N-facing slope of an WNW-ESE ridge, c. 250m N of the broad WNW-ESE ridge of Carnfree. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 35.5m N-S; 34.5m E-W) defined by a slight earthen bank (Wth 4-5.5m; H 0.1-0.2m), with slight traces of an internal fosse (Wth c. 7m) at S. There is no identifiable original entrance (ext. diam. c. 38m E-W). Standing stone (RO028-068003-) is at the centre, and standing stone (RO028-067----) is 40m outside the perimeter to the E. Rath (RO028-245----) is c. 140m to the W. The bank was clearly visible when Beranger drew it and its standing stone in 1779 (Wilde 1870-1, 250-1) and when Knox saw it (1914b, 351).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010  Amended: 6 March, 2014

In gently undulating pasture, with moderate views in all directions. The townland boundary with Oolahills East is 260m to S and enclosure (LI025-015----) lies 350m to NNW. A series of newly discovered ring-barrows lie to the S, SW and W of the site within a radius of between 15-110m. The site is not depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map and is not depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map. The ring-barrow is visible as a small ring-barrow surrounded by a larger semi-circular enclosure on the OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12 and on the Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Inspected by ASI in 1999 when the ring-barrow was described as a circular raised area (int. diam. 5.2m) defined by a scarped edge with a shallow external fosse (Wth 1.7m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1m). The interior of the ring-barrow is level, dry. The fosse is less obvious on the W side where it has been recently infilled. No entrance present. The W side of the outer enclosure (ext. dims. 32m N-S; 21m E-W) has been removed as a surface feature by a modern field boundary.  At the time of the field inspection by ASI the local farmer (pers. comm.) said that other sites were visible in the vicinity of the ring-barrow at different times of the year under different growth and climatic conditions. The ring-barrow within the enclosure is visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018. See attached sketch plan surveyed and drawn by the ASI and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 24 September 2020

On reclaimed pasture, with moderate views in all directions, ring-barrow (LI025-032----) 15m to NW.  Cropmark of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 10m) defined by a ditch visible on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-12 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Edmond O'DonovanDate of upload: 24 September 2020

In gently undulating pasture, with excellent views from the NW to SW to SE and restricted view to the NE. The townland boundary with Keeloges lies 115m to E with an earthwork (LI025-037----) 500m to SE. The site is depicted as a circular enclosure on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map and is not depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map. The ring-barrow (ext. dims. 31m N-S; 33m E-W) is visible as a circular-shaped area with an external fosse on the OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12 and on the Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Inspected by the ASI in 1999 and described as a raised circular-shaped area (int. diam. 20m) defined by a scarped edge with a shallow and wide external fosse (Wth 5.3m; int. H 0.8m; ext. H 0.3m). The interior is level, dry and clear of overgrowth. The fosse is less obvious from the SE to SW to NW. No entrance present. The ring-barrow is visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 05/05/2002 and 18/11/2018.See attached sketch plan surveyed and drawn by the ASI and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 2 October 2020

In improved pasture, on a steep NW-facing slope. Identified during a field inspection of an enclosure (TS066-133----), within which the ring-barrow is off-centre to the SW. An oval area (dims. 4.5m N-S; 3.7m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.2m) and outer bank (Wth 3.1m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.18m) which is well preserved all around except from SSW-W-WNW. Three mature thorn trees are on bank in the W sector.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

In a valley, on the W-facing slope of a low natural hillock, in gently undulating hummocky wet terrain, in pasture. A field boundary incorporating a stream runs roughly NW-SE 4m to the W. The view is generally good along the valley floor and also to the S of the N slopes of a hill range, including Moanour Mountain, Slievenamuck, Carrigeenina and The Steeple. A circular enclosure visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. A low circular flat-topped mound (diam. 5.8m; H 0.15m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.7-2m; D 0.13m) and slight traces of an outer bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.18m). The outer bank is well preserved in the E sector but is completely denuded in the W. There are some nettles growing in the fosse in the S sector. Another ring-barrow (TS066-227----) is located 4m to the ESE and a possible ditch barrow (TS066-228----) c. 100m to the SE. See attached:TS066-226----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2018)TS066-226----_02 Overview from the SETS066-226----_03 Overview from the S with neighbouring ring-barrow TS066-227---- in the foregroundCompiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 14 January 2022

In a valley, on top of a low natural rise, in gently undulating hummocky wet terrain, in pasture. A field boundary incorporating a stream runs roughly NW-SE 25m to the W. The view is generally good along the valley floor and also to the S of the N slopes of a hill range, including Moanour Mountain, Slievenamuck, Carrigeenina and The Steeple. A circular enclosure visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. A low circular flat-topped mound (diam. 7.3m; H 0.15m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.1m) and slight traces of an outer bank (Wth 1.7-2.2m; ext. H 0.1m). Another ring-barrow (TS066-226----) is located 4m to the WNW and a possible ditch barrow (TS066-228----) c. 90m to the SE. Marked only on the 1914 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on top of an E-W ridge. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 6.5m E-W; 5.5m N-S; H 0.1-0.3m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 3.2-3.8m; D 0.1-0.35m) SE-W-NE, and an outer bank (Wth 2.1m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.2-0.3m) SE-S and at NE. Barrow (RO006-135002-) is 10m to the WNW. These monuments are particularly visible on Google Earth (18/03/2019).
