See attached photograph: TS058-087----_01 Image OS Ortho (no date)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 7 January 2020

In pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 12m) with an internal fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 18 November 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. See attached:TS066-123----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 10 January 2022

Situated on flat poorly drained reclaimed grassland.  Outline of ring-barrow (approx. diam. 7m) visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-12.  Faint outline of monument visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13.Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 18 October 2020

At the crest of a N-facing slope. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. of base 8.2m; H 0.2-0.3m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of base 1.5m; D 0.45-0.55m) and an outer bank (Wth 3-3.7m; H 0.5-0.7m). There is an entrance (Wth 1.6m) and causeway (Wth 1.5m) at E (max. ext. diam. 18m).  See the attached image (020) taken from the NW in Winter. See the attached image (023) taken from the NE in Summer. Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on flat poorly drained reclaimed grassland.  Outline of ring-barrow (approx. diam. 9m) visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-12.  Faint outline of monument visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 18 October 2020

Situated on flat poorly drained reclaimed grassland.  Outline of ring-barrow (approx. diam. 6m) visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-12.  Outline of monument visible on Google Earth orthophotos taken 11/03/2014 and 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 18 October 2020

On the N bank of a now dry meandering stream, in low-lying wet pasture. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 14m), defined by a fosse and what appears to be an outer bank, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There are a lot of barrows in the general vicinity, including a large barrow (TS066-057----) c. 170m to the WNW and a ditch barrow (TS066-057001-) c. 200m to the W.   See attached: TS066-230----_01 Google Earth satellite image (imagery date, 18 November 2018)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 8 January 2022

On level ground at base of slight depression, immediately to the S of a stream, in gently undulating pasture. Roughly D-shaped area (dims. 22m NE-SW; 16m NW-SE) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 1.5 m; H 0.8m). At the external base of the scarp is a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 2m) and a low broad external earthen bank (overall Wth 5.3m; Wth at top 2.4m; int. H 0.2-0.4m; ext. H 0.3m). The curving scarp, fosse and external bank enclose the site NE-SW. The scarped edge, fosse and external bank have been removed and the edge of the barrow straightened off SW-NW by a modern N-S orientated field drain. The monument is defined NW-NE by a W-E flowing stream. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011
The cropmark of a possible ringbarrow is evident on Google Earth aerial photographs, at this location.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 4 September 2013

Within enclosure (TS066-060----), off-centre to W, c. 3m to E of scarp. An adjacent ring-barrow (TS066-060002-) is located to the NE. A circular area (diam. 5m) defined by a fosse (basal Wth 0.4m; overall Wth 1.55m; D 0.25m) SSE-W-N and remains of levelled scarp (Wth 0.8m; H 0.1m) NE-E-SSE. The interior is grass covered and level.   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Within enclosure (TS066-060----), off-centre to N. An adjacent ring-barrow (TS066-060001-) is located to the SW. A circular area (diam. 6m) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.65m; D 0.15m) NNE-S-NW and low outer bank (Wth 1.95m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.05m) visible in the NE quadrant and ESE-S-SSW. Only the scarp (Wth 1.15m; H 0.2m) of the interior is evident in the N quadrant which is c. 2m to SW of the enclosing monument. The interior is grass covered and has a gentle S-facing slope.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture on slight E-facing slope, with good views to the N and S, and restricted views in other directions. Located 80m SE of the townland boundary with Longford East and a ringfort (LI025-024----) lies 390m to SW. The site (ext. dims. 66m N-S; 56m E-W) is depicted as a small oval enclosure on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map and as a flat topped mound surrounded by two fosses on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map . Monument visible as a roughly circular area with trees covering the monument on the OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12 and on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Inspected by the ASI in 1999 and described as densely overgrown monument with restricted access. The site consists of a raised circular-shaped area (int. diam. c. 20m), defined by a deep fosse (Wth 12.6m; int. H 2.6m; ext. H 0.4m) and external bank (Wth 5.4m; D 0.4m). The interior appears level and dry. The NE and SE side is partially truncated by two field boundaries that cut across both the fosse and external bank. No entrance is present. The ring-barrow is visible on the latest Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018. The Google Earth image illustrates the levelled outer margin of the site to the SE and S. The linear earthworks visible on the S edge of the site are also likely to be the levelled remains of the external bank of the monument in that location.See attached sketch plan surveyed and drawn by the ASI and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 2 October 2020

On top of a low E-W ridge on the S-facing slope of a ridge. Described as a flat-topped mound (diam. of top 6.7m N-S; 6.2m E-W) defined by a fosse. The barrow was eccentrically placed within an enclosure (diam. 30m E-W; 29m N-S) defined by an earthen bank (Gannon 1972). It is now visible as a circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 5.5m; H 0.9m) with a flat top (diam. 2.4m), located in the NE quadrant of a subcircular grass-covered enclosure (RO006-147002-) (dims 30.5m E-W; 27m N-S) defined by a scarp (H 0.4-0.7m), which has an outer fosse (Wth of top 4.7m; ext. D 0.2m) SW-NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a gentle W-facing slope. Subcircular grass-covered, slightly domed mound (dims of top 9.6m E-W; 8.4m N-S; dims of base 13.5m E-W; 12.4m N-S; H 0.1-0.2m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of top 5.6-7.6m; Wth of base 1.4-2.7m; D 0.05-0.15m) and an outer bank (Wth 3.2-5.3m; H 0.05m). There is no identifiable entrance (max. ext. dims 28m E-W; 24.5m N-S).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a slight SW-facing slope. Circular grass-covered and flat-topped mound (diam. of top 9m; diam. of base 12m; H 0.3-0.6m) surrounded by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of base 3.2-3.3m; D 0.25m) and an earthen bank (Wth 3.7-4.2m; H 0.15m) which is best preserved (Wth 3.2m; int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.2m) N-E (max. ext. diam. 26m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Located at the W edge of a fairly level shelf on the valley floor of the Bonet River, with a N-S section of the stream c. 130m to the W. This is a grass-covered flat-topped mound (dims of top 6m N-S; 9.5m E-W; dims of base 14m N-S; 12m E-W; H 0.2m E-S to 0.6m at W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of top 6-11m; Wth of base 3.5-9m; ext. D 0.4-0.8m) and an outer bank (Wth 1.5-2m; ext. H 0.2m) NE-S-W. In places the bank is separated from the fosse by a slight berm, but an entrance through the bank has not been identified. The NW part of the monument has been disturbed by an old quarry which has left a grass-covered scarp (H 1.5m) at this side, and the perimeter is missing W-NE (max. ext. dims 33m N-S; 28m ENE-WSW).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of revised upload: 19 April, 2016

On top of a low rise. Circular grass-covered and rounded mound (diam. of base 8.5m; H 1.75m) defined by a fosse (Wth of base 1.5m at N to 3.4m at S) and a gapped outer bank (Wth 3.6-4.7m generally to 5.3m at S; int. H 0.05m at N to 0.55m at SW; ext. H 0.75m at SW to 1.9m at S). There is no visible entrance (max. ext. diam. 23m N-S).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the crest of the SE-facing slope of an E-W ridge. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 8.5m N-S; H 0.2m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 2.5m; D 0.2m) and an outer bank (Wth 3.5m; ext. H 0.2m). There is no visible entrance (max. ext. diam. c. 17m). Archaeological testing immediately to the NW failed to produce archaeological material (Read 2009d). Rath (RO016-061----) is c. 80m to the W.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Just off the crest of the W-facing slope of a hill. Subcircular grass-covered mound (dims 27m N-S; 24.2m E-W; H 0.3-0.6m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 5.4m at E to 10.5m at W; Wth of base 2.5-4.4m; D 1.45-1.75m) and a scrub-covered outer bank (Wth 4.5-6.4m; H 0.7-0.9m) which is incorporated into a field bank NE-SE and has been removed SSW-WNW. The W edge of the mound has also been cut back (max. ext. dim. 46m N-S). Pond barrow (RO035-077----) is c. 50m to the NE and embanked barrow (RO035-078----) is c. 60m to the E.  See the attached aerial images from NW (001) and W (004).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a N-facing slope in the foothills of the Galty mountains, in wet, waterlogged pasture. A raised, roughly circular, slightly dished, central area (diam. 15.2m N-S; 14m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.4-1m) and outer bank (Wth 4-4.9m; int. H 0.9-1.6m; ext. H 0.71-1.12m). There is a slight suggestion of an outer fosse but this may be the result of cattle poaching when sheltering up against external face of the bank. Field clearance consisting of stones and small boulders have been dumped in the interior in the N quadrant. The bank is overgrown with scrub, holly, brambles and gorse and the interior is under grass. There is a gap (Wth 1.5m) through the bank in the NW sector.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In low-lying gently undulating wet pasture. Circular slightly raised area (diam. 21m) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 1.3-2.3m; H 0.2-0.45m). At the external base of the scarp is a fosse (Wth at base 2m; D 0.05m) an intermediate earthen bank (Wth at top 1.2-2.2m; overall Wth 3.9-7.7m; int. H 0.2-0.35m; ext. H 0.45m) and an external; fosse (overall Wth 3.3m; Wth at base 2m; D 0.15m). The scarped edge decreases slightly in height from W to E reflecting the ESE facing slope of the interior. There are two modern breaks in the intermediate bank at NE (Wth 4m) and at ENE (Wth 4.5m). The external edge of the external fosse is very faint to the S of a modern NW-SE orientated field boundary skirts external base of the intermediate bank SSE-SW. A break (Wth 5m) in the intermediate bank, with causeways across the fosses, at ESE marks the position of the original entrance. The interior slopes slightly facing ESE and is clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on a rise in a low-lying landscape on the floor of the Glenade valley with a N-S section of the river Bonet c. 400m to the E. Visible as a circular feature on aerial photographs (OSAP: 5/6929-8). This is a grass-covered D-shaped platform (dims 10.5m NE-SW; 8m NW-SE) defined by an earthen bank (Wth c. 2m; int. H 0.1-0.15m; ext. H 0.4m). It is truncated by a NE-SW field bank at N.
column13: The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

column10: On the summit of an ENE-WSW drumlin ridge. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 13.5 N-S; diam. of top 4.75m N-S; H 0.8m at W to 1.6m at S) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 7.25-8.5m; Wth of base 2.9 at W to 4.3m at S; D 0.65m) and an outer bank (Wth 2m at W to 4m at N; ext. H 0.25-0.6m) with intermittent traces of inner facing stones (ext. diam. c. 26m). There is no visible entrance.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the W end of an E-W ridge. Circular, flat-topped and grass-covered mound (diam. of top 4.3m E-W; 4.2m N-S; diam. of base 5.1m E-W; 5m N-S; H 0.2-0.3m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 6.9-7.4m; Wth of base 2.2-3.2m; D 0.4-0.8m) and outer bank (Wth 3.6m; ext. H 0.1-0.2m). There is no identifiable original entrance (max. ext. diam. 21m E-W; 22.6m N-S). Ring-barrow (RO035-035002-) is c. 20m to the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the W end of an E-W ridge. D-shaped, overgrown platform (dims c. 10m N-S; c. 7m E-W; H 0.3m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 4.5m; Wth of base 1.7m; D 0.35m) and outer bank (Wth 3.6m; H 0.2m). The monument is truncated by a NE-SW field wall at E, and does not survive SE of this. There is an entrance in the bank and a causeway (Wth 2.5m) at NW (max. ext. diam. 20.5m NE-SW). Ring-barrow (RO035-035001-) is c. 20m to the W.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked only on the 1928 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated in a grass and furze-covered area towards the bottom of a W-facing slope. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 4.5m; H 0.05m) defined by a slight fosse (Wth of base 0.8-1.4m; D 0.05-0.1m) with an outer earthen bank (Wth 2.2-2.6m; H 0.3-0.6m). There is an entrance (Wth 1.1m) at ESE (max. ext. diam. 12.7m NE-SW).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the W-facing slope of a broad WNW-ESE ridge. Described in 1965 as a circular area (diam. c. 20m) defined by a fosse (Wth of base c. 2m) and an outer bank (Wth c. 1.5m; int. H c. 0.9m; ext. H c. 0.4m) (SMR file), it is no longer visible in improved pasture. Ring-barrow (RO035-036----) is c. 150m to the NNE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Towards the top of a S-facing slope. D-shaped grass-covered platform (dims of top 10.4m NE-SW; 9.6m NW-SE; dims of base 13m NE-SW; 11.4m NW-SE; H 0.45-0.7m), which was straightened at the NW by a NNE-SSW field bank, with a mound (diam. 4.9m NW-SE; H 0.2m) just NW of the centre. Ring-barrow (RO039-014001-) is c. 10m to the N, and rath (RO039-015----) is c. 30m to the S, while barrow (RO039-014003-) may have been just to the S. (Knox 1914b, 352)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the top of a S-facing slope. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. of top 6.4m E-W; 5.9m N-S; diam. of base 12.4m N-S; 12.2m E-W) defined by a rounded fosse (Wth of top 6.9-8.3m; Wth of base 2.4-4.3m; int. D 0.2-0.4m; ext. D 0.35-0.8m) and an outer bank (Wth 1.9-3m; H 0.3-0.5m) which has been removed N-NNE (max. ext. diam. 25.75m E-W; 22.6m N-S). Ring-barrow (RO039-014002-) is c. 10m to the S, and rath (RO039-015----) is c. 50m to the S. Barrow (RO039-085001-) is c. 120m to the W and barrow (RO039-016----) is c. 190m to the SE. (Knox 1914b, 352)  See the attached image taken from the E  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a low-lying landscape. Subcircular platform (dims 34m N-S; 31.3m E-W) with a single mature deciduous tree at the centre while the rest is planted with coniferous trees, defined by a scarp (H 1.15m at W to 2m at N). It is separated by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 8.7-11m; Wth of base 2.5m generally to 5.4m at S; D 0.4m at S to 1.75-2m W-N) from an outer bank (Wth 6.7- 6.9m; ext. H 0.35m at W to 0.8m at N) SW-N-NE (max. ext. diam. 59m N-S). The fosse is utilised by a disused avenue NE-S-SW which led to Croghan House, c. 250m to the S, and there is a gap (Wth of base 1.8m), which is probably modern, in the outer bank at NNW. (Knox 1911, 96)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Field report from Celie O'Rahilly (3 March 1994): 'Possible Ringbarrow, Td LahesseraghThis is located in a flat grazing field which seems to be pegged out as sites, possibly for housing development. It consists of a mound, <1m high, with a roughly circular depression, of ca 14m diameter, in the centre. It was noted when walking the proposed Nenagh By-pass and, although it is not affected by the line of the road'.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

On as gentle E-facing slope. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 18.6m N-S; 18.2m E-W; H 0.4-0.6m generally to 1m at E) separated by a berm (Wth 3-5m) from an earthen bank (Wth 5.5-7m; H 0.05-0.1m). There is no identifiable original entrance (max. ext. diam. 38m N-S). It is visible on Bing images (c. 2013).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the NW-facing slope of a low WNW-ESE ridge. Described as a low circular flat-topped mound defined by a fosse and an outer bank (Gannon 1972), it is no longer visible in improved pasture. Ring-barrow (RO035-037----) is c. 150m to the SSW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the crest of a W-facing slope of a broad hill. Circular grass-covered and flat-topped mound (diam. of top 8.8m; diam. of base 10.5m E-W; 10.2m N-S; H 0.2m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 3-3.3m; Wth of base 0.9-1.3m; D 0.2-0.4m) and an outer bank (Wth 2.5-2.9m; H 0.3-0.4m). There are gaps in the bank at S (Wth 1m) and NW (Wth 1.6m) (max. ext. diam. 18.2m E-W).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

A circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m) with an internal fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 16 December 2016 and 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is another ring-barrow (TS058-090----) c. 5m to the NNE.See attached:TS058-091----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 16 December 2016)TS058-091----_02 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 10 January 2022

At the crest of the N-facing slope of a broad hill. Overgrown circular platform (diam. c. 20m; H 0.2m) defined by a fosse (Wth of base 3m; D 0.85m) and an outer overgrown earthen bank (Wth 2.5m; H 0.35m). There is no identifiable original entrance (ext. diam. c. 30m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

A circular enclosure (diam. c. 15m) with an internal fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 16 December 2016 and 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is another ring-barrow (TS058-091----) c. 5m to the SSW.See attached:TS058-090----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 16 December 2016)TS058-090----_02 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 10 January 2022

On a gentle SE-facing slope. Oval overgrown platform (dims c. 30m E-W; c. 22m N-S; H 0.8m) defined by a rounded fosse (Wth of base 4m), and an outer earth and stone bank (Wth 2.6m; int. H 0.75m; ext. H 0.15m) ENE-WNW which has been truncated at N by a WNW-ESE field bank and hedge. There is no identifiable original entrance.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture. A small circular enclosure (diam. c. 14m) identified on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016) by Jean-Charles Caillère. It appears to have an internal fosse and outer bank. The size and morphology of the enclosure suggest it is a ring-barrow. There is another possible ring-barrow c. 50m to the S. See attached photograph: TS066-204----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 11 December 2019

In pasture. A small circular enclosure (diam. c. 14m) identified on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016) by Jean-Charles Caillère. It appears to have an internal fosse and outer bank. The size and morphology of the enclosure suggest it is a ring-barrow. There is another possible ring-barrow c. 50m to the S. See attached photograph: TS066-204----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 11 December 2019

In low-lying level wet pasture. Circular area (diam. 12m) defined by a low broad earthen scarp (Wth 1.2m; H 0.25m). At the external base of the scarp is a broad flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 2.2m; D 0.1m) and an low broad external earthen bank (Wth at top 1m; overall Wth 3.3m; int. H 0.05-0.2m; ext. H 0.15m). The interior is level and overgrown with bushes and briars along the W edge.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated in fields to the W of Nenagh Mart, behind St Patrick's Terrace on O'Growney Street. A number of nine possible barrows (TN020-099/008) show up on aerial photographs (OSAP 3585, 16.5.1986). These could also have been formed from cattle feeding rings, though the variation in dimensions suggests otherwise.   Ring-barrow consisting of a low circular mound (diam. 2.25m; H 0.07m) enclosed by a wide internal fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.1m) with no outer bank visible.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated in fields to the W of Nenagh Mart, behind St Patrick's Terrace on O'Growney Street. A number of nine possible barrows (TN020-099/008) show up on aerial photographs (OSAP 3585, 16.5.1986). These could also have been formed from cattle feeding rings, though the variation in dimensions suggests otherwise.   No surface remains visible, ring-barrow only visible on aerial photograph (OSAP 3585, 16.5.1986).  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated in fields to the W of Nenagh Mart, behind St Patrick's Terrace on O'Growney Street. A number of nine possible barrows (TN020-099/008) show up on aerial photographs (OSAP 3585, 16.5.1986). These could also have been formed from cattle feeding rings, though the variation in dimensions suggests otherwise.   No surface remains visible, ring-barrow only visible on aerial photograph (OSAP 3585, 16.5.1986).  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

In pasture. A small circular enclosure (diam. c. 14m) identified on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016) by Jean-Charles Caillère. It appears to have an internal fosse and outer bank. The size and morphology of the enclosure suggest it is a ring-barrow.  See attached photograph: TS066-203----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 11 December 2019

Situated in fields to the W of Nenagh Mart, behind St Patrick's Terrace on O'Growney Street. A number of nine possible barrows showed up on aerial photographs (OSAP 3585, 16.5.1986). These could also have been formed from cattle feeding rings, though the variation in dimensions suggests otherwise.  The land rises gradually to the S. There are six possible ring-barrows (TN020-099-005) in this field, roughly in a diamond-shaped arrangement. The most southerly ring-barrow is on a rise in the field, while the remainder are slightly below this level. All the sites are very subtle comprising a fosse and slight internal mound. They are all roughly circular. N site: Diam. 8m N-S; 7.32m E-W; diam. of mound 2.05-2.1m; H from mound to fosse 0.11m; D of fosse 0.04m. W site: Diam. 6.4m N-S; 5.94m E-W; diam. of mound 1.86-2m; H from mound to fosse 0.03m; D of fosse 0.1m. E site: Diam. 6.11m N-S; 6.8m E-W; diam. of mound 2.52-2.19m; H from mound to fosse 0.07m; D of fosse 0.05m. S site: Diam. 8.5m N-S; 9.5m E-W; diam. of mound 3.1m; H from mound to fosse 0.05m; D of fosse 0.1m. The S site is quite denuded at E and it is difficult to determine its extent. The mound itself, however, is quite visible as is the fosse at W; it shows up well on the aerial photograph.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

These could also have been formed from cattle feeding rings, though the variation in dimensions suggests otherwise.  The land rises gradually to the S. They are all roughly circular. N site: Diam. 8m N-S; 7.32m E-W; diam. of mound 2.05-2.1m; H from mound to fosse 0.11m; D of fosse 0.04m. W site: Diam. 6.4m N-S; 5.94m E-W; diam. of mound 1.86-2m; H from mound to fosse 0.03m; D of fosse 0.1m. E site: Diam. 6.11m N-S; 6.8m E-W; diam. of mound 2.52-2.19m; H from mound to fosse 0.07m; D of fosse 0.05m. S site: Diam. 8.5m N-S; 9.5m E-W; diam. of mound 3.1m; H from mound to fosse 0.05m; D of fosse 0.1m. The S site is quite denuded at E and it is difficult to determine its extent. The mound itself, however, is quite visible as is the fosse at W; it shows up well on the aerial photograph.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Internal diam. 15m. This site consists of a circular raised area surrounded by a fosse and an external bank. There are slight traces of an external fosse on the S side. At present there are two gaps in the bank, one in the W sector linked by a causeway to the interior. The latter is probably original. It is situated on high ground in hilly grazing land.  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

In the centre of a larger barrow (TS058-012----) in low-lying wet pasture on a very slight S-facing slope with a second large barrow (TS058-012001-) immediately to the W. Circular area (diam. 6m) defined by an earthen bank (Wth at top 0.4m; overall Wth 1.2m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.1m). The bank is best preserved SW-N and E-SE where the profile is low but consistent being barely visible elsewhere. The interior of is level, slightly lower than external ground level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a very slight S-facing slope in low-lying wet pasture with a barrow (TS058-012002-) located at its centre and another immediately to the W (TS058-012001-). Circular area (diam. 16m) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 2.4m; H 0.4m). At the external base of the scarp is the first fosse (Wth at base 1.6m; D 0.05-0.2m) and the first earthen bank (Wth at top 0.8m; overall Wth 2.8m; H 0.1m), a second fosse (Wth at base 1.4m; D 0.05m), a second earthen bank (Wth at top 1.7m; overall Wth 3.9m; H 0.2m), a third fosse (Wth at base 1.1m; D 0.05m) and a third outer earthen bank (Wth at top 3.1m; overall Wth 5.3m; H 0.25m). The second fosse, second bank, third fosse and outer bank enclose the ring-barrow NW-NE only and are not visible elsewhere at ground level. The external edge of the barrow (TS058-012001-) immediately to the W of this monument lies 1.9m outside the external base of the first bank and across the line of the absent outer banks and fosses WSW-NW. The interior is slightly domed and clear of overgrowth with a barrow (TS058-012002-) located at the centre.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Cropmark of bank and internal fosse of small circular enclosure (diam. <20m) visible in aerial photograph (GSIAP, R699).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cork. Volume 4: North Cork' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2000). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 14 January 2009

Dungravenen, a very spectacular promontory fort (DG107-052001-) isolated by an earthen bank and rock-cut fosse. A causeway crosses the fosse indicating the probable location of the entrance. The interior is fairly level except for a horseshoe-shaped mound (DG107-052002-) with a surrounding ditch to the S of the causeway entrance. There are traces of a low earthen bank around the internal perimeter. Inside the fort is a rock-cut souterrain (DG107-052003-) open in three places to the E, N and S. Only the latter opening affords an entry. It is .47m deep and leads to a N-S running passage 4.06m long, .75m high and 1.2m wide. This widens to 1.32m and 0.88m high at its N end to lead to a central area. This is 1.4m high, 3.7m W-E and 1.5m N-S. Part of the N wall of this chamber is of masonry and contains a small wall cupboard, .3m long .4m high and 0.54m deep. At the E is a low stone 'bench' or slab .83m × 0.33m resting .15m above the floor on two stone supports. Behind this is the blocked up E chamber/passage which viewed from the E surface opening is at least 3.7m long and 1.7m wide. To the W of the central chamber is a rock-cut-opening 1.53m wide and 0.89m high which leads to a chamber 1m high and 3.9m long. A doorway comprising of a lintel resting on a portal stone to the E, and masonry to the W forms the entry to the N passage/chamber which is 1.98m long, .8m wide and 0.68m in height. There is an opening to the surface at the N end of this. All the chambers and passage are roofed with flagstones. This promontory fort is located on the N side of the Erne estuary close to the town of Ballyshannon.  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

On a very slight S-facing slope in low-lying wet pasture with a barrow (TS058-012----) immediately to the E. Circular area (diam. 18m) defined by an earthen scarp (Wth 1.8-2.2m; H 0.5m). At the external base of the scarp is a fosse (Wth at base 1.4m; D 0.1m) and an external earthen bank (Wth at top 1.7-3.2m; overall Wth 4.2-5.2m; H 0.1-0.4m). The barrow (TS058-012001-) immediately to the E of this monument lies 1.9m outside the external base of the bank with the E edge of this barrow extending across the line of the absent outer banks and fosses of the neighbouring barrow. A modern entrance (Wth 8m) cuts through the external bank at N with a causeway across the fosse. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Internal diam. 10.9m N-S, 12m E-W. A low mound up to .37m high, enclosed by a fosse c. 0.4m in width. There are traces of a low external bank c. 0.1m high and up to 4.2m wide on the S half. It is situated in good pasture in the basin of the Owenea river.  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

On a rise in pastureland within the former demesne of Earlstown House. This roughly circular ring-barrow (diam. 14.2m), in fair condition, is defined by a flat-topped earthen mound (diam. 10m; H 0.3m) which is surrounded by a fosse and a low external bank. Several mature trees are growing on the mound. Two tree ring enclosures lie c. 50m to SE and NW. The barrow may have been reused as a landscape feature.              Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

Towards the bottom of a S-facing slope. Circular overgrown platform (diam. of top 9.3m E-W; diam. of base 13.5m E-W; H 0.3-0.4m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 8.5-9.7m; Wth of base 3-3.2m; D 0.5-0.9m) and outer bank (Wth 5.3-6.4m; H 0.3-0.7m) which is incorporated into a field bank WSW-NNW. A NW-SE field bank truncates the bank and fosse at NW. There is no visible entrance (max. ext. diam. 31.5m E-W). Earthwork (RO035-084----) is c. 150m to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Internal diam. c. 5.5m. A circular area enclosed by a fosse and an external bank. There is a causeway entrance on the E side. It is situated in good grazing land on a gently sloping ridge. Nearby is the similar site (DG107-096).  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Attached image: DG107-095-----01.JPG shows barrow viewed from E, with ranging rod marking causeway  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Marked as a circular embanked enclosure (ext. diam. c. 40m) on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map and as a circular wooded feature (diam. c. 40m) on the 1928 ed. Situated at the summit of a broad hill, and described as a low mound and ditch that may have been a ring-barrow (Gannon 1972), it is not visible at ground level in reclaimed pasture.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Internal diam. 7.5m. A circular raised area enclosed by a fosse and external earthen bank. There is a causeway entrance on the W side but also many modern breaks in the bank. The interior is very uneven. It is situated E of (DG107-095) on the same elevated ridge.  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

On the flat shoulder of a W-facing slope of rising ground in an upland area, overlooking Gortnageragh river valley from S through W to N. Possible enclosures (TS044-003---- and TS044-002----) are 220m to the N and 1km to the NE respectively. A well-preserved ring-barrow consisting of a low mound (diam. 4m N-S; H 0.2m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.45m) and external bank (Wth 2.4m; ext. H 0.3m). It is visible as a small enclosure on an aerial photograph (GSI R. 305/6; 08/04/74).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Internal diam. 9.6m. A level platform defined by a fosse, a bank, a second fosse and bank and an outer fosse. The earthen banks are all very low and the fosses very shallow. A causeway enters the enclosure from the E. The site is located on the shoulder of a ridge in rough pasture with good views and to the E of a fine ringfort (DG107-021).  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

On a low rise in an undulating landscape. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 3m) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 2-2.5m; int. H 0.35m at N to 0.7m at S; ext. H 0.35-0.7m) surrounded by a berm (Wth 4-4.6m) defined by a scarp (H 1.5m) (ext. diam. of top 16m N-S; max. ext. diam. of base 26.3m N-S). Rath (RO016-026----) is c. 120m to the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a level, low-lying landscape. Circular grass and rush-covered platform (diam. 27-27.5m; H 0.6-0.7m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 14-15.2m) with an outer earthen bank (Wth 4.6m at E to 7.9m at N; int. H 0.2m at S to 0.75m at E; ext. H 0.3m at W to 0.7m at E). A second complete fosse (Wth of top 8m at S to 12.5m at W) is surrounded by a second outer bank (Wth 3.8-5.4m; int. H 0.1-0.95m; ext. H 0.1-0.8m) W-N-S with a third fosse (Wth of top 3.8m at N to 8.5m at E; D 0.05m at N to 0.75m at E) W-N-SE. A NNW-SSE drain cuts the outer fosse at W, and an ENE-WSW drain cuts the outer fosse at S (max. ext. dims c. 110m E-W; c. 100m N-S). Barrow (RO006-164----) is c. 50m to the S. Archaeological monitoring (03E0070) c. 100m to the NNE during 2003 failed to produce any related material (Read 2006b).  See the attached aerial images taken from the NW (001) and NE (002).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Located c. 180m N of the Cauteen river, in pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m) with an internal fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 11 March 2014; 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Tom Condit and by Jean-Charles Caillère. It is one of three ring-barrows in close proximity (TS050-027----; TS050-028----; TS050-029----) with another ring-barrow c. 75m to the SE. There is also an embanked enclosure (TS050-024----) c. 550m to the NNW and a bowl-barrow (TS050-026----) c. 460m to the N.See attached:TS050-027----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 11 March 2014)TS050-027----_02 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2018)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 11 January 2022

In improved, wet pasture, on a gentle SW-facing slope. Circular area (dims. 4.75m N-S; 5.25m E-W) defined by fosse (overall Wth 1.7m; D 0.1m) W-NE which is best defined (overall Wth 2.4m; basal Wth 1.1m; D 0.1m) NE-W. Remains of levelled outer bank (Wth 3.5-4.45m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1-0.15m). Interior is level. Tertiary road is 40m to SE. Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Located c. 110m N of the Cauteen river, in pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m) with an internal fosse, visible on satellite imagery (© Google Earth, imagery date 11 March 2014; 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Tom Condit and by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is a cluster of three ring-barrows (TS050-027----; TS050-028----; TS050-029----) c. 60-75m to the NW. Situated on poorly drained land in an upland area with a stream immediately to the S. The site consists of a small circular area enclosed by a fosse and outer bank. The overall diameter of the site measures 6m. (Pers. comm. Eamon Cody). Unable to locate site at time of visit.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In lush, level pasture. Monument identified during ASI fieldwork. A circular area (diam. 4.5m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.65m; D 0.06m) and the possible remains of a levelled bank (overall Wth 3.4m; Wth at top 2m; int. H 0.06m; ext. H 0.13m). The interior is level and low in profile.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

In very gently undulating pasture. Monument identified during ASI fieldwork. A circular area (dims. 4.5m N-S; 3.75m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.15m) amd the remains of an outer bank (overall Wth 2.5m; Wth at top 1.25m; int. H 0.05m; ext. H 0.07m) SSE-SW and W-NE. The interior is level and monument is incorporated into the rest of the field as pasture.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

Internal diam. 6m. A circular raised area enclosed by a fosse and an external earthen bank. There is a causeway across the fosse to the W and the interior is very uneven. It is located W of sites (DG107-023003-) and (DG107-023002-).  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Internal diam. 8.3m. A circular slightly raised space enclosed by a fosse and an external earthen bank. There is a causeway to the SE. It is situated W of (DG107-023003-).  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

This site was identified during Phase II test excavation of the N8 Cashel to Mitchelstown road improvement scheme carried out in May 2006. The site was subsequently excavated between 27 June and 12 July 2006. This site consisted of a ring-barrow located near the brow of a gradual north-west-facing slope. There was one cremation burial centrally placed in the barrow and at least four token deposits of cremated bone were found in the fill of the ditch. This site enclosed an area 7m in diameter. The ditch was U-shaped in profile, with gradually sloping sides and a concave base. It had a maximum depth of 0.43m. The western extent of the ring-ditch was truncated and the ditch only survived to a depth of 0.15m.  This site was located c. 550600m to the east of two fulachta fiadh (Site 4602A2, see No. 1244 above, E2339; and Site 4705, see No. 1242 above, E2306) and 80m to the east of an enclosure site with a possible industrial function (see No. 1283 below, Site 47001B, E2342) (Excavations 2006 Site No. 1282; McQuade; Molloy & Moriarty 2009, 163-5).

Internal diam. 12m. A circular area slightly raised above the surrounding field enclosed by an internal fosse and an earthen bank. At the W side there is a causeway across the fosse leading to a gap in the bank. Situated on the E edge of a ridge of well-drained grazing land, with good views over the Erne valley to the S. Beside it are two similar monuments (DG107-023002, DG107-023001-).  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated in level pasture at the bottom of a N-facing slope, overlooking Oakport Lough to the E. It was first identified by Susan Curran as part of an M.A. thesis with University College Dublin using a LiDAR survey dataset commissioned by Leitrim County Council and the National Roads Authority. This is an oval area (dims 30m N-S; 24m E-W) defined by a low bank (at N: Wth 7.1m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.25m) with slight traces of an internal fosse (at N: Wth of top 5.2m; Wth of base 1.8m; D 0.2m) that is best preserved SSE-W-NE. The perimeter at E is disturbed by a small oval, grass-covered quarry (dims c. 4m N-S; c. 3.2m E-W; D 0.3m) and associated up-cast.   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 11 May, 2015

Internal diam. 13m. A circular raised area enclosed by an internal fosse 2.5m wide, an earthen bank 1.6m high, and an exter-nal fosse 1.75m wide. It is possible that the ground outside the external fosse has been artifically raised. The site is very overgrown. It is situated on high ground sloping S towards a cliff edge overlooking Donegal Bay.  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

On a rise in an E-W valley bottom. Circular grass-covered and domed area (diam. 29m NNW-SSE; H 1.7m) separated by a berm (Wth of base 2.3-3.9m) from a flat-topped earthen bank (Wth of base 4.2-5.4m; Wth of top 2.5-3.7m; int. H 0.1-0.2m; ext. H 0.3-0.6m). This is surrounded by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of base 2.6-4.1m; D 0.1-0.2m). There is an entrance through the fosses and bank (Wth 7m) at NE (max. ext. diam. 52m NNW-SSE). Archaeological testing (04E0813) c. 80m to the SSE in 2004 failed to produce any related material (Channing 2007).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level grassland. Well-preserved roughly circular ring-barrow (29.6m N-S; 27.3m E-W) comprising a flat-topped central platform (diam. 14m; max. H 0.5m) encircled by a fosse and external bank. A number of large boulders abutting the N sector of the central platform are suggestive of a revetment. A gap (Wth 5.3m) in the bank at WNW could be original. A number of hawthorn bushes are growing on the monument.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

On a gentle S-facing slope in a fold with sligthly higher ground to the NW and E. Subcircular scrub-covered platform (dims of top 12.7m E-W; 9.4m N-S; dims of base 16.8m E-W; 15m N-S) defined by a low bank (Wth 2.5-5m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.6-0.9m) and hedge NW-NE and at S, and by a scarp at E (H 1.3m) and W (H 0.6m). There is no visible fosse or identifiable original entrance, but field banks in the vicinity, except an E-W one 5m to the N, have been removed. Ring-barrow (RO042-076----) is c. 195m to the NNE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a rise in a fold with slightly higher ground to the NW and E. Described as a low mound (diam. c. 13m) surrounded by a slight fosse and outer bank (Gannon 1972). It is now a circular scrub-covered platform (diam. 19.2m N-S; 18.4m E-W) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 2.4-4.5m; int. H 0.2-0.5m; ext. H 0.55-1.35m) with no visible fosse. The perimeter is slightly truncated by a N-S road bank at E (max. ext. diam. 25m N-S). Ring-barrow (RO044-077----) is c. 195m to the SSW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level pasture with yellow ragweed. Circular area (diam. c. 18m) defined by an internal fosse (Wth 3m; Dth 0.05), a wide low outer bank (Wth 5.2m; int. H 0.05m; ext. H 0.05m), traces of an external fosse (Wth 1.7m; D 0.2-0.4m) are also visible. A second low profile bank (Wth 5m; H 0.2-0.4m) evident and second external fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.15m) is outside latter. Third external bank (Wth 3m; H 0.15m) and a third external fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.05m) define outer edges of monument respectively. Curvilinear feature extending around monument NW-N-E-SSE as shown on aerial photo (Air Corps V. 311/2946-7; R505/6) may be a land drain or levelled field boundary. Stream defines S side of monument. Earthworks possible (TS067-052002-) enclose monument to N and E.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Marked as a circular enclosure on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on the summit of an E-W ridge towards the W end. Circular flat-topped and grass-covered mound (diam. of top 8.3m N-S; diam. of base 13.5m N-S; H 0.2-0.5m) separated by a fosse (Wth of base 3.8m at N to 7.5m at S; D 0.45-0.55m) from an outer earth and stone bank (Wth 4.8-5m; int. H 0.45-0.55m; ext. H 0.15-0.3m) which is disturbed NNE-ENE. There are traces of an external fosse or drain (at WSW: Wth of base 1.4m) most evident SSW-WSW (max. ext. diam. 34.5m N-S). Rath (RO051-070----) is c. 140m to the E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the crest of the S-facing slope of a NW-SE ridge. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. of top 11.7m NE-SW; diam. of base 17m NE-SW; H 0.55-0.65m) separated by a fosse (Wth of top 8.3-8.8m; Wth of base 3.5-5.5m; D 0.45m at NE to 1.55m at SW) from an outer bank (at NE: Wth 4.2m; ext. H 0.75m; at SW: Wth 8.5m; ext. H 1.75m). There is no identifiable entrance, but spoil has been added inside the bank NE-SSE and W-N (max. ext. diam. 38.6m NE-SW).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a S-facing slope in upland terrain, in reclaimed rough pasture. A circular enclosure (int. diam. c. 6m; overall diam. c. 14m), which appears to be defined by a fosse and outer bank, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is an enclosure (TS051-044----) c. 300m to the S.  See attached: TS051-055----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2018)   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 7 January 2022

Located in improved pasture toward the NE end of the crest of a NE-SW ridge. It was first identified by Susan Curran as part of an M.A. thesis with University College Dublin using a LiDAR survey dataset commissioned by Leitrim County Council and the National Roads Authority. This is a circular area (diam. 34m NE-SW; 34m NW-SE) defined by a scarp that is best preserved (at NE: Wth 2m; H 0.4m) SW-N-NE but declines to a slighter scarp (at SE: Wth 1m; H 0.1m) NE-SW. There is an outer fosse (at NE: Wth of top 5.2m; Wth of base 1.8m; ext. D 0.15m) and external bank (at NE: Wth of base 4.6m; Wth of top 2m; ext. H 0.15m) W-NE, but the fosse is also traceable NE-SE. There is no visible entrance. The monument is overlain by a NE-SW field bank and hedge towards the edge at SE.   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 11 May, 2015

Just S of the summit of Sheep Hill which has a trig. station The name of this hill was recorded in Irish by John O'Donovan in the 1830s as Cnoc Loinge - Ship hill (Herity 2010, 15). The barrow is a circular grass-covered mound containing some stone (diam. 3.8m; H 0.1-0.3m) and with a slight hollow (diam. 1.7m) defined by a slight fosse (Wth of base 0.6m; ext. D 0.2-0.3m) and outer bank (Wth 2m; H 0.1m) (max. ext. diam. 9m). The possible rath (RO051-021----) is c. 100m to the E and wayside cross (RO051-023----) is c. 80m to the SSW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In wet undulating hummocky terrain with a river flowing c. 90m to the SW, in pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m), which appears to have an internal fosse, visible as a cropmark on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. Its size and morphology suggest that this is a possible ring-barrow.See attached:TS059-178----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 18 November 2018)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 11 January 2022

Located at the base of a SW-facing slope on slightly undulating ground in pasture. Depicted on the 1954-5 OS 6-inch revision as an irregular hollow. A roughly circular area (diam. 33.5m E-W), the S portion being truncated by a road on a NW-SE axis. The site is defined by an internal scarp (H 1.19m), a fosse (Wth 7.5m; D 1.24m) and an earthen outer bank (Wth 3.9m; ext. H 0.78m). There is a causeway in the NE quadrant. Old field banks abut the NW sector. The site is damaged by uprooted trees and cattle poaching.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In level pastureland. This poorly preserved overgrown circular ring-barrow (diam. 22.6m), which is partly obscured by furze and hawthorn growth, comprises a flat-topped raised area (diam. 10.8m; max. H 0.2m) surrounded by a fosse, with slight traces of an external bank from SW to W. On inspection in February 1985 an old field bank abutted it at SE and at N a narrow drain ran N for 7m. Current aerial imagery (Google 2019) indicates that the field boundary has since been removed. A bowl-barrow (GA100-103001-) lies c. 30m to the SE. de Valera and Ó Nualláin (1972, 29) noted a possible third one (GA100-103002-) c. 25m to the SSW.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

Situated on a natural rise on top of a broad, flat ridge, sloping slightly to NNE, in upland pasture; extensive views in all directions. A raised mound, truncated by a N-S field boundary on the E side (diam. 9.8m N-S; 7.7m E-W). The site is enclosed by a narrow, deep, water-logged fosse (Wth 1.2m; D 0.56m) and a well-preserved outer bank (Wth 0.8m at crest, 2.6m at base; int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.63m). In the SW quadrant there is a large prostrate boulder (L 3m; max. Wth 1.5m; T 0.28-0.33), split in two, with a hollow beneath. The stone, composed of shaley limestone, tapers towards the SW end and is possibly the capstone of a cist (TN033-039002).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

On the NW-facing slope of Redmount Hill. This roughly circular ring-barrow (42.8m NNE-SSW; 41.5m ESE-WNW), in fair condition, comprises a low flat-topped central mound encircled by a fosse and external bank. The line of the fosse is indicated by a darker band of vegetation. The bank has been almost completely ploughed out.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 14 August 2019

Situated on high pasture in an upland region with extensive views to the W and NW over Nenagh river valley. A nearby hut site (TN033-049) lies c. 200m to the NE. A low circular mound (H 0.4m; diam. 6m NW-SE; 4.9m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.5-1m) and an outer earthen bank (Wth 1.6m; ext. H 0.25m) which is best preserved at SE. A field boundary extends across the W side of the site on a N-S axis destroying the bank and partially filling the fosse at W.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

In wet pasture, on a W-facing slope. Monument identified during ASI fieldwork. A low profile, circular area (dims. 4.5m NNE-SSW; 4m ESE-WNW) defined by a fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.05-0.1m) and outer bank (Wth 3.3m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.05m) which is traceable from W-NW and NE-SE. There is a deep pocket of erosion at the N possibly caused by livestock. The fosse and outer bank have been truncated by a land drain (long axis WNW-ESE) across the SW sector.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

In wet pasture surrounded by streams. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 10m), which appears to have an internal fosse, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. Its size and morphology suggest that this is a possible ring-barrow. There are a number of other possible ring-barrows (TS059-158----; TS059-179----; TS059-181----; TS059-182----; TS059-183----; TS059-184----; TS059-187----; TS059-188----; TS059-189----; TS059-190----; TS059-191----; TS059-192----; TS059-193----) in the vicinity.See attached:TS059-182----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 12 January 2022

In wet pasture surrounded by streams. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 15m), which appears to have an internal fosse, visible as a cropmark on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. Its size and morphology suggest that this is a possible ring-barrow. There are a number of other possible ring-barrows (TS059-158----; TS059-179----; TS059-181----; TS059-182----; TS059-183----; TS059-184----; TS059-187----; TS059-188----; TS059-189----; TS059-190----; TS059-191----; TS059-192----; TS059-193----) in the vicinity.See attached:TS059-181----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 12 January 2022

In reclaimed upland pasture. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 15m), defined by a fosse and a possible outer bank, visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is a mound barrow (TS045-006----) c. 560m to the NW and within the Losset townland there is a ring-barrow (TS045-010----) 1km to the E and a standing stone (TS045-002----) c. 960m to the NE.  See attached: TS045-028----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 7 January 2022

Situated on a S-facing slope of poorly drained ground in an upland region surrounded by modern coniferous plantation. A low poorly preserved irregular-shaped mound (Dims. 5m N-S; H 0.5m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.3m) and outer bank (Wth 1.5m; H 0.1m) visible at N only. The bank is intersected at N by a townland boundary extending NE-SW.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated on a N-facing slope of rising ground in an upland area. A well-preserved circular flat-topped mound (H 1m; top diam. 7.8m) enclosed by a wide, flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 5.5m; D 0.5m) with no surviving evidence of an external bank. Laneway to N destroys enclosing fosse.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Within the interior of an enclosure (TS059-112003-), incorporated into the E bank. A circular area (dims. 4m N-S; 5m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.07m) from ESE-W-NE, which is best defined (Wth 1.95m; D 0.25m) from NE-ESE, and an outer bank (Wth 2.35m; int. H 0.07m; ext. H 0.05m) SE-W-N. The interior is grass covered and has a W-facing slope.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a knoll on a NW-facing slope overlooking Lough Melvin. This is a grass-covered circular and dished mound (diam. 9.1m N-S; 8.9m E-W; H 0.1-0.3m) defined by a fosse or berm (Wth 0.6m) and an outer bank (Wth 1.9-2.2m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.35m at N to 1-1.4m generally) (max. ext. diam. 18.4m E-W; 17.7m N-S). There is a faint causeway (Wth c. 1.5m) at SW. The ceremonial enclosure (LE008-004001-) is c. 80m to the SSW and the mound barrow (LE008-002----) is c. 35m to the W.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

Situated on flat poorly drained grassland with good views in all directions.  Bowl-barrow (TN015-024----) in field 128m to NE and fulacht fiadh (TN015-124----) to S.  Impressive well preserved ring-barrow (overall diam. 60m N-S) consisting of a low circular mound (diam. 23m N-S; H 0.1m) enclosed by a shallow  inner fosse (base Wth 4m; top Wth 7m; ext. D 0.1m), earthen bank (top Wth 2.8m; base Wth 9m; ext. H 0.4m), waterlogged outer fosse (base Wth 2.3m; top Wth 4.6m; ext. D 0.2m) with remains of a second earthen bank (Wth 4m; ext. H 0.1m) mainly reduced to a scarp.  The enclosing inner bank and external fosse has been damaged on the E side when drainage ditches were cut into the monument in the 19th century.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 21 May 2015

In good, level pasture. Monument identified during ASI fieldwork. A circular area (diam. 6.5m) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.35m; D 0.1m) and a poorly preserved outer bank (Wth 3.7m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.15m).   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

On the crest of a low N-S ridge in an undulating landscape. Circular grass-covered mound which has been distorted by quarrying (diam. of base c. 5m; H 0.2-0.4m) separated by a berm or fosse (Wth 0.7-1.4m) from an outer earthen bank (Wth 5.9-6.2m; int. H 0.3-0.4m; ext. H 0.6-0.7m). The monument slopes down to the SW (max. ext. diam.18.7m NNE-SSW) and a trig. station is built on the outer bank at NE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on the gentle SW-facing slope of a hill, in pasture. A circular site (12.8m N-S; 12.8m E-W) consisting of a central mound (diam. 4.8m; H 0.26m), a narrow, U-shaped fosse (W 1.7m; D 0.86m) and an outer bank (W 2m; ext. H 0.14m). The bank is steep-sided and the fosse is well defined with some rushes growing in it.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

On top of high ground in upland area with good views in all directions. Nearby standing stone (TS045-002----) to NW. Well-preserved ring-barrow consisting of a low circular flat-topped mound (diam. 10m SW-NE; H 1.35m) enclosed by a waterlogged fosse (Wth 2.9m; ext. D 1.5m) and external bank (top Wth 3m; base Wth 6m; ext. H 1m), the outer face of which has been partially cut into in places. Large limestone slab (L. 2.45m x H 0.68m x Wth 0.5m) protruding from base of waterlogged fosse in S quadrant. Fosse appears to either have been filled in partially or totally from E to SE. May have had an original ramped entrance feature at SE with fosse filling up with peaty soil in SE sector giving the appearance that it has today of a wide earthen ramp leading into the central mound.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Internal diam. c. 5m. A circular area enclosed by an internal fosse 2.7m in width and 0.3m deep and an earthen bank now only surviving on the N and W sides to a height of .35m. It is situated on a low hill in wet marshy land and is very overgrown.The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.Date of upload: 22 September 2008

At the NW edge of a low knoll in gently undulating pastureland with good views towards the NW, N and NE. This fairly well-defined subcircular ring-barrow (ext. dims. 29.1m E-W; 26.3m N-S) consists of a gently sloping roughly circular central area (diam. 10.4m N-S; 9.1m E-W) that slopes down very gently from NW to SE (0.3m over a distance of 10m) and which is defined by a shallow flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 0.9m at W; 2.9m at N; D 0.1-0.3m) and by a low outer earthen bank (Wth. 5.2m at S; 6.6m at E; H 0.1-0.2m). A small portion of the outer bank has been dug away, in the past, between ENE and ESE.    Compiled by: Olive Alcock  Date of upload: 31 July 2017

In a level marshy field adjacent to a stream. This circular earthwork (diam. 14.5m) is delimited by a low  bank and external fosse. The interior is slightly dished in profile which suggests that it may be a ring-barrow.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 16 July 2019

Towards the bottom of an ENE-facing slope overlooking a NW-SE valley. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 6.7m E-W; 6m N-S; H 0.2-0.4m) separated by a rounded fosse (Wth of top 4.7m at E to 7m at W; Wth of base 1.3-2.8m; D 0.5-0.8m) from an outer bank (Wth c. 4m; H 0.1m) which has an opening (Wth 3m) at W (max. ext. diam. 24m E-W; 23m N-S).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Towards to top of the SE-facing slope of Fairymount Hill. Circular grass and furze-covered platform (diam. 14.7m NE-SW; 14m NW-SE; H 0.1-0.3m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of base 2-3m; D 0.5-0.6m SE-SW to 0.8-0.9m NW-NE) and an outer flat-topped bank (Wth of base 2.7-3.7m generally to 6m at NW; Wth of top 0.9-1.2m; H 0.3m at NE to 0.7-1.1m generally). There is an entrance (Wth 1m) at SE and the monument is circumscribed by a field bank and drain NNW-NE (max. ext. diam. 30.7m NW-SE; 27.2m NW-SE). Barrow (RO036-013001-) is c. 110m to the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On top of a broad, low NNW-SSE ridge. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. of top 11.5m E-W; diam. of base 14.2m; H 0.8-0.9m) separated by a fosse (Wth of top 4.6-6.1m; Wth of base 1.9-3.4m; D 0.65-1.1m) from an outer bank with some scrub (Wth 4.4-6m; ext. H 0.4-1.15m). There is no visible entrance (max. ext. diam. 30m E-W).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Visible on aerial photographs (GSIAP: M 469-8), and situated on a slight rise in an undulating landscape. Circular grass and scrub-covered mound (diam. of top 13.4m NNE-SSW; diam. of base 17m NNE-SSW; H 0.7-0.85m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 4m; Wth of base 1-1.2m; D 0.45-0.7m) and outer bank (Wth 4.5-6m; H 0.75-0.95m) which is overgrown (max. ext. diam. 29.5m NNE-SSW).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked only on the 1915 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on a slight NE-facing slope in a low-lying landscape. Circular grass and moss-covered mound with a dished top (diam. of base 14m NE-SW; 13.4m NW-SE; dims of top 6.2m NE-SW; 4.3m NW-SE; H 1m at SW to 1.4-1.6m) separated by a fosse (Wth of base 1.9-2.2m; D 0.3-0.8m) from an outer bank (Wth of base 3.5-4.2m; ext. H 0.2-0.4m). There is no visible entrance and the outer bank is truncated slightly by a NW-SE lane at W (max. ext. diam. 26.4m NW-SE).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On top of a hillock overlooking a broad basin S-W-NE. Circular, domed, grass-covered mound (diam. 20m N-S; 20m E-W; H 0.9-1.5m), which may be the natural hill, defined by a berm (Wth 2.5-4m) which is bordered by a scarp (H 0.5-0.8m). The base (dims 28m NNE-SSW; 27m WNW-ESE) is cut back at NW where there is a straight edge (L 14.5m) parallel with an ENE-WSW field bank that is 10m distant. There is no visible fosse or entrance, but there is an earthfast stone (RO048-109002-) with an oval cross-section (dims 1m x 0.6m; H 0.8m) 8m to the S.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the bottom of a broad NW-SE valley. Circular overgrown platform (diam. 7m) defined by a fosse (at NE: Wth of top 5m; Wth of base 2.2m; int. D 1.05m; ext. D 1.3m) separated by a bank (at NE: Wth of top 0.9m; Wth of base 5.1m; ext. H 1.35m) from an outer fosse (at NE: Wth of top 7m; Wth of base 3.3m; ext. D 0.75m) and second outer bank (at NE: Wth of top 1.2m; Wth of base 3.7m; ext. H 0.35m). The entire monument is completely overgrown (max. ext. diam. c. 39m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the bottom of an E-facing slope. Subcircular grass-covered platform (dims 16m E-W; 13.8m N-S; H 0.2m at W to 1m at E) defined by a fosse (at S: Wth of top 7.2m; Wth of base 2.8m; ext. D 0.5m) and outer bank (Wth of base 6-7m; ext. H 0.2-0.4m), with an outer fosse (Wth of top 4.6m; ext. D 0.8m) SE-SW. The monument is curtailed by a N-S drain and field bank at E, and relict field banks and ditches at W and N. Church (RO042-097001-) is c. 50m to the SW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on an E-facing slope in undulating pasture. A circular area (diam. 22.8m N-S; 21.4m E-W; H 0.68m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth 3.8m; D 0.7m) and outer bank (Wth 3.5m; ext. H 0.75m). A large conglomerate boulder lies on the central mound at SW partially resting on small stones. It may have been dumped here, but is certainly there as long as the landowner remembers. The outer bank is planted with larch trees and it is likely that the site was reused as a tree-ring for Bantis House which is located to the NE.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on a very slight N-facing slope in pasture-land. Indicated on the 1903 ed. OS 6-inch map as a small oval area at the junction of three field boundaries. A circular area (diam. 8m; H 0.85m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 3.3m; D 0.52m) and an outer bank (Wth 2.8m; ext. H 0.57m). Overall diameter 16.9m N-S; 17.6m E-W. The bank on the N side has been augmented to build up a SW-NE field boundary. The E side also has a field boundary joining it but it has not been built up. Much stone protrudes from the outer bank.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In poorly drained pasture. Monument identified during ASI fieldwork. A circular area (dims. 4.2m N-S; 4m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 1.45-1.95m; D 0.1-0.15m) and outer bank (Wth 3m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1m) evident from E-S. The interior is grass covered and level. Small, slightly higher area of ground to NE. Monument is located on a raised, sub-oval area (dims. c. 17m N-S; 14m E-W) defined by a low scarp. A field boundary c. 14m to the NE is densely overgrown with furze (c. 6-8m deep). An enclosure (TS059-059----) is c. 16m to WSW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

On flat partially reclaimed grassland in upland area with good views to the E. The ring-barrow consists of a well-preserved low circular flat-topped platform(diam. 4m N-S; 4m E-W; H 0.2m) enclosed by an inner fosse (base Wth 1.5m; top Wth 3m; ext. D 0.2m) and outer bank (base Wth 4m; top wth 2.5m; ext. H 0.4m). Overall diameter 12.9m NW-SE; 11.1m SW-NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on a gradual, subtle break in a NW-facing slope in hilly terrain, under pasture. The site is in the SE corner of a field with the field ditch skirting the monument at SE and SW. A standing stone (TN039-001001) is situated 3.6m to the NE. A roughly circular site (diam. 12.1m N-S; 12.9m E-W) consisting of a central mound (Wth 3.8-5.1m; H 0.53m), a deep, U-shaped fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.5m) and an outer bank (Wth 1.5m-2.1m; ext. H 0.65m). There is evidence of a stone cist (TN039-001003) in the centre of the mound with two long slabs exposed at right angles (L 1m x Wth 0.3m and L 0.67m x 0.16m). No visible entrance feature.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

At the bottom of a SW-facing slope and at the E edge of a broad, flat-bottomed NW-SE valley. Circular grass and scrub-covered mound (diam. of top 5m NE-SW; diam. of base 12.2m NE-SW; H 1.25-1.45m) separated by a fosse (Wth of top 6.2-8.7m; Wth of base 2.4m; D 0.4-0.6m) from an outer bank (at SW: Wth 5.2m; ext. H 0.45m) which has been truncated by a NE-SW field wall W-NNE (ext. diam. 23.5m NE-SW).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on poorly drained W facing slope overlooking Clodiagh River in mountain valley. River runs through base of mountain valley from N to S. Higher ground overlooks barrow to E. Well preserved site consisting of a low oval-shaped sunken area (diam. 7.5m N-S) enclosed by a slight bank (Wth 3m; int. H 0.1m) and outer fosse (base Wth 2m; ext. D 0.2m). Overall diameter of site measures 21m N-S; 16m E-W. Not clear whether the sunken area in the centre is enclosed by a bank or is this just a bank created by the sunken interior.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

On the shoulder of the S-facing slope of a broad hill. Described as a circular mound (diam. of top 7m) separated by a fosse from an outer bank (diam. 14m E-W; 13m N-S) (Gannon 1972). It is not visible now at ground level in pasture. Ring-barrow (RO045-051002-) is immediately to the S.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On the shoulder of the S-facing slope of a broad hill. Described as a circular mound (diam. of top 4-4.5m) separated by a fosse from an outer bank (diam. 10.5m N-S; 10.5m E-W) (Gannon 1972). It is not visible at ground level in pasture. Ring-barrow (RO045-051001-) is immediately to the N.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In good pasture, within N-area of medieval deserted settlement (TS059-127----). Monument identified during ASI fieldwork. A circular area (dims. 4.75m N-S; 4.75m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 2.25m; D 0.15m) and outer bank (Wth 3.85m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.15m). This is cordoned off within a small, square area defined by low banks of the deserted settlement. Another ring-barrow (TS059-146----) is located c. 150m to the ESE. It would appear that occupants of the later settlement respected these monuments.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

One of a group of four possible ring-barrows although their arrangement and state of preservation may suggest ring-feeders. Their size and siting on a steep slope and situated to a nearby ring-barrow suggests that they may be authentic ring-barrows. It would have been an unlikely location on a steep slope for a ring-feeder, local land-owner has no memory of ever using a ring-feeder in this field. Situated on the NW-facing slope of rising ground in upland area overlooking Clodiagh river valley to W, higher ground to E. Monument consists of a low circular mound (diam. 1.8m; H 0.2m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 2.5m; ext. D 0.2m) and outer bank (Wth 2.6m; ext. H 0.2m) which is visible only on the downward slope side from SW through W to NW only, not visible and doubt if ever there was an outer bank on the upslope side of the barrow. Overall the monument measures 10.5m in diameter N-S. This barrow has a second barrow (TN033-065002) located 12m to the NE and both of these barrows are located 20m to the W of the other two barrows (TN033-065; TN033-065001)  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

One of a group of four possible ring-barrows although their arrangement and state of preservation may suggest ring-feeders. Their size and siting on a steep slope and situated to a nearby ring-barrow suggests that they may be authentic ring-barrows. It would have been an unlikely location on a steep slope for a ring-feeder, local land-owner has no memory of ever using a ring-feeder in this field. Situated on the NW-facing slope of rising ground in upland area overlooking Clodiagh river valley to W, higher ground to E. Monument consists of a low circular mound (diam. 2m; H 0.2m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 3.5m; ext. D 0.2m) and outer bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.2m) which is visible only on the downward slope side from SW through W to NW only, not visible and doubt if ever there was an outer bank on the upslope side of the barrow. Overall the monument measures 10m in diameter N-S. This barrow has a second barrow (TN033-065003) located 12m to the SW and both of these barrows are located 20m to the W of the other two barrows (TN033-065; TN033-065001)  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

One of a group of four possible ring-barrows although their arrangement and state of preservation may suggest ring-feeders. Their size and siting on a steep slope and situated to a nearby ring-barrow suggests that they may be authentic ring-barrows. It would have been an unlikely location on a steep slope for a ring-feeder, local land-owner has no memory of ever using a ring-feeder in this field. Situated on the NW-facing slope of rising ground in upland area overlooking Clodiagh river valley to W, higher ground to E. Monument consists of a low circular mound (diam. 1.6m; H 0.2m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 2m; ext. D 0.2m) and outer bank (Wth 3m; ext. H 0.2m) which is visible only on the downward slope side from SW through W to NW only, not visible and doubt if ever there was an outer bank on the upslope side of the barrow. Overall the monument measures 10m in diameter N-S. This barrow has a second barrow (TN033-065001) conjoined to its NE side and both of these barrows are located 20m to the E of the other two barrows (TN033-065002; TN033-065003)  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

One of a group of four possible ring-barrows although their arrangement and state of preservation may suggest ring-feeders. Their size and siting on a steep slope and situated to a nearby ring-barrow suggests that they may be authentic ring-barrows. It would have been an unlikely location on a steep slope for a ring-feeder, local land-owner has no memory of ever using a ring-feeder in this field. Situated on the NW-facing slope of rising ground in upland area overlooking Clodiagh river valley to W, higher ground to E. Monument consists of a low circular mound (top diam. 2m; base diam 3m; H 0.2m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 3m; ext. D 0.2m) and outer bank (top Wth 2.5m; ext. H 0.2m) which is visible only on the downward slope side from SW through W to NW only, not visible and doubt if ever there was an outer bank on the upslope side of the barrow. Overall the monument measures 9m in diameter N-S. This barrow has a second barrow (TN033-065) conjoined to its SW side and both of these barrows are located 20m to the E of the other two barrows (TN033-065002; TN033-065003)  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

In good pasture, within NE-area of deserted settlement (TS059-127----). Monument identified during ASI fieldwork.
