A circular area (dims. 6.5m N-S; 5.8m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.15m) and the remains of low outer bank (Wth 4.2m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.05m) traceable SW-NNW and possibly at E. A bank (long axis N-S) of the deserted settlement is located c. 9m to E and another bank (long axis E-W) is located c. 26m to N. Another ring-barrow (TS059-147----) is located c. 150m to the WNW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 October 2013

Situated atop high ground with good panoramic views in all directions. Barely visible and much degraded site consisting of a low circular mound (diam. 1.5m; H 0.1m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 3m; ext. D 0.1m) and outer bank (Wth 3m ; ext. H 0.1m). The overall diameter of the site measures 11m N-S. The small size of the mound casts some doubts on its antiquity. May have been formed by the presence of a ring-feeder though not sure, its excellent panoramic views may suggest that this is a burial monument.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated on top of a natural rise of ground in an upland area with extensive views. A circular flat-topped mound (H 0.7m; top diam. 3.5m E-W; base diam. 7.5m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 3.6m) and a poorly preserved earthen outer bank (Wth 1.5m). Overall diameter 17.5m E-W.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on top of high ground in upland region with good panoramic views in all directions. Much degraded monument consisting of a barely visible circular mound (diam. 8m N-S ) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 2m; ext. D 0.2m) and slight traces of an outer bank (Wth 1m). A field boundary bisected the monument on a N-S axis. This field boundary has since been levelled. Monument is barely visible in the winter months and is probably not visible during the summer months.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Impressive well preserved ring-barrow situated on wet poorly drained grassland on N facing slope in upland area overlooking river valley below to W, higher ground to E. Well preserved monument consisting of a circular area (diam. 4.1m N-S; 4.1m E-W; H above fosse 0.6m) enclosed by an inner fosse (base Wth 1m; top Wth 1m; ext. D 0.5m) and outer bank (Top Wth. 1.8m; base Wth 1.8m; ext. H 0.5m). Gap in bank at NNW probably the result of livestock poaching, livestock gap. No other features visible. Site has good views looking down into mountain valley whch runs E-W . Overall diameter of monument 8.9m N-S x 9.8m E-W.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated on a break in an E-facing slope in upland terrain, under pasture. Extensive views in all directions except upslope to SW. A circular area (diam. 11.5m N-S; 11.4m E-W) consisting of a central mound (diam. 4.6m N-S; 4.7m E-W; H 0.23m) enclosed by a water-logged fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.26m) and well-preserved outer bank (Wth 1.9m; H 0.3m), partially denuded in the SE quadrant. There are three stones embedded in the N half of the central mound which appear to be set on edge, possibly indicating the presence of a cist (TN039-038002).  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated in pasture on fairly level ground, in mountainous region with good panoramic views in all directions. Much degraded monument that is barely visible as a low circular rise of ground (diam. 11m SE-NW; 10m NE-SW) defined by a fosse (Wth 2m; ext. D 0.2m) with the slightest traces of an outer bank. Site is severely degraded and is only visible during the winter months.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated in pasture, on a SE-facing slope of rising ground in a mountainous region. Well preserved monument consisting of a raised circular area (diam. 4m N-S; 3.7m E-W; H 0.3m) with sunken depression (diam. 3m) on top of mound, defined by an inner fosse (Wth 1m; ext. D 0.2m) with the slightest traces of an outer bank, only visible in places. Overall diameter 8m N-S. Central depression may be due to collapsed cist in centre of mound.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

In level pasture, in NE corner of field. Raised circular area (diam. c. 20m) defined by low earthen scarp (Wth 3.8m; H 0.75m). External fosse (Wth 9m top; 2m at base; D 0.6m). Remains of an outer bank (Wth 3.6m; int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.45) NE-SE, becomes thinner SE-WSW, eventually petering out. Causewayed entrance (Wth 5m) through outer bank, across fosse and through inner scarp (Wth 2.8m) into interior. Slightly raised (H 0.15m) circular area (diam. c. 5m) within centre of interior and with inner scarp sloping gently down toward it, gives impression of slight internal fosse. Arc of outer bank truncated very slightly to N by field boundary (long-axis E-W). Field boundary also close to E. Enclosure (TS068-035----) c. 80m to SSW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a slight E-facing slpoe at the E foot of Slieve Bawn. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 26m N-S; 25m E-W; H 0.6-0.9m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 3-3.7m; Wth of base 1.8-2.2m; D 0.4-0.7m) and an outer flat-topped bank (Wth of base 3.4-4.6m; Wth of top 2.2-2.6m; H 0.8-0.9m) with mature deciduous trees and scrub. There is no visible entrance.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated in a prominent position on top of a hillock in upland pasture, with extensive views in all directions except upslope to NW. This site has been ploughed over but is still visible. It consists of a circular mound (diam 3.3m; H 0.08m) enclosed by a water-logged and silted fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.3m) and outer bank (Wth 2.8; ext. H 0.2m) (overall diam. 16.1m N-S: 16m E-W). The outer bank is most denuded in the NW quadrant.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated in flat terrain on a valley floor in poorly drained land, under pasture. A roughly circular ring-barrow (diam. 19.1m N-S; 17.8m E-W) consisting of a circular mound (diam 10.7m; 0.42m H) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2-2.5m; D 0.37m) and outer bank (Wth 1.5m at crest, 3.7m at base; ext. H 0.31m). The mound has a central depression probably due to cattle erosion. A standing stone (TN040-040002) lies prostrate in the fosse at W and the outer bank is not visible at this point. Some stone protrudes from the central mound. According to local tradition this is the burial site of the 'Great Dane' and was part of the 'Jewel of Dane' estate. The fosse and central depression become waterlogged in the winter.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated in an undulating, low-lying position in the landscape. This is a grass-covered circular enclosure (ext. diam. 17m) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 2.9m; H 0.2m) and internal fosse (Wth of base 4.3m; D 0.45m). A gap (Wth 3.5m) in the bank at N may be modern. Archaeological testing (04E1299) c. 30m to the SW produced no related material (Read 2007).   The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

Situated in poorly drained land atop low hillock in upland area with panoramic views in all directions. Good views of the Devils Bit mountain to the NE, Slievenamon to the SW and Cooneen Hill. Field boundary intersects monument on an E-W axis. Monument consists of a low circular mound (diam. 6.2m E-W; 7m N-S) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 2m; ext. D 0.2m) and outer bank (top Wth 1m; base Wth 1.8m; ext. H 0.2m) which is intersected at N on an E-W axis. Overall dimater of monument measures 15.5m E-W; 12m N-S.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

In level pasture. visible as slight surface trace of raised (Wth c. 2m; H c. 0.2m) circular area (dims. c. 8m N-S; c. 8m E-W; H c. 0.35m) defined by scarp (Wth c. 0.2m; H c. 0.2m). Very slight fosse (Wth c. 2-3m in places; D c. 0.2m). Identified on an aerial photograph (GSI R.512/511, 16.4.1974).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated atop high ground in a mountainous region with extensive views. A well-preserved large ring-barrow consisting of a circular platform (diam. 17.5m N-S; 16m E-W) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 3m; ext. D 0.5m) and external bank (Wth 2.8m; int. H 0.75-1m; ext. H 0.5m). A small mound of field-clearance debris is dumped in the centre of the platform. The fosse was waterlogged from E to S at time of visit.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated atop high ground in a mountainous region with extensive views; nearby standing stone (TN028-004002) to NW. A circular platform (diam. 8.3m; H 0.3m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.5m) and external bank (Wth 1.8m; ext. H 0.5m).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on a N-facing slope in pasture-land amongst some rock outcrop in an upland region. Good views of mountain valley to the N, higher ground to the S. Site consists of a roughly rectangular shaped flat-topped platform (int. diam. 6m N-S; 3.1m E-W) or mound defined by a scarp (H 0.2m) and inner fosse (Wth 1m; ext. D 0.25m) with outer bank (top Wth. 0.7m; base Wth 1m; ext. H 0.2m). The shape of the central platform is unusual for a ring-barrow, which may cast doubts about its classification. The shape of the platfrom is more like ahut site but there is no eNtrance feature and there is an internal fosse. According to local folklore from the Schools Manuscript there was a legend that there was a grave of three kings in this townland. This folklore may have been associated with this monument.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

Situated on top of a prominent drumlin. This is a grass, rush and scrub-covered and slightly domed circular area (diam. 25m) defined by a fosse (Wth of base 2m at N to 4m at S; D below interior 0.6m generally to 0.8m at S) and an outer bank (at NNE: Wth 5m; ext. H 0.2m) which is incorporated into a field bank and hedge E-S. The monument is bisected by a NW-SE field bank.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

Situated on top of a broad drumlin. This is a grass and rush-covered circular area (diam. 30.6m N-S; 30.2m E-W; H 0.25-0.5m) defined by a fosse (Wth of base 2-2.5m) and an external bank (Wth of base 2.5-3m; ext. H 0.1-0.2m) NE-S-NW. There are traces of a second outer fosse (Wth 2m) SE-W-NW and slight traces of a second outer bank (Wth 3m) SW-NW. The banks and fosses are truncated by an E-W field drain and bank of a farm lane at N, and by a N-S field drain and bank at E.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 15 October 2019

Abutting enclosure (TS068-071----) to N. Raised circular area (dims. c. 5.25m N-S; c. 5m E-W) defined by gentle scarp (Wth 1.5m; H 0.25m), internal fosse (Wth 3.2m; D 0.25m) and external bank (Wth 2.9m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.15m) with stones protruding at E. Interior is level. Enclosures (TS068-145----) and (TS068-146----) are c. 150m and c. 175m to NW respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Located c. 70m W of the Marlow river, in wet pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m), which appears to have an internal fosse, visible as a cropmark on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. Its size and morphology suggest that this is a possible ring-barrow. There is another possible ring-barrow (TS046-069----) c. 11m to the NE.See attached:TS046-068----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 11 January 2022

Located c. 60m W of the Marlow river, in wet pasture. A circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m), which appears to have an internal fosse, visible as a cropmark on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 20 January 2020), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. Its size and morphology suggest that this is a possible ring-barrow. There is another possible ring-barrow (TS046-068----) c. 11m to the SW.See attached:TS046-069----_01 Google Earth image (imagery date 20 January 2020)Compiled by: Jean Farrelly Date of upload: 11 January 2022

Situated on a low rise of ground in undulating countryside with limited views in all directions. An aerial photograph (CUCAP, ATC 73) shows the faint outline of a mound with an internal fosse and an external bank. This is probably the site of a ring-barrow. Not visible at ground level.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated in on a NNE-facing slope immediately above the high, steep SSW bank of the River Finn. Rough mountainous terrain. Grass-covered, dome-shaped mound of earth and stone (dims. 5.2m ENE-WSW - 4.8m NNW-SSE; H 0.25m - 0.92). It is higher and better-defined at the ESE half of the site then the WNW. There is a well-defined depression (Wth. c. 1m; D 0.6m) immediately WNW of centre. The mound is encircled by a well-defined, flat-bottomed, steep-sided fosse (Wth. 1.25m - 1.5m). At the outer lip of the fosse is a substantial bank of earth and stone (Wth. 1.4m - 2.1m; H above fosse 0.65m - 1.2m; H above ext. ground level 0.3m - 0.55m). The site is divided into unequal portions by a modern E-W post-and-wire fence. The much larger portion lies to the N of this.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien Date of upload/revision: : 19 May 2010

Located at the W end of a prominent ENE-WSW drumlin ridge. This is a circular earthen platform (diam. c. 26m NE-SW; H 0.5m at S to 1m at W) which slopes down to E and is defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 4-5.4m; Wth of base 1.4-2.4m) and an outer bank (Wth 2-2.7m; int. H 0.7m at E to 1.5m at W; ext. H 0.2m at W to 0.6m at S). There is no visible entrance, and the SW half of the monument is overgrown while the rest is covered in grass and rushes. It may be a ringfort.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

Located at the crest of the steep NW-facing slope of a drumlin. This is a grass-covered mound (diam. c. 9m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of base c. 1m; ext. D 0.2-0.4m) which can only be traced N-SW (ext. diam. c.19m N-S). There is no visible outer bank.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

On a slight rise in low-lying land with bog to the N and high ground to the S. Irregular shaped mound (H 1.5m; top diam. 7.5m max.) which has a central depression on top (probably the result of quarrying) enclosed by a wide flat bottomed fosse (Wth 2.5m; ext. D 1m) which has been widened in places and an external bank (Wth 3m; ext. H varies from 0.5m to 1.7m) with possible external berm at N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

In level pasture, with drain/stream flanking S-side. Circular area (dims. c. 33m N-S; c. 34m E-W) defined by earthen scarp (Wth c. 4m; H c. 1.5m); inner fosse (Wth c. 9.25m; D c. 1.5m) in which stream enters from SE and exits at SW; inner bank (Wth c. 9.25m; int. H 1.3m; ext H c. 0.7m); outer fosse (Wth c. 5.75m; D 1.1m) and outer bank (Wth c. 6.25m; int. H c. 1.1m; ext. H c. 0.3m). Interior level with numerous badger sets within. Enclosure (TS068-078----) located c. 360m to NNE; Enclosure (TS068-096----) located c. 580m to SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Located in improved pasture on a slight NNW-SSE ridge in a gently undulating landscape. It was first identified by Susan Curran as part of an M.A. thesis with University College Dublin using a LiDAR survey dataset commissioned by Leitrim County Council and the National Roads Authority. This is an oval area (dims 18m NW-SE; 14m NE-SW) defined by a complete low scarp (at SE: Wth 3.7m; H 0.55m), with a fosse (at SE: Wth of top 6.9m; Wth of base 2m; D 0.1m) NE-S-W and an outer bank (at SE: Wth of base 6.6m; Wth of top 1.2m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.35m) E-SSE. There is a possible causeway entrance (Wth 3.5m) at ENE. The perimeter is truncated slightly by a NE-SW field bank at NW and a NW-SE field bank, now removed, truncated the perimeter slightly at SW.   Compiled by: Michael Moore   Date of upload: 11 May 2014

On top of a N-S ridge in undulating countryside. Roughly circular domed area (diam. 51m) enclosed by a wide shallow fosse (Wth 6m; ext. D 0.5m) with external bank (Wth 4m; ext. H 0.7m). W side of external bank acts as a field boundary while the SE sector of the inner fosse and external bank is destroyed. Indicated on 1840 edition of OS 6-inch map as an irregularly shaped earthwork.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

On a SW-facing slope, in the SW quadrant of Carron ceremonial enclosure (TS069-002001-). A small ring-barrow (overall diam. 9m N-S; 9.4m E-W) defined by a low central mound (H 0.05-0.15m; diam. 2.3m), fosse (Wth 0.9-1.2m; D 0.05-0.12m) and outer bank (Wth 1.6m; ext. H 0.1m). A larger ring-barrow (TS069-002002-) is located 4.8m to the NE, also within the ceremonial enclosure, and the fosse of the ceremonial enclosure is 9m to the SW. This ring-barrow is clearly visible on a 3-D modelling image (see https://skfb.ly/KuHP).  See attached images: TS069-002003-_01 3-D modelling image TS069-002003-_02  TS069-002003-_03   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 3 April 2018

Off-centre to W, within interior of a ceremonial enclosure (TS069-002001-) which is a National Monument (No. 537). Oval area (dims. 14m N-S; 17m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 2.45m; D 0.4m). Fosse in-filled at NE where there may be a causeway (Wth c. 10m) and also in-filled at WSW-WNW, where monument appears partially levelled. There may be traces of an external bank SE-S. Identified as an oval cropmark on aerial photograph (DPM 30th April 1979). Described by Cahill (1982) as traces of a mound-like feature. Another internal ring-barrow (TS069-002003-) has been identified in the SW quadrant, clearly visible on 3-D modelling (see https://skfb.ly/KuHP).Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of revised upload: 3 April 2018

On flat pasture with good views in all directions. Identified on aerial photographs (CUCAP 19 July 1971, BGO 2 and GSI 8.4.1974, S. 584/3 and GB89.AB.06, 16 July 1989). Two ring-barrows (TS047-049----; TS047-049001-) are located 54m to the NE and E respectively. Best preserved of three ring-barrows with a small tree growing on top of the mound in the N quadrant. Ring-barrow (overall diam. 29m N-S) with circular flat-topped mound (base diam. 11.5m; top diam. 5m; H 0.6m) enclosed by an inner fosse (base Wth 1.5m; top Wth 3m; ext. H 0.7m) and outer bank (base Wth 6.5m; top Wth 2.6m; ext. H 0.15m).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On flat pasture with good views in all directions, visible on an aerial photograph (CUCAP 19 July 1971, BGO 2; GSI 8.4.1974, S. 584/3 and GB89.AB.06, 16 July 1989). Two ring-barrows (TS047-049001-; TS047-049002-) are located 38m to the S and 54m to the SW respectively. The most northerly of three ring-barrows is located near an old dried up river bed to the N of the monument. This ring-barrow (overall diam. C.17.5m) consists of a low rounded mound (H 0.6m; top diam. 4.4m; base diam. 10.5m; H above surrounding ground level c. 0.2m) enclosed by a fosse (base Wth 1.5m; top Wth 3.5m; ext. D 0.4m) with traces of an outer bank which are too faint to measure.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On flat pasture with good views in all directions. Identified on aerial photographs (CUCAP 19 July 1971, BGO 2 and GSI 8.4.1974, S. 584/3). Two ring-barrows (TS047-049----; TS047-049002-) are located 38m to the N and 54m to the W respectively. The most poorly preserved ring-barrow (overall diam. 20.5m N-S) of a group of three, consisting of a flat-topped mound (top diam. 10m; base diam. 11m; H 0.2m) partially damaged from N to E, enclosed by an inner fosse (base Wth 1.8m; top diam. 5.5m; ext. D 0.3m), no outer bank visible.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On flat pasture with good views in all directions. A well-preserved ring-barrow (overall diam. c. 23m) consists of a circular flat-topped mound (top diam. 5m; base diam. 8.2m; H 0.4m) enclosed by an inner fosse (base Wth 2m; top Wth 5m; ext. D 1m) and outer bank (base Wth 5m; top Wth 1.4m; ext. H 0.65m) which is intersected at the E on a N-S axis by a modern field boundary. The ring-barrow is heavily overgrown and covered in thorn bushes but otherwise in good condition.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In recently sown arable crop. Circular area (dims. 4m N-S; 4.2m E-W) defined by shallow internal fosse 1 (Wth 2.9m; D 0.35m) and low, outer earthen bank 1 (int. H 0.35m; ext. H 0.6m; Wth 6m). Fosse 2 (Wth 5.5m; D 1.6m) is concentric around exterior of bank 1. Outer bank 2 (int. H 1.6m; ext. H 0.55m; Wth 5.75m) breached (Wth 4.0m) at N and again (Wth 5.5m) at SW. Outer bank top is truncated S-SSW-SW, possibly due to ploughing activities.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on the summit of a low E-W ridge in undulating pasture-land. Not indicated on 1st ed. (1840) OS 6-inch map but depicted on the 1954 ed. as a small enclosure with a central mound. The present remains consist of a low circular platform (diam. 16.2m N-S; 15.3m E-W to boundary fence) with the suggestion of a bank at SW and NE (Wth 2.5m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.3-0.6m). The site appears to have been levelled to an extent, the bank being flattened and there is no trace of the central mound. A post and wire fence with a conifer hedgerow, extending N-S, transects the SE sector and forms the boundary of the front garden of the adjacent bungalow. Some limestone protrudes from the surface of the site near the edge at S. A break in the bank (Wth c. 2m) at W may be the remains of a possible entrance.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In pasture, on top of the S-end of a ridge (long axis NNW-SSE) at a height of 500ft OD. Excellent views in all directions. Oval mound (dims. 38m NNW-SSE; 34m ENE-WSW) defined by scarp (max. Wth 4.15m; H 0.6m) best preserved NE-SE. Possible causeway (Wth 4.5m) at W. Fosse SSW-SE is best preserved (max. overall Wth 7.65m; max basal Wth 2.4m; D 0.15m) NE-SE. Fosse is truncated by curvilinear field boundary SE-SSW, which is within fosse and respecting its curvature. Scant remains of outer bank (overall Wth 5.9m; Wth at top 2m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.25m) SW-WNW. Gentle, oval depression (dims. c. 14m ENE-WSW; c. 12m NNW-SSE) off-centre to SSE which is covered by nettles. Depression is also clearly identifiable on aerial photographs (ASIAP (35) 17-20, 03/08/1996). This is a National Monument (no. 581).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Within interior of enclosure (TS061-031----), abutting bank at E. Circular area (diam. 2m) defined by inner fosse (overall Wth 1.9m; basal Wth 1m; D 0.02m) and outer bank (overall Wth 1.9m; Wth at top 1m; int. H 0.02m; ext. H 0.12m) SE-WNW. Interior is generally level and very small. Short linear bank (L 4.5m) flanks N-arc and forms S-side of entrance to enclosure. Conjoined barrows (TS061-031001-; TS061-031002-) are c. 6.5m to W.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on a slight rise in undulating poorly drained pasture with good views of surrounding countryside.  A large roughly circular area (overall diam. c. 75m E-W; int. diam. c. 30m E-W) delimited by a wide shallow flat-bottomed fosse with a substantial earth and stone bank well preserved from S-W-N-NE but elsewhere it is lower in height and has been defaced in places.  There is a modern gap in bank at NE and some old quarry holes at WNW and WSW.  The interior of the monument along with the enclosing fosse is traversed by old cultivation ridges running N-S.  Most of the interior of the monument has been disturbed by these cultivation ridges.    An old ESB pole has been placed on top of the bank at NE.  It has been suggested that this monument may be the remains of a possible henge due to the large diameter of the monument or may be an example of a large ring-barrow (SMR File 29/03/1973).  Compiled by: Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 20 July 2015

In level pasture, on a gentle rise. Scant remains of an oval area (dims. 31m N-S; 28m E-W) defined by fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.1m) and levelled outer bank (Wth 3.5m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.05m) S-NE. Possible entrance gap (Wth 4m) at W. Interior is level and poorly drained. Depicted on 1840 ed. OS 6-inch map as an oval enclosure (dims. c. 40m ENE-WSW; 36m NNW-SSE) and on latest ed. OS 6-inch map as an oval area (c. 30m N-S; c. 27m E-W).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a SW-facing slope in pasture. Depicted as a circular enclosure with the designation 'Fort' on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map and 'Site of' on the 1883 revised edition. A report in 1987 (SMR file) described it as a ring-barrow. It has since been levelled but the outline of its perimeter, defining a circular area (diam. c. 28.5m), is still identifiable. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Poorly preserved ring-barrow which appears to have been partly excavated and damaged by fallen trees. Circular mound (diam. 14m N-S ) with central depression (probably the result of digging) enclosed by a wide shallow fosse (Wth 2m) with external bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 1.5m; int. H 0.8m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

In improved, generally level pasture. Circular area (dims. 32m N-S; 31m E-W) containing low oval mound (dims. 7.5m N-S; 4m E-W) in centre defined by scarp (Wth 0.7m; max. H 0.45m) and shallow fosse (overall Wth 3.1m; basal Wth 1.2m; D 0.15m) best defined NE-SE and SW-NW. Low intervening bank (overall Wth 9.4m; Wth at top 2.2m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.45m) is best defined SW-NW, levelled out yet traceable NE-SE and modified elsewhere. Intervening fosse (overall Wth 11.5m; basal Wth 1.7m; D 0.45m) is best preserved around W-arc and inner edge is backfilled NE-SE, where intervening bank may have been levelled into it. Substantial outer bank (overall Wth 9.9m; Wth at top 1.6m; int. H 1.05m; ext. H 1.45m) is best preserved S-NW and is slightly lower NW-S. Large quantity of stone within fabric of the outermost bank. Entrance (overall Wth 5.75m; basal Wth 2m) at S is one third the depth of total (external) bank height. Outermost fosse (overall Wth 7.5m; basal Wth 2m; D 0.15m) has been backfilled possibly during reseeding of field. It is possible that a fourth outer bank has been levelled as monument is now 11m from field boundary at W and is shown on latest edition OS 6-inch map as almost being truncated by field boundary to W.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture, on lower area of SW-facing slope, overlooking pond to WNW. Identified during field inspection (31/01/2007). Circular area (diam. 3.0m) defined by internal fosse (Wth 3.5m; D 0.15m). External bank (int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.35m; Wth at top 4.75m; overall Wth 1.0m). Linear feature (L 23m) with slight curvature extends from NE toward enclosure (TS069-024001-) to NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 20 May 2014

Located on top of a drumlin. This is a scrub-covered D-shaped mound (dims of base 11.2m N-S; 9.4m E-W; dims of top 9.9m E-W; 8.9m N-S; H 0.6-0.7m) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth of top 4-4.7m; ext. D 0.3-0.4m) NW-E-SW. Both the mound and fosse are truncated by a N-S field bank at W.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 23 September 2008 Amended: 9 December 2019

Not visible at ground level. Not marked on first two editions of the OS 6-inch maps and hachured like a ring-barrow on 1910 edition of OS 6-inch map.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

On a slight terrace on the W side of a ridge in undulating countryside. Roughly circular mound (H 1.5m; diam. 7m E-W; diam. 5.5m N-S ) enclosed by a wide fosse (Wth 2m) which is barely discernible with external bank (Wth 1m; ext. H 0.5m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Located just off the S end of a N-S drumlin ridge. This is a grass- and rush-covered circular earthen platform (diam. 39m E-W; 38.5m N-S; H 0.8m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 4-6.5m; Wth of base 2.8-3.5m) and an outer bank (Wth 3.8-4.7m; int. H 1-1.7m; ext. H 0.3m) with a hedge. The fosse is recut as a field drain E-S and the bank is adapted as a field bank N-E. There are many gaps in the bank but an original entrance is not identified. It may be a ringfort.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 September 2008

Circular area (diam. 10m) enclosed by low earthen bank in low lying partially drained field immediately S of Noughaval graveyard (WM016-012001-) boundary wall.  Outline of earthwork clearly visible on OSI 2005 aerial photographs.  Possibly represents the remains of a ring-barrow.  A low linear earthwork in field to E of graveyard may represent the remains of an old trackway running from the graveyard towards Noughaval House to the E which is clearly visible on Bing Maps aerial photographs.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 2 October 2014

On high ground in upland area. Circular flat topped mound (diam. 9.5m N-S; 9m E-W; H max. 1.5m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 3m) with slight evidence of an external bank at W only. Several large boulders protrude from the surface of the mound in the SW sector.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

On top of high ground in upland area with two tumuli (OF043-040001/002-) nearby to the NNW and NW respectively. Low circular area (diam. 9.5m) enclosed by a shallow inner fosse (Wth 3m) with slight evidence of a much degraded external bank which is destroyed by a field boundary which intersects the site at S. The ring-barrow is poorly preserved and only visible under suitable conditions. One of a group of three burial sites.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Located on top of high ground in upland region with good extensive views in all directions.  Nearby cluster of ring-barrows (OF043-040/001/002) located approximately 300m to the SW.  In pasture, land appears to have been reclaimed and re-seeded with grass, encroaching coniferous plantations near site on land which has not been reclaimed. Nearby barrows to SW have been planted with coniferous trees on wet unreclaimed land.   Present remains consist of low semi-circular shaped mound (diam. 6m N-S; 11m E-W, H 0.35m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 3m;ext. D 0.2m) and low outer bank(Wth 2m; H 0.1m). Site has been transected on its S side by a field boundary running E-W which gives the mound a semi-circular shape, originally the barrow consisted of a circular mound aproximately 12m N-S by 11 m E-W enclosed by a fosse and outer bank. Faint traces of central mound on S half of site but no trace of enclosing fosse or bank on this side.  Monument is best preserved on its N half from W through N to E as depicted on current edition of the OS 6-inch map.  Compiled by:  Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload:  09 August 2012

On high ground in upland area. Well preserved ring-barrow consisting of a circular platform (diam. 8.5m; ext. H 1m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 3.5m) and external bank (Wth 1m; ext. H 0.3m; int. H 0.5m). Area around site has recently been planted by forestry which will make site inaccessible in a couple of years time.   Monument placed on the Register of Historic Monuments on the 18 May 1977.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Situated on fairly level ground, sloping very slightly to S at the edge of a bog which lies immediately to the S. The site is not marked on either the 1st (1840) or 1904 ed. OS 6-inch map but was identified on an aerial photograph taken in June 1973 (GSIAP, S 81/80) as a possible ring-barrow. The site has been levelled but is still clearly visible as a raised circular area (diam. 4.3m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2.3m; D 0.29m) and flattened external bank (int. H 0.44m) (overall diam. 10m N-S; 10.3m E-W). Some stone is evident in the bank. At E there is a possible causewayed entrance (Wth c. 2.6m).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

On top of a low hill, sloping gently to the SE, in gently undulating terrain, in lush pasture. Good to extensive views in all directions, with Slievenamon Mountain to the E. Circular, flat-topped mound (diam. 24.3m N-S; 25.4m E-W; H 0.44-0.69m), sloping gently to a wide, flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 5.6-6.5m) with an outer bank (int. H 0.33-0.56m; ext. H 0.2-0.25m; Wth at crest 4.2-6m; overall Wth 8.2-12.8m) evident in the SE-S as a low, flat, broad bank, not as clear from S-W and not evident N-SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 14 November 2016

No surface remains visible of a ring-barrow excavated in 1985 by the National Museum of Ireland. A ring-barrow situated 10m N of the medieval cemetery (TS054-002005-) on the eastern edge, situated on sloping ground and much disturbed by later activity. The barrow consists of a shallow flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 1m) enclosing a circular area (diam. 6m) with no traces of a mound or of a bank. Two pits containing small quantities of charcoal, cremated bone and unburnt animal bone may represent undisturbed burials (Ó Floinn 1985, 37).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a SE-facing slope in pasture. Depicted as a small, circular tree-ring on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. A report in 1990 (SMR file) interpreted the then extant remains as those of a ring-barrow, which was later reused as a tree-ring. It has since been levelled and is not visible at ground level. Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on top of an E-W ridge in mountainous area. Circular area (diam. 19m N-S; 13m E-W) enclosed by an earthen bank (Wth 2.2m; ext. H 1m; int. H 0.5m) with no evidence of an entrance feature or outer fosse. Field boundary intersects site from N to S, enclosing bank forms part of field boundary from S to N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

On a low natural rise in upland area with standing stone (OF043-073) immediately to the N. Circular flat topped mound (H 1.7m; top diam. 9.5m N-S; 9.4m E-W) enclosed by a wide flat bottomed fosse (Wth 2.5 - 3m; ext. D 1m) with slight traces of an external bank (Wth 2.5m) best preserved at N. Evidence of stone kerbing at base of mound best preserved from W to N. Immediately to the N there is an upright triangular shaped standing stone (OF043-073) which by its close association may be contemporary with the ring-barrow.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

At the edge of a plantation of coniferous trees, c. 25m to the SSW of a rath (LF019-068001-). A low circular mound of earth and stone (diam. at base 6.4m; max. H 0.8m) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth 3.2m; H 0.3m) with a wide, shallow internal fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.25m). There are causeways across the fosse at NNE, E and SE. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 14 November 2011

On a low ridge in poorly drained pasture. A report in 1987 (SMR file) recorded 'a fine example of a small ringbarrow' at this location. It is very densely overgrown with scrub rendering inspection impossible without heavy cutting. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Located on a slight rise in low-lying poorly drained area. Low flat topped circular mound (diam. 6m; ext. H 1m) enclosed by wide berm (Wth 2m), shallow inner fosse and two external banks of earth and stones with intervening fosse. Impossible to examine or measure site due to dense overgrowth.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Monument recently identified and surveyed by Melanie McQuade of the Forest Service who described the monument as following 'The site has been planted (c. 1985/6) and appears to have been ploughed at the time of planting, but there is still reasonably good surface expression.  There is a central mound currently measuring c. 10m N-S x 14m E-W (max) and rising gradually to a maximum height of c. 1m.  Some stone is visible within the mound material (this appears to be local sandstone) An internal ditch is evident and the external bank varies from c. 0.40m  c.1m in width and is c. 0.60m high.  The barrow has a diameter of c. 26m.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled and revised by Caimin O'Brien  Date of revised upload: 22 February 2016

On a low hillock in upland area with good views in all directions. Circular flat topped mound (top diam. 6.4m; base diam. 13m; ext. H 2m) enclosed by a wide flat bottomed fosse (Wth 2m; ext. H 2m) with possible external bank. Large cavity on top of mound due to modern disturbance. Large boulder beside cavity may be result of field clearance/disturbance.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Situated on top of a low hillock in undulating countryside with a poorly drained bog immediately to the N. A well-preserved impressive ring-barrow consisting of a naturally raised area (diam. 29m E-W) defined by a scarp and enclosed by a wide well-preserved fosse (Wth 3-6m; ext. D 1m) and outer bank (Wth 2.2m; ext. H 0.5-0.9m) with possible causewayed entrance (Wth 5m) at SE. The area to the NW of the ring-barrow represents a natural hillock the base of which has been scarped, with a modern trackway intersecting the hillock to the W of the barrow (Stout 1984, 83).  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In pasture, on level area in NE corner of field. Identified on an aerial photography (OS 9874/3). Well-preserved circular area (diam. 10m) defined by internal fosse (basal Wth 0.6m; overall Wth 3.8-3.85m; D 0.1-0.2m) and slight outer bank/lip (Wth 3.75-4m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.1-0.2m). Interior slopes down gently to fosse.   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on a slight SE-NW spur with the headwaters of a SE-NW stream c. 170m to the SW. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. 7.5-8m; H 0.2-0.4m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 4-4.6m; Wth of base 1.7-2.4m) and outer bank (Wth 3.4-4.3m; int. H 0.8-1.1m; ext. H 0.5-0.7m). There is no visible entrance (max. ext. dims. 19.3m NE-SW; 17.3m NW-SE). A ring-barrow (WA013-006----) is c. 70m to the SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 23 December 2008

Situated on a slight SE-NW spur with the headwaters of a SE-NW stream c. 100m to the SW. This is a dished, circular grass-covered area (diam. 17.6m E-W) defined by an earthen bank (max. ext. H 0.6m). It is badly eroded with the bank destroyed at NE (max. ext. dims. 21.4m E-W; 19.2m N-S). A ring-barrow (WA013-005----) is c. 70m to the NW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 23 December 2008

In pasture, on a gentle S-facing slope. Sub-circular area (dims. 25m N-S; 30m E-W) defined by internal fosse (Wth 9.05m; D 0.9m) which is shallow around N arc. Outer bank (Wth 6.25m; int. H 1.05m; ext. H 1.0m) is disturbed at W and straightened along S due to former field boundary at this location. Bank squared-off to a corner at SE and is riddled with rabbit burrows along S. Possible causewayed entrance (Wth 4m) across fosse at S. Interior undulates as it slopes down to S. Depression (10m E-W; 4m N-S) within N sector. Monument had been planted with evergreens (Cahill 1982). Field boundary removed to S and W. Ringforts (TS070-072----) and (TS070-072001-) located 230m and 275m respectively to SSE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved, yet rough pasture, on a SE-facing slope with excellent views of Slievenamon to S. Earthworks (TS062-010002-) to E and W and a henge (TS062-010003-) abuts c. 3.5m to the SE. A multivallate ring-barrow consisting of a roughly circular area (diam. 50m) defined by scant remains of a bank (overall Wth 6.4m; Wth at top 1.7m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.5m) which is best preserved from SE-S-SW and is reduced intermittently to scarp (Wth 1.5m; H 0.45m) SW-SE; a well-preserved fosse (overall Wth 5.4m; basal Wth 3.0m; D 0.4m) with causewayed (Wth 4.5m) at ESE; intermittent remains of bank (overall Wth 4.1m; Wth at top 1.6m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.6m) from NNW-E-SSW which is levelled from SSW-W-NNW; and in the SE-S-SSW sector there is also another fosse (overall Wth 3.65m; basal Wth 1.25m; D 0.2m); bank (overall Wth 3.7m; Wth at top 1.6m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.3m); fosse (overall Wth 3.7m; basal Wth 1.3m; D 0.2m); bank (overall Wth 4.4m; Wth at top 1.9m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.35m) and the possible remains of an outermost fosse. The interior slopes to the SE and together with parts of the exterior appears to have been modified by drainage activities. The innermost bank has been flattened and has spread into the interior in the W sector. A raised area (dims. 36m ESE-WNW; 14m NNE-SSW) within the N sector, which is defined by scarp (Wth 1.5m; H 0.35m) to S, is possibly a result of drainage activity. A leat (Wth c. 4m; long axis NNW-SSE) intersects the inner fosse at SW and NW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

An area, circular in plan and c. 17m across, consists of a low mound, surrounded by an earthen bank with an intervening level area. There is a possible cause-way across the level area on the E. The bank is 4m to 5m wide and reaches a maximum height of .7m at the outer edge on the W. It has been removed on the E where there is now a ruined stone wall. A pole has been set in the outer edge of the bank on the W. At a distance of c. 1m to 1.5m inside the line of the bank is a low mound, c. 0.2m in height which is approximately rectangular in plan and 3 to 4m across on top. On the E a slightly raised area about 3m wide joins the mound to a ruined field wall and appears to have formed a causeway between the mound and the bank. The removal of the bank here prevents confirmation that this was an entrance to the site. The causeway might just be spill from the bank removal. The site is at the Wedge of a N-S running ridge. There is a steady fall to the shore of Mulroy Bay c. 200m to the W. There is good grazing available.  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

On a SW-facing slope in pasture. A circular mound of earth and stone (diam. 5.95m; max. H 0.75m) enclosed by a wide, low bank of earth and stone (Wth 5.3m; H 0.5m) with a shallow internal fosse (Wth 2.2m; D 0.4m). At the centre of the mound, a large boulder is lying on its side. At NW, E and SE low causeways extend from the inner face of the bank across the fosse to the mound. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On low-lying ground, in the flood-plain of a stream. Depicted as a circular enclosure with the designation 'Fort' on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. A circular mound of earth and stone (diam. at base c. 18m; H 0.85-1m). The top is flat (diam. 12.8m) and is enclosed by fragmentary remains of a low bank of earth and stone (H 0.1-0.3m). At the base of the mound is a shallow fosse (Wth 3.1-3.5m; D 0.4m). At the outer lip of the fosse is a second bank (Wth 2-2.8m; H 0.2-0.45m) with traces of an external fosse (Wth 1.7m; D 0.15m) which is identifiable from SE-S-W. The original entrance is not recognisable. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 33) as following: 'This monument was almost entirely removed during construction of a silo-pit between 1971, when first visited by an ASI fieldworker, and 1977, when visited a second time. The 1971 account, identifying it as a ring-barrow, is as follows: A small, low, approx circular flat-topped area surrounded by remains of a well defined earthen bank with an internal wide shallow fosse. From SW-W-NW the bank and a small part of the fosse have been quarried away. A sectional profile of the perimeter of the site is visible in the resulting almost straight and almost vertical quarry face. Modern fences contact the outside of the bank on the NE and SE and between those two points the outer face of the bank has been steepened to form part of a boundary. It is overgrown with thorn trees there now. A gap in the bank on the N is probably a later feature due to disturbance. Sited on a small natural rise and surrounded by gently undulating land of poor to average pasture. Good views to the W and N. N-S diameter from top of bank = 22.20m. The site is disturbed in places by burrows. [SMR file]   By the time it was revisited, only a part of the bank (H. 1.5m) survived on SE side; also a part of W side of interior survived, outside which to NW was a mound of rubble presumably resulting from the destruction of the monument.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Situated on top of a prominent rise, in undulating pasture, with good views to SE, S, W and NW. Monument described in 1971 and 1977 as a circular-shaped area (overall dims. 20.1m E-W; 18.7m N-S) enclosed by an inner fosse, an intervening bank and an outer fosse. The inner fosse is quite slight and shallow. The intervening earth and stone bank is much disturbed and the outer fosse is visible intermittently at N, S and SW. Within the interior is a very low rounded rise (diam. 5m).   Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

On the NE facing slope of high ground in mountainous area. Ring-barrow consisting of a circular area (diam. 7m N-S ; 7.5m E-W) enclosed by an earth and stone bank (Wth 3m; max. H 0.5m) with no evidence of an inner or external fosse. Site very overgrown at time of visit making examination difficult. Several large boulders can be seen protruding from the surface of the sites interior. One of a group of five barrows (OF037-008002/003/004/005-).  According to local tradition these barrows are located on a hilltop which was the inauguration site of the OFlanagans of Cinél Arga (Feehan 1979, 143).  It is possible that these burial mounds form part of a ritual landscape associated with this inauguration site.     The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 09 August 2012

Marked on the 1841 ed OS 6-inch map. Situated on marshy ground midway down a NE-facing slope. A flat-topped circular mound (diam. c. 10m, max. H c. 1.35m) surrounded by a waterlogged and partially infilled fosse (average Wth 2.1m; D 0.7m) which broadens out from SE-SW (max. Wth 3.7m) and is enclosed by a low counterscarp bank (Wth 2.6m, max. ext. H 0.6m). A field boundary skirts the counterscarp at S. Site overgrown with hawthorn and brambles.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

On a low but prominent hillock in pasture. A low, dome-shaped mound of earth and stone (diam. at base 11.8m; H 0.3m) enclosed by a bank of earth and stone (Wth 3.3m; H 1.35m) with an internal fosse (Wth 2.9m; D 0.15m). A break in the bank at ESE (Wth 3.6m) with an accompanying causeway marks the original entrance.Compiled by: Patrick F. O'DonovanDate of upload: 26 August 2011

Located a short distance to the SE of nearby castle (SMR OF024-036002-) in flat pasture land. Poorly preserved slightly raised circular area (diam. 4m) enclosed by low barely visible bank. No other features visible.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 3/1986).

On a hillock in low-lying pasture. Marked as a circular enclosure with the designation Fort on the 1837 edition of the OS 6-inch map and as an oval earthwork on the 1914 ed. A raised oval area (37.2m NWSE; 21.4m NESW) is enclosed by a shallow inner fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.5m), a low inner bank of earth and stone (Wth 2.4m; H 0.25m), an outer fosse (Wth 3.4m; D 0.25m) and an outer bank (Wth 3.4m; H c. 0.2m); the outer face of the latter has been removed. The NE quadrant of the monument has been levelled. The original entrance is not recognisable.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 22 February 2012

Situated on a col in a heather-covered clearing within a coniferous forest, between Milk Hill, an E-W spur of the Monavullagh Mountains to the S and Tooreen Hill c. 400m to the N. Heather-covered mound (dims. 9.2m E-W; 7.2m N-S; max. H 1m) defined by a fosse (Wth at base 1.4-3m) with an outer bank (Wth 1.4-2m; ext. H 0.1-0.4m). A cist (dims. 2.75m x 2.3m) is exposed in the centre of the mound. A stone row (WA006-022002-) is c. 7m to the S and a standing stone (WA006-022003-) is c. 80m to the N, while standing stones (WA006-022005-) and (WA006-022006-) are c. 50m to the W.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 23 December 2008

In low-lying pasture. A low, circular, dome-shaped mound of earth and stone (diam. at base 11.7m; H 0.6m) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth 4.1m; H 0.1-1.3m) with a shallow internal fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.1-0.6m). At the outer foot of the bank is a second fosse (Wth 3.3m; D 0.4-1.3m) and, beyond that, a second bank (Wth 5.8m; H 0.4-1.8m) and a third fosse (Wth 2.9m; D 0.4m). The third, or outermost, fosse is identifiable for its entire circuit. However, from NNW-E-SE the other banks and fosses have been levelled and the lines of demarcation between them are not clearly defined. The original entrance is marked by corresponding breaks (Wth 2.8m) in the banks at SSW with accompanying causeways. The site is partially encircled by modern field boundaries. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on the N-facing slope of a SW-NE valley, and in a clearing in a coniferous forest. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 10m; H 0.4-0.6m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of base 2-3m) and outer fern-covered bank (Wth 3m; ext. and int. H 0.7-1.2m). There is a break in the bank (Wth 0.5m) at SE, but there is no entrance (max. ext. diam. 23.4m N-S). Enclosure (WA006-026----) is c. 60m to the SW, and fulachta fia (WA006-050----) and (WA006-051----) are c. 200m to the WNW and NW respectively.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 27 July 2010

On a prominent rise in rolling countryside. A low circular mound of earth and stone (diam. at base 10.25m; max. H 0.35m) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth 4.2m; H 1.05m) with a shallow internal fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.3-0.55m). At the outer foot of the bank is a second narrower fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.2m) and, beyond that, an outer bank (Wth 2.2m; H 0.5m). From NE-E-SE the outer bank and fosse have been levelled but their outlines are still identifiable. The original entrance is not recognisable.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 27 February 2012

On top of a low hillock on reclaimed grassland in Slieveardagh hills with good views from E through S to W with higher ground to N. Nearby megalithic tomb (TS048-041----) to 175m to N. Well-preserved ringbarrow (overall diameter 19m E-W) consisting of a low circular mound (top diam 8.5m E-W; base diam. 10m E-W; H 0.3m) enclosed by an inner fosse (base Wth 1m; top Wth 2.5m) and external bank (base Wth 2m; top Wth 1m; ext. H 0.2-0.6m). Stone wall field bank bisects the mound on an E-W axis. Originally the ring-barrow was situated on low ridge in wet marshy terrain in upland region. The mound is approximately level with the external ground surface.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Low circular flat-topped mound (diam. c. 14m, H c. 1m) surrounded by a fosse (Wth 3m; D c. 0.4m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 61-2) as following: 'This appears to be the monument identified by Elizabeth Fitzpatrick as a ring-barrow in 1997 [SMR file], but as the survey-team had only very limited time on the site this season, there remains the possibility that there is also a ring-barrow in the area S of Templepatrick church (WM017-061----) and graveyard (WM017-061001-). Roughly circular dished platform (Diam. 7.3m N-S x 8m E-W) surrounded by a ditch up to 1.5m in width, and rising up to 0.4m above ditch where latter is well preserved at NW; ditch is up to 0.20m below ground level at NW side. Upper surface of platform slopes down gently from W to E.  Distinctly hollowed centre of platform, 4.3m across N-S, gives the impression of a bank around the edge of the platform, 1.5m in width; as such, if not for the small size of the monument, it would have the appearance of a ringfort. Where cattle have poached the sod at SW side, monument can be seen to be composed almost entirely of earth.  Monument lies in undulating pastureland c. 150m to S of disused walled graveyard containing  medieval church of Templepatrick (WM017-061----); ruined and overgrown, this unicameral medieval church was found to measure 13.8m x 8.1m during ASI fieldwork in  1980.  St. Patricks footprint stone was documented outside graveyard in nineteenth century (FitzPatrick 2004, 238).  Based  on  extensive comparative evidence, Leo Swan infers the former presence of an early medieval curvilinear monastic vallum or rampart from the quadrantal shape of the graveyard (Swan 1988, 23).  The landscape here shows signs of glaciation, with a reedy depression indicating a probable kettlehole close by to N of the barrow; a second hollow to SW, though now dry ground, might have been another such feature. There is higher ground immediately NW of the monument. A short distance SE of the monument is a bog, now partly planted with trees'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Situated at the bottom of a broad NE-SW valley with the ravine of the NE-SW Araglin river just to the S. Circular area with a slightly dished interior (ext. diam. c. 25m; int. diam. c. 17m). It was removed during land reclamation in 1992. (Moore 1995, 210, Q1)  Moore, M. (1995) A Bronze Age setlement and ritual centre in the Monavullagh Mountains, County Waterford. PPS 61, 191-243.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 18 November 2010

Situated on the floor of the NE-SW upper Araglin valley, on the N bank of a small E-W tributary of the NE-SW Araglin River. Circular, grass-covered earthen mound (diam. of base 7.2m; H 0.9-1.3m) surrounded by a shallow fosse (Wth 1m; D 0.2-0.5m) and the remains of an outer bank (Wth 1.5m; ext. H 0.2-0.4m), both of which are best preserved at N and S. The W side of the mound has been destroyed by the insertion of a limekiln. (Moore 1995, 210, 212, 230-31, 237, 243, Q2)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 18 November 2010   This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 4/1996).

On top of a N-S ridge of pasture with good views in all directions, nearby ringfort (TS043-024----) 300m to W. Impressive well-preserved ring-barrow (overall diam. 55m E-W) consisting of a circular mound (base diam. 30m E-W; top diam. 22m E-W; H above fosse 0.6m) defined by an inner fosse (top Wth 8m; base Wth 3.5m; ext. D 1m) and outer bank (top Wth 3.5m; base Wth 8.5m; ext. H 0.7m). The top of the mound is approx. level with the surrounding ground surface. The bank is reduced to a scarp at N only, elsewhere it is very well preserved. In the S quadrant the bank is intersected by a field boundary running E-W.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

A circular platform (diam. c. 15.6m, H. c. 12m) surrounded by a shallow fosse (Wth c. 3.6m) from SW to E. No other visible surface remains.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Just below top of hill on a W-facing slope of land in upland area with good extensive views in all directions. Ringfort (TS049-036----) visible 600m to W. Poorly preserved monument the interior of which has been used as a dumping area for building rubble and agricultural equipment and field clearance debris. This dumping makes detailed examination or proper classification impossible. Monument now situated on reclaimed re-seeded grassland but originally located on wet marshy land in upland area. Fields to N and W have been reclaimed and field boundaries which immediately enclosed the monument to N and W have been levelled. Fields to E and S have not been reclaimed and field boundaries are intact. Monument consists of a circular area (int. diam. 15m N-S; 20m NE-SW; overall diam. 25m N-S ) enclosed by an earth and stone bank (base Wth. 4m; top Wth. 1.45m; int. H 0.9m; ext. H 0.8m) and wet outer fosse (Wth 3m; ext. D 0.4m) visible at S only. Large gap (Wth 10m) in bank at N which has been inserted to provide access for dumping. Possible remains of a circular mound in centre of monument and indications of an inner fosse would suggest a classification of ring-barrow. Monument depicted as a possible ringbarrow on latest ed. OS 6-inch map. Overall dimensions and location would support classification of monument as a possible ring-barrow. Evidence of cattle poaching to external face of bank at W side. Wet outer fosse has been filled in from W to N probably when field was reclaimed.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Site-specific test-trenching was carried out by Tim Coughlan of Irish Archaeological Consultancy Ltd., under licence No. E2653 as part of an archaeological mitigation programme associated with the N6 Kilbeggan to Athlone dual carriageway in addition to the main centre-line testing programme. This site was identified during site-specific testing undertaken by the writer in August 2005 (A016/025). The site was excavated between October 2005 and April 2006. The area of excavation measured c. 60m northsouth by 80m. The main feature of the site was a probable medieval enclosure (OF002-021----), previously documented as a ringfort; it measured c. 50m eastwest by c. 50m. Excavation results suggest that activity took place here during a number of periods and that the medieval enclosure is actually located on the site of an earlier monument. Within the internal flat platform of the large medieval enclosure were: the remains of a possible Bronze Age ring-barrow (OF002-021001-), possible associated post-holes and a stone-lined cist; possible medieval industrial pits with an associated rectangular structure; and numerous post-medieval cultivation furrows and isolated pits. The site phasing has been divided as follows. Prehistory A circular enclosure c. 14m in diameter was identified at the top of a natural gradual slope. This consisted of an enclosing ditch c. 2m wide and 1m deep. Within this was a smaller enclosing ditch c. 7m in diameter, 0.4m wide and 0.2m deep. It is felt that this may have represented the site of a possible Bronze Age barrow. The barrow was subsequently partially recut during medieval times to accommodate a large industrial furnace (OF002-021002-) with an associated area of stone metalling. Part of a human skull was found with the lower fills of the barrow. This bone may have been disturbed by the later activity in the vicinity, therefore its association with the barrow is unclear. To the north of these features was a stone-lined cist (OF002-021003-) that appeared to contain a disturbed cremation. A number of post-holes were identified between the cist and the possible barrow, although no definitive pattern has been determined. Medieval It is felt that the main enclosure  which is best described as subrectangular  was probably of medieval date. There appears to have been a subsequent phase of possible medieval industrial activity, particularly in the east of the enclosure. This includes the previously mentioned furnace and stone metalled surface. The material excavated from here was charcoal-rich and contained a considerable amount of burnt human and animal bone, nineteen amber beads and small amounts of metal and slag. A number of pits that appeared to have functioned as furnaces were identified to the east and north of the barrow recut, although only trace amounts of slag were recovered. Further analysis of samples from these features will be required to determine the precise nature of the activity. The pits were subsequently backfilled with stone/rubble, suggesting that there may have been some contemporary clearance on the site. A collection of post-holes and three hearths in the south of the site may have formed 1 or 2 possible structures, cutting the bank material, and are also thought to be broadly contemporary with the industrial pits. However, these structures nor the pits did not appear to be of a large enough scale to be contemporary with the original enclosure. An abundance of charred seed remains were recovered from these hearths, as well as from other features on the site, which will provide a more definitive chronology of activity at the site. Post-medieval The north-west area of the enclosure contained a number of probable plough furrows. These curved slightly following the line of a slightly deeper probable boundary that extended from the entrance in the north of the enclosure to the south-east/east. Other isolated features of possible post-medieval date were identified across the site. It seems

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 38-9) as following: 'This heavily overgrown barrow was examined and described for the ASI in 1973: A small circular mound, now slightly disturbed & with a depression on top, surrounded by a fosse & with a good bank of earth & stone outside it. The whole monument is covered with furze and briars, making inspection difficult.  The diam of the earthwork is approx 26m. The barrow is situated on a ridge with good views of the surrounding countryside, which is fairly well drained pasture land. [SMR file] From this description the monument, with a small mound and substantial bank, appears to be a ringbarrow rather than a bowl-barrow with external bank. The depression on top of mound possibly indicates that it has been ransacked by treasurehunters'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

On a WSW-facing slope in pasture, overlooking low-lying ground that has been planted with coniferous trees. A raised circular area (diam. at base 9.6m; H 1.1m) enclosed by a partially denuded, low bank of earth and stone (H 0.5m; Wth 3.8m). A report in 1975 (SMR file) recorded a shallow external fosse, which has since been infilled. A break (Wth 1.55m) in the bank at NNE may mark the original entrance. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On flat poorly drained land with good views in all directions, well drained pasture to S and marshy land to W, N and E. An enclosure (TS043-023----) is located 160m to the SE. A heavily overgrown barrow (overall diam. c. 18m N-S) consisting of a low flat-topped circular mound (base diam. 8m N-S; 7m E-W; top diam. 5m N-S; H 0.3m) enclosed by an inner fosse (base Wth 2.2m; top Wth 2.7m; ext. D 0.3m), an earth and stone bank (base Wth 3.3m; top Wth 1m; ext. H 0.5-1m), a fosse (top Wth 2m; base Wth 1m; ext. D 0.3m) and an outer bank (base Wth 2.8m; top Wth 1.4m; ext. H 0.4m). A modern road intersects the outer bank at S on an E-W axis. The inner bank is very well preserved at NW where the top of the bank is higher then the internal mound and outer bank.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

A report dating from 1976 describes the barrow as a small circular bank of earth/stone with shallow internal fosse surrounding a small central mound (diam. 8m E-W) of stones.  It is situated on top of a high outcrop of limestone and is probably a small ring-barrow.  Located close to the top of the hill.  Excavated by Macalister [No. 2].  There is a modern boundary fence directly to the W of it (SMR file 25/04/1976).  Described by Jim Reynolds as a very small circular earthwork consisting of a small very low circular mound surrounded by a shallow fosse.  Beyond this is a fairly wide low bank.  The earthwork is on the northern slope of a hill with very wide views to east, north and west.  There are several areas of rock outcrop in the vicinity of the barrow.  To the north of the barrow the ground falls away fairly sharply (SMR File).  Another site report dating from 1979 described the monument as a very small stone/earth low mound is surrounded by a shallow fosse which is enclosed by an earth/stone bank very low.  Placed on top of a stony knoll just N of the summit of the hill.  The bank is gapped on the W, N and E.  Macalister put a cutting through it but found nothing (SMR File 15/05/1979).  A second report from the same date describes the monument as following; The approx. circular area on top of a sharp knoll is slightly scarped and surrounded by a shallow fosse which is best seen on the W-S and E but hardly visible in some places.  It is enclosed by a low earthen bank which again is best preserved on the NW, W and SW and also to be seen in the E sector.  There is a probable gap or entrance feature on the N and SE.   The interior rises to the flat top of the knoll and shows no sign of disturbance except in the SE sector where a hole has been dug beneath a large limestone (erratic) pillar.  This may have been a standing stone.  There is some disturbance along the line of the scarp and fosse in the N sector and in the W sector an old field fence runs close to the bank.  Diam. 35m (SMR File 15/05/1979). Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 65) as following: 'Tiny, roughly circular mound  (Diam.  3.2m N-S x  3.5m E-W) surrounded by a ditch, with an overall diameter of 7.8m (NS and EW). Traces of a bank are currently visible outside the ditch on S side, but Macalister and Praeger, who excavated and made a sketch-plan and profile of the monument, clearly document this bank all around the perimeter. Large limestone boulders protrude from the mound and, most noticeably on W side, from the outside of the ditch; these are shown to be part of the bank on Macalister and Praegers plan. To NW of mound a boulder appears to lie in the ditch. Ditch ranges from 1.7m to 2.3m in width, being widest on W side, and is up to 0.49m in depth below external ground level on deepest S side; mound rises up to 0.49m above ditch on N side. The author concurs with Schot (2006) in identifying this site as a ring-barrow. Macalister and Praeger aptly compared it to the ring-barrow at Grannagh, Co. Galway. They trenched across the mound but found absolutely no trace of interments or of any other deposits, although the disposition of the stones inside the mound was not unsuggestive of a roughly constructed grave; no account of the excavation was providedwhere they dug their trench, whether they accurately reconstructed the monument afterwards, etc.although their sketch-plan appears to show these central stones.  Barrow lies at N end of a broad, gently curving ridge with protruding boulders, apparently the terminus of a lateral moraine  (pers. comm. Seamus OBrien); ridge runs S towards ruined megalithic structure known as St. Patricks Bed (WM024-059----) on western summit of Hill of Ushnagh c. 150m to SSE.  Ground falls away sharply to N of barrow.  Frewin Hill (WM011-131---) and Knockdrin (WM012-183---), prominent locations of summit cairns or tumuli (McGuinness 2012, 28, 34-5), are visible to NE and ENE respectively'.  Compile

Outline of ring-barrow possible (overall diam. 48m) consisting of a small circular mound enclosed by an inner fosse, low bank, fosse and traces of an outer bank visible on Digital Globe aerial imagery. The monument is intersected at W by a field boundary which curves out forming part of the enclosing element of the possible barrow.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Edmond O'Donovan  Date of upload: 30 October 2019

On a low rise in undulating pasture. Depicted as a circular enclosure with the designation 'Fort' on the 1883 revised ed. of the OS 6-inch map. A report in 1975 (SMR file) recorded a low mound of earth and stone (diam. c. 4m) enclosed by a wide, low bank of earth and stone with a wide, shallow internal fosse. The original entrance was not recognisable. The monument has since been levelled and is not visible at ground level. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a rise in well-drained pasture. A low, circular, dome-shaped mound of earth and stone (diam. at base 8.9m; H 0.7m) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth 4.3-4.4m; H 0.7-0.95m) with a wide, shallow internal fosse (Wth 5.2-6.7m; D 0.35-1m). In places the bank is revetted externally with low upright stones. A break (Wth 2.1m) in the bank at ENE may mark the original entrance. (O'Donovan 2003, 21)  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated in grassland at W end of glacial ridge running E-W which may have been modified.  Well-preserved ring-barrow consisting of a low circular shaped earthen mound (diam. c. 3.5m; H c. 0.35m) enclosed by an inner fosse (approx. Wth 2.5m; D c. 0.3m) and well preserved external bank (H 0.4m).     Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Melanie McQuade.  Date of upload: 20 March 2017

This possible burial monument is located on the gentle south-facing slope of Uisneach, overlooking a small lake that formed in recent decades in an area that may also have been prone to water-logging in the past (Schot 2005; 2011). Identified during field survey, it survives as a slightly raised, circular area, c.0.15m in height and 3m in diameter, surrounded by a shallow ditch and very low, external bank measuring c.7m in overall diameter. The site provides good views to the E and SW but is overlooked by higher ground on all other sides. A well-defined ring-ditch (WM024-201----) and a second, possible ring-ditch, were recorded by geophysical survey c.65m to the northwest, and an ancient roadway (WM024-067----) runs in a north/south direction to the west. Macalister and Praeger also identified in this general area an earthwork (WM024-175----) which they described as being identical in character to a ring-barrow (WM024-058----) located near the western summit of Uisneach. They trenched through the earthwork, but found it did not contain so much as a construction of stones (Macalister and Praeger 1928, 83).
