A large circular ring-barrow (max. ext. diam. 33.8m) defined by a platform (diam. 16m; H 1.2-1.4m) except from NW_NNE, a flat-bottomed fosse (base Wth 0.8-1.5m) and an outer bank (Wth 4.5m at E, max. int. H 1.8m; max. ext. H 0.8m). The fosse has been infilled with bank material and rubbish from WNW-NNE. Cattle gaps at S and W.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

On a local prominence at W edge of Heath. A sub-circular ring-barrow (max. ext. diam. 10.7m N-S) defined by a central mound (diam. 4-4.5m; max. H 0.5m) and a flat bottomed fosse (Wth 1-1.5m; D 0.8m) which is shallowest at S (D 0.4m).  Site re-visited by Caimin O'Brien on the 08 May 2007. Site consists of a slightly sunken circular mound (diam. 4-4.5m; max. H 0.5m) enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 1-1.5m; D 0.8m) with the slightest suggestion of an external fosse (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.1m). Some dumping has resulted in the infill of the inner fosse in places.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

At W edge of Heath. A ring-barrow (max. ext. diam. c. 14m N-S), overgrown with briars and furze, defined by a D-shaped platform (dims. 7.2m N-S; 5.9m E-W; H 0.5m), with the straight side at W where part of the monument has been removed, a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 0.6-1m) and an outer bank (Wth 2-2.5m; max. int. H 0.8m; ext. H 0.2-0.3m) except from S-WNW. Small quarry in interior at S. An earthwork (LA013-03002-) lay immediately to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

On a local prominence at S edge of the Heath. A sub-circular ring-barrow (max. ext. diam. 15.7m N-SE) defined by a flat-topped central mound (max. diam. 5.6m; H 0.5m) the interior of which has been quarried out, a round-bottomed fosse (Wth 3-4m; max. int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.2m) which is incorporated into a field boundary at W. A stone is visible on outer edge of mound at SSW.  Site re-visited by Caimin O'Brien on the 08 May 2007. Site consists of a circular mound (max. diam. 5.6m; H 0.5m) with hollow depression (diam. 1m; D 0.3m) in the centre of the mound which may be due to quarrying enclosed by an inner fosse (Wth 3-4m; max. int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.2m) and external bank (top Wth 1m; base Wth 2m; ext. H 0.2m)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

On a local prominence, N of the sixth fairway of golf course. A ring-barrow (max. ext. diam. 15.7m), most of which is overgrown with furze and briars, defined by a circular platform (diam. 11m; H 0.2-0.6m) and a shallow V-shaped fosse (Wth 2-2.4m; ext. D 0.2-0.7m) .  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Situated S of an E-W trackway leading W from sixth fairway of golf course. A ring-barrow (max. ext. diam. 21m N-S), completely overgrown with furze, defined by a domed central mound (diam. 12m; H 0.5-0.7m), a flat bottomed fosse (Wth 0.7-1m), and an outer bank (Wth 3.5m; int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.3m). The trackway abuts the outer bank at N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

On level ground beside an ESB pylon. A ring-barrow (max. diam. 15.5m) defined by a low circular mound (diam. 7m; H 0.3-0.4m) surrounded by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 1m; ext. D 0.5-0.7m) which is infilled with cleared vegetation from SSW-NNE. No outer bank.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Situated just NW of the seventh tee on golf course; a platform associated with the tee-off occupies the SE quadrant of the monument. A circular ring-barrow (max. ext. diam. 18m) defined by a central mound (base diam. 15m ; H 0.3m) and a fosse. Traces of an outer bank at W appear to be modern associated with golf course trackway here.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Located at N lip of the hollow which contains the Little Bog Lough. Also first off the fairway for the fourth hole, slightly higher ground to E and W. This site is covered by furze which has been burnt off, small ring-barrow consists of a small mound (diam. 5.1m N-S; 4.8m E-W; H 0.6m) with dimple on top defined by an inner fosse (Wth 0.5m-1m; ext. D 0.2-0.4m), no outer bank visible. Overall max. ext. dims. 10.4m N-S x 10.5m E-W  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

This is a sub-circular raised platform bounded by an inner ditch and outer bank. There are three causeways across the ditch, in the E, W and SE (Gibbons, 1990, 6). The site was partially levelled in 1954. Fragments of animal bone were found in the interior (NMI Correspondence).Compiled by Geraldine Stout

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 53) as following: Very large, previously unrecorded ring-barrow (Diam. 44.5m N-S x 47.2m E-W), comprising a broad and very low domed mound (Diam. 32m N-S x 33.7m E-W) surrounded by a circular ditch; there appear to be the slightest traces of a bank outside the ditch, best seen on aerial photographs, but these are very unclear and the bank has been excluded from the overall diameter given above. Ditch is broadly U-shaped to flat-based with basal width of 2.7m, and, on N side, is sunk 0.22m below central mound and 0.78m below external ground level (or the denuded remains of the presumed bank); rubble has been dumped in its SE quadrant in recent times. Central mound is currently sunk 0.47m below external ground level where measured at N side, and must have been proportionately deeper when outer bank was intact.  Monument is sited in low-lying basin with higher ground surrounding it, greatly reducing visibility. A second circular earthwork, possibly also a barrow, is visible on aerial photographs in an adjacent field c. 60m to WNW, but this has not yet been examined by the survey-team on the ground. Another barrow lies in Edmondstown (WM013-048----) less than 350m to SE of the present monument, and between the two is a small natural lake or pool, possibly a kettle-hole of glacial origin; between this lake and the present site, which lie 130m apart, is a small stream, its curving channel altered in places for drainage purposes.  About 700m to NW in Balreagh is a ruined medieval church in a burial ground (WM013-038----), theregular oval enclosure surrounding the latter being sufficiently diagnostic for Leo Swan (1988, 26) to identify this as an early medieval ecclesiastical foundation; immediately NW of this church site is a motte (WM013-037----) and close by is a souterrain (WM013-039----).  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 8 February 2016

National Monument in State Ownership No. 532.  In pasture on top of Clonin Hill with extensive views of the surrounding countryside.  Impressive view of burial mound (OF010-004001-) on top of Croghan Hill 4.5km to W. Smaller ring-barrow (OF011-001002-) now levelled located c. 20 metres to NW of ring-barrow (OF011-001----). No surface remains visible.  Described in 1970 as following: 'Approx. 56m NW from centre of the barrow is a smaller barrow divided in two by a modern field fence wall.  This smaller barrow measures 11m approx. in overall width, with the fosse measuring 3m in width' (SMR File 23/01/1970)'.  The field boundary described in 1970 and indicated on all editions of the OS 6-inch maps has been removed in recent times and the ring-barrow was probably levelled when the field boundary was removed.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 25 January 2016

National Monument in State Ownership No. 532.  In pasture on top of Clonin Hill with extensive views of the surrounding countryside.  Impressive view of burial mound (OF010-004001-) on top of Croghan Hill 4.5km to W. Smaller ring-barrow (OF011-001002-) now levelled located c. 20 metres to NW. Circular flat topped mound (diam. 46.6m; H 2.5m - 0.5m) enclosed by inner fosse (Wth 2m) with external bank (Wth 5.3m; H 0.3m) intersected by stone wall/field boundary at W. Natural rock outcrop with decorated surface known locally as a mass-rock (OF011-001001-) protrudes from the surface of the fosse at SW.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of revised upload: 25 January 2016

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 51-2) as following: Low, heavily denuded earthwork comprising a circular ditch (Diam. 18.8m NW-SE x 19m E-W) which surrounds a very low central mound or slightly dished ground level platform; where best preserved on E side, ditch is 3m in width, 0.3m in depth below interior and 0.1m below external ground level. The ASI account suggests a much defaced bank immediately within the line of this ditch, although the ditch itself is not mentioned: A small circular barrow consisting of a low rounded earthen bank enclosing a shallow circular depression.  The depression is approx. 4m in diam. while the overall diam. of the barrow is approx. 12m E-W. The low bank is now scarcely visible in the summer grass [SMR file].  Presumably this low rounded earthen bank enclosing a shallow circular depression is simply another way of describing the present writers slightly dished ground level platform, although it is certainly possible that further damage has been done to this low-visibility monument in recently ploughed land, since it was examined for the ASI. If there were a bank around the interior, this barrow would be shaped superficially like a miniature ringfort.  Monument is sited on gentle NW-SE slope, just SE of low summit, in recently ploughed land; visibility is poor all round. A large ring-barrow (WM013-113----) lies c. 350m to NW in Jeffrystown, a kettle-hole lake lying between the two; and a third, unclassified-barrow (WM013-074----) lies c. 800m to S in Edmondstown.  According to the NMI files human bones were found on or in the vicinity of this monument which was described as a 'Rath' or 18th c. Tree-Ring (SMR File).    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 8 February 2016

In poor boggy ground, in a reclaimed field. On a slight height with ground on NW falling away into bog, some 150m away. A ring-barrow in the SW quadrant of a larger circular enclosure (KK001-002002-). The ring-barrow consists of a circular platform (diam. 13.3m) enclosed by a waterlogged fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.3m) and external bank (Wth 3.4m; ext. H 0.3m). There are bulrushes growing in the fosse. The ring-barrow (overall dims. 19.7m) has been preserved, though the field has been reclaimed up to the external bank. A modern field bank and hedge runs NW-SE, immediately NE of the barrow.Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 2 October 2014

Located towards the top of the S-facing slope of a drumlin. It is depicted as a small circular embanked enclosure (ext. diam. c. 20m) only on the 1834 edition of the OS 6-inch map where it is described in gothic lettering as a fort. It was described in 1945 (SMR file) as a curve of a bank (ext. H c. 0.6m; int. H c. 0.9m) with an internal ditch or fosse (Wth of base c. 0.3m) and a slightly domed interior that was truncated by a NNW-SSE field bank at E. No archaeological feature is visible at ground level in pasture (OSAP).The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Monaghan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Revised by: Michael MooreDate of revision: 20 June 2018

Situated on a prominent rise, in gently undulating pasture, with good views toward Lionabin. Depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map as a small circular-shaped earthwork. Monument described in 1980 as a low profile, roughly D-shaped mound (dims. 20m N-S) enclosed by a fosse and an outer bank and which sits in a saucer like depression. The wide shallow fosse is visible from NNE-E-S-W. The outer bank is low and the exterior ground level slopes gently away from it. The E side of the monument has been disturbed.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 04 November 2019

Situated on a generally level area, in low-lying pasture, which is overlooked by higher, gently undulating pasture to E, S and W where views are restricted. Barrows (WM020-112----/114----) lie c. 15m to E and c. 14m to N, respectively. Not depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map or on the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map. Monument described in 1970-2 as a small circular area (dims. 8.5m ESE-WNW; 7m NNE-SSW) defined by a wide, shallow fosse. The remains of a slight bank are present along the outer edge of the fosse. Outline of monument is barely visible on Digital Globe aerial photography.  See attached OS 25-inch map showing location of barrow.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 08 July 2019

This barrow was excavated in 1973 and the following is a summary of results as published in the excavations bulletin (McCabe 1974): 'Six burial mounds have been located at Rathnarrow. Barrow III is a low circular mound with a slight central depression surrounded by a round-bottomed ditch of varying width with a low broad earthen bank at its outer edge. The mound is 15m in diameter and 1 .20m higher than the bottom of the ditch. The ditch is 7  8 broad, the bank 6m broad and about 20 cm high. The 1973 excavation was limited to a preliminary cutting in the N.E. quadrant. This revealed a portion of a pit under the centre of the mound which rises to a maximum height of 40 cm above the old ground surface. Limited excavation of the upper pit-fill produced many fragments of cremated human bone. The cutting exposed two parallel arcs of irregularly weathered grey-white limestones resting on the old ground surface underneath the mound. The arcs, possibly parts of two concentric rings, are 1 .20m and 3.80m from the centre. The stones which have small spaces between them average 30cm long x 25cm broad x 25cm high. Between the two arcs in a concentration of smaller stones. All save four were resting on the old ground surface. Between these stones and on the ancient soil were many fragments of charcoal. Where excavated the ditch was found to have been c. 2.60m deep originally. Traces of broad cultivation ridges were found crossing the bank. One of these yielded a 19th century clay pipe bowl. A thick layer of ancient soil with a clearly defined limit 3m outside the outer lip of the ditch was found beneath the bank The ancient soil and ditch fill promise to yield considerable ecological data. Some waste flint flakes were found but no artifacts.'  See attached OS 25-inch map showing location of barrow.  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 19 March 2015

Small circular shaped site (max diam c. 11m) definited by a barely visible fosse and very low mound (diam. c. 5.5m, H c. 0.2m). Site only barely visible on ground surface.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 63-5) as following: Large, well-preserved ring-barrow (Diam. 32.2m c. N-S) in high relief, its N half and parts of its S perimeter now covered by vegetation. It comprises a roughly circular, flat-topped central mound or platform (Diam. (top) 17.1m N-S; Diam. (base) 19.9m) with sharply defined upper edge and steeply sloping sides, its upper surface sloping down gently to S, which is surrounded by a ditch and a large, flat-topped outer bank. Mound rises 0.74m over ditch on SW side. Ditch is broad, deep and flat-bottomed through U- to V-shaped in section where best preserved, reaching a width of 2.8m at E side where it is not overgrown; in its S side are remains of fallen trees and other vegetation. Where largest on SW side, bank is 2.8m in width and rises 1.28m over base of ditch and 0.65m over nearest part of central platform; although it rises 2.72m over external ground level at this point, its outer face plunges down to the broad side of a large, possibly natural, crescent-shaped hollow (see below) which runs from SW-W, making it difficult to discern where bank ends and natural slope begins; giving a much better sense of actual height of constructed bank, the corresponding measurement just a few metres to E is only 0.74m. Bank is lowest on SE side of monument, where it rises only 0.27m above external ground level.  On E side of monument, running approximately radially across ditch from ENE-WSW is what appears to be a causeway or partially uncut stretch of ditch, 3.10m in width and reaching a height of 0.43m above base of ditch immediately to NW. In its current state this feature is quite irregular in appearance, perhaps due to erosion, and it dips down slightly in the centre so that it is lower than both external bank and central platform; nonetheless it has the rough appearance of a causeway and was tentatively identified as such, along with a corresponding gap in the bank (see below), by the ASI fieldworker who visited the site on 19/5/71 [SMR file].  There appears to be a breach in the outer bank beside the causeway but this is much narrower than the latter and even less regular in appearance, with bank on its N side being much higher and more massive than on S side, where it has been much reduced in height. The bank becomes more massive at the point where the natural ground surface begins to plunge down dramatically as a natural escarpment around NW half of monument, further increasing the apparent height of bank; this appears closely similar to the situation at SW, where bank rises by 0.66m close to the point where its outer face plunges into the crescent-shaped hollow (see above). The bank is much lower and less massive on SE half of monument.  In a postscript, the ASI fieldworker who visited this site on 19/5/71 makes a case for the causeway and corresponding gap being secondary, drawing on observations of certain features which appear now to be concealed by fallen trees and other vegetation on S side of monument: The gap and causeway at the E would appear to be later features. The trench which cuts through the bank and fosse on the S. extends round to E. and has a slight bank along its NW side. The bank is against the inner side of the fosse between S. and E. it crosses the fosse to make causeway-like features [SMR file].  Monument is located on a low rise in undulating pasture, right on the brink of a natural escarpment, and up against what appears to be a second, at least partly natural, crescentshaped hollow, so that the height of its NW edge, where the bank is most massive, is greatly exaggerated by the natural slope. The irregular, stony ground at the base of the crescent-shaped hollow might preserve the foundations of some structure if it does not indicate recent quarrying; the ASI accounts of 19/5/71 and 3/7/78 both identify the hollow as a disused quarry [SMR file]. But for vegetation, visibility would be fairly good on all sides, with a promin

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 65) as following: Severely damaged earthwork, comprising a circular, approximately flat-topped mound or platform (Base diam. 14.8m N-S x 15.2m E-W), its upper surface kept roughly level despite undulating ground level, which is surrounded on its NE side by an arc of ditch and external bank 18m in length; overall diameter of monument including central mound and the surviving ditch and bank on one side, is 21.3m NE-SW. Monument has been deliberately placed on sloping ground rather than on more even ground, or on a local summit; but its builders have made it more massive on N side than S, in order to ensure that it remained approximately level. Bank is up to 4.10m in width and, rising 0.92m over the ditch, is of a similar height to the central platform, which rises 0.90m over the ditch. Height of bank, taken down to a break in the steep natural slope immediately NE of the barrow, is 0.88m; there is a further drop of 1.22m before the natural ground levels out, so that the monument is most imposing from this side in the same way that the other Porterstown ring-barrow (WM027-036----), placed on the edge of an escarpment but kept approximately level, is most striking when seen from the N where its banks are most massive, and further exaggerated by following the slope of the escarpment.  Although this was not observed on a single, short visit to the site by the survey-team, the ASI account of 17/5/71 notes that On the W a slight earthen bank can be seen, extending approx E, on the central area [SMR file].  Although the monument is currently identified as a ringfort on the NMS website, one of the ASI accounts (17/5/71) is nonetheless headed Ring-Barrow? [SMR file], and this classification seems most fitting: there is no clear evidence for an inner bank and there are three other ring-barrows (WM027-020----; WM027-021----) close by, at least two of them within sight in Riverstown; the well-preserved ring-barrow at Porterstown (WM027-036----), only 600m to S, has a very similar appearance, with flat-topped central platform, deep ditch and large external bank, and it too is kept more or less level despite greatly undulating topography, so that one side appears much higher from the outside, where the natural ground is lower.  Monument lies beside road at edge of a large, recently ploughed field; presumably ploughing and related activities are responsible for removal of bank and ditch. Although the site is now mostly clear of vegetation, with only a few young trees growing on it and stumps of two older felled trees, it was covered by dense growth and fallen trees when visited by ASI fieldworkers on 17/5/71 and 5/6/80 [SMR file]. As such, while upper surface of central mound has the overall appearance of being flat-topped, it is in fact heavily disturbed with bumps and hollows presumably left by uprooted trees and burrowing animals.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 10 February 2016

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 70-1) as following: Heavily eroded ring-barrow (Diam. 26.1m N-S x 29.5m E-W) in very low relief, comprising a low roughly circular domed mound (Diam. 13.9m N-S x 13.5m E-W) surrounded by a shallow, poorly defined ditch, and an external bank that is broad, almost flattened and difficult to discern. Where best preserved, ditch is sunk 0.4m below mound and 0.22m below bank. There is an old beech growing in ditch at SSE; part of the stump of a second with saw marks lies at interface of mound and ditch at NW, the ground has been disturbed here, presumably when the tree collapsed or was felled.  Barrow caps or is shaped from a low eminence (kame?) 90m W of a kettle-hole lake, in undulating pasture immediately N of the Royal Canal, just S of which again passes the main railway from Dublin to Sligo.  Monument forms part of a loose grouping of four ring-barrows, lying c. 200m to SE of a second similar but slightly larger one in this townland (WM027-021----) and c. 500m from a third example in Porterstown (WM027-019----); a fourth ring-barrow, also in Porterstown (WM027-036----), lies across the canal c. 700m to WSW. On a gently rounded glacial hillock in Riverstown, on slightly higher ground (OD 90-100m) c. 950m to N, ploughing in 1969 uncovered a short rectangular cist containing a crouched skeleton with Early Bronze Age Bowl Food Vessel; radiocarbon assay of the bones yielded a date of 3645±30 BP, falling clearly within the date range of c. 2200-c. 1800 BC for these vessels (Ó Ríordáin 1972, 234-5; Waddell 1990, 154; Brindley 2007, 67, 74, Table 6). Although the other nearby ring-barrows are visible, overall visibility is poor in this low-lying location.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 10 February 2016

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 66-7) as following: Rectangular or partly sub-rectangular earthen embanked enclosure with external ditch and raised interior containing what appears to be a denuded ring-barrow at its N end. Dimensions of enclosure are 30.3m N-S x 25.4m E-W from outer edges of ditch; 27.2m NS x 21.7m EW from outer edges of bank; and 17.3m N-S x 16.2m E-W for the interior. There are clear traces of a counterscarp bank just outside ditch at NE and S, and slighter traces of one at NW, which would increase overall dimensions for enclosure. Main enclosure bank rises up to 0.5m above interior at S side, where it rises 1.05m above the ditch and 0.90m above the counterscarp bank.  Overall width of flat-topped inner bank is 3.4m at E side, its upper surface 0.80m across. Width of bank at S side is 1.7m, where width of ditch is 1.5m. Part of outer face of inner enclosing bank has been poached, especially on S side. Long axis of enclosure runs roughly N-S (NNW-SSE), with corners being sharpest at NW and SW, and more rounded at NE and especially SE. Interior of enclosure is raised up to 0.50m above external ground level at NE corner but is higher than ground level on all sides. Slippage from the inner bank and raised interior has occurred in various places, most notably midway along W side, although the ASI account of 13/4/70 suggests that this might be the original entrance [SMR file].  At N side of interior of enclosure are remains of what appears to be a greatly damaged ring-barrow (Diam. 10.5m E-W), comprising a ransacked central mound (Diam. 6.5m E-W) surrounded by a roughly circular ditch and an outer bank which is best preserved at E but almost obliterated on S side. Mound rises 0.23m above ditch on E side, where bank rises 0.19m above ditch. It is possible that this is not a ring-barrow, not least in view of its unusual location within a rectangular enclosure; the ASI account of 26/7/72 queried its identification as a ring-barrow, while that of 13/4/70 had described it as two slight banks forming concentric arcs with the open sides on the S., suggesting that These could represent a two-period house site. The inner structure [i.e. the hollowed mound of the ring-barrow] having been built inside the outer. Given its hilltop location amidst the important Killucan group of barrows, and that some other enclosed ring-barrows are known from Ireland, this writer is much more inclined to opt for identification as a ring-barrow.  Monument is located on prominent hilltop close to mobile phone mast; visibility would be excellent all round but for trees. Barrow forms part of a loosely knit cemetery on and around the elevated ground W of Killucan, including two in Rathwire Upper townland (WM020-124----; WM020-123----) within 1.3km to S, and a tight cluster of four or five others in Rathnarrow townland within 1.2km to S.See attached plan of monument surveyed and drawn by the ASICompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.Date of upload: 10 February 2016

A sub-circular area (dims. c. 15.9m N-S, c. 14.2m E-W) with dome-shaped rise in the centre. Slight evidence of internal fosse and external bank.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Situated on the lower SE-facing slope of a hill and at the crest of a NE-facing slope. This was described in 1969 (SMR file) as a low grass-covered area (diam. 6.5m E-W; 6m N-S) defined by a slight fosse (Wth of top 3.5-4.8m; int. D 0.1m at SSW to 0.5m at NNE; ext. D 0.3-0.4m) and an outer bank (Wth of base 3-3.5m; ext. H 0.7m), which was missing WSW-NW. An entrance was not identified (max. ext. diam. 17.5m NNE-SSW). Visible evidence of this monument had been removed by 1995 (OSAP).   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 8 January 2019

On flat pasture land in undulating countryside with nearby tumulus (SMR OF011-022----) to the N. Poorly preserved low circular mound (H 0.15m; diam. 5.5m) enclosed by a slight fosse (Wth 0.4m) with external bank (Wth 0.5m; H 0.5m).barely discernible. Stone protruding from N portion of site.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Located on the N-facing crest of the summit of a prominent hill known as Slieve Gullion. Two small barrows are visible on Google Earth from 2009 but are most clearly visible on the most recent (16/03/2021). This feature appears to be damaged by a relict WNW-ESE field drain running parallel with the current field bank c. 10m to the SW. It appears to be a small grass-covered platform (diam. c. 5m) defined by ditch or fosse and an outer bank (ext. diam. c. 15m WNW-ESE) whose features only survive WNW-N-ESE. The features are also visible on MapGenie imagery (2005-12; 2013-18), Digital Globe (2011-13) and Apple Maps, and were first reported by Jean Charles Caillére.  See the attached enhanced view from Google Earth (16/03/2021)Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 12 July 2022

On a level terrace at the N end of a field that slopes gently to E. A flat platform (diam. c. 9m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1m; int. D 0.2m; ext. D 0.3m) and outer bank (Wth 1.5m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.3m). The bank consists largely of stone, and the fosse is wet in places. The area, known locally as a 'rath', is left rough and untouched due to local superstition.  Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 15 January 2013

On high ground with good extensive views and nearby ringbarrow (OF011-055) to the S. Low rounded mound (H 1.3m; top diam. 2.5m; base diam. 12m) with no evidence of an enclosing bank or fosse. The mound shows signs of modern disturbance to the S probably the result of grazing livestock.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

On an E-facing slope in reclaimed arable land. Listed in the SMR (1987) as Enclosure and in the RMP (1996) as Enclosure Site. The monument is in the middle of the field and has been left untouched by reclamation, due to superstition. On inspection in July 1987 this was found to be a large ring-barrow (overall diam. 18m) comprising a platform (diam. 11m; H above fosse 0.2m) a fosse (D 0.4m below outer bank) and an outer bank (Wth 1.5m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.4m). The bank is best preserved at W due to soil creep which may also have affected the bank at E. Locally known as a rath. Visible on the 1st edition OS 6-inch map as a small circular hachured feature. Erroneously added to the record as a separate monument (KK015-074----).  Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 14 January 2012

Situated on a rise at the N edge of the col between Carrickbrack to the SW and the summit of Slieve na Calliagh to the E. This is a circular grass-covered mound (diam. of top 4.5m N-S; 3.9m E-W; H 0.2m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 3-4.2m; ext. D 0.1-0.3m) from an outer earthen bank (Wth of base 2-3m; ext. H 0.1-0.2m). There may be entrances at NE (Wth c. 3m) and SW (Wth c. 3m) that might also be due to wear (max. ext. diam. 15m N-S; 14.2m E-W). The cairn (ME015-007----) is c. 60m to the E. This monument is not accessible to the public at the moment.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Revised by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 10 January 2019  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 23/1977).

Located towards the bottom of the N-facing slope of the Loughcrew Hills. Land Commission works during 1935 revealed two cists, which were largely destroyed before they could be investigated, but they were in a circular enclosure (diam. c. 25m) defined by a shallow fosse (Raftery 2011, 346). One cist was rectangular (dims 0.9m x 0.75m; D 0.46m) but without a capstone and it contained yellow clay with charcoal inclusions. The second cist was also rectangular in plan with a capstone. It was also filled with yellow clay that had charcoal inclusions, and a few fragments of bone were recovered. A third cist (ME009-055----) was discovered at the same time about 600m to the N. The location of this barrow is revised c. 270m to the S of that in Moore (1987, 21, No. 76) after the discovery of a new map.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 3 March, 2017

Situated on a slight rise on a shelf, which is on the SE-facing slope of a small hill. This is a circular mound (diam. of top 10.3m NE-SW; diam. of base 13.3m NE-SW; H 0.7m) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 4-5m; Wth of base 1-1.5m; ext. D 0.8-0.9m) and an outer earthen bank (Wth of base 3-6m; ext. H 0.6-0.7m) There is an entrance (Wth of base 4.2m) and causeway (Wth of top 1.7m; H 0.4m) at E. The outer bank is incorporated in a NE-SW field bank at SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 10 January 2019

In a level field in reclaimed land surrounded on all sides by marshy ground. A low central mound (diam. 4m; H 0.3m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.2m) and external bank (Wth 2m; H 0.3m). The monument has been truncated by a modern field drain from E to S. Immediately to the SW of the monument are traces of a field bank (KK015-056002-). A fulacht fiadh (KK015-056001-) is 10m to the WSW.  Compiled by: Mary Tunney  Date of upload: 22 January 2013

Located at the crest of a steep N-facing slope. It is not marked on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but is visible on aerial photographs (GSIAP: N 722/723) and on later series. This is a circular grass-covered mound (diam. 14.8m E-W; H 0.6m at W) defined by a fosse (at W: Wth of base 2.2m; ext. D 0.9m) and an outer bank (at W: Wth of base 4m; ext. H 0.4m). The bank and fosse meld into the slope E-SW and a large stone (dims 1.7m x 1m) is lying in the fosse at E (max. ext. diam. 29.6m E-W). It is bisected by an ENE-WSW fence and survives best N of this feature.
column13: The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 31 October 2018

column10: Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 35) as following: Low domed mound (Diam. 9.0m N-S x 8.3m E-W) with flattish summit, reaching a height of 0.8m at SE where highest over external ground level, with traces of a ditch and external bank on S and possibly SW sides. From the ASI account of 13/4/73, the bank and ditch appear to have been in far better condition forty years ago: This consists of a wide deep V-shaped circular fosse with a substantial bank of earth outside it. Inside the fosse is a circular almost flat-topped steep mound like feature. The site is so densely overgrown that it is difficult to judge whether or not some of the fosse material was thrown on to it.  At present the almost flat top of the area inside the fosse would suggest that is it in fact a ring-barrow. [SMR file] Elsewhere its overall diameter is given as 22.5m [SMR file]. Although earthen in appearance, probing indicates that the mound contains much stone. Poaching has removed parts of edge of mound at N, W and SW, but a slight depression in its upper surface might indicate ransacking by treasure hunters, if not a collapsed cist. Probable ditch at S side of mound is 1.7m in width; bank beyond this is 1.5m in width and rises 0.26m above the ditch. On historic OS 25 map, ditch is shown as complete, and an external bank is depicted for NW quadrant. There is a sub-rectangular, tongue-like projection at E side of mound, 2.5m in length, 2.3m in width and up to 0.2m in height; there appears to be a corresponding projection at W side, 2.8m in length, 2.7m in width and 0.4m in height. It is unclear whether these are original features. This monument, which has had a preservation order since 1977 but is currently in very poor condition, is prominently positioned on a low glacial hill (kame) with good visibility to N and E, one of several in this undulating landscape of glacial drift, now under pasture, and is surrounded by a ring of pine trees planted not long before 1973 [SMR file]. About 750m to NW is a graveyard (WM018-045001-) with ruined medieval church (WM018-045----), which Leo Swan (1988, 11) identified as an early medieval ecclesiastical site on the grounds that the shape of the graveyard indicated the former presence of a diagnostic curvilinear enclosure (WM018-045002-) or vallum surrounding the site.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 5 February 2016  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 22/1977).

On flat pasture land with gravel ridge to the N and river to the S. Circular flat topped mound (top diam. 7.5m; base diam. 13.5m; H 1.35m) with slight evidence of an enclosing fosse at SW. According to the local landowner there was a similar mound located about 3m to the W but it was bulldozed out a couple of years ago.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Situated on a small NNE-SSW ridge in an undulating low-lying landscape. This is a circular and slightly domed grass-covered area (diam. of base 17.5m NNE-SSW; 16.5m WNW-ESE; diam. of top 12.5m NNE-SSW; H 0.5-0.6m) separated by a fosse (Wth of top 4.5-6m; Wth of base 1-1.5m; ext. D 0.7m) from an outer bank (Wth of base 3.5-4m; ext. H 0.5-0.6m). Visible evidence of the monument had been removed by 1995 (OSAP).    The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 9 January 2019

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 36) as following: Fairly well preserved but densely overgrown ring-barrow, comprising a sub-circular central mound or flat-topped platform (Diam. 20.4m N-S x 17.9m E-W), surrounded by a circular ditch and outer bank (Overall diam. c. 30m N-S x 29.6m E-W). Running across middle of site from E to W, and cutting through the bank at both ends, and through the platform, is an earthen bank (W. 2.1m) with accompanying shallow ditch (W. 2.8m) immediately to S, the two features appearing in places more as a scarp dropping from N to S than a discrete bank and ditch; the ditch continues to E and W of the barrow and is clearly visible as a thick hedgerow on aerial views; where partly exposed just W of barrow, this feature appears more like a sunken trackway than a ditch. Central mound or platform is raised significantly higher (0.52m) to N of bank and ditch than to S, but there is no clear evidence of rebuilding or disturbance aside from the bank and ditch. There is a plan and profile of monument by ASI fieldworkers in SMR file, clearly showing the split-level platform. Flat upper surface of platform slopes down gently from S to N. Bank reaches 3.9m in width at NW, and rises 0.90m above the ditch and 0.62m above external ground level; at the same point the ditch is 2.5m wide and 0.56m below the central platform.  Monument is sited on a broad, low N-S ridge, which drops down far more steeply to E than W, in a golf course laid out on former demesne land of the Nugents of Ballinlough Castle.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 5 February 2016

On the summit of Ballykane Hill (OD 398 feet). An archaeological excavation (Excavation Licence no. 04E1318) carried out in 2004 confirmed the site as a previously unrecorded ring-barrow, comprising a central mound surrounded by a ditch and an external bank, with an entrance to the southwest. The maximum external diameter of the site was 22m north-south. Finds included worked flints, copper-alloy fragments, unburnt and cremated animal bone and cremated human bone. (Lynch 2007, 202 (No. 843))  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Situated on a rise in an undulating low-lying landscape. This is a low grass-covered mound (diam. of base 10.5m E-W; diam. of top 5m E-W; H 0.7-0.8m) separated by a fosse (Wth of top 8-9.5m; Wth of base 1-2.5m; ext. D 1.3m) from an outer earthen bank (Wth of base 7-8.5m; ext. H 0.6-0.8m) with some bushes, but the bank and fosse have been removed E-SW and the mound damaged in the same area.    The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 25 February 2018

Situated on the summit of an ENE-WSW ridge. It is not depicted on any map but was described in 1969 (SMR file) as a circular grass-covered area (diam. 39.5m N-S; 36.5m E-W) defined by a fosse (at N: Wth of top 8m; Wth of base 3m; int. D 0.5m; ext. D 0.3m) from an outer bank (at N: Wth of base 6m; Wth of top 2.5m; ext. H 0.1m). There was no visible entrance. It is a faint feature but it is visible on Bing images (c. 2013) and Google Earth (24/03/2017; 17/07/2017).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 27 February 2019

Mid-way down a long moderately steep SW-facing slope in tillage. In 2000 (SMR file), the monument survived as a small partially overgrown, circular area (int. diam 5m) enclosed by a low earthen bank (int. H 0.15m; Wth 2.4m; ext. H 0.5m). with no trace of an outer fosse. However, ploughing up to the edge of the monument may have resulted in its infilling. In 2007, the monument was completely ploughed over revealing a central circular area of grey ash, charcoal and burnt bone which was girdled by a band (Wth c. 1.2m) of pale yellow soil with possible human bone, charcoal and burnt earth inclusions.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy   Date of upload: 30 August 2012

Towards the N end of Carbury Hill (0D 470 feet) and the northernmost of three closely associated sites; another ringbarrow (KD008-005----), c. 180m to the SW, and a possible mound barrow (KD008-003----), c. 360m to the SW, all excavated by Willmot in 1936 under a State financed scheme for the relief of unemployment (1938, 130-42 (Site B)). Only part of the central area and a section of the enclosing element at E were excavated. The grass-covered circular area (int. diam. c. 30m) was found to be defined by an inner, rock-cut fosse (Wth c. 4.5m; D c. 1.1m), and an outer 'bank' (Wth c. 4.5m; H c. 0.8m) constructed of broken stone and gravel, with a possible (but unexcavated) entrance gap at the NE. The central area was composed of a layer of decomposed rock (D c. 0.45-0.6m) and contained two postholes of undetermined function and nineteen burials. These included four cremations, two of which were disturbed, and fifteen extended inhumation burials, four of which were children, and some of which contained the remains of more than one individual. The cremations appeared to precede the inhumations and one was accompanied by two iron rings and a pin-shaped fragment of iron. All the inhumations had their heads placed towards the SW, and one was accompanied by an iron shears. Other finds included flint scrapers and knives, a stone disc, a sherd of pottery of undetermined type and a 'bronze knob'. The two burial rites suggest a long period of use, perhaps spanning the Late Bronze Age/Iron Age period. The monument was subsequently restored to it's pre-excavated morphoplogy.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Some 180m NE of the summit of Carbury Hill (OD 470 feet) and the central of three closely associated monuments; a possible mound barrow (KD008-003----) c. 180m to the SW, and a second ringbarrow (KD008-004----) c. 180m to the NE, all excavated by Willmot in 1936 under a State financed scheme for the relief of unemployment (1938, 130-42: Site A). A circular area (ext. diam. c. 26m) was defined by an inner, rock-cut fosse (av. Wth c. 2.4m; D c. 0.45-c.0.9m) and an outer 'bank' (Wth av. c. 4.8m; H c. 0.6m) constructed of broken, rubble limestone. Opposing entrance gaps occurred at NW (Wth c. 3.65m) and SE (Wth c. 2.4m) and were matched by corresponding, undug, causeways across the fosse. The circular interior (diam. c. 11.6m) was covered by a layer of broken rock (D c. 0.3m) and contained a centrally placed cremation. A second cremation was found in the fosse at N. Finds included eight worked flints, a spindle whorl, two sherds of red 'gritless' pottery, a jet spoon, an iron file and a fragment of fused blue glass. An Iron Age date was suggested for the monument, which was subsequently restored to it's original morphology.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Carlow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1993). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Large well preserved monument, consisting of circular area (diam. 19m) enclosed by wide fosse (Wth 10m; D 1.5m). Interior is domed but does not rise above surrounding ground level. Field boundary skirts monument from SE-SW-NW, but no definite evidence of external bank.

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Carlow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1993). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. See also Rathellin ring-ditch (CW016-007----).  Aerial photograph (GB89.P.03) shows cropmark of a circular enclosure defined by three concentric fosses, with evidence of a plough-levelled mound at centre. Comparable to Fenniscourt Barrow (CW016-064).  See attached Google Earth image (imagery date 14 July 2018)   Bibliography Barrett, G.F. In tillage. Visible on Bing Maps Aerial view (pers. comm. P. Reid) a small circular area (est. diam. c. 10m) defined by the cropmark of a back-filled fosse. Possibly the remains of a ring-barrow.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 12 November 2014

In tillage. Visible on Bing Maps Aerial view (pers. comm. P. Reid) a small circular area (est. diam. c. 15m) defined by the cropmark of a back-filled fosse. Possibly the remains of a ring-barrow.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 12 November 2014

Prominently sited on the Redhills, in mixed pasture and tillage, with panoramic aspect in all directions except to the W where higher ground rises less than 50m away from the monument. A low but well-defined, sub-circular, multivallate ringbarrow with three enclosing banks and two intervening fosses (ext. diams. 45.3m E-W; 41m N-S). A relatively small, sub-circular, central area (diams. 7m N-S; 6.5m E-W) is defined by a low, earthen, inner bank (int. H 0.2-0.3m; Wth 2.5m at N-5.1m at E; ext. H 0.3m), a shallow fosse (av. Wth 2m; D 0.2m), a middle bank (int. H 0.2m; Wth 3m at S-6m at E) which has been seriously poached by livestock SW-W-NW, a second fosse (av. Wth 2m; D 0.3m), and by a third, outer bank (int. H 0.3m at N-1m at W; av. Wth 6.5m; ext. H 0.3-0.6m). The monument is virtually covered in thistles.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 05 December 2011

In open level, wet, rough pasture. An oval area (int. diams. 32.3m E-W; 23.2. N-S) is defined by a shallow, wet, internal fosse (Wth 3.3-3.8m; D 0.1m) ESE-NW and a low, broad outer bank (Wth 03.6-4.5m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.4m) which is heavily poached by livestock SSE-W. A possible pond-barrow (KD027-042----) lies c. 50m to the WSW and a possible ring-barrow (KD027-044----) lies c. 35m to the SE.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy   Date of upload: 26 October 2012

In open, level, wet rough pasture. A large, roughly circular area (int. diam. c. 48m) is defined by the remains of a shallow internal fosse (Wth 2.2-3.4m; D 0.4m) NW-NE, and by a low, broad, outer bank (Wth 4.5-6.5m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.3-0.6m) NW-NE, which is reduced to a low scarp (H 0.2-0.6m) elsewhere. The fosse and bank terminate at a heavily poached area at NW which may be an entrance. The S interior and S limits are overgrown with whins and heavily poached by livestock. A possible pond-barrow (KD027-042----) lies c. 65m to the WNW and a possible ring-barrow (KD027-043----) lies c. 35m to the NW.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy   Date of upload: 26 October 2012

On a low short NNW-SSE pasture ridge with a gentle slope to SW and a moderately steep slope to NE, overlooking an enclosure site (KD031-025----) c. 50m to NE. A low heavily overgrown circular earthen mound (diam. 15m; H c. 1.5m) with a domed profile is skirted by a later field boundary bank NW-N-ENE. A shallow enclosing fosse (W c. 2m) noted in 1989 (SMR file) is obscured by cleared field material dumped around the perimeter.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 08 October 2013

On a very gentle, overgrown, SE-facing slope on the Kildare Golf Course, at the NW edge of the Little Curragh. A 1970 aerial photograph (CUCAP BDU 21) shows up to 12 small circular enclosures to the S and SE of a larger enclosure (KD022-040----). A second aerial photo. (undated and unattributed-GSI?) shows these features even more clearly. Described in 1989 as a group of at least 12 small ringbarrows, difficult to discern because of tree and furze stumps and poaching by sheep, but generally small circular areas (est. av. diams. c. 6-c.10m) defined by a very shallow fosse (D 0.05-0.10m) and low outer earthen bank (H0.10m) (SMR file). The area is now almost completely overgrown with whins and the monuments (designated KD022-065001- to KD022-065012-) are no longer clearly visible at ground level. Some of these possible barrows may in fact be lunging rings.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a very gentle, overgrown, SE-facing slope on the Kildare Golf Course, at the NW edge of the Little Curragh. A 1970 aerial photograph (CUCAP BDU 21) shows up to 12 small circular enclosures to the S and SE of a larger enclosure (KD022-040----). A second aerial photo. (undated and unattributed-GSI?) on file shows these features even more clearly. Described in 1989 as a group of at least 12 small ringbarrows, difficult to discern because of tree and furze stumps and poaching by sheep, but generally small circular areas (est. av. diams. c. 6-c.10m) defined by a very shallow fosse (D 0.05-0.10m) and low outer earthen bank (H0.10m) (SMR file). The area is now almost completely overgrown with whins and the monuments (designated KD022-065001- to KD022-065012-) are no longer clearly visible at ground level. Some of these possible barrows may in fact be lunging rings.  One definite ringbarrow (KD022-065001-) lies 10m S of an enclosure (KD022-040----). It is a poorly preserved, partially overgrown sub-circular area (diams. 6.6m N-S; 5.8m E-W) defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 0.9-1.5m; D 0.1m) and a low outer earthen bank (Wth. 1.6m-1.7m; max. ext. diams. 13.3m N-S; c. 13m E-W).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a short, gentle, S-facing slope, overgrown with whins. Described by O'Riordáin (1950, 277: Site E1; scaled section at W Plate XXVII) as an irregular area, 'enclosed by a bank, outside which a slight ditch and low bank are discernible. Interior is sub-divided by banks, the plan of which is not clear as much of the area is overgrown'. A rectangular area (int. dims. L 51.5m E-W; Wth 41m) is defined by a low earthen bank (Wth 4.5m; int H 0.5m; ext H 0.7m) with very faint traces of an outer fosse (Wth 0.9m; D 0.1m) at E. There is an entrance gap (Wth 2.4m) at S. The interior falls 1.5m N-S and a possible ringbarrow lies in the SW sector, where a small circular area (diam. 5.3m) is defined by a broad, shallow fosse (Wth 3.1m at N; D 0.3m) and a low outer earthen bank (Wth 4m; H 0.3-0.8m), N-S. The W-half of the monument has been disturbed and three short lengths of later field banks run from the larger enclosure's bank to converge on the barrow at SE, SW and NW. The larger enclosure may be a later feature and a second ringbarrow (KD022-065001-) lies 10m to the S. The monument is visible on a 1970 aerial photograph (CUCAP BDU 21) which also shows up to 13 small circular enclosures (est. av. diam. 6-10m) in its immediate vicinity; some may be ringbarrows/ringditches, but some are almost certainly lunging rings. The group has been designated KD022-065----.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A slightly domed, circular area (diam. 26m) is enclosed by a shallow fosse with an external bank. An external fosse immediately outside the bank is visible at the S. A second low, concentric bank lies 32m outside the bank (overall diam. of enclosed area 81m). Visible on aerial photograph (CUCAP BDU 21). Two areas of disturbance, several golf greens, and a rectangular house site with attached haggard, defined by low banks and shallow fosses, occur in the area between the inner and outer banks. (O'Riordáin 1950, 276: Site D1; scaled section NW-SE Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Visible on an aerial photograph (CUCAP BDU 21) as the cropmark of a circular area (est max diam. c. 13m), defined by a narrow fosse with suggestions of an outer bank.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A circular area (diam. c. 17m) enclosed by a fosse with an external bank (overall diam. c. 27m). Disturbed at the NE and W by modern trenches. (O'Riordáin 1950, 276: Site C1; scaled section NE-SW Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A raised circular area (diam. c. 20m) containing a small central mound (diam. 3.2m), defined by an inner bank, a fosse, and traces of slight outer bank (overall diam. 32m). Partial excavation by O'Riordáin (1950, 259-269: Site 6) revealed a two-period monument. Phase 1: comprised a low central mound of earth and stone covering the extended inhumation of an adult (head to NW), enclosed by two concentric fosses (c. 6m and c. 8m from the centre) and two smaller fosses close to the central mound - a possible multiple ring-barrow. O'Riordáin suggested that the larger fosses had external banks and that the smaller fosses provided material for the central mound. Phase 2: a cemetery of twelve extended inhumations (head to W), including two children, three adults, two adult females and four adult males was enclosed by the large fosse and bank visible today, and the central mound was also enlarged during this phase. Finds (none directly associated with burials) included six pieces of flint (two worked), one polychrome glass bead (white, yellow and blue), several sherds of medieval pottery and three other sherds with horizontal-line decoration.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A level circular area enclosed by a fosse and external bank (overall diam. 28m) with an entrance at SW. Partially excavated by O'Riordáin (1950, 258-9: Site 5) but no burial or finds were uncovered.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On gently sloping pasture in an area known as the Little Curragh.  Ring-barrow known as Raheenanairy (KD022-042----) located 350m to NE.  Outline of monument clearly visible on 2005 OSI aerial photographs.  Poorly preserved ring-barrow (overall diam. 28m) consisting of a circular area (diam. 19m) enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 2.5m; ext. D 0.1m) and the faintest remains of much degraded bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.1m) now visible as a slight rise of ground.  No other features visible.Compiled by: Caimin OBrien based on details provided by David Brennan.Date of upload: 15 July 2016

A slightly domed, circular area (diam. 5m) enclosed by a shallow fosse with an external bank (overall diam. 13m). Possibly a ring-barrow, but could have been a military field-kitchen.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A small circular area (diam. 5m) enclosed by a shallow fosse and a low external bank (overall diam. 13m). Possibly a ringbarrow, although it may have been a military field-kitchen.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A circular area is enclosed by a fosse and an external bank (max diam. c. 15m). It has a very 'fresh' appearance, and may have been a military field-kitchen.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A level, circular area (diam. c. 28m) is enclosed by a fosse with an external bank (overall diam. 40m). There is an entrance at the W, with a second gap at the NE. Partially excavated by O'Riordáin (1950, 250-253: Site 1). Four post holes and a short shallow trench of uncertain function were discovered, but no evidence of burials was uncovered. Finds included thirteen pieces of flint, including two end scrapers.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A circular area enclosed by a fosse and an external bank (overall diam. 32m), with entrances at the E and W. Partially excavated by O'Riordáin (1950, 254-8: Site No. 4). The extended inhumation of an adult female (head to W) was uncovered at the centre of the monument and finds included fragments of flint and a bronze ring.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Circular earthen mound, surrounded by a fosse with an external bank (diam. c. 60m) (shown on 1908 OS 6-inch map), the cropmark of an outer enclosure, and a curving field boundary at the S and W which may be part of the original monument. The mound (summit diam. c. 2m) appears to be artificial in origin but has been quarried at the E. Small flagstone, possibly a cist capstone, is exposed on the summit of the mound. Aerial photograph (CUCAP BOC076) shows the cropmark of an additional fosse with an external bank between the enclosure and field boundary, traces of which are visible at ground level (max dims of outer enclosure c. 155m x 116m). Both fosses are shallow (W c. 5m); banks are low and wide (W c. 5m). According to Fitzgerald the site was known locally as 'Dun-fin-yeen' and the central mound was 'said to be chambered' (FitzGerald 1899-1902, 132-3). Situated in gently undulating pasture land, on natural hillock. See also Rathwalkin (KD022-021----) which is a similar unusually large barrow.  See attached image of Google Earth photograph taken 14/07/2018   Date of upload: 15 September 2016

A slightly domed, circular area (diam. c. 9m) enclosed by a shallow fosse with a low external bank (overall diam. 18m). Disturbed at centre. (O'Riordáin 1950, 277: Site F1; scaled section NW-SE Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A slightly domed, circular area (diam. c. 4m) enclosed by a broad shallow fosse and wide low bank (overall diam. 14m). Partially excavated by O'Riordáin (1950, 253-4: Site No. 2). Two possible postholes were noted in the central area, but no burial evidence was uncovered. Finds included two fragments of struck flint and a small round scraper.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a slight rise on the Curragh.  A low, raised area enclosed by a fosse with possible low bank is visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 17/01/2020.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 14/11/2019Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles CaillèreDate of upload: 12 November 2020
On a slight rise. A low, raised, central area (diam. 6m) is enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2m) and a low, outer bank (overall diam. 14m).Compiled by: Gearóid ConroyDate of upload: 10 June 2011

On a slight rise on the Curragh.  A  small sunken area enclosed by a fosse with possible low bank is visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 17/01/2020.See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 14/11/2019Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles CaillèreDate of upload: 12 November 2020

Situated on a slight rise and disturbed by the insertion of two military pill-boxes. A circular area (diam. 28m) is enclosed by a fosse and an external bank (overall diam. 42m), and there is an entrance at the E. (O'Riordáin 1950, 276: Site B1; scaled section NE-SW Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Lies between the Gibbet Rath (KD023-042----) to the W and the Curragh Military Camp to the E. Another ringbarrow (KD023-044----) lies c. 160m to the NE. A raised, central, circular area (diam. c. 25m, H 2m) is enclosed by a fosse and an external earthen bank (overall diam. 38m). Causeways and gaps at the NNE and S are possibly modern, and there is some disturbance to the interior, upon which whins are starting to establish. (O'Riordáin 1950, 276: Site X; scaled section E-W Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A circular area enclosed by a very shallow fosse, with faint traces of an external bank (overall diam. c. 40m). A very distinct cropmark of a fosse is visible on aerial photographs (GSI N 340, 341), but these show no causeway or entrance feature. (O'Riordáin 1950, 276: Site A1; scaled section N-S Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Lies c. 160m to the NE of another ringbarrow (KD023-043----). A slightly raised, central, circular area (diam. 23m) is enclosed by a fosse and an outer bank (overall diam. 42m). The N-limits are disturbed by a narrow plantation of trees flanking a road. (O'Riordáin 1950, 276: Site W; scaled section E-W Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Located towards the S end of a N-S ridge and overlooking the W shore of Greaghlone or Beagh Lough, which is c. 250m to the SE. Aerial photographs (GSIAP: H 48/49) from the 1970s show a small circular enclosure. No archaeological feature is visible at ground level in pasture.   Date of revised upload: 25 August 2017

Situated in a slight hollow in a fairly level landscape. This is a low, grass-covered mound (diam. of base 17m NW-SE; H 0.5-0.7m) separated by a fosse (Wth of top 6-8m; Wth of base 1-2.6m; ext. D 0.2-0.5m) from an outer earthen bank (Wth of base 7-9m; ext. H 0.4-0.7m). The perimeter is slightly distorted by a WNW-ESE field bank at N (max. ext. diam. 37m NW-SE).   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 12 April 2019

A level circular area (diam. 19.1m) is enclosed by a well-defined, flat-bottomed fosse and by an outer earthen bank (overall diam. 29.5m). There is a possible causeway at the NE, and the monument is covered with gorse.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A small earthen mound (H. c. 2.3m - 3m; upper surface diam. c. 5m) is badly damaged by heavy vehicle traffic at N and S. Traces of a possible outer bank are visible at the NE. (O'Riordáin 1950, 276: Site V; scaled section NE-SW Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

At the E foot of a long, gentle slope. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). A very heavily poached oval area, used as sheep feeding station, (diams. 7.1m E-W; 4.8m N-S) is defined by low, broad, earthen bank (Wth 1.6m at S-3.5m at E; H 0.2m), which is heavily poached in the W sector.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

In level pasture in an area of extensive sand and gravel pits. Visible on a 2009 Google earth image as the cropmark of a fosse enclosing a circular area (estimated diameter c. 18m), possibly a ringbarrow (pers. comm. D. Brennan, 30-03-2015).   Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy   Date of upload: 22-12-2015

In grassland, immediately E of the townland boundary with Castledermot and S of the Lerr River.  Cropmark of circular-shaped area (approx. int. diam. 12m) defined by a ditch with low external bank visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 22/03/2011 and 05/11/2011. Cropmark clearly visible on Digital Globe orthoimage take 2005-12.        See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Seán Sourke  Date of upload: 11 December 2020

On level ground at the N end of a short, low N-S ridge. A second ringbarrow (KD023-091----) lies 46m away, at the S end of the same ridge. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A sub circular area (diams. 3.1m N-S; 2.2m E-W) is defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.3m; D 0.2m), and by a low, outer, earthen bank (Wth 0.9-1.8m; int H 0.2-0.3m; ext H 0.1m) NNW-E-WSW.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On level ground at the S end of a short, low, N-S ridge. A second ringbarrow (KD023-089----) lies 46m away, at the N end of the same ridge. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A poorly preserved, partially dug-away site, comprising a circular area (diams. 1.8m N-S; 1m E-W) defined by a very shallow fosse (Wth 2.3m; D 0.1m) and low, outer, earthen bank, ENE-SE and S-NW. The interior contains a trigonometrical station at SW.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

At the E end of a low E-W ridge. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A small, sub circular area (diams. 5.3m E-W; 5m N-S) is defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 1-1.4m; D 0.15m), and a low, external, earthen bank (Wth 2.6-3.4m; int. H 0.2m; ext H 0.1m). There is a entrance gap (Wth 2.4m) in the bank, and a corresponding causeway (Wth 1.4m) across the fosse at WSW.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Situated on a broad SE-NW ridge or spur in a low-lying landscape with a small E-W stream curving around the point on the N side and turning S into a mill-pond. This is a circular grass-covered area (diam. 4.3m) defined by a rounded fosse (Wth of top 4.2-4.5m; int. D 0.5-0.6m; ext. D 0.9-1m) and an outer bank (Wth of base 4.5-5.6m; ext. H 0.4-0.7m) with bushes (max. ext. diam. 18.6m NW-SE). There is a causeway (Wth of top 1.2m; H 0.6m) and entrance (Wth 2.6m) through the bank at WNW marked by stones.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Monaghan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Revised by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 30 January 2018

Midway down a short but moderately steep S-facing slope, immediately W of a small, tarred track. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A small, very slightly raised circular area (diam. 2m; H 0.2m) is defined by a narrow, shallow fosse (Wth 0.9-1.4m; D 0.15m), and a slight, outer, earthen bank (Wth 1.9-3.4m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.15m) ENE-S-NNW. A gap (Wth 0.8m) in the bank at S may be an original entrance, but there is no evidence of a corresponding causeway across the fosse. The perimeter is damaged by vehicles at NE.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A slightly raised, circular area (diam. 12m) is enclosed by a shallow fosse and three external banks and two further fosses (overall diam. c. 45m). The banks decrease in height and width away from the centre, and there is an entrance at S. A military pill-box has been inserted into the middle fosse at SW. The site is very overgrown with whins. (O'Riordáin 1950, 274: Site A; scaled section NW-SE Plate XXVII).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a hilltop. A circular area (diam. c. 40m) is enclosed by a broad fosse (Wth 4m, D 0.6-0.8m) and an outer earthen bank. No visible entrance.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 16 October 2013

A level, circular area (diam. 31m) is enclosed by a well-defined fosse and by a low, outer, earthen bank. A slight berm is visible between the fosse and the bank from NE-E-SSE (overall diam. 50m). There is some modern disturbance at the N. (O'Riordáin 1950, 276: Site U; scaled section E-W Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A domed, circular area (diam. c. 13m) is enclosed by a fosse and an outer bank (overall diam. 22m). There is an entrance at S. (O'Riordáin 1950, 276: Site T; scaled section NW-SE Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a low knoll at the S edge of The Curragh. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). Another ringbarrow (KD028-005----) lies on slightly higher ground c. 115m to the SW. A fairly well-preserved, circular area (diam 12.8m) is defined by a fosse (Wth 2.8-3.3m; D 0.2-0.8m) and a low, earthen, outer bank (Wth 3.4-4.8m; H 0.2-0.4m), which has been pushed into the fosse between SSW and NW. There is an entrance gap (Wth 2.5m) and corresponding causeway (Wth 1.6m) at SSW.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

The monument was recorded as Site A9 on an Environmental Impact Statement on the N9/N10 Kilcullen to Waterford scheme: Kilcullen to Powerstown (pers. comm. N. Dunne 30-04-2015). It is described as a fairly prominent subcircular earthen mound (H 2m; diams. 20m; 18m) enclosed along the N by a possibly later fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.3m) which appears to truncate the N slope of the mound. Four mature beech trees stand on the mound. According to local tradition, the mound and surrounding fields contain the burials of rebels who died in the 1798 Rebellion.  In 2002, a geophysical survey in the vicinity revealed ditches apparently girdling and radiating from the mound.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 25 May 2015

On a gentle rise. A raised, circular area (diam. 4m) is enclosed by a fosse and an outer bank. There is a possible entrance at ESE. Site has been damaged by quarrying at S. (O'Riordáin 1950, 275: Site S)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A circular area (diam. 21m) is enclosed by a fosse with an external bank (overall diam. 38m). A second, probably modern, fosse lies outside the bank at W. (O'Riordáin 1950, 275: Site Q; scaled section E-W Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a knoll on the S edge of The Curragh. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). A very poorly preserved, partially whin-covered, circular area (est. diam. 10-12m) is defined by a fosse (Wth 3.3-3.8m; D 0.3m) and by a low, outer, earthen bank (Wth 2.5-3m; H 0.15-0.3m), NW-N-E. There is an entrance gap (Wth 4m) and corresponding causeway (Wth 3.5m) at E. The S and W portions of the monument have been largely quarried out.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On level pasture at the W foot of a low knoll, 11m E of the Slate River. A very poorly preserved, sub-circular area (diams. 6.4m N-S; 6.1m E-W) is defined by a shallow, inner fosse (Wth 0.7m at N-2m at W; D 0.15m), and a very low, outer earthen bank (Wth 2.7m-5.4m; H 0.2m) NNW-SE. The ground immediately outside the monument along the W is poached by livestock.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a slight rise. A circular area (diam. c. 15m) is enclosed by a fosse and an external bank (overall diam. c. 26m). (O'Riordáin 1950, 275: Site P; scaled section NW-SE Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A circular area (diam. 26m) is enclosed by a fosse and an outer bank. The interior is used as a golf-green on the Curragh Golf Course. (O'Riordáin 1950, 275: Site O; scaled section N-S Plate XXVII).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a S-facing slope. A fairly disturbed, circular area (diam. c. 14m) is enclosed by a fosse with an external bank (overall diam. c. 21m). (O'Riordáin 1950, 275: Site N; scaled section N-S Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

At the S foot of a short but moderately steep, whin-covered slope. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A small, circular area (diam. 5.5m) is defined by a fairly broad, shallow, wet and heavily poached fosse (Wth 2.1-3.8m; D 0.2-0.3m) and a low, outer earthen bank (Wth 1.9-3.1m; int. H 0.2m; ext. h 0.2-0.6m). The poaching in the fosse results from schooling horses there, and were it not for the presence of an outer bank, this site could be dismissed as a modern 'lunging ring'. It's possible, however, that an existing barrow was reused as a 'lunging ring'. A second, somewhat similar site (KD013-086----) lies 10m to the NE.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A slightly domed, circular area (diam. 17m) is enclosed by a fosse with an external earthen bank (overall diam. 29m). A townland boundary bank overlies the E-limits. (O'Riordáin 1950, 274: Site D; scaled section N-S Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A circular area is enclosed by traces of a shallow fosse (diam. c. 13m) and a barely discernible outer bank. The site is disturbed by a modern track way crossing N-S over it. (O'Riordáin 1950, 274: Site C; scaled section N-S Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A raised, circular, central area (diam. 19m) is enclosed by a fosse and an outer bank (overall diam. c. 29m). The E limits are partially overlain by a modern trackway. (O'Riordáin 1950, 274: Site B; scaled section N-S Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A small, level, circular area (diam. 5.4m) is enclosed by narrow shallow fosse and outer bank. Modern interference has resulted in some ten, small, regular trenches projecting from the inner face of the bank towards the interior. (O Riordáin 1950, 275: Site L; scaled section N-S Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Visible on GoogleEarth (accessed 09-03-2012) as a small, possibly raised, circular area (est. diam. c. 10m) enclosed by a fosse and also by a possible low outer bank.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 9 March 2012

A slightly domed, circular area (diam. c. 7m) is enclosed by a slight fosse (D 0.4-0.5m) and an external bank (overall diam. c. 17m). Military trenches have levelled the E part of monument. (O'Riordáin 1950, 275: Site J)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A slightly dished, circular area (diam. 17m) is enclosed by a well-defined, flat-bottomed fosse and a low external bank (overall diam. 25m). Extensively disturbed by military trenches at the W and N. (O'Riordáin 1950, 275: Site H; scaled section NW-SE Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A small, slightly domed, circular area (diam. 4m) is enclosed by a fosse with traces of a low outer bank (overall diam. 13.2m). Disturbed at the N by military trenches. (O'Riordáin 1950, 275: Site G; scaled section E-W Plate XXVII)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

A small, raised, central area (diam. c. 6m) is enclosed by a fosse (overall diam. 10.2m) which has been disturbed by military trenches. There are traces of a possible outer bank (W c. 1.5m), and the site is partially covered with gorse. (O'Riordáin 1950, 274: Site E)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Shown on the 1st ed. (1838) of the OS 6-inch map as a small, circular enclosure (est. diam. c. 12m). Described in 1955 as a low circular mound (diam. 16.5m) with a fosse and outer bank, and damaged at the NE (SMR file). Possibly a ringbarrow. At the foot of a gentle N-facing pasture slope. No visible surface trace survives.   Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 13 February 2013

Situated on top of a hill that is described as Gallows Hill in italic lettering on the OS 6-inch maps.
