This is a circular grass-covered area (diam. 37m E-W; 35m N-S) defined by a low scarp (Wth 4-5m; H 0.5m at E to 1m at W) separated by a slight fosse or berm (Wth 2-3m) from an outer grass-covered bank (Wth of base 6.5-9m; int. H 0-0.2m; ext. H 0.4-0.5m). There are traces of a second outer fosse NW-E, and there is a gap in the bank at SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 5 September 2018

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Carlow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1993). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Small circular area enclosed by low earthen bank. Rises very slightly to centre (overall diam.. 14m; Wth of bank c. 1.5m).

In pasture on the long gentle NE slope of Brewel Hill. A second ringbarrow (KD032-024----) lies c. 80m to the E, a third (KD032-023----) c. 230m to the N and a fourth (KD032-022----) c. 250m to the NE. A fairly well-preserved, though overgrown, circular area (diam. 21.5m) is enclosed by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth. 2.2m; D below interior 1.6m; D below outer bank 1.6-2.1m) and a broad outer bank (Wth 9-12.5m; ext. H 1.1m; ext diam. of monument 55m).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 21 October 2013  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 8/1976).

In pasture on a long gentle NE slope of Brewel Hill. A second ringbarrow (KD032-025----) lies c. 80m to the W, a third (KD032-022----) c. 220m to the N and a fourth (KD032-023----) c. 250m to the NW.  A low circular area (diam. 14m) is enclosed by a shallow fosse (D 0.3-0.5m; Wth 3.5-4m), and by a low broad outer bank (int. H 0.3.0.5m; Wth 7.5m; ext H 0.1-0.3m) SE-W-NE, which is truncated by a road NE-SE.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 18 October 2013  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 8/1976).

In a front garden on the NE slope of Brewel Hill. A second ringbarrow (KD032-023----) lay c. 120m to the WSW, a third (KD032-024----) lies c. 240m to the S and a fourth (KD032-025----) lies c. 250m to the SW. Although not recorded on OS mapping, this monument is visibly upstanding on 1963 and 1969 aerial photographs  (CUCAP AIC 91 and CUCAP AYL 88), where it can be seen as a raised circular area enclosed by a broad fosse and outer bank (est. overall diam. c. 48m) In 1985, it was almost imperceptible at ground level; a circular area (diam. c. 17m) enclosed by a broad, shallow fosse. Local information at that time was that the land had recently been improved here (SMR file). In 1994, a report on archaeological trail trenching in advance of the construction of a private dwelling house just to the SW of the site noted that no visible surface trace of  the monument survived. (Opie and Keeley-Schmidt. Excavation Licence No. 94E029) The monument itself was not trial trenched and sub-surface deposits may survive intact.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 18 October 2013

Situated on a NW-SE ridge, it is described as Sallow Fort on the OS 6-inch maps. This is a circular grass-covered area (diam. 30m N-S; 29m E-W) defined by a fosse (Wth of top 3.2m; Wth of base 2m; int. D 0.7m; ext. D 1m) and an overgrown outer bank (Wth of base 8.2m; ext. H 0.7m), best preserved SSE-SW but visible all around. There is a line of boulders (L 6.2m) on the edge of the platform at S. The interior is bisected by a NE-SW field bank with a drain on the SE side.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 3 September 2018

Situated in reclaimed grassland.  Cropmark of circular shaped area (approx. diam. 36m) visible on Google earth aerial imagery taken 02/06/2016.  On this aerial photograph there is the cropmark of a small central circular feature like a small mound.  Could be the cropmark of a possible ring-barrow.  See attached image taken from Google Earth aerial photograph taken 02/06/2016  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Dr. Rob O'Hara  Date of upload: 25 February 2020

Situated at a break in a NE-facing slope on the E side of Tinoran Hill and immediately E of the outer rampart of the hillfort (WI026-004----). Low domed interior (diam. 11m) encircled by a fosse (Wth c. 7m; D 0.2m) and a low outer bank (Wth c. 10m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 17 December 2008

On Silliot Hill (OD 499 feet). A circular area (diam. 33m) is enclosed by a very regular earthen bank (H 1.4m; W 3.7m), with slight traces of an internal fosse. In 1955, it was noted that the bank looked partially remodelled, the fosse was some 12 feet (c. 3.65m) wide but was effaced in parts, and there was a ruined summer house on the fosse and bank at NW (SMR file). Ó Murchadha (2002, 70) concludes that,   here, on or around Silliothill in the parish of Carnalway, Oenach Carmain was celebrated. Oenach/áenach generally denotes an assembly of people, and originally these celebrations were probably funeral rites, so that óenach became associated with such burial sites as Tailtiu, Brug na Bóinne and Emain Macha. Among the Laigin of south Leinster, the assembly known as Oenach Carmain was a highly esteemed one (ibid. 57).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 14 June 2012

Cropmark of possible ringbarrow visible on Google earth aerial imagery.  See attached image taken from Google Earth aerial photographs taken 28/06/2018.  Compiled by; Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Edward O'Riordan.  Date of upload: 2 November 2018

Eight barrows occupy the fairly level, nettle-covered, narrow upper surface of a short, N-S esker in level pasture, with evidence of previous extensive sand/gravel extraction immediately to the N and E. Six contiguous barrows (KD019-001001-, KD019-001002-, KD019-001003-, KD019-001006-, KD019-001008-, KD019-001009-) run N-S, in-line at the N end of the esker and are contained in an enclosure (KD019-001004-) which girdles the lower slopes of the esker, while a seventh and eight barrow (KD019-001005-, KD019-001007-, ) lies c. 48m slightly down slope, and outside the enclosure, to the S. KD019-001---- is the most northerly barrow in the group. A small circular area (diam. 8m) is defined by a shallow inner fosse (Wth 1.9-3m; D 0.1-0.4m), and by a low, narrow, round-topped, outer earthen bank (Wth 1.4m; int H 0.1-0.4m; ext H 0.3-0.7m) SE-WSW and WNW-NE. A second barrow (KD019-001002-) abuts the monument at S.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Revised by: Caimin O'Brien with details kindly provided by Chris Corlett  Date of revised upload: 29 November 2018

Situated on flat grassland immediately N of Knockloe House and to the W of the driveway leading up to the abandoned ruins of this country house.  One of a group of 5 possible barrows (WI037-029001-/005-) clustered in a small field (dims. 59m NE-SW; 110m N-S) clearly visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph taken November 2011. Site consists of a low circular mound (approx. diam. 9m) enclosed by a wide shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.2m) with traces of an external bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.1m) in SW quadrant of field adjacent to driveway leading up to Knockloe House.   According to landowner this field was used to 'ring horses' in the 19th century.  Visible as a cropmark on the 2005 OSI aerial photograph, on this photograph the earthwork (WI037-029005-) in the N quadrant of the field appears to be formed by a circular feeding trough.  The clustering of these earthworks in a small narrow field and their preservation along with their close proximity to Knockloe House may cast doubts on their antiquity.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Dr. Charles Mount.  Date of upload: 9 February 2017

Situated on flat grassland immediately N of Knockloe House and to the W of the driveway leading up to the abandoned ruins of this country house.  One of a group of 5 possible barrows (WI037-029001-/005-) clustered in a small field (dims. 59m NE-SW; 110m N-S) clearly visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph taken November 2011. Site consists of a low barely visible circular rise of ground enclosed by a  shallow fosse in N quadrant of field adjacent to driveway leading up to Knockloe House.   According to landowner this field was used to 'ring horses' in the 19th century.  Visible as a cropmark on the 2005 OSI aerial photograph, on this photograph the earthwork (WI037-029005-) in the N quadrant of the field appears to be formed by a circular feeding trough.  The clustering of these earthworks in a small narrow field and their preservation along with their close proximity to Knockloe House may cast doubts on their antiquity.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Dr. Charles Mount.  Date of upload: 9 February 2017

Situated on flat grassland immediately N of Knockloe House and to the W of the driveway leading up to the abandoned ruins of this country house.  One of a group of 5 possible barrows (WI037-029001-/005-) clustered in a small field (dims. 59m NE-SW; 110m N-S) clearly visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph taken November 2011. Site consists of a low circular mound (approx. diam. 10m) enclosed by a wide shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.2m) with traces of an external bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.1m) in centre of field adjacent to driveway leading up to Knockloe House.   According to landowner this field was used to 'ring horses' in the 19th century.  Visible as a cropmark on the 2005 OSI aerial photograph, on this photograph the earthwork (WI037-029005-) in the N quadrant of the field appears to be formed by a circular feeding trough.  The clustering of these earthworks in a small narrow field and their preservation along with their close proximity to Knockloe House may cast doubts on their antiquity.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Dr. Charles Mount.  Date of upload: 9 February 2017

Situated on flat grassland immediately N of Knockloe House and to the W of the driveway leading up to the abandoned ruins of this country house.  One of a group of 5 possible barrows (WI037-029001-/005-) clustered in a small field (dims. 59m NE-SW; 110m N-S) clearly visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph taken November 2011. Site consists of a low circular rise (diam. c. 9m) enclosed by a shallow fosse in NE quadrant of field adjacent to driveway leading up to Knockloe House.   According to landowner this field was used to 'ring horses' in the 19th century.  Visible as a cropmark on the 2005 OSI aerial photograph, on this photograph the earthwork (WI037-029005-) in the N quadrant of the field appears to be formed by a circular feeding trough.  The clustering of these earthworks in a small narrow field and their preservation along with their close proximity to Knockloe House may cast doubts on their antiquity.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Dr. Charles Mount.  Date of upload: 9 February 2017

Situated on flat grassland immediately N of Knockloe House and to the W of the driveway leading up to the abandoned ruins of this country house.  One of a group of 5 possible barrows (WI037-029001-/005-) clustered in a small field (dims. 59m NE-SW; 110m N-S) clearly visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph taken November 2011. Site consists of a low circular mound (approx. diam. 8m) enclosed by a wide shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.2m) with traces of an external bank (Wth 2m; ext. H 0.1m) in SE quadrant of field adjacent to driveway leading up to Knockloe House.   According to landowner this field was used to 'ring horses' in the 19th century.  Visible as a cropmark on the 2005 OSI aerial photograph, on this photograph the earthwork (WI037-029005-) in the N quadrant of the field appears to be the formed by a circular feeding trough.  The clustering of these earthworks in a small narrow field and their preservation along with their close proximity to Knockloe House may cast doubts on their antiquity.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Dr. Charles Mount.  Date of upload: 9 February 2017

In open, level tillage. Visible on a 1967 aerial photograph (CUCAP ATC042) as the cropmark of three concentric fosses (est. max. diam. c. 30m), but not visible at ground level in 1985 (SMR file). Probably the site of a multivallate ringbarrow.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Situated on the level summit of a low hill. Circular site (diam. 48m) defined by wide, shallow scarped fosse (Wth c. 20m; D 1m) with a domed central rise.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 17 December 2008

Located on top of a drumlin. This is s circular grass-covered area (diam. of top 11.5m NE-SW; 10.5m NW-SE; H 0.3-0.4m) defined by a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth of top 5.3-7.2m; Wth of base 3-3.7m; ext. D 0.8-0.9m) and an overgrown outer bank (Wth of base 3.5-5m; ext. H 0.3-0.7m). There is a gap (Wth of base 1.2m) in the bank but no causeway at W.    The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Revised by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 26 October 2018

Situated on level ground at a break in a gentle S/SE-facing slope with extensive views. Circular mound (diam. 12.3m; H 1.8m) surrounded by exposed stones on the N perimeter of the mound may represent a kerb.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 17 December 2008

On the crest of a hill in pasture. A totally overgrown, level circular area (est. int. diam. c. 20m) is defined by three low, wide earthen banks with three intervening fosses (ext. diam. c. 64m). The outer bank acts as a roadside field boundary NE-ESE (ORiordáin 1950, 273)   Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 08- June 2012

Located in a fairly level landscape. A small embanked enclosure (ext. diam. c. 25m) is depicted only on the 1836 edition of the OS 6-inch map where it is described as a Fort. This is a circular grass-covered area (diam. 9m) defined by two concentric fosses and outer banks (max. ext. diam. 25m). It is faintly visible on Google Earth (28/06/2018).
column13: The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 27 August 2019

column10: In a narrow roadside strip of woodland, in mixed pasture and tillage. A slightly raised (H 1m) circular area (diam. c. 25m) is enclosed by a shallow fosse (D 0.75m; Wth 2.5-3m) and a low outer, earthen bank (H 0.7m; Wth 3m). The bank has been reused both as a woodland boundary SE-SW-NW, and as a roadside boundary NE-E. (ORiordáin 1950, 273)   Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 08 June 2012

Situated at the base of a natural hollow surrounded by marked slopes on all sides. Oval enclosure (dims. 38m E-W; 24.8m N-S) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 5-5.5m; int. H 0.9m; ext. H 0.3m) and an external flat-bottomed fosse (Wth 2-2.5m; D 0.7m). Inside the bank at the N, E and W is a narrow drainage fosse (Wth 0.5m). In view of its location the site could be a landscape feature rather than a ringfort. No visible indication of an entrance or internal features.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 17 December 2008

A Registered Historic Monument (HM01307). On a slight rise and now surrounded by car parking for Punchestown Racecourse. A small and very overgrown circular area (diam. 15m) is enclosed by a shallow fosse (D 0.3m; Wth 3m), a low earthen bank (H 1m; Wth 4m), a second fosse (D 0.5m; Wth 2m) and a second, outer bank upon which cleared field material has been dumped. (ORiordáin 1950, 273)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 11 June 2012

Cropmark of circular-shaped trivallate ditched enclosure/barrow (approx. ext. diam. 30m) visible on Google earth aerial imagery.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Edward O'Riordan.  See attached image taken from Google Earth aerial photographs taken 28/06/2018.  Date of upload: 6 November 2018

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007Circular area with surrounding ditch and outer bank (diam. 33m) (JRSAI 1978, 52, fig. 22, site 3). Barely perceptible on ground.

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007Swan (JRSAI 1978, 52, fig. 22, site 5) identified circular area defined by slight depression (diam. c. 14m). Not preceptible on ground.

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007Slightly domed circular area, defined by slight fosse (diam. c. 20m) (JRSAI 1978, 52, fig. 22, site 4). Barely preceptible on ground. Perhaps Petrie's 'Mur na d-tri g-cogur'. (TRIA 1839, Pl. 7)

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007Circular mound (diam. 10m, H 0.7m) with pit dug through it. Mound may be modern upcast from pit as lazy beds do not run over it. Identified (TRIA 1837 C, Pl. 7) as 'Dall'. (JRSAI 1978, 53, site a)

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007Slightly domed circular area, defined by shallow fosse (diam. c. 18m) (JRSAI 1978, 52, fig. 22, site 1).

Situated on a slight E-facing slope in a low-lying landscape, with a SE-NW section of the River Skane c. 100m to the NE. This feature is most clearly visible on Apple Maps but can also be seen on Google Earth (24/03/2012; 07/05/2017; 14/05/2020) and OSI aerial images. A small circular grass-covered mound (diam. c. 5m) is separated by a fosse from an outer bank (ext. diam. c. 15m). There is a tree on the bank at SW, and the monument was first reported by Jean Charles Caillére.   See the attached enhanced view from Apple Maps   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload; 11 October 2021

Situated on a gentle NE-facing slope 50m E of the top of a ridge with good views over the Kings River valley. A circular flat-topped central mound (5m E-W; 6m N-S) with a broad fosse (Wth 4m; D 1m) and a slight external bank (Wth 2.5-3m; H 0.3m) (max. ext. dims. 18m E-W; 17m N-S). (Information A. O'Sullivan)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 17 December 2008

Prominently located (OD c. 296m) at the NE end of a narrow-topped, moderately steep-sided NE-SW ridge, overlooking Glen Ding valley to the NE and with panoramic views in all directions except SW. A sub-circular area (diam. 14.4m E-W; 13.4m N-S) is defined by a shallow fosse (D 0.2-0.4m: base Wth 0.8m at N  3.5m at E) and by a low, heavily poached outer earthen bank (int. H 0.2-0.6m; Wth 2.5m at S  4.1m at W; ext. H 0.3-0.5m) which has a spine of dense stony material, and possible small inner revetting stones at S (ext. diam. 29m E-W; 27.5m N-S). An entrance gap (Wth 3.3m) at ESE is flanked on its S side by a single revetting stone on the inner face of the bank.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 23 July 2012

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on a slight knoll in undulating countryside. Ring-barrow, consisting of a level circular platform (diam. 5.5m, H 0.5m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 4.5m) and external bank (Wth 4.5m, H 1m). In centre of interior is the side slab of a cist (LH003-019002-). Local tradition of 'cave' in this 'fort', owing to the discovery of this cist.

Situated at W end of a high E-W ridge. Circular, level area (diam. 14m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 3.7m, D 0.3m) and external bank (Wth 6.4m, H 0.3m). The monument, though much degraded, is clearly a ring-barrow.  The above description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 July 2007

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on E shelf of long, wide ridge. Ploughed-out ring-barrow (overall diam. 16m), now visible only as sub-circular area demarcated by traces of a fosse (Wth 1.6m). Possibly part of same barrow group as nearby barrow in Rathlust townland (LH017-069----). (CLAJ 1944, 327; OS Memorandum 6352 B).

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on summit of ridge. Ring-barrow, consisting of a level, circular interior (diam. 11.5m, H 0.7m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.2m at base, 2.7m at top) and external bank (Wth 3.5m, H 0.4m). Referred to as a 'fort' by MacIvor (CLAJ 1944, 327; 1946, 102).

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on summit of shelf at E end of a ridge. Ploughed-down ring-barrow (overall diam. 25.3m), consisting of interior (diam. 8.5m) enclosed by fosse (Wth 4m) and external bank (Wth 4.9m, H 0.1m). Referred to by Stubbs (CLAJ 1911, 354) as a small 'rath'. (OS Memorandum 6353 B).

Situated just below summit of hilltop on rough grazing land in upland area.  Outline of possible ring-barrow (approx. overall diam. 11m) consisting of a circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 7m) enclosed by a fosse that is visible on Google earth aerial imagery.  Possible ring-barrow stands on the county boundary between Kildare and Dublin and the townland boundary between Castlewarden North and Castlewarden, Co. Dublin.
column13: See attached image taken from Google Earth aerial photograph taken 24/06/2018  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien    Date of upload: 10 March 2020

column10: A Registered Historic Monument. Shown as a circular feature in this general area on Taylor's Map of County Kildare (1783). Prominently sited on a wooded hilltop (OD 815 feet) with excellent views in all directions. A slightly raised, almost circular central area (diams. 25m E-W; 23m N-S; H 0.6-0.8m) has a small, low mound in its SW sector (diam 4.5m; H 0.6-0.7m), probably the remains of the Trigonometrical station shown on the OS 6-inch mapping, and is girdled by a broad, shallow fosse (Wth 6m), and a low outer bank (H 0.7m; Wth 2m). Intermittent traces of a possible second, narrow, shallow, outer fosse (Wth 1m; D 0.2m) may be a later feature. Some 4m to the SW, a large, roughly squared, stone block (dims. L 1.2m; Wth 1m; H 0.9m) appears to have been deliberately set in place, while two further, overgrown blocks to the SE are of uncertain significance. The monument may be a barrow which was subsequently modified for use as an inauguration site.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on top of a slight natural rise in rolling grassland. Ring-barrow (max. dims. 24.8m by 20.8m), comprising a flat, slightly oval-shaped interior (diam. 14m NE-SW) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2.2m) on S to W and N to NE. External bank (Wth 3.2m) visible only from S-W-NE. A modern field fence truncates the fosse and bank from S-E-NE. The site is referred to as a 'small mount' by Stubbs (CLAJ 1909, 129).

Located on top of Athgoe Hill. This monument comprises a circular, rounded area (int. diam. 44m) which is enclosed by a continuous internal fosse and external bank. The bank is flat-topped (Wth 5m; H 0.5m) and has narrow breaks in the E and W which are probably secondary. There are no corresponding causeways in the fosse (Wth 0.8m; D 0.35m). Within the interior are numerous bumps which were evidently caused by the removal of trees from the site (Healy, pers. comm. ; Thornton 1980; Swan 1986, 4-5). Part of a barrow (DU020-006----) lies c. 150m downslope and N of this ring-barrow.  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Date of revised upload: 12 December 2017

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on summit of Mt Oriel, to SE of LH020-005001- and LH020-005002-. Circular, roughly level area (diam. c. 14m) enclosed by slight traces of a bank (Wth c. 1m, H c. 0.2m) on SW, with slight traces of a shallow internal ditch (Wth c. 2m) at this point. The site has a wide, shallow external fosse (Wth 6m, D c. 0.3m) from N-W-SE (overall diam. 26.6m). The site is possibly a type of ring-barrow but interpretation is badly affected by tree-planting and by a former field bank (Wth c. 2-3m) running across the site NE-SW.

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on terrace of E slopes of Mt Oriel. Ring-barrow (max. dim. 21.4m) comprising a circular, level interior (diam. 7.1m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.3m at base, 2.5m at top; D 1.1m) and external bank (Wth 4m overall; H 1.1m internally, 0.6m externally), now much eroded and best preserved on W. Site marked on the 1835 ed. of OS 6-inch map as 'Mount Oriel Fort'.

Located in a low-lying field of pasture at the bottom of Saggart Hill. The site comprises a double-banked barrow (ext. diam.79m). A slightly sunken roughly circular area (diam.27m) is enclosed by a wide flat bottomed fosse (Wth 5m; D 0.55m) an external earthen bank (Wth 10m; H 0.8m) with external shallow fosse (Wth 6m; D 0.45m) and external earthen bank (Wth 8.8m; H 0.6m). The external bank is partially levelled along the N side. A field boundary cuts across the west section of the external bank (Stout 1998, 150, 152). The form of this site is similar to that described in the OS Letters as the 'Rath of Cumhal' (Herity 2001, 42)). Compiled by Geraldine Stout

Excavations in 1995 of a circular mound revealed an enclosing fosse (Wth 0.7m; D 0.25) which produced flint flakes and modern pottery. A copper-alloy brooch pin was found at the edge of the mound. The removal of the mound exposed an earlier ditch that produced cremated bone and a funnel-shaped pit complex which produced iron slag and an unidentified iron object (Mullins 1996, 13).  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated at Knockandinny, on the northern extremity of Saggart hill. A ring-barrow consisting of a raised circular platform, surrounded by a fosse with a low external bank. The platform (diam. c. 30m) had been built of small stones (Kilbride-Jones 1950, 314-15). Today, this is in the area of Hole 3 on Slade Valley Golf Course. Not visible at ground level (Healy 1975, 1-19).  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig Clancy  Revised upload on: 6 July 2018   This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 154/1940).

Located on the N-facing slope of Saggart Hill at a point known as Knockaniller.  Shown on the 1843 OS 6-inch map as a circular enclosure. This site lay to the SW of the passage tombs at Knockaniller (DU024-005001-, DU024-005002-). Kilbride-Jones (ITA Survey 1939) described it as a raised, perfectly flat-topped, circular platform, surrounded by a circular fosse which was uninterrupted (diam.28m; H 0.95m). The area has been planted with trees leaving no visible trace at ground level. (Healy 1975, 1-19).  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig Clancy  Revised upload on: 6 July 2018  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 153/1940).

Situated on the northern slopes of Saggart Hill, in what is today known as Slievethoul Woods. A ring-barrow indicated on the 1843 OS 6-inch map as a small circular enclosure (diam. c. 20m). The site is under tree cover and not visible at ground level (Healy 1975, 1-19).Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 6 July 2018

Situated on the crest of a ridge at the rear of Glenaraneen House. The ground falls away steeply to the Slade valley and there is a stream to the S of the site.  A ring barrow, the central barrow (ext. diam. 12m) of three,  is defined by an outer bank (Wth 2.5m; H 0.3m) and inner fosse (Wth 1.1m; D 0.28m)(DU024-009003-). The southernmost (ext. diam. 14m) of three, is defined by an outer bank (Wth 2.3-2.5m; H 1.2m) and inner fosse (Wth 2.5m; D0.45m)(DU024-009002-). The southern section of this site is formed by the bank of the outer enclosing area. The N barrow (ext. diam. 11) is defined by an outer bank (Wth 2.5m; H 0.3m) and internal fosse (Wth 0.95m; D 0.25m)(DU024-009004-). The banks of the three possible ring-barrows are planted with scots pine, the outer barrow is planted with thorn. An oval or subrectangular area extending N-S (L 36m; Wth 24m) defined by a bank (Wth 2.3-2.5m; H 1.2m) and outer fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.45m)(DU024-009001-) encloses the three possible ring- barrows.Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 6 July 2018.

Situated on the crest of a ridge at the rear of Glenaraneen House. The ground falls away steeply to the Slade valley and there is a stream to the S of the site.  A ring barrow, the N barrow (ext. diam. 11) of three,  is defined by an outer bank (Wth 2.5m; H 0.3m) and internal fosse (Wth 0.95m; D 0.25m)(DU024-009004-).The central barrow (ext. diam. 12m) of three,  is defined by an outer bank (Wth 2.5m; H 0.3m) and inner fosse (Wth 1.1m; D 0.28m)(DU024-009003-). The southernmost (ext. diam. 14m) of three, is defined by an outer bank (Wth 2.3-2.5m; H 1.2m) and inner fosse (Wth 2.5m; D0.45m)(DU024-009002-). The southern section of this site is formed by the bank of the outer enclosing area. The banks of the three possible ring-barrows are planted with scots pine, the outer barrow is planted with thorn. An oval or subrectangular area extending N-S (L 36m; Wth 24m) defined by a bank (Wth 2.3-2.5m; H 1.2m) and outer fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.45m)(DU024-009001-) encloses the three possible ring- barrows.Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 6 July 2018.

Situated on the crest of a ridge at the rear of Glenaraneen House. The ground falls away steeply to the Slade valley and there is a stream to the S of the site.  A ring barrow, the southernmost (ext. diam. 14m) of three, is defined by an outer bank (Wth 2.3-2.5m; H 1.2m) and inner fosse (Wth 2.5m; D0.45m)(DU024-009002-). The southern section of this site is formed by the bank of the outer enclosing area. The central barrow (ext. diam. 12m) is defined by an outer bank (Wth 2.5m; H 0.3m) and inner fosse (Wth 1.1m; D 0.28m)(DU024-009003-). The N barrow (ext. diam. 11) is defined by an outer bank (Wth 2.5m; H 0.3m) and internal fosse (Wth 0.95m; D 0.25m)(DU024-009004-). The banks of the three possible ring-barrows are planted with scots pine, the outer barrow is planted with thorn. An oval or subrectangular area extending N-S (L 36m; Wth 24m) defined by a bank (Wth 2.3-2.5m; H 1.2m) and outer fosse (Wth 2.5m; D 0.45m)(DU024-009001-) encloses the three possible ring- barrows.Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 6 July 2018

Located in a forest clearing on the upper E-facing slopes of Saggart Hill immediately above the Slade Valley and overlooking the Verschoyles Hills (Kilbride-Jones 1950, 313-32).  Prior to excavation of the site in the 1940s the site comprised a central mound (Wth 8.4m; H 1.2m) defined by a fosse (Wth 3.2m; D 0.7m), a bank (Wth 2m; H 0.75m) and an external v-shaped fosse (Wth 2.25m; D 0.84m; overall diam.41m). Both fosses had an outer retaining wall. Excavation revealed that the central mound covered two burials, both cremations, which were laid directly on a clay surface accompanied by Early Iron Age pottery. This  composite site had been constructed over a habitation site and a timber structure referred to as a 'Sanctuary site' by the excavator. The habitation site consisted of five hut sites and a single communal fireplace. The 'Sanctuary site' was represented by three fireplaces and a total of 160 post-holes forming no clear pattern. The site is very overgrown with furze and regenerating trees.Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 6 July 2018

Situated on the broad ridge of Dowth c. 190m W of Dowth henge (ME020-010----). A remote sensing survey (12R0080 ext.) conducted over most of the Henge field during 2014 recorded a subcircular enclosure (dims c. 44m N-S; c. 41m E-W) defined by a wide fosse (Wth 5m plus) and a possible external bank, with a possible central structure in its interior. This enclosure could lie within a larger enclosure, as suggested by a quiet magnetic halo effect surrounding it. (Ní Lionáin and Davis 2016, 152)   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 9 December, 2016

Situated in a shallow basin at the source of the W-E River Lask, with a slight hill c. 800m to the E and higher hills c. 2km to the NW in Co. Wicklow. This is a circular area (diam. 8.2m) surrounded by a wet fosse (Wth 4.55.8m; D 0.8m) and an outer earthen bank (Wth 1.52m). It is truncated by a NW-SE field bank at SW (max. ext. diam. 21.5m). Pond (WX006-083003-) is c. 30m to the SW. It is now in a coniferous wood.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wexford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1996). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 2 March, 2012

Situated on the summit of the Verschoyles Hill. A ring- barrow  shown on the 1843 OS 6-inch map as a hachured enclosure (diam. c. 37m). It was described by Ua Broin (1957, 43) as a low rath, enclosing a very small circle somewhat higher than the outer one and close to the S side of the latter. The site was ploughed and planted with trees in 1965 (Healy 1975, 1-19). This area is referred to in the OS Letters (1837) as 'Lauree' or 'Lathair na Riogh' on Saggart Hill (O'Flanagan 1927, 22). Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig Clancy Revised upload on: 6 July 2018

Geo-physical survey and test trencing in 2000 revealed a ring barrow. This was located in a slightly elevated position. It comprises a ditch (Wth 2.5m, D 1.6m) which encloses a maximum area of 13m. Fragments of a human skull was found in the upper fill of the ditch. A 'cist-like structure' was exposed in the northern quadrant of the ditch. Cremated bone associated with Early Bronze Age pottery and a bead were found within the interior of the enclosing ditch. Soil samples from the ditch contained remains of barley, wheat, oats and evidence for hazel, haw and sloe (Doyle 2002, 75-6). Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated at the summit of a narrow elongated ridge on the lower SE slopes of the Verschoyles Hill, enjoying extensive views of Tallaght and Lugmore to the N and Seahan Mountain to the E. A ring-barrow initially discovered from aerial photographs taken by BKS in 1978 (2776052/3). It comprises a circular raised area (int. diam. 19m) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 2m; H 0.3m) and inner silted-up fosse (Wth 1.5m; D 0.15m). The bank is very denuded in the W but well preserved in the N and there are breaks at NE, E, and S. Within the interior in the SW and E are a number of furze-covered clumps that may indicate a stone feature. In the SE there is a single boulder (L 0.55m; Wth 0.36m; D 0.3m).Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 6 July 2018

Situated to the W of Mountseskin Road. Marked on the current 1937 OS 6-inch map as a circular enclosure, truncated along the N by a field boundary (diam. c. 30m). According to Ua Broin (1957, 46) this area was called 'Carraig na ffiach'. Part of the site was demolished during field division in the 19th century. Not visible at ground level (Healy 1975, 1-19).Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 6 July 2018

Situated to the E of Mountseskin House, on a SE-facing slope in rich pastureland. A ring-barrow indicated as a roughly circular enclosure on the 1843 OS 6-inch map. It was still standing in the mid 1970s (diam. 16m) when inspected by Paddy Healy (1975, 1-19). It had been cut by a field boundary. Not visible at ground level.Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 7 July 2018

Situated to the E out Mountseskin House, on sloping of ground that falls away steeply to the SE. A ring-barrow comprised of a circular area (int. diam.37m) defined by an inner fosse and outer bank (bank Wth c. 4m; H 0.5m). The site was shown on the 1843 OS 6-inch map as a horseshoe-shaped enclosure. It was surveyed by the Archaeological Society, UCD in 1942. Not visible at ground level (Healy 1975, 1-19). The site is located to the E of a ring-barrow (DU024-022----) and to the west a mound (DU024-023----). Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig Clancy Revised upload on: 7 July 2018

Situated beside the railway line at Greenmount in the paddock are three conjoined circular features, comprising external bank (av. dims. Wth 2.5m; H 0.6m), internal fosse (av. dims. Wth 2m; D 0.25m) and raised interiors (av. ext. diams.11m). Test excavation (Licence no. 06E0348) was undertaken to determine the exact nature of three conjoined ringbarrows possible barrows. Testing on the east-west axis located a ditch along the interior of the bank of one of the three conjoined circular embanked features. Its presence strongly suggests that the feature is a type of barrow and, by inference, that the other two circular features belong to the same monument typology (Lynch 2006; https://excavations.ie/report/2006/Dublin/0015328/).  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/01/2017 showing the conjoined barrows  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Updated by: Christine Baker  Date of upload: 19 January 2015

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007  Flat-topped circular mound defined by fosse (diam. 12m) with external bank (max. ext. diam. 25m). Seven small mounds on outer bank give it beaded appearance.

Discovered prior to road construction (Excavation Licence No. 93E0098). Excavation revealed a penannular ditch with an opening at the NE (max. diam. c. 10.5m). The width of the ditch varied between 1m and 1.5m and the depth varied between 0.2m and 0.9m. It was filled with cremated bone, slag, pieces of metal artefacts, a bead, sherds of flat-bottomed pottery and flint flakes. These finds together with radiocarbon dates suggest the site was constructed and used during the Iron Age. A platform with postholes was discovered beside it and appeared to be contemporaneous. (O' Sullivan, 1993)  Compiled by: Claire Breen  Date of upload: 4 May 2012

This is the denuded remains of a ring-barrow on Tallaght Hill, immediately S of a cist burial (DU0 21-053----). It is divided into two parts by a townland boundary extending N-S. The W section is covered in furze and quarry debris; the E section is the best preserved (ext. diam. 14m N-S). It comprises an external bank (Wth 1.5m; H 0.3m) with inner fosse (Wth 1m; D 0.25m). (Healy 1974, 25). Compiled by Geraldine Stout

Excavated as part of the Dundalk Western by-pass project (Excavation Licence No. 03E0873). One of two small ring-barrows (see also LH004-134003-), (ext. diam. 5-6m; int. diam. 4m), both contained small central pits, possibly containing cremations. (Bayley 2006, 340-1; Bayley 2005, 10)  References:  Bayley, D. 2005 M1 Dundalk Western by-pass site 127: Carn More 5 chainage 24.810-25.100 NGR: 304912 / 310860, Post-excavation assessment and project design on behalf of Louth County Council and the National Roads Authority Licence. Unpublished Report, DAHG 03E0873, Irish Archaeological Consultancy.  Bayley, D. 2006 Site 127, Carn More 5, Faughart Bronze Age cemetery in I. Bennett (ed.), Excavations 2003: summary accounts of archaeological excavations in Ireland, 340-1 (No. 1275). Bray. Wordwell  Compiled by: Claire Breen  Date of upload: 18 November 2011

Excavated as part of the Dundalk Western by-pass project (Excavation Licence No. 03E0873). One of two small ring-barrows (see also LH004-134004-), (ext. diam. 5-6m; int. diam. 3.5m), both contained small central pits, possibly containing cremations. (Bayley 2006, 340-1; Bayley 2005, 10)  References:  Bayley, D. 2005 M1 Dundalk Western by-pass site 127: Carn More 5 chainage 24.810-25.100 NGR: 304912 / 310860, Post-excavation assessment and project design on behalf of Louth County Council and the National Roads Authority Licence. Unpublished Report, DAHG 03E0873, Irish Archaeological Consultancy.  Bayley, D. 2006 Site 127, Carn More 5, Faughart Bronze Age cemetery. In I. Bennett (ed.), Excavations 2003: summary accounts of archaeological excavations in Ireland, 340-1 (No. 1275). Bray. Wordwell  Compiled by: Claire Breen  Date of upload: 18 November 2011

A multi-phase ring barrow (external diam. c. 13.2m), with a centrally placed cremation contained within a pottery vessel, was uncovered here in 2000 prior to construction of the M1 Motorway (Excavation Licence No. 00E0429). The ditch (max. D c. 1m; Wth 1.9m) displayed three distinct phases of activity and at least six token cremations were discovered in the SE quadrant of the final phase. (Chapple 2002, 242-3)  Compiled by: Claire Breen  Date of upload: 25 June 2013

Situated on a prominent rise in pastureland with extensive views. A circular raised area (ext. diam.25.5m) defined by an external bank (Wth 3.8m; H 0.4-0.5m) and internal fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.3m). The E section of the barrow has been truncated by a field boundary extending N-S. (Healy 1975, 1-19).Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 7 July 2018

Situated on a steep N-facing slope which is furze covered, and falls away to a dried-up valley. A ring-barrow identified by Healy (1975, 1-19) as being double-banked. There are man-made terraces on the slope to the SW of the ring-barrow.Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on 7 July 2018

Situated on a hillock, overlooking the Liffey Valley on the grounds of Stewarts Hospital. A circular raised platform (H 0.8m) defined by a slight bank (H 0.3m). The slightly domed interior is completely overgrown (overall diam. c. 15m). It could possibly be an overgrown tree-ring (Healy 1974, 22). Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated in a low-lying landscape. Traces of a ring-barrow showing as cropmark of two concentric ditches (int. diam. c. 30m; ext. diam. c. 45m)  are visible on aerial photograph (ACAP) (Buckley 1987, 20-1). It is also visible on OSI aerial images (1995).   The above description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of revision: 27 Octob3r 2015

Located on the northern slope of a saddle-backed ridge to the south of a townland boundary, c.17m east barrow of DU004-012004-. Tillage right up to the base. The site comprises a subcircular, flat-topped mound (diam. 11.5m; H 1.5m) with a shallow depression near the centre of the flattened top. It was formerly enclosed by a fosse (Hartnett 1957, 267). Part of an extensive barrow cemetery identified by Keeling (1983, 70, Site II).  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Updated by: Christine Baker  Date of upload: 29 October 2014

A small circular grass-covered feature (ext. diam. c. 12m) defined by a slight earthen bank is visible on Google Earth (21/11/2005). The barrow (ME021-026----) is c. 60m to the SE.   Date of upload: 15 September 2017

A small circular grass-covered feature (ext. diam. c. 15m) defined by a slight earthen bank is visible on Google Earth (21/11/2005). The barrow (ME021-025----) is c. 60m to the NW.   Date of upload: 15/09/2017

Situated on the summit of a dome-topped hill with extensive panoramic views. Circular site (int. diam. 17.9m N-S; max. ext. diam. 21m N-S) defined by an earthen bank and internal fosse (int. D 0.5-0.6m; Wth 2.7m). The bank (int. H 1.1m; ext. H 0.9-1m) consists mainly of earth and may have been retouched recently as the edges are very sharp and regular. The interior of the site is flat and is crossed by five lazy-beds. There is a causeway (Wth 1.8m) at the E opposite which two large boulders form an outer facing to the bank. A trigonometrical station is set on the bank immediately N of this point. Marked as an enclosure on the first edition OS 6-inch map. (Robinson 1937, 305-6)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 17 December 2008

In pasture, S of Ballinapark House located 40m to N.  A cluster of three possible ring-barrows (WI040-063-/065----) located in field to S of Ballinapark House which are clearly visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13.   Remains consist of a circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 8m) enclosed by a fosse and slight traces of an external bank.  Possible barrow (WI040-063----) 8m to E and second barrow (WI040-065----) immediately to SW.  These earthworks are clearly visible on Google earth orthoimages taken 30/09/2009.  The sharpness and circularity of these cropmarks along with their close proximity to Ballinapark House may suggest that they could be designed landscape features or some other activity in the post-1700 period.  It is possible that they may have formed by circular-shaped livestock ring-feeders although this is uncertain.  The antiquity of these earthworks remains uncertain.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages taken between 2009-2019  Compiled by: Caimin OBrien based on details provided by Aoibheann Lambe  Date of upload: 8 July 2020

In pasture, S of Ballinapark House located 40m to N.  A cluster of three possible ring-barrows (WI040-063-/065----) located in field to S of Ballinapark House which are clearly visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13.   Remains consist of a circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 11m) enclosed by a fosse and slight traces of an external bank.  Possible barrow (WI040-064----) 8m to W and second barrow (WI040-065----) 15m to SW.  These earthworks are clearly visible on Google earth orthoimages taken 30/09/2009.  The sharpness and circularity of these cropmarks along with their close proximity to Ballinapark House may suggest that they could be designed landscape features or some other activity in the post-1700 period.  It is possible that they may have formed by circular-shaped livestock ring-feeders although this is uncertain.  The antiquity of these earthworks remains uncertain.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages taken between 2009-2019  Compiled by: Caimin OBrien based on details provided by Aoibheann Lambe  Date of upload: 8 July 2020

Ring-barrow situated on the upper slope of a proposed development site with views of Bray Head to the E, Sugar Loaf Mountain to the SE, and Djouce mountain to the S.  The public road located 70m to N marks the townland boundary with Parknasilloge.   Unclassified megalithic tomb (WI007-021----) 370m to NNE, motte castle (WI007-018001-) 300m to SSW, St. Moling's holy well (WI007-016----) 550m to W.   A detailed gradiometer survey was conducted by J. M. Leigh Surveys Ltd. under licence No. 18R0026 in the townland of Powerscourt Demesne, which identified a possible triple-ditched barrow (approx. overall diam. 25m).  The site consists of a small circular area (approx. diam. 8m) enclosed by three widely spaced circular ditches.  The outer circular ditch has a diameter of 25m, the middle ditch 16m and the inner ditch 8m (Leigh 2018, 4).  Archaeological test trenching was undertaken by Irish Archaeological Consultancy Ltd. on behalf of Lota View Holdings Limited, under licence No. 18E0045 in order to archaeologically assess the results of the geophysical survey. The test trenching confirmed the presence of a probable barrow (c. 25m diameter), with three enclosing ditches. No evidence of a burial or cremated remains was identified during the test trenching (Lynch and Kavanagh 2018, i).  The south?western part of the barrow appears to have been removed by agricultural ploughing. Two of the three ditches were identified on the north?eastern side of the site, although the outer ditch was sealed by a spread of archaeological material. The inner ditch was found to have a depth of 0.34m, which suggests that the entire monument has been subject to some truncation due to ploughing.  A number of lithics were recovered during testing, including a quartz core, several individual pieces of quartz and a piece of flint debitage. The items were all recovered from the archaeological spread (C7) and the fill of one of the barrow ditches (ibid., 7).  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 14 May 2018

Situated on the summit of a steep-sided hill with panoramic views. Circular barrow (diam. c. 36m) defined by a broad earthen bank (Wth c. 4m) and an internal fosse with a causeway at the SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 17 December 2008

This monument was discovered during stripping of topsoil on a flat ridge in 1998. It comprises a circular ditch (D 0.6m) with an internal diameter of c. 8.5m which encloses a mound. There were no surviving traces of an external bank. Within the mound was a supine juvenile inhumation in poor condition, and there was no indication of a formal grave-cut. A pit cut into the mound containing five cattle teeth. The central mound was capped with a layer of clay that contained a pit cremation and a number of small spreads of charcoal. There was a small amount of fragmentary burnt human bone in the cremation, suggesting token deposition. Within the ring-ditch the primary fill contained a large number of fragments of burnt bone. The quantity of this material suggests that it may represent pyre debris. Burnt human and animal bone and disarticulated animal bone was distributed irregularly but appeared in various densities throughout the ring-ditch. The faunal remains included cattle teeth and shed antler. Pieces of struck flint were found (mainly at the four cardinal points), including two thumbnail scrapers, which suggest a possible Bronze Age date (0'Neill 2000, 40-42, ).  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Date of upload: 29 April 2009

Geophysical survey (Licence no. 03R0074) undertaken identified two ring barrows external to the bank pf promontory fort  (DU009-001013-) and circular structures within (Cooney 2009, 21). Further geophysical survey (Licence no. 12R078) of the promontory was carried out by The Discovery Programme for the LIARI Project which confirmed the presence of previously identified internal circular anomalies (Dowling 2014).Compiled by: Geraldine StoutUpdated by: Christine BakerDate of upload: 31 December 2014

In a slight hollow in flat pastureland. A well-preserved circular earthen mound (D 13.8m, H 1.9m) with a flat-topped summit and stepped profile. It has been partially dug into at NNE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In pasture, situated on a rise c. 80 from the S shore of Sligo Bay. Circular, flat-topped mound (diam. at base 21.6m; diam. of summit c. 10m; H 1.9-2.4m) of earth and stone. Centrally positioned upon the summit is a small, circular mound (diam. 7m; H 0.7m) which is well defined at S, W and N but which merges with the slope of the main mound at E. The main mound is encircled at its base by a shallow fosse (Wth. 2.6m - 3.4m; D 0.6m). At its outer lip at S are the remains of a narrow bank (Wth 2.8m; H 0.2m) of uncertain antiquity. A modern field wall overlies the fosse at NE-E. Known locally as 'Coggin's Hill' (FitzPatrick, E. (2001), PRIA, 100).   FitzPatrick, E., with contributions by Fenwick J. (2007), 'Interpreting a cultural landscape: a case for sea-weed harvesting at Aughris, Co. Sligo' JIA, 11-34.  FitzPatrick, E. (2001) 'The gathering place of Tír Fhiachragh: archaeological and folkloric investigations at Aughris, Co. Sligo' PRIA 101C, 67-105.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In undulating pastureland. Marked on the 1838 edition of the OS 6-inch map as an embanked circular enclosure (diam. c. 60m) with a central mound is shown. On inspection a well-preserved circular earthwork (diam. c. 10m) comprising a low platform of earth and stone with a small circular raised area (diam. c. 2m) at its centre was visible; possibly a mound barrow. A series of hollows and trenches surrounding the monument appeared to be modern. Quarrying had occurred on its S side.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 25 July 2019

In low-lying poorly drained pasture, on the W bank of a stream. A low circular platform (22.6m N-S; c. 21m E-W) defined by a low bank (Wth 1.2m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.6m) from which some stones protrude. Centrally placed on top of this platform is a smaller flat-topped platform (10.8m N-S; 11m E-W) defined by scarp (H 0.7m). On the S side of this and visible where the scarp has been eroded, is a quantity (c. 4m E-W) of heat-shattered stones in a dark soil matrix, possibly reused fulacht fia material. The barrow is slightly eroded by the adjacent stream N-NE. A holy well (SL038-120002-), cut into the perimeter of the barrow at SE, is surrounded by a cross-slab (SL038-120003-) and a millstone (SL038-120005-). (Farrelly and Keane 2002, 100-101)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In reclaimed pasture 30m SE of a watercourse and 100m W of the townland boundary with Adamstown. One of 13 barrows (LI040-070001/013-) recorded within an area measuring 200m N-S x 250m E-W. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by the Discovery Programme as a potential barrow on examination of Bord Gáis Éireann aerial photograph (BGE 2557; Site No. 6) taken 03/11/1984. No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached Bord Gáis Éireann aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 26 May 2021

In level wet pasture. Bowl-barrow (TS057-011----) is located 180m to the NE. Circular area (diam. 18m) defined by a low earthen scarped edge (Wth 1.2m; H 0.2m) separated by a wide flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 2m; Overall Wth 3.2m; D 0.2m) from a flat-topped earthen berm (Wth at top 2m; overall Wth 5.3m) with an external wide flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 2.3m; overall Wth 3.7; D 0.15m). The fosses and the berm are best preserved ESE-SSE and are absent SW-WNW where a NW-SE orientated modern field drain abuts the external base of the scarp defining the interior at WSW. Interior is level and clear of overgrowth. Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level wet pasture. Ring-barrow (TS057-036----) is located c. 40m to the NE and a barrow (TS057-010----) is located c. 180m to the SW. Low circular flat-topped mound (diam top. 7-8m; H 0.5m) enclosed by a wide flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 1.75m; overall Wth 4.5m; D 0.4m) with an intermediate flat-topped earthen berm (Wth at top 4m) and an external wide flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 1.75m; overall Wth 2.95; D 0.4m). The fosses and the intermediate bank are absent from SE-SW where a modern drain truncates the S side of the central mound and the external fosse has been infilled from SW to W. A modern entrance (Wth 4m), where the fosses have been partially infilled, allows access to the interior at E. Interior is dry and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

At the summit towards the NW end of a NW-SE ridge. Grass-covered circular platform (diam. of top 37m N-S; 37m E-W; H 0.35-1m) separated by a berm (Wth 19-21.6m) which is really a fosse from an earthen bank (Wth 4.4-8.6m; int. H 0.6-1m; ext. H 1.4-1.7m). The bank is surmounted by a stone wall and incorporated into a townland boundary with Rathmew N-SE. This bank is separated by a rounded fosse (Wth of top 6.3-7.2m; Wth of base 1.5-3.3m; D 0.4-1.1m) from an outer bank (Wth 2.4-4.3m; H 0.3-0.45m) which survives only SE-W-N (max. ext. diam. 100m N-S; 96m E-W).  There are small mound barrows at the NW (RO034-035002-) (dims 4m x 4.8m; H 0.3m) and NE (RO034-035003-) (dims 7.2m N-S; 6.2m E-W; H 0.45m) edges of the central platform, and a concentric bank (Wth 3.4-4.4m; H 0.1-0.35m), probably a modern feature, exists on the berm between the platform and the first bank WNW-N-SSE. There is an entrance (Wth 1.8m) through the two outer banks, but no causeway, at WSW. A D-shaped enclosure (RO034-035004-) (int. dims 4.6m N-S; 2m E-W) defined by an earthen bank (Wth 2.4m; H 0.2-0.4m) is attached to the outer bank at WNW. Misinterpretation of the location of barrow (RO034-037----) led to the invention of an enclosure (RO034-035005-) attached to the outer perimeter of the barrow at S. Ditch-barrows (RO034-036----) and (RO034-037----) are just outside the perimeter at WSW and S.  See the attached aerial view taken from the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 24 August 2015  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 17/1977).

In low-lying level wet pasture. Ringfort (TS057-002----) visible c. 185m to the NW and an enclosure (TS057-003002-) visible c. 125m to the SE. Central roughly circular slightly raised area (diam. 12m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 4m; ext. H 0.25m) with a level circular area (Wth 4m) around its base. At the external edge of the level area is a narrow earthen bank (int. H 0.4m; ext. H 1.3m; Wth at top 0.4m; overall Wth 3.8m) with a distinct inner lip (Wth 2m; int. H 0.2m) and an external flat-bottomed water-logged fosse (Wth 4m; D 0.6m). There is no distinct entrance feature. A NE-SW orientated relic field drain links to the fosse at NW and an E-W orientated relic field drain links to the fosse at ESE. The interior is dry and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a slight E-facing slope in pasture. Ring-barrow (TS057-031----) is located 100m to the WNW. Slightly raised area (diam. 18m) enclosed by an earthen scarp (Wth 2m; H 1m) separated by a wide flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 2m) from an intermediate bank (int. H 0.5-0.95m; ext. H 0.5-0.70m; Wth at top 4m; overall Wth 7.4m) with a second wide flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 1.25m) and an low broad external earthen bank (int. H 0.4-0.7m; ext. H 0.15m; Wth at top 2m; overall Wth 5.7m). From E-SE the fosses and the intermediate bank are very denuded with only very slight remains visible at ground level and the external bank is absent NW-SE. Interior slopes slightly facing SE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on top of a hill in a mountainous region with extensive views. A steep-sided, flat-topped mound (H 5m; diam. 21m NW-SE) with a berm enclosing the base from S through W to NW. A modern quarry has destroyed the E face of the mound. The exposed section revealed no evidence of burials or any archaeological activity.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In level ungrazed pasture to SE and pasture to NW. Bisected by road, long axis NE-SW. Extant half to SE survives as a semi-circular area (dims. 18m NE-SW; 8m NW-SE) defined by scarp (H 0.9m; Wth 3.75m) NE-SW. The scarp defining the interior falls gently to an almost level berm (L 9m) NE-SW. Truncated by shallow drain (D 0.75m; Wth 2.95m) and tertiary road (long axis NE-SW) through centre. A drain has been cut around exterior of berm NE-SW. Slight rise around edge of berm (Wth 6.5m; int. H 0.35m; ext. H 0.5m) probably upcast from drain. A short portion of outer bank is visible at NE, but there is a gap (Wth c. 10m) ENE-E. Bank (Wth 9m; int. H 0.8m; ext. H 0.6m) continues E-SW. This may have been fosse recut as drain. Interior slopes down uniformly from a higher point at NE to a lower area to SW. Half of monument to NW, generally levelled, but may be a very slight trace of outer bank SW-NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In undulating elevated pasture, on a slight NNW-facing slope. There are excellent views N-SE though views are moderate to poor in other directions. A slightly raised circular area (diam. 22m) defined by a fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.3m) and an external bank (Wth 2m; int. H 1m; ext. H 0.8m). The bank has internal and external stone revetments. In the centre of the interior is a slightly raised circular platform (diam. 6m; H 0.4m) defined by a low bank or sod-covered stone foundations (Wth 0.4m). Extending from it to the inner edge of the fosse at W and N are two linear earthen banks (Wth 1m; H 0.4m; L c. 9m), that to N marked by a boulder at its S terminus. At NNW is a small earthen mound (4m E-W; H 1m), partially incorporated into the enclosing bank but projecting 1.5m from its external face. A N-S field boundary lies immediately to W.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On top of the level summit of a prominent hill with panoramic views in all directions. A standing stone (TS058-079----) is visible 800m to the NE; a large barrow 1.5km to the WSW and a mound-barrow (TS058-047----) 1.8km to the S. Four monuments are visible at ground level in the interior; a standing stone (TS058-023004-) atop the centre of the stepped-barrow, a ditch-barrow (TS058-023005-) in the berm in the SW quadrant, a second ditch-barrow (TS058-023007) in the berm against the inner edge of the fosse at SSW and a ring-barrow (TS058-023006-) in the berm between the inner edge of the fosse at SSE and the SSE edge of the central mound of the stepped barrow. The enclosing elements are in good condition with the exception of the SW quadrant of the external bank which is very degraded and low in profile. Enclosure consists of a circular area (diam. 56m) defined by an earthen scarped edge (Wth 1.25 m; H 0.3-0.5m) with a flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at base 1.6-2m) and a broad external bank (overall Wth 3.5-4.2m; Wth at top 1.2-1.8m; int. H 1.15-1.3m; ext. H 0.25-0.4m). The scarped edge and fosse enclose the monument on all sides and have a consistent gently sloping profile. The external bank encloses the monument but is best preserved W to S where the profile is low broad and consistent. The external bank is degraded and irregular in profile S to W. A causeway across the fosse and break (Wth 4m) in the external bank at ESE marks the position of the original entrance.The interior is dry and clear of overgrowth across the N three-quarters with dense gorse in the S one-quarter.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 23 July 2012

On the E-facing slope of Rathcroghan ridge. Circular grass-covered platform (diam. 41.5m NNE-SSW; 39.4m WNW-ESE; H 0.2m at E to 2m at W) which slopes down to the E (H c. 3.5m). It is bisected by a NNE-SSW field bank and drain, and is barely visible E of this feature. The platform is defined by a fosse (Wth of top 10-11m; Wth of base 5-7m; D 0.6m) and outer bank (Wth 1.5-2.2m; H 0.3m) SSW-WNW, but the fosse is reduced to a berm (Wth 7.5-10m) defined by a scarp (H 0.1-0.9m) and the bank is absent elsewhere (max. ext. diam. 63m NNE-SSW; 63m WNW-ESE). Just NW of the centre is a low mound (RO022-056054-) (diam. 5m; H 0.1m). The road (RO022-056034-) runs W from this barrow past Rathscreg barrow (RO022-056035-) and the smaller barrows (RO022-056036-; RO022-056037-), which are c. 180m, c. 130m, and c. 100m to the WNW respectively. (Knox 1914a, 23-4 fig. 9; Herity 1983, 131; 1984, Kilnanooan; Waddell 1983, 39-41; 1988, 12, No. 42)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In improved, gently undulating pasture and 115m E of the Reask River which also forms a townland boundary with Coolnapisha. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OS 25-inch map as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork (overall 40m E-W; 37m N-S). Described by ODwyer (1959, 77) as a platform (int. diam. 70ft/21.3m; overall diam. 135ft/41m) defined by a broad berm (Wth 27ft/8.2m) and a shallow fosse.   Possible stepped barrow surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as an oval-shaped area covered in impenetrable overgrowth. Where visible, the raised area appears to be defined by a scarp (Wth 3.0m; H 1.15m), an intervening berm (Wth 6.0m; H 0.3m) and an outer scarp (Wth 2.1m; H 0.35m). An outer fosse (overall Wth 5.0m; basal Wth 1.4m; D 0.25m) is evident from NW-N-NE may have been widened by a natural water course and is now used as a drive line. There are possible traces of an outer bank (Wth 4.8m; int. H 0.25m; ext. H 0.2m) NE-ENE. Monument is truncated by a field boundary running E-W across the extreme S arc. Monument is visible as a roughly oval-shaped tree-planted earthwork on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached a profile of monument drawn by ODwyer in 1959, a sketch plan and partial cross-section which was measured and drawn by the ASI in 2008 and a Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 27 September 2020

On top of a low rise (343ft/105m OD), in pasture, with excellent views from SW-W-NW. Depicted as a raised circular shaped are enclosed by a wide berm on the 1840 ed. OS 6-inch map.   An OS trig. station marking 345 ft. OD is shown standing on N side of enclosure on Cassini 6-inch map.  Monument surveyed by the ASI in 1999 and described as a raised circular-shaped area (33m E-W; 31m N-S) defined by a scarp, berm and the remains of a low outer bank with entrance gap (Wth 5m) at E and a corresponding entrance gap (Wth 2m) in the outer bank.  The intervening berm is level and present from NW-N-E-S-SW and a steep natural slope falls from the outer edge of the monument from SW-W-NW. The outer edge of the berm is defined by a low earthen bank from NNE-E-SE and by a scarp from SE-S-SW. The interior is slightly dome-shaped.  Monument is visible as a circular-shaped, tree-planted enclosure on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 12 July 2020

On the summit of a WNW-ESE esker ridge. Grass-covered circular stoney platform (diam. of top 10.8m E-W; H 0.3-0.8m) with a few spaced kerbstones laid circumferentially and a slight outer fosse (Wth of base 1m; D 0.1m) which is reduced to a berm (Wth 1m) at N, at the edge of the ridge. A conical cairn (diam. 3.7-4m; surviving H 0.8m) with a flush outer face is at the centre of the platform, but the top of the cairn is missing. This cairn, or the mound, might be the feature that was disturbed in the 1950s (RO047-088----) when 'a jar with bones' was discovered (NMI file). It was disturbed by quarrying more recently and the S part of the platform to the edge of the central cairn has been removed. The possible barrow (RO047-058016-) is 8m to the W.Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 24 August 2010

On a slight E-W rise. Circular, slightly domed and grass-covered platform (diam.42m NNW-SSE; 40.5m ENE-WSW) defined by scarps (Wth 5-6m; H 2m) separated by a fosse (Wth of top 16.8-19m; Wth of base 8m) from an overgrown earthen bank (Wth of base 8.5-10m; Wth of top 1m; int. H 2m; ext. H c. 4m). This has an outer overgrown fosse (Wth of top 10m; Wth of base 2.5-3m; ext. D c. 2m), which is complete (max. ext. diam. 100m NNW-SSE). There is a second outer bank (Wth 3m) NNE-SE which might not be original as it is separated from the fosse by a slight berm (Wth c. 1m). There is an entrance through the outer bank (Wth 4m) with a causeway (Wth 3m) on to the platform (Wth 2-3.6m) at ENE, but a more recent entrance and causeway is at SSW while a N-S field wall overlies the monument towards the W edge of the platform. Cairn (RO048-002002-) is c. 20m to the NE.  See the attached aerial views taken from the W (001) and N (002).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

At the summit of a broad NNW-ESE ridge. The name 'Sheegort' is derived from Ceat Magach, one of Queen Meave's warriors, according to local tradition (Gannon 1972). Subcircular grass and scrub-covered mound (dims of top 33.8m NE-SW; 28.5m NW-SE; dim. of base 40m NW-SE; H 4.6m at NW and SE) with a dished summit (diam. of hollow 21m NW-SE; D 1-1.6m) that may be the result of ancient quarrying. At the base is a fosse (Wth of base 3.2-4.5m; D 1-2m) and there is a ramp onto the mound at NNE (max. ext. diam. 54.4m NW-SE). Barrow (RO045-038----) is c. 45m to the NNW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In poorly drained, gently undulating rough pasture, on a low rise. A circular raised level area (dims. 7.5m N-S; 6m E-W) defined by low scarp (Wth 1.6m; H 0.2m) which is best preserved (Wth 2.7m; H 0.6m) from N-ESE. This central area is enclosed by a level berm (Wth 2.65m), defined by a scarp (Wth 2m; H 0.2m) from SSW-NW, which may be utilising the natural topography. A townland boundary abuts to the SE and the Tipperary-Dundrum road runs NE-SW c. 25m to the NW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Marked as a circular feature (diam. c. 40m) on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map, and situated on a low-lying karst landscape overlooking a basin to the W. A subcircular grass-covered mound (dims 28m N-S; 24.5m E-W; H 0.8m at S to 1.7m at N) is separated by a berm (Wth 6m at N to 13m at E) from a drystone field wall and townland boundary with Curraghalaher SSW-NW, an earthen bank (Wth 3m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.4m) NW-N, and a low scarp (H 0.2m) N-E. The portal tomb (RO045-043001-) and cist (RO045-053002-) are c. 40m to the NE. It may be a passage tomb, and the description of a cist (RO045-239----) discovered at Lecarrow in 1923 may be from this monument.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In rough, ungrazed pasture, on a natural rise. Large mound (diam. top c. 8-10m; base c. 30m; H 3.75m) surrounded by a berm (Wth 8-9.5m) defined by scarp (Wth 4.5m; H 0.85m) from SE-NW and the possible remains of a scarp (Wth 4m; H 0.4m) in the NW-NE (in improved pasture). There is another lower berm (Wth 7.5m) in the S quadrant, from SE-SSW, which is defined by scarp (Wth 3.2m; H 0.6m). The monument is truncated by a townland boundary (long axis NW-SE) across the ENE sector from the base of the scarp; the truncated area is in improved pasture. The interior is very overgrown with briars and furze while the scarp is obscured by ash trees, shrubs and furze. The monument is named 'Cliaghan' on the 1904 edition OS 6-inch map.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on a slight rise on a N-S ridge in gently undulating pasture-land. A platform (diam. 29m NW-SE) of earth and stone with a central mound, berm (Wth 2.5m) and fosse (Wth 3m; D 0.17m). Field-clearance debris up to 2m high along the edge of the site while the interior is covered by dumped wood and heavy scrub growth which greatly hindered inspection. Possible original bank in SE quadrant (Wth 2.5m; int. H 0.26m; H above fosse 0.9m). The interior slopes with the natural topography to the E and W. Slight hollow at top of mound.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated in a low-lying area in very undulating, hillocky terrain. The site appears to utilise a natural hillock and consists of an oval mound (overall diam. 37m N-S; 42m E-W) enclosed by a berm (Wth 2.5m) and outer bank (Wth 1.3m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 1m). The central mound, which is less evident in the SE quadrant, rises 1.56m above the berm and is steepest at W where the berm is less evident. There is a small area of disturbance in the W sector with low heaps of grassed-over spoil. Some large boulders appear to be dumped on the site at NW. The site is transected at SE by a stone wall extending NE-SW.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on top of a hill with commanding views of the surrounding countryside. According to local tradition this hilltop enclosure was the inauguration place of the Mac Amhalghaidh / Magawley clan (Cox 1972, 155).  Fitzpatrick (2004, 171) however suggests that the bowl-barrow (WM030-104----) on Knockdomny Hill is the more likely location for the inauguration place of the Mac Amhalghaidh clan. Monument consists of a circular raised area or platform (diam. c. 29m) enclosed by an earth and stone bank, berm and outer bank. Gap in bank at W appears to be of recent origin, second gap in bank at NNE may be remains of original entrance feature. A trackway leading up to this possible entrance gap may be remains of an ancient pathway. The interior of the monument is divided by a field boundary consisting of a low bank and fosse running N-S. This field boundary is a later feature as it runs across and cuts into the enclosing bank and scarp of the monument at NNW. At the S end of this bank there are two stones set in line with the bank which suggests contemporaneity with this feature. The N stone (H 1.25m x 1.25m x 1m) is higher than the S stone which is more stump like in its appearance. Large boulders and rock outcrop can be seen protruding from the surface of the interior and from the top of the enclosing bank. A small depression in the N quadrant of the interior facing onto the inner face of the enclosing bank may be the remains of a possible hut site or could be the remains of a small post medieval quarry hole. Ordnance Survey trig. station marking 387 ft OD located in centre of monument as depicted on 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map.
