Compiled by: Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 21 July 2015  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 1/1980).

No surface remains of mound situated on flat pastureland at the base of an esker ridge which has been partially quarried away in recent times. Depicted as a small enclosure on first two editions of the OS 6-inch maps.  This feature is depicted as a landscaped feature rather than as an antiquity on the 1838 ed. OS 6-inch map   On the 1838 ed. OS 6-inch map this monument is depicted as a small enclosure 20m to the N of a family vault located in a demesne woodland associated with nearby Droughtville House.  The monument is depicted differently on the revised 1908 ed. OS 25-inch map.  On this map the monument is shown as a small mound standing on a wide berm with a similar plan to a stepped-barrow.  A second enclosure or small mound (OF036-024----) is depicted 71m to the SE.  It is possible that the monument was re-used when it was landscaped in the 18th/19th century.  This possible monument is located on the demesne woodland associated with Droughtville House located 730m to the SW.  Alternatively this feature may have been built as a landscape feature in the 18th/19th century by the occupants of Droughtville House.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload/revision: 30 December 2011

In pasture, on gentle N-facing slope. Identified on aerial photograph (GSI S.637/8, 16.4.1974). A circular area (dims. 20m N-S; 17m E-W) defined by low profile earthen scarp (Wth 0.2m; ext. H 0.15m) and an intervening fosse (basal Wth 2m; overall Wth 7m; D 0.2m). Generally level area/berm (Wth 5m) outside intervening fosse and slight trace of a wider circular area (overall dims. 50m N-S; 52m E-W) defined by an outer fosse (Wth 11m; D 0.15m). Truncated by drainage ditch and field boundary) SW-W-NW.   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 3 December 2014

Situated on a low hillock in undulating countryside with good views in all directions. A natural hillock, the base of which has been scarped and the top flattened to form a flat-topped mound (diam. N-S 37m; H 1.5m) enclosed by a wide berm (Wth 3-5m) with no evidence of an outer fosse.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 51-3) as following: 'Subcircular mound (Diam. 8m N-S x 7.3m E-W) with two or three steps or tiers, up to 1.5m in height on SW  side, and with two megalithic blocks at its edge on either side of a line running NNE from the monument. The southernmost orthostat, smaller of the two (L. 2.15m; W. 1.4m; H. 1.65m), stands upright against middle step of barrow (no lower step being visible at this point), tilting out slightly due to pressure from the barrow on the W and the exposure of its base on the E due to erosion; it appears to be in situ. The northernmost boulder (L. 3.7m; W. 2.25m; H. 1.5m) lies recumbent just N of the edge of the barrow, which appears to have been severely damaged here and around as far as the other boulder, partly due to animals sheltering under a thorn tree growing beside the southern boulder but perhaps in great part due to the northern boulder having collapsed in the pastespecially if it too had originally stood upright against the barrow, revetting its edge. Flattish to slightly domed upper tier of mound is badly eroded on NW and SE sides but appears to have been originally circular (Diam. 2.3m N-S x 2.5m E-W), and rises up to 1.45m above middle step where this step adjoins the southernmost boulder (see below) on E side. The middle step, only evident in an arc running clockwise from N to SW where it appears to drop down to the lower step, rises up to 0.55m above the lower step at SW, although middle step has been disturbed here. The lower step is evident only in an arc running clockwise from S to NW and rises up to 0.42m above ground level on W side. In width the middle step reaches up to 2.1m at E and the lower step reaches up to 2.9m on W side. On SW side, where the middle step is 2m in width, irregular in appearance and apparently disturbed, it and the upper tier appear to have spilled out onto the lower step. Where the mound has been eroded and the sod removed in many places, it is composed of numerous small stones with some soil, such that it could almost be described as a cairn. As it is in a poor condition, being badly damaged or partly removed on N and NE sides, and with spillage from different tiers on all sides, other readings of this monument than the one given here are conceivable.  Monument is very prominently sited on a local eminence, c. 38.5m to SW of large curvilinear mound (within graveyard wall (WM031-079001-) on which site of medieval church (WM031-079----) of Kilcumreragh is located; ground drops sharply 12m to NE of barrow before rising again towards the church.  Little is known about the history of this church. When John ODonovan visited the site in 1837, the locals had entirely forgotten the latter part of the name, referring only to the parish of Kill, and the original dedication to a native, pre-Norman saint had been replaced by one to St. Thomas. But ODonovan knew well his Martyrologies and saints Lives: Groping thus in the dark it is very difficult (for one) to come to any certain conclusion and still I have no hesitation in asserting with every confidence that this is the church of comráire near Uisneach, where in the primitive ages St. Colman was venerated on the 25th of September (Herity 2011, 76).  In support of this, Leo Swan inferred from the quadrantal shape of the graveyard an original monastic enclosure or vallum having formerly surrounded the site, sound indication of an early medieval origin (1988, 17)'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

In flat wet boggy pasture with relatively clear views in all directions due to low lying terrain. Since being visited in 1987, this and neighbouring fields has been planted with forestry, a buffer being left around the monument. An oval, raised platform (max. dims. 22m N-S; 19m E-W; H 1.2-1.4m), enclosed by berm (Wth c. 8.5m) with an outer bank (Wth c. 3.5m; int. H 0.2-0.3m; ext. H 0.6m). There is no entrance. Though originally classified as a platform rath, the morphology suggests it may be a stepped barrow.Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 25 September 2017

On an ENE-facing slope in low-lying pasture. A low, almost D-shaped, mound of earth and stone (dims. at base 9.3m ENE-WSW; 6.9m NNW-SSE; H 0.8m) with the straight side at SSE. It is enclosed by a wide, very low bank of earth and stone (Wth 6.2m; H 0.1m) from WSW-N-NNE. Elsewhere no visible surface trace of the bank survives. An embanked barrow (LF015-037001-) lies c. 5m to the S.Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 24 November 2011

Situated on a rise towards the bottom of the SE-facing slope of a drumlin. This is a raised, circular, and overgrown earthen platform (diam. 29m E-W; H 1.2-1.4m) planted with deciduous trees. It is defined by a fosse (Wth of top 5.5-8.6m; Wth of base 3m at W to 6m at E; ext. D 0.3m at W) which has silted up to the top of an outer bank (at W: Wth of base 10m; Wth of top 3.5m; ext. H 1.7m) almost everywhere, reducing the bank to an outer scarp (at E:  Wth 6.3m; H 1.5m) (max. ext. diam. 58m E-W). There is no identifiable entrance feature. It could be a platform rath, but the wide outer bank suggests it is more likely to be a platform barrow.    The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Leitrim' compiled by Michael J. Moore (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2003). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 14 October 2019

In pasture, on top of a low rise of ground or hillock in undulating countryside with good views in all directions. The field to the N has been reclaimed and re-seeded in grass while the perimeter of the barrow is overgrown and covered in thorn bushes. The adjoining fields to the SE and SW are under tillage. This possible stepped barrow (overall diam. 52m E-W) consists of a circular mound (H 0.5-0.8m; top diam 20m; base diam. 24m) enclosed by an inner fosse (top Wth 6.3m; base Wth 3.5m; ext. D 0.5m), berm (Wth 5m; H 0.5m), earthen bank and outer berm (Wth 10m). As the monument is heavily overgrown detailed examination was impossible. The interior has been used as a rubbish dump. A field bank runs across the centre of the barrow on a NW-SE axis. There is a quarry (D 1.5m; dims 6m x 7m) in the SE sector of the interior between the inner face of the bank and the mound, the inner fosse has been quarried away in the N quadrant. An entrance causeway gap (Wth 3m) at S, appears to have been augmented by nearby quarrying activities.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Located on top of an esker ridge in an area of undulating countryside with good extensive views. Raised circular platform (8.5m N-S x 8m E-W; H 0.5 - 1m) enclosed by berm (Wth 2m) defined by a scarp which is particularly evident at E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 57) as following: 'Roughly circular earthwork (Diam. 41m N-S x 37m E-W) comprising a low, poorly defined circular mound or platform (Diam. 19.4m N-S x 18.2m E-W) surrounded by a lower, berm-like feature ranging in width (from base of inner mound to external ground level) from 9m on S side to 12.5m on N side, and up to 1.2m in height on W side; overall height of monument reaches up to 2.5m above ground level on W side. Inner mound rises up to 1.6m above berm on SE side, being much higher on S than on N side. Limestone boulders protrude from the monument at various places, a very large split one lying at the junction of berm and inner mound or platform on SE side. To SE of centre of monument is a tiny irregular mound, apparently limestone boulders covered by a thin layer of soil. Cutting  5m into SW edge of berm but extending beyond it is an oval stone-filled depression, about 7m in width at edge of berm; this appears to be of relatively recent origin (limekiln?).  Monument has been identified as a ringfort in the RMP and as an Earthwork by Schot (2006, Fig. 2), but seems better classified as a stepped barrow.  Barrow lies on NE spur of Hill of Ushnagh, E of a point midway between mound-barrow in Mweelra (WM024-173----) to S and ringfort and associated mound in Togherstown (WM024-025----) to N. Immediately E of monument is a linear feature running NNE-SSW, which appears to comprise a grassed-over wall with what appears to be a gate (a huge block of stone forming one gatepost), but farther SSW this wall or bank appears to have been flattened and has the appearance of a low, linear causeway. This feature, which runs for many hundreds of metres to N of site, appears from aerial photograph on ASI website to end about 150m to S of barrow, possibly at a large oval enclosure. It is clear from this aerial photograph that the linear feature swerves slightly to E to avoid the barrow'.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Located in improved pasture on top of a natural hillock, which is nestled in a low-lying landscape with higher drumlins all around NE-S-NW, and Carn Lough is c. 240m to the N. It is visible on the OSi series of aerial photographs (2005) and on Bing images (c. 2013), and it was first noticed by Katherine McCormack. This is a circular area (diam. 40m N-S; 37m E-W) defined by a steep scarp (at W: Wth 4.4m; H 1.25m) with a berm (at W: Wth 3m) separating it from a scarp or natural slope (at W: Wth 7.0m; H 1.4m) SW-W-NNW. The perimeter declines to low scarp (Wth 4.0m; H 0.8m) NNW-SE and merges into a natural scarped slope (Wth 17.9m; H 3.4m) SE-SW.  There are ramp entrances at N (Wth 3.2m) and at NNE (Wth 3.5m), which are c. 4m apart, and there are traces of a fosse (Wth of top 5.75m; Wth of base 1.25m; D 0.1m) NW-NE. The interior slopes down slightly to the N and there is an enclosure inside the perimeter at S. This is a penannular area (dims c. 12m E-W; c. 11.5m N-S) defined by a slight scarp ENE-SE (Wth 2.2m; H 0.05m) and SW-WNW (Wth 1.9m; H 0.3m), but the perimeter is incorporated into that of the platform SE-SW and is absent elsewhere.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revised upload: 24 March, 2014

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 33) as following: 'Approximately teardrop-shaped platform with long axis (22m across) running NE-SW, the pointed end to SW; close to broad end (17.5m across) a roughly circular mound (Diam. 8m N-S x 7.5m E-W) rises from the platform, being 9m from SW end but only 4.5m from NE end. Platform has a sharply defined edge, possibly due in part to ploughing in its immediate vicinity, and rises up to 1m above ground level on SE side; the mound is up to 1m in height above the platform. There is an unpublished plan and profile of the monument in the SMR file.   Monument is located on a low eminence in undulating, reclaimed pasture and ground drops away to SE more sharply than NW. Monument is marked  Mweeleen Moat on OS  6 map, the first term (maoilín, in the sense of bald or bare) apparently descriptive of the appearance of this prominently sited barrow. According to Kane, monument goes by the name Croc na Maoil, or sometimes Cnoc na Maoilin, and he identified it as one of the three bald hill of Meath, whose tops were cut off by Ferguss sword in the Táin Bó Cúailnge. Shaw dismisses Kanes suggestion, identifying the monument as a sepulchral tumulus (Kane 1916-17, 563, Shaw 1921, 127)'.Monument described in 1977 as a small circular shaped earth and stone mound surrounded by a flat berm like feature. The circular shape of the delimiting berm has been altered by land spill on the N side and defaced and destroyed on the S and W by the line of a post-1700 field fence (now removed). This has produced the rather straight profile on this side. There is a distinct round curve to E and N to the original curve of the berm feature. Probably a small bell barrow. Sited on a small ridge with an excellent view over the surrounding pasture land (ASI Field Report 21/07/1977)See attached plan of monument surveyed and drawn by the ASICompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.Date of upload: 23 February 2015

On a break of a W-facing slope in upland pasture, just below the crest of Spahill. There are extensive views across the plain to the N, S and W. A circular area (diam. 24m N-S; 23.4m E-W) enclosed by a stoney bank (int. H 0.1-0.55m; ext. H 0.43-0.85m; Wth at crest 1.3m; overall Wth 2.2-2.9m) and outer fosse (Wth 1.2m; D 0.05-0.7m), with a circular mound (diam. 4.6m at top; 7.1m at base; H 0.25-0.3m) slightly off-centre in the interior, being closer to the N bank. The interior forms a flat berm between the mound and enclosing bank. There is an entrance (Wth 2.3m) in the WSW quadrant where there is a break in the bank, partially defined by stones on the S side, and a causeway (H 0.17m) over the fosse. A stone wall field boundary runs roughly N-S along the E edge of the monument, kinking out to run along the top of the bank. Monument identified by Melanie McQuade (pers. comm. 10 November 2016).Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of revised upload: 3 September 2018

Situated at the NE edge of a low rise, in pasture, with wide views to N and E and overlooked by rising ground to S and W. Ringfort (WM025-037001-) and souterrain (WM025-037002-) lie c. 40m to S. Not depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map or the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map. Monument described as a circular-shaped area enclosed by a low, wide bank of earth and stone which is almost reduced to a scarp which remains quite steep from N-E with no evidence of an external fosse. In the centre is a high roughly rectangular-shaped platform, which may be a house site. A field system intersects the monument at N, E and SW.   Morphology of monument visible today on Digital Globe aerial photograph suggests that this site may be the remains of a barrow rather than a ringfort with central house site.  Outline of central mound clearly visible on oblique aerial photographs (CUCAP AOZ001/AYR012/017/018) taken 12/07/1966 and 11/07/1969 respectively.    See attached plan and profile of monument surveyed and drawn by the ASI.   Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 05 September 2019

Situated on the summit of a natural hillock in grassland with extensive views of the surrounding area.  A medieval roadway annotated as 'Bohereenamarve' runs past the monument 20m to the W,  Templecross church (WM011-051----) and graveyard (WM011-051001-) 600m to NE.  A small circular-shaped mound that appears to have been landscaped in the post-1700 period when a curving terrace leading to the top was built.  The mound is enclosed by a wide berm with traces of a slight bank and narrow deep fosse which seems to have ben re-cut in the post-1700 period possibly when the monument was enclosed by a field boundary.  A  causewayed entrance feature at N appears to be a post-1700 feature.  A spiral step pathway has been cut into the mound from NNE, curving around to the top of the mound. The top of the mound was used as a trigonometrical station by the OS marking the spot height of 277ft.   The landscaping of the monument and the deepening of the fosse may have been related to landscaping carried out by the OS when placing their trig. station on top of the mound.  The stepped-barrow stands in the centre of a large circular enclosure (approx. diam. 33m) which appears to date from the post-1700 period when the monument was enclosed by a circular field boundary.  The larger circular enclosure is clearly visible on aerial photograph taken in 1969 (CUCAP AYR008).  The monument could be interpreted as a prehistoric bell-barrow or stepped-barrow which was either landscaped as an ornamental mound or modified by the Ordnance Survey in the 19th century when a trig station was placed on top of the mound.See attached profile of monument surveyed and drawn by the ASI. Compiled by: Frank Coyne and Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 18 August 2017

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 29-30) as following: 'Fairly well-preserved roughly circular stepped-barrow (Diam. 39.3m N-S x 40m E-W) strikingly sculpted from a natural kame in a glaciated landscape, such that the central mound (Diam. 19.1m N-S x 18.7m E-W) is  1.70m higher than the surrounding bank on E side and  1.37m higher on W side, and the ditch between mound and bank is higher than external ground level. The overall diameter of the monument given above should be taken as an approximation, as its construction from a natural knoll makes it difficult to distinguish between the outer slope of the bank and the natural slope of the knoll. Mound is partly eroded on W side, exposing boulders beneath the sod, some very large. Mound has a markedly flattish upper surface (Diam. 9.3m N-S x 9.5m E-W) which rises up to 2.1m above ditch on W side and slopes down 0.86m from W to E; there is a sharp junction between top and sides of mound. Bank and ditch also slope down from W to E, the bank being much higher on W side than on E. Where highest and most massive at W, bank is 7.5m in width and rises up to 0.63m above the ditch and up to 1.4m above external ground level; at E end of monument, as on N and S sides, bank is barely visible, such that there is more of a step on a level with the base of the ditch, which then falls off to the natural slope of the knoll; this berm-like feature is up to 7m in width. Breaches in the bank, probably due to erosion, are evident on NE and SE sides. On NW side there is a funnel-shaped gap in the bank measuring 6m from inside to outside, widening towards the outside; to S of gap, bank is much thinner than to N. Ditch is up to 3.8m in width, where clearest on W side. Outside bank on E side of monument are two other low mounds apparently forming part of the same glacial feature on which barrow is situated.   Monument lies in rough, undulating pastureland. Four other barrows (WM018-070----; WM018-106----; WM018-107---; WM018-151----) lie in the same townland, the nearest being c. 400m to SSE.  Frewin Hill is visible to NE and mound-barrow on glacial hillock at Kilpatrick (WM018-097----) is visible over 400m to NNW'.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 39-40) as following: 'Well-preserved stepped barrow comprising a subcircular mound  (Diam. 10.8m N-S x  10.8m E-W) with flattish top and shallow sloping sides erected on top of a larger, flat-topped, subcircular mound  (Diam. 27.5m N-S x 34.9m E-W), which slopes down gradually to natural ground level, such that there is a step around the uppermost mound. As upper mound is not located centrally on lower platform, being located closer to NE than SE side, step varies greatly in width, being 1m at N, 2.4m at S, 3.6m at W and 4.8m at E; the narrow step on N side is not clearly evident as a flat area. Upper mound rises up to 1.9m above step on N  side, and overall height of monument reaches up to  4m  at S. An  additional low  step at base of monument on N side appears to relate to the construction of field fence on this side. Upper mound has large boulders or rock outcrop visible around the edges and on top, apparently representing the natural topography; this, and the fact that there is no ditch visible around this substantial monument, strongly suggests that it, like many other Westmeath barrows, has been shaped from a kame or other pre-existing glacial landform. Thorn trees are growing on and especially around the edge of the monument except for a short arc of perimeter on SE side.  Monument is located on a local eminence in good pasture, and would have good views all round but for trees.'  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Surveyed in 2012 and described by McGuinness (2012, 38-9) as following: Three roughly circular, flat-topped earthen mounds (WM018-078---; WM018-078001-; WM018-078002-) on elongated, flattish hilltop running NE-SW. Westernmost mound (WM018-078----), on highest part of hilltop, is the largest of the three and easternmost mound (WM018-078002-) is by far the smallest The mounds are not positioned on a straight line, centre of Mound B (WM018-078001-) being slightly to N of a line joining centres of Mounds A and C.  Mound B is 6m from Mound A and Mound C is 11.5 m from Mound B. The mounds have been severely eroded by cattle in recent times, Mound A and especially Mound B having lost large pieces on the perimeter. This is most striking when they are compared with the photograph published by Shaw in 1921 (Pl. 1).Mound A: Tall, steep-sided, roughly conical mound with flat top (Diam. 15.7m N-S x 17m E-W) on ground sloping down to E and SE, so that its height above surrounding ground varies from 2m on SW side to 2.7m on SE side. Flat top of mound measures 4.1m N-S by 4.6m E-W and slopes down gently from S to N, with a drop of 11cm, and from E-W, with a drop of 16cm. Between one-third and half way up the sides of the mound is a thin ledge (0.5m in width where best preserved at NE) running horizontally around its circumference in contrast with the varying ground level, and reaching a height of 1.16m above ground level where most clearly defined at NE. This ledge also marks a break in slope in the mound's profile, the upper part being slightly steeper. Traces of a shallow ditch, 2.8-3.1m in width are visible on W side of mound; ground naturally dips down on E and SE sides, between Mounds A and B.To N of the mounds, 24m from Mound A, 14.5m from Mound B and 11.5m from Mound C, is a ditch 2.5m wide, immediately outside of which is a bank, 1.8m in width, which rises 0.36m above ditch and 0.95m above ground level to N. This ditch and bank run roughly E-W from a N-S running hedgerow at W end, curving outwardly to N in a gentle arc around the flattish hilltop, but, 70m to E of the hedgerow, ditch is no longer apparent and bank swerves to NE, or rather appears to join onto a second bank which runs in a NE-SW direction. The NE stretch of this bank is 2.5m in width and 0.5m in height and runs for 6.7m to NE from its point of junction with the E-W running bank and ditch before reaching a gap 23m in width, apparently an entranceway, and then continuing for another 24m downhill to NE where it abruptly ends just 1m before joining at a sharp angle onto a N-S running bank and ditch. The SW stretch of this bank is separated from NE stretch by a gap of 2m. It runs for 23m to SW, with two slight but clear kinks, until it joins onto or runs along N side of Mound C and then continues in SW direction for another 19m, before finally kinking to S and running for another 3.5m.The S side of the hilltop is delimited by a roughly E-W-running ditch with hedgerow on its S side, which swerves S to curve around Mound A at a distance of 2.7m. To S of Mound C there is a gap in the ditch that serves as a modern passage between fields, beyond which it runs off in a straight line to E.  At E side of gap, a further bank and ditch, again forming a modern field boundary, run downhill to N, almost intersecting with NE stretch of bank described above.  Within c. 250m to SW are two further barrows (WM018-079----; WM018-080---) and a third possible prehistoric burial mound (WM018-081---). All six sites form an approximately linear arrangement from NE to SW. Frewin Hill (WM011-133----) is clearly visible to N'.See attached plan of barrow cemetery surveyed and drawn by ASICompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.Date of upload: 25 April 2016This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 19/1977).

Surveyed in 2012 and described by McGuinness (2012, 38-9) as following: Three roughly circular, flat-topped earthen mounds (WM018-078---; WM018-078001-; WM018-078002-) on elongated, flattish hilltop running NE-SW. Westernmost mound (WM018-078----), on highest part of hilltop, is the largest of the three and easternmost mound (WM018-078002-) is by far the smallest The mounds are not positioned on a straight line, centre of Mound B (WM018-078001-) being slightly to N of a line joining centres of Mounds A and C.  Mound B is 6m from Mound A and Mound C is 11.5 m from Mound B. The mounds have been severely eroded by cattle in recent times, Mound A and especially Mound B having lost large pieces on the perimeter. This is most striking when they are compared with the photograph published by Shaw in 1921 (Pl. 1).Mound B, centrally positioned and again roughly conical (Diam. 11.7m N-S x 11.1m E-W), is 1.74m in greatest height.  As with Mound A (WM018-078----), there is a ledge or step running around its circumference, 0.5-0.8m wide, being widest at SSE, but here it is just below top of mound and much more clearly defined, giving the appearance of a smaller, flat-topped mound (Diam. 3.8m x 3.5m) up to 0.65m high, on top of a larger one (See Pl. 1). Traces of a shallow ditch 3-4m in width are visible on N and NW sides of mound; ground naturally dips down on SW side, between Mounds A (WM018-078----) and B (WM018-078002-).To N of the mounds, 24m from Mound A, 14.5m from Mound B and 11.5m from Mound C, is a ditch 2.5m wide, immediately outside of which is a bank, 1.8m in width, which rises 0.36m above ditch and 0.95m above ground level to N. This ditch and bank run roughly E-W from a N-S running hedgerow at W end, curving outwardly to N in a gentle arc around the flattish hilltop, but, 70m to E of the hedgerow, ditch is no longer apparent and bank swerves to NE, or rather appears to join onto a second bank which runs in a NE-SW direction. The NE stretch of this bank is 2.5m in width and 0.5m in height and runs for 6.7m to NE from its point of junction with the E-W running bank and ditch before reaching a gap 23m in width, apparently an entranceway, and then continuing for another 24m downhill to NE where it abruptly ends just 1m before joining at a sharp angle onto a N-S running bank and ditch. The SW stretch of this bank is separated from NE stretch by a gap of 2m. It runs for 23m to SW, with two slight but clear kinks, until it joins onto or runs along N side of Mound C and then continues in SW direction for another 19m, before finally kinking to S and running for another 3.5m.  The S side of the hilltop is delimited by a roughly E-W-running ditch with hedgerow on its S side, which swerves S to curve around Mound A at a distance of 2.7m. To S of Mound C there is a gap in the ditch that serves as a modern passage between fields, beyond which it runs off in a straight line to E.  At E side of gap, a further bank and ditch, again forming a modern field boundary, run downhill to N, almost intersecting with NE stretch of bank described above.  Within c. 250m to SW are two further barrows (WM018-079----; WM018-080---) and a third possible prehistoric burial mound (WM018-081---). All six sites form an approximately linear arrangement from NE to SW. Frewin Hill (WM011-133----) is clearly visible to N'.See attached plan of barrow cemetery surveyed and drawn by ASICompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.Date of upload: 25 April 2016This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 19/1977).

Surveyed in 2012 and described by McGuinness (2012, 38-9) as following: Three roughly circular, flat-topped earthen mounds (WM018-078---; WM018-078001-; WM018-078002-) on elongated, flattish hilltop running NE-SW. Westernmost mound (WM018-078----), on highest part of hilltop, is the largest of the three and easternmost mound (WM018-078002-) is by far the smallest The mounds are not positioned on a straight line, centre of Mound B (WM018-078001-) being slightly to N of a line joining centres of Mounds A and C.  Mound B is 6m from Mound A and Mound C is 11.5 m from Mound B. The mounds have been severely eroded by cattle in recent times, Mound A and especially Mound B having lost large pieces on the perimeter. This is most striking when they are compared with the photograph published by Shaw in 1921 (Pl. 1).Mound C (Diam. 9.3m N-S x 7.1m E-W), sub-circular in shape, is 1.3m in greatest height. Upper part of mound appears to have been disturbed: in Shaw's photograph, published in 1921. (See Pl. 1), it appears to have been stepped at the top like Mound B (WM018-078001-), with an approximately flat-topped, sub-circular cap (Diam. 2.3m N-S x 2.7m E-W), up to 0.4m high at highest SE side, and surrounded by a broad shelf or ledge.To N of the mounds, 24m from Mound A, 14.5m from Mound B and 11.5m from Mound C, is a ditch 2.5m wide, immediately outside of which is a bank, 1.8m in width, which rises 0.36m above ditch and 0.95m above ground level to N. This ditch and bank run roughly E-W from a N-S running hedgerow at W end, curving outwardly to N in a gentle arc around the flattish hilltop, but, 70m to E of the hedgerow, ditch is no longer apparent and bank swerves to NE, or rather appears to join onto a second bank which runs in a NE-SW direction. The NE stretch of this bank is 2.5m in width and 0.5m in height and runs for 6.7m to NE from its point of junction with the E-W running bank and ditch before reaching a gap 23m in width, apparently an entranceway, and then continuing for another 24m downhill to NE where it abruptly ends just 1m before joining at a sharp angle onto a N-S running bank and ditch. The SW stretch of this bank is separated from NE stretch by a gap of 2m. It runs for 23m to SW, with two slight but clear kinks, until it joins onto or runs along N side of Mound C and then continues in SW direction for another 19m, before finally kinking to S and running for another 3.5m.  The S side of the hilltop is delimited by a roughly E-W-running ditch with hedgerow on its S side, which swerves S to curve around Mound A at a distance of 2.7m. To S of Mound C there is a gap in the ditch that serves as a modern passage between fields, beyond which it runs off in a straight line to E.  At E side of gap, a further bank and ditch, again forming a modern field boundary, run downhill to N, almost intersecting with NE stretch of bank described above.  Within c. 250m to SW are two further barrows (WM018-079----; WM018-080---) and a third possible prehistoric burial mound (WM018-081---). All six sites form an approximately linear arrangement from NE to SW. Frewin Hill (WM011-133----) is clearly visible to N'.See attached plan of barrow cemetery surveyed and drawn by ASICompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.Date of upload: 25 April 2016This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 19/1977).

Surveyed in 2012 and described by McGuinness (2012, 30-1) as following: 'About 17m to SSE of Site 11 (WM011-137----) is an unrecorded monument, comprising what appears to be a natural hillock, rounded in appearance (Diam. 20m N-S) and clearly defined on all sides but S, where it blends into natural slope.  This hillock is capped by a roughly circular, flat-­topped mound (Diam. 5m N-­S x 5.5m E-­W), poorly defined at W side, which rises 0.5m above upper surface   of hillock where highest on E side.   The hillock itself rises up to 1.1m above surrounding ground.  Overall impression is of a stepped barrow with upper surface of natural hillock forming a broad circular shelf around the artificial mound. Same field fence that cuts through Site 11 (WM011-137----) also runs roughly N-­S  through this monument.  This monument  and Site 11 (WM011-137----) are aligned on the mound or cairn on summit of Frewin Hill (WM011-133----).   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

On a slight natural N-S hillock, a little below the crest of a hillside on gently sloping very wet grassland, on the W slopes of small N-S river valley. There is a stream running immediately outside the SE quadrant and another stream c. 40m to the N-NW, both indicated on the 1st (1839) ed. OS 6-inch map. There are fair views to N-E-S, but limited by rising ground to W.  A flat, waterlogged oval platform (dims. 30m N-S; 25m E-W) defined by scarp (H 0.9-1.5m) and external berm (Wth c. 7m E and W side; 10-15m N and S side) of lower oval mound (H c. 0.5-1m above external ground level), possibly a modified natural hillock.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 March 2020

Surveyed in 2012 and described by McGuinness (2012, 26-7) as following:  'Large, roughly circular, stepped barrow, comprising a central mound or platform, beyond which lie, on NE half of monument, a ditch, outer bank and second ditch, and on SW half of monument, a broad ledge and outer ditch identical to second ditch on NE half.  Overall diameter of the monument is 40.4m N-S x 40.2m E- W.   It is located at edge of state forestry plantation in grounds of the old Clanhugh Demesne, and there are mature deciduous trees associated with the demesne along its perimeter; in addition, SE half is densely overgrown with brambles and difficult to examine.   The central platform (Diam. 20m N-S  x 21.5m E-W) is slightly dished, especially on NE side, and rises up to 0.70m above inner ditch on NNE side. The  inner ditch, which is raised well above external ground level, is up to 3m in width, flattish to flattened V-shaped in section, and, on NE side, reaches a maximum depth of  0.45m below and perpendicular to a line joining top of bank to upper surface of platform.   On S and W sides, where external ground level is much lower than elsewhere, central platform drops in a broad, shallow sweep down to a surrounding step or ledge.   On SW side, it rises 1.5m above this ledge and 3.2m above outer ditch.   At its broadest, on W side, the ledge is 7m in width and it reaches as high as 1.4m above ground level beyond outer ditch.  The shallow outer ditch, 2.2m in width, is best preserved on S and SW sides, but further traces are visible on E and NW sides.  Bank on NE half of monument varies in width from 3.5 to 6.8m.  Where not obscured by vegetation, its   height above inner ditch varies from 0.10m on N side to 0.43m on NE side.   It rises up to 1.15m above outer ditch on NW side.   Ground around monument slopes down sharply to W, though much less so on other sides.  Monument lies 21m N of NE shore of Lough Owel. Frewin Hill (WM011-133----) is prominent to SW from adjacent lakeshore, and the sites would be mutually visible across the lake but for the trees at Clanhugh Demesne.   There is an enormous, monumental bivallate ringfort (WM011-109----) in the forest c.0.45km to NNE'.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Situated on a generally level area, in low-lying pasture, which is overlooked by higher, gently undulating pasture to E, S and W where views are restricted. A pond lies c. 45m to N and barrows (WM020-112----/113----/114----) lie c. 240m to SW. Townland boundary with Rathnarrow lies 35m to S.  Monument (overall diam. 27m) described in 1970 as a circular-shaped round-topped mound (approx. diam. 8m) defined by a wide berm and a shallow flat-bottomed fosse (Wth at top 3.6m; basal Wth 1.9m; D 0.4m) that is almost filled in at E and from S-W. There is a modern quarry hole on the top of the mound at W. Monument is visible as a roughly circular shaped earthwork on Digital Globe aerial photography.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 08 July 2019

Situated at the end of a low ridge on partially reclaimed grassland with good views of the surrounding countryside.  Townland boundary with Ellenstown 80m to E and mound barrow (WM009-0035----) 300m to N.   Monument depicted on 1838 ed. OS 6-inch map as a small mound enclosed by a fosse and outer enclosing berm.    Described in 1973 as a ringfort consisting of a low circular mound (approx. diam. 7m) enclosed by a shallow internal fosse and flat berm (approx. diam. 35m N-S; 21m E-W)  the outer edge of which is defined by a low earthen bank and external fosse.  The presence of the circular-shaped mound in the centre of the monument suggests that this monument represent the remains of burial site rather than a ringfort.  The mound in the centre of the site was described in 1976 as an unusual feature the purpose of which was uncertain. The mound could represent the remains of a burial mound enclosed by an internal fosse with berm and external fosse.  The profile of the monument suggests that this site may be the remains of a barrow.  The mound could be a later landscape feature built onto the interior of a platform type ringfort as hinted at in the 1973 site report.     Compiled by: Frank Coyne and Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 27 August 2018

Situated on a fairly level landscape with a small E-W canalised stream to the S. This feature is not depicted on any map but is visible on aerial photographs (ACAP: 306/ 1363, 1364), and on some later images (Digital Globe; OSAP (2017); Google Earth 18/06/2017). This consists of a low grass-covered mound (diam. 54.3m N-S; 51.3m E-W; H 1.4m) separated by a berm (Wth 4.8-6m) from a low earthen bank (at SSE: Wth of base 8m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 1m) ESE-SSE that is largely reduced to a scarp (H 1m) (max. ext. diam. 72m).
column13: The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 16 April 2019

column10: Near the top of a gentle S-facing slope. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A low but well-preserved, gently domed, circular mound (base diam. 13m; upper surface diams. 11.6m E-W; 7.8m N-S; H 0.4-0.8m) is girdled by a narrow berm (Wth 1.5-2m).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a knoll at the foot of an E-facing slope, overlooking a small, N-S valley to the E. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). A fairly poorly preserved, low, sub circular earthen mound (basal diams. 19m N-S;16.5m E-W; H 0.9m), the upper surface (diams. 9m N-S; 8m E-W) of which is defined by a narrow berm (Wth 1-1.5m), outside of which is a low scarp. Disturbance has occurred at W and E.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

On a short E-facing pasture slope at the N foot of Knockaillinne and overlooked by Dun Aillinne (KD028-038----) c. 630m to the S. A low, partially dug-out, circular area (diam. 18m; H above external ground level 0.6-1.6m) is girdled by a broad berm (Wth 2.9-3.1m) SW-N-SE, which is heavily poached at W, and by a wide outer fosse (Wth at base 1.5m at S-2.4m at N; Wth at ground surface 7.8m at E-8.6m at S; overall diam. of monument 44.4m).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 18 February 2013

Situated at the S end of a ridge running N-S, with marked slopes on the SW and SE sides. Circular mound (diam. 20m; H 4m); the outer portion is formed by a low berm (Wth 3m; H 1.5m) possibly representing an eroded bank (Price 1934, 47). A cist (dims. 0.8m x 0.45m; D 0.5m; aligned E-W), S of the centre of the mound, covered by a single capstone was discovered during the destruction of the site in 1958. It contained cremations of three adult females, a newborn and a 6-8 year old child with a flint arrowhead. Not visible at ground level. (Lucas 1960, 84-8)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wicklow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 17 December 2008
Shown on the 1837 OS 6-inch map as a circular area surrounded by bank, and on the 1939 edition as raised circular area (max diam. c. 40m).  Date of upload: 6 September 2016

Eight barrows occupy the fairly level, nettle-covered, narrow upper surface of a short, N-S esker in level pasture, with evidence of previous extensive sand/gravel extraction immediately to the N and E. Six contiguous barrows (KD019-001001-, KD019-001002-, KD019-001003-, KD019-001006-, KD019-001008-, KD019-001009-) run N-S, in-line at the N end of the esker and are contained in an enclosure (KD019-001004-) which girdles the lower slopes of the esker, while a seventh and eight barrow (KD019-001005-, KD019-001007-, ) lies c. 48m slightly down slope, and outside the enclosure, to the S.  KD019-001003- is the third-most northerly barrow in the group. A small circular area (diam. 6.6m) is defined by a low, broad berm (Wth 3.2m; ext H 0.1-0.4m) NW-NE and SE-SW. The monument is abutted at N by another barrow (KD019-001002-).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Revised by: Caimin O'Brien with details kindly provided by Chris Corlett  Date of revised upload: 29 November 2018

This two-tiered earthen mound is located in a field of pasture NW of a 17th century manor house (DU021-015001-) and within a ceremonial enclosure (DU021-015006-). The first stage of the earthwork is a raised, steep-sided platform (diam.42m; H 2.5m) with a wide berm around the upper edge (Wth 3.5m). The second stage is a smaller earthen mound (diam. c. 20m; H 2.5m). A circular stone wall of limestone masonry runs around the top of the upper mound (diam. 10m). Inside of this is a square turret with a plain doorway and window with chamfered brick corners. The upper stage of the earthwork had been landscaped to insert an external stone stairs on the SW side. Beranger's drawing of 1767 shows this as a two-storied turret. This 'Sham Ruin' was probably erected on the earlier mound in the 17th century as part of the landscaping of the manor (McDix 1898, 40, 19; Handcock 1899, 6; Ball 1906, 116, Stout 1998, 145-154). Compiled by Geraldine Stout

Located towards the bottom of the S-facing slope of Monalee Hill, with a NW-SE stream c. 40m to the W, and just S of a NE-SW road that tuncates the monument. This is a low D-shaped mound (dims. 12m NE-SW; 6m NW-SE; H 0.2m) surrounded by a berm (Wth 15m) defined by a scarp that is only traceable SE-SW (max. H 0.4m at SW). According to Kinahan (1879-88, 153) a cist (WX002-038----) was discovered at its E edge c. 1840.   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upoad: 31 January, 2012

Knockaunbaun: Located on a level flood plain on the S side of the Inny river, this mound is suboval in plan, with its longer axis orientated N-S. It appears to be entirely composed of earth and gravel, and measures 11m long and approximately 2m high. Local tradition records the existence of an underground passage in the mound.The above description is derived from A. O'Sullivan and J. Sheehan (compilers), 'The Iveragh peninsula: an archaeological survey of South Kerry'. Cork University Press (1996), no. 395. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload: 28 July 2013

For descriptive account see O'Sullivan and Sheehan (1996, 113, no. 385).The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Kerry. Volume I: South-West Kerry' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2009). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 30 May 2011
In grassland.  Cropmark of circular-shaped earthwork (diam. c. 12m) defined by a ditch visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached Google Earth orthophoto taken 20/01/2017
column13: Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 11 July 2022

column10: The land is quite marshy and wet and is used as rough grazing for cattle at the moment. Several low banks of earth and stone also occur in this complex, but, as yet, their relationship to the barrows is unknown. Located on the west bank of a small river which is prone to flooding, c.200m from the coast in an area of marshy grassland. This barrow is oval in shape and consists of a central platform 12m N-S by 14m E-W and 0.65m high surrounded by a fosse with an average width of 4.0m. This fosse is 0.40m below the level of the top of the platform and 0.45m below the top of the bank. The enclosing bank has a maximum external height of 1.00m at west, average height being 0.50m. The barrow slopes in an E-W direction and the bank is less substantial at the point nearest the river, probably because of being partially denuded as a result of flooding. Total dimensions of the site are 20m N-S by 30m E-W. The south-eastern portion of the site has, or appears to have been truncated by a small mound.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 30 April 2012

The land is quite marshy and wet and is used as rough grazing for cattle at the moment. Several low banks of earth and stone also occur in this complex, but, as yet, their relationship to the barrows is unknown. Located on the west bank of a small river which is prone to flooding, c.200m from the coast in an area of marshy grassland...... this low mound is located on the immediate SE side of the barrow [KE038-137----]. This mound measures 9.50m N-S by 11.50m E-W at base and is 1.75m high. It is constructed of a mixture of earth and stones, and narrows slightly towards the top. A hollow occurs at the crest of the mound, 3.40m N-S by 4.0m E-W and is 0.50m below the top of the mound. This hollow may be the result of relatively modern interference. An opening occurs at east, 1.00m wide, but again probably represents the result of this interference. This mound is situated c.15m to the west of the river.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 30 April 2012

The land is quite marshy and wet and is used as rough grazing for cattle at the moment. Several low banks of earth and stone also occur in this complex, but, as yet, their relationship to the barrows is unknown. Located on the west bank of a small river which is prone to flooding, c.200m from the coast in an area of marshy grassland...... located c.15.0m to the south of the above mound [KE038-138----] is a second similar but smaller example. It measures 4.00m N-S by 5.00m E-W at base, and is 1.25m in height. It is now eroded on its eastern side, probably due to flooding of the river eroding this side of the barrow. The top of the barrow is slightly eroded where a 2.00m N-S by 3.00m E-W, 0.20m deep depression occurs. This mound appears to be constructed of a mixture of stone and earth.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 30 April 2012

This unusual feature located on the western side of the Finglas River, near the head of Scotias Glen, seems to be partially cut by the river on its south - south-eastern side. The site affords spectacular views down the glen to the south. The site consists of a bank with internal ditch and traces of an external ditch with a central platform or raised area. The bank is composed of earth and stone and is visible on the northern, southern and western sides of the site. It is 0.47m high both internally and externally and 2.1m wide. The inner ditch is again clearly visible except on the eastern side. It is flat bottomed, 0.50m in depth and 1.7m wide. The external ditch is less clear but can be traced on the western and southern sides. It appears to be 0.25m deep and 1.2-1.5m wide. The inner platform area is circular, 6.4m in diameter and 0.54m high, with a central depression measuring 1.7m by 1m and 0.22m deep. The total dimensions of the extant site are 16.55m N-S and 13.2m E-W.'  Description from The Prehistoric Settlement of the Lee Valley, Tralee, Co. Kerry; A Landscape Perspective by Michael Connolly. PhD Thesis UCC 2008  Date of upload: 22 June 2012

See field inspection report (diary NF6, 36-7) (SMR file). According to the report, this is a levelled  earthwork identified on aerial photographs (Hunting Surveys Ltd. 1:10,000 8131/8132) taken 1962 and on Irish Air Corps aerial photographs (V.163/49) taken 10/05/1949.Situated on the lower foothills of the Slieve Mish mountains, this partially destroyed barrow commands a dominant view from east through north to west. The field in which this site is located has recently been planted with deciduous forest, thereby almost completely obliterating the east and west elements of the barrow. It is described in the RMP manual as fulacht fiadh, however this was probably misidentified because of the large amount of scattered red sandstone which occurs on the almost scree-like slope.The central platform is still visible, although much denuded, and measures 13.0m N-S. An accurate E-W measurement cannot be gauged as only a 4.0m wide strip has been left untouched, and the use of this strip as an access way has substantially flattened the barrow itself. In its present state the surrounding fosse is 3.50m wide, 0.30m below the top of the central platform and 0.35m below the top of the enclosing bank. This bank is approximately 4.0m in width and is 0.40m above external ground level. No trace of burning or burnt stone could be found to indicate that there was a fulacht fiadh in this area (Connolly 1996).Above description is from 'Tralee Area Monument Catalogue' part of a PhD thesis submitted by Michael Connolly to UCC.Matt Kelleher 31 May 2012

See field inspection report (diary NF6, 58-61) (SMR file). According to the report, this is a levelled enclosure.  Depicted as a small earthwork possibly a barrow type earthwork intersected at W by a field boundary running N-S.

These sites are situated on top of a limestone reef approximately 300m to the west of the cairn/complex [KE038-101----]. These sites have been much denuded because of an attempt to reclaim this reef which is located on a large dairy farm, and have been much trampled by cattle. Also a substantial N-S running stone wall has neatly bisected this reef, and probably utilised stone from the enclosures and banks in its construction. The top of this reef affords unobstructed views in all directions, but the dominant aspect is primarily southwards........a possible barrow occurs on the north-eastern side of the knoll, and is now very overgrown and denuded, and has been truncated by the field wall. A subcircular ditch, 2.00m in width and 0.30m in depth encloses what appears to be a low mound now very overgrown, 12.0m in diameter and rises to 0.60m above the bottom of the ditch.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 25 April 2012

These sites are situated on top of a limestone reef approximately 300m to the west of the cairn/complex [KE038-101----]. These sites have been much denuded because of an attempt to reclaim this reef which is located on a large dairy farm, and have been much trampled by cattle. Also a substantial N-S running stone wall has neatly bisected this reef, and probably utilised stone from the enclosures and banks in its construction. The top of this reef affords unobstructed views in all directions, but the dominant aspect is primarily southwards........to the south of this [KE038-163----] is a circular hollow 10.0m in diameter and 0.50m deep. Because of the overgrowth it is impossible to determine if there is an enclosing element surrounding this hollow. A large amount of loose limestone is scattered in this area.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 25 April 2012

Situated in poor pastureland on a gentle SE-NW slope, the barrow is barely perceptible and is enclosed by a fosse and external bank. It has an external diameter of 11.2m NW-SE. The earthen bank enclosing the fosse and inner mound is low and wide. In width it measures 2.4m, its maximum height above the external ground level is 1m, while it measures .4m above the fosse.The above description is derived from C. Toal, North Kerry Archaeological Survey. Dingle. Brandon in association with FAS Training and Employment Authority (1995), no. 84. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.Date of upload: 2 August 2013

This site was located in land that sloped down to the south-east and was identified on black an white aerial photography. The site showed up clearly and the photograph suggests that in 1998 the site still had a very low level enclosing bank approximately 4m wide, enclosing a sub-circular area measuring approximately 23m by 18m. The photograph suggest that, internally, there was a centrally placed mound or rise, which while it may represent a collapsed structure, would suggest the site may have been a barrow. The site was destroyed by housing in 2002.'  Description from The Prehistoric Settlement of the Lee Valley, Tralee, Co. Kerry; A Landscape Perspective by Michael Connolly. PhD Thesis UCC 2008  Date of upload: 22 June 2012

This site is located in a field, which has been reclaimed for pasture for cattle, on the southern side of a low limestone outcrop. A low circular mound, 4.00m in diameter, now grass covered but apparently composed of stone, is surrounded by a bank curving from west through south to south-east. This bank has an average width of 4.00m and an average external height of 0.35m. From east through north to north-west the limestone outcrop has been cut into to form the remainder of the enclosing element. The top of this cutting is level with the ground surface of the limestone spur. The circular mound is slightly off-centre, being more to the north. This mound is surrounded by a depression from east through south to south-west, which at its deepest is 0.75m below the crest of the mound and a maximum width of 5.00m, but it is not clear if this is, in fact, an internal ditch. Total dimensions of the site are 18.0m N-S by 22.0m E-W.'   Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 30 April 2012

Situated in a field on the immediate eastern side of a tributary of the River Lee. The portion of land on which these sites occur slopes gently westwards. The main features within the complex are earthen enclosures, small mounds, a linear earthwork and a possible barrow with portions of double banks remaining. All of these sites are partially denuded due to reclaimation, this field still being slightly marshy despite efforts to reclaim the land for the purposes of pasture.............to the east of the terminus of the above earthwork [KE038-152----] is a possible, though substantially denuded barrow, which would appear to be surrounded by a second bank from north through east to south to south/south east. The barrow takes the form of a sub-circular bank, averaging 4.50m in width and surviving to a maximum of 0.50m above external ground level at north. This encloses a shallow ditch, 1.50m in width, which was 0.30m below the crest of the bank. This ditch is 0.38m below the level of the circular central platform, which is 6.00m in diameter. Total dimensions of the barrow are 18.0m E-W by 16.0m N-S. Surrounding this at an approximate distance of 10.0m is a second bank. This has an average width of 10.0m on its south side, widening to 12.0m in width at the northern extent of the bank. This enclosing element is 0.40m high externally, being 0.60m high internally.'  Compiled by Michael Connolly for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as part of a survey of the Lee Valley area in 1996-97.  Date of upload: 02 May 2012

The possible barrow (KE039-202002-) abuts the enclosure [KE039-202001-] to the west  north-west and while it is built back against the natural slope of the land, there are clear traces of a low mound 17m in diameter. Due to the slope of the ground the mound is 1.25m high to the east but, on average, 0.48m high elsewhere. The probable ditch is only clearly visible on the eastern side of the mound, however, it does appear to run out under the field boundary and the existing N22. The ditch is on average 1.45m wide at base and 0.22m below level of the existing ground surface. Interestingly the ditch would also appear to be impinged on by the embanked enclosure.'  Description from The Prehistoric Settlement of the Lee Valley, Tralee, Co. Kerry; A Landscape Perspective by Michael Connolly. PhD Thesis UCC 2008  Date of upload: 25 June 2012

This potential feature was reported by Michael Connolly, County Archaeologist, Kerry County Council. It was identified by him during the course of an assessment of a 40 square mile area for the purpose of choosing a road route in 2000 to the north of Killarney.  In level, impenetrable coniferous plantation, at base of a steep N-facing slope; Gweestin River to N. Access not gained. Reported to the Archaeological Survey of Ireland as the cropmark of a barrow. No potential feature evident at this location upon historic mapping. This area is obscured by forestry upon modern aerial photography indicating that the area of the potential feature may have been planted (OSi 2010; Bing 2015).

In pasture, on a low rise. A circular slightly raised area (diam. c. 20m) surrounded by a fosse and a slight external bank is visible as a shadow site in an aerial photograph taken in 1956 (ACAP, V 245/96-7). This possible barrow is not visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

In pasture, on a low hill. A roughly circular raised area (27m N-S) defined by an earth and stone bank (Wth 3.8m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 1.5m) which is slightly denuded along the S and W arcs. The bank is stone-faced externally, especially along the S, SW and N arcs and there cattle gaps at S and NNW. Field boundaries (on NW-SE and NE-SW axes) have been incorporated into this bank along the NE and SE arcs. The interior is almost entirely occupied by a central circular mound (diam. 1.6m; H 0.1m) which is surrounded by three concentric earthen banks (Wth 1.4-2.3m; int. H 0.1-0.3m; ext. H 0.1-0.5m) and an arc of a fourth bank (Wth 1.4m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.1m), which is evident NW-NE. This is probably the 'Danish Fort' described in the 1840s as being in the SE end of Ballynamaunagh (OSNB, Kilcummin, no. 2, 5).  Compiled by: Elizabeth Byrne, Ursula Egan and Sheila Ronan, Archaeological Survey Unit, University College, Cork.  Date of upload: 31 January 2011

On a ridge summit surrounded by bogland. A subcircular platform (NNE-SSW 14.5m, WNW-ESE 11.5m), in fair condition, defined by a scarp. The interior is slightly dished and a gap at E could be original. Possibly a barrow.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. I - West Galway'. Compiled by Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1993).  Date of upload: 05 August 2010

Located on a small peak on top of a knoll, in an area of rolling average pasture dotted with drumlin-like knolls and hummocks. There are good views in all direction: Rathfran Bay is visible to E, the Ox mountains to SE, and Nephin and the Nephin Beg range to WSW.  This is shown on the 1838 and 1922 OS 6-inch maps as a small circular enclosure (diam. 10-15m). It is evident as low, circular slightly domed rise (diam. c. 6-7m; H 0.4m) on top of the knoll. It is degraded and poorly defined. Another possible barrow (MA015-044006-) is located 15m to NNE. There are a wedge tomb (MA015-044007-) and two enclosures (MA015-044002- and MA015-044003-) c. 70m to NE; there is a rath (MA015-044004-) c. 100m to SE and another (MA015-044001-) c. 100m to NW.  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 6 December 2018

Encompassing a small peak on a top of a knoll, in an area of rolling average pasture dotted with drumlin-like knolls and hummocks. There are good views in all direction:  Rathfran Bay is visible to E, the Ox Mountains to SE, and Nephin and the Nephin Beg range to WSW.  This is shown on the 1838 and 1922 OS 6-inch maps as a small circular enclosure (diam. 10-15m). A low, circular slightly domed rise (diam. c. 8-10m; H 0.5-6m) is apparent on the top of the knoll. It is degraded and poorly defined, and it is not possible to determine its original form. Another possible barrow (MA015-044006-) is located 15m to NNE. There are a wedge tomb (MA015-044007-) and two enclosures (MA015-044002- and MA015-044003-) c. 55m to NE; a rath (MA015-044004-) c. 100m to SE and another (MA015-044001-) c. 100m to NW.  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 6 December 2018

Near the top of a low hill, in unreclaimed pasture, on the S-facing slope of an oval hillock (c. 40m E-W;  20m N-S) which is likely natural and overlooking Lickeen Lough to the S. Hachured on the 1840 and 1916 OS 6-inch maps. Listed as ring-barrow (possible) in the RMP (1996).A subcircular mound of earth and shale (L 9.9m E-W; Wth 8m N-S) which varies in height (0.25-1.5m). A hole has been dug in the centre (D 2m) and is now overgrown with brambles. A curving channel (Wth 1m) has been dug at SE towards the road potentially to provide access to the interior and the road has truncated the edge of the barrow at S.Compiled by: Mary Tunney and Lynda McCormackDate of upload: 22 May 2022

In pasture, sloping to S. Circular area (12m N-S; 10m E-W), enclosed by low bank of earth and stone (H 0.8m). Local tradition of childrens burials (MA121-142002-).  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 675.  Date of upload: 13 January 2015

Situated in good pasture. A tumulus (JRSAI 1935, 82) was destroyed c. 1926. It had covered a cist (MA100-095----).  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 36.  Date of upload: 6 February 2013

In improved pasture, located on elevated ground, with a gentle slope down to NEE.  Shown on the 1838 OS 6-inch map as a small embanked enclosure (diam. c. 10-15m); not shown on later map editions. There are scant remains: a circular area (13.3m NS; 11.3m EW) defined by a slight bank (Wth 2.5m; int. H 0.3-0.4m; ext. H 0.2m). Stones protrude from the top of the bank on the NW arc, and there is a tree stump in the bank at N. The interior appears slightly sunken, but a slight central rise is discernible off centre to N. Possibly the remains of a barrow.  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 1 April 2020

In reclaimed pastureland on the summit of Knockcarragh Hill. Hachured on the 1916 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. Classified as enclosure in the RMP (1996). Described by Westropp (1913, 258) as a conspicuous little tumulus.A grass-covered subcircular flat-topped mound (basal dims. 13m E-W; 11.3m N-S; H 1.4-2.2m) constructed of earth and large stones (dims. L c. 0.3m; L 0.3m). Its top (8m N-S; 5.7m E-W) slopes to the S and is covered with overgrown field-clearance stones. A drystone field wall crossing it from NW to SSE was built by the Land Commission during the 1920s, according to local information. The N edge of the mound has been straightened and is aligned NE-SW. Compiled by: Olive Alcock and Lynda McCormackDate of upload: 25 April 2022

Atop knoll, in undulating pasture. Low circular mound (diam. 5.4m E-W), enclosed by fosse (D 0.3m) SSW to E, levelled E to SSW.  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 45.  Date of upload: 12 December 2014

In pasture, on high ground. Circular area (6.4m N-S; 7m E-W), enclosed by earthen bank (H 0.45m); levelled W to NNW.  The above description has been derived from D. Lavelle (compiler), An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District including Lough Mask and Lough Carra. Lough Mask and Lough Carra Tourist Development Association (1994), No. 43.  Date of upload: 24 January 2013

This monument is shown on the 1838 and the 1929 OS 6-inch maps and was listed as enclosure in the RMP (1996) for Co. Mayo. It was recorded in An Archaeological Survey of Ballinrobe and District (Lavelle 1994, 10, no. 50) as follows: Barrow  In pasture, atop knoll. Circular raised area (13.8m NS; 14m EW; H 0.3m), enclosed by earthen bank (H 0.6m). Linear earthen bank runs off W side. The barrow was still extant in 2005 as it was recorded on the OS Ortho aerial photographs. An inspection in July 2012 found that all upstanding remains of the barrow had been destroyed during land reclamation sometime during the period 2005-2011. The earthen bank, which extended to the W of the barrow, was also removed.   Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 23 July 2012.

Situated on a NW-SE ridge in pasture. Not marked on any edition of the OS 6-inch map. Low, subcircular grass-covered mound (7.3m NE-SW; 6.8m NW-SE; H 0.3-0.45m). In the centre of the relatively flat top (diam. 4.6m) there is a circular hollow (diam. 1.6m; D 0.15m).  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

Situated on a low rise overlooking the Moy Estuary a short distance W. Raised circular area (diam. 12m) enclosed by an earthen bank (Wth 2.3-2.7m; int. H 0.2-0.3m; ext. H 0.6m). On 1913 OS 6-inch map it is shown within an oblong tree plantation.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, located on level gently elevated ground, in an area of undulating terrain. Low, circular grass-covered earthen platform (diam. 13m NE-SW; 13m NW-SE) defined by a levelled bank. The bank appears as a well-defined scarp (ext. H 0.3-0.35m) with a very low internal rim (Wth c. 2m) which is almost flush with internal ground level. The scarp is highest (ext. H 0.45m at W) at WNW, and lowest at NNE-E. At E there is a very low area or gap (Wth 2m). A slight dip in ground level is evident outside the bank at NE but it is not possible to be certain if this is evidence of an encircling fosse. The interior is level and featureless.  Attached image (SL022-026----_1) shows barrow from SE.  Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 11 September  2014

In pasture, located c. 40m E of a rocky shoreline. When first noted in 1991 this consisted of a rectangular area (c. 7m x 3m) defined by a shallow ditch (Wth c. 1m) with slight traces of an external bank (Wth 1m) (pers. comm. Victor Buckley, 2013). An inspection in 2013 found that land reclamation has taken place and there is now no visible trace of the monument. When noted in 1991 it was interpreted as a barrow, however, it appears to have been very similar in form and size to kelp-drying kilns (See for instance SL012-002001-) found elsewhere along the west Sligo coastline. There is another possible barrow (SL011-078----) located c. 150m to NNE.   Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 26th November 2013

Located in a pasture field bordered at W by a rocky shoreline. When first noted in 1991 this consisted of a rectangular area (c. 7m x 3m) defined by a shallow ditch (Wth c. 1m) with slight traces of an external bank (Wth 1m) (pers. comm. Victor Buckley, 2013). An inspection in 2013 found that land reclamation has taken place and there is now no visible trace of the monument. When noted in 1991 it was interpreted as a barrow, however, it appears to have been very similar in form and size to kelp-drying kilns (See for instance SL012-002001-) found elsewhere along the west Sligo coastline. There is another possible barrow (SL011-077----) located c. 150m to SSW.   Compiled by: Jane O'Shaughnessy  Date of upload: 26th November 2013

On gently sloping land to W of, and overlooking, the River Corrib on NW outskirts of Galway city. An overgrown steep-sided circular mound of earth and stone (D 19.55m, H 2.78m). The top is flat and traces of a shallow fosse (Wth c. 3m) encircle its base. (Killanin and Duignan 1967, 288)The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. I - West Galway'. Compiled by Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1993).Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In a thicket of overgrowth in a field of level pasture. The Pollagh River is located c. 200m to E where its course takes a broad bend. A circular embanked enclosure (diam. 15-20m) is shown on 1838 OS 6-inch map; it is not shown on later map editions. It is known locally as 'Lisheen'. This possible barrow consists of a circular, flat topped mound (overall diam. 11m EW; 10m NS; H 0.5 at N, 0.7m at W) of earth and stone. The top (diam. c. 5-6m) of the mound is intermittently defined by several low, moss-covered stones protruding from the sod. The stones vary in size; two on the N side are large and appear set in the ground, but there are also smaller stones, some of which may be field clearance. A large boulder abuts the base of the mound at S. Engulfed in blackthorn, hawthorn and brambles; difficult to examine. A low stony rise (6m by 4m; H 0.5m) is located 4m to W, probably a field clearance heap.  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy
column13: Date of upload: 10 September 2021

column10: Situated on the NW-facing slope of a low N-S ridge in undulating pasture. Shown on the 1913 OS 6-inch map as a circular hachured feature (diam. c. 10-15m), this monument has been partly levelled. A slightly raised circular area (13m N-S; 11.4m E-W; H 0.1m at SE, 0.65m at NE) can still be discerned.   Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In low-lying grassland. A small poorly preserved circular enclosure (D 8.15m) defined by a low earthen bank. There is a possible entrance at S and the interior is hollow. Possibly a hut site but is recognised locally as a 'burial ground'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In an area of rough pasture and exposed bogland. A small circular enclosure (diam. c. 12m), possibly a ditch or ring-barrow, is  visible on OSi digitalglobe aerial imagery (2011-2013). Another possible barrow (GA028-056002-) lies c. 18m to its SE. Identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. The following image has been uploaded: GA028-056001-_01.jpg OSi digitalglobe image (2011-2013)Compiled by: Olive AlcockDate of upload: 4 July 2022

In an area of rough pasture and exposed bogland. A small circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m), possibly a ditch or ring-barrow, is visible on OSi digitalglobe aerial imagery (2011-2013). Another possible barrow (GA028-056001-) lies c. 18m to its NW. Identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère. The following image has been uploaded: GA028-056002-_01.jpg OSi digitalglobe image (2011-2013)Compiled by: Olive AlcockDate of upload: 4 July 2022

In low-lying, gently undulating pasture, overlooking the River Deel c. 0.9km to E and the Shannon Estuary to N. A second similar feature (LI010-124----) lies approx. 90m to N. Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Identified as Site 1 in 1999 as a possible enclosure by Celie ORahilly when walking the route of a proposed ESB power line. Described as an oval-shaped mound (L 16m E-W) defined by a low bank from NW-N-E-S-SW. This incorporates some rock outcrop and stones, some of which may be attributed to field clearance. A field boundary is close to S and a gallops track lies c. 10m to E. The description of a mound enclosed by a bank could suggest a possible barrow or a possible burial mound/cairn.  Monument is visible as an irregular oval-shaped stony area on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 08/04/2015.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and field map by O'Rahilly  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and  Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 6 July 2020

In flat pastureland. This circular barrow (D 11m int.), consisting of a wide earthen round-topped bank (Wth 9m, int. H 1.4m; ext. H 1.1m) was noted during aerial reconnaissance (ASGAP 226:47). The interior is hollow and featureless. There is no visible trace of an entrance gap or fosse. A holy well (GA028-016----) lies c. 60m to the SW. (Alcock et al. 1999, no. 1078)Updated by: Olive AlcockDate of revised upload: 13 May 2022

In undulating grassland. A circular grassed-over stony mound (D 16m, H c. 1m), in fair condition, with a deep cone-shaped depression at centre. A shallow encircling fosse is visible from S to W tp N. A field wall abuts the monument at N and S. (ASGAP 226:53)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In flat grassland. Marked on 1st ed. of OS 6-inch map as a small circular enclosure (D c. 10m) but on 3rd ed. (1916) as a small hollow. No visible surface trace survives. A similar monument (GA015-031----) lies 90m to SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In reclaimed grassland, with post-1700 field boundary running NNE-SSW across NW quadrant of monument.  Cropmark of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 17m) defined by a scarp and external ditch visible on Digital Globe orthophoto taken 2011-13.  Cropmark of earthwork clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 08/04/2015. See attached Google Earth orthophoto taken 08/04/2015.Compiled by: Caimin OBrienDate of upload: 31 May 2020

On a hummock in grassland. Poorly preserved almost circular earthen mound (N-S 19m, E-W 18m, H 0.5m) with a shallow central depression.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

On SE-facing slope of a small hill. A well-preserved circular earthwork (D 12m) defined by a bank of earth and stone which encloses a slightly hollow interior. A vegetation band running outside the bank from NW through E to S could be the last remnants of a fosse. Gaps in the bank at E and SSW appear modern, and a field wall cuts across it at SW and NW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In low-lying grassland. A circular barrow (D 56m), in fair condition, comprising a flat raised central platform (D 24.2m, H c. 1m) encircled by a wide internal fosse (Wth c. 5.5m), a berm and an external bank. (Wilde 1872, 60)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In level grassland. Poorly preserved circular enclosure (D 37.8m) comprising a central platform (D 17.1m int.) encircled by a wide fosse and external bank. The surface of the platform is uneven and there are faint traces of a possible internal bank from S to W. There are also faint traces of a possible causeway across the fosse at SSE and the tradition of a spring well in its base at SE. The monument is locally referred to as a 'burial ground'.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

On flat pasture 115m N of the townland boundary with Ballywilliam North. The enclosure is within the demesne lands surrounding Abbey House and is located 620m SE of the ruins of the Augustinian Priory (LI029-031006-) on the Main Street in Rathkeale.
