The site is depicted as a small circular enclosure or antiquity on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map.  Not shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map or subsequent maps. The enclosure is not visible on either the OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12 or on the Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. The site (ext. diam. c. 12.5m N-S; 12.5m E-W) is faintly visible on the Google Earth orthoimage taken 05/02/2009, but not visible on the orthoimage taken 28/06/2018. The monument could be a ring-barrow or landscape demesne feature / tree-ring. A similar feature survives 125m E of the site in the next field and is visible both on aerial orthoimages and on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 25 September 2020

In pastureland. A small roughly circular enclosure (diam. c. 15m), possibly a ditch or ring-barrow, is visible on Google Earth aerial imagery dated March 2014. Another possible barrow (GA057-178002-) lies c. 28m to its NE. Identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère.The following image has been uploaded: GA057-178001-.jpg Google Earth image (11 March 2014)Compiled by: Olive AlcockDate of upload: 5 July 2022

In pastureland. A small circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m), possibly a ditch or ring-barrow, is visible on Google Earth aerial imagery dated March 2014. Another possible barrow (GA057-178001-) lies c. 28m to its SW. Identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère.The following image has been uploaded: GA057-178002-.jpg Google Earth image (11 March 2014)Compiled by: Olive AlcockDate of upload: 5 July 2022

In pasture, on the N-facing slope of a low rise. Depicted on the 1914 OS 6-inch map as a small mound (diam. c. 10m), c. 15m SE of a rath (SL036-029001-). There are no visible remains of this mound. Its size and location, however, suggest a barrow.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On a SW-facing slope in pastureland. A very poorly preserved subcircular barrow (WNW-ESE 17.8m) consisting of a flat central area (D 10.3m), evidently much disturbed, which is enclosed by an earthen bank/scarp, best preserved at E and from S to W. There was a CBG (GA029-143001-) in the interior.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

On E slope of a ridge. A poorly preserved circular barrow (D 12.6m ext.) consisting of a central circular area (D 6m), now much disturbed by a sheep-feeding unit, which is encircled by a low but substantial earthen bank. This is overlain by a modern bank in S sector. A gap at NE appears modern, and there is a shed immediately outside the monument at E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In poorly drained rough grassland, 90m E of townland boundary with Ballyhahill, a ringfort (LI037-114----) lies 55m to the SSW. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Monument visible as circular enclosure on ASI aerial photographs taken 18/09/2005.  Monument visible as a circular-shaped area (diam. c. 20m) defined by a scarp with fosse, bank and external fosse on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages. An external bank from E-S-W is visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 24/09/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and ASIAP taken 18/09/2005.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 20 April 2021

In low-lying level farmland. A subcircular barrow (N-S 22.5m) cut by a field wall running N-S: no visible surface trace survives to E of this wall. It consists of a low central mound (N-S 7m) encircled by a fosse and earthen bank.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

Situated on a low rise in rough pasture. Circular, round-topped, grass-covered mound (diam. 13.7m; H 2.3m). On the W and S sides are narrow buttresses of uncertain antiquity. Probably a barrow.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

On NW shoulder of a slight rise. A subcircular barrow (WNW-ESE 21.5m, N-S 20.5m) consisting of a roughly level area (D 9.3m) delimited by a fosse and earth and stone bank. The monument has been disturbed by quarrying from NE to E, and at NW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

Located in level pasture, 15m SSE of the rocky shoreline of a cove. The mouth of a river, which enters the sea in the middle of the cove, lies 100m to W. Knocknarae is visible on the horizon to E. The Ox Mountains dominate the skyline to SE. Slightly raised, circular area (diam. 16m NS, c. 17m EW) defined by a broad, low bank (Wth 3m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.65m, at W) with a gently rounded profile. A few stones protrude randomly from the sod covering of the bank, particularly at W and NW. A roughly circular, poorly defined rise (diam. c. 2m) is barely discernible in the centre of the interior. A later field wall (Wth 0.5m; H 0.9m) on a NS axis cuts the E edge of the barrow.  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 7 February 2015

One of four barrows on Athenry golf course (GA083-066----; GA083-067----; GA083-068----; GA083-075----).  Situated on a slight S-facing slope, it now acts as a trap in front of the 9th tee. It consists of a poorly preserved subcircular area (13.6m N-S; 12m E-W) comprising a low central mound (diam. c. 5.5m), which appears to have been dug out, surrounded by a low earthen bank.  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 2 March 2015

In pasture, prominently located on a hillock, with a steep fall of ground to S, W and N and S.  Depicted on the 1838 OS 6-inch map as a circular embanked enclosure (diam. 15-20m), and on the 1917 edition as a small hachured feature (diam. c. 10-15m) encircling a trigonometrical point (455ft).  The SW slope of the hillock was entirely quarried away in the past, and this area has been levelled out and grassed over. The top of the hillock has been graded, and a concrete water tank now occupies the summit, possibly overlying the site of the enclosure.  This monument may have been a form of barrow, perhaps similar to the mound barrow (MA092-033----), located c. 800m to SE in the same townland, or the mound barrow (MA092-012----) located c. 500m to NW, but insufficient above ground evidence survives to confirm this.  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 24 February 2022

In pasture, located the SE end of a NWSE ridge, on a level area or slight terrace at the break of slope, with fall of ground to NE. Depicted on the 1838 OS 6-inch map as a circular embanked enclosure (diam. 15-20m), and on the 1917 edition as a small circular hachured feature (diam. c.10-15m).  Destroyed during land reclamation; there is no visible trace at ground level. The siting of this monument, and its depiction on the 6-inch map, suggests that it may have been a mound or a type of barrow, perhaps similar to the mound barrow (MA092-033----), located c. 600m to SE in the same townland, or the mound barrow (MA092-012----) located c. 700m to NW.  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 24 February 2022

This barrow, known locally as The Moat, was fully excavated in 1963 in advance of road-widening works on the N 59 Sligo-Ballina road (Danaher 1964). Prior to excavation the barrow appeared as a roughly circular mound (diam. 13.5m; H 2.3m), gently domed in profile, with a somewhat steeper slope near the summit on the W and N side. Excavation determined that the barrow was composed of a roughly circular cairn (diam. 11.85m; H 1.5m) of stones and gravel, with a kerb-like setting of stones at SW and NE, overlain by a mound of stony soil. There was no evidence of an enclosing fosse. The primary burial in the barrow was of an ox. It was unburnt and unprotected, lying slightly NW of centre, 0.25cm above the old ground level. Associated with the ox burial were twelve poorly-preserved sherds of pottery and a waste fragment of chert. A few other unburnt animal bones of calf, pig and ox were found within the lower layers of the cairn material. In a secondary phase of activity at the barrow, a cist (SL012-053002-) was inserted into the summit of the barrow on its W side, and a pit-burial (SL012-053003-) was inserted into the E side. Both contained cremated remains.  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 7 May 2013

In flat pastureland and tillage. A circular barrow (D 37m), in fair condition, composed of a large central mound (D 6.25m, H 3.1m max. at S) encircled by a substantial fosse and external bank of earth and stone. The bank is extant for only c. 4m at NW. A large central depression in the mound suggests sturbance. A cairn (GA071-035----) lies c. 220m to E.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In gently undulating grassland, crowning the summit of a hill, close to a break of slope on the NE side where there is a steep and abrupt fall of ground. The hill affords extensive views that encompass Croagh Patrick on the far horizon to W and Nephin to NW. It overlooks a pool, now an area of boggy ground, which is located at the base of the slope c. 150m to SE. The pool is named Loughsheebaun on the 1916 OS 6-inch map.  A slightly raised circular area (10m NS; 10.3m EW) defined by a raised rim (ext. H 0.8m at N, 0.6m at S) that slumps seamlessly into a concave interior (diam. 2.8m). An ogham stone (MA093-038002-) is set in the NE edge of the hollow. There is a low berm-like extension (Wth c. 1m; H 0.2m) at the external base of the barrow on the NEE side. Another barrow (MA093-096----) is located c. 200m to NNE.  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 23 June 2022

In pasture, located in a lowlying area, with poorly drained wet ground immediately to N, and rising ground to NW and NE.A circular area (diam. 11-12m) defined by a low bank (Wth c. 3m; int. H 0.35-0.4m; ext. H 0.1-0.2m), best preserved on the W half. The interior area appears slightly sunken and encloses a slight rise (diam. c. 3m) off-centre in the NE quadrant. The remains are barely discernible and difficult to classify.Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessyDate of upload: 22 December 2021

On a slight hummock in otherwise level recently cleared pastureland. An oval barrow (E-W 24.3m, N-S 17.75m), in fair condition, composed of a slightly raised central area (D 11.25m, H 0.6m max.) encircled by a shallow fosse and external bank. The bank and fosse have been dug out at SE and the latter has been refilled with rubble. There is a small hollow (D c. 0.5m) to E of centre.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

On a rise in reclaimed pastureland. Poorly preserved circular earthwork (D 7.5m, H 0.5m) defined by a bank and external fosse, the latter being visible only at S. The interior is slightly hollow, and it and a possible gap (Wth 2m) at W are much obscured by field-clearance rubble.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In pasture, on a slight natural rise. An irregular grass-covered mound of earth and stone (c. 8m E-W; c. 10m N-S; H c. 0.8m). A small roughly central stony core (diam. c. 3m; H 0.4m) protrudes above the remainder of the mound. One hawthorn bush grows on the S edge of the mound while a second has fallen on the E side. It is known locally as 'the fairy fort' though its dimensions would preclude it from being a rath and it may be the remains of a barrow. A very slightly curving field boundary lies c. 30m to N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture. A raised circular area (diam. 18m; H 0.35m) cut by a lane on its W edge and the resultant material dumped into the interior. It was described in 1978, when it was used as a place for feeding cattle, as flat-topped and containing numerous stones. (pers. comm. M. A. Timoney)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture on a gently E-facing slope, with good views in all directions.  Standing in the centre of a tree-lined avenue running S to Caherass Court located 415m to S.  Tree-ring (LI021-087----) 120m to NW. Not shown on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map.  Depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as an oval-shaped mound (ext. diam. 36m NE-SW; 35m NW-SE) defined by a fosse located within a tree lined landscape demesne avenue. The fosse (Wth c. 6m) encloses the site on all sides with a possible entrance at NE. Inspected by the ASI in 2001 when it was described as levelled with irregular undulations at the site. The location of the levelled earthwork is visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018 and 14/02/2020.   Possibly a small mound enclosed by a fosse similar to small barrow type monument.  The siting of the earthwork on a tree-lined avenue associated with Caherass Court may suggest the remains of a 19th century landscape feature rather than a prehistoric burial mound.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 16 August 2020

On NW extremity of a glacial ridge, on E outskirts of Dunmore town (GA017-002----): the Sinking River flows past to NE and the old fair green lies a short distance to NW. A small well-preserved mound, roughly circular in plan and conical in profile (D 6m, H c. 1.8m). Traces of a low linear bank and shallow fosse are visible running along the ridge summit to SE. According to Bradley and Dunne (1992, 70), this mound 'seems to be the remains of a barrow'. They also express the opinion that the linear bank may be part part of 'a hollow way leading up to it ... the north side ... formed by a scrap, the south by a bank'.The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In lowlying pasture, 170m SE of the Barnakyle River, 200m N of Elmpark House and 100m WNW of barrow (LI012-100----). This earthwork is not indicated on the 1840 OS 6-inch map or subsequent OS maps. The outline of a circular-shaped area (approx. dims. 30m N-S, 27m E-W) defined by a bank is clearly visible on both Digital Globe aerial photos taken 2011-2013 and Global Earth orthoimages taken in 2009 and 2018. Traces of a bank running NW-SE 7m to the N is also visible on these images.See attached Google Earth orthoimages taken 19/11/2019 and 23/05/2018Compiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 22 June 2020

In pasture on slight W facing slope, 300m SW of the Barnakyle River, 200m NW of Elmpark House. No surface remains visible. Potential monument identified from examination of 1:10k OSi aerial photographs (OS5 740; Nr 0686) where the outline of an enclosure was identified. This earthwork is not indicated on the 1840 OS 6-inch map or subsequent OS maps. Outline of a circular-shaped area defined by a bank (approx. overall dims. 70m N-S, 62mE-W) with trace of bank running NE from E and possible rectangular annexe/enclosure to the immediate W visible on Digital Globe orthophoto taken 2011-2013. Traces of a second smaller enclosure or possible barrow (LI012-163----) 100m to the NW.  Outline of monument clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimages taken between 2009/2019.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 22 June 2020

In level pasture, on the demesne lands of Faha House located 220m to NW. Not depicted on the 1840 OS 6-inch map or the 1897 25-inch map. Earthwork depicted as a small mound enclosed by a on the 1923 OS 6-inch map.  No surface remains visible today.  Faint cropmark of levelled earthwork visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 19/11/2019 and Digital Globe orthophoto 2011-13.   Representation of earthwork on revsied OS 6-inch map suggests possible barrow monument, however its location on demesne lands may suggest the remains of a designed landscape feature.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate upload: 22 June 2020

On top of a ridge. This barrow is not visible at ground level. According to local information, a mound (diam. c. 8m; H 1m) was levelled c. 1988. It was one of four barrows (SL032-071----; SL032-072----; SL032-224----) on the same ridge.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, approx. 50m NW of ringfort (LI013-170001-) and immediately W of ringfort (LI013-071----).  Not depicted on the 1840 0S 6-inch map or the 1897 25-inch OS map. Identified as site 29 by Celie ORahilly, archaeologist, Limerick Corporation as part of an archaeological assessment for the development of a racecourse at Greenmount, Co. Limerick.  It was described as following; a hollow sub-circular area circa. 30m north-south.  The western side is higher due to the sloping ground and it is open to the east.  There is a low mound centrally placed (ORahilly 1995).  Monument not visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 14/02/2020. See attached location map by Celie O'Rahilly showing location of site 29.Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate upload: 1 July 2020

In pasture, on a gentle E-facing slope. This barrow is not visible at ground level. It was indicated as a hachured circular raised area (diam. c. 10m) on the 1914 OS 6-inch map. A possible barrow (SL032-184----) lies c. 15m to SE and a ring-barrow (SL032-182----) c. 250m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on a gentle E-facing slope. This barrow is not visible at ground level. It was indicated as a hachured circular raised area (diam. c. 15m) on the 1914 OS 6-inch map. Another possible barrow (SL032-183----) lies c. 15m to NW and a ring-barrow (SL032-182----) c. 250m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008
Cropmark of circular-shaped area (diam. c. 48m) defined by a ditch visible on Google Earth photograph taken 20/09/2020.
column13: See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère   Date of upload: 10 January 2022

column10: Encircling a hillock in an area of rough pastureland. This very poorly preserved oval enclosure (c. 70m E-W; c. 60m N-S) is defined by a bank of earth and stone (Wth 2m, H 1m) and an internal fosse (Wth 7.5m) from N through E to S. At S it peters out and there is no visible surface trace elsewhere but the slope appears to be scarped from NW to N. A field boundary cuts across the hillock, close to its base, at W and quarrying has encroached upon N sector. Field-clearance material is evident on the SW slope. There is a children's burial ground (GA105-020----) within the interior, on the summit.   Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 2 June 2017

Situated on the S-facing slope of a low rise in pasture. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 6m) defined by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth. 0.7m - 1m; H 0.2m - 0.5m) with internal and external stone kerbs. At NW is a break in the bank at NW (Wth. 0.5m). However this may be the result of modern disturbance rather than an original entrance feature.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

On a level landscape. D-shaped grass-covered mound (dims of base 13.6m NNE-SSW; 9m WNW-ESE; H 2.4-2.6m) which is truncated by a N-S roadway and rockery on the E side.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In reclaimed pasture 45m E of a roadway that marks the townland boundary with Ballincolly.  Enclosure (LI047-058----) lies 200m to S.  Depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map as a circular-shaped earthwork.  It is shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a circular-shaped area (diam. c. 30m) defined by a scarp with fosse, external bank and outer fosse.  Outline of overgrown monument is visible on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 13 August 2021

Situated in pasture with a fall off in ground level to E. Not marked on either edition of the OS 6-inch map. Identified an aerial photograph as a small circular enclosure. There are a number of barrows in the vicinity of the potential monument, including ringbarrows (SL019-039----) and (SL019-041----), located c.200m SW and c.200m SSW respectively. This may be another. There are no remains visible at gound level.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In undulating pasture, on top of a low rise. This barrow is not visible at ground level. It was indicated on the 1838 OS 6-inch map as a circular earthwork (diam. c. 10m); only the S half, on the S side of the field boundary, is indicated on the 1941-2 OS 6-inch map. This is one of five barrows in the vicinity (SL038-011----; SL038-012----; SL038-013----; SL038-015----).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on a low ridge on a W-facing slope in pasture. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 11.7m E-W; 11.5m N-S) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth. 3.3m; H 0.3m). No fosse. The monument, particularly the perimeter, is thickly overgrown with scrub.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, 368m E of townland boundary with Athalacca South. Depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map as an oval shaped platform defined by a scarp. Shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as an oval-shaped sunken area (dims. c. 13m N-S; 10m E-W) enclosed by a bank. Monument visible as an oval-shaped cropmark truncated at SE and SSW by a modern field boundary running NE-SW on the OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12.  Cropmark clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 12 April 2021

In undulating pasture, on a low rise. This barrow was levelled during the construction of a farm trackway c. 1991 and is not visible at ground level. According to local information, it consisted of a low flat-topped mound (diam. c. 10m) covered in gorse and brambles. It is one of five barrows in the vicinity (SL038-011----; SL038-012----; SL038-014----; SL038-015----).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, on a low rise on a S-facing slope. A circular slightly raised area (int. diam. c. 7m) enclosed by an earthen bank (Wth 2.3m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.55m). A small hole was recently dug in the centre and there is a small quarry immediately to SW. The S portion of the interior is raised c. 0.45m to compensate for the hillslope. Indicated on the 1838 OS 6-inch map as a circular enclosure but inadvertently named 'Megalithic Monument (Site of)' on the 1941-2 OS 6-inch map. The OS Name Books of the 1941-2 survey noted that the name applied to 'an ancient mound site of a Giants Grave' (Ó Nualláin 1989, 99, no. 26).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Marked only on the 1914 ed. of the OS 6-inch map where it is described in gothic lettering as a Sheeaun - little fairy mound, and situated on the crest of the SE-facing slope of a low hillock which is largely quarried away. Circular overgrown mound (diam. of base c. 28m; dims of top 8m E-W; 5m N-S; H 4.8m at S to 6.3m at E) with terraced sides. There is no visible fosse, kerb or other feature.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Situated on a narrow, steep-sided hillock. Raised circular area (diam. 8.5m N-S; 7.5m E-W) defined by a scarp (H 0.7m - 0.9m) with large stones protruding through the sod at intervals. No fosse. Original entrance not recognisable.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

Situated on a gentle SE-facing slope in undulating pasture. Circular platform (diam. 10m; H 0.3m) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone (Wth. 2.8m; int. H 0.5m) except at E and SE where the defining element is a low scarp (H 0.5m). Traces of a possible external fosse at NW (Wth. 1.2m). There are breaks in the bank at N (Wth. c.2m) and at E (Wth. 1.8m).  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

Situated on a low rise in pasture. Circular platform (diam. c. 9m; H 0.6m) defined by traces of an eroded bank (H 0.1m) which has an external fosse (Wth. 1.7m; D 0.3m) from S-SSW-SW. Original entrance not recognisable. Field clearance debris etc. has recently been placed on top of the site.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

Situated on the narrow E-side of a N-S ridge in pasture. Slightly raised circular area (9.5m NE-SW; 8.3m NW-SE) enclosed by a low, sod-covered stoney bank (Wth c. 2.6-4.5m; H 0.4-0.8m) with a broad internal slump which may incorporate some field clearance debris. The remains of a square enclosure (SL019-024001-) are 20m to S.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

Situated in undulating pasture. Depicted on both editions of the OS 6-inch map as a small circular enclosure. On the 1913 edition a NE-SW field boundary abutts its E side. The site has been levelled and there are no remains now visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

Situated on a low rise in undulating pasture. Depicted on all editions of the OS 6-inch map as a small circular enclosure at the SSW side of the Sligo-Ballina road. A NNE-SSW field boundary is shown adjacent to the E side of the site. An earlier field report (SMR (1989) file 1994) described a poorly defined area of raised ground outlined by an irregular scarp (max. H 0.4m) extending in an arc from S-SSW-SW. The remainder of the site was occupied by an animal pen. The site has since been levelled and there are no remains now visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

Situated on a low rise. Depicted on the 1837 edition of the OS 6-inch map as a small circular enclosure. A 1994 field report (SMR file) described a circular platform (diam. 9m; H 1.35 at N, 1.55m at S) defined by a scarp with traces of a possible bank (Wth 1m) at its upper edge at S. From WSW-NE the perimeter was incorporated into a field boundary which marks the boundary between Tanrego West and Carrownacreevy townlands. No fosse was evident. The monument has since been levelled/destroyed and there are no remains now visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In flat wet reclaimed floodplains of the Morningstar River 80m to NW, ring-ditch (LI039-205----) immediately to SSE.  Depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map as a sub-circular shaped platform (diam. c. 16m) defined by a scarp. Not marked on 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map indicating that the monument was levelled between these map dates. Partially levelled monument visible as a circular-shaped area defined by a scarp and wide fosse on aerial photograph (ASIAP (328) 7, 3) taken 5/10/2002. Monument visible as a sunken circular shaped area (diam. c. 10m)  standing inside a larger circular-shaped area (diam. c. 48m) defined by a waterlogged fosse visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages.See attached Archaeological Survey of Ireland aerial photograph (ASIAP (328) 7, 3) and Google Earth orthoimages.Compiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 14 April 2021See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP  328/1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 on 15/10/2002.

Situated at the S end of a low rise in undulating pasture. Slightly raised circular area (diam. 9.5m) enclosed by a bank of earth and stone (Wth. 2.2m - 3.4m; int. H 0.45m - 0.9m) which incorporates some field clearance stones. Some revetment stones are visible. No fosse. Narrow eroded break in bank at NW (Wth. 0.4m) may represent original entrance. Within the interior at S and SW a low stony scarp (H 0.4m) borders a hollow which may be the result of quarrying.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

Situated on a low rise, on a small penninsula jutting into Ballisodare Bay. Not marked on any edition of the OS 6-inch map. Identified by Timoney M.A. (1989, pers. comm.) Oval-shaped, low, flat-topped mound or platform (dims. 5.2m N-S; 3.4m E-W) defined by a low scarp (H 0.3m). No fosse.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 19 January 2011

In pasture, in undulating terrain, located at the NW end of a narrow, elongated NWSE ridge. Ground falls away c. 60m to S into an area of lowlying marshy ground.  This consists of a circular mound (diam. 5m) with gently domed profile, slightly flattened on top (diam. c. 2m), with low, broadly sloping sides (Wth slope c. 1.5-2m; H 0.3m at NW; 0.6m at SE) that grade into the slope of the ridge on which it is located. The mound is grass-covered. The S side has been partly eroded away, revealing the largely stone-free, earthen core of the mound. According local information, this location was traditionally known as Sheeaun.  The ridge, on which the barrow is located, consists of an elongated, grass-covered mound (L c. 70m; Wth c. 15m; H c. 2m) orientated NWSE axis. It has a narrow, flattened top (Wth 3-4m NESW) and steep, broadly sloping sides. At both the NW and SE ends, the mound tapers off in a long, gentle slope that grades into the surrounding field surface at SE, and at NW terminates at, or is slightly truncated by, a N-S field fence. The SW side of the ridge appears to have been partly dug away or scarped back in the past. Close to the SE end, there is a shallow, square or rectangular depression (3m NWSE; c. 3-5m NW-SE) which also appears to be the result of past disturbance. The nature of the ridge as a whole is uncertain. It may be a glacial deposit but, in this locality, its size and form are unusual. The possibility that it was artificially created cannot be ruled out entirely but, on the present evidence, it is taken to be a natural feature.  Attached images: SL007-050----_01.JPG possible barrow viewed from W SL007-050----_02.JPG possible barrow located at NW end of long narrow ridge, viewed from NE SL007-050----_03.JPG ridge with possible barrow at NE end, viewed from E  Compiled by: Jane OShaughnessy  Date of upload: 10 November 2014

Situated on reclaimed grassland, ditch barrow (LI031-028----) 150m to SW.  Outline of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 34m) defined by a fosse is visible on OSi orthoimages teken 2005-12.  Faint outline in monument visible on Digital Globe orthophoto taken 2011-13.Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 2 November 2020

In low-lying level pasture 10m S of a stream that marks the townland boundary with Fanningstown.  Ringfort (LI022-229----) located 120m to SW. Surveyed by the ASI in 2000 and described as an ovoid shaped area (9.5m N-S; 12m E-W) defined by a scarped edge (H 0.4m) and an external fosse (W 2.8m; D 0.5m) only visible from NE-E-SE.  Vegetation indicates the outline of a filled-in fosse from SE-S-W-NW.  The undulating interior is clear of vegetation.  The outline of the monument is clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/03/2017 but not on Google Earth image dated 07/02/2018.  See attached sketch plan surveyed by the ASI and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  7 August 2020

On a slight E-facing slope, in gently undulating pasture, with moderate views from N-E-S, 90m NW of the townland boundary with Fanningstown. Enclosure (LI022-031----) 65m to NE. Monument is not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as an oval-shaped cropmark on Bruff Survey aerial photographs (Bruff 107: AP4/3702). Monument surveyed in 2000 by the ASI and described as a raised circular-shaped area (diam. 18m) defined by a scarp (Wth 4m; H 0.2m) with external fosse (overall Wth 8.9m; D 0.2m). The scarp defines the site on all sides and the fosse is visible from NW-N-E-S-SW, although is infilled from SW-W-NW. The interior is gently undulating, is dry and free of overgrowth. Monument is visible as a distinct oval-shaped cropmark on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.See attached Bruff Survey aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 16 August 2020

In improved pasture 100m N of enclosure (LI031-097---) and 115m to NE of enclosure (LI031-144----).  Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified as a sub-rectangular shaped earthwork from examination of aerial photograph (BGE 1:5000 No. 46) of the region taken on 03/11/1984 associated with Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraghleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline. Visible as a circular cropmark (diam. c. 13m) on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.   See attached Google earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  8 April 2021

In reclaimed pasture, an enclosure (LI031-067----) lies 170m to SW. Possible barrow not depicted on OSi historic maps. Earthwork (Site No. 031125) identified during work on the Bord Gáis Éireann Curraghleigh West-Limerick. No surface remains visible of any feature on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 25 March 2021

Located in low-lying pasture. Comprises a circular, saucer-shaped area (diam. 30m) which is enclosed by an external bank (Wth 7m, H 2m) and internal ditch (Wth 10m, D. 0.5m) giving the monument an overall diameter of c. 70m. There is a waterlogged area in the SE which coincides with a break in the enclosing bank. There is another break in the bank in the N which coincides with a causeway in the ditch (O'Kelly, 1942, 90).Compiled by: Geraldine Stout Date of upload: 3 February 2012

Situated immediately S of Rathbane Golf Course, in gently rolling pasture, prior to road construction. The monument has been impacted on by the construction of the N20. Indicated with hachures on the 1924 OS 6-inch map, as an oval platform or mound (diam. c. 40m NW-SE; 20m N-S). Test excavations were carried out in 1997 by Audrey Gahan for ADS (97E0287), in advance of road construction for the N20/N21. The site 'appeared on inspection as a sub circular mound. Slight depressions in the surrounding area suggested the possibility of a ditch. The mound, which was approximately 15m in diameter, was constructed by layers of redeposited subsoil. A row of large stones was uncovered which may represent kerbing. That the mound had been heavily truncated became immediately apparentUnder the redeposited material the remains of a ditch, encircling the mound, were uncovered. This was roughly v-shaped and was also largely filled with redeposited subsoil. The possible remains of a second ditch were found, between 1m and 2m beyond the first ditch. This was ill-defined and was filled by redeposited boulder clay. No artefacts were recovered which could suggest a date for the site.  Excavations by Frank Coyne of Aegis under licence No. 99E0630 were summarised as following; 'This site was first noted during fieldwork for an archaeological impact assessment for the Limerick Southern Ring Road and identified as a possible barrow. It was subsequently test-trenched and found to be of archaeological merit and was then excavated from December 1999 to February 2000.  This site was almost perfectly circular, measuring 14.5m north-south by 14m, and survived to a maximum height of 0.75m. It was already known from local information that this mound was substantially denuded in recent years in an attempt to level the land. However, a sufficient amount of the site survived to indicate two distinct phases of activity. It appears that this site originally took the form of a low mound, created from a layer of stone cobbles and capped with a layer of redeposited clay. This clay was removed in recent years in the course of land improvements, but the cobbled layer survived. A small quantity of cremated bone and a quantity of charcoal were recovered from this surface. Removal of this layer of cobbles exposed a substantial amount of pre-mound activity in the form of several irregular cut features in the naturally occurring boulder clay. The largest of these measured 3.18m north-south by 4.54m, having a depth of almost 2m. A substantial amount of charcoal was recovered from this cut, as was a quantity of animal bone, a piece of flint and portion of a human femur.   A nearby pond, which curved around the site from west to north, measuring 25m in length, may have been the source for the original clay capping of the site. Several post-holes were excavated around the perimeter of the site but did not form any discernible pattern.  A 50m area was stripped of topsoil on either side of this site, but no additional features were uncovered. No enclosing element was uncovered. The available evidence seems to point to this site being the remains of a funerary monument in the barrow tradition.

In pasture, on the SE-facing slope of a ridge. This barrow is not visible at ground level. A small oval enclosure is visible in an aerial photograph (OSAP, 6 2424).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In undulating pasture, on a natural rise and densely covered with undergrowth and trees. The natural rise is utilised to form a high flat-topped circular platform (24.6m NW-SE) defined on top by an earthen bank (Wth 3m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 4.8m) S-N and by a scarp N-S. A tumble of loose stones was noted on the external slope of the bank. The base of the platform is enclosed all round by a fosse (Wth 3m) with an external bank (Wth 5m; int. H 1.5m; ext. H c. 3.6m). A tumble of loose stones is evident on the internal and external slopes of this bank, most noticeably at NW. The interior is mostly level with a slight slope down to SE. A shallow depression (Wth 1.4m; D 0.15m) skirts the bank internally S-N. At NNE a sunken pathway (Wth 1.6m) through the outer bank leads to a series of steps, bordered on the W side by remnants of a low stone wall, which have been cut into the external slope of the platform. Another pathway approaches the barrow from the road to the E and curves up the slope of the hill to an eroded section of the outer bank at SE where a causeway (Wth 1.8m) crosses the fosse. A field boundary abuts the outer bank at WNW and another crosses the fosse at SSE. A large boulder (1.3m x 1.4m; H 0.75m) in the fosse at NNE is known locally as a mass-rock (SL025-071003-). A cist (SL025-071002-) containing an urn is said to have been found on the summit (Wood-Martin 1887-8, 270-72).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, just below the crest of a NE-facing slope and with a panoramic view of the surrounding countryside. A roughly square mound (c. 14m NE-SW; 15.4m NW-SE; H 0.9m) with rounded corners which is well-defined on the downslope (NE) side but is low and degraded on the SW side where it is almost level with the ground surface. The S corner has been removed by quarrying as well as smaller areas at N and SE. On top of the mound, slightly SW of centre, is a small irregular secondary mound of earth and stones (4.7m NW-SE; 3.3m NE-SW; H 0.75m), possibly the result of field clearance or upcast from areas of disturbance. As it is indicated as a circular mound (diam. c. 20m) on the 1941-2 OS 6-inch map it is possible that its present shape is the result of recent modifications. Its size and location suggest a barrow. A possible circular enclosure (SL038-096----) lies c. 80m to SE and a possible rath (SL038-097----) c. 190m to SSE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture 95m E of a roadway that marks the townland boundary with Tobernea West.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  A possible bowl-barrow (LI047-090002-) lies 65m to NE.  Identified as a possible bowl-barrow by Matt Kelleher when visited on the 12/04/1997.  Visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. c. 9m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13.  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages dated 14/09/2019.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 25 August 2021

In pasture 160m E of a roadway that marks the townland boundary with Tobernea West.  Not depicted on the OSi historic maps.  A possible barrow (LI047-090001-) lies 65m to SW.  Identified as a possible bowl-barrow by Matt Kelleher when visited on 12/04/1997.  Visible as a circular-shaped depression (diam. c. 7m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13.  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages dated 14/09/2019.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 25 August 2021

In wet pasture immediately S of a stream which marks the townland boundary with Dromin South. Enclosure (LI039-138---) lies 160m to NE. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 27; AP 5/2112) as an enclosure.  Outline of monument visible as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark (diam. c. 20m) on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-13.  Visible as a cropmark of a circular-shape area defined by wide fosse (Wth c. 9m) on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 10 May 2021

In a clearing within a modern coniferous forestry plantation.  Enclosure (LI039-149----) lies 200m to W. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 20; AP 5/2064) as a ring-barrow.  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 or on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.   See attached Bruff aerial image with possible barrow labelled Bruff 20 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 8 May 2021

In wet pasture immediately N of stream which marks the townland boundary with Cloonygarra.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 26; AP 5/2112) as an enclosure.  Surveyed by the ASI in 1996 and described as a raised roughly circular-shaped area (diam. 18m) enclosed by a low bank (Wth 3.2m; H 0.25m) from NE-SW reduced to a scarp elsewhere. The interior rises to NE where there is a sub-circular shaped mound (diam. 4m) with a shallow depression (Wth 1.05m; D 0.2m) in the centre.    The outline of the monument is visible as a raised circular-shaped platform on OSi orthophotos taken between 2005-2012.  Visible as a faint cropmark of a circular-shaped area defined by a fosse on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached ASI sketch plan of monument, Bruff aerial photograph (Bruff 26) and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 10 May 2021

In a low-lying area surrounded by bogland. An oval barrow (N-S 37.5m, E-W 33.5m), in fair condition, consisting of a flat central area encircled by a low flat-topped earthen bank immediately outside of which is a fosse, possibly recut for drainage purposes. A gap (Wth 2m) at S could be original. (Knight c. 1975, 107)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In pasture, immediately to N (c. 4m) of the avenue leading to Ash Hill Towers country house. A grass-covered oblong mound (14.6m N-S; 22.8m E-W) with the traces of a possible shallow fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.15m) NNW-ENE. The mound is highest (H 1.2m) at its centre point and is abutted by a farm trackway at NW. It would appear that when trees were planted along the N side of the avenue about 200 years ago, they were planted in an arc around the mound as if to respect its presence. In a letter to her American fiancé dated 15 March 1908, Eileen (Weldon) notes "close to the avenue, as they call it, although there are trees on only one side of the road, is a large green mound which is supposed to mark the burial place of one of the Irish chieftains and a number of his followers. It was the custom in those days to bury a dozen or so of his slaves with every chieftain. Father says he would like to explore the spot, but not a man could be found who would put a spade into the sacred earth".  Compiled by: Matt Kelleher  Date of upload: 30 April 2015

In former Deerpark, on the demesne lands of Cahir Guillamore House (LI031-041019----) located 380m to NE.  Within NW quadrant of field system (LI031-041001-), a rectangular enclosure (LI031-014021----) lies 40m to NW and cashel (LI031-014005)- lies 90m to SE.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 1006; AP4/3598) as a small semi-circular shaped cropmark.   Possible cropmark visible as on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12.  Possible cropmark visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.  See attached Bruff aerial photograph labelled Bruff 1006 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 31 March 2021

In pasture, on top of a low rise on a slight SE-facing slope. Views are good to excellent in all directions. A roughly circular area (7.5m N-S; 8m E-W) defined by an earth and stone bank (int. H 0.6m; ext. H 0.75m; Wth 1.3m at top). Large limestone stones (diam. c. 0.4m) occur frequently in the bank material. The interior is level and flush with the external ground surface.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on undulating, poorly drained pasture. The monument is heavily obscured by dense scrub vegetation and deciduous trees. A circular area (14.3m N-S) enclosed by a gentle bank (int. H 0.2m; Wth. 2.7m; ext. H 1.1m) and external fosse (Wth. 1.8m; D 0.4m). The interior is uneven and obscured by vegetation.

In rough pasture, 30m N of townland with Ballinlee North and 130m E of townland boundary with Parkroe.  Enclosure (LI039-043----) lies 170m to NE. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Possible site  (Site No. 039135) identified during examination of aerial photographs (BGE 1/50000 2514) taken 03/11/1984 on the Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh-Limerick gas pipeline. In reclaimed pasture 120m NW of the townland boundary with Ballyania.  Not depicted on 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map.  Possible enclosure (LI039-136----) lies 75m to E.  Monument (overall ext. diam. 1c. 00m) shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a small depression in the centre of a platform (diam. c. 20m) defined by a scarp with wide internal waterfilled fosse (Wth c. 24m), bank (Wth c. 5m) and outer fosse (Wth c. 7m).  Monument is transected at W by a 19th century drainage channel running NE-SW which is depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map.  Outline of monument on poorly drained land is clearly visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12. and on Google Earth orthoimages  See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload: April 30 2021See attached ASI aerial photograph ASIAP  372/6, 8, 9. 10 on 05/01/2003.

Situated on poorly drained, partially reclaimed rushy pasture, that was formerly the floodplain of the Camoge River.  This stream flows from N to S immediately to the E.  A post-1700 linear drainage channel to W is visible as a cropmark on aerial photographs and on the revised edition of the OS 6-inch map.  One of five mounds recorded as feature G01F003 in 2012 LiDAR Survey (Motherway 2012, 77, 276).  Four mounds or possible barrows (LI022-258-/59-/60-/061) are visible on OSi orthophotos taken 2005-12.  On this aerial photograph three possible barrows (LI022-258----/59-/60-) are roughly aligned on a NW-SE axis.  The fourth possible barrow is located directly N of barrow (LI022-260----) and the fifth possible barrow (LI022-262----) is located to the S.Earthwork barely visible on OSi aerial photographs taken 2005-2012, present remains consist of a low circular-shaped mound W of original watercourse of the Camoge River which can be seen closer to the possible barrows on OSi aerial photographs 2005-2012.  This possible barrow is not visible today on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-2013.See attached LiDAR plot showing location of 5 mounds, courtesy of Ella Motherway 2012, fig. 5.2, 77.Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Sarah McCutcheon and Ella MotherwayDate of upload: 30 April 2020

Situated on poorly drained, partially reclaimed rushy pasture, that was formerly the floodplain of the Camoge River.  This stream flows from N to S immediately to the E. In pasture, at the end of a low ridge and with a good view of two standing stones (SL044-057----; SL044-058----) c. 600m to SSE. A five-sided mound of earth and stone (7.3m N-S; 8.2m E-W; H 1-1.5m). The mound was probably originally circular and its present shape may be due to erosion. Its size and location suggest a barrow. The top of the mound is uneven and slopes down from W to E. It is partially overgrown with bushes.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In low-lying ground, between drumlins. Described in 1995 as a low circular platform (diam. 37.2m E-W) defined by a slight scarp (H 0.1m) and composed of soil similar to that of an embanked barrow (SL033-117----) c. 100m to E; the platform surface was uneven and had traces of cultivation ridges; a N-S field boundary cut across the E half of the barrow (pers. comm. M. Keane and J. Farrelly). During a subsequent inspection, low irregular undulations were visible but no definite outline of the barrow was visible at ground level.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

When inspected in 1994 the monument was described as follows: In an area of undulating fertile pasture on top of a slight natural rise.  The view from the site is excellent. An oval enclosure measuring in plan 10.5m NW-SE by 8m NE-SW is surrounded on all sides by an earthen bank with an indistinct outer edge.   It averages 2.5m wide at the base and is 0.4m high inside.  Externally, is rises to 1.65m at the NW but otherwise averages <0.5m. The interior slopes gently down to the E and is clear of excess growth. It is featureless.  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 19 August 2014

In rough poorly drained pasture. Indicated on the 1840 OS 6 inch map as a small circular shaped area (approx. ext. diam. 24m E-W) intersected at S by a field boundary running E-W.  Not marked on the OS 25 inch map, where the field boundary to W curves following the outline of the monument.  Monument barely visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 2019 which shows the site partially overgrown with trees.See attached Google Earth othoimage taken 19/11/2019Compiled by: Fiona RooneyDate of upload: 7 July 2020

In low-lying grassland approx. 40m W of the Mulkear River, that forms the townland boundary with Ballyvollane. The site is not indicated on the 1840 OS 6-inch map or any subsequent OS maps.   Identified in 1990 by Celie ORahilly as a possible ring-barrow when it was described as following; 'Located in the south-east corner of the area, on flat ground, is a possible Ring Barrow.  It consists of a trace of a circular feature defined by a very low bank, ca. 30m in diameter, in the centre of which is a depression.  This appears to have been recently infilled with clay' (O'Rahilly 1990). An Archaeological Assessment Report carried out by Aegis Archaeology Ltd. in 2009/10 recorded the following details about this monument; 'The fieldwork and survey carried out a part of this report has the found that the dot (on www.archaeology.ie) is slightly too far to the north.  The true location is marked by means of an arrow on figure 5.  The site is visible as a sub-circular platform approximately 30m in diameter, and 0.6m above the surrounding ground level.  The sides of the platform slope gently towards exterior ground level.  No trace of the bank mentioned in the O'Rahilly report was noted.  A depression was noted in the NE quadrant of the site, measuring 3m north-south by 2m east-west, 0.3m deep.  A possible ditch although very indistinct, was noted from S through E to NW, (in parts discernible as an area of greener vegetation than the surrounding land) averaging 3m wide and 0.2m deep, although the suggestion of the ditch at S has been augmented by tractor tracks.  the ditch could not be clearly defined at W, due to flattened long grass at this side' (Coyne 2009, 12-13).   Google Earth orthoimage taken 2018 indicates faint traces of a sub-circular shaped cropmark at this location. Compiled by Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload: 11 June 2020

Timoney (1984, 322-3, no. 7) describes this as follows: The total diameter of this barrow, sited on a glacial ridge, is 24m. The central area is 9m in diameter and is 80cm above the surrounding field. The central area is surrounded by a bank 2.90m wide and varies in height from 50cm to 75 cm. This is enclosed by a complete fosse, 2.60m wide, the bottom of which is 30cm below the surrounding field. The complete enclosing bank is 2.10m wide and 45cm high and it contains stones in its make-up. Burenhult (1980:1, 94) lists this as Structure 25, Knocknahur North, recte Breeoge. It is within Phosphate Field XIV Only very small increases of phosphate values were recorded (Burenhult 1980:1, 105).   Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 28 January 2014

In reclaimed pasture, possible (LI040-195002-) lies 8m to the SW. Circular area (int. diam. 12m) enclosed by a low bank (Wth 1.70m, H 0.20m) and an external ditch (Wth 2.50m, D 0.30m) (Timoney 1984, 323).  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Date of upload: 31 July 2013

Timoney (1984, 323, no. 8) describes this as follows: The total diameter of this barrow on flat ground is 20 m. The central area, which is at the same level as the surrounding field, is 8.40 m in diameter. There is a slight bank, 2.70 m wide and 10 cm high, on the edge of this area. There is a flat-bottomed fosse, 3.20 m wide and 20 cm deep. There is no evidence for an outer bank. Burenhult (1980:1, 97) lists this as Structure 70, Knocknahur North. It produced very low phosphate levels which argues against it being a hut site.  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 28 January 2014

Situated on a NE-SW ridge in rolling pasture with good views in all directions. Sub-oval shaped area (7.5m ENE-WSW; 7m NNW-ESE) defined by a scarp (Wth. 1.8m; H 0.3m) and enclosed by a fosse (Wth. 1.2m; D 0.1m).

Located 500m S of Cummeen Strand, the inner reaches of Sligo Bay, on an E-facing slope in undulating pasture, formerly part of the estate of Cummeen House.  A flat-topped, sheer-sided mound (17m N-S; 19m E-W; H 4m) of earth and stone construction. The mound is largely grass covered though in areas of slippage, detail of stone revetment can be seen. On the W side there is a broad V-shaped depression, forming a path to the top (measuring at the top 4m E-W; 2m N-S; D 1m). Timoney (1984, 324, no. 17) suggests that this and a nearby cairn (SL014-047003-) may be 'nineteenth century demesne monuments on the Ormsby demesne'.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 21 April 2011

In reclaimed pasture, 45m E of townland boundary with Tankardstown, a possible ditch-barrow (LI040-055003-) lies 170m to the SW. Not marked on OSi historic maps. In pasture within a large field, 50m S of the townland boundary with Ballingoola. The NE shore of Lough Gur lies 675m to S. It is visible on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12 and on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013 and appears to be a mound. A relic road (orientated N-S) visible on the OSi orthoimage taken 2005-12 is located 60m to W. The relic road appears to be part of an historic road (LI032-037----) that extends N along the E side of Lough Gur. The earthwork (ext. diam. c. 13m) was identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 140: AP 4/3641). The earthworks are visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 16/03/2016 and 28/06/2018.  OKelly (1942-3, 180) referred to a series of standing stones which marked the route of an ancient road which ran 'from Lough Gur Cross (LI032-061----) to the N barony boundary.See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 140 and Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Edmond ODonovanDate of upload:

Timoney (1984, 324, no. 14) describes this as follows: This oval bowl-barrow, sited on gently sloping ground, measures 17.25m northnorthwest/southsoutheast by 15m and it is 1.40m high. There is no evidence for a bank or fosse and the edges of the base of the barrow have been squared by ploughing. Though this monument lies on flat ground southwest of no. 27 [SL014-209049-] it is not marked on the Ordnance Survey maps nor has it been referred to by any writer prior to 1980. Burenhult (1980:1, 97) lists this as Barrow 1, Carrowmore. See also Kitchin (1983. 168, "unrecorded").  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 28 January 2014

Timoney (1984, 323-4, no. 13) describes this as follows: The total diameter of this badly mutilated barrow is 19.30 m. The central area is 13m in diameter. An irregular bank, varying in width between 2.50m and 4m and reaching 60cm in height surrounds an irregular depression, averaging 7m in diameter. There is a "U"-bottomed fosse, 3m in width and 60cm deep around the central area. On the west side of the  monument there is evidence of an enclosing bank for about 10m of the circuit. It averages 2.40m wide and is at most 50cm high. This monument lies on flat ground between nos 27, 48 and 51. It is marked on the current, 1940, Ordnance Survey map as "Stone Circle, site of" but not at all on the original, 1837, map. It has not been referred to by any previous writer. The map designation was probably due to its location among the Carrowmore tombs, many of which are marked as "Stone Circle" on the maps, rather than to any proper archaeological reasons. However classification is not possible due to its disturbed nature. Perhaps it was a ring-barrow but with only the short length of bank on the west side surviving or a bowl-barrow of the ditched variety. Burenhult (1980:1, 93) lists this as Structure 8, Carrowmore.  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 28 January 2014

In reclaimed grassland, with stream marking townland boundary with Srahane West immediately to E.  Outline of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 26m; ext. diam. 53m) defined by a scarp and wide fosse or moat (approx. Wth 13m) visible on Digital Globe orthophoto taken 2011-13 and earlier OSi orthoimages.  Outline of monument clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 05/04/2006.  On this image the fosse appears to be waterlogged with evidence of rushes in the wet fosse or moat.  The location on wet marshy land adjacent to a stream with wide waterlogged fosse suggests a prehistoric ritual site in the barrow or henge tradition rather than that of a medieval settlement or ringfort.  Cropmarks of old watercourse is visible to N of monument with channels feeding from old stream into fosse or moat of the monument which is clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 06/02/2018.See attached Google Earth orthophotos taken 05/04/2006, 25/03/2017 and 06/02/2018.  Compiled by: Caimin OBrienDate of upload: 3 June 2020

In reclaimed pasture 120m W of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Ballinvala. Earthwork (LI040-097----) lies 25m to SE.  Impressive trivallate earthwork (overall diam. c. 105m) depicted on 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a raised circular-shaped platform (diam. c. 25m) defined by a scarp with wide wet fosse (Wth c. 13m), bank visible from S-N-NE, with fosse, bank, fosse and external bank visible from NNE-S-NNW.Westropp (1917-19, 178) recorded this impressive trivallate monument as a ringfort which he described as follows; The fort is a large earthwork in a very marshy field which, before the great drains were dug, must have been a shallow lake in wet weather.  It has a low mote in the centre, girt by a ring of level field, fenced by a ring mound and two fosses and mounds, fairly concentric, and measuring 280 feet (85m) overall.  There seems to be traces of a causeway through the marsh to the east, but there are no entrance gaps on that side.  The fosses are as wide as the rings and are literally filled up with lush marsh vegetation, rushes, peppermint and such water-loving plants.  The interspace round the mound is from 42 feet (12.8m) to 45 feet (13.7m) wide.  The mote is from 6 feet to 7 feet (1.8m-2.1m) high, 60 feet to 62 feet (18.2m- 18.9m) across the summit, 87 feet (26.5m) to 90 feet (27.4m) in diameter at the base; it has no apparent house sites.  The southern gangway is 15 feet (4.5m) wide.  The monument is clearly visible as a raised circular shaped-area enclosed by three banks and two fosses on aerial photograph (ASIAP (304) 10) taken 13/09/2002.  Visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 14/09/2019 as a trivallate earthwork intersected at N by field bank running E-W with an agricultural yard immediately to N.   Classification of this impressive monument is uncertain, Westropp suggested that this earthwork was the remains of a trivallate ringfort, however the small central platform enclosed by a wide wet fosse is more akin to a burial site in the barrow tradition rather than a trivallate ringfort.  See attached aerial photograph (ASIAP (304) 10) and Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload: 15 June 2021

On low lying wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, on the floodplain of the Camoge River 265m to W, which forms a townland boundary with Ragamus. Ditch-barrow (LI032-241----) lies 130m to SE. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 224: AP 5/2015) as a roughly circular-shaped mound defined by what appears to be a wide fosse. Monument is visible as an oval-shaped earthwork (39m N-S; 35m E-W) defined by a possible fosse from W-NW-N, on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 20/09/2020. A wide fosse is highlighted by flooding where it is waterlogged from S-W-N-E-SE with an obvious causeway from SE-S, as seen on Google Earth orthoimage 20/03/2018. The width of the waterlogged fosse varies from 13m at E, to 16m at N and 20m at WSW. The central mound and wide fosse would suggest that this is a bowl-barrow.See attached Google Earth orthoimages taken 20/03/2018 and 20/09/20 and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 224Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 19 November 2020

In reclaimed pasture, 40m W of townland boundary with Rathanny. Cropmark of a possible earthwork (LI040-207001-) lies 50m to the SW. Identified as a circular cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 93.02; AP 5/2102). No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13. Linear cropmarks visible on aerial images, some perpendicular to each other, appear to represent drainage channels of land reclamation works.   See attached Bruff survey image showing cropmark labelled Bruff 93.02 and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 28 June 2021

One of a cluster of 6 barrows (LI014-162/164/155001/155002/156----) in wetland, located to the immediate SW of large barrow (LI014-155001-). Identified by Melanie McQuaid, archaeologist, Forestry Service Inspectorate, Dept .of Agriculture, Food and the Marine in 2016 during site inspection of forestry drains and removal of saplings.  The site was described as following; It measures c. 19m in diameter (north-south and c. 0.6m high. It is cut by three forest drains and at the time of inspection the only indicator of archaeological material evident in the drain face or the minds created from the excavated soil was a small charred black fragment of bone. McQuaid concludes that this monument is a geomorphic feature (McQuade 2016).  The possible monument is visible as a circular green-coloured area on the Digital Globe orthoimage and on Google Earth image taken in 2006 and 2017.  See attached Google earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 3 July 2020

One of a cluster of 6 barrows (LI014-162/163/155001/155002/156----) in wetland to the immediate N of large barrow (LI014-155001-). Identified by Melanie McQuaid, archaeologist, Forestry Service Inspectorate, Dept .of Agriculture, Food and the Marine in 2016 during site inspection of forestry drains and removal of saplings.  Site described as following; During the site inspection a raised area was evident here which seems to correspond with the c. 6m diameter feature indicated on the aerial photographs. No archaeological deposits or artefacts were noted at this location at the time of inspection. McQuaid concludes that this monument is a geomorphic feature (McQuade 2016).  Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and the Google Earth image taken in 2006 and 2017 shows a raised green in the location of the monument.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 3 July 2020

On poorly drained rushy pasture, 160m E of a townland boundary with Herbertstown (OGrady) and 200m NE of the village of Herbertstown, in the valley of the Camoge River which is 765m to W. An enclosure (LI032-200----) lies 75m to SE. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 292: AP 4/3607), as a cropmark of three conjoined barrows arranged contiguously on a N-S axis. Monument is clearly visible as a pair of conjoined barrows (LI032-199---) with the remains of a possible third barrow adjoining to S, on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 20/09/2020. The northern barrow is visible on these orthoimages as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 25m) defined by a fosse (Wth 8m) which is highlighted by a dense growth of rushes; the central barrow (LI032-199----) is visible as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork (diam. 30m) defined by a fosse (Wth 11m) which is also highlighted by a dense growth of rushes; the southern barrow is a circular-shaped platform (diam. 37m) defined by a scarp and the possible remains of a fosse which is visible from SW-W-N-NE. See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image labelled 292 Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 16 November 2020

Described by O'Kelly (1944, 22) as following; 'A circular platform surrounded by a fosse. Overall diameter 152' [46.3m], height 4' [1.2m]. The entrance is not recognisable. Centred on the E-W diameter and just inside the E. edge of the platform there is a ring-barrow [LI032-142003-]. This is a low mound surrounded by a fosse and has an overall diameter of 30' [9.1m]. Immediately to the S.E. of the platform is another barrow [LI032-142002-], similar in appearance, but having a diameter of 21' [6.4m]'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien   Date of upload: 09 August 2019  See attached ASI aerial photographs ASIAP - 348/6, 348/9, 348/10 taken on 05/01/2003.

One of 37 possible barrows (LI040-078002/035-/-037/039-) recorded within an area measuring 230m N-S x 300m E-W. Listed by the Discovery Programme as a potential barrow (Site No. 18) on examination of gas pipeline aerial images and Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff AP 2123). Cropmark of possible barrow visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13.   See attached aerial photograph (Site No. 18) and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 3 June 2021

In reclaimed pasture, N of the Camogue River and W of a stream flowing into the river. Earthwork (LI020-025----) immediately to S. In forestry, 75m NW of the Ballynamona River and 400m SW of a townland boundary with Portboy. Ring-barrow (LI032-097002-) lies 60m to NE and barrow (LI032-098----) lies 60m to SE. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a ring-barrow and recorded as Ballynamona (Hospital) 2 by Grogan (1989, 218). The area has been planted with forestry and monument is not visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-2012, or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013, or on Google Earth orthoimages taken 05/04/2006.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 6 November 2020

Earthwork complex described in 1943 as following; 'Complex of 2 Earthworks of Type A and 3 Ring-barrows.  No. I. This is the larger of the Type A structures and consists of a low circular platform surrounded by a fosse. Outside this there was a bank which now remains on the east side of the monument for about one-third of its circuit. The maximum height of the platform over field level is 3' [0.9m] and the monument had an original overall diameter of 200' [61m] approximately' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 172).   Outline of monument visible today on Digital Globe aerial photograph.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 24 February 2020

In forestry, 100m NW of the Ballynamona River and 325m SW of a townland boundary with Portboy. Ring-barrow (LI032-097001-) lies 60m to SW and barrow (LI032-098----) lies 50m to S. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a ring-barrow and recorded as Ballynamona (Hospital) 3 by Grogan (1989, 218). Area of monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped, unplanted forestry exclusion zone (overall diam. 30m) on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-2012, on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 05/04/2006.See attached Google Earth orthoimage.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 6 November 2020

Mound-barrow described in 1943 as following; This monument consists of a, circular mound which does not seem to have had a fosse (Fig. 11). There is no bank either on the platform or ground the mound. The maximum height of the platform is 7' [2m] and the overall diameter is 120' [36.5m]. It is situate on the bank of the  Ballynamona River and during drainage operations on this, part of the mound on the south side has been cut away. The land around it is marshy. The barrow is in the north-east quadrant of the platform. It consists of very low mound surrounded by a fosse. Its overall diameter is 30' [9m]' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 178-9).  See attached profile of monument taken from O'Kelly 1942-3, Fig. 11   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 26 February 2020

In gently undulating pasture. Subcircular area (13.5m N-S), truncated on E side (now 8m E-W), defined by scarped edge (Wth 1.25m; H 0.4m) SE to NE, with external fosse (basal Wth 2m; total Wth 9.8m; D 0.95m) W-N. Fosse opens out into a water-filled depression at WNW where there is a natural spring.   Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 15 November 2013

In undulating pasture, on top of a hill at the break of slope. Indicated on the 1914 OS 6-inch map as a mound. The remains consist of a low roughly circular ill-defined rise (diam. c. 12m) into which a semicircular quarry pit (diam. 7m; D 1.4m) has been dug. A low rim (Wth c. 2m; H 0.55m) on the perimeter of the quarry NW-N may be the result of upcast material. The size and location of this monument suggest a barrow.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, Cloheen Church and Graveyard (LI040-115001/002-) lie 260m to the W. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified as a circular feature on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000 2569) taken 03/11/1984. No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached BGE aerial photograph (040272) and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 21 June 2021

In pasture, on an upland terrace on the lower NE-facing slopes of Kesh Corann Hill. A large mound (20m N-S; 16m E-W), the centre of which has been quarried leaving a rim (H 3m) around a central irregular hollow (diam. 10m). A break at E gives access to the grassed-over quarry pit. The mound appears to be primarily earthen in composition but incorporates some stone. A slight depression NE-SE may indicate a silted-up fosse (Wth 4m). At E, a low berm-like feature between the fosse and the mound may be due to the disturbance of the mound as it is located in the area of the access gap into the quarry pit. A field boundary skirts the base of the mound at W. A circular enclosure (SL040-003002-) lies 2m to N and a rath (SL040-004----) c. 40m to S.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).  Attached images: SL040-003001-_01.JPG Barrow (at R) viewed from W, with enclosure (SL040-003002-) beside it (at L)  Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Enclosure and ring-barrows (LI032-149002-/003-/004-) described in 1942-3 as following; 'This is a circular earthen platform surrounded by two banks and two fosses. The entrance is not recognisable. The maximum height of the platform over the fosse-bottom is 5' [1.5m] and the overall diameter is 306' [93m]. A fence and drainage trench have cut through the west side of the defences and another trench has cut through them on the south. Situated in wet low-land.  In the field immediately to the N.E. of this there were at least three ring-barrows, one of which now remains. This consists of a very slight mound surrounded by a fosse. The overall diameter is 18' [6m]. The field is a meadow and the other barrows were levelled to facilitate the operation of machinery therein. Nothing was found when they were cleared away' (O'Kelly 1942-3, 237).  Upstanding monument clearly visible on oblique aerial photograph taken 20/07/1968 (CUCAP AVT024).  Cropmark of enclosure visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.  No cropmark visible today of levelled barrows in field to NE of enclosure.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 4 March 2020

On a prominent hill in grassland, c. 500m SW of Cappataggle village. In wet pasture, immediately S of watercourse that forms townland boundary with Hammondstown. Rectangular-shaped earthwork (LI040-133----) now in forestry to S.  Depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map as a circular shaped platform defined by a scarp with fosse transected at NNW by stream. Shown on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a raised circular shaped area (diam. c. 27m) defined by a scarp, with fosse truncated at NW by a watercourse running NE-SW. Monument visible on aerial photograph (BGE 1/5000 2571) taken 03/11/1984 on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline. Poorly preserved monument visible as depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map on the Digital Globe orthoimage. No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimage.See attached gas pipeline aerial image and Google Earth orthoimages.
