In improved wet pasture, cut by land drains and watercourses, 32m NW of a townland boundary with Oldtown. One of a complex of five monuments aligned roughly NE-SW along the townland boundary, over an approximate distance of 165m and consisting of a standing stone (LI032-160001-), three ring-barrows (LI032-160002-/03-/04-) and an enclosure (LI032-160005-). Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument identified as a small, circular-shaped cropmark by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 275: AP 5/2047).  Monument is not visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-2012 or on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013 or on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff aerial survey image (third northern most monument).Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 9 November 2020

On a W-facing slope in undulating farmland. A well-preserved circular barrow (D 15.3m) consisting of a flat-topped mound (D 6.6m, H 0.7m), with a slight depression at centre, which is encircled by a fosse and bank. A gap in the bank at E could be original. An old field wall, running E-W, cuts the monument at SSE and SSW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In pasture, on top of a low ridge with excellent views in all directions. The barrow was densely covered with overgrowth and waterlogged when inspected. The remains consist of a slightly curved section of earthen bank (L 11m; H 1.5m; Wth 1.9m at top, 4m at base; long axis WSW-ENE). A possible fosse (Wth 6m at top; D 0.7m) is parallel to the bank on the N side. To the S of the bank is a circular hollow (diam. 12m; D 0.6m), probably due to recent quarrying. During a previous site inspection in 1987, the remains of field boundaries projecting at right angles from the ends of the bank were noted (SMR (1989) file). A trigonometrical station was indicated here on the 1838 OS 6-inch map. There is a rath (SL034-004----) c. 50m to N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Within NE-quadrant of embanked enclosure (LI023-058----), abutting inside of scarped edge at NNE. Circular area (dims. 3m N-S; 4m E-W) defined by scarped edge (Wth 1m; H 0.1-0.15m) with an external fosse (Wth 3.45m; D 0.1m) and a counter-scarp bank (Wth 6.9m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.3m).  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 18 November 2013

On flat undulating pasture. The site is located 460m E of the townland boundary with Wonderhill, 150m NW of a ringfort (LI023-102----) and c. 300m S of a ring-barrow cemetery (LI023-226001-/009-). The barrow is not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 158; AP 4/3665) as an oval feature (ext. diam. c. 15m). It appears to have been levelled as there are no surface remains visible on the most recent Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Bruff survey image showing ring-barrow labelled Bruff 158 and Google Earth orthoimage  Compiled by: Edmond ODonovan  Date of upload:  31 August 2020

In reclaimed pasture, 87m W of a stream that marks townland boundary with Boherroe and 174m E of stream that marks townland boundary with Ballyphilip. Ring-barrow (LI024-179003-) lies 27m to S and linear earthworks (LI024-179002-) lie 80m to SE. Not depicted on OS historical mapping. Identified by the Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 23(01); AP 4/3665) as a small circular cropmark of a possible ring-barrow. Cropmark of a roughly circular shaped feature is visible on OSi orthophoto taken 2005-2012. Possibly the outline of a small pond or quarry feature rather than a prehistoric ring-barrow.  Faint trace of feature visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/07/2017.  On this map a series of linear features run out to E from n side of feature.  These may be the remains of field drainage channels feeding in to an old watercourse running N-S in E side of field.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/05/2017 and Bruff survey image marked 23(01).  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 27 July 2020

Barrow described in 1942-3 as following; 'This consists of a circular platform surrounded by a fosse. Outside the fosse is a slight bank which is broken in four places. These breaks seem to have been caused by the making of drains in the field. But in spite of the drains the fosse remains water-logged. The platform has a height of 1' [0.3m] over the field level and the overall diameter is 204' [62m]. It is in low-lying marshy ground. In the north-west quadrant of the platform is a very well made ring-barrow. This consists of a slight mound around which there is a fosse which is well defined. Outside this there is a very slight continuous bank. The overall diameter is 36' [11m] (O'Kelly 1942-3, 239).  Outline of barrow clearly visible today on Digital Globe aerial photographs.Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 6 March 2020See attached ASI aerial photographs ASIAP - 369/2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 on 10/05/2003.

In wet unimproved pasture, 10m W of a stream. A ring-barrow (LI024-214----) lies 150m to NW. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OS 25-inch map as a roughly circular-shaped platform defined by a scarp.  Surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as a raised roughly circular-shaped area (dims. 26m NNE-SSW; 24m ESE-WNW) defined by a scarp and outer fosse (base Wth 9.5m; D 0.75m) from E-NW.  The raised interior (max. H. 2.65m) has a possible ring-barrow in S quadrant.  The monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork surrounded by a ditch overgrown with rushes on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimages.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload: 3 April 2021

Modern coniferous forestry plantation located in area where possible burial mound is marked on OS 6-inch map.  Unable to locate presence of burial mound inside forestry plantation where monument is marked on the OS 6-inch map.  Monument described in 1972 as a small artificial mound (not shown on the map) about 3 ft [0.9m] high x 10 paces overall (roughly circular) diameter. It looks like a burial mound of some kind. It is grass-covered and not apparently stony. It lies approximately 123 paces N.E. of a boulder marked Gallaun [TN025-030----] on the 25 inch map, but not shown on the current 6 inch map (SMR File 12/06/1972).  This monument was placed on the Register of Historic Monuments in 1975.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 8 April 2015

In level pasture  on the demense lands of Killeenavera House located 150m to W and 335m NE of a townland boundary with Boherroe. Possible ringfort (LI024-034----) lies 50m to SW. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OS 25-inch map as a small circular-shaped platform (diam. 17m) approx. 5m NW of a small pond. Monument described by ODwyer (1964, 98), as a platform (diam. 45ft/13.7m; H 4ft/1.2m). Earthwork surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a slightly raised circular mound (diam. 12m) enclosed by mature trees. According to local information, this was a pond that was backfilled for safety approx. 30 years ago and the level of the ground was raised and deciduous trees planted around the perimeter. It is possible that this may have been a form of barrow prior to backfilling. Monument is visible as a tree-planted area on OSi orthimage taken 2005-2012, Digital Globe orthoimage taken 2011-2013 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.See attached profile drawn by ODwyer in 1964 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly Date of upload: 28 September 2020

Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 12 October 2021

In improved pasture, 90m NE of the townland boundary with Cromwell.  Possible unclassified barrow (LI033-125----) lies 30m to SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 93.01; AP 4/5024) as a ring-barrow. Faint trace visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam. c. 7.5m) on OSi orthophotos taken between 2005-12.  Not visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 93.01.  Compiled by:  Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 18 April 2021

In improved pasture, 70m N of the townland boundary with Cromwell.  Possible barrow (LI033-124----) lies 30m to NW. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 93.02; AP 4/5024) as a ring-barrow. Visible as a circular- shaped cropmark on OSi orthophotos taken between 2005-2012.  Not visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 93.02.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  18 April 2021

In wet pasture 140m SE of a watercourse.  Cairn (LI049-213----) lies 140m to NW. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as Ballyfroota 4 by Grogan (1989, 215).  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimage. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 17 October 2021

In improved, wet, pasture 80m S of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Newtown.  Barrow (LI049-213----) lies 135m to SW and possible barrow (LI049-215----) 115m to SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as Ballyfroota 2 by Grogan (1989, 215).  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 17 October 2021

In marshy pasture at S end of townland. One of three additional barrows identified by the Discovery Programme (No. 12) that formed part of a barrow cemetery that includes 13 ring-barrows (LI033-029001-/017-) concentrated in three fields.  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 or on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Discovery Programme aerial photograph with barrow labelled 12   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 30 March 2021

In wet pasture 25m E of a stream. Earthwork (LI049-042----) lies 110m to the SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as Raheen 9 by Grogan (1989, 245). No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 12 October 2021

In reclaimed pasture, 15m S of a stream that marks the townland boundary with Raheen. Moated site (LI049-039----) lies 75m to the SW. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as Newtown 1 by Grogan (1989, 244). No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 11 October 2021

In reclaimed pasture.  Cropmark of circular-shaped area (diam. c. 26m) defined by a fosse and possible outer bank (overall diam. c. 48m N-S) bisected by field drain visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached Google Earth orthophotos
column13: Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 29 October 2021

column10: Situated on an E-facing slope of rising ground in an upland area with nearby barrow cemetery (TN031-024/025/023) to NW. A sunken area (diam. 6.5m N-S; D 1m) with traces of a possible enclosing bank. This may be the quarried-out remains of a barrow.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In pasture, on the demesne lands associated with Ryves Casle (LI041-021----), located 300m to NW. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Monument visible as a  raised roughly circular-shaped area (diam. c. 12m) on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages. Outline of earthwork clearly visible on aerial photograph (ASIAP 342, 10). See attached Google Earth orthoimage and ASIAP aerial image. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 4 August 2021 See attached ASI aerial photographs ASIAP  342/12 on 05/01/2003.

In wet pasture, 25m N of a stream that marks the townland boundary with Newtown. Earthwork (LI049-248----) lies 150m to the S. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as Raheen 10 by Grogan (1989, 245). No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 11 October 2021

In wet pasture 125m W of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Knockderk. Within field system (LI033-074001-) with fulacht fia (LI033-031----) 155m to NW.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 61; AP 4/3616) as a circular-shaped cropmark. Visible as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophotos taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 29 March 2021

In wet pasture, 120m E of the Morningstar River that marks the townland boundary with Knockaunavlyman. Barrow (LI049-236001--) lies 30m to the NW and barrow (LI049-236002-) 12m to NW. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible  barrow listed as Newtown 6 by Grogan (1989, 244).   No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 12 October 2021

In reclaimed pasture 160m N of the townland boundary with Killeenagallive.  Depicted on OSi 25-inch map as a sub-circular-shaped platform (dims. 32m NE-SW, 34m NW-SE) defined by a scarp and ditch from SE-S-NE, truncated at NE by a post-1700 field boundary running NW-SE.  Depicted as circular-shaped earthwork on 1838 ed. OSi 6-inch map . Surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as a circular-shaped area (diam. 22m) defined by a scarp (Wth 2.2m; H 0.7m) with external fosse (Wth 6.8m; D 0.5m) best preserved from ESE-WSW.   A deep drainage ditch intersects the E side of the monument.  Surrounding land drains are visible on OSi orthophotos 2005-2012.  Outline of monument clearly visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 28/06/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 22 March 2021

Situated in poorly drained pasture with good views in all directions. Identified from aerial photography (Bruff Survey Map 15, no 18; 4/3731) as a possible ring barrow. No trace of the monument was evident when the site was inspected.  Compiled by: Denis Power  Date of upload: 23 October 2013

In reclaimed pasture 115m SW of townland boundary with Knockderk.  Earthwork (LI033-150) lies 60m to E.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Hugh Carey from examination of Bing aerial photographs in 2015 as a possible barrow. Visible as a circular-shaped depression (diam. 12m) enclosed by a bank from NW-S and a scarp elsewhere on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12.  The monument is visible as a circular cropmark  on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.    See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload:  22 April 2021

In pasture, 65m W of townland boundary with Duntryleague. Possible barrows  (LI049-048004-; LI049-52----) lie 105m to the NW and 40m to the N, respectively. Not marked on OSi 6-inch maps. Barrow identified as a circular cropmark on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000 2582; No. 219) taken 03/11/1984. No surface trace visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached BGE aerial photographs and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 21 September 2021

In reclaimed pasture 60m N of the R663 roadway.  Possible barrow (LI049-220----) lies 85m to SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as Duntryleague 11 by Grogan (1989, 227).  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 13 October 2021

In improved pasture 35m N of ditch-barrow (LI033-126----) and 6m NW of possible barrow (LI033-128----). Not depicted on historic OSi maps. In improved pasture 30m N of a ditch-barrow (LI033-126----) and 6m SE of a possible barrow (LI033-128---). Not depicted on historic OSi maps. On top of a very slight rise in gently undulating low-lying pasture c. 2m to the NE of another barrow (TS065-063007-) with other barrows in the vicinity. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but identified during field survey (Martin Doody) and appears to be visible as a circular area (diam. c. 8m) on an aerial photograph (Bruff No. 5/2041). No visible surface trace at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 15 September 2014

On top of a very slight rise in gently undulating low-lying pasture c. 2m to the NE of another barrow (TS065-063007-) with other barrows in the vicinity. On top of a very slight rise in gently undulating low-lying pasture appearing to truncate the N side of an enclosure (TS065-063005-) and 2m to the SW of another barrow (TS065-063003-) with other barrows in the vicinity. In reclaimed pasture 225m E of the townland boundary with Duntryleague.  Earthwork (LI049-067----) lies 190m to S.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified as a circular feature during examination of aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000, 78) taken 03/11/1984 on the Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline. Monument is visible as a raised circular-shaped area  (diam. c. 27m) defined by a fosse on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018 where it is truncated at N by field boundary running E-W.  Visible as a circular cropmark on Google Earth orthoimage dated 21/06/2021.  See attached Bórd Gáis Éireann aerial photo and Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 7 October 2021

In pasture, on top of a ridge. A circular area (int. diam. 10m) enclosed by a low earthen bank (Wth 1.5m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 0.5m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Possible site of unclassified barrow identified in field to the W of gas pipeline (Gowen 1988, 73).  No surface remains visible on OSi orthoimages or Google Earth orthophotos.See attached gas pipeline location showing possible barrow identified with open triangle to the W of gas pipeline and Google Earth orthoimages.Compiled by: Fiona Rooney Date of upload: 3 November 2021

In wet pasture immediately S of a watercourse and 210m S of the townland boundary with Ballynamona. Moated site (LI049-066----) lies 100m to W. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible barrow listed as Duntryleague 16 by Grogan (1989, 227).  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick Date of upload: 13 October 2021

In level farmland. Circular enclosure (D c. 40m), in fair condition, defined by a central platform, an internal fosse, intervening bank and external fosse. A gap (Wth 4m) at NNE may be original. Possible traces of an inner bank are visible at NNE, though this may simply be due to the slightly dished profile of the central platform.   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Galway Vol. II - North Galway'. Compiled by Olive Alcock, Kathy de hÓra and Paul Gosling (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999).   Date of upload: 05 August 2010

In gently undulating improved pasture with other barrows (TS065-059----, TS065-060---- and TS065-068001-) nearby to the N and NE. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible in an aerial photograph (Bruff 44, 5/2041) as a circular area (diam. c. 8m). No visible surface trace at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 16 September 2014

In gently undulating improved pasture with other barrows (TS065-059----, TS065-060---- and TS065-068002-) nearby to the N and SW. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible in an aerial photograph (Bruff 44, 5/2041) as a circular area (diam. c. 8m). No visible surface trace at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 16 September 2014

In gently undulating improved pasture with other barrows (TS065-060----, TS065-068001- and TS065-068002-) nearby to the S and SE. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible in an aerial photograph (Bruff No. 5/2041) as a circular area (diam. c. 8m). No visible surface trace at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In pasture on the demesne lands of Derk House, located 560m to N. One of a cluster of 14 barrows (LI033-036001-/009-; LI033-090/091-; LI033-121/122----; LI033-154----) concentrated in the S half of Derk townland with the closest barrow (LI033-036008-) 175m to W. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 75; AP 4/3626) as a ring-barrow.  Faint traces of circular-shaped cropmark (diam. c. 10m) visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 75  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 12 April 2021

On level ground in gently undulating improved pasture at base of slight N-facing slope. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible as a circular area (diam. c. 8m) on an aerial photograph (Bruff 46, 5/2040).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 16 September 2014

In gently undulating improved pasture with other barrows (TS065-059----, TS065-068001- and TS065-068002-) nearby to the NW and SW. In pasture on the demesne lands of Derk House, located 420m to NW.  Possible barrow (LI033-191001-) lies 200m to SW.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 80; AP 4/3626) as a ring-barrow.  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 or on Google Earth orthoimage dated 20/09/2020.  Doubtful antiquity.    See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 80  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 12 April 2021

Marked on the 1837 ed. of the OS 6-inch map as a circular feature (diam. c. 20m) and situated on the crest of a NW-SE ridge. Grass-covered and round-topped earthen mound which has a sub-rectangular base (dims 11.2m N-S; 11m E-W; H 1.6m at N to 2.4m at S) where some old field banks have been removed. The base of the mound is overlain by a N-S field bank at E.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In gently undulating low-lying wet pasture with a ring-barrow (TS065-065002-) located c. 70m to the S. Identified during field survey by Martin Doody but not now visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 16 September 2014

In gently undulating low-lying wet pasture with a ring-barrow (TS065-065001-) located c. 70m to the N. Identified during field survey by Martin Doody but not now visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 16 September 2014

Marked only on the 1914 ed. of the OS 6-inch map as a trig. station described in gothic lettering as 'Caraun', and situated on a low E-W ridge. Subcircular grass-covered and rounded mound (dims 7.5m N-S; 6.5m E-W; H 1.05m at W to 1.65m at N).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture,  one of fourteen barrows (LI041-032001/013-). Enclosure (LI041-031----) lies 150m to the W and a barrow cemetery (LI049-072001/026-) lies immediately to SSW. Not marked on OSi historic maps. Identified in 1936 during a survey of the area undertaken by Ó Ríordáin (1936, 175). No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached plan of survey from Ó Ríordáin (1936).  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 15 July 2021

In reclaimed pasture. One of 11 barrows (LI049-072017-/026-/33-) in the SW corner of Lissard townland that makes up a barrow cemetery concentrated in an area measuring 240m N-S x 230m E-W. Barrow cemetery (LI049-072010/015-) is located in field to W and barrow cemetery (LI041-032001/014-) in field to N. Not marked on historic OSi maps. In 1934 Ó Ríordáin (1936, 173) recorded numerous barrows in the townland of Lissard which he described as very low earthen mounds surrounded by a slight ditch and sometimes showing also the remains of an outer bank. The rise to the centre was in all cases very slight and the monuments were such that that one might easily walk over them without noticing them. The slightly sunken circular ring which marked the position of the ditch was the most distinctive feature and was frequently to be noticed by reason of its wetness as compared with the surrounding ground, this causing the vegetation in it to be fresher and greener. Barrow (LI049-072033-), located 65m to NW, is the only barrow in this cemetery excavated in 1935 by S. P. Ó Ríordáin (1936, 173-175). No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13. Faint trace of circular shaped cropmark (diam. 4m) on Google Earth orthoimage dated 14/09/2019.   See attached location map taken from Ó Ríordáin and Google Earth orthoimages   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 5 October 2021

In wet, level pasture, with excellent views of Knockseefin to WNW and 45m NW of a townland boundary with Ballyhurst.  A cluster of six possible barrows (LI024-049002-/007-), with enclosure (LI024-049001-) in centre of field. Not depicted on OSi historic maps.   No surface remains visible.  See attached Bruff aerial photo taken in 1986 numbered 90.1 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 30 September 2020

In wet, level pasture, with excellent views of Knockseefin to WNW and 45m NW of a townland boundary with Ballyhurst.  A cluster of six possible barrows (LI024-049002-/007-), with enclosure (LI024-049001-) in centre of field.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 90.04; AP 4/3678) as a ring-barrow.  No surface remains visible on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 or on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached photocopy of Bruff aerial photograph labelled 90.04 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 6 April 2021

In wet, level pasture, with excellent views of Knockseefin to WNW and 45m NW of a townland boundary with Ballyhurst.  A cluster of six possible barrows (LI024-049002-/007-), with enclosure (LI024-049001-) in centre of field.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 90.05; AP 4/3678) as a ring-barrow. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a circular-shaped area (dims. 5.0m N-S; 4.75m E-W) to W and a subcircular-shaped area (dims. 3.2m N-S; 2.85m E-W) to E which are conjoined by a fosse (Wth 2.55m; D 0.1-0.3m). The outer bank (Wth 2.5m; int. H 0.15m; ext. H 0.05m) is best defined from NE-E-S-SW and is reduced to a low profile bank (Wth 3.05m; int. H 0.05m; ext. H 0.05m) from SW-W-N-NE. Monument appears to be cut into the remains of an outer bank of enclosure (LI024-049001-).  Monument is visible as a faint oblong-shaped cropmark (dims. 15m WNW-ESE; 7.5m NNE-SSW) on Google Earth orthoimage taken 25/05/2017.  See attached photocopy of Bruff aerial photograph labelled 90.05 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick and Alison McQueen  Date of upload: 6 April 2021

In reclaimed pasture, 95m N of townland boundary with Ballynamona. One of 11 barrows (LI049-072017-/026-/33-) in the SW corner of Lissard townland that makes up a barrow cemetery concentrated in an area measuring 240m N-S x 230m E-W. Barrow cemetery (LI049-072010/015-) located in field to W and barrow cemetery (LI041-032001/014-) in field to N. Not marked on historic OSi maps. In 1934 Ó Ríordáin (1936, 173) recorded numerous barrows in the townland of Lissard which he described as very low earthen mounds surrounded by a slight ditch and sometimes showing also the remains of an outer bank. The rise to the centre was in all cases very slight and the monuments were such that that one might easily walk over them without noticing them. The slightly sunken circular ring which marked the position of the ditch was the most distinctive feature and was frequently to be noticed by reason of its wetness as compared with the surrounding ground, this causing the vegetation in it to be fresher and greener.  Barrow (LI049-072033-), located 140m to NW, is the only barrow in this cemetery excavated in 1935 by S. P. Ó Ríordáin (1936, 173-175). No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached location map taken from Ó Ríordáin and Google Earth orthoimage   Compiled by: Fiona Rooney   Date of upload: 5 October 2021

In wet, level pasture, with excellent views of Knockseefin to WNW and 45m NW of a townland boundary with Ballyhurst.  A cluster of six possible barrows (LI024-049002-/007-), with enclosure (LI024-049001-) in centre of field.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 90.06; AP 4/3678) as a ring-barrow. In wet, level pasture, with excellent views of Knockseefin to WNW and 45m NW of a townland boundary with Ballyhurst. In improved pasture 140m N of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Cloghilawarreela. Possible barrow (LI033-129----) lies 17m to SW and enclosure (LI033-104----) 85m to NE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 99.02; AP 4/3618) as a ring-barrow. Visible as a circular cropmark truncated at N by a field drain running E-W on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 99.02.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 18 April 2021

In pasture, on high ground overlooking Ballinafad Bay in Lough Arrow. Indicated on the 1914 OS 6-inch map as a circular mound (diam. c. 10m). There are no visible remains of this mound. Its size and location, however, suggest a barrow. A boathouse has been built on the site.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

On N edge of the interior of an enclosure (TS066-090001-) that is located on a slight N-facing slope in pasture. Identified on aerial photograph (Air Corps V. 263/102-3. 2-9-1959; Bruff 43). A second enclosure (TS066-090002-) is located immediately to the E. Roughly circular area (diam. c. 5m) defined by a low poorly defined earthen scarped edge (Wth c. 2m; H 0.05m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

In improved pasture, on a very gradual S-facing slope. A ring-barrow (TS066-075005-) is located within the NW sector. A sub-circular area (dims. 18m N-S; 20m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 2-2.75m; H 0.15-0.25m) N-ESE, SE-W and on the straight side (L 16m) to the WNW with a possible fosse (Wth 4.1m; D 0.12m) along the WNW side which may be a result of drainage activity, and a very broad fosse in the NE quadrant which may be a result of natural water activity. The interior has a S-facing slope and is slightly uneven.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In level pasture with a ditch-barrow (TS066-090004-) located c. 50m to the NNW. Identified on aerial photograph (Bruff Survey aerial photo 5/2090). Circular slightly hollow area (diam. 9m) defined by a gently sloping earthen scarped edge (Wth 2m; D 0.1m) with traces of a slightly raised central circular area (diam. 3m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

In reclaimed pasture 100m W of watercourse and 260m S of Ballyneety House. One of three monuments aligned on a NW-SE axis. Enclosure (LI033-039002-) to immediate NE and ringfort (LI033-039001-) 50m to NE.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 98; AP 4/3618) as an enclosure. Visible as a raised circular-shaped area (diam. c. 25m) enclosed by a fosse, truncated at N by a field boundary running NE-SW on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 28/06/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage and Bruff image   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 13 April 2021

In pasture on the S slope of Duntryleague Hill, the summit (922 ft., 281m) of which  lies 540m to NE.  A megalithic tomb (LI049-077----) and two cairns (LI049-076/78----) are located at the summit of Duntryleague with enclosure (LI049-256---) 140m to E.  Not depicted on OSi historic maps.  Identified by W. Forbes in 1986 as a possible ring-barrow cemetery located on S slope of Duntryleague Hill.  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached location map and Google Earth orthoimages.  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  5 October 2021

In pasture, 350m E of townland boundary with Ballylanders, 120m S of  Coolcormick House and 20m S of a local road. Earthwork (LI049-172----) lies 165m to the SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified as a possible barrow on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2609, No. 372) taken 03/11/1984.  No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13 or on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload:  8 October 2021

In improved pasture 200m W of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Knockaundoolis. One of eight possible barrows (LI033-115001/008-) concentrated in a large field (125m N-S; 175m E-W) in the W of the townland. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 122.02; AP 5/2028) as a ring-barrow.  Visible as a circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12.  Not visible on Google Earth orthoimages.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 122.02  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 15 April 2021

In improved pasture immediately N of a farm track. One of eight possible barrows (LI033-115001/008-) concentrated in a large field (dims. 125m N-S; 175m E-W) in the W of the townland. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 122.01; AP 5/2028) as a ring-barrow. In improved pasture 190m W of townland boundary with Garrydoolis. One of eight possible barrows (LI033-115001/008-) concentrated in a large field (125m N-S; 175m E-W) in the W of the townland. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 122.03; AP 5/2028) as a ring-barrow. In improved pasture 190m W of townland boundary with Garrydoolis. One of eight possible barrows (LI033-115001/008-) concentrated in a large field (125m N-S; 175m E-W) in the W of the townland. In improved pasture 145m W of townland boundary with Garrydoolis. One of eight possible barrows (LI033-115001/008-) concentrated in a large field (125m N-S; 175m E-W) in the W of the townland. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 122.04; AP 5/2028) as a ring-barrow.  Visible as a circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12  and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  A relict field boundary running N-S to immediate E and field drains running E-W to immediate S.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 122.05  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 15 April 2021

In improved pasture 105m W of townland boundary with Garrydoolis. One of eight possible barrows (LI033-115001/008-) concentrated in a large field (125m N-S; 175m E-W) in the W of the townland. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 122.04; AP 6/2028) as a ring-barrow. In improved pasture 30m W of townland boundary with Garrydoolis. One of eight possible barrows (LI033-115001/008-) concentrated in a large field (125m N-S; 175m E-W) in the W of the townland. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 122.04; AP 8/2028) as a ring-barrow. In reclaimed rough pasture, c. 140m ENE of the Mulkear River. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Identified by Frank Coyne during test trenching under licence No. 98E0196 in 1998. Impressive remains of a large barrow (overall dims. 85m N-S x 50m E-W) consisting of a low circular-shaped mound (dims. 10m N-S x 8m E-W; H 0.5m) intersected at E by a townland boundary of Gortnagarde running N-S with internal waterlogged fosse and external bank with possible entrance gap at S. Timber settings were encountered in the fosse, from where a blue glass bead of Iron Age date was recovered. A worked flint flake was recovered from the surface of the central mound area.   Monument preserved in situ.See attached plan of monument taken from excavation reportCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 10 July 2020

In improved pasture 120m E of townland boundary with Garrydoolis. One of two barrows (LI033-114001/002-) aligned E-W.  barrow (LI033-114002-) lies to immediate E. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 123.01; AP 5/2028) as a ring-barrow.  Visible as a circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12.  Visible as a shallow depression on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 123.01  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 15 April 2021

In improved pasture 120m E of townland boundary with Garrydoolis. One of two barrows (LI033-114001/002-) aligned E-W.  Ring-barrow (LI033-114001-) lies to immediate W. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 123.02; AP 5/2028) as a ring-barrow.  Visible as a circular-shaped cropmark on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12.  Visible as a shallow depression on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and Bruff image showing monument labelled Bruff 123.02  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 15 April 2021

Situated on flat pasture in an upland area. A poorly preserved, low, circular, flat-topped mound (H 0.5m max.; diam. 14m NW-SE) with a slight central depression and traces of a shallow external fosse.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

In flat pasture 130m E of the townland boundary with Ballyshoneen. Ring-barrow 40m ESE of an enclosure (LI024-234----) and 60m SSE of a ring-barrow (LI024-232----). The monument is not depicted on historic OSi maps, nor is it visible on OSi orthoimages taken 2005-12 nor on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-2013. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 91; AP 4/3672) as a circular ring-barrow. The ring-barrow is not visible on the Google Earth orthoimages taken 18/11/2018. See attached Bruff survey image showing the site labelled Bruff 91 and Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by:  Edmond ODonovanDate of upload: 17 September 2020

In undulating rocky pasture, on a slight SW-facing slope c. 30m SW of a ring-barrow (SL034-207001-). A roughly circular raised area (diam. 4.6m) defined by an earth and stone bank (ext. H 0.4m) NNE-W and by a scarp elsewhere. Possible stone kerbing was noted along the external base of the bank NNE-E. The ground falls away sharply 4m to SW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In wet pasture, 160m W of townland boundary with Knockaunnacurraha. Possible barrow (LI049-246----) lies 40m to the SE and possible barrow (LI049-239----) 100m to SE. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Possible monument listed as Spittle 1 and identified as a ring-barrow by Grogan (1989, 249).  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages.   See attached Google Earth orthoimages.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 8 October 2021

On elevated area of a gentle S-facing slope, in undulating pasture, with good views of Knockseefin/Pallashill to WNW (O'Dwyer 1964, 96). Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as a raised circular-shaped area (8m N-S; 7.25m E-W) enclosed by a bank (int. H 0.16m; ext. H 0.25m; Wth 3.55m) only visible from E-S-W-NW, elsewhere reduced to a scarp (H 0.4m; Wth 1.25m).  A wide earthen field boundary running E-W (resembling a trackway), and a field drain are visible to the immediate S. Ring-barrow (LI024-053002-) and possible barrow (LI024-053003-) lie c. 50m to SW and E respectively. A high concentration of barrows are located within a 300m radius of this monument.  Monument is not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.  See attached plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI.   Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly   Date of upload: 15 July 2020

In wet pasture, 140m W of townland boundary with Knockaunnacurraha. Possible barrow (LI049-238-) lies 40m to the NW and possible barrow (LI049-239-) 60m to E. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified as a possible barrow on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2609, No. 373) taken 03/11/1984.  Visible as a faint circular cropmark on Google Earth orthoimages where it is located immediately N of a farm track running NW-SE. See attached BGE aerial photograph and Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload:  8 October 2021

In wet pasture, 90m W of townland boundary with Knockaunnacurraha. Possible barrow (LI049-246----) lies 60m to the NW and possible barrow (LI049-238----) 100m to W. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Monument listed Spittle 2 and identified as a ring-barrow by Grogan (1989, 249).  Shallow depression visible in centre of field visible on Google Earth orthoimages may be the earthwork listed 'Spittle 2'.    See attached Google Earth orthoimages. In reclaimed pasture, 95m W of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Ballywire and the County boundary with Tipperary.   Possible barrow (LI041-065----) lies 15m to SE. In reclaimed pasture, 75m W of a watercourse that marks the townland boundary with Ballywire and the County boundary with Tipperary.   Possible barrow (LI041-064----) lies 15m to NW. In gently undulating wet pasture with a ditch-barrow (TS066-092010-) c. 10m to the SW. Identified on Bruff Survey aerial photograph (ref. 2090). Slightly raised circular area (diam. c. 6m) defined by a very slight irregular earthen scarp (Wth 1m; H 0.1m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth. Towards the top of the N-facing slope of Rathcroghan ridge. Circular grass-covered and flat-topped earthen mound (diam. of base 7.6m NE-SW; 7m NW-SE; diam. of top 3m NW-SE; 2.8m NE-SW; H 0.8m at NW to 1.2m at SW) with a rectangular grass-covered platform (dims 6.5m NW-SE; 7.3m NE-SW) defined by scarps (H 0.6-0.8m) attached to the NW. (Waddell 1983, 37, No. 31)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On slight rise in gently undulating pasture with a ring-ditch (TS066-092004-) c. 15m to the SE and another (TS066-092002-) c. 30m to the NNW. Identified on Bruff Survey aerial photograph (ref. 2090). Circular area (diam. c. 4m) defined by a very slight irregular earthen scarp (Wth 0.4m; H 0.05m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 September 2014

In improved, gently undulating pasture, on a ENE-facing slope, overlooking area of fen to WSW. Circular area (dims. 10m N-S; 9.5m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 0.75m; H 0.15) which has been raised (scarp Wth 1.5m; H 0.2m) to E to compensate hillslope. Fosse (basal Wth 0.3m; overall Wth 2.55m; D 0.15m) WNW-NNW. Interior has a slightly uneven surface and slopes gently downward to ENE; slight depression within centre. Identified as a circular anomaly on an aerial photograph (OS 2397/8). Field boundaries indicated on latest edition OS 6-inch map to W and S have been removed.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In generally flat marshy terrain, in gently undulating ground. The land is quite hummocky to the W has a lot of reeds. The field to the E has been reclaimed. A large pond barrow (TS058-046----) is located 280m to the ENE and two ring-barrows (TS058-070001- and TS058-070002-) are located 200m to the E. The barrow (TS058-023002-) and standing stone (TS058-023004-) at Longstone are visible 1.7km to the NE. A raised earthen monument (diam. 16.5m N-S; 17m E-W) defined by a broad bank (Wth at base 3.7m; Wth at crest 1.5m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 1.05m) which is best preserved in the N-NE and almost reduced to scarp elsewhere. There is a slight, roughly circular raised area in the interior (dims. 5.8m N-S; 5.4m E-W; H 0.05m) which is off-centre towards the northern edge of the monument. A deep wide field ditch, running E-W, truncates the monument in the S quadrant. The E quadrant is similarly truncated by a field bank and ditch running N-S. A field ditch runs N-S along the external base of the bank in the W quadrant. In the N quadrant there is a wide, flat-bottomed depression (Wth 4.6m; D 0.3m) at the external base of the bank which may be an external fosse though the ground appears to be rising naturally northward, perhaps creating the appearance of a fosse.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2013

In pasture at base of hollow, 100m S of public road.  Enclosure (LI024-312----) located 110m to NW, enclosure (LI024-167----) 130m to W.  Not depicted on the OS maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 114; AP 4/3676) as a circular shaped cropmark with traces of a possible outer ditch from S through to W.  OSi orthoimage  taken 2005-12 shows a circular-shaped area (int. diam. 20m; ext. diam. 48m) enclosed by a ditch (Wth approx. 5m) with a bank (Wth approx. 8m) and an outer ditch. Visible on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018 as a circular -shaped area enclosed by two ditches with an intervening bank.   See attached Google Earth orthophoto and Bruff aerial survey image labelled Bruff 114.   Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload:  24 July 2020

In pasture, 110m NE of townland boundary with Knockaunacurragha, a possible earthwork (LI049-146----) lies 45m to the NW. Depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map as a raised oval-shaped area defined by a scarp.  Depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as a raised oval-shaped area (dims. c. 27m NW-SE; 26m NE-SW) defined by a scarp, intersected at SE by a post-1700 field boundary running NE-SW. No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13. Monument visible as a circular cropmark with possible external bank from NW-N-NE on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018. A linear feature running NW-SE intersects the monument at N.See attached Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Fiona Rooney Date of upload: 1 November 2021

In wet pasture 10m S of a stream and field boundary that marks the townland boundary with Newtown.  Barrow (LI033-166----) 50m to SE.  Depicted on the OSi 25-inch map as a raised circular-shaped area (diam. 15m) defined by a scarp. Surveyed by the ASI in 2007 and described as a raised circular-shaped area (diam. 14m) enclosed by a bank (Wth 10.8m; H 0.35m) from SE to W reduced to a scarp elsewhere with an outer fosse (Wth 4.5m; D 0.15m) only visible from S-SW. Described in 1964 as a; Platform 60 feet (18m) in diameter and 1 foot (0.3m) high.  Encircled by a shallow ditch, 2 feet (0.6m) wide (ODwyer 1960-1964, 98; Rahard 77).  Outline of monument visible as cropmark defined by fosse on OSi orthophotos 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages and profile of monument drawn by O'Dwyer  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick  Date of upload: 29 March 2021

At the summit of a hill overlooking the W-E Boyle River and Lough Key. Round-topped, grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 8m; H 1.1-2m) incorporated as the E bastion of the bastioned fort (RO006-068001-).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level pasture with a possible barrow (TS066-007002-) located c. 30m to the SW. Identified on aerial photograph (OSI 2398/7). Roughly circular area (diam. 6m) defined by a barely perceptible earthen scarped edge (Wth c. 2m; H 0.05m). The interior is level and clear of overgrowth.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 12 October 2015

In gently undulating pasture; poorly drained to N and S. Circular area (diam. 17m) defined by an inner bank (Wth 10.3m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 3.05m), fosse (basal Wth 1.2m; overall Wth 10.85m; D 0.7m) and outer bank (Wth 5.6m; int. H 0.85m; ext. H 0.15m). The inner bank is almost reduced to scarp NW-NE and steps outwards at base, possibly due to cattle erosion and slippage over time. The fosse is well defined W-N-SE and traceable yet inconspicuous SE-S-W. Possible remains of low outer bank are best defined NE-SE. Interior appears featureless. Ring-barrow (TS066-123002-) is c. 6-8m to NNE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a generally N-facing slope, in pasture, with ringfort (TS058-045----) 100m to the NW. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible as a circular area (diam. c. 10m) on an aerial photograph (Bruff No. 5/2029). Not visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a slightly raised area, on N-facing slope, in rough wet pasture. Surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as an oval-shaped area (approx. dims. 20m NE-SW; 12m NW-SE) defined by a scarp (H 0.95m; Wth 1.1m), with fosse (overall Wth 3.5; base Wth 1.4m; D 0.4m) and an outer bank (Wth 2.75m; int. H 0.4m; ext. H 0.25m) only visible from NNW-N-NNE.  Only the enclosing elements are visible in the N sector, the rest of the monument is covered with dense vegetation. The outer bank appears to have a terminus at NNE. Some large stones were noted at SW.  Monument is visible as a tree-planted earthwork on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 28/06/2018.  See attached sketch plan and cross-sections surveyed and drawn by the ASI.   Compiled by: Alison McQueen, and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 17 July 2020

In gently undulating wet pasture. An embanked enclosure (TS058-046----) is located 200m to the W. Not shown on any edition of the OS 6-inch map but visible as a roughly circular area (diam. c. 10m) on an aerial photograph (Bruff No. 5/2029). Not visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In a hollow on the Rathcroghan plateau and just outside the ceremonial enclosure (RO022-057012-) around Rathcroghan mound (RO022-057010-) at SE. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 43m N-S; 42.5m E-W) defined by a fosse, best preserved at N (Wth of top 9-10m; int. D 0.3m; ext. D 0.2m) and S. A N-S field wall overlies it E of the centre, and it is barely visible E of this feature. It has no outer bank (max. ext. diam. 66m N-S; 59m E-W). Barrows (RO022-057015-; RO0-22-056016-) are c. 60m and c. 40m to the NW and N while barrows (RO022-056017-; RO022-056020-) are c. 85m and c. 110m to the SSW and S respectively. (Knox 1914a, 29, cashel 3; Herity 1983, 130; 1988, 131, Glenballythomas 7; Waddell 1983, 29, No. 9)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In rough pasture, enclosed by approximately 8 year old forestry to the W and N. Identified on an aerial photograph (OS 2397/6 and 2348). A large oval area (dims. 21.5m N-S; 23m E-W), raised (H 0.95-1.05m) above the surrounding ground level and defined by a substantial bank (Wth 7.35m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 1.05m) and possible fosse (Wth 12.25; D 0.7m) NW-N-E. The bank is best preserved in the N quadrant and is reduced to scarp (Wth 5.3m; H 1.0m) NE-S-NW and is very gradual S-W-NW. The interior slopes down gently to the SW and contains two ditch barrows (TS066-041003- and TS066-041004-).  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture 20m SE of a field boundary that marks the townland boundary with Garryheakin. Ring-barrow (LI033-110----) lies 140m to E, ring-barrows (LI033-135/137----) 150m to SE and earthwork (LI033-111002-) 140m to S.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 108; AP 4/3620) as a ring-barrow.  Visible as a circular-shaped cropmark (diam c. 7m) on OSi orthophoto taken between 2005-12 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018.  See attached Bruff image labelled Bruff 108 and Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Martin Fitzpatrick   Date of upload: 14 April 2021

In pasture 30m W of the townland boundary with Ballyfauskeen.  Possible barrow (LI057-010----) lies 55m to S. Not depicted on historic OSi maps.  Identified as a possible ring-barrow on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 2615; 072) taken 03/11/1984.  No surface remains visible on Google Earth orthoimages. See attached Bórd Gáis Éireann gas pipeline aerial image and Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload:  12 November 2021

In pasture 70m W of the townland boundary with Ballyfauskeen.  Possible barrow (LI057-008----) lies 300m to S. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. In improved pasture 105m S of the townland boundary with Garryheakin. One of three possible barrows (LI033-135/137----) located immediately N of a drainage ditch running NE-SW. In improved pasture 90m S of the townland boundary with Garryheakin. One of three possible barrows (LI033-135/137----) located immediately N of a drainage ditch running NE-SW. In improved pasture 30m S of a field boundary that marks the townland boundary with Garryheakin. Barrow (LI033-109----) lies 140m to W, ring-barrows (LI033-135/137----) 70m to S and earthwork (LI033-111002-) 120m to SE.  Not depicted on historic OSi maps. In improved pasture (longish grass at present), on top of rise. Good views in all directions especially to Galtee mountains to SE. Plectrum shaped/sub-circular area (dims. 34m N-S; 36m E-W) defined by remains of levelled scarp (Wth 1.7m; H 0.2m) best preserved W-N, and surviving in a reasonable levelled out, yet traceable form N-S-W. Mature deciduous tree on scarp at W. Possible fosse (Wth 2.8m; D 0.1m) visible intermittently all around. Interior generally level in SSW-half and sloping down to NE in NNE-half. Disturbed area within NW-quadrant is also visible on aerial photograph (ref. OS 2437/6) and is likely a small-scale quarry (disused and now grassed over). Ditch barrow (TS066-083004-) within interior, just off-centre to NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In improved pasture 30m S of a watercourse and 170m N of field boundary that marks the townland boundary with Arrybreaga. One of three barrows (LI033-112001/003-) aligned NW-SE. In improved pasture 35m N of a watercourse. Possible barrow (LI033-131----) lies 60m to NW and enclosure (LI033-130----) 80m to N. Not depicted on historic OSi maps. Identified by Bruff aerial photographic survey in 1986 (Bruff 102.04; AP 4/3620) as a ring-barrow. On the W-facing slope of a drumlin. Circular, round-topped and grass-covered earthen mound (diam. 6.3-6.5m; H 0.8m at E to 1.7m at W). There is a slight berm (Wth 1.5m; H 0.3m) at the base of the mound at S. Barrow (RO006-072----) is c. 30m to the ENE. Archaeological testing (05E0121) to within c. 30m of the site in the fields to the S, W and N failed to produce any related material (Read, C. 2008).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level pasture, land falling gently to W and S. Circular area (dims. 24.5m N-S; 26m E-W) raised (H 1.15m) above external ground level and defined by scarp (Wth 3.4m; H 1.85m) ESE-S-W-N. Base of scarp stepped at W due to erosion by cattle and scarp is slightly lower either side of a broad causeway (Wth 10.5m) ENE-E. Well defined fosse (basal Wth 2.5m; overall Wth 8.05m; D 0.7m) E-S-W-NE is waterlogged. Interior slopes down gently to ENE toward causeway and blends in with slope of causeway. A ring-barrow (TS066-047005-) is cut into W-side of interior and ring-ditch (TS066-047004-) is c. 29m to the SE, with two other ring-ditches (TS066-047002-; TS066-047003-) c. 105m and c. 117m to the NW and NNE respectively.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

In low-lying level wet pasture. Not depicted on any edition of the OS 6-inch map. Visible as a poorly defined series of approximately five closely grouped circular areas (average diam. c. 10m) on an aerial photograph (Bruff No. 5/2030). Not visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Marked as a circular feature (diam. c. 15m) only on the 1915 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. Situated on a gentle W-facing slope c. 450m from the River Suck to the NW and SW and planted with deciduous trees within the demesne of Mount Talbot. Oval mound (dims. 19.5m E-W; 14m N-S; H 3.2-3.6m) with an oval summit (dims. 4.5m E-W; 1.5m N-S).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture, on a W facing slope of a natural ridge, within the former demesne of Massy Lodge, located 470m to NE.  Not marked on the historic OSi maps.  Identified as a possible earthwork on Bórd Gáis Éireann Curraleigh West-Limerick gas pipeline aerial photographs (BGE 1/5000; 2620) taken 03/11/1984.  No surface remains visible on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13.  Faint outline of small circular-shaped cropmark visible on Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018. See attached BGE aerial photograph (057069) and Google Earth orthoimages. Compiled by: Martin FitzpatrickDate of upload:  5 November 2021

In level, wet pasture, 135m NE of a townland boundary with Brackloon. A ring-barrow (LI024-060----) lies 170m to NW. Not depicted on OSi historic maps. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 2008 and described as an oval-shaped area (5.25m NNE-SSW; 7m WNW-ESE) defined by a scarp (Wth 1.5-1.8m; H 0.35-0.45m). The interior is grass covered. A dry land drain to N which runs WNW-ESE is channelled toward a pond 40m to WNW. Monument is visible as an oval-shaped earthwork on OSi orthoimage taken 2005-2012 and on Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  See attached Google Earth orthoimage taken 28/06/2018.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera Rahilly  Date of upload: 14 October 2020

In undulating pasture, on top of a ridge. Indicated on the 1914 OS 6-inch map as a small hachured oval mound (c. 10m NE-SW). There are no visible remains of this mound. Its size and location, however, suggest a barrow.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture, in a slight hollow on a N-facing slope. This barrow is not visible at ground level. It was described in 1974 as a 'circular mound, probably sepulchral' (Raftery 1974, 73).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In pasture. A possible barrow (diam. c. 17m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 18 November 2018) by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is another possible barrow (TS066-221----) c. 110m to the NE.  See attached photograph: TS066-220----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (18 November 2018)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 8 January 2020

In pasture. A possible barrow (diam. c. 17m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 18 November 2018) by Jean-Charles Caillère. There is another possible barrow (TS066-220----) c. 110m to the SW.  See attached photograph: TS066-221----_01 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (18 November 2018)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 8 January 2020

Raftery (1974, 73) recorded a 'tumulus' (diam. c. 21m) on a rise surrounded by an earthen bank, 1.6km N of Kilmactranny. This is not visible at ground level. There is a ring-barrow (SL035-090----) c. 100m to NW which was named 'tumulus' on the 1914 OS 6-inch map.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

In reclaimed pasture, 100m E of  townland boundary with Gortakilleen. Spring well annotated 'Tobernafinnoge' 95m to NNE.  Not marked on 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map. Depicted on the 1897 ed. OSi 25-inch map as circular-shaped area (diam. c. 26m) defined by a fosse. Described in 1960 as; One half of platform missing. Diameter of remaining part is 51 feet [15.5m]; 5 feet [1.5m] over field level. Has an 18 foot [5.4m] wide continuous ditch (ODwyer 1958-61, 115; Shanaclogh West 56).  The monument is clearly visible on OSi orthophotograph taken between 2005-22 and on Google Earth orthoimage dated 18/11/2018. A linear cropmark running E-W is visible to the W of the enclosure with post-1700 field system in field to the W.  See attached drawing by ODwyer and Google Earth orthoimage.  Compiled by: Fiona Rooney  Date of upload: 21 April 2021

The site of a mound and 'Stuckerd (Pillar Stone)' (SL041-038005-) are indicated on the 1914 OS 6-inch map in a field c. 50m SE of a graveyard (SL041-038002-). There are no visible remains of the mound. Its association with a standing stone, however, would suggest a prehistoric monument, possibly a barrow. Wood-Martin (1883-4, 448) referred to the site of 'a large stuckerd, or pillar-stone, on the summit of an earthen mound' close to the church (SL041-038001-).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Outline of possible ring-barrow clearly visible on Google Earth aerial image taken 05/03/2009.   Monument  consists of a low circular mound (approx. diam. 9m) enclosed by a fosse with external bank (approx. overall diam. 22m).  Upstanding monument visible on Google Earth aerial photographs taken 20/03/2018, but not visible on aerial photograph taken 18/11/2018.    See attached aerial photographs taken from Google Earth.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Dr. Rob O'Hara  Date of upload: 24 February 2020

On level poorly drained ground in upland area, on the edge of a SSW-facing slope, with panoramic views from E-S-W-NW. Summit of Cullaun Mountain 1km to N.  A possible pond barrow (LI008-004----) or quarry hole lies c. 35m to SW. Depicted on the 1840 ed. OSi 6-inch map as a circular shaped enclosure standing immediately S of the townland boundary with Gannavane Upper.   Shown on the OSi 25-inch map as a suboval-shaped area defined by a fosse intersected at N by the townland boundary running E-W. Monument surveyed by the ASI in 1999 and described as a slightly raised subcircular-shaped area (31m E-W; 28m N-S) defined by a scarp (H 0.2m; Wth 1.1m) from NW-N-E-S-W-WNW. The scarp is absent from WNW-NW and may represent an entrance feature. The interior is generally level. A relic field boundary running E-W extends from the exterior at SSE. This is a very low profile monument and is not known locally as a fort.  Visible as roughly oval-shaped area enclosed by a green band of differential growth on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 18/11/2018.  The interior is covered in rushes suggesting a poorly drained pond-like interior which could be the remains of a barrow rather than that of a ringfort.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 3 July 2020

In elevated pasture, on the summit of a ridge with excellent views in all directions. A circular raised area (diam. 7.4m) defined by an earthen bank (int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.5m). An external fosse (D 0.4m) is evident NNE-NNW; the fosse is truncated at N by an oval flat-bottomed pond-like depression (12m N-S; 10m E-W) which lies 2m from the base of the bank. The depression is defined by a scarp (H 1.1m) and is waterlogged with some peat growth at its centre. This may be a ritual feature associated with the barrow. Traces of a low external bank (Wth 1.5m; H 0.25m) around the barrow, noted during a previous site inspection in 1993 (SMR (1989) file), are no longer visible.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Sligo' compiled by Ursula Egan, Elizabeth Byrne, Mary Sleeman with Sheila Ronan and Connie Murphy (Dublin Stationery Office, 2005).   Date of upload: 18 January 2008

Situated on flat poorly drained reclaimed grassland.  Outline of possible barrow (approx. diam. 6m) visible on Google Earth orthophotos taken 11/03/2014 and 18/11/2018. Not visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 18 October 2020

In gently undulating, level pasture. Circular area (dims. 21m N-S; 23m E-W) defined by low earthen bank (Wth 7.3m; int. H 0.45m; ext. H 0.9m) ESE-S-W-NNE which is reduced to a scarp (Wth 2.5m; H 0.65m) NNE-E-ESE. Bank and scarp are eroded on exterior corresponding to cattle breaches through bank at W, NW, NE and ESE. Fosse (overall Wth 7.6m; basal Wth 2.3m; D 0.4m) best preserved SW-NE. Fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.2m) is less defined NE-ESE. Wide lazy beds (long axis ENE-WSW) truncate interior across a distinct SE-facing slope. Depression in NW-quadrant, cut by lazy beds, may be a damaged barrow. Ditch barrow (TS066-57001-) is c. 3.5m to W.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a small plateau on the W-facing slope of a hillock, in pasture, overlooking the valley of the Aughvaria River to N and the Gortnageragh River to S. A standing stone (LI016-002003-) and a stone row (LI016-002001-) lie c. 20m to W and c. 25m to NW, respectively. Not depicted on OS historic mapping. Described as an unclassified type of barrow. Monument is visible as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork (12m N-S; 13m E-W) on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and on Google Earth orthoimages taken 11/03/2014.See attached Google Earth orthoimagesCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 10 July 2020

In wet pasture; frequent rushes. Circular area (dims. 21m N-S; 22m E-W) defined by scarp (Wth 2.3m; H 0.95m). Causewayed entrance (Wth 4m) at SSE. Fosse (basal Wth 3.3m; overall Wth 7.4m; D 0.25m) S-N-ENE and ESE-SSE; fosse is best defined SW-NW. Interior is generally level and contains two ring-barrows (TS066-60001- and TS066-60002-) in NW-sector and one ditch-barrow (TS066-60003-) in E-sector. Shroughnagowneen stream to immediate S. Mound (TS066-061) is c. 275m to ENE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On level ground, on the floodplain of the Aughvaria River, in poorly drained pasture, with good views to E and W and moderate views to S. Depicted on the revised 1924 ed. OS 25-inch map as a roughly circular-shaped mound (diam. 9.5m). Monument visited by the ASI in 1999, however it was densely overgrown and inaccessible. Described on an ASI index card as an enclosed circular-shaped mound, possibly suggesting a type of barrow (SMR file).  Not clearly visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13 and Google Earth orthoimage taken 11/03/2014.See attached Google Earth orthoimageCompiled by: Alison McQueen and Vera RahillyDate of upload: 3 July 2020

Towards the top of a S-facing slope. Knox (1914b, 352) describes four features in a N-S row with diameters corresponding to those of barrows (RO039-014001-; RO039-014002-) and rath (RO039-015----). While the location of the missing barrow (diam. c. 15m) is uncertain it may have been just S of (RO039-014002-) where there is a now a small quarry (diam. c. 5m; D 0.35-0.9m).  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In level wet improved pasture. Circular area (diam. 25.5m) defined by a low earthen scarp (Wth 2.1m; H 0.35m). At the external base of the scarped edge is the first fosse (Wth at base 3.7m; D 0.3m), the first earthen bank (Wth at top 2m; overall Wth 4.2m; int. H 0.1m; ext. H 0.4m), a second fosse (Wth at base 1.8m; D 0.8m) and a second outer earthen bank (Wth at top 1.6m; overall Wth 4.3m; int. H 0.9m; ext. H 0.1m). The first fosse and bank low in profile difficult to trace at ground level NW-NE. There is a modern break (Wth 8m) in the first bank at E. The second outer bank is very low and difficult to trace at ground level N-E. There is a modern break (Wth 2m) in the first bank at ESE. There are two possible entrance features, either of which may be original. The first is at E where there is a break (Wth 4m) in the first bank with a corresponding break (Wth 6m) in the second outer bank. The second is at WSW where there is a break (Wth 3m) in the first bank with a corresponding break (Wth 4m) in the second outer bank. The interior is level and clear of overgrowth with bushes and briars along the tops of the banks S-NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a gentle SE-facing slope. Circular grass-covered mound (diam. of base 20.6m E-W; 20m N-S; H 1.65m at N to 2.2m at E) which has been quarried on top (diam. 8.6m N-S; 7.1m E-S; D 0.25m at N to 1.6m at E). Barrows (RO039-014001-; RO039-014002-; RO039-014003-) and rath (RO039-015----) are c. 150-190m to the W and NW. (Knox 1914b, 352)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a rise in undulating grassland. Marked on the 1838 edition of the OS 6-inch map as an embanked circular enclosure (diam. c. 40). On the OS 1:2500 plan (surveyed 1912-16) it is shown as an enclosure cut by a roughly N-S running trackway and field boundary from NNE to SSE. On inspection all that was visible was a circular stone-filled depression (diam. 16m; D 0.6m) much overgrown and obscured by field clearance. Possibly a barrow.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 30 July 2019

On the summit of a WSW-ESE esker ridge, 8m W of barrow (RO047-058017-). Rectangular grass-covered stoney area (dims 9.3m E-W; 6.2m N-S; H 0.2m) defined by a slight fosse (Wth 1-1.5m) and outer bank (Wth 1m; H 0.1m) at E and W, and by a berm (Wth 1.2m) and the edge of the ridge at N and S.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

On a N-facing slope overlooking the valley of a W-E stream. A cist (RO028-195002-) containing a Bowl Food Vessel and a cremation, which may have been under a mound, were recovered in land reclamation in 1965. It is no longer extant. (Lucas 1968, 120-1; Waddell 1990,130; Ó Ríordáin and Waddell 1993, 128)  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In gently undulating, poorly drained pasture. A circular area (diam. 22m) defined by scarp (Wth 1.1-2.3m; H 0.65-0.7m) and an external fosse (Wth 3.8-6.45m; D 0.1-0.3m) which is best defined from SSE-NW. There is a possible causewayed entrance (Wth 6m) at the NNW. The interior is generally level with frequent rushes. There is a possible ditch barrow (TS059-002001-) within the SE quadrant.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 24 September 2013

In low-lying wet terrain criss-crossed with rivulets, with a stream flowing c. 10m to E, in rough pasture. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 10m) visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth satellite imagery, 18 November 2018), identified and reported by Jean-Charles Caillère.   See attached: TS059-203----_01 Google Earth satellite image (imagery date, 18 November 2018)   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly   Date of upload: 8 January 2022

In pastureland. de Valera and Ó Nualláin (1972, 29, no. 11) noted a circular bushy area 'some 30m south' of the more westerly example (GA100-103----) of two barrows (see also GA100-103001-) and they believed it may have concealed 'a third mound'. On inspection in February 1985 the small clump of dense overgrowth was inaccessible and it was not possible to determine whether it was of archaeological significance or not.  Compiled by: Galway Archaeological Survey, UCG  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

On the crest of a slight NNW-SSE ridge. Circular, flat-topped, grass and scrub-covered platform (diam. of top 17.8m ENE-WSW; 17.3m NNW-SSE; diam. of base 25.8m NNW-SSE) defined by a scarp (H 2-2.5m), with a scrub-covered berm (at NNW: Wth 7m; H 0.85m) around the base SW-N-NE which is replaced by a quarry S-SW. The berm may represent an outer bank back-filled into an inner fosse.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

In pasture. A possible barrow (diam. c. 12m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016). One of a number of possible barrows (TS059-171---- c. 18m to S; TS059-172---- c. 50m to S; conjoined barrows TS059-173---- and TS059-174---- c. 80m to SE and TS059-175---- c. 100m to SE).  See attached photograph: TS059-170----_01 Image ©2019 Maxar Technologies: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 January 2020

In pasture. A possible barrow (diam. c. 11m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016). One of a number of possible barrows (TS059-170---- c. 18m to N; TS059-172---- c. 26m to S; conjoined barrows TS059-173---- and TS059-174---- c. 50m to SE and TS059-175---- c. 90m to ESE).  See attached photograph: TS059-171----_01 Image ©2019 Maxar Technologies: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 January 2020

In pasture. A possible barrow (diam. c. 10m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016). One of a number of possible barrows (TS059-170---- c. 50m to NNW; TS059-171---- c. 26m to NNW; conjoined barrows TS059-173---- and TS059-174---- c. 20m to SE and TS059-175---- c. 80m to ENE).  See attached photograph: TS059-172----_01 Image ©2019 Maxar Technologies: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 January 2020

In pasture. A possible barrow (diam. c. 8m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016), conjoined with another barrow (TS059-174----) to the SE. Within a cluster of possible barrows (TS059-170---- c. 80m to NW; TS059-171---- c. 55m to NW; TS059-172---- c. 20m to NW and TS059-175---- c. 60m to NE).  See attached photograph: TS059-173----_01 Image ©2019 Maxar Technologies: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 January 2020

In pasture. A possible barrow (diam. c. 8m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016), conjoined with another barrow (TS059-173----) to the NW. Within a cluster of possible barrows (TS059-170---- c. 80m to NW; TS059-171---- c. 55m to NW; TS059-172---- c. 20m to NW and TS059-175---- c. 60m to NE).  See attached photograph: TS059-174----_01 Image ©2019 Maxar Technologies: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 January 2020

In pasture. A possible barrow (diam. c. 10m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016). One of a number of possible barrows (TS059-170---- c. 100m to NW; TS059-171---- c. 90m to WNW; TS059-172---- c. 80m to WSW and conjoined barrows TS059-173---- and TS059-174---- c. 60m to SW).  See attached photograph: TS059-175----_01 Image ©2019 Maxar Technologies: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 January 2020

In pasture. A possible barrow (diam. c. 10m) identified as an earthwork on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 16 December 2016). A group of possible barrows (TS059-170----; TS059-171----; TS059-172----; TS059-173----; TS059-174---- and TS059-175----) are located c. 400m to the NW.  See attached photograph: TS059-176----_01 Image ©2019 Maxar Technologies: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (16 December 2016)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 13 January 2020

In level, low-lying area of good pasture, within an old flood plain. Circular area (diam. 32m) defined by scarp (Wth 6m; H 1.5m), a well-preserved fosse (Wth 13.1m; D 1m) and an outer bank (Wth 7.35m; int. H 1m; ext. H 0.01m) from SW-NE. There is a possible entrance (Wth 8m) at the E, where there is a dip in the scarp. Livestock have eroded the scarp at the NNE, S and E. The interior is in lush pasture and contains ring-barrow (TS059-112007-) which abuts the edge of the scarp at N. There is also a possible ring-barrow (TS059-112006-) c. 60m to the NNE, a ring-barrow (TS059-112009-) c. 115m to the SW and a possible embanked barrow (TS059-112008-) c. 130m to S. The field is called 'Knockannahoirky Field' on the 1st (1840) ed. OS 6-inch map.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011
