On the W-facing crest of a small NW-SE ridge on a broad plateau. Circular grass-covered area (diam. 20.7m N-S; 21.5m E-W) defined by an earthen bank (at S: Wth 4.5m; int. H 0.7m; ext. H 0.9m) incorporated into a field bank with scrub E-S-W and reduced to a scarp (H 0.7m) elsewhere. Three stones from a cist (RO045-048002-) (dims 1.2m x 0.9m; H 0.5-0.7m) are exposed at the centre. Mound barrow (RO045-047----) is c. 75m to the NW.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Marked only on the 1915 ed. of the OS 6-inch map as a small feature (diam. c. 20m), and situated at the summit of a limestone hill. Described as an earthen mound which was thought to be sepulchral (OS Name Book). The location is now occupied by a quarry. Burial (RO042-107----) is c. 160m to the NE.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 25 January 2010

In poorly drained grassland atop low rise of ground with good views in all directions. Overgrown monument consists of a raised circular area (approx. int. diam. 10m NE-SW; 12m E-W; overall diam. 20m N-S; 30m E-W) enclosed by a bank with sunken interior. Rectangular trench (dims. 14m L x 4m Wth; D 0.7m) running E-W cut into SE quadrant of interior probably to accommodate construction of electricty pole recently erected on the monument. Interior impossible to examine due to dense cover of vegetation. Location and small size of interior as well as local placename 'The Mount' suggests a possible barrow classification. Present road intersects W side of mound on a NW-SE axis as indicated on first edition OS 6-inch map.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Marked on the 1837 and 1914 eds of the OS 6-inch map, but named 'Cruckawn' only on the later map. Situated on the E-facing crest of a low N-S ridge, c. 150m from the River Shannon N-E. Circular overgrown earth and stone mound (diam. of base 14.5m; diam. of top 6.7-8m; H 0.8m at S to 1.8m at N) with traces of facing-stones at S and W. There is a conical stone-lined pit (diam. of top 2.3m; diam. of base 1.4m; D 1.2m) on the summit. Rath (RO018-004----) is c. 70m to the W.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 24 August 2010

Not visible at ground level. Potential monuments identified by T. McDonald as part of an archaeological survey of the Clonmacnoise region in 1987 (McDonald 1987, 9). Described by McDonald as 'ploughed-out remains of what may have been a group of barrows (McDonald 1987, 9).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Not visible at ground level. Potential barrow site of identified by T. McDonald as part of an archaeological survey of the Clonmacnoise region in 1987 (McDonald 1987, 2).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876 eds. Sited on the SE slope of a mountain. Circular mound of earth and stone (diam. 11.9m; H 0.65m) encircled by a wide, shallow, external fosse which has been infilled from WNW-N-NE where a modern stone field boundary skirts the site. The mound is largely flat-topped except for a low irregularly shaped rise in the centre.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

In generally level pasture, in the E corner of the field. Sub-circular area (dims. 20m N-S; 14m E-W) defined by gentle scarp (Wth 3.8m; H 0.3m) and fosse (top Wth 9.8m; basal Wth 2.5m; D 0.6m) S-W-N-ENE. Truncated by pond ENE-S which occupies SE-quadrant. Base of fosse is wet and water probably flows into it when levels in the pond are high. Enclosure (TS069-068----) located 900m to NE.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a steep NNW-facing slope within a modern golf course. Described in 1986 (SMR file) as a raised platform (diam. c. 15m) with a wide, shallow fosse, suggesting that it might be a possible barrow. On a revisit in 1998 the monument had been levelled and was not visible at ground level.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 17 November 2011

Situated on W facing slope of rising ground in upland area. Low natural looking irregular shaped earth and stone mound (diam. 13m E-W ; 10m N-S; ext. H 0.5m) which is best defined at W. May be the remains of a barrow however other similar natural looking mounds in the vicinity of this earthwork suggest that it may be of no archaeological significance.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 23 May 2011

Situated on a gentle SE-facing slope within a slight basin with the head of an E-W stream c. 100m to the S and slightly higher ground all around, except to the W. Overgrown, low flat-topped mound (diam. c. 15m; H 0.5m) separated by a grass-covered berm (Wth 8.5m) from a wet, flat-bottomed fosse (Wth c. 4m; D 0.2-0.4m). A grass-covered outer berm (Wth c. 11m) separates the fosse from a slight outer fosse (Wth 2.5m; max. D 0.5m) NE-SE. The outer fosse is visible NW-S (max. ext. diam. c. 65m) on vertical aerial photographs (ACAP, V186/4-6).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Waterford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1999). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 10th October, 2011  Compiled by: Michael Moore

Situated on the crest of a ridge, in undulating pastureland. A roughly circular area (diam. 20m NE-SW; 19.5m NW-SE) which has been disturbed; the perimeter of the site is obscured by brambles and scrub. The site is defined by a denuded, possibly levelled bank of earth and stone (Wth c. 1.5m; int. H 0.16m; ext. H 0.3-0.5m) and there is no visible evidence of an external fosse or entrance feature. A small manure heap is dumped in the interior at E.  The above description is derived from 'The Archaeological Inventory of County Tipperary. Vol. 1 - North Tipperary' compiled by Jean Farrelly and Caimin O'Brien (Dublin: Stationery Office, 2002). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 September 2008

Situated on the summit of a hill with earthwork (WM023-044----) 110m to S.  Small poorly preserved irregular-shaped mound (overall diam. c. 18m NNE-SSW) of earth and stones which has been quarried away on the S (SMR File 17/09/1971).  The shape of the mound has been altered by the extensive damage caused by the quarrying of the mound.  Not depicted as an antiquity on 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map.  This mound marks the ordnance datum point for 401 ft. as depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map.  It is possible that the earthwork may have been modified or constructed by the Ordnance Survey when taking a datum point from this hilltop. The classification and antiquity of this monument is uncertain and its poor condition makes it difficult to be certain about its original appearance. It has been suggested that this earthwork may represent the remains of a poorly preserved bowl-barrow (SMR File 17/09/1971).  However in profile the mound has the appearance of a stepped-barrow rather than a bowl-barrow.  Compiled by: Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 20 July 2015

On a S-facing slope in undulating terrain, under pasture. Possible fulacht fia (TS062-151----) located 4m to NE. Small roughly circular raised area (diam. 21m N-S; c. 18m E-W) of gravelly clay construction, defined by scarp (H 0.46-0.88m). The interior rises slightly towards the centre (H 0.34 over 4m). The W quadrant is incorporated in a field boundary which curves around the edge of the monument and is surmounted by hedgerow with conifers. An external ditch is associated with the field boundary.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

On a S-facing slope in undulating pasture, surrounding field quite waterlogged at time of inspection. Monument visible on aerial photograph taken in 1974 (GSI S.597/8, 16-4-1974). Circular flat-topped mound (diam. 18m N-S; 17.6m E-W) defined by scarp (H 0.58-0.72m) and shallow ext. fosse (Wth 2.8-4.2m; D 0.13-0.72m). Scarp slips into the fosse in the NE, SE and SW quadrant, may be entrance features or cattle denudation. Interior is slightly raised (H 0.34 over 4m) in the N quadrant.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 8 October 2014

Situated on flat poorly drained land with drainage channels traversing the field.  Outline of circular shaped area (approx. int. diam. 40m; overall ext. diam. 60m) defined by a fosse,  earthen bank and external fosse visible on Digital Globe aerial imagery. The W quadrant of the monument has been intersected by a post-1700 field boundary running N-S.  Earlier OSI aerial photography shows the outline of this monument to the W of the field boundary. The poorly drained land suggests that this may be the remains of a possible barrow although due to the large size of the monument it could be the remains of a ringfort of a raised platform nature.    See attached image from Google Earth taken 02/04/2013  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Eoghan Doyle  Date of upload: 11 March 2019

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 54-5) as following: 'Less than 150m NNW of monument (WM030-023----) just described, is another feature which on the surface could be interpreted as a barrow. This greatly damaged monument is preserved only on N side of E-W running field fence, S side of monument apparently having been removed. Although remaining part of monument is by no means regular in appearance or easily classifiable, it appears to comprise an irregular-shaped mound incorporating blocks of limestone and rising to its highest point on E side. This mound appears to be delimited on E and W halves by a bank, but bank on the W side is on markedly higher ground than that on E, being not much lower than the mound itself. It is not certain that the western stretch of bank is indeed a bank and it does not obviously join up with the much better defined eastern stretch; if it is accepted that the two banks join up to form one half of the perimeter of the monument, its maximum visible diameter from E to W is 46.5m. There appears to be a slight inner ditch associated with both E and W stretches of bank. On E side, where bank is much more low-lying than on W side, the central mound rises 1.95m above the ditch on inside of bank. On E side, bank is 4m in width; on W side it is 2.6m in width. Although this is unclear, eastern stretch of bank appears to veer off to N, running towards the rushy, reedy area close by; if this is so, it would clearly not join up with the western stretch. The aerial photograph  of  the  genuine  barrow in Moyvoughly  on  the  ASI  website,  which  takes  in  the  present monument,  suggests  that  the  impression  of  an  outer  bank  of  unusual  form,  and  by  implication  the monument as a whole, may be the accidental result of the intersection of snaking natural escarpments and man-made banks. Though possibly a barrow, this monument must be treated with serious doubt.   Monument is located in undulating, partly drained pastureland. Immediately to N of monument is a narrow band of low-lying grassland adjoining a rushy area 23m to N of barrow that may formerly have been a lake; part of the lakeshore appears to be delimited by a bank of uncertain origin. In this area of grassland just NW of barrow and between it and the lake is a small oval or subrectangular earthwork possibly representing a hutsite'.    Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Situated on a slight rise, in low-lying, wet pasture. Partially levelled monument described in 1977 as an oval-shaped area (dims. 41m E-W; 31m NNE-SSW) enclosed by a low preserved bank and shallow external fosse.  The interior rises slightly toward the centre and there are shallow cultivation ridges running E-W. There is no trace of an entrance.  Siting and morphology of earthwork suggests that this is not a ringfort.  Wet marshy location may suggest the remains of a possible barrow.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 24 July 2019

A 'barrow' levelled here in 1854 is said to have contained an 'urn and kistvaen' (Kinahan 1889, 286). The site today consists of a flat-topped rise, approximately circular, c. 22m across. It is c. 1m high. A slab 1.51m × 1.05m on top is thought to be part of the 'kistvaen'.  The above description was derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Donegal. A description of the field antiquities of the County from the Mesolithic Period to the 17th century.' Compiled by: Brian Lacey with Eamon Cody, Claire Cotter, Judy Cuppage, Noel Dunne, Vincent Hurley, Celie O'Rahilly, Paul Walsh and Seán Ó Nualláin (Lifford: Donegal County Council, 1983). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated.  Date of upload: 22 September 2008

In wet, low-lying pasture, c. 35m to the S of a rath (LF014-082----). A raised circular area (diam. at base 8.1m) enclosed from SE-S-W by a much-denuded, low bank of earth and stone (Wth 3.8m; H 0.1-0.25m) and defined elsewhere by a scarp (H 0.7m). There is no trace of an encircling fosse or bank. A depression (Wth 1.45m) in the scarp at NNW may mark the original entrance. Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Situated on high ground in mountainous area. Site consists of a low circular mound (diam. c. 10m; H 0.5m) enclosed by a poorly preserved fosse (Wth 1.3 - 3m at N; ext. D 3m at S) with no evidence of an outer bank. Site appears to have been quarried out of the side of the hill thus explaining the difference in external depth of fosse from N to S. Unusual location and morphology of site casts some doubt about its antiquity.  One of a group of five barrows (OF037-008001/002/004/005-).  According to local tradition these barrows are located on a hilltop which was the inauguration site of the OFlanagans of Cinél Arga (Feehan 1979, 143).  It is possible that these burial mounds form part of a ritual landscape associated with this inauguration site.     The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Offaly' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1997). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien.  Date of upload: 09 August 2012

Cropmark of circular-shaped earthwork (approx. ext. diam. 27m; int. diam. 15m) defined by a shallow ditch visible on Digital Globe aerial imagery.  Could be the remains of a ditch-barrow.  Compiled by: Caimin O'BrienDate of upload: 16 April 2020
Situated on a precipitous E-facing slope in an area of dense coniferous forest. Site not located.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Sited immediately S of the highest point of a drumlin ridge. Raised circular area (int. diam.12.7m N-S) enclosed by a substantial earthen bank with wide, shallow, internal fosse. Original entrance not recognisable.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Sited immediately E of the highest point of a drumlin hill. Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876eds. Roughly circular raised area (int. dims. 29.6mNE-SW; 27.6m NW-SE) enclosed by a low earthen bank with a very wide, shallow, internal fosse. The greater part of the bank has been modified and incorporated into the field boundary. Slight traces are identifiable from ENE-NNE. Original entrance not recognisable.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876 eds. Sited on the highest point of a low natural rise .Raised circular area (int. dims 15.7m N-S; 15.3m E-W) enclosed by a low but well-defined earthen bank with a wide, shallow, internal fosse. Original entrance not recognisable.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Sited immediately S of the highest point of a prominent drumlin hill. Small, circular, flat-topped mound of earth and stone (int. diam. 7.5m NNW-SSE) with the remains of a kerb of low stones about the perimeter of the summit. The mound is enclosed by a narrow, well-defined bank of earth and stone with narrow, deep, internal fosse. The bank has been removed from SW-W probably in relatively modern times. Of the kerbstones, fifteen remain in position; four at SSE and the remaining ten from SW-NNW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876 eds. Sited on the NE slope of a low drumlin ridge. Low flat-topped circular mound (diam. 5.3m E-W) enclosed by a low earthen bank with wide, shallow, internal fosse. From NE-E-SSE the bank has been greatly disturbed by the construction of a field boundary. Original entrance not recognisable. An earlier report (OPW 1969) recorded a shallow circular depression immediately E of the centre of the mound.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876 eds. Sited on the WSW slope of a prominent drumlin ridge. Levelled in the early 1960s. The outline of the site was still identifiable in 1969 (OPW 1969). It apparently comprised a small raised subcircular area (int. dims. 8.7m E-W; 7.1m N-S) enclosed by a low earthen bank with possible traces of a shallow external fosse. There was a break in the bank at NNE (local information). Not visible at ground level.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

In flat terrain at base of long N-S running ridge which slopes down to WSW, in pasture. Long, shallow pond with low trees growing around it is located immediately E of mound. Low, roughly circular flat-topped grass-covered mound (top diam. 15.7m N-S; 15.1m E-W; overall diam. 27.4m N-S; 28.2m E-W) defined by shallow scarp (H 0.96m; Wth 5.2m), less clearly defined in the E quadrant where the mound gradually slopes down towards the adjacent pond. Trace of external fosse (Wth 3.6m; D 0.27m) from S-W-NW.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876eds. Sited on the NNE slope of a prominent drumlin ridge. Low circular earthen mound (diam. 9.4m)enclosed by a low earthen bank with wide, shallow, internal fosse. Bank identifiable from WSW-N-E. Original entrance not recognisable.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Described in report (OPW file) as a low oval platform (dims c. 22.5m N-S, 18m E-W) with an external fosse (Wth c. 2.1m; D c. 0.15m) visible at NW and faint traces elsewhere. Now appears as a low flat-topped mound (diam. 21m, H c. 1m). No visible surface remains of fosse.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

A flat topped circular mound (diam. c. 22m; H c. 1.75m) with slight dome in the centre.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Not marked on any OS ed. Largely levelled. Remains comprise a low earthen mound(diam. 1.55m; H 0.2m) enclosed by a low earthen bank (Wth 1.35m) with internal fosse (Wth 1.35m). Situated c. 75m NE of a court tomb (31).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Situated on a gravel ridge, in undulating pasture. Annotated  Moat on the 1837 OS Fair Plan. Depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map as a large earthwork (overall approx. dims. 50m NE-SW; 45m NW-SE) which is bounded by a townland boundary to SE, SW and NW. Not depicted on the 1910 ed. OS 25-inch map and possibly was levelled during the construction of the Midland Great Western Railway (b. 1845) (Clara Branch opened 1863) which cuts N-S directly across this location. The townland boundary has been adjusted to E of the monument on the 1910 ed. OS 25-inch map.   In 1858-8 the Royal Irish Academy purchased antiquities supplied by W. R. Wilde one of which was described as a 'A very beautiful cinerary urn, now numbered 49, in continuation of those in the printed Catalogue. It is of the vase shape, 5½ inches high, 6½ in diameter of mouth, and 7½ in the widest part. Although the material of which it is composed is not of so fine a character as that of many of the other urns in the Museum, the style of ornamentation is unique, and much more complicated than in any other specimen. It was found in a stone chamber at the moat of Sionan, near Horseleap, county of Westmeath, and was purchased from P. Fagan.  Four beads, one of vitrified paste, and three of rough coloured glass, purchased along with the former, and now numbered 181 to 184 in Railcase D' (PRIA 1857-61, 128). This may be the 'Moat of Sionan' described by Waddell (1970, 134) as a bowl food vessel which was found in a stone chamber suggesting that the stone chamber in question may have been a Bronze Age cist that was situated in this earthwork thus confirming it as a type of burial mound or barrow. Levelled monument described in 1973 as no surface remains visible. The railway line seems to have cut through a small gravel ridge or hillock at this location. The line has since been lifted and the edge of a gravel ridge is now visible to the immediate E side of it. A laneway adjoins the E side of the residual portion of gravel ridge. Levelled monument is not visible today on Digital Globe aerial photography.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 22 November 2019

Situated on relatively low-lying ground, in wet pasture, with reasonably good views to N and S, townland boundary with Skeagh Beg lies immediately to S. No monument depicted at this location on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map. Depicted on the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map as a small oval-shaped earthwork truncated at SW by a field boundary running NW-SE.  Monument visible as a roughly oval-shaped earthwork on Digital Globe aerial photography.  Described in 1980 as a roughly oval-shaped earthwork (25m N-S; 18m E-W) defined by a low scarp with slight traces of a fosse visible from NNW-N-E, and a narrow causeway (approx. Wth 1.8m; H 0.3m) at N which may indicate an original entrance. The scarp is very poorly defined and is barely traceable from SSW-W-NW, where the monument has been truncated by a modern field fence running NW-SE.   A large number of field clearance stones obscure the scarp from E-SE. The fosse is very faint and poorly defined. The interior is uneven and rises irregularly from the perimeter towards a long central mound-like rise. There are a number of small, shallow depressions and loose stones on the surface of the interior, which are due to disturbance. Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrienDate of upload: 19 December 2018

Situated on the edge of a scrub-covered ridge, otherwise in pasture. Barrow (WM031-084----) abuts directly to NW. Annotated 'Fort' on the 1837 OS Fair Plan. Depicted on the 1837 OS 6-inch map as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork. Not shown on the 1910 ed. OS 25-inch map. Levelled monument described in 1973 as no surface remains visible. Levelled monument is obscured today by scrub vegetation on Digital Globe aerial photography.   Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 22 November 2019

Situated on a slight natural rise, in gently undulating, wet pasture with good views in all directions. Depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map as an oval-shaped area (dims. 17m E-W; 14m N-S) defined by a scarp.   Remains consist of a roughly circular-shaped mound defined by a low bank of earth & stone from NE-W and incorporating some rock outcrop at NNW. The top of the mound (dims. 8m E-W; 7.5m N-S) is slightly concave with a gentle N-facing slope and is occupied by thorn trees. Field clearance stones have been deposited on the sides of the mound and within the interior. A possible barrow (WM017-020----) lies c. 37m to E.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 28 November 2018

Situated on a low rise, in gently undulating, wet pasture with good views in all directions. Depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map as a sub-oval shaped area (dims. 26m N-S; 25.5m E-W) defined by a bank and truncated by a trackway across the NE sector.   Remains consist of a  small earthen mound (diam. 8m) defined by a low bank-like feature which is enclosed by a fosse-like feature WNW-NW, which may be accentuated by an enclosing wall of modern appearance which defines a larger enclosure.  The relatively modern stone wall is built against a low scarp visible from W-NE. The remains of a low earthen bank defined the upper edge of the scarp at S and SW.   The top of the mound has a large, shallow depression and there are further indents in the side of the mound at NE, E and W, all owing to disturbance. The perimeter is overgrown with trees & thorn bushes. The interior has some thorn bushes and boulders have been deposited at SW.  According to local tradition there is a cave at or near the site which may represent a possible souterrain. A possible barrow (WM017-019----) lies c. 37m to W.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 28 November 2018

Situated on floodplain of the River Rhine to NE.   Cropmark of circular-shaped area (diam. c. 50m) defined by two banks with intervening fosses visible on Google Earth orthoimages and on Digital Globe orthoimage taken between 2011-13. See attached Google Earth orthophoto taken 2022
column13: Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 11 July 2022

column10: Situated on a hillock on the S side of the Hill of Ushnagh, in pasture with excellent views to SSE, S, and W. Holy well annotated 'Tobernaslath' (WM024-060----) lies c. 15m to W. Bivallte earthwork described in 1971 as a roughly circular-shaped area (dims. 36m WNW-ESE; 31m NNE-SSW) defined by an inner fosse and two outer banks. A narrow, shallow inner fosse is visible at W, NNW and E. There are two widely spaced outer earthen banks which are not concentric, although they make contact at N. The original entrance is not recognisable. The interior rises gently from the perimeter towards the centre and a large slab lies prostrate in the SW quadrant.   Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 12 August 2019

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876eds. Sited on the S slope of a steep hill. Raised circular area (int. diam. 11.8m) enclosed by a low earthen bank with a wide, deep internal fosse. The internal area is greatly disturbed by a modern field boundary running NNW-SSE which divides the site into two roughly equal portions. Original entrance not recognisable.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Surveyed in 2013 and described by McGuinness (2014, 62-3) as following: 'Enormous subcircular mound (35m N-S x  30m E-W) reaching up to 4.4m in height on NE side, with sharply defined edge marked by a clear step or scarp. Traces of a shallow ditch are visible immediately beyond the step, running clockwise from S to N or NE; where clearest at NW, this is up to 1.5m in width, which would give an overall diameter for of 38m N-S. In SE quadrant, domed summit slopes down fairly uniformly to edge of mound, but elsewhere, the slope lessens from highest part towards edge of mound, giving the impression of a kind of berm. Numerous limestone boulders and outcrops of rock are visible over surface of mound, especially in NE quadrant and along part of perimeter. Old deciduous trees, located just inside the perimeter of the mound, were clearly planted, probably as shelter for cattle; a few others farther in towards the centre appear younger in date and presumably result from natural seed-dispersal. Clear  traces of a dry-walled revetment to the stepped edge of the mound on SW, S and E sides may relate to the same episode of landscaping that involved the planting of trees; the step is best preserved where the walling has survived, reaching up to 0.84m in height.   Macalister and Praeger examined the mound with no satisfactory results. They had taken it for a mound of stones, possibly a large artificial carn, but it proved to be a mere outcrop of much decomposed rock. Their examination presumably involved some kind of excavation but no record of this has been left.  Their dismissal of the site as a mere outcrop is completely inconsistent with its current appearance, that of an artificially shaped mound, although substantial areas of outcrop were clearly incorporated into it by its builders; its location in immediate proximity to a large ringfort-like structure (WM024-027----) is also consistent with an artificial origin.  Presumably with similar reservations about Macalister and Praegers conclusions, Schot (2006) marks it as a Barrow/mound on her map of the Uisneach complex.  Monument lies on a low eminence just 8m to NNW of the large and complex bivallate ringfort excavated by Macalister and Praeger (1929-31); prehistoric rock art reused in this fort (OReilly 2010) was conceivably taken from the barrow.  At least one other ringfort (WM024-027----) lies close by to W'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 23 February 2015

Situated on a rise, in pasture, with good views of the surrounding landscape. Annotated 'Moat' n the 1837 OS Fair Plan map. Monument described in 1973 as an irregular oval-shaped mound of earth and stone. The W portion and the top have been quarried away. There is no trace of an enclosing fosse. This may represent the remains of a disturbed barrow. According to local information, a burial was found here when quarrying for sand in 1969. Monument is visible as a disturbed mound on Digital Globe aerial photography.   Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 17 November 2019

Within a small thicket of hawthorn and bramble. Depicted on the 1837 edition of the OS 6-inch map as a small circular enclosure with the designation Fort. A small, circular earthwork (diam. c. 7m), possibly a barrow.  Compiled by: Patrick F. O'Donovan  Date of upload: 24 January 2012

Situated on a slight rise, in relatively low-lying pasture, with stream to NW, N and NE marking townland boundary.  On the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map the townland boundary is show to the S of the ringfort and square-shaped earthwork. Annotated 'fort' on the 1837 OS Fair plan Map.  On the revised 1913 ed. the townland boundary is depicted to the N following the line of the stream.  Depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map as a square-shaped earthwork with ringfort (WM018-089001-) immediately to NW.  Depicted on the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map as a a small square shaped mound enclosed by a fosse and outer bank with partially damaged ringfort immediately to W.   The depiction of the monument on the OS 25-inch map would suggest possible barrow classification.   Monument described in 1970 as a rectangular-shaped, steep-sided earthen mound, which is enclosed by a deep fosse and an outer bank along its NW, NE and SE sides. The bank is gapped at the E and S corners.  Monument visible as a tree-covered earthwork on Digital Globe aerial photography.   See attached plan of monument surveyed and drawn by the ASI  Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 05 February 2019

Situated in area of modern forestry plantation with ring-barrow (WM018-106----) 80m to NNE.  Small mound may be the remains of a possible barrow visible on Digital Globe aerial photography.  Not depicted on any edition of the OS maps.  Exclusion zone of forestry around the low mound in a similar fashion to nearby ring-barrow.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 11 February 2019

In upland terrain. A circular enclosure (overall diam. c. 25m) identified on Google Earth Pro imagery (imagery date 8 March 2010) by Jean-Charles Caillère and also visible on Digitalglobe satellite imagery (no date). Possibly a ring-barrow as it appears to have an internal fosse and wide outer bank (Wth c. 5m).  See attached photograph: KK018-104----_01 Image © Digitalglobe KK018-104----_02 Image ©2019 CNEW/Airbus: Google Earth Pro satellite imagery (8 March 2010)  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 December 2019

Situated atop a small hillock that would be a good location for a barrow with good views from E-S-SW.  There are no surface remains visible of any feature that corresponds to a cropmark consisting of two small concentric circles visible on aerial photographs (SMR File).  The field has been recently reclaimed and a field fence at N has been removed.    Compiled by: Caimin OBrien  Date of upload:  11 March 2013

On a low rise of ground with good views of the surrounding countryside.  Cairn (WM040-002----) located 140m to S.  No surface remains visible of a small mound depicted on the current ed. OS 6-inch map.  Not indicated on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map.  The depiction of this monument suggests that it may have been a barrow.  Compiled by:  Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload:  01 August 2013

Situated on the summit of a ridge, in undulating pasture, with good views in all directions.  Depicted on the revised 1910 ed. OS 25-inch map as a very small oval-shaped earthwork (approx. dims. 10m NW-SE; 7m NE-SW). Monument described in 1973 as no surface remains visible. The location of this mound would have been suitable for a barrow. Levelled monument is not visible today on Digital Globe aerial photography.   Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 16 December 2019

Situated on a hillock, in pasture.  A stream lies c. 32m to SW. Annotated 'Fort' on the 1837 OS Fair Plan map. Levelled monument described in 1971 as no surface remains visible. A complex of banks, scarps and quarry depressions are visible across this area and do not appear to form any discernible pattern. There are natural water-formed scarps at the base of the hillock. The monument is visible today as a roughly circular-shaped cropmark on OSI aerial photographs and as a semicircular-shaped earthwork defined by a fosse and outer bank on Digital Globe aerial photography.  The morphology of the monument visible on Digital Globe aerial photography suggests that this may be the remains of a barrow rather than a ringfort.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 11 September 2019

Situated on the SE side of a slight rise, in relatively low-lying pasture, surrounded by gently undulating terrain. This area appears to have been liable to floods prior to drainage in the 1970s. Ringfort (WM018-075----) lies c. 10m to NW. Not depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map or the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map.Monument described in 1975 as a penannular-shaped area (approx. dims. 18m NE-SW; 17m NW-SE) defined by an inner fosse, an outer bank and open to SE. The inner fosse is wide, shallow and U-shaped and evident from SW-W-N-NE. The outer earthen bank is low, broad and grass-covered and also visible from SW-W-N-NE. There is no trace of an entrance. There are several drainage depressions and banks of possible drainage material in the vicinity. Monument is visible as a penannular-shaped earthwork which is undefined to SE, on Digital Globe aerial photography. Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrienDate of upload: 05 February 2019

Situated on a natural rise (397ft/121m), in pasture. Not depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map. Annotated Tuitestown Moat on the 1837 OS Fair Plan map at a spot height located to the immediate NE of a roadway. Monument is not visible at the convergence of four field boundaries on Digital Globe aerial photography.  The annotation 'Tuitestown Moat' along with the location on top of a hillock suggests a possible barrow classification.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 12 February 2019

Small circular area defined by a fosse visible on Digital Globe aerial photography.  One of three barrows (WM018-166-/167-) roughly aligned NE-SW.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 12 February 2019

Small circular area defined by a fosse visible on Digital Globe aerial photography.  One of three barrows (WM018-165-/167-) roughly aligned NE-SW.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 12 February 2019

Small circular area defined by a fosse visible on Digital Globe aerial photography.  One of three barrows (WM018-165-/166-) roughly aligned NE-SW.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 12 February 2019

Surveyed in 2012 and described by McGuinness (2012, 38-9) as following: Greatly damaged and densely overgrown monument on ground sloping down to SW, roughly circular (Diam. 25-30m) in plan with NE side removed during road-widening c. early 1980s (pers. comm. Tommy Cassidy of Slane More). Monument is raised above surrounding ground, though its centre is irregularly hollowed out to varying depths (due in part to cattle), and is surrounded by a bank in varying states of preservation. At E side, the clearly defined bank is 5.2m in width; at N side it is 7.3m in width and more massive. At N side bank is raised 1m above external ground level and 1.3m above deepest part of hollowed. area inside. N and E stretches of bank end with a sheer cut just inside modern field boundary, clearly showing where the monument was damaged by road-widening. The bank is very stony, most clearly visible on N side where cattle have worn away the sod; there are many stones in the hollowed interior, especially at the cattle-worn N side, although some of these may have slipped from the bank. It is also to be wondered whether the varying levels of interior of monument might relate to disturbances from time of road-widening project.  In its current state, monument is difficult to classify, although given its appearancea raised area apparently surrounded by a stony bankit is difficult to accept its classification as a barrow in the RMP.  If a burial mound at all, it might be a hollowed out cairn or mound-barrow. In support of its interpretation as a burial monument, there are two barrows c. 50m (WM018-080----) and c. 100m (WM018-079----) uphill in field across road to NE, and on hilltop c. 150m to NE are three further barrows (WM018-078----). All six sites form an approximately linear arrangement from NE to SW'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 25 April 2016

Classified as a ringfort in the RMP for Co. Westmeath but re-classified by McGuinness following field survey of barrows in Co. Westmeath.  Surveyed in 2012 and described by McGuinness (2012, 37-8) as following: Large sub-circular earthwork, comprising a slightly dished platform (Diam. 39.5m NNE-SSW x 43m ESE-WNW) surrounded by a ditch (Diam. 49m NNE-SSW x 50m ESE-WNW), with traces of an external bank. Despite dished appearance of platform, there is no clear trace of a bank around its edge that might justify its classification as a ringfort in the RMP. A field fence marked by mature deciduous trees crosses ESE end of site from NE to SW, so that the monument extends over two fields, with only the smaller segment on ESE side showing traces of a low, external bank, 4m in width, below level of central platform. If bank originally extended into adjacent field, around the entire monumentand there is no reason to doubt that this was the caseoverall diameter would be c. 58m. Where best preserved on SW side, ditch is approximately flat-based, 2-2.5m in width at base, and up to 0.44m in maximum depth below and perpendicular to a line joining upper edge of platform to external ground level, although this measurement must be regarded as minimal given that outer bank is no longer visible in this area. Central mound rises up to 0.64m above base of ditch and appears to be raised above surrounding ground. Monument lies in broadly SW-sloping pastureland, 8m to NE of a bowl-barrow (WM018-080----) and c. 100m to NE of another, possible prehistoric burial mound (WM018-081----). Further upslope, on hilltop c. 150m to NE, are three further barrows (WM018-078----). All six sites form an approximately linear arrangement from NE to SW'.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 25 April 2016

Situated on top of a hillock, in gently undulating pasture, with extensive views to S, E and NE. Monument described as a small oval-shaped area (dims. 60m N-S; 57m E-W) enclosed by a bank (ext. H 1.2m) and external fosse visible from S-SW-W and at NE. No clear entrance feature visible.  The bank has almost been reduced to a scarp, primarily due to ploughing.  The ground across the bank, fosse and interior has traces of cultivation ridges running NNW-SSE which appear to have denuded the enclosing elements and interior to their present low profile state. The ground within the interior rises towards the centre where there is a wide, flat platform which is defined by a low bank which is best preserved at N, NE, SW and W. A tree-lined field boundary surrounds the base of the hillock and is not concentric with the bank or fosse. It is flanked on the exterior by a modern drain from S-W. There is a modern quarry hole at the base of the enclosing field boundary at E. Later field banks intersect the enclosing boundary at N and SW.  A Preservation Order was placed on this monument on 17/08/1990 (SMR file).  The classification of this monument is uncertain with the possibility that the low mound or platform in the centre is the remains of a burial mound rather than a house platform.  The profile of the monument and the possibility of the presence of a ditch around the central mound may suggest that this is the remains of a barrow rather than a ringfort with central house platform.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 05 September 2019

Situated on top of a small rise, in undulating pasture, with fairly good views in all directions. A tree-ring (WM018-145----) lies c. 67m to NE. Depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map as a roughly circular-shaped tree-lined earthwork. Depicted on the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map as a roughly circular-shaped earthwork.  Monument described in 1980 as a small, roughly circular-shaped area (diam. 11m) enclosed by an inner bank and an outer fosse. The inner earthen bank (int. H 0.35m; ext. H 1.1m; Wth at top 0.2m; overall Wth 2.7m) is low and present from WNW-N-E. There is a large, deep depression at the foot of the bank from SE-S-W which is probably due to disturbance caused during construction of the Royal Canal and fence line. There is no obvious entrance. A very narrow and shallow fosse-like feature (Wth at top 1.4m; basal Wth 0.6m; D 0.3m) is present from WNW-N-ESE. The outer face of the fosse is very sharp suggesting that it is relatively modern. The interior is level. There are some small areas of rock outcrop in the vicinity to NE. The exact nature of this site is unclear as the bank and fosse may not be original features. It may be a disturbed barrow or simply an estate feature associated with Belmont House, which lies c. 260m to SW. Monument is obscured by a roughly triangular-shaped tree-planted area on Digital Globe aerial photography.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 12 February 2019

Situated in undulating pasture. Hopestown Castle (WM018-140----) and bawn (WM018-140001-) lie c. 50m to N. Earthwork depicted on Larkins 1808 Map of  County Westmeath (NLI, MS 46,580 ). Not depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map or the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map.   Described in 1970 as no surface remains visible. A small circular-shaped earthwork earthwork visible today on Digital Globe aerial photography may be the earthwork depicted on Larkin's map of County Westmeath.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 12 February 2019

Situated on top of a knoll in low lying pasture, near the N shore of Lough Ennell. A possible barrow described as a ring-work in 1976 was depicted as a circular-shaped earthwork on Larkin's 1808 map of Co. Westmeath.  Shown as a circular-shaped earthwork on Lyons Estate Map of 1823 (NLI MS 2753). In 1976 a cist burial (WM025-076002-) was exposed when backfilling a small disused gravel pit at the base of a glacial hillock.  The cist was situated just below the break of the hillock on SE facing slope.  Eamonn Kelly of the National Museum of Ireland carried out an investigation of the site and recorded the following details; 'The capstone (dims. 0.91m x 0.76m x 0.08m) was fully removed and the cist was seen to contain a small pottery vessel and a pile of cremated bones.  Excavation relocated the grave (max. L 0.47m x Max. L 0.41m x D 0.5m) which had not been further damaged in the back-filling operation.  It was trapezoidal in shape and was made up of 4 slabs set into a sub-rectangular pit (dims. 0.95m x 0.8m x D 0.5m).  Mr Maguire informed me that a ring-work consisting of an earthen bank approximately 50cm high and 8m in diameter once crowned the knoll.  A large tree known locally as 'The Hangman's Tree' grew in the centre of it.  The cist being reported on was situated outside this earthwork' (Kelly 1982-3,  87-8).   Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 11 September 2019

Situated on a natural rise in undulating grassland with good views over Lough Owel 230m to SW.   Depicted on the 1837 OS Fair Plan map as an oval shaped earthwork with circular feature in centre and annotated as fort.   The depiction of this monument on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map may suggest that this was the site of a burial site or possible ring barrow rather than that of a ringfort.  No surface remains visible of levelled monument. Visible as a circular crop mark (approx. diam. 22m N-S) on Digital Globe aerial photograph taken November 2011.  Compiled by: Frank Coyne and Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 19 February 2018

On flat well drained land with good views of the surrounding countryside.  Depicted as a small mound on the revised 1910 ed. OS 25-inch map.  No surface remains visible of mound that has been destroyed by quarrying.  Compiled by:  Caimin OBrien  Date of upload:  02 August 2013

Surrounded on three sides by streams. Indicated on the 1st (1839) ed. OS 6-inch map as a roughly lozenge-shaped area (dims. c. 48m NNE-SSW; c. 55m NW-SE) with five concentric circles within the interior, the inner circle being N of centre of the lozenge and the outer three circles are only represented by arcs, as their radius would have extended beyond the boundary of the lozenge-shaped enclosure. The circles indicated diameters of c. 12m, 25m, 40m and the arc of the outer circles, if complete, would give diameters of c. 50m, 70m and 90m. There is no large house nearby and it is not part of a demesne. On the 1st ed. two NE-SE flowing streams are indicated, one c. 40m W of the monument and the other c. 60m to the E, with a third stream flowing NW-SE c. 10m to the S. The W stream forks to flow into the SE side of the lozenge-shaped enclosure and another stream flows along the SW side, appearing to form a waterlogged fosse. On satellite imagery it is evident that the monument has been levelled, with only the SW edge being retained as part of a field boundary. Given its association with water and its suggested morphology on the 1st ed. map, this may be some form of barrow, which was partially enclosed within the lozenge-shaped area at a later stage. Though even this latter feature was regarded as being of some antiquity by the OS surveyors as it is hachured.   Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 25 June 2020

On a N-S ridge between two small valleys. There are very fine views in all directions. A possible barrow associated with burials (KK013-099----). According to Graves (1852-3, 190-2) the townland of Rathmoyle, takes its name from a rath of the same appellation, which, when entire, crowned a small eminence of lime-stone gravel situate on the elevated ridge, which rises to the south of the parish church. The ridge was quarried and, a great part of the rath has been removedThe excavation thus formed presents a section of the rath, and proves it to be, not a remain of military or defensive class, but a thickly peopled cemetery (ibid.). He describes how, about eighteen inches or two feet under the surface may be seen, protruding from the sides of the sand-pit, human bones, which are found not confusedly buried, but belonging to perfect skeletons which had been interred without any coffin or cist of stones or flags. They lie for the most part with the head to the east, and feet to the west, and show no signs of cremation. I have been assured by the neighbouring peasantry that no arms or ornaments of any kind have ever been turned up; while the human remains are so abundant, that I was informed by one man that he had often carried away as many as two or three skulls in one horse load of gravel (ibid.). He also noted that, the north face of the excavation exhibits a perfect section of a pit sunk into the gravel about five feet deep, and ten or twelve in diameter. This pit may be traced by a well marked line of charcoal, calcined bones, and clinkers or slag (ibid.). Graves presented some of the bones from examination by a Dr. Crane who stated that, the greater portion of them belonged to human beings who appeared, from the teeth, to have been aged about fifty. A few of the bones seemed to have belonged to the skeleton of a sheep (ibid.). The description of the earthwork as a rath, suggests that the monument had an enclosing bank, it was probably a barrow. The townland is dominated by a N-S ridge and on the 1st (1839) ed. OS 6-inch map a quarry (diam. c. 85m) is indicated at the highest point of this ridge, with a limekiln immediately S of it. It is likely that this is where the burials were located.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 22 April 2020

In pasture. Indicated on the 1st (1839) ed. OS 6-inch map and on the 1948 revision as a small circular enclosure (diam. c. 17m), with a stream running N-S along the W side and a field boundary running roughly E-W immediately to the N.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 10 May 2022

Sited on the W shoulder of a prominent drumlin hill. Raised circular area (int. diam. 18m) enclosed by a low earthen bank. Break in bank at ENE probably represents original entrance.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

On a low rise of dry ground on marshy land, with restricted views of the surrounding countryside.  Monument visited in 1971 and revisited in 1978 and described as a small circular area (dims. 7.3m NNW-SSE; 6.6m WSW-ENE) enclosed by a slight earthen bank (base Wth 2.4m; top Wth 0.4m; int. H 0.3m; ext. H 1.1m) with a narrow shallow external fosse (top Wth 1.3m; ext. D 0.25m).  No entrance feature visible.  A large stone is visible lying in the fosse at ESE.  Not indicated on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map but depicted as a small barrow type monument on the revised 1910 ed. OS 6-inch map where it is annotated as 'Knocknakill'.    Compiled by:  Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload:  23 July 2013

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876 eds. Sited on the summit of a prominent drumlin hill. Raised circular area (int. diam. 11.3m) enclosed by a berm (Wth 4.4m), a poorly defined shallow fosse (Wth 2.3m) and a low earthen bank. Original entrance not recognisable. Overgrown with vegetation.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Sited immediately E of the summit of a prominent drumlin hill. Small circular raised area (int. dims. 14.7m N-W; 13m E-W) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone. No fosse. Narrow break in bank at NE. Internal area uneven. At centre is a low irregular grass-covered mound of stones of unknown significance.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

On a S-facing slope, with land rising northward to a E-W ridge overlooking the River Nore which is c. 370m N of the monument, in tillage. There are good views along the river valley. Identified as a cropmark on aerial photographs (CUCAP BGG041, 16 July 1971; BDI016 and BOC094, 10 July 1973). A multivallate enclosure (overall diam. 100m) consisting of circular central area (diam. c. 22m), possibly of a mound, enclosed by berm (Wth c. 15m); wide fosse, berm (Wth c. 11m), fosse, outer berm or bank (Wth c. 5m) and outer fosse. The outer fosse is not visible in the SW quadrant where it appears to have been truncated by a NW-SE running field boundary. When visited in 1987 the low remnants of the monument survived, consisting of a central concave platform (diam. c. 32m; int. H 0.2m; ext. H 0.4m) enclosed by a wide fosse (Wth 16m) and a low wide outer bank (Wth c. 25m; ext. H 0.25m).  See attached OS Ortho.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 21 May 2020

Sited on the summit of a prominent drumlin hill. Raised circular area (int. diam. 8.2m) enclosed by an external bank and two scarps with outer berms. Outside of the outer bank is a shallow depression which may represent a fosse. Both outer fosse and bank are incorporated into the field boundary. Original entrance not recognisable. The site was formerly planted with trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

An element of the above mentioned complex of burial and ritual sites (11, 60, 61, 65, 97). Low flat-topped mound (diam. 12m; H 0.4m) enclosed by an earthen bank (H 0.3m; Wth 2m) with internal fosse. A field boundary traverses the site in a NW-SE direction.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

One of a complex of burial and ritual sites which occupy an area 150m by 130m on a patch of uneven elevated pastures overlooked from the NW by Slieve Glah (CV026-004004-, CV026-004001-, CV026-004003-, CV026-004005-, CV026-004006-). A largely leveled low circular mound (int. diam. 6.2m; H 0.27m) enclosed by a much-defaced low earthen bank with vague traces of an internal fosse. Original entrance not recognisable.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Situated in pasture. Depicted as a small circular-shaped earthwork on the 1840 ed. OS 6-inch map but not on the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map. Possible curving ditch of barrow visible today Digital Globe aerial photography.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 02 October 2019

Sited on the SW shoulder of a high drumlin hill. Low circular earthen mound (diam. 5m; H 0.5m) enclosed by a low earthen bank with shallow internal fosse. One of six small circular enclosures noted on OS 1836 and 1876 eds. under the collective designation 'Cromwell's Camp' - presumably a barrow cemetery.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 12 January 2009

Low earthen mound (diam. c. 15m; H. 0.5m) located in wet flat land. Not marked on any edition of OS 6-inch map and discovered by V. J. Keeley during work on Portlaoise by-pass in 1992. (See also LA013:107).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

Low earthen mound (diam c. 15m, H 0.5m) located in flat wet land. Not marked on any edition of OS 6-inch map and discovered during work on Portlaoise by-pass in 1992. (See also LA013:108).  Archaeological excavation revealed this monument which was carried out by Valerie Juliana Keeley in 1992 under excavation licence no. 92E0168. A possible barrow (ext. diam. 10.8m; int. diam. 7.86m.) on the field surface. The site consists of a circular stone bank enclosing a flat interior. There is no evidence for an entrance feature, internal ditch or funerary deposit; however, it has been substantially disturbed by milling activity. The least disturbed sections, at the field center to the E and W, were cleared of loose peat revealing a bank (Wth 1.37-1.64m). The stones (av. L 0.22m; av. diam. 0.14m) are packed in a haphazard, irregular manner with various stone types and sizes in use. The majority of the stones can be described as cobbles, while a very small number of flags are present. There is a lot of natural wood in close proximity. An ex situ flint flake, a possible hone stone and a possible quartzite hammer stone (01E0663:14; 01E0663:15 and 01E0663:17) were recovered from the stone bank and a possible quartz hammer stone (01E0663:16) was recovered 24.8m to the W. (01E0663:4), a possible arrowhead, may also derive from this site. The site is in a soil-like peat with traces of minerals (e.g. sand) and a thin lens of charcoal immediately below this. SMR OF011-059---- is approximately 15m to the NW and may be associated.  In 2008 archaeological testing was carried out by Jane Whitaker of ADS Ltd. in Toberdaly and Clonin townlands in Ballybeg Bog, Co. Offaly, on 2226 September 2008. A stone enclosure (OF011060---) and stone-lined hearths (OF011059----) were initially identified during a survey by the Irish Archaeological Wetland Unit in 2001, when they were recorded as a barrow and prehistoric habitation site. The sites, which are located 15m apart, were partially excavated by Ellen OCarroll (formerly of ADS Ltd) at the site, in 2002. The area (NGR 251372 / 233357) subject to testing, in 2008, was located on a Bord na Móna production field between the two sites. This central production field was not investigated at the time of excavation but the northern drain face was cleaned and charcoal and stones were recorded within the section. The site has been set aside from production since 2002; however, Bord na Móna wished to establish the full extent of the site in order to put an appropriate programme of works in place. The purpose of the testing was to determine the full extent of the archaeological features/activity at the site. The licence was re-activated and transferred in September 2008. A total of five trenches were excavated by hand to archaeological levels.  Archaeological features were recorded in three of the five trenches and were composed of charcoal spreads and charcoal and stone features. The archaeological activity was orientated north-west/south-east over three production fields and measured 45m in length and a minimum of 35m in width. A total of seventeen flint lithics were recorded and recovered from three of the trenches. The radiocarbon dates obtained after the survey and the excavation indicate that the site, as a whole, dates to between 4220 and 2300 bc (Bennett 2011, 302).   Compiled by: Irish Archaeological Wetland Unit (University College Dublin).  Date of upload/revision: 08 November 2011

On the NE outskirts of Kilkenny City, immediately E of the outer ring road which was completed in 2007, a river flows southward into the Nore c. 90m to the E, in tillage. Identified on an aerial photograph (GB89.Q.26, 13 July 1989) as a cropmark of a circular enclosure (diam. c. 20m) defined by a deep fosse and an external bank, probably representing a plough-levelled barrow; a cropmark of a small pit in the interior indicates a probable burial deposit. An adjacent cropmark of a circular feature (KK019-122----) appears contiguous and interlinked with a common enclosing external bank. Both monuments are located within a series of fosses delineating a rectilinear field system (KK019-123----), however, these features may not be contemporaneous. The ring-ditch is also visible on Google Earth Pro (imagery date 13 August 2015).  See attached Google Earth image (imagery date 13 August 2015)  Compiled by: Dr. Gillian Barrett for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland and Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 20 October 2020

On the NE outskirts of Kilkenny City, immediately E of the outer ring road which was completed in 2007, a river flows southward into the Nore c. 90m to the E, in tillage. Identified on an aerial photograph (GB89.Q.26, 13 July 1989) as a cropmark of a circular enclosure (KK019-021----), probably representing a plough-levelled barrow and an adjacent cropmark of a circular feature (diam. c. 12m), also probably a form of barrow. This latter feature appears contiguous and interlinked with the other enclosure, sharing a common enclosing external bank. Both monuments are located within a series of fosses delineating a rectilinear field system (KK019-123----), however, these features may not be contemporaneous. The probable barrows are also visible on Google Earth Pro (imagery date 13 August 2015).  See attached Google Earth image (imagery date 13 August 2015)  Compiled by: Dr. Gillian Barrett for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland and Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 20 October 2020

Not marked on OS 1836 or 1876 eds. Sited on the summit of a low hillock. Small circular mound (diam. c. 8.5m; H 1.5m) enclosed by a low but well- defined earthen bank. Original entrance not recognisable.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. Immediately SW of ring-barrow (LA013-030001-). Marked on the 1841 edition of the OS 6-inch map; a very small circular enclosure (max. diam. c. 10m).
