All that survives of this levelled barrow is the semi-circular arc of a low earthen bank (H 0.3m), according to local information this barrow consisted of a circular area enclosed by a bank which was located beside an old mass-path. Site has been levelled and degraded due to extensive ploughing over the years as a result of the landscaping of the golf course that it is situated on.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

On a prominent hillock with good views to the N, E and S.  Possible ringfort (WM034-005----) 350m to SE.  A small roughly circular flat-topped, mound (diam. 5.2m N-S; 6.3m E-W; H c. 1.3m) defined by a scarp with slight narrow fosse (Wth 1.6m; D 0.2m) around the base of the mound best preserved from W-N-E, not visible at S.  Traces of a very slight depression visible on the centre of the mound.  Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 60-3) as following: Monument comprises a roughly square-shaped mound with rounded corners (8.5m NNW-SSE x 9.2m WSW-ENE), flat top (5m N-S x 5.2m E-W) and steeply sloping sides, delimited by a shallow ditch formed of four straight lines (Overall dims. 11.5m NNW-SSE x 13m ENE-WSW), the corners sunken deeper than the channels connecting them as if the ends overlapped; possibly these represent pits or hollows left by decayed timber posts. Mound is oriented ENE-WSW (NE-SW), being higher and more massive at SW end; ditch is slightly trapezoidal in shape, the SW end measuring 11.9m in length while the NE end measures only 10.4m. Where highest at SW, mound rises 1.26m above ditch. Ditch appears to be best preserved on W side, where a thorn tree growing from side of mound arches over it; here it is up to 0.16m below external ground level.  Ditch at E side appears at least as deep but is densely overgrown and inaccessible; ditch is very poorly preserved on S side. Ditch ranges in width from 1.6m at well-preserved W side up to 1.8m at N side. Immediately Beyond ditch on W side is what appears to be a low external bankas this is by no means certain, maximum dimensions for the monument given above are derived from the ditch This barrow, marked Moateen on OS 6 map, is strikingly positioned on flat summit of S end of low but very prominent glacial hillock with long axis running N-S, just N of the N6; and, but for vegetation, there would be good views in all directions. A raised bog visible only a short distance to N has been harvested for peat on an industrial scale, as have other raised bogs to S.  This hillock is at N edge of the pass or strip of dry land that gives the townland its nameless than 1km across at this pointwhich runs E-W between areas of bog that have been an impediment to movement since prehistoric times: a remarkable cluster of ancient trackways has been discovered in the bogs to the S, the nearest cluster being c. 1km to SSE (WM034-009----/010---/01-2----/014----/015----), including one (WM034-014----) that has been radiocarbondated to 1390-1046 cal. BC, placing it around the junction of Middle and Late Bronze Age. The ASI document a possible ringfort (WM034-005----) about 350m to SE. Although not yet examined by the survey-team, a motte (WM034-003----) lying immediately S of the N6 c. 700m to WSW of the present site could, from the ASI account given on the NMS website, be interpreted as a bowl-barrow, perhaps with stepped or otherwise shaped summit like those at Slane More and elsewhere in Ireland (McGuinness 2012, 12-13):  Steep-sided mound (H 2m), there is a low rise on the centre of the summit, the significance of which is unclear. At the base of the motte from NE-E-S-W to WNW there is a wide shallow fosse. No visible trace of a bailey. Traces of linear earthworks in field to the SW are visible on Bing Maps. [and] could be the remains of a medieval road associated with the motte. [NMS website].  Monument lies between two ruined medieval parish churches on sites which Leo Swan (1988, 13, 21) attributed to the early medieval period: Pass of Kilbride, with St Bridgets Well (WM034-001----/002----), only c. 700m to W but not certainly of early medieval date; and Clonfad, 2.5km to ENE, with a ruined medieval church, standing stone, early medieval high cross (Crawford 1927, 1-2) and a burial ground, including the bishops grave, surrounded by sub-circular earthworks representing the enclosing monastic vallum (WM027-066----/067----).  The unusual rectilinear eart

Marked on first edition OS six-inch map as a small circular earhwork (approx. diam. c. 15m), the present remains consist of a barely visible much degraded earthwork of which only the slightest remains of an arc of a levelled bank which is visible under good lighting conditions from W to N only with the slightest suggestion of an inner fosse and a possible central mound. May be the remains of a much degraded unclassified barrow.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload/revision: 09 December 2011

Low poorly preserved remains of an irregular shaped mound enclosed in places by a poorly preserved fosse visible only in places. May have been a barrow which has been degraded by agricultural activity.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload/revision: 09 December 2011

Situated on the W bank of the S-N Larah River. A large, low and grass-covered earthwork is most clearly visible in parched conditions on Apple Maps. It appears to consist of a central circular area (diam. c. 22m) separated by a fosse (Wth of base c. 5m) from a wide outer bank (Wth c. 10m) and an external fosse (Wth c. 10m). No entrance can be detected, although there might be a second outer bank (max. ext. diam. c. 75m). It is also visible on OSI images (2005-2012) and it is faintly traceable on Google Earth (08/04/2020; 13/04/2020). See the attached view from Apple MapsCompiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload: 22 December 2021

Outline of small circular enclosure (approx. diam. 9m) visible on Digital Globe aerial photographs, not depicted on any ed. OS 6-inch map.  Possible barrow.  Compiled by Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien.  Date of upload: 04 November 2019

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 52) as following: This monument, densely overgrown with thorn trees, furze and brambles, comprises a steep-sided, bowl-shaped mound (Diam. 8.5m N-S x 9.3m E-W) surrounded by a circular ditch (Diam. (overall) 14.4m N-S). Mound is mostly well preserved, although part of it appears to have been removed at Sapparently the same feature described in the ASI account as a depression in the top of the mound which continues down the side on the SE, due to disturbance [SMR file]; possibly the site has been ransacked by treasure hunters. Where its edge is damaged on E side and the sod removed, mound can be seen to be composed of earth with some stone. Height of mound above well-preserved ditch on S side is 1.5m, but reaches 1.75m over line of filled-in ditch on E side.  Where best preserved at NW and S, width of ditch is 1.8m and 3.2m respectively; the corresponding depths below ground level at these points are 0.14m and 0.60m. Although shallow and narrow on N and W sides, and not visible at all on E where it was presumably filled in when adjacent NNW-SSE-running field fence was constructed, ditch is both broad and deep on S side, at least in part due to the barrows location on land falling appreciably from S to N. There is no clear evidence of a bank having enclosed the ditch; possible traces of one at S are likely attributable to the natural ground rising in this direction, although the ASI account does refer to a faint bank outside the fosse [which] seems to have been redug in the past [SMR file].  Barrow is situated in pastureland close to road. Although visibility is poor in its relatively low-lying location, with land rising immediately to S and SW, the best views are to N and W, with the striking Ben of Fore only c. 3.5km to NW.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 8 February 2016

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 69-70) as following: Large, heavily eroded ring-barrow (Diam. 33.2 N-S x 32.8m E-W) in very low relief, comprising a low roughly circular domed mound (Diam. 20m N-S x 18.7m -EW) surrounded by a shallow, poorly defined ditch and what appear to be the remains of an external bank which is now broad, almost flattened and very difficult to discern.  Although neither ASI fieldworker who saw the site in the 1970s refer to a bankthe 17/5/71 account, headed Platform barrow?, describes the site as A small circular or sub-circular low, smooth sided platform surrounded by a wide shallow fosse [SMR file]an outer bank is nonetheless clearly depicted on the 1838 OS 6 map. Where ditch is deepest and best preserved at SE, it is sunk 0.74m below mound and 0.11m below bank.  When the site was visited by the ASI on 17/5/71, it had been ploughed recently and it supports corn now [SMR file], indicating that the monument was more pronounced until quite recently.  Barrow is situated in undulating pasture that has been under the plough in the recent past, and which slopes down very gently, but noticeably, from WNW-ESE; it lies a short distance N of the Royal Canal, just S of which again passes the main railway from Dublin to Sligo. Immediately to W is a crescent-shaped hollow with high back wall to N and low bank forming mouth on lower S side, which is marked on 1838 OS 6 map; this type of feature, taken to be artificialin one case a quarryby ASI fieldworkers on 17/5/71 and 22/7/76 [SMR file], is common in the Westmeath landscape and found near other barrows (WM013-016----; WM020-015----), and appears to be a dead-ice hollow where a fragment of ice left by a retreating glacier was embedded in the gravel and silt at the front of glacier, and then melted away (pers. comm. Seamus OBrien). Monument forms part of a loose grouping of four ring-barrows, lying c. 200m to NW of a second similar, but slightly smaller, one in this townland (WM027-021----), and c. 280m to E of a third in Porterstown (WM027-019----); the fourth ring-barrow, also in Porterstown (WM027-036----) lies across the canal c. 600m to SW. On a gently rounded glacial hillock in Riverstown, on slightly more elevated ground (OD 90-100m) c. 950m to N, ploughing in 1969 uncovered a short rectangular cist containing a crouched skeleton with Early Bronze Age Bowl Food Vessel; radiocarbon assay of the bones yielded a date of 3645±30 BP, falling well within the date range of c. 2200-c. 1800 BC for these vessels (Ó Ríordáin 1972, 234-5; Waddell 1990, 154; Brindley 2007, 67, 74, Table 6). Although the other nearby ring-barrows are visible, overall visibility is poor in this low-lying location.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 10 February 2016

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 67) as following: Markedly tear-drop-shaped or eye-shaped earthwork (Diam. (overall) 24.6m N-S x 31.7m E-W), broader at W end than E, comprising a large basal mound with gently domed upper surface (Diam. 18.4m N-S x 26m E-W) and delimited by a steep scarp on all sides; on top of this is a low mound, eccentrically positioned 15.2m from broad W end of basal mound but only 6.5m from narrow E end. This upper mound is irregular shaped but roughly circular (Diam. 3.9m N-S x 3.8m E-W), and rises only 0.5m above basal mound where highest on S side. Height of scarp defining basal mound is up to 1.2m on N and S sides; and absolute height of monument, from upper surface of upper mound to ground level, is 2m at SE. Various kerb-like boulders protrude from edges of scarp, with several visible on N and S sides; but these are found at differing heights, and, as one ASI fieldworker observed on 27/7/72, there is no clearly visible indications that they are formally set [SMR file]. Chunks have been removed from edge of mound in various places, especially at NNE but also at SE, the result of cattle erosion or small-scale quarrying; but overall the monument is well preserved. Faint traces of a bank observed by an ASI fieldworker on 10/4/70 were in the disturbed NNE area and, as such, were probably not original [SMR file].  Barrow is sited on a local eminence from which it has at least in part been shaped, given that there is no ditch to account for the massive basal mound. The complex, prominently positioned barrow at Rathwire Upper (WM020-123----) is visible uphill to N, on S slope of hill that is capped by a ring-barrow in an unusual rectilinear enclosure (WM020-087----). Lower down again, a couple of hundred metres to S of present barrow, are two branches of the E-W flowing Riverstown River, a tributary of the Deel.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 10 February 2016

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 67-9) as following: Complex, challenging and greatly damaged earthwork, currently comprising an elongated, roughly heel-shaped and steep-sided basal mound or platform (20.1m N-S x 16.4m E-W), with curve of heel to S, on which end is a roughly circular, steep-sided mound with overall EW diameter of 7.6m and flat top (Diam. 3.8m N-S x 4.2m E-W). Basal platform rises up to 1.05m above ground level on E side and 1.1m at W. Its N end is defined by a straight line running at an oblique angle to its long axis; although this has the appearance of having been done by modern farm machinery, and we know that the site has been extensively damaged in recent decades (see below), it nonetheless seems to be depicted on 1838 OS 6 map where it runs at right angles to long axis of monument here shown with its long axis running NNW-SSE. On the surface, this appears to be the result of confusion on the part of the surveyors: the WSW-ENE orientation of the straight line is accurate, but the surveyors have projected the rest of the heel symmetrically at right angles to this line. Earlier accounts provide a significant challenge to this interpretation, however, which will be considered below. Near centre of flat side of heel as it currently presents is an indent 1m in width and c. 2m in depth, sloping up from current edge of mound to top of platform, with the appearance of a ramped entranceway. Close to N end of platform, just S of this indent, is a low, E-W running elongated mound or ridge of earthmuch overgrown when visited by the survey-team on a single occasionwhich effectively blocks direct access from ramp to mound. On its N side, upper mound on S side of platform rises 1m above basal platform which extends 7.8m to N of it; its height is similar above the narrow ledges forming adjacent E and W sides of platform; on S side the slope of side of mound continues that of basal platform, giving a total height of 2.3m at this end of monument.  This site has been severely damaged, leaving it with the appearance of a miniature motte and bailey. For a start, the historic OS 25 map shows a segment of bank composed of three straight lines surrounding SW quadrant of basal platform, c. 10m out from it, which has been removed by ploughing but still shows up in aerial photographs. When the same ASI fieldworker visited the site in both 1970 and 1977, the bank was still visible with a ditch between it and the platform, and more intriguingly, a greater extent of N end of platform survived. The more complete account of 29/4/77 is given here: The site consists of two conjoined artificial earthen mounds enclosed from NW-W-S-SE by an earthen stone bank which is best preserved on the SWW. The bank is absent on the E, NE and N  may have been ploughed out  there are traces of old cultivation ridges between the bank and the mounds in the W sector. Between the bank and mounds there is a wide flat shallow fosse and the area enclosed is roughly set circular or square in plan. Three are no indications of a fosse outside the bank. The bank has been dug into on the SW and here too there are two boulders on the crest. The mounds have a fairly circular shape, the S mound somewhat steeper than the N. There is some recent defacement on the SW slope of the S mound and the N mound has an older depression on top. The junction is regular and show incurving. The bank has sharp corners and a sharp profile. It may be that the two conjoined barrows are the original site with a later stone earthen (field) bank placed on the W-S. There is also a short projecting bank at the SW corner extending down the natural slope. [SMR file] The account of 10/4/70 gives additional information on the mounds and dimensions for the bank: The two conjoined mounds are unusual. They may be barrows or they may be formed from the material of the demolished part of the bank. They are conjoined in the N-S line. The S. one is flat-topped and o

Not marked on the 1841 or 1906 editions of the OS 6-inch maps. A circular area (diam. c. 14m) defined by a low bank with twenty-two stones protruding slightly above the ground except at the E. From N-E the stones touch each other. There is a slight rise in the centre of enclosure. Large erratic boulder to the S, possible outlier.  Situated in an upland area on wet ,marshy land with nearby ring-barrow (LA031-020) to NE. A slightly concave circular area (diam. 14) enclosed by an earth and stone bank witn stone facing visible in bank face. Not a stone circle but more like a small embanked enclosure or pond barrow.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Laois' (Dublin Stationery Office, 1995) compiled by P. David Sweetman, Olive Alcock and Bernie Moran. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload: 17 December 2007

In reclaimed pasture. Indicated on the 1st (1839) ed. OS 6-inch map and on the 1900 revision as a small circular enclosure (diam. c. 19m). The monument has been levelled and is visible on satellite imagery (Google Earth Pro, imagery date 20 November 2005) as a cropmark. The small size of this enclosure suggests it may have been a barrow.  See attached satellite image: KK020-014----_01 Google Earth Pro, imagery date 20 November 2005  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 17 November 2020

Situated just E of the summit of Sion Hill and immediately N of townland boundary,  in pasture, with extensive views in all directions. Depicted on the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map as a suboval-shaped earthwork. Possible burial mound (WM020-045----) lies c. 62m to WNW. Partially levelled monument described in 1970 as a much disturbed, raised roughly circular-shaped area (dims. 13.7m ENE-WSW; 10m NNW-SSE) defined by a steep scarp (H 1.8m). There is no visible trace of a fosse or an outer bank. The original entrance is not visible. An elongated quarry hole extends from the centre of the interior to the perimeter at SE. Monument is not visible today on Digital Globe aerial photography.  Hilltop location and small diameter of earthwork described in 1970 suggests that this may may been a prehistoric burial monument.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrienDate of upload: 04 July 2019
Cropmark of circular-shaped area (approx. diam. 10m) enclosed by two widely spaced ditches (approx. overall diam. 60m) visible on Google earth aerial imagery.
column13: See attached image taken from Google Earth aerial photographs taken 02/07/2018Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 09 September 2019

column10: On a gently sloping terrace, on the very steep W side of a N-S valley, at 700 feet. Mostly rough pasture on the valley sides. Good views to N, E and S but poor up hill to W. A small roughly circular enclosure (diam. c. 13m) defined by a degraded earthen bank (Wth 1.75m; int. H 0.3-0.5m; ext. H 0.5-1m) planted with thorn bushes. The flat interior, slopes to the E and is very wet and cattle trampled. There is a gap (Wth 3m) in the W quadrant which may be the original entrance.Compiled by: Jean FarrellyDate of upload: 24 February 2016

Monument surveyed in 2015 and described by McGuinness (2015, 34) as following: Monument consists of an approximately square mound (6.5m N-S x 6.8m E-W) with slightly rounded corners (due to erosion), flat top (3.5m NS x 3.3m E-W) and steeply sloping sides, its two axes aligned NNW-SSE (N-S here) and ENE-WSW (E-W here); no trace of a ditch is apparent. Where thickest on W side, it rises 0.76m above ground level; it is most massive here, arguably so that upper surface of mound would appear approximately level despite ground surface sloping down to W. Mound is well preserved except for NE corner, where there has been extensive damage and some small boulders exposed. Flat upper surface of mound slopes down gently from W to E; a slight depression at centre could indicate either ransacking or a collapsed chamber, but more likely it relates to an episode from recent decades, as an ASI fieldworker was informed by the landowner on 18/5/71 that a few years ago one of his farm labourers dug into the mound and found a lot of bones. Although minuscule, this flat-topped mound is most prominently positioned on the flat summit of a striking, steep-sided glacial hillock with stepped base on its W side, the highest of several in the area; visibility is excellent in all directions. A gigantic erratic stands isolated in a field c. 250m to ENE; a large gravel quarry is visible a few fields to S.  This unusual rectilinear mound is not obviously a barrow: As one ASI fieldworker described it on 18/5/71: Barrow? A small, low, sub-circular, steep flat-topped mound of stony earth. It looks as if it is a very modern platform. Its significance is unknown. [SMR file].  The account of 10/6/80, while acknowledging its angular shape, is also sceptical: A small, low, sub-rectilinear, flat-topped mound of earth & stones. There is no visible sign of a fosse. The sides of the mound are relatively steep on the N, S & W, but on the E the mound is somewhat defaced & it slopes gradually there. The N, S & W sides are almost straight & it looks as if the mound has been scarped at some time in the relatively recent past. [SMR file] Nonetheless, this monument in which bones have been found is very strikingly located on a glacial hillock with excellent visibility, a type of location common for barrows in this and other counties; and the recognition of what appears to be a second, prominently sited rectilinear barrow at Pass of Kilbride (WM034-004----), only c. 8km to SW, seems to suggest that it is indeed a barrow, albeit of a hitherto unknown type in Ireland.   Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by David McGuinness.  Date of upload: 5 February 2016

Situated on a steep but local E-facing slope. This is a circular grass-covered area (diam. 25.5m N-S; 25m E-W) that slopes down to the E (H c. 1.5m) defined by a wide and low earthen bank (at W: Wth of base 10-10.5m; int. H 0.5m; ext. H 0.2m) S-W-NNE that is largely reduced to an external scarp (at ESE: Wth 6.5m; H 1.8m) elsewhere. There is no visible fosse or entrance.    The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 9 January 2019

Eight very small 'Forts' marked on OS 1836 ed. Marked 'Site of on 1876 ed. Situated on the SE slope of a high drumlin hill. Probably a barrow cemetery. Not visible at ground level.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Situated on floodplain of the River Deel located immediately to E.   Possible monument visible as a low irregular-shaped earthen mound with curving arc of enclosing bank to S of mound visible on Digital Globe aerial photography. Could be the remains of an unclassified barrow due to its morphology and location poorly drained land.  Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 10 July 2019

Situated on a ridge, in undulating pasture, with good views in all directions and overlooking the valley of the River Deel to E.  Annotated fort on the 1837 OS Fair Plan map as and depicted as a small, roughly circular-shaped mound (approx. overall diam. 18m) on the revised 1913 ed. OS 25-inch map. The depiction of the monument on the OS 25-inch map suggests that this may have been the remains of a burial mound or possible barrow.  Levelled monument described in 1970 as no surface remains visible. The site was on the upper edge of a ravine which has been stripped of topsoil for the purpose of sand quarrying. There was a large quarry hole at the WNW end of the cleared area and visible in the face of this is the cross-section of a steep, flat-bottomed fosse. The fill consists of layers of fine silt with specks of charcoal and layers of rough gravel and large stones. Area of levelled monument is visible as a large quarry, on Digital Globe aerial photography.   Compiled by: Alison McQueen, Vera Rahilly and Caimin OBrien  Date of upload: 10 July 2019

Situated a slight rise in undulating grassland with good views of the surrounding countryside. Ring-barrow (WM009-002---) 410m to W. Depicted as a small circular shaped enclosure and annotated as fort on the 1837 OS Fair Plan map. On the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map the monument is depicted as a small circular mound or earthwork intersected by a public road running E-W at N, at SW by a field boundary running N-S and with farm buildings [Rose Cottage] immediately to W.  Monument not depicted on subsequent editions of the OS 6-inch map.  No surface remains visible of this levelled monument.  This levelled earthwork is depicted in a similar fashion and is the same size as ring-barrow (WM009-002---) 410m to W.  Possible levelled burial mound or ring-barrow.  Compiled by: Frank Coyne and Caimin O'Brien  Date of upload: 26 April 2017

In tillage. Aerial photographs (GB95.FQ.42, 43 & 44 and GB95.FS.06, August 1995; ASIAP (15), 15 and 19, August 1996) show the cropmark of a circular enclosure (int. diam. c. 16m; overall diam. c. 40m) defined by two widely spaced fosses (c. 9-12m apart), the outer fosse being wider and deeper. Given the close proximity of ring-ditches (KK021-042002- c. 20m to the NW; KK021-042003- c. 30m to the N; KK021-042004- and KK021-042005- c. 20m to the NE and KK021-042006- c. 60m to the W), this monument is likely to be funerary or ceremonial in character, and is probably a plough-levelled barrow.  See attached phototgraph: KK021-042001-_01 ASIAP (15) 19, August 1996  Compiled by: Dr. Gillian Barrett for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland and Jean Farrelly  Date of revised upload: 26 April 2021

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876 eds. Situated within a plantation of deciduous and coniferous trees. A poorly preserved low circular mound (diam c. 20m N-S; H c. 0.4m) defined by a low scarp. This is clearly identifiable from NE-S-W; elsewhere it is largely levelled. Immediately NNW of centre is a roughly circular shallow depression (diam c. 9m).  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Situated on the summit of a low drumlin hill. The NW site is very poorly preserved. It comprises an ill-defined low circular earthen mound (int. diam. c. 10.5m) enclosed by vague traces of a bank with internal fosse. Original entrance may have been at E. From ESE-S-SSW its bank merges with that of the SE barrow. The SE site comprises a low circular earthen platform (int. diam. 6.6m; H 0.5m) enclosed by a low but well-defined earthen bank with internal narrow fosse. Break in bank with accompanying causeway at E represents original entrance.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 3/1956).

Sited on the NW shoulder of a high drumlin ridge. Almost completely levelled. An earlier report (OPW 1969) described a low circular mound (diam. 4.5m) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone with a narrow, shallow, internal fosse.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

In tillage. Powerstown River flows roughly E-W c. 150m to the S. Indicated on the 1st (1839) ed. OS 6-inch map as a circular enclosure (diam. c. 20m) with a field boundary running ESE-WNW along the N perimeter and another running roughly N-S along the W perimeter. On the 1900 revision neither the enclosure or the field boundaries are indicated, suggesting that they were removed between 1839 and 1900. A cist (KK025-009----) was discovered during ploughing in 1962 either within or in the immediate vicinity of the levelled enclosure (Prendergast 1962, 18-21). This suggests that the cist and enclosure are associated and, if so, that the enclosure is a levelled barrow.  Compiled by: Jean Farrelly  Date of upload: 28 February 2022

Situated in demesne lands on the post-1700 Deerpark of Killua Castle located 570m to NNE.  Ringfort (WM009-010----) 90m to N, two landscape features (WM009-009-/011----) located 160m to NNE.  One of seven small circular-shaped earthworks (WM009-050-/051-/052-/053-/054-/055-/056-) roughly on a line running  E-W that are visible on Digital Globe aerial photograph taken November 2011.  Could be a group of prehistoric barrows later reused as landscape features.  Alternatively the earthworks could be solely associated with post-1700 landscaping of the Deerpark belonging to Killua Castle. This area was once planted with tree groves with an old pathway running through the deerpark as depicted on the first ed. OS 6-inch map.  A post-1700 Monument has been erected on the demesne approx. 270m to the NNE.   The Old Deer Park of  Killua Castle is located 650m to the S as depicted on the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Emmet Byrnes, Senior Archaeologist, Forest Service Inspectorate, Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine  Date of upload: 3 May 2018

Situated in demesne lands on the post-1700 Deerpark of Killua Castle located 570m to NNE.  Ringfort (WM009-010----) 90m to N, two landscape features (WM009-009-/011----) located 160m to NNE. Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Emmet Byrnes, Senior Archaeologist, Forest Service Inspectorate, Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine   Date of upload: 3 May 2018

One of two 'circles' (see also CW015-023001-) uncovered and destroyed during soil stripping. Length of fosse examined by NMI (Wth 0.7m; D 0.3m). Burnt clay and charcoal noted. Possibly two ring-ditches.  Compiled by: Claire Breen  Date of upload: 13 January 2012

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Carlow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1993). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Two 'circles' uncovered and destroyed during soil stripping. Length of fosse examined by NMI (Wth 0.7m; D 0.3m). Burnt clay and charcoal noted. Possibly two ring-ditches.

Cropmark of circular-shaped enclosure (approx. diam. 11m) visible on Digital Globe aerial imagery. See attached image taken from Google Earth aerial photographs taken 17/01/2020
column13: Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Jean-Charles Caillère Date of upload: 15 April 2020

column10: In tillage. Visible on Bing Maps Aerial view (pers. comm. P. Reid) as the cropmark of a small circular area (est. diam. c. 15m), possibly the remains of a mound or barrow.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 12 November 2014

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876 eds. Sited on the NE shoulder of a drumlin ridge. Depicted as a tree-ring on the 1913 ed. Small circular area (int. diam. c. 14m N-S) enclosed by a low bank of earth and stone. The enclosed area rises from the perimeter to the centre where there is a large irregularly shaped boulder. The site has been planted with coniferous trees.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Carlow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1993). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of revision: 15 April 2011 Revised by: Claire Breen  Earthen mound with gently sloping sides and small summit (H c. 3m; base diam. c. 18m). Enclosed by cropmarks of four concentric fosses visible on aerial photograph (CUCAP ASW 25-6, BGH 26-8) (max. diam. of outer enclosure c. 70m). A decorated stone (CW016-064001-) was recorded on the NW slope.  Aerial photograph (GB95.FQ.26) shows cropmarks of three concentric fosses surrounding the denuded central cairn of the barrow.  Reference:  Barrett, G.F. 'Early landscapes in County Carlow: an aerial perspective, in T. McGrath and T. O'Keefe (eds), County Carlow: History and Society, Geography Publications, Dublin. Forthcoming 2008.

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Carlow' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1993). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of revision: 2 February 2012 Revised by: Claire Breen  Aerial photographs (CUCAP ASW 27, GB89.W.16) shows cropmarks of two concentric well-spaced fosses enclosing very small area (est max. diam. of outer fosse c. 30m, est diam. of inner fosse c. 10m). Possibly multiple ring-barrow or ring-ditch. Cropmarks of possible trackways to W (CW016-092----) and to S (CW016-133----).
Aerial photograph (GB89.O3) shows the cropmark of a circular pit with faint traces of a widely spaced concentric narrow fosse.  Compiled by: Gillian Barrett  Date of upload: 12 December 2011

On a narrow terrace in a W-facing slope near the S-foot of the Red Hills (OD 197m). A very large and well-defined, oval earthen mound (H 1.9m at NE-3.5m at SW; base diams. 68m NW-SE; 58m NE-SW; upper surface diams. 17m NE-SW; 14m NW-SE) is girdled by a broad berm (total ext. diams. 129m NW-SE; 111m NE-SW). Aerial photographs (CUCAP BDO 41 (1970) and BGN 16 (1971)) show the cropmarks of both a wide external fosse and a narrow inner fosse. These features are no longer visible at ground level. Possibly an exceptionally large barrow like the one in Hallahoise (KD037-051----).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 06 December 2011
Aerial photograph (CUCAP BOC 70) shows the cropmark of a fosse surrounding a small circular area (est. max diam. c. 20m). Probably a ringbarrow or ringditch.  Date of upload: 8 September 2016

Marked 'Fort' on OS 1836 and 1876 eds. Sited at the foot of a high drumlin hill. Circular area (int. diam. 9m N-S) enclosed by a low earthen bank. Traces of a possible external fosse at NW and W. Original entrance may have been at NW.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

This barrow is located in the NW quadrant of a large circular enclosure (CV028-012002-). Raised circular area (H 0.5m; diam. c. 13m) surrounded by a shallow fosse (Wth c. 3m) which is almost completely infilled at N.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Cavan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1995). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of upload/revision: 22 December 2008

Possibly a multiple ring-barrow consisting of a central slightly domed area (diam. 8m) surrounded by a wide, shallow fosse and an external bank (overall diam. 16m). The small external fosse may be modern. Situated in a hollow of a west-facing valley. Site is very well preserved.  Date of upload: 15 September 2016

On the crest of a gentle E-facing pasture slope. According to Fitzsymons (1906, 104), This moat, according to the present version of the story, was thrown up over the spot where the two bodies in the plague-shed were consumed. The hawthorns of the ballad are still growing upon it. The ballad referred to is the Ballad of Oonah More and is associated with Inch Castle (KD035-026----) some 250m to the NW. A low sub-circular earthen mound (surface diams. 5.2m E-W; 4.3m N-S; H 0.7-1m) is enclosed by a shallow fosse NW-NE and SE-SW (D 0.1m; base Wth 2m; ext diam. N-S 14.8m).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 13 December 2013

Situated at the E edge of a shelf overlooking a N-S valley (Wth of top c. 250m) with its stream c. 30m to the E. A cist (WX034-074002-) survives within the remains of an amorphous grass and scrub-covered mound (diam. 23m N-S; 23m E-W; H 0.5-1m).   Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 13 September, 2012

Marked as a circular bivallate embanked enclosure on the 1839 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. It is located on the level landscape of the Hook peninsula. It was described in 1987 as a circular area defined by an earthen bank of irregular dimensions, within which was a wet sunken area, rising to a dry mound towards centre (SMR file). It was subsequently reduced to a flat topped, oval, grass-covered mound (dims. 22m NE-SW; 13m NW;SE; H 1 2m) surrounded by a berm of wet uncultivated land (Wth 15-21m). It is a possibly barrow. The S end of linear earthwork (WX049-015002-) is c. c. 30m to the ENE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wexford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1996). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 4 February 2014  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 3/1958).

Visible on an aerial photograph (CUCAP BDU 21) as the cropmark of a fosse enclosing a small circular area (est max diam. c. 11m). No visible surface traces survive.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Located in a deciduous wood towards the bottom a the N-facing slope of Lacken hill and at the head of a SE-NW valley. This is an earthen mound (diam. of base 12.7m E-W; 11m N-S; H 1.5 2.5m) with a fosse (Wth of top 5.4-6m; Wth of base 1.5-3m; D 0.2-0.5m normally to 1.4m at S (up hill)). The centre and the N side have been excavated out, resulting in a trench (Wth at base 1.5m; L 5m N S) through the mound and the destruction of the fosse and the mound profile at N. There is a causeway or spoil (Wth 1.5m) in the fosse at SW. Rath (WX029-017----) is c. 150m to the NE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wexford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1996). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 1 August, 2012

On a long, gentle, S-facing slope. The northern 'outlier' (5m off-line to the NW) of a linear group of nine possible barrows (KD022-090---- to KD022-098----) with a second 'outlier' (KD022-099----) at the S end. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD 1999). A very small, and very slightly raised, circular area (diam. 3.1m; H 0.10m) is defined by a low, penannular earthen bank (Wth 2m; int. H 0.10-0.15m; ext. H 0.2m), with a gap (Wth 2.2m) at SW.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

The presence of a small inner enclosure may suggest that this is the site of a levelled ring-barrow.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Edward O'Riordan. A concentration of monuments along highest part of Mullamast Hill, includes a barrow cemetery of five barrows. Of these, KD036-009---- has been extensively damaged by quarrying; KD036-011---- is clearly visible as a large ploughed down barrow, and the site of KD036-014---- is used as a dump. No surface traces of the remaining two sites (KD036-012---- and KD036-012----) are now visible, but Fitzgerald in his description of the area, mentions that they were levelled before O'Connell's monster meeting of 1843 (JKAS 1891-95, 379-389), during which operation a cist was discovered (KD036-012001-).   The complex also includes two ringforts; one large (KD036-008----), and one small (KD036-010----), a standing stone (KD036-017----), and two other monuments (KD036-015---- and KD036-016----) now levelled, but illustrated in Gough's edition of 'Camden's Britannia' (1789). These are described as 'a circle of small tumuli, each about four feet high, on the north side of which stands one single [sic]...' Neither of these monuments is preserved and their precise location is unknown, but they stood near the standing stone. Quarrying has damaged this barrow (est max diam. c. 25m), which lies to the S of the ringfort (KD036-008----). Visible on aerial photographs (CUCAP ALV 14, AYL 83).  Date of upload: 5 September 2016
A large but almost completely ploughed out barrow (est. max diam. c. 40m). Visible on aerial photographs (CUCAP ALV 14, AYL 83).  Date of upload: 5 September 2016
One of the group of possible ring-barrows described by Fitzgerald (JKAS 1891-95, 379-389). No visible surface traces.  Date of upload: 5 September 2016
One of the group of possible ring-barrows described by Fitzgerald (JKAS 1891-95, 379-389). No visible surface trace survives.  Date of upload: 5 September 2016

The site which is furthest to the S in the barrow cemetery is adjacent to the road and is in use as a dump (est. max diam. c. 25m). Visible on aerial photographs (CUCAP ALV 14, AYL 83).  Date of upload: 5 September 2016

Cropmark of small circular-shaped enclosure or possible barrow (approx. diam. 10m) visible on Google Earth aerial photograph taken 28/06/2018. Visible on aerial photographs including OSi Orthophoto (1995) and on Google Earth imagery. A small slightly raised, circular area is enclosed by a shallow fosse (diam. c. 7m) (pers. comm. Colm Chambers 26-08-2013).  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 011 November 2013

The site consists of a level concrete foundation surrounded by a slight bank, a deep fosse and a second, outer bank (overall diam. c. 65m). Shown as a circular enclosure on the 1st ed. (1838) of the OS 6-inch map, marked 'Observatory' on an 1866 revision, named 'Pavilion' on a 1911 revision and shown again as a circular enclosure on the current, 1941, revision. While the enclosing elements almost certainly occupy the position of the original enclosure, they have been extensively altered. (O'Riordáin 1950, 275: Site R)  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Prominently sited on a now conifer-forested hilltop c. 120m to NNE of a standing stone. Described as being 'In the Long Stone Field on Mr. Leonard's farm ... a small rath, much demolished on the south-east side; it has one encircling parapet, with the fosse, strange to say, inside, moat fashion.' (Fitzgerald 1906, 465). In 1955, it was described as having a fosse with a low, broad external bank (diam. c. 32m), (SMR file). The monument is no longer visible at ground level but was probably a ringbarrow.

Prominently sited on a knoll. Visible on an aerial photograph (DoD, 1999). A small, low, grass-covered, sub circular, earthen mound (ext. diams. 11.7m N-S; 9.2m E-W; H 0.5 - 0.9m), the interior of which has been dug out to a depth of 0.3-0.6m (over an area of 2.7m N-S; 1.1m E-W). The edges of the mound have also been dug away intermittently along N and E..  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Circular area surrounded by two banks, each with an internal fosse (original overall diam. c. 45m). The outer bank and fosse are levelled at the S. Situated on hilltop in pasture land.  Date of upload: 5 September 2016

A raised (H 1m), circular area is enclosed by a wide berm and fosse (diam. c. 15m), with traces of a possible outer bank (overall diam. c. 22m). Disturbed by military trenches at W and N. According to O'Riordáin (1950, 275: Site F; scaled section NE-SW Plate XXVII), 'Bones found in the material from this trench [a recent L-shaped cutting  west of centre] have been identified as human - fragments of femora of two individuals.'  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Aerial photograph (GB91.EK.19) shows cropmark of a circular enclosure defined by two concentric fosses, probably a plough-levelled barrow.  Compiled by: Dr Gillian Barrett for the Archaeological Survey of Ireland.  Date of upload: 15 April 2011

Located on a NE-facing slope. It is depicted as a small circular enclosure (diam. c. 5m) on the 1834 edition of the OS 6-inch map where it is described in italic lettering as a mound. It is depicted similarly on the 1907 edition of the map. The feature has been quarried away. According to Shirley (1879, 536) the mound at Knocknacran East was opened in 1860 but nothing was found. It has been quarried away.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Monaghan' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Date of revision: 31 July 2017

Marked as a bivallate embanked enclosure (ext. diam. c. 40m), possibly with a pit at the centre, on the 1839 ed. of the OS 6-inch map and situated in a broad N-S valley with a stream c. 10m to the E. It is not visible at ground level at the lowest point of a field planted with cereals.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload: 16 August, 2012

In pasture on the NE slope of Brewel Hill. A second ringbarrow (KD032-022----) lay c. 120m to the ENE, a third (KD032-024----) c. 240m to the SE and a fourth (KD032-025----) c. 200m to the S. Described in 1985 as the barely perceptible traces of a low circular area (diam. c. 16m; H above base of fosse c. 0.4m) enclosed by traces of a fosse  (SMR file). The monument is no longer clearly identifiable at ground level, but sub-surface features may survive intact.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 18 October 2013

Described as small circular enclosure (diam. c. 15m) defined by low bank, and similar to Ballon ring-barrow (CW013-074----). (Local information). No visible surface traces.

Cropmark of small circular-shaped enclosure (approx. diam. 10m) visible on Google earth aerial imagery.  Ringfort (KD009-005----) 400m to NW.    See attached image taken from Google Earth aerial photographs taken 28/06/2018.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Edward O'Riordan.  Date of upload: 2 November 2018

On a gentle W-facing slope in improved pasture: field boundaries shown abutting the monument NW-N-E on the current ed. (1910) of the OS 6-inch map have been levelled, whins removed from the monument are piled to the SW and the monument is freshly grass-seeded. A slightly raised (H 0.5m) subcircular area (diam. 20.6m E-W; 17.5m N-S) is defined by a wide shallow fosse (Wth 3.2m at E-5.7m at N; D 0.2m). there is no obvious trace of an outer bank, but the local land improvement works may have resulted in its levelling?  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 25 November 2013

Located on a slight S-facing slope. Circular and dished, grass-covered area (diam. 34.5m N-S; 32.5m E-W) defined by two low earthen banks (Wth 2.5-6m; H 0.3-0.7m) separated by a fosse (Wth of top 5-5.5m) but with a berm (Wth 7.5m) intervening between the banks at S (max. ext. dims. 53m N-S; 46m E-W). Both banks are absent NW-NE, and there is no visible entrance.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wexford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1996). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 3 July, 2012

Eight barrows occupy the fairly level, nettle-covered, narrow upper surface of a short, N-S esker in level pasture, with evidence of previous extensive sand/gravel extraction immediately to the N and E. Six contiguous barrows (KD019-001001-, KD019-001002-, KD019-001003-, KD019-001006-, KD019-001008-, KD019-001009-) run N-S, in-line at the N end of the esker and are contained in an enclosure (KD019-001004-) which girdles the lower slopes of the esker, while a seventh and eight barrow (KD019-001005-, KD019-001007-, ) lies c. 48m slightly down slope, and outside the enclosure, to the S.   Compiled by:  Caimin O'Brien with details kindly provided by Chris Corlett  Date of upload: 29 November 2018

Eight barrows occupy the fairly level, nettle-covered, narrow upper surface of a short, N-S esker in level pasture, with evidence of previous extensive sand/gravel extraction immediately to the N and E. Six contiguous barrows (KD019-001001-, KD019-001002-, KD019-001003-, KD019-001006-, KD019-001008-, KD019-001009-) run N-S, in-line at the N end of the esker and are contained in an enclosure (KD019-001004-) which girdles the lower slopes of the esker, while a seventh and eight barrow (KD019-001005-, KD019-001007-, ) lies c. 48m slightly down slope, and outside the enclosure, to the S.  KD019-001005- is the most southerly barrow in the group. A small circular area (diam 13.3m) is defined by a scarp (H1.9m), and an outer fosse (Wth 1.2m; D 0.8m) SE-SW.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Revised by: Caimin O'Brien with details kindly provided by Chris Corlett  Date of revised upload: 29 November 2018

KD019-001002- is the second-most northerly barrow in the group. A small, circular area (diam. 7.5m) is defined by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.4m) NE-SE and SW-NW. The monument is abutted by a barrow at N (KD019-001001-) and by another barrow at S (KD019-001003-). At the NE foot of a low ridge in improved, mixed tillage and pasture. A low, circular, earthen mound (diam. 9m; H c. 1m), has a shallow depression (D 0.2-0.4m) on its upper surface, and is girdled by a shallow fosse (Wth 2m; D 0.15m), with a causeway at SE.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy  Date of upload: 10 June 2011

Cropmark of small circular-shaped enclosure (approx. diam. 13m) visible on Google earth aerial imagery.    See attached image taken from Google Earth.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Edward O'Riordan.  Date of upload: 3 November 2018

Located on a rise at the NW foot of Tullaghmedan Hill. It is depicted as a partially quarried mound described as Croghan Crin in gothic script on the 1836 edition of the OS 6-inch map and as a gravel pit on the 1912 edition. It was described in the mid-nineteenth century (Searake 1850) as an earthen mound about twenty yards in diameter at the base (c. 7m) and raised above the level of the adjoining land about twelve feet (c. 3.6m) and was known as Croghan Erin. What appears to have been a slab-lined burial covered with a single large slab was in the body of the mound seven feet (c. 2m) above the level of the base. The inhumation was recorded as being in an upright position and an iron spearhead was recovered from it. In a pit beneath the inhumation with an urn and bronze sword eighteen inches long (c. 0.45m) were unearthed. The artefacts were donated to the museum of the Royal Irish Academy. A disused sandpit was at the location in 1969 (SMR file).   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 21 August 2019

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on top of ridge in drumlin landscape. Sub-circular, flat-topped mound (max. dims. 14.4m N-S, 11.5m E-W, H 0.8m). There are traces of a circle of kerb stones 1m inside the edge of the mound. The mound material has spread beyond the kerb stones, giving an irregular shape to the barrow.

On a hilltop (OD 567 feet) in  pasture, with panoramic views in all directions. A road bends and partially truncates the outer limits of the monument WNW-NNE. A low oval, central area (base diams. 9.7m E-W; 6.9m N-S; summit diams. 6m E-W; 4.4m N-S; H 0.1m at W-0.6m at E) is encircled by a broad level berm (Wth 12.2m at E-18.7m at N), enclosed by a shallow fosse (Wth 1.8m; D 0.4-0.6m) NW-E-S-SW, and by an outer earthen bank (int H 1.1-1.6m; Wth 3.3m at N-7.7m at S: ext. diams. 54m E-W; 54m N-S). Rubble is dumped on the central mound and clay is dumped on the outer bank and fosse at WNW. Wire and post fencing is erected on the outer bank along the N and runs immediately inside and outside the bank at NE. A telephone pole stands on the outer bank at E. The latest ed. (1939-40) of the OS 6-inch map records a souterrain (KD029-021002-) in the interior of the monument.  Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy   Date of upload: 11 September 2013

Located on an E-facing slope. It was described locally (SMR file) in 1967 as a small ring defined by a low mound or bank about 10 feet across that had been removed c. 1955 and had been W of a stone (ME006-014002-).   The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Revised by: Michael Moore  Date of revision: 26 October 2018

On the 1837 ed. OS 6-inch map this earthwork was located in a woodland plantation on the demesne lands of Mount Cashel Lodge located 330m to NNE.  Bullaun stone (KD029-010----) located 100m to S.  Outline of circular-shaped sunken area (approx. diam. 10m) enclosed by a curving bank visible on Digital Globe orthoimages taken 2011-13.  Could be the remains of a pond-barrow or a designed landscape feature such as an ornamental pond associated with landscaping of the demesne lands of Mount Cashel Lodge.    See attached Google Earth orthoimages  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details kindly provided by Seán Sourke.  Date of upload: 16 October 2020

According to OConor, jointly compiling the OSL in 1839 (Herity 2002, 198 (279-80)), It [a standing stone: KD029-014001-] stood in a small earthen moat, but now lies on the ground, having been thrown down about 2 or 3 years ago. The 'moat', which may have been a barrow, was described by Fitzgerald (1899-1902, 358) as, now levelled. Walshe (1931, 137) was told that when the stone was thrown down, ashes and Dutch pipes of clay were discovered beneath its base. No visible surface trace of the moat survives.   Compiled by: Gearóid Conroy   Date of upload: 05 September 2013

Located towards the bottom of a W-facing slope in the valley of the NE-SW River Bann with the stream c. 100m to the W and c. 600m from its confluence with the NW-SE River Slaney. This is an overgrown earth and stone mound (diam. 15m; H 1.52m) with traces of a kerb protruding through the mound from WN. The standing stone (WX020-002001-) is c. 10m to W, and the flat cemetery (WX020-001----) is c. 300m to the NW on the other side of the River Bann.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wexford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1996). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 31 May, 2012

In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on a natural terrace at the W end of a high ridge. Circular, level area (diam. 12m, H 0.5m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 4.7m, H 0.7m internally, 0.9m externally). The bank has been disturbed on the W and the fosse recut at this point in recent times. The site is divided in two by a modern fence running NNW-SSE.  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 3/1998).

Ring-barrow (overall diam. 17m) comprising a level, low platform (diam. 5m) enclosed by an external fosse (Wth 2m, D 0.4m) and external bank (Wth c. 4m, H 0.4m). The outer bank has been largely defaced but is best preserved on the N.  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 3/1998).

On gently undulating terrain in the landscaped demesne of Damshire House. Circular mound with external annular ditch (max. ext. diam. c. 14m). No visible surface remains. Visible on aerial photograph (G.S.I. O 73/N 332/333 (1973)).   Compiled by: Matt Kelleher  Date of upload: 04 December 2012

In the area to the E of the dividing fosse and bank of Dunmore (LH020-004001-) are three features (A, B and C), all of which are barrows.  Site A (LH020-004003-) consists of a circular level area (diam. c. 6m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth c. 4m) on N-WSW and outer bank (Wth c. 1.5m) on N-WSW. The fosse and bank are altered by the outer bank of the enclosure on SW-NE.  Site B (LH020-004004-) lies to the N of A, and consists of a level, roughly circular area (diam. c. 8m) with a fosse (Wth c. 3m) and outer bank (Wth c.2m) on the W. The fosse and bank are modified by juxtaposition with the outer bank and Site C to the NE.  Site C (LH020-004005-) consists of a level, circular platform (diam. 2m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 1.5m) and outer bank (Wth 1m).  The above description is derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991), No. 70, p. 45. In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  LH020-004003-_01.jpg: Plan of the enclosed barrow group.  Date of upload: 12 July 2012  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 3/1998).

The above description is derived from the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991), No. 70, p. 46. The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated near the summit of Mullaghash. Ring-barrow (overall diam. 27m) consisting of a circular, level area (diam. 8m) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 4m; 0.4m below interior, 0.8m below bank) and outer bank (Wth 5.5m, H 0.6m externally). The outer bank is truncated on the S by modern land reclamation, giving a D-shaped plan. Referred to as a 'small rath' by Stubbs (CLAJ 1910, 286).

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on the summit of a long, narrow E-W ridge. Ring-barrow (overall diam. 33m) comprising a level, circular platform (diam. 16m, H 0.6m above base of fosse) enclosed by a fosse (Wth 2.8-3.4m) and external bank (Wth 4.5-7m, H 1.3m above base of fosse). The bank is incorporated in the modern field fence on the N and the fosse is recut at this point. The site is recorded as a 'fort' in 1836 in the OS Letters (CLAJ 1918, 273).

Located on the N face of Athgoe Hill in an area indicated as a copse on the 1837 OS 6-inch map. A sub-circular area (diam. c. 46m) defined by a fosse (Wth 2.8m; D 0.9m) and an outer flat-topped bank in the NW and W (Wth 4m at base; 1.2m at top; H 0.6m) and by bushes in the E and SE. The interior of the site is planted with trees (Stout 1998, 151-2). Compiled by Geraldine Stout

Located on a level landscape. This is a circular mound (diam. of base 28m NE-SW; H 4.3m) growing some young trees. It has stepped sides and a gently rounded top (diam. c. 5m NE-SW). The mound is truncated on the NW side by a NE-SW road and it is retained by the wall of the demesne of Johnstown Castle.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wexford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1996). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 27 May, 2013

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on a natural terrace on the N side of a high ridge. Roughly circular, round-topped mound (diam. 17m, H 1.5m). Partly quarried into on WNW. The ring of trees and encircling modern stone wall are part of landscaping. MacIvor (CLAJ 1950, 122-4) described the site as a ringfort, owing to the field name 'Liss field'.

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991).
