Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated at the S end of a long ridge running N-S, the site consists of an oval, flat-topped mound of earth and stones (max. dims. 17m N-S, 13.2m E-W, H 1m).

A possible barrow identified from Lidar Survey of the Boyne Valley (Davis et. al. 2010, 172-3).  Recorded by Davis as Site E5-ii.   See attached Lidar image of the monument, taken from Davis et. al. 2010, 172.  Compiled by:  Geraldine Stout  Date of upload:  15 November 2013

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on the summit of a broad ridge in undulating countryside. Circular mound of dark red clay (overall diam. 17.5m, H 2.3m) with modern depression in the centre. The mound is enclosed by a modern stone wall forming a square enclosure (23m by 22.5m).

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on W side of an outcropping ridge overlooking the Mattock River. Ringbarrow, comprising a flat central platform (diam. 7.5m) enclosed by two fosses with intervening bank. The inner fosse (Wth 3.7m, D 0.2m) is enclosed by a bank (Wth 7.7m) which has been denuded almost to ground level from SW-N-NE. The outer fosse (Wth 9.5m, D 1.7m), visible only from NE-S-SW, has recently been recut. (Overall diam. 45-50m).

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on low, natural ridge. Roughly circular earth and stone mound (max. dims. 26.5m NE-SW, 20m E-W, H 1.8-2.9m). OS Letters refer to site as 'Lios Milibin' (CLAJ 1923, 203).

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007  Circular mound (diam. 14m, max. H 2.7m), situated on a slope.

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on summit of a broad ridge. Large ring-barrow, comprising a level, circular central platform (diam. 15.3m) enclosed by two fosses and two banks. The innermost fosse (Wth 6-9m, D 0.2-0.8m) is enclosed by the innermost bank (Wth 6-10.5m, H 0.8-1.5m), and the outer fosse (Wth 9m, D 1.5m) is in turn enclosed by an outer bank (Wth 9.5m, H 1-1.3m). The outer fosse and bank are replaced from NW-N-SE by modern fences. If the circuit of earthworks was complete there would have been an overall diam. of 84.3m. The site is alternatively known as 'Lios glas' and 'Lios na Reitean' (CLAJ 1923, 203). (CUCAP, APD 85, AOX 68)

Situated on the summit of a hillock in a gently undulating landscape, on land that was once part of the demesne of Monasterboice House which is c. 250m to the S. An earthwork that looks like a circular, grass-covered mound (diam. c. 10m) is separated by a berm from an earthen bank (diam. c. 18m) and outer fosse (ext. diam. c. 30m). It is visible on Google Earth (23/01/2021), and on older images. It may be a barrow and it was first reported by Anthony Murphy. Compiled by: Michael MooreDate of upload; 24 June 2021

Excavated in advance of the 'M1 Dundalk Western Bypass - Northern Link' (Excavation Licence No. 03E0157). A circular (diam. 18m) terrace cut into sloping ground with two pits and three postholes in the interior. (O'Donnchadha B. 2005, 10)  Reference:   O'Donnchadha B. 2005 Dundalk Western Bypass: Site 116: Balregan 1 Chainage 23.470 - 22.600 Post-Excavation assessment and updated project design on behalf of Louth County Council and the National Roads Authority, Licence Number 03E0157. Unpublished Report DAHG, Irish Archaeological Consultancy Ltd.  Compiled by: Claire Breen  Date of upload: 23 November 2011

Situated in recently cleared upland pasture by the roadside close to Mountseskin. The site appears as a slightly raised platform of earth and stone (diam. c. 16m; H 0.4m) (Healy 1975, 1-19).Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 6 July 2018

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Low mound, which on excavation by G.D. Liversage in 1958 (JRSAI 1960, 49-60) revealed a Neolithic settlement (LH024-007001-) deliberately sealed by a clay layer and built up for use as a burial mound, in which three cremations were interred (see LH024-007003-, LH024-007004-, LH024-007005-).

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Roughly circular, flat-topped mound (6.8m E-W, 6.3m N-S). Truncated on N by field fence.

Located on hilltop in field of corn. A circular dome-shaped mound (diam.25m; H 4.5m) with possible berm (Wth 5m) around the base and shallow external fosse (Wth 5m; D 0.2-0.4m; Healy 1975, 15). Fantastic views in every direction. Mound is very overgrown to the point of inaccessibility.  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Update by: Christine Baker  Date of upload: 27 October 2014

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on a level plain, immediately S of the old course of the River Fane. Originally a rougly circular, earthen, flat-topped mound (diam. 12.5m N-S, 8.8m E-W on top; overall dims. 20m N-S, 17.5m E-W; H 1.8m) enclosed by three fosses and three banks from E-S-W. Innermost fosse Wth 3.7m, D 0.3m; first intervening bank Wth 7m, H 0.3m; middle fosse Wth 5m, D 1m. The second intervening bank (Wth 6.5m, H 0.5m) is enclosed by a shallow outer fosse (Wth 3m, D 0.3m) and a large but degraded outer bank (Wth 8m, H 0.2m).  The outer bank may have been added to by alluvial deposits in the course of flooding, and Wright (1758, pl. 5) shows the ditches as flooded. The central mound has been affected by erosion, particularly on the N side, and though Wright records that part of the mound was cut away in deepening the river it is clear that the earthworks did not extend to the N of the river.  The site is variously referred to as 'Cnoc-an-innse' (CLAJ 1925, 46) or'Dundugan'. Owing to its location and nature it has been variously described as a ringfort or a motte. The site may be a hybrid form of large ring-barrow and bell-barrow, which at a later stage was reused as a motte.

Located on a gentle E-facing slope with a small SE-NW stream c. 180-200m to the E and N. This is as circular domed, tree and scrub-covered area (int. diam. c. 47m) defined by two low earthen banks (Wth 3-4m; H 0.5m) separated by a berm (Wth up to 4m) and surrounded by a fosse or ditch and field bank, both probably modern. There is an entrance through both banks (Wth 2.5-4m) at E. (max. ext. diam. c. 80m)  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wexford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1996). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 21 May, 2012

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated at the NW foot of Red Mt. Circular, round-topped mound (diam. 13m, H 1.5-2m) enclosed by a fosse, of which slight traces only remain at N. On top of the mound is a slight depression, owing to modern disturbance, in which lies a slab (L 0.7m, Wth 0.5m). Under this slab was found a large portion of an urn and fragments of cremated bone (see LH021-041002-). These are now in the National Museum (NMI reg. nos 1967: 198-9). Site known locally as 'Cooney's Moat'. (JRSAI 1970, 152)

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  'Rath or tumulus originally enclosed by a breastwork of earth of inconsiderable elevation' (PRIA (C) 1840-5, 259-61). Removal of soil from the brow of the hill in 1841 to fill a quarry-hole led to the discovery of between 150-200 inverted urns containing bones and charcoal. These were destroyed by the landowner, but subsequent 'excavation' of an untouched area by J.H. Smith revealed several more urns and a few artifacts (JRSAI 1967, 42) (see also LH024-002002-). The site appears to have covered about 5 or 6 acres, and the urns, which were embedded in the natural clay, were at a depth of 1m, which suggests a mound of some description covering at least part of the area.

Situated in a forest clearing at the E end of Tallaght Hill. A barrow comprising of a raised circular platform (diam. c. 30m) enclosed by a fosse. Marked on the 1843 OS 6-inch map as a double-banked enclosure with a central mound. McDix (1925, 126-127) described the site as a circular area (diam.32m) enclosed by a bank and external fosse. In 1960 the site was ploughed and planted with trees but was clear-felled in 1994. The site is badly damaged. (Price 1940, 123; Healy 1975, 1-19).Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 7 July 2018

Marked as a small circular enclosure (diam. c. 10m) defined by a field bank in an area of small fields only on the 1940 ed. of the OS 6-inch map. It is situated on a level landscape that has been largely reclaimed, with the E shore of Ladys Island Lough c. 60m to the W. This is a subcircular grass-covered area (int. dims 8.75m E-W; 8.25m N-S) defined by granite boulders of various sizes that have probably been deposited on the perimeter as field spoil (Wth 2-3m; H 0.2-0.7m). There is some evidence of an underlying bank at W, and there is an entrance gap (Wth 0.5m) at ENE. It may be a barrow.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wexford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1996). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 25 March, 2014

Situated close to the summit of Slievenabawnoge Hill, c. 25m W of a cairn (1306 feet) which marks the trigonometrical station. A barrow consisting of a circular hollow (diam. 12.2m) defined by a bank of loose stone (Wth 1.5m; H 0.4-0.9m). There is a gap in the bank in the N (1.3m) and S (0.8m). A section of drystone wall extends up the slope and joins the W side of this feature. The Hill has been recently planted with pine trees.Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 7 July 2018

On inspection in 1985 it was described as a slightly domed circular area defined by fosse with external earthen bank (diam. 5m). (Moore 1987, 78). The monument was excavated in 2007 (License no. 07E0249) in advance of quarrying. The report summarises the results as follows: 'The sod and topsoil was removed by hand and carefully examined to maximise finds retrieval. During the removal of the sod and topsoil a baulk or section was developed across the centre of the site, thin section clearly showed that at some point in time the surface expression of the earthworks associated with this barrow had been subject to disturbance and that only a small section of bank remained in the form of an earthen bank approximately 0.30m in height, located to the west of the barrow. The barrow itself takes the form of an oval shaped earth-cut ditch measuring on average between 1.00m and 0.90m wide and approximately 0.40m in depth with a diameter of 4.20m E  W and 3.10m N  S. The ditch was continuous with no breaks or openings. The ditch contained three fills or deposits a loose, light brown deposit with the general appearance of topsoil overlaying a lower charcoal-rich deposit (c4), overlaying a light grey silt. During the excavation of the ditch no traces of cremated bone were identified, however the general appearance of (c4) suggested that this deposit was formed by the placing of burnt material within the ditch on a number of occasions and not one single event. In total two fragments of flint blades were retrieved from (c4) and four pieces of flint debitage. During the excavation and assessment of the site no other archaeological features and deposits were recorded. However it must be noted that the area surrounding the barrow has been subject to high levels of ground disturbance associated with the development of the quarry. (Russell 2007)  Compiled by: Paul Walsh  Date of upload: 13 August 2015

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on low ridge in undulating countryside. Circular, flat-topped mound (diam. 15.5m, H 3-3.6m). Flattening of summit probably due to modern landscaping. Site known locally as 'Kelly's mote'.

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007  Cooper (Price 1942, 109) records the discovery of a 'clay urn with elegant beaded rim round it, containing calcinated bones', when a small mound was being destroyed. Half of mound survives (diam. 12m, max H 1.3m).

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007  Oval mound (dims. 25m E-W, 21m N-S, H 1.6m)  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 17/1976).

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007  Oval mound (dims. 15m E-W, 12m N-S, H 2m) of earth and stones covering and containing pit burials (ME033-031001-). (PRIA 1971, 75-81)

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated in low, arable land. Roughly circular, round-topped, earthen mound (diam. c. 16.5m, H 2.2-3m). Known locally as 'Mota-Cillin' (CLAJ 1965, 31) and 'Corrigan's Moat' (IFC Schools MSS 674, 162). Burials were reputedly found on the site (IFC Schools MSS 675, 97) and it was reported locally that 'a large flag', possibly a cist, was uncovered on the SSE side.  This monument is subject to a preservation order made under the National Monuments Acts 1930 to 2014 (PO no. 16/1977).

The following description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Meath' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1987). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 10 July 2007  Flat circular area defined by fosse, partly rock-cut, and external bank (diam. 63m). Causeway may exist at ESE but bank unbroken and incorporating large slab at this point. (PRIA 1957, 263, No. 2)

This barrow is situated on a hilltop under pasture beside the Naul to Fourknocks road and near the Ford of Fyne. A circular dome-shaped mound (diam. 15m; H 2.5m) which rests on a circular earthen platform (diam.30m; H2m). (Healy 1975, 16; Scully 1972-3, 103). Slopes down steeply to north and south to circular tree-lined enclosure. marked on the OS 25" as a 'moat'. Directly to the north on the other side of the Delvin is the Fourknocks ridge. When the grass is down large stones are visible.Compiled by: Geraldine StoutUpdated by: Christine BakerDate of upload: 29 October 2014

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Local tradition of bones being found during the removal of a mound (see also LH019-004002-). (CLAJ 1908, 31)

Marked on the 1839 and 1940 eds of the OS 6-inch map and described as a tumulus on the latter. The townland name, Knockavota, means the hill the moat, and the locatin is on a gentle SW-facing slope. This is an oval grass and scrub-covered mound (dims. 26m NE-SW; 13m NW-SE; H 0.6m at N to 1.5m genearally) with slight traces of a fosse or quarry at the NW and SE.  The above description is derived from the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Wexford' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1996). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research.  Compiled by: Michael Moore  Date of upload/revision: 15 March 2012

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Aerial photograph (ACAP) shows traces of ring-ditch (max. diam. c. 18m). Possibly a ploughed-out barrow (Buckley 1987, 20-1).

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Aerial photograph (ACAP) shows faint traces of a ring-ditch (max. diam. c. 22m) comprising two concentric ditches. Possibly a ploughed-out barrow (Buckley 1987, 20-1).

Located on the summit of a saddle-backed ridge under tillage within the site of a hilltop enclosure (DU014-012001-). The site comprises a low circular flat-topped mound (diam.9m; H 0.75m). A trigonometrical pillar (586') was placed on the site by the OS. Charcoal deposits were found near the centre of site during the burial of a sheep (Hartnett 1957, 266-7). This site is part of an extensive barrow cemetery identified by Keeling (1983, 70, Site III). Gorse covered low mound, square shaped around base of mound whihc provides some semblance of a buffer. Amazing views, north to Mourne Mts, south to Dublin and Wicklow Mts, east to Lambay and west as far as the eye can see. Geophysical survey undertaken by The Discovery Programme (13R0084) uncovered extensive remains in the vicinity of the barrow.Compiled by: Geraldine StoutUpdated by: Christine BakerDate of upload: 31 October 2014

Situated on the northern, very steep,  slope of a saddle-backed ridge, close to the townland boundary. The site comprises a circular round-topped mound (diam.7.5m; H 1m). Considered to be the smallest of the possible barrows in an extensive cemetery identified by Keeling (1983, 70, Site IV). Overgrown with gorse, single moss-covered stone on top.   Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Updated by: Christine Baker  Date of upload: 29 October 2014

Located on the northern slope of a saddle-backed ridge under pasture, c. 52m north-east and slightly downslope of barrow DU004-012001-. A circular flat-topped mound (diam. 12.5m; H 2m). The top of the mound at N has been damaged and eroded by livestock. Considered to be one of the largest of the possible barrows in an extensive cemetery (Keeling 1983, 70, Site V). Overgrown with gorse and extensive rabbit burrowing.  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Updated by: Christine Baker  Date of upload: 29 October 2014

Located in tillage on the northern slope of a saddle-backed ridge, to the south of a townland boundary. Extenive views. A circular, slightly round-topped mound (diam 9.5m; H 1.25) formerly encircled by a fosse (Hartnett 1957, 267). Partially overgrown by gorse and appears to have been clipped at the base by machinery along western edge. Considered to be part of an extensive barrow cemetery identified by Keeling (1983, 70, Site I).Compiled by: Geraldine StoutUpdated by: Christine BakerDate of upload: 29 October 2014

In pasture, S of Ballinapark House located 40m to N.  A cluster of three possible ring-barrows (WI040-063-/065----) located in field to S of Ballinapark House which are clearly visible on Digital Globe orthophotos taken 2011-13.   Remains consist of a semicircular-shaped area (approx. diam. 11m) enclosed by a fosse and slight traces of an external bank.  Possible barrow (WI040-064----) immediately to N and second barrow (WI040-063----) 15m to NE.  These earthworks are clearly visible on Google earth orthoimages taken 30/09/2009.  The sharpness and circularity of these cropmarks along with their close proximity to Ballinapark House may suggest that they could be designed landscape features or some other activity in the post-1700 period.  It is possible that they may have formed by circular-shaped livestock ring-feeders although this is uncertain.  The antiquity of these earthworks remains uncertain.  See attached Google Earth orthoimages taken between 2009-2019  Compiled by: Caimin OBrien based on details provided by Aoibheann Lambe  Date of upload: 8 July 2020

Situated on the upper crest of a hill above the old chapel in Glencullen village. A barrow comprising of a circular round-topped mound (diam.25m; H 3.2m) defined by an inner fosse (Wth 5m; H 0.5m) and external bank (Wth 2.5m; H 0.5m). The site is damaged in the S where its bank has been truncated by a field boundary extending E-W. There is a single standing stone (DU025-047002-) to the NE of the bowl-barrow (Healy 1975, 1-19; Turner 1983, 14).Compiled by: Geraldine Stout and Padraig ClancyRevised upload on: 28 July 2018

Identified during pre-development testing on the Airport-Balbriggan Bypass (Lynch 2004, 127). Comprises a circular ring barrow with an entrance at the N and W part of the ring. A deer antler was found directly opposite the W causeway. A deposit of cremated bone was found within the ditch and on the E side of the site. The NE side of the ring-ditch was cut through by five inhumations oriented east-west. Beside these inhumations were four others, oriented north-east/south-west.  Compiled by: Geraldine Stout  Date of upload: 26 August 2011

Three circular areas defined by banks (diams. av. 6.25m) were identified near the shoreline immediately S of Bremore passage tomb cemetery in the 1950s (Hartnett 1957, 264). Geophysical survey (Licence no. 06R0050) identified an enclosure located approximately 110m SW of Mound I (DU002-007001-) that may correspond with one of Harnett's sites. The geophysical anomaly comprises as a circular ditch (25m diam.). No internal features were identified. The remaining two sites were not identified by the geophysical survey (Gimson 2006, 10). The field is under tillage. Not visible at ground level. The Bremore headland was also subject to a constraint study carried out by Margaret Gowen & Company Ltd. in advance of a proposed port. In addition fieldwalking and lithic analysis was undertaken for an MA study (Collins, 2007).Compiled by: Geraldine StoutUpdated by: Christine BakerDate of upload: 16 April 2015

The following description is derived from both the published 'Archaeological Inventory of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1986) and the 'Archaeological Survey of County Louth' (Dublin: Stationery Office, 1991). In certain instances the entries have been revised and updated in the light of recent research. Date of upload/revision: 17 July 2007  Situated on slight natural rise in level tillage country. Circular, round-topped mound (diam. 22m, H 2.3-2.8m), truncated by agricultural practices on SW.

An annular ditch (diam. c. 13m; D 0.19m  0.43m) excavated as part of the construction work associated with the Greystones Southern Access Route (Excavation Licence 04E0401). The enclosed area of the ditch contained 22 post-holes and three cremation which were placed in Late Bronze Age vessels. A series of pits, post-holes, a cremation (also placed in a Late Bronze Age vessel) and a number of linear ditches (one of which extended beyond the limit of the road take) were found outside the annual ditch. (Wiggins 2007, 490-2).  Compiled by: Claire Breen  Date of upload: 9 January 2013

Cropmark of circular-shaped feature possibly a levelled mound with enclosing ditch visible on Google earth aerial imagery.  See attached image taken from Google Earth aerial photographs taken 02/06/2018.  Compiled by: Caimin O'Brien based on details provided by Conall Coleman  Date of upload: 01 April 2019
